post
This week is officially my last of school in NUS before I graduate. I will really miss NUS, my friends, the happy times, the laughters, the fun :( I would try to meet up with as many NUS friends as possible over lunch/dinner in the next few days in school. All I want to say is thanks for giving me such wonderful memories in NUS. Because of you people, I have never once regret coming to NUS <3  
-
 
I want you to hug me tight and kiss me gently and tell me that everything's gonna be okay. 

And I would love to do the same for you too. 
Right now at this moment, do you miss me too?
-
 
I am always looking at the time when I was close to my family. When going home felt right. When I look forward to going home. When being at home is the normal thing. Now everything has changed. Going home no longer felt right. Instead I experience so much negative emotion when I go home, fear of loneliness, fear of losing what I have established for myself after so many sacrifice, and anger at myself.

There's no problem in my family. The problem is me. I am the one that have changed. I am the one that is becoming another person. They seems to believe that I have changed and I do tell them I am no longer the same person. I pride myself at changing, because that's how I have survived living alone and managing everything myself. However deep within my heart, I desperately hope to hear them saying just one sentence to me: That's I have never change and I am still their same old boy.  I just want them to believe in me and I really did not have any choice in changing because I need to survive. I missed my old life so much but there's no going back. Moving forward is the only way. But does that mean I need to discard them? Why can't I turn back to how I was back then? I don't know.

When I am outside wandering alone, when I saw people eating with their family together at food court, I will think of them. How I wished I can do that with them every day. How can something so normal seems so distant to me nowadays. I really want to tell them a lot of stuff that is happening to me nowadays. The happy stuff and the sad stuff, especially the sad stuff. But when i saw them and when there is a phone call, all these thoughts somehow just turn into one short sentences: I am fine. Don't worry about me. How can I make them worry? How can they help me when they are not by my side when I need them. I don't know why I am pushing them away, even though I am yearning for them so much.

People tell me that I don't know how to appreciate my family. Yes I really don't. Whenever I meet them for a short while  and I have to leave them, I tell myself quietly that I don't really deserve such a good family and I hope they can really live well. I am so selfish, always thinking about myself and never really spend any effort to be with them. They did have their woes in their lives too but all I can think about is my own pain. I guess that's what living alone did to you after a while. What will you do? If you have to abandon your current life to spend more time with your family? Which path will you choose? Friends or family? Work or family? School or family? Freedom or family? I never choose family in any of the option and this is the consequences. 

I hope that in a few years time, everything will be better and I can once again return to them without sacrificing anything. Is it possible? I don't know. I can only hope and pray that my family will still be well until then and that I don't lose anyone of them. For now, all I can do is keep moving forward, and to never look back.

Sorry it is a long post.

It is that time of the year again. Where people frantically try to cram a semester's worth of knowledge in preparation for judgement day. Some are daunted by the rapidly approaching dateline, I too am no exception, but for an entirely different reason. 
We have five more days till the study break. Only five more days to walk from lecture to lecture together. 

Only five more meals together. Five more days to spend in your company before you leave for your internship or SEP. 

Thank you for being my companion for the past few semesters. Thank you for spending time with me even though I am probably not the best friend I should have been. Thank you for seeing the good in me that even I myself couldnt find. But most importantly, thank you for being my friend. Without you, my university life probably wouldnt had been as interesting as it was. For all that and more, I thank you. 

To the people that took the time to read this post, do not be too focused on your finals. Treasure the last five days you have with your friends. Of course some may say you can keep in touch, it just isnt the same. Be grateful for the friends you made. Speaking from the perspective of an introvert and likely socially awkward person, I am grateful for all the friends I have made in my university life. I have never been good at making and keeping friends. So if it isnt too much I have one last request. Won't you keep in touch?

I thought being on the giving end of unreciprocated love hurts the most. But being on the receiving end really hurts too.

There's this girl I've known for 3 years now. She's amazing: beautiful, kind and funny. I started getting more attracted to her in our final year of school and she did too, as we became closer.

I thought maybe she could be someone I could be better for, someone I could give a piece of myself to, someone I could fall for. But after a while, I realised it wouldn't be that way. I do not seem to have the capacity to love her the way she deserves or wants to be loved. I wish I do. I really do.

Of course, I have told her this and she wants to at least remain as friends, which I am very open to. But sometimes I feel that she's still trying and it saddens me to think of how exhausted she might be. I don't really know what to do. I feel guilty and trapped.

The main reason why I visit NUSWhispers is to click on "x and y other friends like this", then click on the photo of z to go to her Facebook profile. (x, z∈{Facebook friends}, y∈ℕ) 

A long time ago, I was all about doing well in school to please my teachers and parents, toeing the line in my CCA, being prim and proper, politically correct etc... In other words, a nerd who seems to have no emotions, even though I used to have soft toys, and talked to and treated them well as if they were real.

Growing up, I had some crushes, eye candies and such, but nothing really came of these trivial distractions in my life. It wasn't until my sophomore year that incidentally I got to know someone and accidentally had a crush on her. Accidentally because I wasn't intentionally seeking out a girlfriend, and wasn't emotionally ready for anything of that sort. As you can guess, I am still evergreen.

Fast forward many years to now, I just want to thank her for making the colours of my world more vivid. The grass is still green, and the sky is still blue. It has always been. It's just that the person who looks at it is different.

In my more lucid moments, I could see that she and I were so different in terms of life goals, directions, motivation and drive, and now we're even further apart. Still, it doesn't stop me from thinking about her.

Selfishly I hope she finds her happiness soon (only if she intends to be attached or married). Selflessly I wish her happiness.

When I stayed in campus, I invited a girl who didn't stay there to come over to my room. We were sort of interested in each other, but not yet boyfriend-girlfriend. She appeared a little awkward at first as I told her we were going somewhere else for dinner. Of course my intention was to bed her, but as we chatted in my room...well, it got too awkward and I decided to cancel my plan. In the end, we didn't become a couple. Thinking back, it was a stupid move to 'eat' her before we went steady. If I had managed to up her, she could have easily accused me of molest or rape, since she was in my room and she could have claimed that she couldn't resist. I've learnt since then to respect girls' limits, and certainly not invite them to my room unless they are interested.

-
 
Last time I refused to watch Naruto because I don't like changes. Eventually, I watch Naruto and like it alot.

Last time, I refused to change phone because changing phone it take time to transfer data but changing to a better phone proved to be worthwhile.

Last time, I refused to find another target when I like a girl and decided that she is "the one" but months after rejection,  I finally decided to find new girl and thought to myself," If only I find a new target earlier."

What is the moral of the story?
Accept changes. If you gone through a breakup, don't try to get back to the way it was. Accept it and give up any hope that it will be back to the way it was. Months after you do this, you will want to give your past self this same advise.

I don't know what is wrong with me. I have been an evergreen for the longest time, and after seeing all my friends getting hitched up and some even getting married soon, I am lamenting the fact that I am still a miserable single doing things alone mostly. 

After my friend introduced me to tinder, I have tried it for a couple of months so far.  The girls on it were typically a waste of time. Majority of them are either not replying/ just swiping for fun usually or are already attached and yet giving out numbers to guys like me (just why?). Just lately, I have been chatting up with this girl, and our correspondences were very sporadic, though lengthy, and I have asked her out for a meet up.

I think it is because I have been single for all my life, I completely didn't expect her to say yes. She was even eager to meet up and she gave me her number without me asking. Now I am at a lost. Because I expected that I will be excited when a score a date, but yet right now I don't feel any excitement, and frankly I find the prospect of meeting up and dating a stranger to be scary/ a chore, and I don't know what to do. 

Any advice?
-
 
As a bro, I have some advice to my fellow Singaporean guy friends. Stop drowning in self-pity when girls don't desire you, because you're worth more than that. Just assume girls are after you for your success and money, and work for it. Think from a university Singaporean girl's point of view.  A poor university girl would want a better life in the future, having been sick of living that life for 20 over years, while a rich girl would never want to compromise on her existing life style. Love is never enough for a relationship to last towards marriage. Money(security) is. So if you're a poor Singaporean guy without a charming accent, or something that is terribly unique about yourself, just forget about finding any Singaporean girl for the time being, because it simply will not work out. Always remember that girls are biologically wired to look out for mates that could protect her using the resources that a guy has. Stop feeling sorry for yourself and go and earn money. The girls will come after that, I guarantee, no matter how unattractive you are. Just remember the affair of the Bukit Batok MP and judge for yourself. Take care brothers, don't let any girl be your world. Remember, you live in materialistic Singapore. So know how the game is played, and have the materials needed to be desired by these materialistic girls.

With reference to all the recent whispers about "guys are seen negatively if they are single (involuntarily)" - It's true. Before when I was single till my third year in NUS, most girls wouldn't even speak to me (much less befriend me) and would block me for no reason. 

But now that I do have a girlfriend, suddenly it feels like everybody treats me so much nicer - the girls who acted so high and mighty before now actually treat me like a person now, they now are willing to talk to me without recoiling in disgust. Even the guys are friendlier, and this has happened even though I do not feel I have changed in terms of personality and how I deal with people in any significant way.

Well, too bad. I'm not going to befriend people who treated me like shit before for absolutely no reason other than my relationship status. Hypocrisy is what this entire thing is.

Evergreen guy speaking and I have a rather unique situation here. I'm taking a module where there're only a handful of people in class. Now there are 3 girls involved in this story, let's call them A, B and C. I took another module together with A and B last semester while I only knew C this semester. However, I know that A, B and C know each other much longer than any of them has known me.

Last sem, I started liking A while ignoring the hints B seemed to give. However, other than A dropping hints that she didn't like me, nothing much happened until C came into the picture this sem. Being 'old' friends, one day A teamed up with C to tell me a fake fact about A that I cannot accept, hoping that I would let go of A. It worked, and I didn't reconsider her even after discovering the truth, realising the extent A would go to state her disinterest. 
It took me a while before I decided to give more attention to B, having remembered her hints previously. However, C would try to prevent me from talking to B too much and snatch over my 'airtime' with B as long as she was present together with me and B. Furthermore, it also seems that B is no longer interested by her latest hints; the 'escalation window' has lapsed. I then decided to pull out from B before I sink in further. 
A few days ago during a class event, I sort of finally realised why C was doing what she did: she had liked me all along. Being buddies, the 3 of them would have probably discussed what is happening, and seeing that I was finally safe from A and B, C decided to make her move. The hints are unmistakable. I would have probably experienced whatever hints you can find from google, like staring, tidying her hair, 'accidental' touching and so on. 
I never really liked C, and can only remember how she stopped me from getting close to A and B. I'm not that desperate, but I'm also on my final year and am worried that when I step out to work and have no time to socialise with girls. I also understand that feelings can be slowly cultivated. Should I try to accept C in this case? 

I know I'm screwed up, but then so is C. 

-
 
There have been a recent influx of girls sharing their personal stories of being raped, molested, some of whom didn't even realise something insidious about it until much later. My heart breaks for them, but at the same time I admit I got a little frustrated at times and wondered, "Why do you want to meet him again?" Or "Why do you not feel more hatred or fear of him?" 

These thoughts played in my mind until it hit me. Oh my God, it happened to me too. Except mine was not a case of rape or molestation, but rather, pregnancy. 

He never liked to wear condoms. In the end, I think we've only used condoms 1% of the time. No surprise I got pregnant, right? I was crushed with grief, but I wasn't surprised either. But after the abortion last year, I only realise today that I've only been grieving over the baby loss. The guilt, the pain, the could have beens. 

It was only today after reading all those posts that I belatedly realised, "Wait, why have I not gotten outraged at his behaviour?" I was stunned by my blindness - every other student who got pregnant was as a result of an accident, they took precaution but it failed, or they usually take precaution but a few times they didn't, it happened. 

I was shocked that I've only been feeling pain and guilt over the baby loss when I should've realised and tackled the root cause from the start. 

He never wanted to use condoms, and I always put up a weak resistance. "It's not safe", I protested. But my insistence unknowingly eroded away over time. At the start, he'd count my period cycle because he wanted to not have to pull out (it's a huge downer while climaxing) during my non-fertile days. Again, I protested weakly that it was not safe. But again, my resolve wore off and his gentle (yes, he made it sound so gentle) insistence triumphed. Eventually he stopped pulling out entirely and I didn't even put up a fight anymore. I still liked him so much. Such a blinded fool. 

Tonight I lie on my bed staring blankly at the ceiling, overwhelmed yet numb with emotion. I always thought I was someone who knew better. I can't believe it happened to me and that I have been so, so blind. And I and my poor baby forever paid the price.

-
 
A recent rejection really made me do some self-reflection on why I was never attractive to the opposite sex. I try my best to be objective. So here goes...

Average physical attributes. Slightly below average height, average looks, fit build, bad hair. I'm not blaming my lack of good physical attributes but just recognizing that there is nothing on me that would be considered attractive except I take effort to keep fit.

Boring. I like to do the same things over and over again. I can run the same route for years, eat caifan over and over and be fine. I take comfort in routine. I'm considered a laggard in the adopter cycle so I'm not updated with the latest apps, gossips, hottest places to go etc. General lack of interest to try new things, learn new hobbies.

No effort to dress up. I personally find shopping tiring so I don't really have many clothes. I just wear the same stuff, function over form. Not that I dress badly, but it's just jeans, polo, drifit. Probably due to me being boring.

Nerdy. I'm not talented in sports/music/arts. My only strength lies in the ability to focus on doing something for long periods of time and not be bored, which is probably why I excel at studies. I like taking time to understand complex science/math stuff.

Introvert. I don't want to start a debate here so my definition is that my social energy gets drained as I interact with people and I need to recharge.

Not a good conversationalist in general. Not good at teasing, being animated, being energetic, telling jokes, saying interesting stuff.

Nice guy. I'm good at listening and empathizing with people, doing favors. But easily friendzoned.

Lack of ambition/direction in life. I study hard for good grades, but I've got no idea what to do with them. Unlike people who study for good grades to do achieve their next goal (e.g. get an internship, land a job).

There you have it. Now that I've listed them down, it makes perfect sense to me. To me, this really looks like a recipe for disaster. I wouldn't date myself if I was a girl actually.

The next step would be to improve on some of these aspects and turn some weaknesses into strengths. It's going to be hard, but I'm really going to try. I don't buy the "just be yourself and find someone who likes you as you are" theory.

Thanks for listening.

-
 
I'm not a good writer but I hope to convey how I feel through this confession. #confessionsofaserialkisser
I'm a girl who has met more than her fair share of guys. I'm single and I believe in having fun as long as I'm not hurting or causing harm to someone else. But what about myself? Before I met all these guys, went out on casual dates and got physical and sexual with, I never once stopped to think what psychological harm I am causing to myself. Sure, it's fun. It brings instant gratification, it's consensual and there aren't any strings attached. But aren't there really? I'm a sensitive person but I've always managed to keep any kind of romantic feelings away from all these. But then again, some encounters just leave you wanting more and more. Not physically. It's the emotional craving that kills me. Some of these guys I click so well with, it's really hard cutting off ties with them. Most times it's not even me doing the cutting. What starts off with friendship develops into more and then it's a hit and run before we can blink our eyes. These encounters which start off meaningful end meaninglessly and leave a tiny hole in my heart. Then onto the next guy who fills that hole for a while but then takes it along with him when he leaves. It's painful and unnecessary and I guess that is why I'm lying here alone in the dark feeling utterly lonely and sorry for myself. Maybe the cutting off ties with another guy I'd become emotionally attached to is causing this feeling again. Well the logical thing would be to stop wouldn't it? But when you're stuck in this vicious cycle with no willpower, you know you won't stop anytime soon. What's the purpose of this post? Just to put into words what I'm feeling and rant I guess.
-
 
Recently I fell out with a friend over our disagreement regarding my insecurity of my singlehood. For the context, I'm a single male and turning 23 this year. 

I've always been very insecure of my self-worth even outside of a relationship and all through my life my growing up years have not helped matters much. All my life I've been the one chasing. Be it friends for outings, group mates for work, or girls in love. Now for the record I'm not some horrible human being who's a psychopath or something. I'd call myself an intense individual who's passionate about his values and loyal to a fault. But for some reason, other men who are utterly irresponsible (I believe the term "fuckboy" can be used here) seem to get all the luck in dating, love and friendships. Never mind that being fake or an asshat to gain popularity is pathetic to the max, the fact that they seem to succeed at doing so does nothing but make me feel depressed. 

I was the one that posted an earlier confession regarding how I felt bitter about hearing people console me about my relationship status with the "waiting for the right person/right time" quibble. That was precisely the argument I got into with my ex-friend. She thought I was too hung up on my singlehood status, and that I shouldn't be lurching from crushing moodiness to recklessness in mentality whilst dealing with it and growing up. I was the one that retorted saying that 1) good things don't always happen to good people so who has the right to decide when someone gets a happy story or ending? And 2) if a single person (be it male or female) can't date when he/she is young and not yet bogged down by life's commitments (jobs, bills, whatever), then good luck with finding love when you grow older and all these commitments start coming into your life permanently. 

Like it or not, society stigmatises single men as much as it does single women. Males are shamed tremendously for being single and/or not having a girlfriend or a significant other. Single males in media are portrayed as nerds or all-around losers. As soon as a male of a dating/marriage age goes without a significant other for any particular amount of time, the speculation starts. Is he gay? A player? Just a loser? Low self-esteem? Man child? It’s never discussed that he may be single by choice/no choice (because somehow he never catches someone's eyes), it is always speculated that it is some sort of failing on the part of the male. 

If you can’t even get into a relationship and hold it down and make it work when you have minimal commitments and are still young and in your prime, good luck imagining that it would supposedly get better with age because hey, society seems to believe that men’s dating values only go up as they grow older! How many older men get hitched up because true love happened, or is it because the women who hitched up with them are themselves afraid of being left on the shelf, or worse still these women are just gold diggers cosying up to men they perceive to be materially stable for themselves?

Maybe I'm just very cynical about love and relationships now. I'm not religious and therefore I refuse to believe in religion's rhetoric about how some "sky father in the sky" has a higher purpose for us all and that he has planned everything out for our life. I feel myself becoming increasingly bitter and jaded internally and in my heart I really don't know if I'll have what it takes to have faith in myself anymore. I'm confident in my own innate abilities to make it for myself in life, but who ever cares if one can make it on his own in life, when he doesn't have a woman who loves him for... him? 

I'm sick of it. For once, let me be the one who's desired and wanted.

-
 

To the OP, know that you are not alone in this. While I wasn’t raped, but similarly, I was molested by friend, a childhood friend. It’s really a mentally torturing experience to face to the fact that it’s frequently the closest to you that hurts you the most. How could this guy, whom I have always been holding hands with when crossing the road, or standing in front of me to defend me from bullies, be the same guy who molest me against my will? We are not talking about just touching, it was essentially rape without penetration part. We always talk about molest and rape by perverts lurking in the dark of night outside when we are alone and skimpily dressed or drunk. But that is only a small part of rape cases. In fact, the major percentages of these sex crimes are committed by people close to us. It doesn’t matter if you were giving hints or not, wearing sexually suggestive clothes or not. It only matters that there is easy access to our body and the fact that they have a higher chance of getting away with it. 

All these said, I am not trying to say that you should have reported him to the police 3 years ago or anything like that. Because it’s true, even if they did hurt us, how can we bear to get them into trouble and possibly ruin their life? If I did report him to the authorities 9 years back, I do not think he would be the same man, married to a smart and capable wife, graduating with a first class honours and working in an MNC while attempting a business idea on the side. In some sense, I gave him the chance to be a better person and at the minimal, I dun regret not bringing him to the authorities. If I did and he went to jail, then I would have condemn him to a totally different life, a totally worse off life. “He molested me, so he deserve it!” can sound righteous, but at least for me, I couldn’t bear the thought of taking revenge on his life because he molested me. 

It’s so hard to face someone who has rape you in the past isn’t it? I disappeared for a few years the way you did. Those few years were horrible, and not very different from what you described yourself. It’s also during that period of time that I spent so much time reading books on rape and survivor accounts. From there, I learnt that for many of these survivors, facing your rapist is a way to move things forward. There are of course other options and therapies, but the most direct way to face my own inner demons, is to meet that demon, that childhood friend, head on. Because most other option will involve revealing that I was nearly raped and utterly molested to someone else who may alert the authorities. And so I did.

Much like your friend, he was very apologetic. But at least this childhood friend of mine was honest and sincerely regretful and apologetic. I have thought so much of how I would have bash him and scratch his face, but when it came down to it, all I ever did was a light ‘punch’ and a lot of crying and breaking down. How crazy was I be showing my weakness to my molester, crying uncontrollably silently, because the tears would not stop no matter how hard I tried. Because, my molester was also my childhood friend. They say its always those closest to us that hurt us the most, but that also means its those we are closest to whom we hurt most too isn’t it?

He ask me how can he ever make up to me over that incident. He has been guilty all these years and told me it was a terrible mistake he made. Much like in your case, he was only 19 when I was 17. We were both young and we do make mistakes. And that scar, we carried on with it for so many years. We talked, and I told him about the emotional trauma I have been through, while he told me of his guilt, his confusion, and his fears. He apologies, and strangely, forgiving him wasn’t as hard as I have imagined it to be. And with that, after some time, I found a proper closure. 

While rape and molest are all terrible crimes, but the eye for eye kind of justice system may not always have the best result, especially when it’s between friends and family. For those who wants revenge as a form of closure, by all means. But for those of us, like you and me, closure is probably what we are seeking for. Past can’t be changed, revenge isn’t what we are looking for, than closure is the way to go. 

You dun have to be friend with him if you dun want to. It was and still is his fault. But more importantly, its about you finding closure. I have, over the last 2-3 years, gradually let him into my life again, and sees him more as my childhood friend rather than my molester. I have also learnt that during those years when I wasn’t around, the kind of family abuse he has suffered silently about. He molested me, his family burnt and slashed him; we all have scars and wounds from those who are supposed to be the closest to us. End of the day, we all need to move on and not dwell on it and let it take over our life. If revenge was your cup of tea, you would have reported him long ago. But since it isn’t, and you are sure he is a changed man, then help yourself, find closure.

It's the end of the semester and we're getting back our graded assignments... 

Everybody is your friend until they realize you are doing better than they are.

-
 
To  and  I was bullied into performing sexual acts for a guy when I was still a minor. He was of legal age. 

I see him in NUS sometimes. I hate him to the core and I cannot forgive him. He took my innocence.

Because of him, I wasn't able to speak to guys. I lost most of my guy friends then. We have mutual friends but I refuse to go anywhere near him without my boyfriend accompanying me. I'm scared he'll approach me and touch me. I'm afraid he'll pinch my cheek and tell me I'm cute. I'm afraid he'll tell me I'm smart but he's smarter. I'm afraid he'll tell me I should straighten my hair. I'm afraid he'll tell me I should wear makeup to enhance my face and chest. I'm afraid he'll tell me I'm too tall. I'm afraid he'll tell me I'm too heavy. I'm afraid of his compliments because in the end they make me feel incompetent. 

I never made a police report because I thought my innocence was worthless. That I was ugly and stupid and that I was so lucky to have someone showing even the slightest interest in me. He told me all that. 

Today, I'm afraid of random guys approaching me and telling me I'm cute or asking for my number. I'm afraid they will push me against a wall and forcibly kiss me. I'm afraid I can't run fast enough. I never walk home at night while listening to music because he followed me one night and groped me while I wasn't paying attention. He laughed it off as a joke but I didn't.  

I recently heard that he'd done these things to other girls in university as well. I want to smack his face with a chair. I've outperformed him in every aspect- academically, socially, but I cannot get his smirking face out of my head.

I have trust issues. I have body image problems. My boyfriend tells me I'm unique and perfect and I feel happy but deep down, I don't know.

My advice to OP, stay far far away. You're better than that, unless you want the past to repeat itself.
-
 
I lost my childhood friend. She pushed me away. I always thought little of what people teased us, even our parents and other adults. It was until I developed feelings for her that I wanted to be more than friends. Childhood sweethearts. Even the mention of these two words sounded sweet itself. Perhaps it was our common hobbies, or the time we spent together because we were neighbours, or maybe it was always being in the same group during projects or class works, and i recall the days we used to sit together or near each other in class.

But after that night, what can i  do but weep over all the hope that is lost?

She got popular. Her blog gained traffic. People wanted to know her more. Guys and girls both. Role model. Beautiful internet idol. Social media sensation. 1000 LIKES within minutes. So on and so on...

But they didn't know her. They didnt know the her before she was popular. The girl who had her hands dirty from art class. Ate chocolate til it smudges over her lips. Her bad hair days. How informal she looks in her pyjamas. Or how she cried during her first period cos she thought she was goin to die and i even dialled 995.

And she told me that night that not only does she not want a relationship, she doesn't want me in her life. "People laugh at me for knowing you."
I will never forget that. Gone
... just like that. People will tell me to move on. Tell me it is her loss. She doesnt deserve me.
Yes. She doesnt. She deserves someone better. It isn't her loss, it is mine. Because the truth is despite everything, i can still forget and forgive her. If she were to step up to me, call, text to apologise,  with open arms i will accept her, even as a friend. 

And yet years passed and the day never came. Perhaps she never knew how much those words hurt a nobody like me. Seven years...

We can always change the future. The real feat is to change the past. And that is a feat i can never achieve. 
-
 
Yesterday I was having my dinner at the food court when I saw him there. I froze up and pretended not to see to him but he saw me and came to me saying hi and asked if he could join me. I reluctantly agreed. He was my best friend during poly, and I was once been raped by him.

I met him through a sports event at poly as I was an athlete. He was not a good looking guy. A little nerdy, skinny with thick glasses and slightly shorter than me. But he was very well spoken and charming. He was very talkative and funny, so I enjoyed his presence most among our friends. Back then, I had a boyfriend. However I was interacting more with him than with my boyfriend, because I felt more comfortable and at ease with him. My boyfriend definitely noticed it and he became jealous so he initiated a break up with me. Honestly I wasn't really upset about it at all. I figured I was too young to be in a serious relationship, and felt that great friends can replace the role of a boyfriend.

I am from a single-parent family and I am the only child. My mother frequently drives to Malaysia for her business and she stays at our house over there whenever she goes for her business trip. So I am at home by myself most of the time. One night, he came over to my flat to chill out with me as I told him I get bored and lonely at home especially when my mother is in Malaysia. He even brought along a few drinks and snacks. We watched movies online. I was not a strong drinker, so I only tried a bit of the alcoholic ones. Then past midnight, I felt really tired and my head starting throbbing. So I told him to go home because I needed to rest. Till this day, I hate myself so much for not making sure he left my house before going to sleep.

When I woke up in the middle of the night, I felt like puking because of a stench. I was only partially wearing my clothes and I felt saliva residue on my upper body. The mixed sensation of pain and numbness was difficult to forget. I couldn’t remember how it happened as everything felt like a series of dream sequences. But I knew exactly what happened.

I got shocked and became frightened by reality. I quickly got up, wrapped myself and he was outside sitting on the sofa. He immediately stood up and wanted to say something but I smacked him across the face, screamed and forcefully pushed him out of the door, while he kept apologizing. It was so humiliating and embarrassing he saw and used my body. And took my virginity. I was so angry I thought of killing him or myself on the spot. 

After that, I did not socialize with anyone or attended classes for the next few weeks. I just stayed at home, slept and cried. He kept sending me messages but I did not give a F damn reading and I deleted all of them. Many times, I considered reporting to the police to have him arrested for violating me. But I didn’t. I hated him for what he did, but deep down inside I admit I have a slight crush on him as well. I could not bear ruining his future.

And looking back, it was partly my own fault too. I wore a low cut tank top and very short pants during that night. Since it was my own home and he was no stranger, I didn’t realized it was too provocative and I might have sent him the wrong message. But the fact that he betrayed my trust and took advantage of me is certainly unforgivable. Whenever I am alone and think about this, I cry and scream hysterically. And occasionally I cut myself as the pain on my skin distracted me from the agony inside.

Until now, I have never personally spoken to anyone about this, including my mother. I know she loves me but she will kill me if she knew I invited a boy back home during her absence and the thing she fears most had happened. She has always been warning me about it. I hated myself for betraying her trust in me. Judge me for all you want and call me stupid, but I rather keep this to myself than to face the embarrassment of being seen as a victim of rape.

Subsequently, I developed an unhealthy obsession of using pregnancy test kits. Every time I pass by Watsons, I will buy one and use it. I was afraid I got pregnant. Luckily the tests were all negative. And now, I am still doing it. Although there is no chance I will be pregnant now, it helps calm my nerves whenever I feel uneasy about it.

I became more wary around guys. I am usually a loner in uni but that doesn’t mean I don’t want friends. I want to have friends. But whenever a guy want to get closer to me, I get very uncomfortable and I make it too obvious. And some of my male friends in Nus are really trying hard to get to know me better, but I didn’t let them and always cut them off. I certainly noticed them although I pretend I don’t. I hope they understand that I am not thinking highly of myself or being a cold person. It’s because I cannot forget the grievous harm a male friend had inflicted to me, and my protective instinct kicks in. I am aware there are many nice guys around me in school who are not the type who would casually get into my pants, but I am really really sorry. Don’t ask too much why I am so emo or anti-social, and just leave me be for now.

So yesterday at a food court, I met him after 3 years without contact. He spoke to me and tried to catch up with me. I didn’t say much and I kept looking down while trying to finish my food quickly so I can get out of there. He still retains his sense of humor, and I noticed he has matured a lot, probably because of NS and because he started working. Although he didn’t say anything explicitly about that night years ago, he dropped hints of regret and apology relating to that incident.

Despite what he did, I still somehow liked him. He was not outstanding and definitely not my ideal type of man, yet I found him attractive in some ways I cannot explain. But I just couldn’t accept that he violated me before. I sensed his sincerity to be friends with me again, so I gave him my new number when he suggested to catch up again some time soon.

I wanted to rekindle our friendship, and discuss with him about that incident when I have the courage. He is the only person I felt I should talk to regarding this. When I didn’t interact with him for the past years, all these negative thoughts about him always come to my mind. I even mentally accused him for spiking my drink even though I cannot confirm it. But when I met him yesterday, the way he spoke to me made me feel positive about him again.

I want to let go of my grudge to live a more productive life. And maybe if I give him the chance to explain himself, I may eventually forgive him because we were young during that time and we made mistakes. But even if I forgive him, I will make sure he will be nothing more than an ordinary friend to me. I need more time to decide if I should let him into my life again.
 
Anyway, I wasn’t in the mood to go for classes today as I want to just stay at home to rethink about myself and maybe watch TV. And the subject today is quite boring anyway (sorry prof!). This is my first time posting on NUSWhispers so I hope you can pardon me for this long post. Thank you all for reading despite your busy schedules. It really makes me feel better to let someone know about my plight, even though it is anonymous. 

I pray for success in the exams for each and every one of you. Please take good care (:

As guys, social pressure has it that we must initiate conversations/ talk more, but I don't, not because I haven't tried, but because I gave up trying after I saw no results in my improvement of my social/ love life. My social life is almost non-existent since I kept on evading social events like a plague, fearing that things may go wrong/ awkward and I might get judged. My behaviour is so irrational, but yet I can't seem to escape it due to it having happened to me before in poly. -
 
@ the OP of 
You have to decide if it's preferable to (1) bear the weight of never telling her, against (2) the worst case (but likely) scenario that you may not be able to be friends with her anymore due to awkwardness. There's nothing wrong with telling her how you feel, but do think through it carefully. 

For not telling her: 
I know that there's a great temptation to be just confess, but sometimes that's just an urge that will pass. Your desire to let her know how you feel may pass. And your feelings for her may change. You stand nothing to gain from this except clearing it off your chest. Plus she'll be gone soon anyway, so this will be an old part of your life soon and you could have had a friend in a foreign country, but instead you might be left with awkwardness and regret.

For telling her: 
You get it off your chest and even if it's awkward you never have to see her again :D

Well there you have it! I'm not one to judge either way - besides I don't think it's immoral, if she loves her boyfriend she'll just reject you, if she gets together with you it means they were having problems anyway and you're just an excuse. You have to think about how this situation (esp in worst case scenarios) is gonna impact you.

Cheers (:

I keep fretting whether he likes me back because sometimes he glances/stares at me when I'm "not looking" and he goes out of his way to say hi to me, (etc.etc...), but the pessimistic realistic side of me always wonders if I'm just blowing things out of proportion and if he's simply a nice guy. Either way, the exams are coming and my heartache makes it near impossible to concentrate on my studies. I really became a fool in love and I'm tortured by it. What wonderful timing you have, heart. 

And coupled with a lot of extra factors, such as the fact that I'm mostly an introvert and he probably is too, and that I naturally have a tendency to act bad around him (sorry >.<) because I irrationally want to push him away so I never have to see him again, make it very likely that this relationship will never happen. Even though, at the very bottom pits of my heart, I want it to. (Seeing how some people understand MBTI, I'm an INTJ if that helps you understand my character and I suspect he is an ISFJ. Sooo... if I did my research right, it's highly likely neither of us will show obvious signs that we like the other, and therefore without confirmation, neither of us will make the first move.)   

Despite it all, I've thought of confessing to get over it, but I know I can't as it'll be awkward later if/when he rejects me, because I'll still be living in the same building as him for at least two months more, and there will definitely be certain times where my clique will have to sit with his clique... And I do know that some of the girls that surround him will definitely gossip. It's like mean girls you know, except they aren't that mean but simply girls who like to talk about the "latest happenings". And I try to avoid those kinds of things.  

I've never fallen this hard before. There's an internal conflict raging inside me every day that I just wish I could get over it fast, ideally before exam starts...   

At least I've gotten this off my chest now, albeit anonymously. Sorry for the long post... I. just... feel... sad and frustrated with myself. 

-
 
I have a boyfriend who's in NS now and we always talk about how we're gonna live our future together. I like how serious he is in our relationship, taking the initiative to introduce me to his family and wanting to be part of mine as well. He's also a very positive person, don't have much to complain about, very easy going. 

However, I'm extremely driven to save money for us, wanting to be financially independent and not depend on my family for my university loan. I hope we will be able to support ourselves early and get married young(he supports the idea of early marriage) without having to worry about (the lack of) money. I've taken up part time jobs and internships and worked hard to save up enough to pay off my uni loan. He knows I have enough money and this is where I feel things are beginning to feel wrong. 

He tells me that I'll be very capable in the future and we will be able to have a great life with our degrees which could fetch us decent jobs. However, from the way he spends his money, throwing in thousands into an (expensive) sport he actively pursues as a hobby, living in deficit every month even though he gets an NS allowance of 1.2k a month, I can't help but to feel insecure. He wants to live the 'sit and enjoy my wealth' kind of life, stay at home, pursue his hobbies and not work. He even told me that since I will graduate first, I will be a lot richer than him and would advance faster in my career. 'So we can depend on you to bring bread home and I will stay at home and cook for you, but you do the dishes' as he says. In addition, I am always the one paying for him when we're out as he's always broke. He says we're living like our money are each others, but it seems like it's only him who's taking mine. I cannot recall a time when he paid something for me, or gave me any presents. I'm not saying I need him to be rich, or that I need to be showered with gifts. I just hope for him to at least put in some effort, and for our relationship to go 2 ways. 

He always floods me with his love for the sport that he does, telling me about all the technicality and how good his equipment are. How he made a new personal record, etc. I'm happy for him that he has such love for something he does, but that's all he wants to say when we meet! When I try to tell him my life in school, he always cuts me off and go on with his sport. We only get to meet on weekends and I can't wait to tell him about what happened the past week but all he seems to be bothered with is his sport. Are guys just like that? 

I don't know whether he's serious about what he says, wanting to solely depend on me to support us. I tried to clarify but he says contradictory things. I love him a lot and I'm really serious about us, but if that's the way he's gonna live, i don't think I'll be able to live with it.

To OP of 18783, I graduated from NUS about five years ago. My boyfriend and now husband graduated from ITE (#truestory #nottrolling). We met while we were in secondary school, and back then, he was from NA and I was from express stream. I got to admit I was a mugger while he just slept his way through most of his classes. Similarly, he does not understand the need for mugging nor did i understood why he was just wasting away his chance to learn. Our differences was quite huge.

However, we continued dating and fast forward to today, we have children of our own. To be honest, the difference in our educational qualifications was not a major concern for me while we were dating (okay, maybe I was pretty naive back then). Today, we still have our fights and quarrels but it was never about the differences in our educational qualifications. Yes, sometimes I wish he was more academically gifted so that he can share the load of teaching our children when they grow up but at the end of the day, to me, these are just minor (but still important) parts of a relationship. 

What is crucial is how he makes you feel when both of you are together, how he make an effort to make you laugh with his silly jokes, how you both can laugh and talk about anything under the sun, how he cares and show his love to you in his own ways, how both of you fight against difficulties and brave it through together etc. These are the most important memories you will think of when you reflect upon your relationship with him, and not so much of his educational qualifications, his language etc. Education, money, status are just an external part of him. Take away all these, that is the man you really want to be in a relationship with. 

Of course everyone wants someone who is smart, rich, talented etc but no one is perfect. It is always a give and take in a relationship. But if you find it hard to maintain the relationship after considering education, money, language, status, then perhaps these factors are really important to you and you may need to rethink about this relationship.  

Thanks for reading! I wish you all the best in your relationship and studies of course! :)

To be honest, I don't know how to phrase this without sounding callous, but hey, that's what anonymity is for right? Let's give this a shot.

For the vast majority of my time in NUS, I've been attending nearly all my lectures and tutorials with a certain few friends, the first few people I got to know in NUS who happened to be in the same course as me. We weren't "share our deepest darkest secrets with each other" close, but through sheer force of constant exposure to each other, we got along alright. 

That is, until we left for SEP. Because we had mostly become separated into different countries and universities, and because I took a weird combination of modules in the overseas school, I have been going for lessons without my usual group of friends and even without any Singaporeans at all, so I've kept pretty much entirely to myself. And I cannot express how LIBERATING it feels. How I can freely choose to listen to the lecture if it's interesting, or zone out on the internet if it's not, without having to engage in incessant small talk about inane topics I couldn't care less about. To be perfectly honest, I do not miss any of them in the slightest.

Looking back, I guess it was pretty obvious that this would happen. I have absolutely no common interests or talking points with them whatsoever. Our conversations in school usually revolve around discussing that previous lecture or that upcoming test or that looming deadline. Scrolling through my past whatsapp convos with them, I was slightly amused to find that all my past interactions with them, EVERY SINGLE LAST ONE OF THEM, had been either school or admin-related. It is painfully clear to me now that these are nothing more than friendships of convenience, friendships that I ended up with because making any more would be tiresome, friendships that are destined to fall apart once we all leave school and they no longer have any practical reason to speak to me. In fact, it's only been a few months of SEP and I can already see it happening now: I've become utterly disinterested in the whatsapp group convo, and only reply when specifically singled out. My apathy seems to grow more insurmountable every day.

Now the question is how I'm going to deal with this once SEP ends. Maybe I should continue to trade polite niceties with them for another year before we part ways permanently. Maybe I should start to distance myself from them. Maybe I should make one final attempt to find some connection, any connection, with these people whom I call friends. Or maybe this is just my latent sociopathy finally taking form.

When she finally said she couldn't go on any longer and that she needed space to settle herself before she got into another relationship, I was helpless to stop her. She said her feelings were numbed, but I guess mine were flayed and laid raw. Tears were shed, promises broken and words left unsaid.

So here I am, alone and on the road again. 

It's tiring to be happy when you're not, difficult to move on when you're lost, impossible to reflect when you're broken.

But we go on.

-
 
 I probably had depression once. It was after a breakup. It was the longest month in my life. I literally ran out of things to do and the days were so long. No motivation to do anything. Not even the thing I used to love, video game. You know, usual things: loss of apetite as well. At those times I realize that friends are of no help. They don't really cheer you up. You don't wanna get out of the house. I live alone, far away from my parents.

Anti-depressants, though personally I have not had them; studies showed that don't work too well. They are basically like amphetamines or cocaine. It jacks up your dopamine and helps you get through the day. It gets you to function, but part of the problem of depression is you have no close bonds, no close intimacy that get you happy. It's not really different from any other addiction. Like porn, sex, heroin, or cocaine.

Anyway, there's the issue of how to deal with work. Not really study. Study requires motivation; something you are in short supply in depression. Work, I can soldier my way through the more monotonous tasks. Not reading or writing though. I got through that with massive amounts of cheap instant coffee. They are really disgusting (now that I drink fancy specialty coffee; and manage to differentiate the coffee brewed at 2 degree Celcius difference), but they provide the dopamine required to not crash.

Other than that I went to lots of meetups and parties. Download the Meetup apps. Talking and socializing with strangers put your depression into the background noise. I learned so much socializing from those. Not realy making friends though. But a few hours after work drinking and talking with strangers take my minds of the depression. Made me tired enough to actually sleep and get 8 hours of bedtime.

I learn improve and acting. I read Homer and a few books. Online dating. All of those. Just to pass the time.

Well, what really kicked me off depression train is my current relationship; which I got into after that one long long month. Somehow my conduct on my first date was attractive enough to land myself a new relationship. I've never been happier in my life. She's just perfect.

To . I am really sorry for what happened to you. 

I suffered an ordeal similar to yours. But I can't say I know how you feel because I understand how insulating it was to me back then when others say " I know how you feel."
All i replied was: Do you really? 

My girlfriend back then was an insurance agent. That was how we met. On the street, a name card. Like any fairy tale story, except there wasnt a happy ending. 
Country obligations made me serve my two years. And i hope i would not contribute to sparking arguments about how NS makes boys lose their gf. I am not so immature to blame the necessary evil for my breakup. Time passed. 3? 4 years? She works, I study. And she meets with clients. It was until the last few months of our breakup that I realised she keeps meeting with this Mr Hadman client of hers. But I tried my best to be understanding, so i didnt pursue the matter. I placed the trust I had for my gal in front of the jealousy I felt. Hadman was rich. I will give him that. And he wasn't any spoilt rich brat. I met him once and hell, even I respect him. He has this vibrant aura of confidence that he has his life planned out like how an NSF plans his MC days. 
I can still remember it was when i literally reached the halfway mark of my savings (while studying) to be able to commit to a BTO flat (even though I never proposed it yet) that she drove the BMW that Hadman GAVE her as a gift to find me for a date.
Hadman treated that as a gift cos she salvaged his business loss blah blah blah. I accepted it and I believe Hadman had no ill intentions.
I am not a small minded man. My parents taught me well. I dont mind my wife earning a larger salery than me. Hell i could even be househusband for her sake. Tongues wag and I didnt even bat an eyelid. 
Then the dreadful day came.
She never cheated on me, to be fair. And when the words came out of her mouth, i realised that I couldnt stop her or change anything. Hopelessness hit me first. Not rage, sadness or anger.
She told me a lot of things that night, but i didnt know how to reply, how to react. All I could think of was: Would anything I say matter? Would it change her mind.

She said she couldnt bear the fact that people looked down on me. And she was the reason. She said she felt the r/s gave her guilt. And that she wanted a better life. Indifferent from what your ex said. Security. 

The thing is... I never blamed her. I called my ns frens out for a drink that night and amongst the bitching by them about how a gaijin took my girl and how ns caused it and all, I found myself thinking of only one thing that night. She once told me that she led a tough life since young. Working and studying at the same time. Single mother. Tough family.
This is the part where haters like my ns frens come in and throw assualts. About how her sob story is BS. And this is where i tell them they are wrong. They have no rights.
I was the victim. And even i feel no hate or rage for her. Just regret that thing didnt work out, and just sadness at my helplessness. Til today i never blamed her or called her a bij. She led a sad life. And as the only child she probably felt the responsibility to give her mother a happy life. I understand that. Did I mention she was 4 yrs older than me? She couldnt wait. One of the many things she told me that night. 

And after the drinks, i remained sober, i called and tell her what i meant from the bottom of my heart and what i meant to say.
"I hope you will be happy. 我希望你幸福。"

You are a religious man. I respect that. I am a Taoist. I don't pray. But I have values and beliefs taught to me which I treasure.  And one thing I always believed was that You can learn something from everyone. And that everyone is brought into our lives for a reason. Perhaps you were brought up with the belief that life is planned by Him. Then so, let it be. I was taught to learn from everything and everyone, and with time, i moved on, although it wasn't easy. And now, i am learning how to live, and how to love again.

-
 
 There is a problem, is that you rush things too much. As such, you burn out too quickly. The solution being, you have to learn how to take things slowly. 

Meeting a new person, you will have this rush of wanting to find out more about this person, who is he, etc., right? 

1) Well, you have to feel more confident in your own skin first - because partially, you're reacting this way in response to something alien to you.  

As a guy, I learnt more about myself, about what kind of behaviour will stress me out, etc., so that I will learn how to deal with various situations less anxiously. You have to be more confident, and less insecure.

What I do, about that rush that comes along, is that I try to calm myself down, and distance myself a bit (not too much) - because from hindsight, I can analyse the situation better, and adjust my pace. 

2) I focus more on learning about the new person's situation first, rather than immediately knowing how the person is like, what he does, etc. In time, this is the way I know a person better. 

Understand that if I meet you, and if you talk to me, I will take a bit of information about you, and that tidbit is what I allow myself to take and develop further; I think about it, and delve deeper into the topic, rather than asking you about all other stuff that you do.

This is how I prevent myself from rushing head-on into friendships and relationships - because it's not about the intensity of the fireworks, but more about keeping the fireworks alive. 

You should re-evaluate your efforts - because, as how we engineers describe problems, it's not just about the amount of effort put in, but is your approach wrong?
-

She has her current boyfriend now and I hope she is much happier now. I just missed her. To other guys out there, dont neglect your girlfriend just because you have your 'excuses'. Do not think that your gf is such a nag, she nag because she want you to be a better man. Behind every successful man, there is a woman. That woman will nag to guide you once you go off course. Treasure her. Dont be like me.

-
 

 
You're jealous by your friend dating, you're wavering and feeling guilty towards your boyfriend...come on now, be honest with yourself. 

You don't have to cut all contact with your friend, but some distance now will do you and your relationship good. If you wanna do what's right you'd set yourself clear boundaries with your friend. 

When in a relationship and you start feeling tempted by another person (be it emotionally or physically), it is all on you to take a deep breath and carve distance before it progresses further. Otherwise you're being cowardly and yes, cheating, wanting the best of both worlds, doing your partner very wrong indeed. 

I also think you might have to work on your independence. You seem to be very dependent on regular close company, relying on them to combat loneliness so much so you get emotionally attached. I don't think that is healthy or fair to most of all your bf, but also to your friend and even yourself. 

As to your last question on what you should do when your bf goes to Australia to study...ldr? It's pretty obvious. You have mentioned you two talk about the future together a lot, so why have you lost confidence before even getting there? He might still think all is well. 

Truly, some distance from your friend now to clear your head and straighten out your thoughts will be very helpful. All the best.

-
 
To  hello there, your post has been greeted by rather angry-sounding, indignant responses from other people but I'm here to play the devil's advocate (to them) and express some opinions that you may agree with. 

As with many things in life, a timeline for anything to happen is arbitrary and people do things when they are ready. What's right or wrong is very subjective, so it's up to your threshold/ inclinations. You're not wrong in preferring certain things and if your boyfriend doesn't see eye to eye with it, you need to decide for yourself whether you can live with someone who separates certain parts of his life very distinctly from yours. It may well be an extension of other secrets that you're unaware of because he is able to hide them from you. (case in point: my ex cheated on me with one of the girls in his group of friends and I know her personally) 

I would say that being with someone includes the entire universe that the other person comes with, not just *merely* the other person alone. It is justified to want to meet his friends and be shown off so that you know that he is proud to be with you. In my opinion, there is absolutely nothing wrong with wanting to meet his friends and seeing the kind of people he hangs out with. In my case, my boyfriend's friends are absolutely welcoming even though they have long solidified their bonds before he met me. They're mature, sensible human beings who understand that the world doesn't revolve around them and so their group is permeable to SOs and even friends of SOs who occasionally join.  

Personally, I think it's important that you are able to involve yourself with his social circle up to an extent (to your discretion) because of very practical reasons as well. If you want to plan surprise events/ know your boyfriend better, you'll have a group that is familiar with him to provide you the necessary information/ support. I think you should be free to be yourself when you're with your partner and not put up a front by overly-tolerating things you're so uncomfortable with and poisoning yourself with all these thoughts. 

Also, in response to a commenter's point about power placements, it should not be a numbers game when you meet his friends. It's not about you against them, or any semblance of a fight for attention or priority. It's just a get-together, don't overthink that shit man. I expect and know that my boyfriend will protect/ explain to me if anything goes wrong since it's not about the length of time you know someone but how intense your connection is. I date with the view to marry, so if he chooses his friends over me he can jolly well marry them, adios I'll show myself the way out.

Hope you know that you're not alone in wanting a partner who shares everything with you!

Ever felt deeply hurt because you lost your girlfriend to a rich guy? I did. I will probably post this since neither is she an NUS student, nor does she read these confessions. So my gf and I have been together for about 2 years when we met at church. We started off as friends then we got along well and I confessed to her, then we became an item. She is probably the prettiest in the group but I love her because we have something in common; we are both committed to the gospel and we love reading books. 

So there's this new guy from SMU who joined our church group via a common friend. I am not in the position to judge him, but I feel he is simply in church for fun, and not serious about learning more about the gospel and grow as a person. It is okay. In fact, to be very honest, most of us are in church for various reasons such as to find the meaning of life, or to seek God's blessing etc. I love it that he is a happy-go-lucky person and very easy to get along with. As my gf is quite conservative, she would usually just say "hi" to him but kept her distance from him. 

During an occasion, we held a prayer meeting at this guy's house, since he said his house has ample space to accommodate our large group of church mates. His house is a luxurious modern mansion at Bukit Timah Hill and he's got four cars at home. The one he usually drives is a modest Honda SUV and the other three cars are less modest; a Mercedes, a Lamborghini and an Alfa Romeo. The first thing that came to my mind when I stepped into his compound was that this guy is freaking rich. The interior was breathtaking as well, it felt like a 5 star hotel. So we did our prayers and sang the hymns, and then the group disassembled to socialize with each other. Then it was when I started feeling uneasy.

My gf became more friendly to the rich boy and kept hanging around him at the balcony and talking to him. Naturally I joined in the conversation, and then I noticed the guy is the one trying to include me in their conversation while my gf relentlessly tried to exclude me from the conversation. And she wouldn't stop patting his arm. I felt really really uncomfortable. I put my arm around her shoulders, to subconsciously remind someone we are an item. But it was just very awkward and so uncomfortable. And this was only the beginning.

Subsequently, I felt my gf is no longer enthusiastic in our relationship. I have to keep initiating conversations and dates with her. She is nonchalant to everything I said when we talked, and she seems to just want to go through the motion and be done with it. Whenever I asked her if she is okay, she would say yes but her behavior contradicts her statement. I was very tired and upset. Back then I believe maybe it's because`she had other troubles at school. However, I realized that at church or when dealing with other people, she seemed perfectly alright. So I asked her straight if the problem is with me.

She told me she just needed some personal space for time being as there are a lot of things going through her mind. So I gave it to her. We stopped going on dates or talk about anything beyond what ordinary friends will. This went on for about a few months. Then one night, she called me. I was so happy she did. However, my heart broke when she told me she has fallen in love with someone else and that the person has reciprocated her feelings. 

Yes, it's the rich guy. I got angry and asked her why is that so. She politely told me it's because she felt he was a more driven person and explaining he has plans to go to the U.S. for further studies, whereas she said I am always easily contented with life, and she felt I am not the type of guy she truly likes. And she kept emphasizing he gives her a lot of security due to his good family background. I teared up a bit and told her if it's okay if we can still be friends. She agreed and apologized once more before hanging up.

I always told her I plan to work full time at church after graduation, but I didn't expect her to interpret it as a lack of ambition, considering she is devoted to church as well. Most associate ambition with material rewards. But I strongly disagree. Even a person who wants to help make the society a better place is also an equally ambitious and self-driven person. 

I know my gf wants a better life. She comes from a poor family and sometimes I feel that she is in church because she wants to believe in something spiritual to give her some hope for a more prosperous life. My background is similar to hers. My parents are poor and works as a coffee shop assistant and a taxi driver. However they are very hardworking and it is not because of a lack of ambition they are not better off. Their ambition is to earn enough money to support me and my siblings through school so we can have a more comfortable life in the future. And if you classify all poor people as lazy or lack ambition, then I am afraid you are out of touch with reality.

Nonetheless, I still attend the church. But I control my emotions whenever I see the both of them arriving in a sports car while I alight at the bus stop. Haha. I reminded myself they are humans like myself I shouldn't blame any of them for my misery, because I believe if I forgive others, I am also freeing myself from these negative emotions. And on a positive note, I am thankful my gf (ex-gf now) was honest about her feelings and material desires, and does not cheat while keeping me in the shadows. Although I still pray that things could have been better for me. 

I used to think that I will only get along with someone of similar religious beliefs, following the advice of my pastor. However he and I were both wrong. For two people to love each other isn't about how similar they both are. You can be of any race, any religion, any socioeconomic status... who cares. It's all about having the courageously love to accept your differences and forgive the shortcomings of the other. Not many have such courage it's because they fear others around will judge them for not meeting up to the expectations. Therefore, they would rather please the larger crowd of people in their social life, then the person who they should truly love. 

Perhaps in good faith, I will find the right person one day.

Many people around me (boyfriend included) seem to be depressed- not just upset, but legitimately unable to get out of bed/can't study/non-stop crying sad (to varying degrees).  I'm not talking the self-diagnosing sort; some of them are very obviously clinically depressed and one is even diagnosed but refusing medication.

I'm not surprised given our relatively stressful position as university students, or even some NSF buddies. But it's just immensely tiring to be around negative people so often. This means things like spending hours just sitting next to a sobbing friend, or forcing myself to actively reply FB messages that don't accomplish anything. 

I know that this isn't any of their faults, and that they can't help it. 
I know it's presumptuous to assume that I'm doing some immense service that deserves praise, and honestly I don't even think I'm helping by just repeating the same things over and over.

Hell, I've gone so far as to physically force two of them into a counsellor's office because I want so badly for them to be somewhere close to okay again. But I can't keep up with all of this sadness, and it's gotten to a point where I've considered breaking up with my partner and cutting off all contact with these friends just so I can spend a week without having to watch another loved on hurt so much.

Some of these people have suicidal ideations, and on days that I've run out of things to say and energy to listen, I find myself wondering if I should even bother trying to dissuade them?

it's frustrating to want to help when it seems like nothing is getting better, so I'm wondering-- should I be bothering at all?

I saw her on stage. That was the first time I saw her. And I would tell you what I told everyone, I swear that at the moment I laid my eyes on her, I fell for her.
She wasn't pretty. Quite plump, but not obese. Short and I remember how clumsy she looked while dancing on her fat thighs. She wasnt perfect. But as textbook as it sounds, I love her for her imperfection. I would never forget how confident she looked when she was dancing on that stage. And I told myself as I stood in the audience, that I HAVE to know her.
I am what you youngsters would call evergreen. Never asked a girl out, never dated, and I even screwed up my first date with her. No experience in dating. No confident. And just the average John Doe asking himself what is he doing with his life. I am the exact type of person who spends 5 awkward minutes answering the question "Name something special about yourself."

And years passed. Ordinary me never had to miss the confident crush which I saw on that stage. Every time i doubt where my life is heading towards,  the regret of choices I make, the life I could have had, there is always one thing I will never regret.

Because no matter how long has it been, no matter how many times I said it, every time, every day, every night when we had dinner together, every quarrel every reconcile, I would thank the stars at the bottom of my heart and the tears in my eyes.

I thank that I had the courage back then, to do the bravest thing I have ever done in every truth-or-dare combined, to do the dumbest thing I never thought I would do and to do the one thing I never thought I could ever do.

"May I have the honor to date you?"

Be dumb enough to try everything. 
I read about so many young boys and girls get worried about love, contemplate, hesitate. But events are only embarassing if you yourself are embarrassed by it.
I recall myself at what seem to be the bravest moment telling myself that " i am a nobody anyway. So why not risk it? Shame? No face? No one would remember me anyway."

And this story. No matter how many times. I would say it with pride, with tears, with thanks.
10 years on, at every anniversay party, at every gathering and on the day of our wedding itself. Today is the 10th. And i lie on my bed, thinking about the memories we shared in the school. My wife would be too shy for me to reveal who she is. But I just want to reassure every reader, I was a nobody filled with uncertainty too. But in life, there is no correct path. Just different ones. Dont be too busy being worried about what might happen, until you find yourself regretting what you didnt do. #YOLO
