-
 
I will not say that I am very successful at the dating game. After all, in the past 5 year, I've only in 2 relationships. However, the break time between those 2 relationships are only about 1 month. I have not spent any of the past 5 Valentine days alone; and probably will not; since I'm marrying at the end of this year, unless one of us die a sudden death or we break up. Anyway, I can probably attribute my success to my psychopathy. I'm not a psychology major, but according to the self-report psychopathy test, I am a high primary psychopath but low secondary. According to the test, primary psychopathy concerns affection side of psychopathy with the lack of empathy for others; while the secondary deals with the anti-social side of psychopathy: withdrawals, rejection, failure to learn, and inadequate motivation.

I can attest to the lack of empathy. When I read the recent news that a little girl got her head chop off by a crazy fucker, my first thought was not "how horrible", but "Holy shit, off-the-shelf meat cleavers can do that?" followed by "that crazy dipshit was lucky to be alive to be arrested". I generally do not give two shits about people I do not know. Live and let live. As long as they are not in my way, we are cool. I do not care if you die away from me. But if you die in front of me, it signals to me that something dangerous is going on and I should GTFO. But if you are in my way, or harm someone I care about, I will go to the end of the Earth to destroy you. My views on the refugee crisis is: "the fact that they can run away will make the war a lot longer". War's objective is to stack up corpses. War usually ends when enough corpses are piled up and people are too exhausted to fight. All the ceasefire, peacetalks, and people running away just delay that inevitable end; leading to Eternal Wars. Get on with the dying and perhaps we can end these war (before you flame me, take 15 minutes to read this excellent essay https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/1999-07-01/give-war-chance . Give War a Chance!). The best way to stop the crisis is to send commandos to attach mines to refugee ships BEFORE people get on them. That's also perfectly legal. Countries are only obliged to care for refugees when they are on its soil. As long as they die somewhere else, it's not out business,

As for the secondary psychopathy, luckily, I'm quite good at not having. I'm sociable enough, appear friendly enough, and somewhat motivated for my work and study. I also found that while I do have enough energy to care and love others, that list is unfortunately very very short. I have no problem with staying faithful since my capacity for loving someone is limited. I learn from my past mistakes in my first relationship and apply it to my current life. Some of the mistakes are quite generic: taking them for granted, wanting to win in an argument, losing physical affection and attraction, failing to surprise, being a bit needy. I can't be happier in the current rs, but I still hate my ex for causing me one month of pain and suffering. I don't exactly hold on to the grudge, but I will leave my ex alone. Unless I can get away with it, and the opportunity presents itself.

So there, some guides on the dating game. Here's a few thing you could do to improve your social skills (very important). Download Meetup apps and find things you might want to do. Sports, drinks, party, interest groups. I suggest learning Social and Ballroom dance. It's a good opportunity to interact with the opposite sex, there's always more girls than guys, most girls there are single (if they are not, they will be there with their bf. And those twos only dance with each other). Improv is an excellent thing to learn because it teaches you to be extremely fast on your feet, and how to be expressive. Acting is not bad, if you can find the class.

If you are in a relationship, here's a big tip: physical intimacy changes everything. It's like sitting on a truck, closing your eyes, and hitting the pedal to the metal. It increases the closeness and intimacy very very quickly. It also blinds you BTW. But be consistent. Always escalate; not descalate, if you want it to be steady. Don't suddenly one day say: "I don't want us to do it anymore"; unless you want to derail the r/s. Without physical intimacy, you two are just a pair of close friends. It does not always mean sex. But a few orgasms here and there by whatever means work wonder. Yeah, guys, learn your arts and crafts of making a girl orgasm. It helps immensely. And no, not with porn.

I am the OP of . I wanted to write a note thanking everyone for all your encouragement.

After I submitted that post, I took a job as a cashier at a supermarket near my home. It wasn’t a job I had in mind, but I just needed a reason to wake up everyday and do something.

I took on the night shift together with a Makcik. The first night, she looked at me and asked why a university graduate was working in a supermarket. 

I said I wasn’t having much luck with a full time job and that I was just recovering from my struggle with depression. She looked at me and she said, “Oh, it’s okay lah. Good to hear you’re doing better.”

Over time, I got to know her better. She kept assuring me that one day, I was going to find my lucky break and to not give up.

Well, I got my lucky break.

After three rounds of interviews, I finally got a job offer at an MNC. I thought I screwed the final interview. But when I got the call yesterday telling me of the job offer, I was just so happy.

The first person I told wasn’t my parents but that makcik. She was happy for me and said she’d miss having someone to talk to on the night shift. I didn't tell my parents first. Though they supported me financially during treatment, I felt that they didn’t understand what being mentally ill meant. I didn't feel like I could talk to them without having accusations thrown at me. Often, they thought I was just being lazy or faking the depression. 

I’m so happy to start work next month. I feel like I’m finally getting my life together. Strange as this might sound, I will miss the cashiering job, the night shifts and the encouraging makcik.

At the early stage of our relationship, I mentioned that I wanted to meet them, but he wasn't keen on the idea, citing awkwardness and a lack of commonalities between his friends and me. "They are not like your friends," he told me. "Group A likes talking about guy stuff like marvel movies, group B (mixed sex) doesn't have a culture of inviting our SOs to meetings."

Today, after one year of being exclusive, I popped the question of when I would get to meet his friends again. His response was the same. He asked his friends if he could bring his GF to one of their meals and they responded negatively, reason being they rarely get to meet up with their busy schedules and it would be very awkward if a stranger was in their midst. It would be uncomfortable.

"So your friends are all exclusive social groups," I reasoned.

"Yes, they are."

"Unlike my social groups where SOs are all welcome and where we've all met each others' SOs in person, your groups are exclusive."

"Yes."

"So when will I get to meet your friends...? When we're about to get married?" I asked.

"Well, that looks like the case," he replied as we walked through a crowded shop.

I hope that readers can weigh in on this situation. Whenever my friends ask me "What are _________'s friends like?" I have no answer to give them. They're always surprised when I mention that I've never met his friends in person.

When is reasonable for one to expect to meet her BF's friends? Am I asking too much to meet his friends just once...? I'm not asking to hang out with them on a regular basis. I just want to be a part of HIS life. I feel shut out from his social life. I feel uncomfortable that I haven't met his friends. One is the average of their closest friends, right?

I dreamt about you last night. 6 years after you walked out of that door, telling me you can't do this anymore. Best April's Fool joke played on me - a dream about you.

I dreamt that you came back to me, to my arms. I dreamt that we continued, or we started over. We were together. We had a future. We had a family. We had each other.

I woke up. Trying to replay the dream in my mind. Trying to recall every single moment of that fantasy. Us. Together. You always did call me stupid for letting my dreams affect me so deeply. But as reality hits me, and I prepare for the day, a drop of tear escaped my eyes. Unintentionally. I didn't even have enough time to hold it back. The harsh reality that like all April's Fool joke, it is a joke. You would never come back. Like your final words: there is no more us.
Perhaps the most heartbreaking thing is the fact that neither of us was wrong. Neither of us were the demanding party, or the childish one. In fact we were both too  mature that we understood how both of us couldn't have a future together. 
Nothing went wrong. Because it was never right to begin with. We werent compatible. But I was convinced I could make it work. But I couldn't convince you. And as i lay on my bed now, thinking about you,  looking through our photos together, typing this. I wonder if i will dream of you again tonight. I am grateful seeing you in my dreams. For you will always be in my heart and memories.

Every day since that night, I doubted if I could ever love someone as much as I loved you. Or if I could even love again at all.

And like every cheesy romance movie: I will choose it all again if I had a choice.
Sleepy. I close my eyes. I cry. As I remember the day I first met you. How we got lost and met on the bus. The words I first told you. And the words that I always told you out of the blue, during our dates, and the night you walked out of my life. Do you remember?
"Did I ever tell you how lucky was I to have met you?"
Goodbye my pris-cess

Hi You,

It's Me again from . Lately, I've been thinking about you more than ever after I wrote that confession. I was reminiscing about us and how we came this far.

Do you still remember that day? I mustered up a monstrous amount of courage and approached you that day? I knew it was my last opportunity to do so I was glad I did. As a female who would never fall for a younger male, you were an exception.

Remember those talks about the ideal characteristics we would like our future significant other to possess? I was secretly hoping that I would match those descriptions of what you shared. However I was the complete opposite. Thus I kept my feelings hidden as I was unsure and afraid of rejections.

Despite that, we still fell for each other. Yet, we didn't happen. Our story ended on the day it started. Thus, we parted ways.

I only knew about your feelings months later but it was all too late. It was at that moment when all feelings have faded, confessing were therefore much easier. It was also then when I found out that you fell for someone else. Thus it was easier for both of us to move on.

5 years isn't a short period of time. 5 years later, certain things still reminded me of you. 5 years have passed and I never fail to wish you on your birthday. I'm thankful for you being a part of my life even though it was for a short while.

Love is capable of turning a rational person into a fool. I still remembered making up stupid excuses just so I can see you once again after 5 years. 

I hope you'll do well in my alma-mater even though I've graduated from NUS. I wish I hadn't... Because I still miss you.

Love,
Me.

Got blasted recently by my boss for not doing something which I was sure I did but have no way to prove, only to later doubt if I have actually done it, and only much later to realise that I have most likely done it (meaning not my fault), but still no way to prove.

I looked at my falls, glaring at me every day, reminding me that, if I had worked harder then, I would have been in a much better position today. 

I look at my falls, and realise, how much I have yet to learn, about materials, about drafting work, about control, fluids and much more to come.

I learnt how I can learn - by doing more machining. Though seriously, paperwork does not work at all on me for some reason - things just don't make sense to me that way - but they do make sense when I see them coming together, falling into places.

Ironically, it is my failing grades at my uni level, that returned the spark and flame, to drive me to be interested in becoming an inventor again, after so many lost years.

Strange, isn't it? That a guy sharing the same name (not background) as that other guy from Meet the Robinsons, is telling himself the same thing, to Keep Moving Forward?

I just wanted my own fairytale of being together with my first and didn't want to let go despite being repeatedly poisoned by an arsehole. I told myself I could take it,  and psyched myself to think that it was good training ground for my character (lol). Luckily for me, the time came for me to leave, albeit it being far too late.

I am not naturally an introvert, but I have since become afraid of speaking out and being myself because I've been so used to being submissive, compliant and passive under his bidding and expectations. 

Since then, I have met a certain someone who has all the qualities that every girl would want in a boyfriend, and while I haven't accepted him, he is breaking my walls down in the softest, sincerest ways. His affection towards me is unthinkable, to the point where I catch myself feeling unworthy of such love and kindness from another human being. The way I know my heart will be secure with him, the tenderness with which he beckons me, how he pays attention to my boundaries and remembers my preferences, how he respects the things I'm good at without comparing me to others who are better.. I feel like crying. Has the world we live in become so hardened that basic human decency makes one teary? 

Previously, I always thought that I deserved a lot from my partner because I am above average, but after going through what I had and then being treated like royalty, I know that my sense of entitlement makes me a shitty person.  Even though the second guy comes from an incredibly humble background, his ability to give me everything he has is so unreal. In a nurturing environment like that, I see my old healthy self peeking out once in a while. I am so afraid that he will not like what he sees, so I constantly expect him to ghost me or unveil his true colours after the excitement of the chase has died down, but it has been half a year and he is still at it, more wonderful with each passing day. I don't have to earn any of his goodwill as a reward for being abused, and this is what I've always known a functional, loving, sustainable relationship to be like. Seeing it play out in real life is truly surreal.

All I want to say is, thank you for making me believe in love again. And a heartfelt thank you to all the guys out there who conscientiously treat their girls like queens. May you all receive the love you so much deserve. To girls who are in a toxic relationship, grow some (really big) balls and leave. Never look back. Take care of yourself. To the singletons, keep focusing on making yourself a great partner, and love will find you soon enough. Don't lose hope.

I've also seen many short male acquaintances getting attached. I think height is not an issue. When the girl really likes you, your height and look will not matter much.

Have faith in yourself and never give up trying! There's no harm in giving your best. Clothes-wise, wear something you're comfortable in. All the best to you.

*warning: long post ahead*
Hi , I do hope you see this. I'm sorry that you haven't been able to find someone who reciprocates your love, but I'm sure you will one day. As a single lady, I'm also waiting for someone I love who loves me back. You aren't alone here in this, there's a lot of single people out there - and who knows? What will be will be; it's best to wait and find the right one rather than end up with the wrong one.

And yes, studying can seem like a real chore if you don't like what you're studying or if you don't do well in it, I agree. But..if it isn't something you can change, then I guess all you can do is to grit your teeth and bear it. Worrying and being upset over what cannot be doesn't make things better - perhaos what you can do is think on what you really want and pursue it :) after all, a degree really is just a piece of paper. Just like how grades are just a number. Being in a course you dislike doesn't mean you must be condemned to it your whole life~ 
As for internships, may I ask what field you are looking at? Is it a field within your engin degree, or a field within your passion? If it's in line with the internships I'm looking out for, I may be able to help :)

And if you think being unattractive and short is an issue.. I would say no, it isn't. 
Really.

This is coming from a girl who is also not what you'd call pretty, short (probably -2SDs below the mean lol) and kinda chubby, I definitely don't fit the bill of what you'd call 'chio bu'. But I've learnt to let that go because love isn't about looks but about personality. Cliché, I know, but looks can only go so far right? It may be the face/look/body that attracts, but it's the personality that makes someone stay.

I can tell you're doing your best, and given the circumstances life has given you, it's a testament to your inner strength you have overcome them. To be able to continue trying and working so hard even though you may feel like it's hopeless. To be able to even tell your story here on NUSwhispers.

Don't think badly of yourself because you are much stronger than you think you are.

Sometimes I feel just like you do. Why the things I pursue don't go right, why I can't get decent grades, why can't I at least have lesser things to stress about even as I deal with studies and the prospect of never finding a guy. Why I can't have a 'normal' family.

It's depressing. It's hard. It makes us feel shitty and crap when those who don't understand make snide or insensitive comments. I won't tell you to ignore it because frankly..the phrase "words can never hurt me" is utter bull, isn't it? Sometimes words cut deeper than sticks and stones ever will. 
So..screw those peers of yours who laugh at you. You're fighting a hard battle - one they are unaware of, I presume - and those words are the last things you need to hear. I distance myself from people who are like that, so perhaps you can too :) no point associating with such negativity. 

About work..is it possible for you to find work somewhere else? It isn't healthy for your well-being to be stuck in a place where you have to deal with even more negativity. 
And no, it isn't you. It's probably just the supervisor..for reasons unknown, but it isn't your fault okay? You didn't do anything wrong so there's no reason for him to angst.

Right, now for family. 
I can't comment on your family situation, but I'm guessing everyone is stressed over finances? And it might affect the mood of having a meal together.
I really am in no place to give you advice here, but I do hope it turns out well for you. I'm sure your mum and brother care about you too even if they don't show it. All the best :)

If you ever need someone to talk to, you can PM me (though Idk how we can do this lol maybe you can reply this anonymously or something, things can be worked out somehow).

So before I end this..I just wanna say
I hope you find peace within yourself, and continue with the strength and courage in dealing with daily life.
All the best for your family, your internships, your love life, and your work. I hope you have trusted friends you can confide in too :) take care! And know that while you probably don't know the writer of this post, know that whoever she may be, she cares - and I believe there will ve others that do too.

Hey dear, I am having the same problem, and it seems like I will give you an opinion different from that of the guys. I say you move on.

He is busy, yes and you can put up with that, but what is the point in trying so hard when the effort is one-way? Relationship must be mutual and balanced, you get his problem but he never bothers to get yours. Then is it fair for you? 

I know this makes me sound like a spoiled brat, but there is a fine line between cannot affford to make an effort and not even think about trying. Seems like your guy does not care enough to see any potential problem in the way he is behaving. If he truly cares for you then he should be worried about the way you may feel. It seems like he may like you...but not to any significant extent. Otherwise he would not confuse you like this. If you are looking for a serious relationship, as opposed to a casual one, it's not the time yet.

My life is never smooth. Everything I want, no matter how hard I try, I usually don't get it.

After the rejection, they deliberately avoided me like the plague. Yea, say all you want about the benefits of being a single and all, but personally, I want to find someone I love and who loves me just as much to spend my life with.

I wanted to study business at university, I worked very hard for my 'A' levels. In fact, I did well for prelims. But unfortunately during my 'A' levels, my father passed away and it deeply affected me. And most unfortunately, the GP questions which came out are totally out of my grasp. I passed my A levels but the only option for me is engineering, but I disliked it. I considered to study business in a private university but they do not allow me the financial benefits a local university would. And since my family is not well-off, I don't have a choice.

I really try to love whatever I am studying. However maths and physics isn't my strong suit and interest, and obviously this is important in engineering. And I wanted to change course, but my CAP must be good in order for the faculty to accept my transfer. But my grades are below average. I feel stuck.

Any internships I apply to, I got rejected. I realized that internship is not really for students to learn, although that's what those companies claim to be doing. That's a myth. In reality, internships are either for companies to look for cheap labour or find potential talents to work them. I am willing to be either if they can offer me the chance at all. But after the interviews, I do not hear from them.

My part time job as a retail staff is tough as well. Whenever I work, my supervisor finds trouble with me. It is not constructive criticism to help me improve myself, but it is outright sarcasm and bullying. And when I asked the other staffs if the supervisor treats them the same way, they disagreed with me and said the supervisor is a very nice person. I really think something is wrong with me.

My relationship with my mother and brother is bad. I am always trying to bring them together for outings or meals to bond our family together. However, they are usually busy or not interested at all. I cannot change them. It really hurts me to see other families spending time with each other but mine doesn't. 

I know there are plenty of opportunities out there. But I am just so unlucky that whatever I want to pursue, it always fail. I have the opposite of the midas touch, everything I touch turns into rust. Maybe I should lower my expectations on others and on myself? Yes I tried. But guess what? When I lower my expectations, the real results are often even below those low expectations. I just can't get anything right even though I try very hard.

I am a physically unattractive short person and I cannot articulate myself very well. And I believe people will judge me for that. Even if I try to dress nicely, my peers sarcastically joke I am going for a date, even though they know I don't have a girlfriend. It's very hurtful and even though I am a guy, I have feelings as well. And I am a human. Although I am not useful to you, and I don't have anything special to offer you, I have dreams and aspirations for a happy life too like the rest of you. Please don't treat me like a lesser being. Please at least give me a chance to try before saying no :(

His slow-ness in replying messages may not necessarily be a representation of a low level of interest. 

I can only text properly after I ended work. Even during meal times, my brain will be pre-occupied. So unless it is really urgent, or a yes/no kind of message, I tend to only reply after I finished work. I might not even catch the urgent message since I don't check my phone when I am working. It is not so much of a lack of concern/interest, but rather I would not want to reply messages without an ounce of thoughts into it. 

Some people are just like that, and it depends on whether you are comfortable with this level of aloofness during working hours. Don't expect him to change when you two get together. I think my ex hated this part of me. :(

A very good example would be when my mom hid my gameboy because I was starting to get addicted to it, I would scour the entire house just to find it and when I found it, I would return to doing whatever I was supposed to do. I wouldn't play with it but I love the feeling that I know where it is with utter certainty and that I could choose to play with it whenever I wanted to. But I never would...

Back to the present, I think I am currently experiencing the same feeling. -
 
Social media and numbers.

People tell you - numbers don't matter. Which is true. They mostly don't, especially in the context of social media. The endless comparisons, mostly built upon insecurities we have about ourselves can destroy ourselves completely.

There are times I thought I had completely understood and internalised the concept that numbers are not important. Yet, there would be times where I would check my instagram every two minutes after making a post, and would get disappointed and depressed when the number of likes is not what I would have liked it to be. 

It's worse when thoughts like "This person has such an ugly and toxic character, why can he/she gather so many likes but I can't?" Then it would dawn on me. 

Ah. I'm the ugly one now. No wonder the lack of likes.

I know I shouldn't think this way. It should never be the case where your value is determined by such superficial numbers. I know. But sometimes, I would be extra conscious of it, feeling that my worth is based on the little numbers underneath my posts. On days like this I feel incorrigibly shallow and ugly on the inside. 

I wonder if the day will come when I can fully get rid of these feelings and appreciate social media without all these toxicity. Even now, I'm typing all these out in deliberation, with some hopes that I'd gather likes.

Ugly, isn't it?

Hey! I understand how you feel. So I am a person who does not have many friends, but I have a number of good close friends. Most of the time, I couldn't stop, just couldn't, stop thinking about what others may think about me. Even to some of my second degree close friends, I may really appear very rational and reserved and careful under every situations, so as to be cool and..be 'normal'. 

So I too, realize that this isn't going to work. I can't live my life like this and I decided to change, by focusing on myself, listening to my thoughts, and trying to be sincere to people around me, instead of being fixated on those unstoppable overthinking. So I took up some external classes alone, to boost my confidence. The progress is slow, but it's making a difference! :) After some time, a friend of mine, after we talked, told me that she loved seeing the human side of me. Then it hit me that, we are all human. Humans make mistakes, wrong choices, and so many more imperfections. Even perfectionists get criticized/negative comments by some people. So, the thing is, if I continued living, pretending to be a 'sane' and 'normal' person, I'd be boring, and lifeless to be honest. Try thinking that the things people talk about, will also attract and appeal to other people. Our qualities are liked and disliked by different people, right? :)

So, if your friends leave you, then too bad they step away from a valuable friendship. If you really want to continue with them, it's okay to compromise to achieve that goal, but remember to put yourself in priority. If they don't treasure you or your effort, then it's really not worth the time to please them. 

Keep holding on. :)

To  
I feel that you should go ahead and pursue her :) what is past is past, so don't bring it into your present & possibly future w her.
From the way how you don't wish to repeat the "happenings" with her, you obviously care about her.
Perhaps the reason why she had shown less interest is becos she may feel that you're not serious about her, or even seeing her as a fling like the wild girls in the past (if you had told her about them). So be more obvious about what you want with her, more clear that you're interested in her. 
And if she doesn't like you, it will show (extreme slow replies or ignore msges, reject going out, try to avoid you etc). 
If she likes you, it also will show (willing to go out, reply your msges quickly, cares about you etc). 
If she doesn't like you, at least you tried your best to chase her anyway :) 
If she likes you, all the best!

To  Don't you think that it's super premature to get together with someone whom you already acknowledged not to have a deep personal connection with? It leads to a much higher chance of a break up later on if you don't know the person properly first, presuming you are not into casual dating. Unless you're prepared to face a rejection if you were to confess first, or get a rude shock when you finally find out some things after getting together (which you could've known beforehand), I highly recommend that you do your due diligence before getting together with someone. 

That said, kudos to your courage for thinking of making the first move. As a girl myself, I would never make the first move because I want to know that the guy is vested in this potential relationship. I would at most drop obvious hints to gauge his response, but otherwise it's typically no loss for me if he doesn't pick up the hints. Don't really want someone who can't pick up on such cues. Call me a traditionalist for waiting for the guy to initiate, but at least it makes me feel more secure knowing it's two-way and he's leading it.

Hi, would appreciate some advice here (no trolling please).

I met this girl 1 or 2 months back. We've become quite comfortable with texting each other, and she always replies very quickly and the replies are the kind that can keep the conversation flowing. She will sometimes ask about me e.g. "How about your...". We've been texting almost daily and we can text late into the night until she sleeps, sometimes until 3 or 4 AM. We've also journeyed to school together a few times and it's quite enjoyable chatting with her (not awkward or anyth). I've managed to ask her out to exercise once.
However, there are a few signs that she's not interested being more than friends.

1) she doesn't initiate the conversations (99.9% of the time). So if I don't text her for 1 or 2 days, there's not going to be any texting.

2) she doesn't say goodnight unless I catch her at the exact moment when she's about to sleep. But if she doesn't say goodnight, she will just continue the convo the next morning.

3) I've jioed her twice to go out for movies/a meal but so far she's been busy, and she doesn't offer to reschedule.

4) Once, she did say she would likely be free for a meal, but the night before she gave some reason on why she couldn't make it.

5) I haven't had much luck asking her out to exercise again (tried 3 or 4 times). Mainly because she's busy (doesn't reschedule).

In a nutshell, if I don't initiate anything (texting or jioing her out for anyth), nothing's going to happen. Basically I feel like I won't be missed if I just disappear.

I'm more of a pessimist so if I'm to analyze her behaviour I would say she's 90% not interested to be anything more than friends. However, my friends tell me there are some good signs (e.g. the texting) and tell me not to give up yet (maybe this is her busy sem, maybe she's the independent kind).

I'm really confused and also emotionally getting fatigued from trying to guess the situation. Also, there's a limit to how many times you keep asking without being a creep. Should I find out from her directly and move on if she's not interested?

Would appreciate some advice (especially from girls who have had similar experience/fit the profile).

Thanks a lot!

-
 
To  Dear confused guy, I sound very much like the girl in question since I seem to exhibit similar traits to hers, but I can assure you that I'm not her. 

For starters, make your intentions very clear to her i.e. that you see a potential relationship from this and you're serious about it etc. Don't use ambiguous language to let her guess your intentions because that just adds to the fluff. Definitely sound her out by asking her directly how she feels about you since this is the best way of finding out than play guessing games by yourself. 

If she is lukewarm about it or unsure, I think you should mentally set a time frame for yourself (e.g. 3 months etc) on how long you can keep going at this. Once the time is up and there is no palpable progress you know it's time to move on.

However, don't become threatening/ coercive/ passive-aggressive, thinking that you can instigate some kind of action from her. Give her space, be encouraging, genuine, and constantly tell her what lies on the other side with you around so that she can feel thrilled at the prospect of being with you. Do not over-promise, though. Allow her to see that your presence adds value to her life and that your company is sweeter than her solitude. Lead her but don't make decisions for her. It is also okay to be the last person to say something in your conversations. It is an ego thing for the girl. 

For myself, it's a really weird phenomenon how I gravitate towards being (extra) passive towards someone whom I feel has a romantic interest in me just to see how much he wants it. I recognise that it's a bad habit but I just can't help myself. I want to know that he has the balls to take the initiative and that he wants this (me) a lot. Unfortunately, this passiveness can also translate to my not wanting a relationship very much with said person. I am currently trying to be more upfront about my thoughts and feelings when chased so that he doesn't waste his time but it's hard. Girls love being adored and to an extent, worshipped. 

I find that I am usually quite fast in deciding whether I could potentially be with someone. Any further conversations/time spent normally affirm my initial suspicions. Some girls can be moved with more persistence and sincerity, but it is difficult to overcome the first gut feelings, especially for me. Indeed, your friends are right that the texting could be a positive sign; I honestly wouldn't bother if I had zero interest, but take this with a huge pinch of salt. The premium is on getting her to actually hang out with you more.  

Good luck :)

I cried in the shower and I had never cried so hard before. Suddenly all of the love songs were about you. Suddenly the colour of my world was washed away. 

First week: 
I no longer received messages from you. I no longer studied with you. I no longer walked with you. 

First month:
I would see you talking to people and I would watch you by the sidelines. My heart still yearned for you. 

Second month:
Exam time came and you talked to me again. I was over the moon. I missed you. But then I realised you just needed help. I was disappointed and heart broken again 

Third month: 
School finished. I was not able say my final goodbye to you. I cried that night, because I knew I would never see you again 

Fourth month: 
I would religiously check my social platforms to see if I could find you, to see what you have been up to. 

Fifth month( present)
I am still constantly thinking about you. I no longer feel grief for my loss but I do wonder how life has been treating you? I just want to hear your voice. I was tempted to message you a few days ago but I know that our friendship is beyond reparable. I am sad. Bye bye? But I don't want to say goodbye. 

Sixth month (future) 
Will we ever meet again? Will I forget about you? Will I ever stop missing you?

@ In my experience, it's code for "I want people to think I am not shallow. Actual depth might varies". It does not really matter in the inital stage of dating.

Also in my experience, actually discuss those stuff are not gonna help building a rapport. Ok, let me explain: once you are very familiar with each other, like being in a relationship, seeing each other day in day out, blah blah, those topics are a nice change of pace. You can pass hours, and hours doing it. Occasionally you will fight (and hopefully make-up sex, some of the most awesome sex out there). But in the initial stage, talk about yourself, for herself. Personal stuff. It builds rapport.

And there's deep rapport. It's after you two are already past the getting to know part, quite comfortable with one another, find each others' company enjoyable and fun, etc .... This is when you break out and start on the kinds of things that happened in your past that kinda make you into the person today. Like past relationships, parents, familiy, etc ... Future aspirations, personal philosophies on love, deepest fear and insecurity, etc ... This is in the relationship territory. If you tend to talk like this, it has a relationship vibe to it. If you keep everything light and fun, it might be just a causal thing, a hookup of sorts, but once you dwell into these things, it's kinda an exclusive, love, relationship thing. It can be a bit confusing.

Whoops, I wrote a bit too much. Well, I've meant to write a small guide to dating. Too lazy to actually start writing, despite already drafting out in my head. I'll settle for shorter writings.

Whatever emotions that manifest are what I deem appropriate of the situation. Sorry that I (and I guess most of the well-meaning comments) can't be of much help. Just thought I'd share that I'm going through something similar - it's not self pity, wanting to be the best, or being too hard on myself, simply wanting figure out what's wrong and working on the issue. 
-
 
To  I'd like to respectfully disagree. Everyone - and I mean EVERYONE - needs to take ownership for their own relationship status. If you're single and you want to find a life partner, take responsibility for your singlehood. Ask yourself how to improve your chances of finding a life partner. Are you putting yourself out there? Are you meeting new people? Or are you stuck in your own social circle of same-sex friends and platonic friendships with the opposite sex?

My friends used to tell me to wait for the right one to come along. Throughout my life, I've met many potential girlfriends. We'd talk on msn after school every day, sms each other after school, stay up all night talking on the phone. Some girls would agree to a date, some would turn cold and ghost me. Every failed romantic encounter left me sad for awhile, but eventually I'd meet the next girl and the cycle would repeat itself. Despite all this, I never really found the right girl, the one that I had confidence in committing myself fully to and who wanted to commit herself fully to me. By full commitment, I mean taking the relationship seriously (the goal being marriage) and being completely honest with me, keeping no dirty secret in the dark.

I grew tired of meeting girls naturally. Natural is too slow. If I had left it to nature, I'd probably be single by now. In university, I joined OkCupid and spent my free time scouring through the profiles, looking for my potential partner. Unlike Laoniang, I didn't go out on many dates. I only went out on three dates. And it took a lot of effort for me to secure myself these dates with these three different ladies. It took conversation and rapport building. Success! I eventually asked one of the girls to be my girlfriend and she said yes! This is my first girlfriend and she means the world to me. She's kind-hearted, selfless and I can imagine waking up to her sweet smile every morning for the rest of my life. If I had not made the effort to actively date, I would still be single.

Whether one chooses to use dating sites like OkCupid/Tinder/LOLA/Paktor or chooses to ask their friends to set them up on blind dates doesn't matter. My point is that people cannot be so passive about their dating lives or relationship status. Take some damn ownership for your singlehood. The statistics shows that the number of singles in Singapore are growing over the years. If you want to be passive about dating, good luck to you. You're headed in the direction of singlehood for life. Start doing your financial planning for singlehood.

Life isn't a romance movie, nobody is going to come and "find you" if you're going to lock yourself up in your own social circle. Put yourself out there, start actively finding your own partner and be proud of it! You know what you want, so go and get what you want with your head held high. If your friends jeer at you for being  "despo," remind yourself that these friends are not going to be responsible for you being a 45 year old single. Only you are.

-
 
When I was younger, I always dreamt of being able to represent my country in the olympics. Coming from a family who had a firm sporting pedagogy; My dad represented Singapore at the SEA games at his prime, my Uncle represented Singapore at the Asian Games. My older Brother is currently still in the national team. Growing up in such a family, it was inevitable that I also concentrated a lot on sports since I was young. When I was 9, my coach and others around me were already commenting on my talent in the sport. 
Everyone all said that I could go far with the talent I had. I trained hard. I was disciplined. As I grew older, I won everything there was to win at age-group level competitions. I proceeded to represent my country at age group level against the ASEAN countries, and did well there too. My school recognised my achievements. I went on stage multiple times to receive awards and medals I won from competitions. I didn't become complacent, instead I worked even harder. My ultimate goal was to to represent Singapore at the Olympics. It was only 2010 and I was only 16 years old, but I already had a goal in sight then: Rio 2016. I really felt I could do it. 

Then, when things were progressing so smoothly, everything came crashing down.  Due to a freak accident which I shall not describe here avoid revealing my identity, I tore my ACL. For those of you who don't know, an ACL tear is one of the worst injuries that could befall a sportsman, an absolute nightmare. It was not a minor or  partial tear. It was a complete tear. I required an operation. Recovery would take at least a year and half. Even after that,  the doctor said that it would be extremely difficult for me for me to reach the level I was before my injury. The mental trauma of such an injury, he said, would scar me for life. 

Regardless, I tried my best to recuperate and recover. It was a painful and long  road towards recovery. But I never recovered eventually. Although I was "cleared" to be able to play my sport again after what seemed like an eternity, my performances were nowhere near the level it was before my injury. I tried, I did try. For 2 years after my injury I tried. But I couldn't even get a look in to the national team anymore. I faded into obscurity and I quit the sport shortly after I enlisted. During NS, I withdrew into my shell, suffered bouts of depression and started to binge-eat to drown my pain. I grew fat and unrecognisable from what I was before my injury. It was a painful two years of NS for me but the passage of time eventually helped me to recover, albeit not completely. All this time, my parents and brother were supportive of me. But the more they showed their support for me, the more ashamed I felt and my mental state worsened as a result. I kept all my issues to myself all this while, and my family still doesn't know of it even till know. 

Fast forward to the present. I'm just a unknown fat low-esteem student studying in a mediocre faculty. I have no friends. Girls shun me because I'm fat and sweating all the time. Guys think I'm weird. No one knows about my past. 
How I wish I could rewind time and go back to the past before my injury. Before my life ended.

To , yes I got out of the friend zone.Here's how you do it. Have a personal connection with the person you have in mind. Talk about important stuff that's close to the heart like family and deep thoughts. Talk about smart people things like philosophy and shit. Then, when thats established, text them more often. Have lunch, just the two of you. Go do things that both of you like. Show how confident you are, how attractive you are. It took a while for me but finally managed to get this dude who was wayyyy out of my league to date me. Flirt a little, be secretive a little. Then BOOM. You're in bed together. However, it came at a cost. Our mutual Friend really hated it and we no longer talk but ayy whatever right? 

All da best!

 I feel you man. 

I picked up a sport in JC and played for almost 6 years before injury derailed everything. Well, I was only ever an amateur at my sport at my peak, but I had dreams and I had passion too. One year ago I tore my left ACL - complete tear too. Had it reconstructed and went through physiotherapy religiously. Plenty of "suggestion" from my parents that I give up this sport for good. But 7 months later I was overly optimistic, I was impatient, and I went to play a match. Guess what, I partially tore the graft and a bit of meniscus too. So I decided to lay off for a while longer. So this year I thought, perhaps I can start again slowly, and so I did. Going back to light trainings once a week, and everything was going well for a few weeks. But life sucks and shit happens. Three weeks ago I tore my right ACL at a training. While I was slightly mentally prepared that I could possibly tear the left again, this was completely unexpected and I am beyond devastated. And I still had to contend with I-told-you-so's from my parents, which I have to quietly suck up because they're footing my bills.

What's my point here? I don't really know. I can't offer anything actually useful. I too know that sympathy and well wishes don't heal ACLs. I won't pretend that everything's going to be fine - it's not. Having something that has been a major part of your life suddenly taken away hurts like hell. In my quiet moments the rage and the feeling of helplessness consumes me. I guess if you were or are still passionate about your sport, you could still play it recreationally or maybe even coach; I reckon you still have at least 1.5 good ACLs. Me, I'm out for good. With or without surgery for the right ACL, the risk is way too high for me to ever play again at any level. 

I could've made it big. I also could've remained mediocre. But now I will never know.

Hey! Oh my gosh, I always wonder that I'm alone at this. I always question why would I even feel nervous during group discussion when it's supposed to be informal, somewhat getting to know each other, yet I feel utterly uneasy when I want to voice out my opinions.

You're not alone in this. :) Yes, I believe it's largely due to low self-esteem. We are not confident in ourselves. However, I feel that, say in a group discussion.

(1) It is really not necessary to voice out opinions just because everyone else is doing that. We may take time to think and that's alright, it's not like we're slacking. We're just processing the thoughts until we are certain about them before suggesting it out loud.

(2) Which brings me to the next point. When you want to speak up, do try to rehearse it in your brain once or twice real quick. Think about your logic and sentence structure. Even if it was a topic discussed earlier on, just bring it up and say hey, about the thing you discussed earlier, I have some thoughts on it. It really doesn't harm your image for doing that. :)

(3) Like what the commentators have said, slow down. One trick I find is useful is to keep reassuring yourself. Just keep thinking, "it's alright, I can do it, I'll be fine". This sounds cheesy, but I feel that when you keep thinking this until it becomes automated in your mind, it brings wonderful effect. :) Even if you don't have much faith in yourself, thinking about positive things could really help.

I admit that I'm still struggling in this area too, but one thing I feel is that we could have faith that the other parties would be patient and listen to what we have to say. Trust is important. :) You can try to practice looking into people's eyes, this really helps to show sincerity. :)

Good luck in everything. :) Many of us are here for you. :) Cheers!

Warning: long post ahead. 

I am not very sure what's wrong with me; from young I have been praised as smart and talented, along with criticism along the lines of laziness and arrogance. I did reasonably well for PSLE (258) and got into a good school. 

The first setback came in sec 1, when I failed a test for the first time, on math as well which was my strongest subject along with English. It seems I never recovered from that, as I continued to struggle with math even in JC. I got bullied as well that year, and perhaps that sapped what confidence and self esteem I had left. I transfered to another class.  I was an outcast, almost always alone. To be fair some of my new classmates tried to involve me, but I had become socially awkward. I had refused them multiple times. And eventually they stopped. I would have too. 

More recently, I screwed up my A Levels. I could not even attain the National average, let alone the school's. The subjects I had the most confidence in, I did not get a distinction grade. As a result I could not get even an interview for the course of study I wanted. My sense of self-worth dipped even further. 

I was in a UG during secondary school, and returned as a cadet officer in JC. OCS is a shoo-in, I thought. But no, I was let down by myself yet again. I got posted to SCS instead. I couldn't understand how certain people could get into OCS yet I couldn't. 

It was hard putting up a brave front, telling people the setbacks didn't matter, keeping up smiles all around. I had become worried my friends would look down on me. That they were getting tired of me. I wanted reassurances, yet I could not bring myself to ask. I don't think I would have believed their answers if I did ask too. You see, I just lost belief in myself. 

My parents almost constantly remind me of my failures. They would say "if only you did better on your exams." "if only you had been more prepared." "if only you had gotten that internship, what a waste." and while most times I ignore them, hurting inside, sometimes I can't help but lash out. 

It has been some time since I noticed that my emotions are numb. I do not feel joy, or sadness, or jealousy, or peace. I feel mostly empty, and sometimes rage. The emotions I display are those I deemed appropriate for the situation. And I feel detached from it all. I'm afraid of pushing everyone who cares away, if there are any. 

I have friends, I have family, I'm not sure why I feel so alone. I'm not sure what to do or what I need. And I'm not very sure what's wrong with me.

 I would say it really depends bah. I come from some course where there are quite few ladies, and frankly speaking, (or maybe by nature of my course), the average lady w/o make-up looks quite pretty, actually. 

I see such ladies all over the place, and generally, I feel that they seem a lot more approachable than a lady who wears make-up. It's frankness on their part, and the girl-next-door feeling that I get when I see them around. I won't feel nervous. I can say and wave hi to them with a laugh and cackle, no problems.

Now, a lady who wears make-up, well, I look at it from a very different perspective - they know what they want, and take the time and effort to look good (like how some guys go to the gym). They have a lot of class, but they seem a lot less approachable because of that. If they ever appear in front of me bare-faced, well, I already gave my answer.

It won't really be weird, though, because I do believe that most guys can just look closer and see through make-up. I'm a scale-modeler, so I do pay a bit of attention to details (so I'm biased in a way), like how that lady I randomly walked past on the way to Arts in the morning today... Her mustache is smoother than mine.

Now, after the looks, comes your character - because if I feel comfortable around you, I don't look at you by your looks anymore - I look at your character instead, because at this point, you're a friend, so the demographic changes.

You're a friend, you're defined as, well, like that, it's a given common sense thing that I would accept you regardless of your looks. It's like... "Omg you're so cute!!!!!!!!" Uh... Ok can. Let's get a move on.

Well, at least, this is an oddball's honest opinion bah. Not sure about other guys though.

To  and all other guys who think Singaporean girls are close-minded: 
I'm a Singaporean girl in university, like 

May I put out another perspective: 
I was using Tinder for a while back, for about a month. I had a bunch of matches and talked with a handful of guys. Being the awkward person I was, I didn't initiate conversations with many of my matches. I usually wait for them to initiate it. I mean I could then double confirm whether the guys I matched with mindlessly swiped right, right? Not to mention, I honestly have no idea what to talk about.  Most of them were genuinely nice (except that one guy who had to point out, hey your friend is cute. Wow, well-played!) 

Okay, so my main point is a few asked me out for a friendly meal/ meet-up quite early into the conversation. I just rejected them (even though I honestly felt bad) but guys needs to understand that some girls rejecting you is not that they think first dates are "akin to marry" the guy. There could be plenty of personal reasons by the girls, like 
1) they are not comfortable with you yet
2) they don't know you well enough yet (I mean come on, there are probably rapists on Tinder right?)
3) they are too self-conscious to meet you (I am not as pretty as my picture, I might look better in the photo because I chose the best looking one and no I didn't photoshop it OR the pictures I chose does not show my full body, my thighs are actually quite thick)
4) they are genuinely busy (like I didn't came up with an excuse that I have a project/test) etc. THE LIST GOES ON, just because girls like to overthink (or am I over generalising? okay maybe I am) 

And also, after I reject the guy, I usually don't ignore them. Unless they reply "Haha Lol" "haha yeah" etc and don't say anything else. LIKE DUDE, what do you expect me to reply to that? "Haha lol to you too"? sure! There was a guy who asked me for a meet up quite early on, I rejected him a few times (SO SORRY TO HIM) but, he was understanding and he continued to talk to me normally, eventually when I felt comfortable enough, I did decide to meet him (so no, I don't think some girls ghost you after you asked them out. Could it be the fact that you didn't talk/ ask about anything else?)

But generally, I prefer to have a bit of rapport/ common topics first before we agree to meet up. If not, it's really going to be a waste of yours and my time if we were to sit there just for a meal with a weird and awkward atmosphere. (and yes, I did meet a few Tinder guys eventually. The conversations somehow died after and no my replies didn't change. I mean the topics just ran out (guess I'm too awkward))

In my opinion (and my preference): I don't really like guys who are too buff. I prefer if they are lean instead, then again. I prefer boyish-looking men to very guyish-looking men because I go for cute rather than handsome. And cute is general and very broad, so good-looking is really subjective. As for social clout.... Maybe girls are just looking for guys who are sociable, I mean when guys are sociable, they are naturally easier to be friends with right? But don't some girls think that guys who have too big a social clout is bad as well? I mean for me I would tend to think that he would have a lot of friends to meet and he would be pretty busy (meaning less time for me and cause I would definitely hate it if I had to ask you to choose!) and not to mention a bigger social clout means more female friends (self-consciousness alert!)

TL;DR: don't just see from a guy's perspective. I mean well, the grass may be greener on the other side.. But how about widening your search? Like instead of just looking at girls who are that cup size/ height/ body shape/ etc basically widen your circle in terms of aesthetics. 
(Personally I do hate it if all guys started to date girls from other nationalities, cause I do prefer Singaporean guys because I think it's easier to communicate since you know Singlish. LOL. My English suck and my Chinese is worse. My best language is Singlish :( Then again, my personal preference is just for me, if you want to date girls from other countries, sure sure! Just don't miss the local girl who might be right in front of you.)

Hello! I have a few points regarding dating in Singapore.

As a reasonably social male student, I have hundreds of female friends, and many of them are attractive, have great characters, are intelligent, friendly and have good values. Would I be open to wooing or dating some of them? Yes, of course. That being said, i'm not sure if its because i'm conservative or have high standards, but out of all these friends, I would only have an immediate yes to one of them, the reason being that I like her.

Someone pointed out that all the details don't matter as long as you like someone, which I believe is true. Love is blind, and despite all my extremely eligible female friends, I am not attracted to them in that way and hence I am not immediately open to dating them. Conversely, I am not particularly fond of a girl who would date anybody, since that anybody could also be anyone but you. I would like a girl who knows what she wants and sets standards for herself.

I guess one moral of the story is that if you have found someone who likes you and whom you like, please cherish each other because love is not easy to find. Have a great week everyone!

Hello . Thanks for your suggestions on why I probably am still single. These are indeed possible reasons for why someone can still be single. They don't all apply to me completely, but I know that you're simply suggesting various reasons in general, so I don't have to explain myself.

I'm sorry to hear about your experience with the ladies at your previous workplace. I have also been with good-looking friends who get a lot of attention. You sound a bit bitter about it so I hope you won't hold this unhappiness as you go about your life.

The main point I want to bring up regarding your comment is that there might be more reasons why someone is single. (I'm not talking about myself, but in general. Some may apply to me.)
1, Social circle. A lot of my very nice single friends who are nice to people around them, just have no one they are interested in their social circle, and no one made a move on them. 
2, Expectations too high. You talked about expectations of looks. There can be other expectations that become barriers, e.g. personality, values, hobbies, beliefs. 
3, Lack of interest in relationships/marriage when younger. 
4, Conservative upbringing, which makes one feel like going on dates is a huge thing so the person tends to not be very open to dating.
5, Low self-confidence/no confidence of being able to get married. Lack of confidence makes you restrict your own socialising, and you don't dare take action when you like someone. Also, someone lacking in confidence is less attractive, from a psychological point of view. I think.
6, Personality when younger. I was from a girls' school and a lot of girls were quite non-feminine and sporty and rough, which was cool then. All single then. Hard to attract guys if the girls are too boyish. Some are still boyish and attached, some became attached after becoming a bit more ladylike. Maybe this is a reason too.
7. Luck. Sometimes you like a person but the person doesn't like you back. 

I have a small problem with you mentioning the overweight part. You kind of implied that someone overweight is unattractive and unpleasant (correct me if I'm wrong). I think attractiveness is a holistic thing - personality, looks, character also factor in attraction. I have found an overweight person attractive before because of his awesome personality and cute face haha. If someone's weight factors solely in determining the chances of being attached, then this is pretty shallow (just like your female coworkers) right?

All the best to everyone out there looking for a companion.

 It's nice to know that Singaporean girls like you exist. But there is something I wish to say that might or might not be applicable to your situation. You have mentioned that you're in your mid 20s and still looking. 

Assuming that you would do the things you have claimed you would do, there are some possible reasons why you might be single from a guy's pov. Number 1, you might have offended or turned off a lot of potential suitors through your actions when you ere young. It sounds quite silly listing this as number 1 but I know of many Singaporean girls who have behaved one way in their 20s and changed track the moment they realized they weren't getting the guy that they want. Some examples of this include being very condescending when you're young. Again, you might say you were young and immature but these things stick. 

I remembered going out for lunch with a very good looking guy friend for a couple of times when I was young and working some job. I was completely ignored by some of my female coworkers whom obviously showed how shallow they were. Would I give these girls a chance now that they are older, less desirable and I am much richer and successful now? Not a chance. No one wants to be second choice, period. 

Number 2, actions speak louder than words. I think it's very easy to say you will do A or B or C. If you truly would treat your partner that way then show it and be appreciative of the people in your life. The word will get out, and you will either be introduced or guys will want to get to know you better. Already in NUS whispers, you can see it for yourself, right? 

Number 3, looks and aesthetics. I don't think guys are looking for super models nor are we looking for super pretty girls for wives. Just look pleasant and take care of your appearances. If you're overweight, lose weight. This will bolster your chances. 

That's it. My take, hope you aren't offended.

I've been through this, and dated someone 12 years older than me when I was 19 years old. It did not end well. I was evergreen, and somehow a guy who was funny, able to drive, with high purchasing power was really attractive to me. A little similar to you, I like to build walls and do not fall for people easily, and was surprised that I would like someone like him (physically not my type). I kept desiring to meet and see him, for some reason. 

I was very opposed to the idea of us getting together initially, and only wanted to treat him like a very close good friend. However, he kept bringing up the idea of us getting together, and kept convincing me, and somehow this age gap became more and more acceptable to me as time passed. We got together, and he kept pushing my physical boundaries (we had talks about this and I expressed my discomfort but he kept pushing). I still regret everything I've done with him and wished it did not happen. We were also very different people (the age gap meant that our childhood/friends/lives were very different, and we were at different stages of our lives - me entering uni, him working). Beyond our "liking" (unsure whether we really "liked" each other) for each other and lust (maybe just from him), I don't really think we had many common topics to talk about. Today we are no longer in contact and neither do I want to remain in contact.

Frankly I still don't know if he was just looking for a young girl to date (or easy prey) or he did take it seriously, but I'm in a happier position now. Perhaps your case is different from mine. Ultimately it is your choice, and I hope you wouldn't regret whatever decision you make.

So I helped her out with her applications, and even went through some interviewing tips etc.

Anyhow, this isn't meant to be about me. As I have said to my fellow Singaporean guys, go out and try dating other girls from other countries and do a cross comparison for yourself. Just be careful of posting it publicly on NUS whispers.. because hint hint, it's social suicide :)

This is a shout out to all the evergreen guys in NUS. I used to think it was me, and that maybe if I had a better personality, I would have been able to get a Singaporean girl as my gf. While I have gone on dates with some, it didn't lead to anywhere. I had more rejections than dates to be fair. However, after going on exchange, I realized that I was misled into thinking that being "unwanted" in Singapore means you're unwanted globally. Throughout my time in exchange, I was able to date girls from many nationalities, korean, taiwan etc. When I came back, it was back to the same old, same old. 

One thing I realized is that a good number of foreign girls are actually very open to date local men. They might even come from developing countries like Vietnam and Indon but that shouldn't be an issue if you truly like her. In my personal view, I hope I don't get flamed for this but.. I think that Singaporean girls tend to be pretty close minded. Unlike girls from many of the places I have travelled to, they would rarely if ever give chances to MOST guys for first dates. To them, it's akin to asking them to marry you, the whole "wanting to know you better" line doesn't fly here. It's how buff you are, how good looking you are, how much social clout you have. Don't believe all the tinder stories on dating.. They tend to be the exception rather than the rule. I thought I was having it bad.. but a lot of my single guy friends have confided in me that they were shot down pretty badly. And a lot of the time, it ends with the girl becoming a complete stranger, as though asking her out is some sin that you have committed.

To put a long story short, Singaporean guys who are still single, open your eyes, and be willing to date girls from other nationalities. You might really be surprised.

Reply to 
Ok. Here's the thing. I had really bad social anxiety just 1 year ago. I didn't dare to join any ccas cause I was afraid others would judge me for not being fit or strong enough, was afraid to eat alone, was afraid to be seen studying alone, I even trembled when I wanted to show my friends videos that I found funny; because I was scared that they would not find it funny. I was permanently looking for books like "how to win friends and influence people", "the charisma myth" etc etc, except that I would never have read it in public, for fear of being judged. I was afraid to go to the toilet during lectures for fear of interrupting others lr the lecturer.

Fast forward a year, I'm not afraid of anything now. I go to the gym alone, not afraid that other buff guys will judge me for being too skinny, lift too little etc. I can even have long conversations with complete strangers with ZERO anxiety (even if I don't particularly like it) I am not afraid to stand up for myself against the "alpha" or cool kids. I stopped comparing myself to others. I found my life purpose. And more.

You wanna know how I did it?
Hard work. Im in NS now, so every weekend when others were spending their time playing dota, watching anime or whatever shit, what I did was to tackle my social anxiety head on. Don't listen to the advice of others who don't know shit or hasn't gone through the stuff you are going through, or hasn't found a solution themselves. 

I spent hours outside, first, by asking strangers for directions, then asking them for the time, then slowly increasing the difficulty, to giving them compliments, to asking them how was their day. To giving them high fives. To doing jumping jacks in the middle of a mall. And more. And of course, this increased my social courage. I began to see people as potential friends, not people who'd judge me or demean my value. 

If you don't believe that such acts will increase your confidence and reduce social anxiety, check out youtube: ted talks: how to be more confident, lie down on the street for 30 seconds.

There's another thing I did. I am not going to post it here. All I am going to say is, you can read all the self help books in the world, which is what I did, and nothing in your life will change. If you are serious about handling this area of your life, I left my email address with the admin.
 
You can ask the admin for it and email me.

I would like to add on to  

Im a singaporean guy and most people regard me as nice and all, ive had alot of trouble dating singaporean girls in the past largely due to the kind of expectations they have. I feel that many singaporean girls have spolit expectations, but it really isnt their fault. Guys in general have spolit them for all of us. 

Maybe because of social media proliferation and stories of tinder and perhaps even feminism, singaporean girls expect certain traits of an ideal guy, eg, someone who plans big birthdays and anniversaries, perfect buff bodies, perceived as cool amongst our peers, spend alot on her etc, which they have gotten before! Because it is relatively easy to fake these things in the short term, especially during the courting phase. Which is why girls want to "chase" to never end, or say that their boyfriends "changed" once they gotten together, and start to be drawn to new guys who seem to be more their ideal again(new guys courting mode). These guys havent changed, they just became themselves again.

I never gotten around to pretend or meet these expectations, i chose to be myself when i date, it was not enough. I often ended up friendzoned or end up in a situation where the girl loses interest after awhile. I always thought it was me, something wrong with me, so i started being the "ideal guy", i drove my parents car to pick her up, spent hundreds on her birthday presents, did "cool stuff" like joining parties and basically did things i normally didnt do, i was a douche. It worked, it was easier to connect with girls with my new "status", i dated afew for awhile but i realised it was an unsustainable lifestyle, not so much about the cost but i hated not being myself. So i went back to doing so.

Everything changed when i went on exchange, it seems Singaporean guys are incredibly popular and demanded amongst foreign girls. They often say we are not Male Chauvinists, we are more considerate and more mature than the equivalent foreign guy counterparts. They also like the fact we undergone NS and work alot harder to "chase" girls too. I personally found it disturbing how other foreign guys treat women, if girls ever thought singaporean guys were oppressive, they should visit other countries, even the first world ones like japan, korea. It opened my mind to many things, i also realised these girls were very realistic and not living in a constant princess-like fantasy. They wanted to find a guy with an honest character, who was hard-working and shared certain interests. So was i.

Fast forward, I met my girlfriend there and we've been dating a couple of years now, shes applying for her EP here now and we hope to get married within 2-3 years.

I dont know if im right or completely wrong, but this has been my genuine experience. I dont think singaporean girls did anything wrong, i think that due to many factors, their expectations in general has risen alot quicker than guys can keep up with. But everyone has the right to set their own expectations.

My advice to fellow guys facing similar situations, keep your eyes open, there are many amazing girls around us even in NUS, those studying here from ASEAN, those here on exchange, and they too are looking for someone realistic and honest.

To  I write from the perspective of a currently single Singaporean girl in university. While I'm sure each girl has her own standards for choosing a boyfriend, I'm personally quite willing to go out on *first* dates with guys just to get a feel of our chemistry. As long as I feel like we could have a good time and I don't mind being seen in public with him, I don't see why I would reject someone just for the sake of it. Not sure if you're being too presumptuous by stating that local girls are close-minded, but I can only speak for myself. If a girl already does not feel comfortable with the thought of you, I think the rejection for a date may actually be a blessing in disguise considering that no one's time/money/emotion is further wasted. To be an advocate for your side, why would any self-respecting individual continually waste his time on a dead end cause? 

It sounds like you and your buddies have been having quite a tough time getting local girls, but maybe the fault really lies in not having enough magnetic compensation for whatever you lack and your misjudgments cloud you from picking the right league for your game. Take an objective look at yourself and try to see from the perspective of a potential girl you target. Your mentioning that girls want buff/ good-lookers/ influential may not be misguided, but it is also in line with how, in exchange, you may want a hot/ intelligent/ chef for a girl etc (fill in with your own criteria) Each for his own really; not every girl wants the same thing and any girl worth her salt will know that 'perfect' doesn't exist without imperfection in this world. 

I might get backlash for this but since you mentioned girls from developing countries, I would offer my two cents on that matter. I would go as far as to say that perhaps educated and pragmatic girls are changing the tide for guys, in the sense that they know what they want and will therefore demand more just because they are able to offer more to their partner. People with simpler mindsets usually want less and are easier to satisfy. Of course there will always be black sheep everywhere and girls who just want too much for the little contributions they give and vice versa, but I'm sure you would be able to judge for yourself in those circumstances and run from it. 

Like you mentioned, after a girl gives a rejection she might become a complete stranger - this could be that she thinks you're a creep and it's too weird/uncomfortable to continue being friends with the wonderful you. Unless you are able to give a sensible, mature reply to the rejection, it will be awkward to keep such a friendship going. Equally, it could be the case of immaturity on the guy's part. Some guys I know have brutally fragile huge egos, so little wonder why being rejected would lead to two people becoming strangers. I understand that some girls just don't know how to let a guy down easy (which is NOT easy by the way), but in the event they don't, you could take it as their loss and a nice summary of themselves for you as a last impression. You don't want a girl who can't appreciate effort. 

Take heart. I get that it's not easy being the chaser.
