-
 
I've been reading some confessions on 'racial preferences' when it comes to dating and I thought I'd share my opinion. I'm Chinese, an ex-NUS student and gay. I work in the military as a uniformed personnel and for the most part, at work, I'm closeted. I've to be for obvious reasons. For the last five years, I've been with a Malay boy. We live together now and like me, he works in public service. I met him on Grindr - an app gay guys use to meet other gay guys - and for the first week, we kept our conversation to within the app. When we finally met for a date, halfway through it, he asked, "You don't mind that I'm Malay?" I said no. I genuinely found him attractive. And he was smart and driven, and he spoke about his work with lower-income groups with great conviction and passion. I found that charming.

When it comes to my dating life, I happen to have physical preferences. I like lean fit boys. I like big eyes and sharp jaws. I like someone who's sporty and tall. Race, for me, was a non-issue although I must admit that I've been with more Chinese boys than Malay ones. He was the third Malay guy I've gone on a date with but the first I saw a future and a life with. For me, it's simple. As long as you fit my physical preferences and I think of you to be someone worth pursuing, I will make the chase and not beat around the bush with regards to my intentions. If I want to fuck someone, I will say so. If I want to be in a relationship with a guy, I will go to great lengths to woo him.

Over the years in our relationship, we've had some difficult conversations. One of these happened to revolve around the insecurity he had built over the years being Malay and gay. One night, while we were watching Bridget Jones after dinner at my place, he confessed something to me. He told me of his experience growing up Malay and gay. He said that he had this deep attraction for Chinese boys and for a long time, he wouldn't date anyone else but a Chinese. 

At the time, when I messaged him, he had only started seeing other non-Chinese boys and he thought I was a troll. That night at my place, I asked him, "Why? Why this preference?" He related to me the environment he grew up in. In school, he had more Chinese friends than Malay or Indian ones; naturally, over the years, his school crushes were always Chinese boys. He watched a lot of Taiwanese dramas - Meteor Garden happens to be his favourite (ewww) - and he had built this idea in his head that he would find a Chinese boy to settle with for the long-term. He grew up not liking what he saw in the mirror - his tanned skin which I happen to find really, really beautiful - and he felt it to be a limiting factor when it came to dating. He's dealt with a lot of rejection from Chinese guys who preferred other Chinese guys (and he realises as well that he had built an internal racism to his own and that he's been a jerk to other non-Chinese gay guys). For the most part, he dealt with those rejections well, but he quickens to add that at times, he felt his sense of worth and confidence ruined. 

When I talk to some of my Malay and Indian gay friends, they often say the same thing. I noticed they've 'yellow fever' as well. It's a real phenomena especially within the gay circle and it can have damaging effects on someone's psyche. I know it did on my partner. I had to remind him, especially during the first year, that I loved him for all that he was and will be. 

During NUS, I visited San Francisco to visit a friend over the term break. He's an American-born Chinese. I got to know him when he visited Singapore for a holiday. When I told him the issues my boyfriend faced, he said the same thing about himself except now, instead of 'yellow fever', he had a 'white fever'. As a teenager, he grew up attracted to White guys. He preferred dating White over a non-White (he refused to even date a Chinese guy). He told me about the profiles he saw on Grindr and Jackd that said, "No Asians. No Chinks. No blacks. No Indians." It did affect his confidence level when he was a teenager struggling to manoeuvre around the gay scene, but he's grown out of it. He doesn't feel affected anymore by those profiles because he knows exactly his worth. Last I saw on Facebook, he's with a Latino guy now and he seems happy. 

As for my partner, yes, he eventually found a cute Chinese boy - me! - to settle down with but this was unplanned for both of us. I didn't date him because he was Malay. I am with because I saw a future with him. I had a list of attributes that I wanted in a life partner. He doesn't satisfy all of it, but he's perfect for me. Great to have expectations, but expectations can sometimes limit possibilities and love can happen in the least likely scenario.

Personally, I think it's fine to have racial preferences when it comes to your life partner. It's a very individual thing. Cultural similarities do attract. And you should never dictate someone's choices when it comes to a life partner. What's not fine and racist is when your racial preferences are based solely on racial stereotypes you've of that person. If you like someone who's fair skinned, you'll also find attractive a fair-skinned Malay, Indian or Latino or whatever.

I've always believed in what Ellen Degeneres says. We've a short time in this world. Let's just be kind to one another. See from different perspectives; put yourself in different shoes; if you've done that i.e. really put effort into challenging your value system, and you still hold onto it, that's fine but do show empathy for someone who doesn't share your view. If you can't do that, then I guess... my advice for you would be to write a blog and remember to turn off the comment feature.

-
 
I have been on three dating apps over the past few months and even though I am still remains as an evergreen guy, I really learn a lot about online dating and will like to share it over here. Online dating is really not suitable for everyone unless you are really a guy who can catch the attention of a girl among the hundreds or thousands of guys that are vying for her attention. Secondly, most girls really don't look at looks (though they look more on your height and physique), they look mostly at a guy's personality and whether he can start and maintain a good and interesting conversation. If you ever find yourself stuck, it means both of you don't match. However, that does not mean your profile picture is not important. It tells a lot about your personality. Lastly, when you are on these sites, you have to accept the fact that the probability of finding your significant other over these sites are still very low (can go google on the statistics, btw there are a lot more guys than girls on these sites). Girls still prefer the traditional way of finding their significant others as it may not be very safe meeting someone online and it is hard to tell someone's true colour online. Having said that, guys, please dont feel so let down. Online dating is really more than just dating, you learn a lot more about yourself (and improve on yourself) and the opposite gender and I am still in the process of learning.

-
 
To  That is because the meaning in the term GG has evolved over the years in the era of online gaming... It was normally used as compliment or show appreciation at the end of games; but because it started to get so popularized, it started to also signify the end of a game - more often implying or predicting a coming lost rather than a win. So, when people describes something as GG, it describes a seemingly futuristic "end"/"lost case". This is the age of the internet we live in! :)

After years of regret, I decided to go for a dream of mine. I took what little money I had saved up and dedicated myself full time. One year later, I did not succeed. I dealt with a ton of rejection, self doubt and feelings of being utterly lost in life. But I fought through it and kept trying. I did not succeed on paper. I poured my heart and soul into something and felt absolutely devastated by failure. But I learned I'll be okay in life. And I'll find something else I can be passionate about. 

You don't need someone else's approval or some outside influence or opportunity to be happy. 

Be good to yourself, focus on what you can control and don't beat yourself up for things that you can't control.

To  I was in this exact (and I do mean exact) scenario a couple years ago, and it later transpired that they had physical dalliances behind my back. At first I chose to trust him since he told me nothing was going on; I was allowed to read their messages under his supervision; the other girl was attached anyway, but in this case it turned out that they were weaker than their desires. 

You've got every right to be in a relationship that you feel secure in, and if your boyfriend is not doing enough to settle your mind, you need to decide for yourself if this is a deal breaker and not prolong your misery. I personally want someone who chooses me over his friends (especially over those of the opposite sex. Duh, right?) If it has been going on for awhile and you've been tolerating it, I hope that you find the strength to change things for yourself. Give (him) enough warning and carry yourself with self-respect. It's not easy but leave if necessary and start over again with someone else who truly values your presence and not take advantage of your kindness. 

On another note, I wouldn't approach the other girl to get her to stop because any decent, self-respecting dude would be able to rise up to the occasion and deal with it appropriately. Extrapolating it a little further; if she wants him and he goes, she can have him. You don't want someone who doesn't know how to stay.

Maybe I am hardened from my particularly scarring incident but it's always a good reminder to keep your long term happiness in view. You don't want to be in a relationship that constantly acts like a heavy metal ball at your ankles, dragging you down from being happy.  I wish you well.

I just woke up from a nightmare. You were in it. 

It:
I was in one of the labs, doing my work, when it happens, that you, and some unnamed boyfriend entered the lab. I overheard your converstation, and your boyfriend left you to do your work. 

In a moment of foolishness, a moment of courage, I mustered all I could, and took the initiative to talk to you. "Hey, it's been a while." You replied, with a simple, "Hey," and went back to doing your work. 

"How have you been?" 

And the conversation went on with a short series of short replies. "Look, I see that you're busy, just wanted to apologise..."

And we started quarreling. I let everything out. 

I am very sorry, that initially, I pushed you to someone whom I thought, would be able to provide a better future, than if you're with me. I threw attitude problems, etc., and ended up, by alienating myself, you ended up with the person, who still broke up with you.

I am very sorry, that after that, I took the convenient excuse, to chase my grades that weren't there. I worked hard, but I never held anything in my hands. 

I AM SO SORRY, that while you were undergoing difficult times, I was never there for you, chasing something that was never there, when I could have been beside you, even as a friend.

I am sorry, yet again, that I simply cannot face you anymore. I cannot try to fake a smile if I ever talk to you again. I actively ignored you, even if you tried to say hi. I am so sorry. 

If anything, someone snatched my phone the other day, and messaged you, to apologise on my behalf, to clear a bit of load off me, at least, I think.

I again, took the convenient exit; I feel all these, but you do not know that. You don't see me around anymore, and very much less talk to me. You're living a better life already, I hope. I apologise for this, but you won't know.

I wish, that this nightmare was real, because if it was, I would be a lot happier, because at least, I am with you, little birder.

From,
A person who summitted a mountain, but never could get over people.

This is more directed to people who are engaged/married; how do you decide if your partner is as good as it gets and your search stops there?

I'm single and someone is hot on my heels because he's really enamoured by me. While he's not packaged into something I would have picked off the shelf (no, I'm not objectifying him, it's just a metaphor of speech), quality-wise he's everything I need and this is deeply troubling. Looks ARE important to me even if they aren't to someone else (think of the kids, think of the kids. Good-lookers do get an edge in life although I know smarts and bravery can triumph later on), and I want a partner who is roughly in the same category as I am. How much do people forgo looks in deciding if your potential partner has top notch qualities in compensation for the lack of looks?

it's really hard to find a good quality guy who has the same love ideals and overflowing chemistry with me but at the same time God giveth and taketh; as superficial as it sounds, I am postulating that should I get together with him, I may not feel as comfortable posting pictures of us on social media. This is NOT  for mere societal validation sake or anything, but a real personal preference to be someone who is closer to being an equal with me. I want to love the face I wake up to, as much as the next person would want to pick a guy whom she can sing duets with. Before people start hating on my fussiness regarding looks, please understand that this is a genuine concern for me and recognise that there are many types of preferences out there and we should not impose our own value judgements on one another. I know people grow old and ugly but while I still get to pick, I'm not sure if I'm keen on the constant negotiation and cognitive dissonance within myself to accept someone who did not arrive in somewhat acceptable terms. He is otherwise a 8.6/10 lover. 

Additionally, he has not fulfilled his earning potential and I'm wary about committing to someone based on potential (in any aspect) because I'm someone who needs to see concrete proof of effort and substance first. Potential is merely that and if it goes unfufilled, I would be really upset with myself. I can only make one choice this lifetime and I want to have no regrets. 

I know that people say pick someone who loves you more than you love him and I recognise the merits in that but I can't help feeling like maybe it could be that I'm addicted to the feeling of worship that he gives me? He treats me like a princess! I can learn to love the person I'm with, even though it would've been better if I liked him from the get-go. It seems like people are getting together with someone they can live with, but I'm just wondering how many people out there are together with someone they can't live without? Please let me know if you got lucky and are in the latter category! 

For me, that distinction makes a world of difference since I'm not someone who gets attached at the drop of a hat. I'm incredibly picky about the people I associate myself with and ain't nobody got time to get a heart broken or break hearts. Excited at the prospect of being able to choose a partner but it's really daunting business! Peace out and love to everyone x

-
 
 Hi there! Firstly, there are many orientation camps available, so don't limit your options! In FASS, Arts Camp and Arts OWeek are bigger scale. If you prefer something more "quiet", different majors in FASS also hold camps, some of which are smaller scale. These camps *might* not (depends on the major) involve loud cheering, social night or games with physical contact with the opposite gender, which might suit you better! 

I've attended many camps in NUS, and haven't seen any hazing or girls being taken advantage of. Perhaps these are rare incidents but received more attention In fact, during my social night, the guys in my OG constantly looked out for our safety :')

I'm not sure about special traditions, but Arts Camp and OWeek would involve things like cheering and social night. If you feel awkward cheering loudly, or feel uncomfortable reciting cheers with sexual connotations, you can always choose not to do so. Some people also skip social night because they don't like clubbing. Most seniors would be understanding and respect your decision. 

I think orientation camps are great for meeting new people, and you stand to gain so much if you get over the initial fear of awkwardness. On your part, this is a good time to get out of your comfort zone and meet new people. There will be many opportunities in life that you can enjoy if only you step out of your comfort zone, so why not start here?

Of course, this also depends on your luck. Some OGs remain close, some drift apart. I also have friends who are not close to their OG, but made a few close friends from camp. All you need is those few good friends to make your camp experience worthwhile. Friends don't fall from the sky, and it takes a bit of initial effort to get to know new people. 

From orientation camps, I have made friends who were there for me during difficult times, and also met seniors who were incredibly helpful especially when I was a confused freshie. Of course, many people end up as acquaintances, but that is what happens in life and should not be a reason to deter you from meeting new people!

Hope you'll enjoy your life in NUS! :)

I backtrack her posts and realize that 5 years after we broke up she was still not over me. I took about the same time to try to get over her too. Sadly, due to the cut-throat and competitive nature of the industry, all of them end up driving NUS internal shuttle buses. :(((((((((((((

So the next time you feel like wallowing in self-pity, remember these poor souls and be grateful. #deepthoughts #boulevardofbrokendreams #yolo

Hi, I am someone who regularly unfriend people on Facebook, insta and other social media etc. 

I unfriend people because they are probably people who i don't really know, only met ONCE through camps (tricky~) or other events. (might have advantage in networking, up to your discretion)

& i don't see any harm in doing it. Because firstly, i feel weird looking at feeds of people who i only saw once.
Secondly, i will feel weird FOR the people who i only met once. looking at MY feeds (through just timeline, not because stalking). 
Thirdly, you wonder if people who you don't really know are just kaypohs.

Now i learnt my lesson, never give my social media accounts that easily for such situation that i have to unfriend them for privacy sake.

& For those who get unfriended... Don't think too much. I do get unfriended too. But really, you only need to focus on people who mean to you. (which you don't even need the use of social media to interact anyway) Take those who unfriended you as people who you don't need in your life.

Xx

-
 
response to 
I think there is a misconception of an evergreen girl. Although an evergreen girl has not officially dated, it does not mean that they have not been asked out before. Some evergreen girls receive lots of requests to date officially but reject the guy as they feel that he is just not the one. Thus, they might not necessarily feel flattered etc. One shouldn't be in a relationship just for the sake of being in a relationship - it has to be the right person. In fact, if they want to remain as friends, it might be quite a burden. Just hanging out together means that they really like your company and probably that you guys can communicate. My best advice to protect yourself from emotional hurt would be to make sure the girl has some degree of romantic feelings towards you as well.

He is special: definitely not the best looking, but he is nice, he is very helpful, he treats me well and talks to me like a friend I have known forever even though we have only known each other for less than half the year. In these late nights I find myself feeling extremely lonely and wishing that I never ran away, because I still feel so strongly. They say you never forget your first love. -
 
 You've said something I've been saying and want to say now. Effective communication. Maybe you know who I am in real life. Maybe. After all, what's in front of me is only a screen.

Here's how I think the text kills:
1) Face-to-face interaction (FTF): There's a face attached to the conversation.
Text: In the worst case scenarios, there isn't, but in some, there is.
Note: You want to know who you're talking to and not have to guess although you may get it 9/10 times right. Unless you are wanting to talk to a random stranger. Things don't get pretty even if that's 1/10 time when you don't be skeptical and commit to the person's identity together with what he or she has said.

2) FTF: There's speech, and with that comes tone
Text: There's no speech, no tone, but only words.
Note: Tone plays a very important part in conversations. Someone with the same words can have a straight face, be smiling, or be angry. Tone helps us understand the other party's mood, and hence, their attitude towards us. Their attitude towards us helps us understand the intention behind their words and the meaning of those words. What do you get from text? The best you get is emojis and maybe a few gifs, and I think we all know not to trust those. To be sure, people fake their tones in FTF interactions as well, but those are less common and you get to cross-check with other cues being presented. Also, words help us to read mood as well, but in this aspect, FTF interaction is way better than texts where correct words are less readily chosen (keep one's sensitivity constant).

3) FTF: There's body language, including facial expressions.
Text: There isn't body language.
Note: The cues we get from body language is somewhat different from tones but they ultimately help us comprehend the meaning behind those words. It's one of those factors that help you cross-check with the information you get from tones of speech. Not just that, but the actions themselves convey meaning. Again, they're all subjected to misinterpretation and false signals. But even if you are talking to a well-trained evil doer and you are extremely bad at picking up cues from body language, I'm sure FTF interactions do better than texts (no body language), most of the time anyway.

4) FTF: Instantaneous.
Text: Not instantaneous.
Note: Texts are not instantaneous, although the technology might be. That's why you have people, me included, who reply at a later time. Some because they are busy or because they want to spend more time with a better crafted message, or for some other reasons. And there's nothing wrong with the latter, just as some people prefer to make sure that their words are appropriate in the context they're in before they speak. But what happens in the interval for the party waiting to receive a reply? Thoughts start to wonder (constantly check your phone for new messages is a sign), and that's bad if you commit to your thoughts. This is detrimental in several ways, especially emotionally. I've been there. That's just one aspect of spontaneity. I think most people find that overall, texting is extremely tiring or at least more tiring than just talking, and needless to say, things get worse for texts. How many people actually prefer sending and reading huge chunk of texts? Another pro of spontaneity is that everything gets cleared up on the spot. Anything that you don't understand about what the other party is saying or has said, or events that are occurring or has occurred gets clarified readily. More understanding and less "unnecessary" thoughts, and whatever that leads after.

With technology, there are always better alternatives than texts, than the worst kind of texts, besides FTF interactions. There may be various reasons especially in our hectic life that we have to do less with FTF interactions, but my thoughts are that, always try to get the best form of communication. This applies regardless of whether or not there's a conflict. Worse yet is when there isn't a clear understanding of what kind of person the other party is and all the cons of texts that has been mentioned above gets amplified.

That's what I can come up with for now. Maybe there's a better guide out there online and if that's the case, sorry for wasting your time. Maybe readers just think I'm an a**hole but that's not important now. Thanks for reading this and best wishes to everyone.
-

Or, you could stop trying. You could let yourself be persuaded instead.

On the surface, the book How to Win Friends And Influence People and How to Stop Worrying and Start Living doesn’t seems to give relationship advise but on a deeper look, it does.

Here are some relationship advises you can learn from the book How to Win Friends And Influence People
1) Arouse in the other person an eager want. Instead of thinking about getting a good girlfriend, why not, think about giving the girl a good boyfriend instead?
2) Let the other person feel the idea is his or hers. Instead of confessing directly to a girl and hope that she will accept you, why not, let her be attracted to you first and make her think that he gained a boyfriend.
3) Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view. Think about it. If you are a girl, would you give your number to some random boy?
4) Make the other person happy about doing what you suggest. Similar to point 2

Here are some advises from How to Stop Worrying And Start Living
5) Use the law of averages to outlaw your worries. So what if you crush rejected you? There are many people you can potentially fall in love with. If this isn’t true, you wouldn’t have a crush on anyone else except your first crush.
6) Cooperate with the Inevitable. What is the first thing you should do after a breakup? Accept it. Acceptance is the key to recovery from losses.
7) Expect ingratitude. Instead of complaining that girls don’t like nice guy, why not, do nice thing for girls unconditionally and expect ingratitude.
8) Count your blessings, not your troubles. Instead of complaining about the flaws your girlfriend has, why not, think about what make you like her in the first place?

1) Q: Are you superficial?
   A: Yes

2) Q: Have you had any suitors?
   A: Yes. Great personality, fun to be with, hardworking person, but i can't accept them because i am just now physically attracted to them

3) Q: So you only go for good looking people?
  A: No. They can be good looking but that doesn't mean i like them in that way.

4) Q: If your suitor is good looking, even if there was no feelings initially, will you give the person a chance?
  A: Yes, most likely. But that is just to try it out initially to see whether both of us have chemistry. Because since i am physically attracted to them and the looks factor don't bother me, they pass the first stage for us to date and progress further if possible.

5) Q: Have anyone that isn't that attractive caught your attention because of their personality?
  A: Yes. Some of them are really confident that made me feel that their personality outweighs their looks. 

6) Q: Didn't you say that if the person is not attractive, usually you won't give them chance?
  A: It varies from one person to another. Someone might find them ideal but not me. But in my opinion, if i really , just really, doesn't find him physically attractive enough, i am guilty of casting him aside as potential partner regardless of how great his personality is , or how hard he tried. It is just how my heart feels.

 This is general given that you didn't provide specific details. If you can manage on your own, then that's fine. If you can't, you simply can't. You can't change that fact now. Don't push it. Know when it's time to seek help, and everyone needs help from others from time to time, even the strongest or smartest people.

1 - If you can't help yourself, simply seek proper help. What is to be considered proper help might not be the best help you can really get, but you have no choice but to make do. Find friends? Talk to your professor? Seek a counsellor?
2 - Know that help from others is limited, especially when you don't cooperate, don't help yourself, or the like.
3 - Reflect and work on being able to handle similar situations better in the future.

Hi,

Just wondering why do friends slowly distance from u even though there haven't any arguments etc.. It's just like slowly lost contact with each other. I understand relationship works in both ways, perhaps it is my fault, but I just could not figure out what happened. 

I have decided to share my story here and hope others could help me figure out or give advice to my issue. Sorry, my story might be a little lengthy.

"So....I went for an overseas school trip. I went for this programme alone as none of my friends got into this programme. I guess I am an Ambivert girl, I tend to be shy and awkward with people at first but when I get comfortable with them, I will be talkative. I decided to go for this trip despite having no friends along as I feel it may be a good platform to boost my social skills, making new friends etc and also to gain the experience. 

It was a small group for this overseas programme. As there are seven girls, I had two roommates. Let's name them Roomie A & Roomie B. The three of us got along pretty well. However during the trip, there are a few incidents which I felt the other girls do not really like one of my roommates, Roomie A. I remained neutral as I do not like taking sides. Slowly, I felt that Roomie B does not like this Roomie A too. She would be hanging out more often with the other four girls instead of us (me & Roomie A ). Roomie A told me she knew that Roomie B has a WhatsApp group with the other girls but did not include her in.. which it kinda made her feel left out or something? (*I did not have WhatsApp then). There are times that Roomie A told me she can feel Roomie B are like distancing from us, and she also felt that the other girls do not like her. (*Ps just for info: The other four girls were already friends before this trip.)
I decided to stick with Roomie A more as I understand that being ostracised is not a good feeling. Roomie B and the other girls still get along with us well, it is just that sometimes they tend to hang out together, leaving me and roomie A alone. I guess the guys might be able to sense about this situation but they remained neutral. On the surface, everyone seems to get along well. I enjoyed myself during this trip, and I felt everyone (esp the other girls) are fine with me.

When we returned back to Singapore, as I did not have Whatsapp then, I felt I have missed out in some ways. However, it did not really bother me then as I felt that as long Roomie A and I are keeping in contact, I'm fine. Slowly I realised that Roomie A is actually quite close with some of the guys in the trip. She has been keeping contact with them. I did not really talked to the guys as I am pretty shy and awkward with guys... I guess I am more comfortable with being friends with girls?
Roomie A and I still kept in contact for quite a while. I did not really kept in touch with the other girls including Roomie B because partly I felt they are kinda obvious in not wanting Roomie A to "join" them (hence, unknowingly I guess I kinda choose to be with Roomie A. And thus, perhaps the other girls sort of treated me and her the same?). "

Ok to sum up. One day, Roomie A and I met up for some school event. While casually chatting, She told me that she went out with the few guys (our trip mates). I was quite surprised because I did not know about it and she did not ask me along etc. I understand perhaps maybe it was some impromptu outing... but the fact that  Roomie A did not even ask me if I wanna join them along makes me felt left out. At that moment, I can't help but felt a little "betrayed" (in a way). I mean, usually for girls, she will ask you to join her along especially if she is going out with a group of guys alone for the first time? (that's what I think for most girls...Sorry if I'm wrong).
Slowly, Roomie A and I distanced. However, I know Roomie A is still close with the guys and they are still keeping in touch. 

To end off, I felt a little upset that Roomie A chose to be close with the guys and neglected me once she is close with them. Perhaps she is those girls who prefer to mix around with guys, but the fact that she did not once asked me along to join them.. kinda convey a meaning to me. At times, I do have a thought that... "what if during the trip I have been closer with the other girls instead of Roomie A? Perhaps I would have gained true friends instead." 
I understand it is not right to think it that way but I couldn't help it. Through this incident, I feel that sometimes being a neutral person doesn't always seems to be a good thing. Or perhaps the problem lies with me? Maybe it is the way how I deal things.

Sorry for the lengthy post. Thanks for reading it.

-
 
 Here's my understanding of people like you since I'm one myself.

Short version:
They don't get angry over small stuffs and they do have a high tolerance level. But sadly, there are instances where people can really push you pass the edge. At this point of time, there's definitely explosion but I would think the manner of explosion varies from individual to individual. Perhaps some would vent it out through screaming, abusing a punching bag or walls, or worst come to worst, start getting violent on the opposite party (really not a pushover kind).

Long version (w/ advice):
Stage 1: Either things are too petty for your concern or you're simply upset. In the latter case, things don't call for much concern and you're only pissed at that moment. Hold it in and you'll be fine the next day. I would think that's a sign of maturity so that's good.
Stage 2: People are starting to get on your nerves but well, you're already past stage 1 and it's best to settle things before any escalation. I would think here's the dilemma you mentioned where you don't want to ignite conflict (still want to maintain as friends, acquaintance, or you still need to look at the person's face from time to time), and the truth is that you still can tolerate. The right way to go here would definitely be to send signals. You definitely want them to be effective. The issue now is how many signals and how strong of a signal you want to send, and how you want to send that signal, either now or in the future. It really varies from here on and depends on the parties involved including yourself. You just need know that you can't possibly send no signal or full signal.
Stage 3: You are at the brim and either your signals were ineffective or that the other party/parties has/have serious issues, or both. But to reach to this point with your high threshold level, no matter how bad your signals were, (to put it in a very nice way) the problem has to lie elsewhere. It's best to stay away from the other party/parties less you explode. If it's not obvious, that's not good because at that stage, you can't control yourself and there's no return. You don't want to do anything reckless.
Stage 4: Things are beyond your control and you explode. Remember to clean up the mess and hopefully things aren't serious.

Few more things to note: For such people, best try to settle things at stage 1 and 2, and that should be easy considering your tolerance. There are many ways not mentioned here to do that and perhaps even prevent stage 1. Also if you're willing, you can always severe the ties at any stage and the problem is solved. But that also means that the other party/parties is/are to a certain extent not important to you. Also, as in all human relationships, there's bias. So some really do get special privileges and stay longer at each stage.

In the midst of midterm revision and there's something weighing on my mind. 
What is the best way to resolve conflicts? I often try to tell myself that it is pretty useless to have a huge reaction over things that don't go your way, since 5 or 10 years down the road they probably wouldn't matter. And hence, whenever something upsets me, I try to play down my displeasure and tell myself "it's okay". This is especially so when it's someone you love saying something/doing something that resulted in that displeasure, and because you love that person, you tell them "it's fine" and just let it go. But sometimes, you start to wonder if letting it go too frequently makes you seem like someone who is okay with anything, and you become a pushover. And sometimes you actually do feel hurt but you just don't want to say you're hurt because you think this conflict won't matter 5 years later... Maybe it's healthier to just say you're hurt? But you don't want to ignite conflict...
Ah. So conflicted.

So I've only ever been in a relationship once that lasted for three years until the end of the first year of army. Since then, I've never committed myself again to asking girls out because I felt there was too much energy and time involved. I couldn't do the whole emotional rollercoaster and the ignoring you for days bullshit again. (I lost my ex to hall activities that took up her weekends which was the only time I was out of camp) I decided for myself that single life was better off and I remained cold emotionally for a long time. 

Until only recently, I met this girl who was able to stir my heart once more. Although we don't get to see each other much because of different timetables, I was really happy whenever she was around. Eventually I asked her out once. She was willing and very spontaneous. We sat for dinner and talked for about 4 hours straight before we left the place. She even said she'd like to take me out to dinner around the time of my birthday. I was over the moon. 

So about a week or so later, I asked if she wanted to catch a movie w me again, this time she said no. I wasn't sure if it was because of the movie choice or if she just wasn't interested and just wanted to stay as friends. I also get that she's a busy person. Usually I would text and reply within 10 mins of her messages. She on the other hand would take hours or even a whole day to reply. I don't really mind it at all, but sometimes I would just stare at my whatsapp chat with her especially when she's online, hoping that it'll suddenly go "typing..". 

Perhaps I'm thinking too much about it but nonetheless I'm still hopeful. There are so many things that I like about her and I hope she'll give me a chance to prove myself. Oh and if she's reading this, try not to sleep too late past 2. She has a really bad sleeping habit. 

Sorry for the long post and best of luck to those with the remaining mid terms! :)

-
 
 Well, have you tried doing something nice for a lady? It is not as simple as it seems.

If you're sincere enough, though, you will be sensitive enough to consider others' feelings towards your actions.

If you're doing something "nice" and you mind it, take note of it, you're actually expecting something out of it. Isn't that a bit paradoxical?

Of course, more often than not, people do things with strings attached, but that does not necessarily mean that he/she is not a nice person. 

A lady can just flat out refuse the invitation, and the guy's (see how he handles it) just trying his luck. Nothing wrong with that, but you really cannot generalise such scenarios.

Many of us have done nice things for others, and people, in general, are actually very nice, if you know them better, instead of judging them and focusing on their character flaws from the sidelines.

Then again, there are people going around with that "I am a nice guy" attitude.

Very common, nothing wrong with that, but do you know the difference, between "aiya, ok one lah~", and "I sacrifice my effort for this, I am doing something nice, I am a nice guy, 我是好人"?

If you're a nice person, the first and foremost thing, that you must know, admit and accept, is that you're quite far away from being the nicest person on earth.

Whenever a boy says that girl is so pretty, others will say she already have a boyfriend.

Having a boyfriend and being pretty isn't mutually exclusive. In fact, it is usually in union

People assume that a guy like a girl just because he think he is pretty. This shows that male are superficial creature and can like a girl just because he find her pretty. This make sense because according to the YouTube video Why Sexy is Sexy, beauty is a language that convey health and fertility. It is a male's instinct to find a fertile woman to give birth to alot of offspring to  ensure the survival of homo sapien. 

Man cannot be friend with the woman he find attractive. Most people just assumed the guy wanted to be that girl's boyfriend instead of just friend. 
-
 
If you want to do nice thing for a girl, do it unconditionally.

First of all, if you do "nice" thing for a girl with an agenda, you are actually a bad person. Imagine that you are a girl and is asking for donation when a guy walks up to you and offers to donate $10 on a condition. You have to give her your number, watch movie with him and date him, do you think the guy is a nice guy?

He is not a nice guy. He is emotionally black mailing the girl and expect the girl to prostitute herself over just $10.

Secondly, human tend to take kind act for grant. Don't be surprised if she doesn't remember your kind act.

How do you know if you are a "nice" guy or a good person?

Ask yourself these 2 questions
1) For those nice thing you are doing to a girl, would you do the same for a male friend you know for the same period of time?
2) Would you still do those nice act even if she doesn't remember it?

-
 
 First of all, please don't say such things or take such words lightly, especially to the guy on the other side, whether or not he is your date/partner or otherwise. It's extremely hurtful and some words and actions once said or done, cannot be taken back. What I'm about to say doesn't represent the views of all guys nor am I intending to offend any girls. I'm not generalising either.

Personally, I dare say that I do such things unconditionally but even if the guy has an agenda other than wanting you to be happy, please don't expect us to treat you girls unconditionally, because frankly, we don't owe you girls that. It's the same the other way around. We don't expect you girls to date us given that we've asked you girls out or have done some nice things for you girls. If you are concerned about sincerity, you can observe that for yourself. Ask yourself if he really likes you, if you're really worth $10 to him, if he really expects you to prostitute yourself whatever that means. Regardless, what I've said still stands.

Here's the complication. It's a whole different story altogether if the girl has agreed to turn up but has intentionally disappeared with an excuse or otherwise, is late on purpose, or misleads the other party into thinking she is going to turn up but doesn't. Things are seriously wrong here on many levels. I've experienced this several times and whether or not that's who you are, please don't take it personally. Using your donation example, it's as if the girl has lied or has intentionally misled the guy into thinking that if he donates $10, she will give him her number, watch movie with him and date him, but when he donates, all of which don't occur. To worsen things, the girl may say that she doesn't owe him anything, or that he has only himself to blame for being so gullible, or that he ought to treat the girl unconditionally. If things are still not obviously wrong, try switching gender roles. Respect is key here and things are not wrong only on this level. Think about it.

In the current context, you've defined a "nice" guy or good person as one who would:
1) For those nice thing you are doing to a girl, would you do the same for a male friend you know for the same period of time?
2) Would you still do those nice act even if she doesn't remember it?
With respect to 1), when guys value each other, it's more of being loyal, helpful, sticking their guts out for one another and so on. And you can't define a "nice" guy or a good person that way. Even if there's a common measure, just because someone treats their romantic interest "better" than his bros (same known time or equal strength in bonds), that doesn't mean he's not a "nice" guy or a good person. Same applies in reverse. A person can be a "nice" guy or a good person but just value them differently. With respect to 2), it really depends. I would think most "nice" guys or good persons you have in mind would still do it as the girl would still be happier for that moment. But some guys may simply be more practical yet at the same time sincere. I don't see how he's not a "nice" guy or a good person in which case, and especially so if the girl is also practical and considerate, and doesn't want the guy to "waste" money.

I'm not happy being single. 

But then again I'm too scared and scarred to contemplate about what direction I want to go in for a future relationship with anyone. No, scratch that. After my last disastrous breakup my whole life was irrevocably scarred. Try being an ISFJ type with life plans five to ten years into the future, and you really thought you found the right person and finally for once things are working out. And then get screwed over in a breakup so bad nobody has the right words to console you, and six months on now when someone asks you "what do you want to do in the future?" you can't even bloody answer the question anymore with any degree of self-confidence. It feels like someone yanked the rug out from under you and you're falling into an abyss with your whole world crumbling around you. And you're still falling and you don't know where the bottom is in sight.

I'm still me. But there is only so much scarring one can take, before he just simply gives up trying because like you said, dating time and time again is like insanity doing the same things over and over expecting different results. I might feel like deluding myself into having hope, that "I'm just growing up and finding myself again/the right person is still out there/good things come to those who wait". But at the end of the night, the only question I can ask of myself is "how can I even believe that there's someone out there for me whom I've never met yet?"

No reason is good enough to justify being single. And there's nothing more scary than being stuck in the middle, unable to consider a future relationship but loathing the feeling of singlehood emptiness when everyone around me is just running off getting hooked up every single goddamn night.

Of shy girls, locked doors, close friends...

I'm generally a shy person. I like someone but I think I am giving him mixed signals. As someone shy, I do not express myself readily to him. This will change if I know that he likes me too. I can't speak for every shy girl out there, but I tend to take things slowly. But I am in it for the long run. Why rush things? If he cannot be patient for a few weeks or months (I would like to get to know him better before jumping into anything), then we are probably not suited for each other. What's a few weeks/months compared to years ahead? As for meet-ups, as another confessor said, I will try to free up my time for him. When I say I am not free, I am really really not free. People interact differently. Some people enjoy writing as a means of expression. Others enjoy talking face to face. Given a chance, I would love to see him all the time. That's if and only if we are together. 

To you: if you are reading this and you think this is for you, I really really want to hug you. That is all there is.

-
 
Hi again, I am the OP of . Thanks for sharing your thoughts on the part pertaining to friends raking up the past. I understand where all of you are coming from, but I also feel that it differs from person to person, friendship to friendship.

I get that people who bring up the past aren't necessarily the people with small hearts (paiseh paiseh - I was too quick to generalise!), but like what one commenter mentioned, it is unhealthy when done repeatedly... Especially if the other party comes across as self-righteous and even starts comparing you (the 'best friend', in her words) with other friends, I don't think anyone would feel good yup? At first I thought it was the wine hahahaha I actually asked if my 'friend' was drunk but nope she was sober as hell, so.... Haha. And the convo went on for about three hours or so at the restaurant and the atmosphere turned rather tense because she was basically pointing out all my faults one by one and telling me that I shouldn't do this, shouldn't do that, so again... The waiters were looking at us because the other party looked like she was lecturing me... Yup. While I got really stressed, she actually felt so much better sharing everything. And the reason why she did that was because she was looking through Sec school photos on FB and she remembered everything?! Sigh. I do actually talk about issues from the past with other close friends, but I think that the tone matters a lot. Also, if all is well in the present, I tend to live and let live BUT if issues arise I try to address them as quickly as possible with tact. Not to keep quiet then drag on. And when to bring up the past, is important too. Not during a 'relaxing' dinner and then going on for a few hours haha right? 

While hearing her out I started to remember the tension in the early stages of our friendship but chose to filter a lot of it because the tension was already stressful and people were staring at us. I am not trying to justify myself but only stressing that friendship really is a two-way street. You need to be aware of yourself and your actions, and others' emotions. So sensitivity and self-awareness is crucial really. You can't possibly make me listen to you all the time when you have issues and call me out on what happened almost ten years ago in a restaurant. I am not a confrontational person so it took me aback and really made me pull away from the friendship. Spoke to my bf, older cousins and parents about it and they felt that while I was at the wrong for being immature and causing hurt in the past (girl clique issues), what she did was overboard... Anyway I was too tired emotionally after that. I was drained, 'squeezed dry' (so so sorry but don't know what metaphor (symbol????) to use) Plus, according to her comparison, she had other friends who were more "patient" and easy to talk to, so I just let it be. I Guess the hurt was too much, after all that I had done as a "best friend". So I decided to let it go. 

So I think that these opinions are specific to each friendship but in any case, whatever you do, do it in moderation and with tact. Yup. Anyway thanks for all your comments, I appreciate them. I will also share them with my younger cuzzies - it is good for them to have more perspectives on such issues. ^^

To the "evergreen" girls who were kept awake at night thinking: I have not dated anyone in my life etc ... Is there something wrong with me? Let me say this: if I were to ever write a dating guide for guys, I can't. Because women are so complex that there's no sequence of actions that can definitely hit all the button for any woman. 

But if I were to write a dating guide for girls, it would be one sentence. And one asterisk. It goes something like: "If you are a girl, or even just an effiminate guy, somewhere out there, there is a straight guy* who will f*ck (or date) you".

*quality is non-homogenous and might vary.

A bit more detailed though, so many guys are so desperate that all it takes is a bit of hint for him to jump all over you. Now typically they are not very attractive; not in the alpha male kind of way: the muscular, toned, talkative, confident, funny, humorous, etc ... If you do get in to a relationship, they might even appear to be clingly; which is not attractive as well. Also, men are generally stupid and they don't get the subtle clues and hints to women behaviour. The aforementioned alpha types read these very well and they enjoy it thusly.

Dear NUSWhisperers,

I noticed recently that some of us have difficulty feeling up to things or just being happy. And as someone who came close to depression but is feeling much better now, I would like to share some practical tips to improve your life - these worked for me and I hope that they will work for you.

1. Jump out of bed, open your windows and curtains 
Getting up quickly in the morning makes you less lethargic and miserable for the rest of the day. I find that experiencing fresh air and sunlight in the morning gives me energy.

2. Exercise
It doesn't have to be a daily 5km run. Doing simple stretching exercises, chest stretches, pushups or even jumping jacks wakes me up and helps me prepare mentally for the day ahead. I find that steps 1 and 2 have improved my daily mood significantly, and I think my friends and family have noticed the difference.

3. Get out of the house/hall/residence
Home is where you are conditioned to rest and your mind to wander, and introverts may know that sometimes your thoughts are self-destructive or self-consuming. So go ANYWHERE outside, to school to study, go shopping, or just walk in the park. Spend as much time outside as possible so that you appreciate your home and come back to rest.

4. Find supportive friends
If you observe very carefully, some of your friends are more genuine than others. Find those that truly care about you, rather than "fair-weathered" or "fun" friends. If you need to get work done, find friends who are driven so that you guys can help and motivate each other. Finally, for those with relationship woes,

5. Spend more time on yourself
I used to be one of those people who preoccupied my time and thoughts about the person I liked, in hindsight, it wasn't a good experience. Now that the infatuation phase is over, I can now speak to her normally and have a genuine interest in her before deciding whether to make a move or not.

The saying goes, "spend so much time improving youself that you have no time to criticise others". Instead of changing yourself so others will like you, I suggest taking time to explore the real you and working towards improving yourself. Have the confidence that someone amazing will be drawn to that, and seize the opportunity when it comes.

Have a great week!! :)
-
 
At this age (I am approaching my mid-twenties), I have started to invest less in friendships, i.e. I tend to be less emotionally invested nowadays. Not saying that I advocate insincerity, but perhaps more discretion when it comes to determining who stays in one's social circle of trustworthy and dependable friends. And in some cases, the duration which you have known someone does not matter. Someone you have known for a twelve years may turn out to be a friendship vampire/frenemy while another person whom you have known for three years may actually be a kindred spirit. So keep an open heart yup and be rational. It's quite contradictory  but I don't know how to better describe it. 

I have had bad experiences in the past where close friends treated me like a venting outlet, going on and on their problems whenever we met up. Usually such things went on for hours at a time. And they would go on and on about the same issues quite unapologetically like a broken record. I was unaffected at first, thinking that it was my responsibility to lend a listening ear but over an extended period of time, I found myself drained and weary while the other party felt better after each 'conversation'. I felt like a sponge sopping up all the negative energy in their life and those 'friendship vampires' were taking up my time and energy which I could have set aside for more productive endeavours so to speak... Even when I needed a listening ear, the conversation would somehow end up about them -- yes they did hear me out and gave me advice and stuff, but it seemed as though their issues always took precedence and had to be dealt with first. In the end I really couldn't take it any longer and decided to distance myself away from them. We are all still on good terms but I have put them on the back-burner. They are no longer the people I would think of first when I want to hang out with friends. 

I have far fewer friends now but at least I do not have that negativity in my life and I have more time for the people who truly care for me (my family and relatives, my bf and a couple of close friends). I find myself more positive too, and a reason why I have more time is because I do not have to deal with their texts any longer. Their rants used to continue on WA even after our meet-ups for hours straight and I would have to respond to them lest they question me and I end up feeling guilty for doing otherwise. I actually prefer having acquaintances now because it is just so much easier to handle how much you invest in the relationship. There is more freedom in how much you wanna divulge and keep to yourself. Those 'friends' of mine expected me to share details of my personal life with them because 'we [had] known each other for so long' and they would make me feel guilty for not keeping them updated. Even when I got to know my Bf, they expected me to fill them in with all the details. And they probed when I refused and induced guilt in me. So. I could have handled it more firmly but I didn't have the maturity back then. In retrospect I should have been more outspoken but now I know better. 

Yeah I know this post is pretty circular but hopefully it provides some kind of relatability for the people out there who are experiencing the same thing? Adulthood is a very transitionary period of our lives and many things change, including our relationships with friends. People who used to be 'best friends' realise that they are actually drifting apart (and sometimes for the better really) and acquaintances start to establish strong friendship bonds. And to be honest.... I honestly don't think that there is a need to verbally state who are your 'best friends' -- I mean, we are adults and most of the time, we just know, by intuition, and the thing is, usually the other party gets it too. If there is a need to verbally reaffirm your status, then perhaps there are issues to be dealt with, issues which have been overlooked for a long time. But please - don't 旧事重提(bring up old issues from the past - sometimes it is the breaking point of a friendship. Bringing up bad things which happened NINE years ago in SEC 3 (?!?!?!) when we were immature and impulsive in the midst of a dinner with good food and wine on a weekend isn't exactly the best way to 'clarify' things with your friends-- not even to your 'best friend'!!! (Ehhh.... Best Friend doesn't mean you can just shoot your mouth like that right hahaha) To me it just shows how much that person harbours grudges (记仇) and it really pisses off the other party. It really dampens the mood so even if you MUST do it, do it with discretion and gentleness? Perhaps you could share your thoughts here :)

Hmmm lastly, these issues are inevitable so take it easy yup? We grow up, our personalities change and so do our friends. A few younger cousins shared with me their friendship woes last weekend so I thought I should share my experiences just in case some people are struggling win similar issues. It may be difficult for a while but honestly, it works out well in the end as Long as you treat people the way you want to be treated. :) jiayou everyone!! :D

Does anyone else occasionally realize that they have been so selfish and self-centered their entire life? 

When you realize that almost all our time is spent thinking about ourselves - obsessing over a stupid interview mistake, replaying events in your head over and over again, having imaginary conversations with people where you argue and win, thinking about what others think of you, and thinking of ways to sound smart and of ideas to impress people.  

It is quite sickening when I realize how pointless and useless it all is. What good does all that selfish thoughts do? It is painful to acknowledge against the belief that I'm a caring and kind individual. Do normal people get over this? Is this why I have so few friends?

Well, to satisfy my curiosity and perhaps establish a baseline to compare (note my selfish intent here), how many seconds a day do you spend thinking about other people - friends, family or stranger? What do you think about for them? How much of what you do daily is done with the thought of others? 

As I wrote this, I remembered this saying from years ago " At 20, you care about what others think about you. When you're 40, you stopped caring about what others think. When you finally hit 60, you realize no one was thinking about you at all."

-
 
Four lessons for everyone. I was really clueless when it comes to relationships. A few years back, I met a guy who expressed interest in me. He was very kind, smart ... basically, he's your typical nice guy. He was a little odd, but I found his oddity a little cute and I was especially flattered when he admitted that he liked me. However, I was unsure if I really liked him as a person, or whether I am just reciprocating because I feel like I owed him a favour.

Over time, I discovered that he was really 'sticky'. In my view, we were only dating but he's moving too fast for my liking. It's his first relationship, so I guess that might have contributed to his behaviour. But he was just SO weird. My parents warned me not to hang out with him and told me that we have no future together. I was also ashamed of introducing him as my boyfriend. In fact, I often hesitated in saying that he was my boyfriend. We are, after all, merely dating (for three months!). So when he introduced himself to my friends as my 'boyfriend' and placed his arm around me, I felt very embarrassed (but I was too shy to correct him).

One thing led to another and we had sex. I didn't know what I was doing. I felt conflicted - I liked him but I was not sure that he was the one. He's terribly awkward, not exactly the best looking, and my parents/friends did not like him.

We dated for only 4 months before he had to go to Hull for further education. I thought it's a good time to end the relationship. I would rather choose my parents and my friends over someone I was not even sure I want to go on a long-term relationship with. It is also easier for me to end the relationship over long distance (bad mistake). Anyway, I decided to ignore him hoping that he would get the hint and move on.

Unfortunately, he did not get the hint and he messaged me persistently. In the end, I told him point blank that I want to break up with him (although technically in my view, it wasn't a break-up because we weren't together to begin with). My parents were delighted that I agreed to stop dating him. However, nobody expected him to fly back to Singapore to find me. I was very afraid of what he might do since he's a bit unpredictable, but since the breakup was my parents' idea, they helped me to shoo him off in a nice way.

I am glad I have him off my life, but I did feel very bad for some time. So dear NUS friends, three valuable lessons: 1) always communicate and be clear as to your relationship status, and 2) don't 'ignore' and hope that everything will be fine, 3) don't break up online and, most importantly, 4) don't date weirdos.

Reading through some of the posts here and was wondering, why so much hate for people who go for a girl/guy because of looks? As much as I agree that personality is important, are you able to take a first look at someone and go, "Wah, that girl/guy's personality sibei chio/hansum sia!". Don't bs and tell me can la, the answer is obviously no. One cannot deny that having good looks give one the advantage of the initial attraction, which may lead to further interaction and perhaps something more given the "right" personality.  So instead of whining "why no love for ugly guys/girls" or "why can't he/she love me for my personality instead of picking on my looks", why not spend the time to make yourself look better, be it proper grooming, learning to dress up or what not. At least with better "packaging", you stand a better chance, with the added bonus of appearing as someone who puts in the effort to look presentable. When I was 15 the bathroom was renovated and got a new detachable shower head.

@17234
17234

It's hard to give advice on such a grey area. On one hand this guy is attached but on the other hand, you like him a lot and feel that he deserves better because his girlfriend doesn't appear to cherish him. If you go after him, you are seen as a third party, if you let it go, you will never know if the two of you could ever be something more. In fact something similar like this happened to me, except I'm in the guy's shoes in this case. 

I was dating a guy years ago and had been in that relationship for 2 years. It was a pretty ok relationship. 

And then one day I got to know another guy through work. Somehow both of us clicked really well, we had many things in common and could never seem to run out of topics to talk about. We hung out together but back then I had always seen him as a friend and nothing more. Overtime, we became close and yes this guy was aware that I had a boyfriend then. I guess you can say we were both attracted to each other but because of the boyfriend, neither is us acted on it because it felt like the 'right thing to do'. 

That is until one day, the guy confessed to me. It was difficult for him and believe me he felt like a here for doing it but he decided to tell me because he could not stand not knowing if we could be something more. I can tell you it is the happiest and yet at the same time, most heart wrenchingly guilty feeling. I felt guilty because here I was, feeling all these things I had never felt when I was with my ex and it felt wrong because it was with someone else. It felt like cheating and yet not cheating at the same time. Somewhere somehow but I don't know how, I had fallen out of love with my ex and in love with someone else. Someone whom I appeared to share so many affinities with. And so after that, I formally broke up with my ex before getting together with the new guy. 

There were moments where I felt like a horrible person, and that people would judge me for doing 'the wrong thing'. I never wanted to be a bad person and I never asked to fall in love with someone else whilst still in a relationship. The only thing I could do was to own up to having a change of heart and initiate a clean break immediately before anything could get out of hand. It felt like the right thing to do. 
It has been 3 years since the new guy and I got together and we will be getting married in a few months. Though our relationship is a path less taken, or perhaps spoken about, I have never once regretted my decision to be with him. I know that I am now with the right person for me, someone who gets me and loves me wholly. 

I cannot garentee that what happened to me can also happen to you but if the both of you are truly meant for each other, somehow,  you'll find a way. Just be true to yourself and your heart. It is easy for others to judge but as far as relationships go, there is no right or wrong, only consequences to your actions.

In response to 17225:

I am in your position once and i can understand your fears. Personally, coming out to the first person was definitely the most difficult as i had no idea how he would respond and i had imagined that my friends would treat me differently. However, that is untrue as my friends still treat me the same as before. 
Granted there might be some people who might reject you but i think most people now are tolerant or even accepting. 

I also understand the fear if someone,who identifies as hetero, finds out that you are interested in him. I personally have told some of my friends i would date them,only because they asked, and it turned out fine since i draw the line clearly. I do not hit on them or make advances so i am sure if you do the same there is no reason for your friends to feel weirded out. Finding a partner is pretty tough, but if you choose to be open about yourself, it might help though this is obviously not easy. Other ways include the apps which granted isnt the best but can work occasionally. or through mutual friends which i find is ideal. 

Have faith in the goodness of people!

-
 
Each individual has their own private space and guarding that space is a door locked from the inside, some locked much more tightly than others. Most of the time, the door is there to keep unwanted people from entering but once in a while, it too allows people to enter. To establish a romantic or platonic relationship with another party is not just required that you be willing to open your own door but also for the other party to be willing to enter. But willingness of both parties is not all that is required. Some fate is required as well. Not everyone can find your door in their lifetime, even if it's a locked one. Even if one can find it, the time has to be right such that at that point in time, you are willing to open your door for him or her and he or she is willing to enter.

But things don't get any simpler from here as all of the above just take into consideration the perspective of just one person while relationships are hardly one-way. What we also need is for the other party to be willing to have his or her door open and at the same time you be willing to enter. So what we need in sum is two parties who are willing to have their doors open for each other and each willing to enter one another's private space. Even more willingness and fate. And all these is just the start because we still need to sustain this.

There seems to be at least another layer of complexity to be added which is this. Sometimes it's just not so straightforward that if you want someone to enter, you simply open the door for them. And if you don't want them to do so, you simply close those doors. Sometimes, it's the reverse. Many times, we close those doors only to want them to return at a later time. This is as what we have in our own private space, amongst many other things, are our very own vulnerable hearts. We want to first make sure that we really know who they are and that they know what they really want before we let them in. On other occasions, we open those doors for them only to close them later on. This is so as we want to first make sure that they know how to handle things right before we let them in again. All of which are done just so that they won't wreck havoc when we let them in or when we let them in again.

However, the bubbly me was draining. I start to close up after several instances of social rejections. Most were not explicit, but rather feelings disappointment and regret would hit me. 

After the 2 years in NS, everything is no longer the same. Time seemed to froze and I can't communicate on the same level anymore. The quiet me is now associated with always having something on my mind and being perceived as having matured. I hated this extreme. I would act like the 13yo me in front of my family. It feels as if I'm trying to find a balance in all these dispositions. Everything was ok until my mum chided me for being so childish on one occasion. It hurts only after I realized the inner me has literally no where to go. The rest stops seem to be at polarized locations, and my personality just tries to fit in. 

Now I just feel like stop trying. I would avoid emotional conversations with close friends by changing the topic or appear immature to annoy the h*ll out of them. I wear dark clothing on a daily basis, and cut my hair only when someone comments on how untidy I look. I try to avoid social gatherings with people I'm not close with, and freak out in a group of people whom I don't even know the names of. It's like a part of me just shuts down, leaving the rest to deal with the mess.  

Even in group projects with allocated members, I would always appear very enthusiastic at the start. Then I would realize how pointless it would be since everyone else has their priorities, and I appear to have none. All it takes is a trigger, like the Prof rejecting our chosen article to base our project on. I take every setback as a sign that I should stop trying. Every time I try to step out, I just sink lower.

I'm evergreen. Stopped trying after one bad experience when I was 16. I can no longer initiate conversations without any purpose. No more "How's your day?", no more "ah so stress". I'm becoming a recluse, an emotional deviant.

I wonder what has changed. I know I've to come to terms with it. It gets so tiring I would sleep for half the day. I hate it but I've to appear strong in front of people I love. I hate to have so much time on my hands. I hate myself for not trying harder, and I know I've myself to blame. Talking to people on an emotional level creeps me out, because I know I'm an emotional wreck. I don't want to hurt anyone when I implode. Sorry to waste your time.

Our feud went back generations; it was only natural I despised him. And I couldn't, for the life of me, figure out why she would befriend  him - by all accounts, she was everything he could never be. Popular. Brilliant. Radiant.

And so I squashed down my feelings for her. For even though I fell, bewitched, every time I looked deep into those blazing eyes, my rivalry with him was more important than a stupid crush, right?

And then, years later, I understood.

It was love.

She rejected me at first, and, looking back, it makes sense. Obviously. I kinda let my 'jock' status run to my head a little, and that bothered her. So I cleaned up my act (cleaner than HE could possibly get) and she finally let me be with her, in all her glory.

To be honest if someone can rebound in weeks or months even after years of being in a relationship; it just goes to show how easy it is for two people to fall in love, or perhaps how some of us desire companionship. 

(Perhaps some of us find it easier to break off; place less sentimental attachments in our relationships; are more objective with our emotions.) 

To sustain that connection is a different story, requires effort, communication and compromise.It really takes two mature souls (in terms of understanding/empathy, not in every sense of the word maturity)

 I've seen incompatible characters work shit out and I've seen the opposite fall apart.

In response to  I would like to share my personal experience.

I think having fwbs is actually quite common as I had a few before and some of my friends had theirs too. 

My fwbs were not planned.  I didn't set out looking for one but somehow things just happened and for some,  it became 'long-term' and we just continued with it while continuing to be normal friends. 

At first I found such relationships awkward but as my fwbs all were the type who pretended there was nothing between us in normal situations,  I gradually also forgot about it when we were in the 'normal mode'  and I find it exciting to know them on these different levels. 

Generally I think having fwbs are acceptable but I do regret some of them.  When I was younger I had some who already were attached and one even married.  Those I definitely do think that I did wrong but I guess it is too late to make amendments.  I have just stopped my escapades,  especially since I am attached now and do not wish to cheat :)

The importance of a hug. You taught me that. I really appreciated every hug that I had from you. It was a small gift but it was so rare in my life.

I came from a family that takes hugging as a form of problem. If I needed a hug, it means I have problems. And if I had problems, I would not share because no one in my family can be trusted not to share. Share with any of them a problem, the loudspeaker blares and the next thing you know, everyone knows. If I told them I have depression, they all would worry and also keep asking me why am I still unhappy with what I have. 

But you were different. You went through depression, you understood me. I can tell you everything, you would never even dream of sharing with anyone my problems. You hugged me whenever we met. Your hugs were my comfort and solace, a heaven I never knew existed. I forgot even what depression was like.

Alas, you were a drug that I could not let go. We had to go separate ways because I did not wish to ruin your life.

I drowned further in depression. From the day you left, no one hugged me. I always had family problems but no one to tell to. I tried confiding in my friends but they were not like you. I needed your familiarity and warmth. I need to say out things I have bottled up for a long time. Most importantly I needed someone who understood me. 

I avoided my friends and only remained in contact with my closest friends. I quit my CCA. I lost my motivation in life. In fact, I think I kind of quit life too. I have became a robot, struggling to graduate as soon as possible. I wish I can tell you but now that you are married, I shouldn't. Your wife certainly would not want you to keep texting this crazy woman. I'm closer to death than you can imagine.

-
 
 Dear OP, people tend to trust me for advice, so take me very seriously when I say that not just communication, but effective communication is very important in a relationship, for your future relationships. The problem might lie somewhere else but the aforementioned point still stands.

I too had a great boyfriend but at that point in time while we were still together, we didn't really communicate effectively at all. It then went to a point where there were many miscommunications and misunderstandings, and they piled up as they weren't resolved. Thinking back on it now, it was extremely unhealthy. He wanted to talk, but I didn't. It also didn't help that I was impulsive. Despite all these, he still sticked around. Things then went way out of hand one day and he really had to leave, and cut off all contacts he had with me. His very final message was something like he doesn't blame me at all but leaving was just something he had to do and hoped I understood his situation from his POV. That was my story. I'm unsure how you've hurt your boyfriend, but I'm sure if he loves you as you say he does, as much as my boyfriend loved me back then, he doesn't want you to be too hard on yourself. Pick yourself up again and move on. Life goes on for both of you.

 Based on my past dating experiences, I think a lot depends on the context. Disregarding contexts that are to be considered promises or assurances, especially made when the guy is extremely angry and/or sad,
If a guy can't keep to his words when he says not to find him again; or
If a guy can't keep to his words when he says he's really already had enough; or
If a guy can't keep to his words when he says he would throw away some of the memories he's had of you,
He probably likes you a lot.

Now that you've brought this up, guys know what to do now. :(
The idea for them is not to stop making promises but make them elsewhere where evidence is more controversial, like hooking pinkies. You just spoiled the market!!
