Wow why is it whenever I told my friends I have a crush. The first question they ask is does she have a bf? Gosh do you all really think that I'm the sort that snatches people's gf? Or do you all think that I'm fated to get unrequited love?  
-
 
I have not gone out with many girls in my life so far. Among these girls, I have two whom I still feel that I have let them down. (This is going to be a long post with no TL;DR)

Girl 1 - my ex.

1. We were each other's first gf/bf. I did not admit it at that time but it was really a case of she loving me more than I loved her. She was not top-of-the-range in terms of looks (neither am I), but she treated me really well. I took her for granted and it got to a point when I would message her once every few days, claiming that I was busy with different events in school. The last straw that broke the camel's back was when I let slip that my parents did not think we were compatible in terms of character, future earnings etc. She initiated the breakup soon after, not because of these, but because she felt I was unwilling to fight for a mutual future together.

2. To make things worse, we were (are?) each other's first sexual partner, having started during our relationship. After the breakup, we continued sleeping together for a few months. Even though I made it clear that we are never ever going to get back together and she ostensibly understanding that, it felt like she harboured a hope that we would get back together and therefore she agreed to our continued sexual liaisons.

3. Alas, things did not last. Shortly before Christmas Day one year, I was overseas and dropped her a message asking whether we wanted to have a short staycation so that we could have an extended session together. She refused despite my attempts to persuade otherwise. Finally, I said, "Fine" and ignored her. Even when she changed her stance and claimed that she felt that she needed "to do it", I continued ignoring her out of spite. After that Christmas Day, our messages stopped and a few months later I heard she got attached.

4. Over these years, we re-established contact and today we are friends, or at least acquaintances. She is still happily attached to that same person while I am also happily attached to another girl. We do not speak about our past, except for the one time she said something about it being disgusting to imagine me naked and I retorted with a "Haven't you seen every part of me, and vice-versa?"

5. Yet, under this seemingly normal acquaintanceship, I still feel that, in a way, I used her soft spots towards me to continue sleeping with her even outside of a relationship. I am glad, on hindsight, that the sexual liaisons stopped, because continuing them would have hindered both of us from truly moving on.

Girl 2 - my fling

6. I knew her from attending this particular event and got her contact soon after. The reason for getting her contact, however, was to persuade her to join a certain committee. After many nights of persuasion, she finally relented, but not before confiding to me that she has a clinical condition which may hinder her time in the committee. I assured her that it was fine and agreed to keep it a secret for her.

7. Subsequently, I started going with another girl while maintaining a platonic friendship with Girl 2. My dates with the other girl ended up in failure when she decided that I was not the right person she was looking for. I was devastated. I felt that I truly liked the other girl, even to the extent of liking more strongly compared to my ex, Girl 1 (ironic how karma works).

8. During my post "breakup" phase, I started to communicate with Girl 2 more frequently. The communication grew in both frequency and intimacy. Soon, it escalated into meetups, study sessions etc. The sexual tension between us grew. It all culminated in one day when we were about to leave a tutorial room after studying for the whole day, she happened to stand very close to me when I was about to open the door. Looking into her eyes, I leaned forward to kiss her and the sexual tension was released as we literally dropped our bags at the door and went to a corner to make out (luckily it was a weekend).

9. On the MRT home after that, she asked me if we had a future together. I said I was unable to give her an answer. At that point in time, I felt that she was willing to commit if I said yes, but I wussed out, leaving two hearts separate.

10. After that, we ignored each other for a few months, until I required her help in some project. This time round, she told me she was attached already. The date she got attached? That very night after we made out, she went home and her boyfriend confessed to her. Feeling that he can promise a more secure future, she agreed. Then, as if to rub it in further, she said she offered her boyfriend oral sex that night because she had to offer him something more than what she offered me during the make out session.

11. We remained platonic, but like peat fires, the flames are unseen but lay un-extinguished underground. It took a dinner, after her tiff with her boyfriend, and a walk in the park for the flames to reignite. From then on, we started a fling - we would do everything except the full course while she remained attached to her boyfriend. I justified to myself morally that she was the attached, and therefore the cheating, one, not me (who was unattached).

12. Obviously, such fling is not sustainable. Passionate? Yes. Torrid? Yes. Sustainable? No. Things came to a head when she confessed to her boyfriend about the fling, which in turn triggered his own clinical condition. When I stupidly asked her if she was willing to leave her boyfriend to be with me, she said she could not decide. It was then I told her that if she could not choose, I would choose for her and that is to leave. Cynically speaking, the barrier to me leaving was lower since I was not getting any full course sex anyway. She offered as a desperate attempt to keep me, but I declined out of fear that it was her ploy for me to impregnate her and complicate matters.

13. After these years, I am glad to have ended that toxic fling. Similar to my ex, the ending was acrimonious. Dissimilarly, we never reconnected after that and I saw no reason to. On hindsight, it was quite obvious that I personally treated her as a substitute for the girl whom I did not work out with. Girl 2 is an intelligent and above-average looking girl herself and I should have done better than to treat her that way.

14. Am I b*stard in treating her the way I treated her? Certainly yes. Should I have treasured her more? I am not so sure because she was attached at that point in time. Besides, the raison d'etre of our "relationship" is on a sexual/physical basis, not on an emotional basis. We let emotions come into play when we should have known better. This is also why I firmly believe that separating physical and emotional needs is very difficult, if not impossible, because of the way we are wired.

Conclusion (finally!)

15. To Girl 1, thanks for teaching me what *not* to do as a boyfriend and sorry for having continued to sleep with you after our breakup. I really wish you all the best in your relationship and, should you invite me to your wedding, I will certainly turn up with a fat angbao.

16. To Girl 2, I am sorry for causing you all the hurt and for letting my emotions destroy the safeguards I had built into our brief time together. Please let it be known that I have absolutely no intention of contacting nor disturbing you. As I heard you are still together with the same guy, I sincerely wish you all the best in your relationship as well as your future.

P.S. My only purpose of writing this is to revisit, albeit mentally, my emotional journey. It was cathartic writing this. Thank you for reading if you made it here.

-
 
To the OP of confession ,

You might not know me, or you might do. I am one of the regular contributors of comments on NUSWhispers, and coming across your confession post my heart broke a little more inside for you. Your mental strength to even compose yourself enough to write what you wrote, without malice of exposing the architects of your betrayal is something I both admire, and yet at the same time add rage towards your friend and now-ex that had wronged you in the most heinous manner possible. 

I have only dated once in my life. Wasn't as long as yours, heck it wasn't even as long as what most people would have dated on average. I was with my ex for the three to four months before I left Singapore for university overseas. For someone who admittedly was not blessed with luck in love, she meant everything to me back when I was a more turbulent and tempestuous being. For someone who had been planning to leave Singapore, study overseas and never return, she gave me reason once again to hope for a future with someone here in Singapore, someone whom I could share my life and heart and love with. 

Slightly more than a week after I arrived at my university, what had started out auspiciously as our budding LDR suddenly went sour. For no reason my ex ghosted me on all communication channels. Whatsapp, Facebook, phone calls, everything. My mind went into overdrive and I nearly went mad with worry over her safety and our relationship. I still remember vividly the afternoon that I was in university attending events for Freshers' Week when her Whatsapp message came through. She said that she had found out right after I left Singapore than she was pregnant with my child, from our last night spent together in the same bed. We had done it only twice in our relationship, and according to her words against all protection we both took she still struck the biological jackpot and got pregnant. I was shellshocked to read next that she ghosted me the entire week because she was pondering her decision to make, and that the very morning she Whatsapped me she had just come back from the clinic where she had induced the abortion, and with that she broke up with me. 

Two hours after I received the message I had booked the first flight back home that I could. Five hours after the message was read I was on the train to the airport. No phone calls went through. No messages went answered or even read. I called my parents and broke down on the phone to my dad, and to his credit he did not tell my mother the terrible incident, and fully supported me to fly back home to see what support I could give for my ex, or failing that how best to end the relationship on a proper footing. My train got delayed, and my flight left early, so I ended up staying overnight at the airport hotel before catching the first flight back the next morning. I had fallen badly ill throughout this time, and my family doctor whom I subsequently visited when I returned home said he would have grounded me from flying had he seen to me in the country from which I flew from.

When I arrived back at Changi Airport I tried to contact my ex again, and when I failed I did the only thing I thought an honourable man should do. I called her mother and tried to find out where her daughter was. She was surprised that I was suddenly back in Singapore until I confessed to her everything my ex told me. I guess you could call it foolish honour on my part, I genuinely thought that I'd offer myself up, physically and mentally and emotionally for whatever punishment that was to await me from her parents, if it meant that I could somehow see my ex again and find out the truth of the matter. But it was not to be. 

My ex sending me off at the airport proved to be the last time I'd ever see her face again. After their own personal discussions both my ex's parents called me back. Far from the anger I  expected to receive from them, their responses were very much the opposite. They thanked me for being an honourable man who would fly back from two continents away to attempt taking responsibility for their daughter, but that they couldn't persuade their daughter to see me one last time and end things right. In the mother's words "our family does not want anything more to do with you, so I thank you for being a good partner to my daughter for the past few months, and that you fly back and complete your education. Leave my daughter and this relationship behind, forget that we ever existed." And promptly after I returned back to university, my ex's family and friends all blocked and deleted me off every single avenue of contact, online or through the phone. 

The clincher of all this was that when I returned back to visit last summer, I got into contact once more with a mutual friend of me and my ex. And she finally told me what I had suspected all along as I dealt with the emotional turmoil of a breakup so bad alone in a foreign country. My ex had never been pregnant, the friend told me. She thought I would be like most guys who would be scared off with talks of pregnancy by their hands, and that fundamentally she decided to break up after we started our LDR because she was paranoid that I would not be able to resist the temptation of foreign girls compared to her waiting for me back home. So I lost my first proper relationship and the girl I loved, to her paranoia and a lousy lie of a reason that left me emotionally wrecked for the rest of the year to come. 

So, OP of confession , I thought that with your courage of sharing your breakup on NUSWhispers that I'd share mine as well. Might not be comparable to yours in terms of magnitude (god knows I didn't even get to a first anniversary, much less BTO talk), but I believe our stories though different share a similar trauma. The rage and despair you feel now must be unimaginable and almost unsurvivable. No words will comfort you, no gestures will warm you. You will be playing over everything in the past you shared with your cheating ex and castigating yourself on what you did wrong, and what you could have changed. But as someone who took almost a year to move on significantly (and not even fully) I can tell you this. Time will heal you, whether you believe it does or not. Do not blame yourself, because the last thing you need now is to bring yourself down when others have given you such a crushing blow that few will ever receive in similar fashion. I hope you will have better fortune and mental fortitude to deal with the emotional scars you must bear with such pain now, than I had with my own wounds. I'm still fighting every day to move on, to live on and love and feel again after all the trauma that I had gone through. We all will have to, you and I both and others out there who have similar stories to share. But know that you are not alone, you will never be alone, and that what support I did not receive back in my darkest hours I am offering mine to you when you need it most now. I do not want you to come out of everything as badly or worse than how I came out of my own breakup. There are enough people in the world who are irreparably hurt emotionally, you deserve so much better than the cheating ex and traitorous friend of yours. 

Keep breathing, keep fighting, keep living, don't stop hoping. We are the ones who have to go through hell and high water because of our love for the wrong people in our lives, but I believe that Fate will ultimately prove kind to us and give us back what we've lost. If you're still wondering who I am after reading all this that I've written, I'm the only comment contributor on NUSWhispers who is currently studying in the UK. Talk to me, message me, I will always have time for you and I will always have your back. 

Never forget, never regret. Stay strong brother. 
-
 
Some of the guys here who post about their girls problems are really salty af. Seriously, girls do not owe you a date just because you're nice to them, or because you get good grades, or because you've been a good boy in general. If you really want to attract the opposite sex, get a personality, be interesting and try to get in good shape. It's really that simple. Whining about being perpetually friendzoned won't do you any good--in fact it's the fastest way for you to get friendzoned.

So I have this very close female friend. Typical story. Boy and girl. Childhood friends. 

But we never dated. We never fell in love. Or at least, the very least, we never confessed to each other.

Recently, one mutual friend disclosed to me a secret. That my childhood friend actually had a crush on me before. 4 years ago. But she never spoke of this crush ever again since. 
And now i think back, her actions back then really did seem so. Small things, minor things like asking me out, calling me more than often.

We shared many "first times". We had many memories together, went out together (though those weren't official dates) and we talked almost everything. Very naturally, carefree. Mostly on the phone. I find that a feat cos i cant really engage in a non awkward convo with others on the phone except for her.

The thing is, I love her. I truly do. But i dun know as what:
I care for her. But our r/s, as corny as it sounds, is akin to a brother/sister relationship.
While I feel that I can spend the rest of my life with her, married, cos she knows me before, I dont have other romantic feelings for her.

I dont fantacise about us having intercourse, yet i always picture us having a family. I dont feel the urge to kiss, hug her, yet I want told hold her hand, to never let her go.

Recently, i felt that she is slowly leaving my grasp. She is having her own life. Own friends. Friends whom we didnt share. Her own new social circle. We shared schools, classes (from pri sch to JC ) for so long that i barely remembered what was it like without her . We studied together,  shared notes, copied each other's notes. We meet up lesser, and i don't blame her. 

I never dated.
She is in her 3rd year. I barely completed my 1st. (Cos ns ).
They say it is never too late. And i am ready to confess. To make a change. But before that, i really need to know:
Should I? Do I love her enough to be with her? Or is my love for her too platonic? Is it normal to have such a platonic love for my best friend? Are we indifferent from parallel lines - so close together but we will never meet?  If so, will it be fair for her? Will I hurt her if she knows that, I dont harbour the most romantic feelings for her.

Please help. ;'(

-
 
I am not a nice guy.

I am impatient. I don't have the ability to communicate with naive children. I don't see the need to waste my time justifying my actions to people who don't matter, such as mere acquaintances or classmates.

I don't see the point of sugarcoating or beating around the bush. I say things to people straight to their face.

Cause of that, some people say that I am rude.

I am pragmatic. I weigh options, I prioritise. I choose the option that would make the most out of my time. 

I am simple and boring. I eat simple meals. I eat the cheapest meals. I don't instagram my meals. I don't tweet. I don't update my facebook. I just read up about scientific discovery, I don't follow celebrity news or gossips.

I am self-centered. I do not respond to obligatory group meals, class gatherings if I won't be happy going. Even if my friend(s) are involved.

The kinder people say I am introverted. The others use the word @$$. I deny neither accusations.

And from you can read from above, I probably don't have a lot of friends either. I have less than 10. That's probably cause I highly regard the word 'friend' , not just as a status, but as a title, referring to someone I treasure a lot to be , and for me to keep, in my life.
Guess before I lose your interest, let me state this:

This isn't about me, This isn't a self introduction post, a john cena joke or a post looking for a girlfriend.

This is about me wanting to change.

I am a Singaporean guy. 21 this year I just ORD-ed from NS not long ago and I am enrolling into NUS Engineering School this coming new semester.

It is a fresh experience for me. I was a JC student, so I never got to experience the university/poly lifestyle.

While I am eager to start my uni life, eager to learn and move onto the next stage of my life, there is something bothering me.

I hate orientation camps. I don't see the point of doing forfeits or shameful things together to forge new bonds or meet new people.

More than that I actually hate making new friends or meeting new people.

It is bothersome, tiring and to me, a waste of time.

Call me old fashion but I would much rather be on a speed-dating process talking to a stranger over a table and making friends via introduction. And if I don't like him/her , I will just shout: NEXT!

I believe that making friends is no different from dating.

You get to know someone. You evaluate the person's character and you determine if you still want someone like him/her in your life.

That is my opinion. Like I mentioned before, I am pragmatic. And from you would have gathered by now, pessimistic. 

To me, if someone is of a character I don't like, that doesn't make either of us 'bad friends' or 'bad people'.

It is just that since our characters don't match, why bother continue being friendly or keeping in contact?

Sure, we aren't complete strangers, we can still be acquaintances, some would say.

But to me, someone who hates small talk, acquaintances is no different from strangers.

I wasn't always like that. 

Believe it or not, and even I find it hard to believe it myself, I wasn't always like this.

I used to have friends. Whoever talked to me once, that was my friend. That was me... last time.

Then shit happens.

It became so bothersome to hold onto friendship. onto bonds.

It started with a small thing. A birthday gathering. Some couldn't make it on Day 1, others had something on on Day 2.

I had to choose a date.

And I upset some friends.

First came the drama. Arguments, eye stares, hatred.

Then the picking of sides.

Then pettiness and blame kicks in. 

And after everything, I was left standing alone taking the blame from both ends.

"You were the reason the group broke apart." I remembered hearing.

That, and many other things, made me sick and tired of forging new relationships, making the effort to know people.

I still do, as previously mentioned, have friends. Some. They don't share the same personality as me. Some are even the polar opposite. 

And I am happy with having just them as friends.

I don't need new ones.

I don't need new drama, new picking of sides, and new petty people in my life.

I don't want to go through all the trouble, after putting in all the effort to forge relationships, only for someone else to destroy it. 

And I am the one ending up getting hurt.

To put it in a plain way, guess I was Spongebob, but I ended up being like Squidward
"I built the walls from the bridges that I burnt down."

People often say that you have to know influential people in life, or broaden your social network or the people you know.

"It is the political game" they say. "Office politics"

If that is so I would rather not play the game.

Guess after writing for so long (and thank you, anyone who bothers to read such a lengthy and boring post), I want to know:

What do you think of a person like me? Am I abnormal?
I want to change, but how?
Should I really join such introduction/orientation camps? Would it really change me?
And if it doesn't, I would have wasted money, time and effort, all over again.

Signed,
A Troubled Soul
-
 
 People do not dislike you for being introverted. It is more likely that they are put-off by you pretending to be what you are. Faking confidence is different from faking a whole new persona. I would probably wonder why you are sometimes so enthusiastic to interact with me and sometimes not. I would probably come to the conclusion that you aren't all that interested to know me. What you need to learn is to open up to people, not how to make yourself seem like what you are not.

-
 
  "One thing I don't understand though, is why you would give up so easily when you claimed that you liked me that much?"

 "Maybe I should let you go, because of how much you're affecting me. I haven't told you, but I have two suitors currently after me. Maybe I'm hoping if I leave, if I go with someone else, you'll come chasing after me, but I'm just deceiving myself, like a fool. :("

There are two scenarios that could be playing out in each of these cases:
(1) You are extremely insecure. You do not love the opposing party. You are trying to seek self-validation through the attention and the pursuit from others.
Advice: Please learn to love yourself first and do yourself and others a favour.
(2) You are extremely insecure. You love the opposing party.
Advice: Is that how you ought to love someone?

In either case, either you are oblivious to the opposing party's feelings for you or you are just playing dumb. Please don't push the blame onto others and accuse them of not loving you.

Yesterday while I was having dinner with my family and my sister's Boyfriend, I noticed something which really troubled me. 
At the dinner, we were seated as such so that the couple could be given as much privacy as possible without being conscious of our existence. 
However, once we were seated and orders were taken, both of them just whipped out their phones and did whatever they were doing on the phone before the food came. There were no words exchanged between my Sister and her Boyfriend throughout. My sister's eyes were glued to her phone, texting and visiting social media sites. Her Boyfriend was not much better. He was continually playing his game and not even once he bothered to look up at my sis. Even after the food came, they just went back to using their phones while eating the food. My parents were puzzled as it was the first time we went dinner with her Boyfriend tagging along, and they had assumed that they would want to be left alone to "lovey dovey". How wrong my dad was lol. 
The entire dinner took about 1.5 hours. My parents soon noticed that there was no conversation going on between the couple. Even after my parents initiated a conversation to get the couple to start talking, it was futile as it was evident that whatever they were doing on their phones took a greater priority. My Dad even commented after the dinner " even after 40 years of marriage with your Mother, I still can talk to her with more frequency than those 2 just now". 
I don't know whether it is me or what, but I have been seeing such incidents on a frequent basis nowadays. Whenever I go to cafes with my friends(I'm single), more often than not I see couples using their phones more than interacting with each other. I know social media sites can be attractive but you can always access it all the time when your SO is not around right?? Whereas one usually meets their Boyfriend/Girlfriend for 3-4 hours for a date? So why can't one just put aside his/her phone for those 3-4 hours and spend it fully with their loved one? If 3-4 hours is too long, surely not using the phone during the course of a meal (which is like 1.5 hours at most? ) at all is reasonable right? 
I feel that as a sign of respect for your SO, one should give him/her your full attention whenever they are out on a date. Maybe I'm wrong about this because I'm still single, but the thought of myself doing this with my future girlfriend...it doesn't feel right.

In a couple more months, it would be a year since we broke up. She was my first girlfriend. It still feels like she will be my last. I believed so strongly that we could make things work, I really liked her. My heart still aches the familiar pain of regret whenever I think of her.

I will always remember the period of absolute bliss, when everything felt perfect and it was just the two of us, in this crazy world full of strange, unfamiliar people. I feel like I might have irreversibly romanticised that period of time, until I can no longer move on from it. I think of the sweet things she did for me that still puts a faint smile on my face. I think of the arguments that make me want to close my eyes, just for a moment, as I wallow in regret.

Since the breakup, I have had brief moments of positivity. There were days where I genuinely believed that it can only get better from here, and I feel happier. Now I feel like I have regressed back into this emotional maelstrom of pain, triggered by the smallest of hints of what we once had. A silly joke. A note you made for me. Dinner receipts. Thus is the life of a heartbroken student, still nursing my wounds and forcing myself to carry on 'living' according to schedule, like clockwork, when inside I am suffering in silence.

I have loved and I have lost. I do not know if I have experienced both ends of the emotional spectrum. I am inclined to think so, and that would only lead to the conclusion that there isn't anything better to look forward to in life. I know it's the wrong mindset, but I am still hanging on, by a thread, for someone to come along to convince me otherwise. That this broken soul is still capable of loving and being loved.

How do you have confidence when you are not rich or popular or able enough to compete with the other suitors that your crush have?

People always love me when I suddenly have the burst of energy to socialize, having a smile on my face, talking and chatting with people I know. But as an introvert, this is a facade that I simply cannot sustain forever. Whenever I start to show my introverted and quiet true self, the people I attracted based on first impression, start to drift off from me. And as a guy that doesn't like to intrude into peoples lives, it is hard to make friends with girls due to the very fact that girls don't normally make the first move to make friends with you. And also after so many years of social rejections, I also lost confidence in myself. I have been trying to tell myself, it is okay to be me, it is okay to be quiet and introverted, "people will eventually like you for who you are". But my past experiences just prove otherwise... People always like guys with lots of energy, sporty, and talkative. I have tried on that persona, but I can never sustain it, because that its not me. And that's why I keep people at an arms length and not see anyone for weeks at times, because I have no idea what to do to sustain relationships with people. I want to change this, because I am graduating this year already and everyones already getting engaged or already married at my age, and I don't want to stay single for life, it is just too sad.

I realise that I am a mess, I am typing all these right now because I can't keep my mind off her. If anyone identifies with my past midnight incoherent writing and have any advice to give, I would greatly appreciate it.

-
 
So I have just sent my girlfriend off to LA for a business trip, and I am feeling a tad chummy inside. 

We have gone through 2 full years together. And the 2 years are filled with countless excitements, sweetness, sorrows and disappointments.

We first met each other in college. Back then she was a studious typical-girl-next-door and I was a typical playful ah beng. We had little common interests. She disliked my carefree attitude; I hated her boring routine. Anyone would say it is impossible that this 2 kids will one day get together. 

But we did. 

Honestly the first few interactions were meh - no spark at all. Then one fine day, she threw a wink at me. And something magical happened. My impression of her just changed. I started to develop little good feelings for her. I found everything about her to be attractive. The way she talks, the way she walks; all seemed to be so cute. I felt as if I was blind and suddenly I could see! How could I have not noticed a girl so angelic close to me? And the good feelings for her grew stronger and stronger with every passing day.  

One day I woke up and said, "Okay. I am in love. I need her in my life." 

And I confessed to her. 

She was skeptical at first. I would too - how can someone who is as playful as me be a good partner in a relationship? But I did not give up at her initial rejection. I know I have to be a more responsible guy if I were to win her heart. It is about time to be serious about my life, and so I changed for the better.  

A few months later, we got attached. And now we are on the path to our happily-ever-after. We are really happy together! Quarrels are still common. Tantrums are frequently thrown. Cold wars are always fought. But below all the dramas, both of us know that our hearts belong to each other. 

I daresay that the confession is the best decision in my life. 

We will see each other in 3 months time. And I miss her already. I hope she enjoys her business trip and stays safe. 

On serious note: I really hope she does not accidentally dropped a wink at some other random ang moh guy. That wink, is dangerous. 

;)

-
 
 It would help to understand the person better, and place him/her in less stressful environments. The outbursts (or at least, in my case) happen impulsively, when we are stressed and cannot think properly (something like a short-circuit). 

So, it would really help if you're a person we actually open up to and accept, and we are in an environment where we can feel cam, and more in control.

Saying this, it adversely impacts us a lot (or anyone for that matter) if someone tries to change our behaviour. However, the person in question must also have hope, and make an effort as well.

* The keyword here is UNDERSTAND. Conventional methods will not work, because you're doing it from your point of view, from your perspective. It will not help, rather, it will raise our guard against you even more, because we're insecure enough, and yet you're still approaching us with methods that we find a bit difficult to trust - because typically, we are left alone for very good reasons that we cannot fault you for, but we can feel bitter about. 

That, and what  said.

Just gonna come out and say this first: I'm not pushing for any ideas or whatnot, just here to say something to whoever wants to read it, after seeing all the posts on NS. 

Additional spoiler alert - Do not read this if you are:
1. Someone who liked NS or feels the need to tell everyone how much they loved it/ why this country needs it.
2. Someone who feel NS  or the govt has wronged them in some way.

To the above: Don't read this, my views are my own and there is no need for you to take time out of your life to read, comment and construct an intellectually-sounding, fact-quoting wall of words to justify your stand to me. I am but a random confessor. Honestly. Don't read and don't comment. I'm not going to read the reactions to this post anyway. I just wanted to say something that I have kept within my heart for some time. And don't hijack this post to tell everyone how patriotic/honorable you are or how whatever I am doing is bad/ pressing for anti-/pro- govt propaganda. Probably no one cares much for what you, or I, have to say within minutes of reading.  

So I bid you, scroll past this, all ye who art honorable, all ye who within doth dwell bitterness. These words are for my catharsis and mine alone. There is no place for you here. Reading this will just get you worked up for naught, they are not worth your time. Your energies are better focused elsewhere. 

And so, on to what I would like to say:

Truth: 2 years is 2 years. I will never get it back again. I did/do my best to make the most of it, but I will never get it back again. Were there things I wish I had done better? No. I like to think i did my best in those 2 years. There were good and bad times, but nonetheless, it was time i can never get back again. 

So, to those who felt it was not wasted and still stubbornly read on, good on you. Move along. Same to those who will spout anti-NS rhetoric. You and I, we will not meet, either in a clash of words or in a verbal battle. I have said my part and I will move on from hence forth. Wasted/not wasted, they are both subjective. I won't judge you for whatever reason you felt that it was either. You have the right to feel the way you feel. Just as I do not have the right to tell you if you are right or wrong, you have no right to do so here. Just as my thoughts are my own, your thoughts are your own. 

To those like me, who simply felt that part of their lives were wasted, I can empathize. Don't let it eat you up. Just keep it inside as a reminder/motivation for whatever you are working towards. And know that you are not alone. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise and don't let anyone fan the bitterness into something that will continue to burn us inside till the day we die. 

Hold this like a silent whisper of affirmation, close to your heart. And rest easy, knowing you are not alone. 

That is all. Thank you for listening to the words I have been wanting to say for a long time.

-
 
this is to  the thing about people with BPD is that when they do have their outbursts, it's really all about them. i don't suppose they can help it to stop and think before they react, so very often it's the people around them who suffer just as much emotional damage as them. that being said, people who have BPD are definitely not trying to inflict pain or casually unload their own problems onto just anyone. i would think that if you have to see them at their worsts, they probably trust you a plenty lot. i get that it is incredibly hard to be on the receiving end, especially when you don't know what's going on half the time. but if you really do want to help people with BPD (or if you think they do), you've got to ask yourself first "why". why is it that you want to help them? i think that's where you're going to find perseverance for sticking it through with them. but if you think you might end up leaving them because you can't take it some day down the road, please leave them gently or let them know that you're there for them as long as they reach out to you. i mean, a few google searches and you'll get to see things like BPD, along with the Narcissistic personality disorder, is one of the hardest and thankless traits you'd have to live with for someone else (close to you) possessing them. but to make the relationship work in the end, it still takes effort from both sides. toughen yourself up for this person, and let them know you ain't going anywhere but if they don't want you to leave as well, they have to work for you to stay as well. i'm almost certain after their outbursts, they know more than anyone else they're in the wrong too. more than anything, they just want to know that they'll have support as they proceed to change themselves for the better and overcome the inhibitions BPD imposes upon them.

to OP , I am in the position of person B you've described. i can give you my perspective and hope it makes you feel less conflicted.
1) there is a reason why A and B remained separated even if A still loves B. in my case as a B, it was a mismatched of personalities and expectations. We both wanted different things in our lives, and it was best remain separated.
2) depending on the personality of B, it is not a bad idea to reach out to her. in my case as a B, i would rather not talk about it as the breakup went through a series of very, very bad arguments, and it even affected my personal life. As a person who would prefer to hide my pasts, I'd rather not share it with friends, so questions like these by strangers would not be appreciated too. if the B is someone otherwise, you can approach her, but bear in mind of the scars she already had from the bad arguments, and that no matter how long time has passed, she still remained hurt.

-
 
After being in a few relationships, I've come to the conclusion that people often break up over compatibility issues. But the truth is, compatibility is overhyped. Why do I say so? I think the real underlying reason is respect. There can be a couple as different as day and night or introvert/extrovert,  but as long as they respect their differences for eg the extrovert respecting the introvert's wish of not wanting to go for a party. And being able to communicate that understanding well. We can have couples that are "not compatible" thriving. It's a pity that I only realised this after a few failed relationship. Looking back, although there might be varying levels of "compatibility" if one would just have respect for their partners, there wouldn't be breakup everywhere. Anybody here agrees??

Well...you'll never be "friends" again if that's what you're asking. But here's my story, I've known this girl for a good 8 years, I've been together for 4 years and I was best friends with her for the other 4.
One thing is, if you were friends before, it's not that hard to stay "friends" after an amicable breakup. But the both of you would still have feelings for each other. Maybe it's buried so far down that neither of you realise it but let me just tell you that it's there.
For me, we know each other inside out and are almost idiosyncratic at times so it's easy to connect and start resorting to the old couple habits. "bae" and " I love you" would slip during calls and I'd start missing her when we stop talking for a while. 
So...friends? Possible. But both of you need to awknowlege that feelings are still there and not freak out when old habits back

-
 
Before you deride this as someone being stuck up...

How far are friendships like business? You make friends with people whom you think will help you. Either emotionally (when you're down), physically (to safeguard), or for connections (jobs, raising money).

Sometimes you want to make friends with someone not so much for him/her, but his/her friends. This is using someone as a connection hub. At some point in time you hope to decouple this hub person and directly be friends with the real targets of interest in his/her group if you can sustain it.

Sometimes you also make friends with someone who is not that promising because he or she could be great in the future. You help him/her be great in return for help.

But sometimes, we also cut loss-making friendships. Friends who cannot serve any interest because they are really of no value get cut. For instance, if a "friend" is so down and out and cannot help himself or herself, what is the point in helping him/her if he or she cannot even be self-secure?

Sometimes you can even just hold onto a friendship not because he or she is likeable, but you would rather have a semi-cordial relationship and figure out what his/her intentions are before he/she turns against you.

Eventually I hope to have a hub of very high-yield friends. :)

For those who say that social status doesn't matter in relationships probably hasn't really faced that dilemma in your life before. In a conservative society like ours, marriage is not simply a choice between two like-minded people, but involves everyone within each's social circle. And probably that difference in social status could result in different perceptions of what a relationship should be about.

We can only do things in good faith, one moment at a time. Ah, the mind tricks of a non-jedi. Always doubting and second-guessing.

Checking the date again, I felt a tinge of disappointment. A little slighted, even - it's just a little over two weeks from now. The deal is sealed. I know exactly what to do. I still feel ashamed at my initial miserly thoughts, but I'm more sad that I'm even called at all, if it was to be this late.

Perhaps I will always remain an acquaintance to my friends. Nonetheless here's a wish to all that may you be a friend to your friend.

-
 
To poster of ,
I also have gone through a period of time where I was excessively worried abput my future and depressed over the apparent meaninglessness of life. I believe it is a form of existential crisis / anxiety.

What is important is for you to realise that feeling lost is the start of understanding yourself and what you value in life. There is no need for you to worry. You are still young and there is no urgency for you to make any big change to your life. There are people who experience something similar in their fourties in what is known as a midlife crisis. So, instead of being worried, you should be happy that you are reflecting on your life at this age.

You say you used to live a life with meaning but now you have nothing to live for. Try to remember the things you enjoyed doing and you will realise that these are the things that make your life meaningful. You are right that there is no ideal path or purpose that applies to everyone. Instead of being afraid and worried, take it as an oppurtunity for you to explore and try new things. There is no such thing as taking a wrong path and living your life in regret. You can also talk to your friends as they might understand you in ways that you don't know yourself.

Also, don't let one relationship make you give up on everything. Not everyone is superficial as you believe. Even if you insist that romantic love is superficial, there are still a million other things that can make life meaningful.

As for your question about romantic love, it is true that romantic love is a form of attachment in the sense that one desires reciprocation and fear the loss of the other person. But it can also be a form of altruism and compassion when you care for someone. In Buddhism (though I might be wrong), I think the view is that attachment is a double edge sword in that it leads both to happiness and suffering. That said, I don't believe that we must lead an ascetic life and free ourselves from all attachment. In fact, the Buddhist view of romantic love is different depending on the school of thought you subscribe to with some accepting it as a natural part of life. While I am not a Christian, I see no conflict between the buddhist view of attachment and the view that love is a gift from god. It may be the case that both are focusing on different aspects of  romantic love, buddhism on attachment and desire, while Christians on the compassion and altruism that love entails. I think what is important is not to judge prematurely based on limited observations and to always experience things with an open heart. Many things can only be learnt through personal experience.

That's all. Don't worry too much and take things slowly. All the best!

But I guess the pain of getting backstabbed and betrayed will never go away..

If you feel like you need to do something for your crush then go for it! Don't bother asking anyone for advice because everyone is different and their advice isn't likely to work for you.

If your friend tells you shit like he/she isn't into you/want to reject you, please don't believe it, it will make you lose confidence and not strive for something that is potentially there. Because your friend isn't him/her and only him/her will know the answer.

If your friend tells you to give up/move on/there are many fishes out there, don't believe it either! You are the one who knows who you want. You know the person you want is irreplaceable.

 Not to be narcissistic, but I always believed that for a relationship to be sustainable, both of them need to be equal on all grounds. If you feel he doesn't understand half the things you are talking about, and you feel half the things he says is nonsense, I would see it as something that can go on forever. For example, 5 years later when you have a work problem or are stressed and want to vent about it, and he just doesn't get it. This isn't the only problem, but you get the idea I suppose. I am not saying such relationships can never work - then can. But it sounds like you are already confused. Feels like you love him for what he could be if he changed, and that is an idealist view to have. Just my two cents from my personal experience.

After reading countless of nus whispers, posts of regrets, girls , boys , sexual history , dilemmas and whats not , i decided to share my advice on basic relationship issues.This benefit both gender so please read with an open mind. if you disagree, i openly accept any criticism in the comments. i am doing this to educate YOU so that you can protect yourself from playboys or playgirls. 

Rule of thumb in BGR. A VERY SHORT GUIDE
* ALWAYS TRUST YOUR GUT FEELING - COMMON RULE

Girls- this would benefit you more , your body is precious.. please dont let any guys take advantage of you, always think it through
1. First dates, please do not agree to go drinking or clubbing! obviously if you are looking for a boyfriend/husband material.. even if the guy is extremely good looking, it sounds too good to be true no? obvious trap is obvious? even if it worked out, do you foresee yourself getting heartbreaks from his night activities? 
2. Never date a bad boy hope to change him into a good boy .. unless of course he is WILLING to do it for you by himself. lets face the truth , nothing goes well when its forceful. what do you get in the long run?
3. If he never ask you to be his Girlfriend, you are not! DONT ASSUME! Ask and clear the cloud before it escalates further *ahem sexual activities* just because you kiss and hold hands does't mean your TOGETHER. From the OP of ,

After the unexpected success of my post about Power Rangers, I decided to write another post with reference to Power Rangers.

TL:DR You may find a girlfriend while you didn't expect it.

Many students from engineering school doesn't see much hope of finding a girlfriend. This is because the girls to boys ratio are very low in engineering school. After graduation, it will be hard to find a girlfriend in workplace due to workplace politics.

Nothing to worry about.

Remember how Tommy(MMPR green ranger) started out as just a new student in school? In an unexpected twist of fate, he became the legendary green ranger and get to know the other rangers including Kimberly(MMPR pink ranger) who Tommy eventually got into a relationship with.

Another example is Andros(Red space ranger). Andros was a loner who worked alone. He didn't even intend for the other 4 rangers to join him initially. After time, he learnt how to trust other and he eventually fell in love with Ashley(Yellow Turbo and space ranger) and the feeling is mutual. Who would expect that a loner would find a girlfriend?

You may think that these are just fictional story so I am going to share a real life story of my own.

I once met a girl trying to learn how to cycle so I offered to teach her how to cycle. While we didn't have any feeling for each other, this story proves that you may just know a girl in some unexpected place.

Basically, don't worry about not being able to find a girlfriend. You never know what your future life will be like or who you will meet. You may just meet your other half somewhere unexpected.

TDLR: Find friends who accept you and not friends who make you want to feel accepted.

-
 
@  

You have 2 choices: 

1) confess to him, risk the friendship. He either accepts you or rejects you. Either way you get closure. 

2) keep your feelings and live forever with the regret of "what if i told him.." 

I chose the former and no doubt, it jeopardized the friendship a little. But at least, i was true to my feelings and made a move to try. Nobody can tell you whether to confess or not, it all boils down to weighing your options and deciding what matters the most to you: The friendship, or the "what ifs". 

Anything can happen. Stay strong! Fate is a rather peculiar thing. 
If its meant to be, you can not confess and you will end up with him. 
If its not meant to be, it does not matter how many times you confess or how much effort and feelings you put in to appear 'desirable'.. It just simply will not work out.

Since it is impossible to mend the past, let's focus on the present. Instead of scrolling FB and wondering the many ifs, why not take the initiative to start a conversation again? 
This FB initiative is a constant reminder for me to put in more effort into all my relationships. 
Yes, Vday is just over, love is around the corner. Let's not forget our friends who were once/still with us before we meet our precious one.

-
 
In response to , I'd say I'm in the same boat too, and since everyone is allowed to confess anonymously, let me talk about my lack of emotions on this platform. Let me breathe my heavy,dark,dangerous secret here since nobody knows who I am anyway. 

I came into this world with kind intentions in the beginning: I wanted to feel emotions and love like a normal person would. But due to how I'm raised by my parents, all forms of feelings are sucked out of me like a vacuum cleaner. 

1. When I was in secondary school, my peers were talking about the movie "a walk to remember", show touching it was and how it made them cry buckets. Curious, I went online that night to watch it on YouTube only to see my mum lurking up behind me, switching off the monitor, and coldly saying" no need to watch this,understand? Study! It's your topmost priority  now. Can you get hundred in your Maths? Look at your physics. I dunno what you're up to these days, not even studying. You're ruining your future if you don't score. Don't waste time watching stuff like this, study!" 

2. From then on I had no access to movies,so feeling touched by movies was out of the question. My mum supervises my every move like a hawk. She stands behind the screen,scrutinising every webpage. So I thought of another alternative: books. I borrowed some romance books from the library but just as I thought I could understand love from reading them, my mum RAIDED MY BAG and dug them out. 
Worse, the cold,snide remarks began again,"if only you can use all this energy into your studies. Can't you see that other people score better than you? Focus in your studies and don't read trash!" 
From then on, all the books I read are kept within the confines of science,technology,and history. Good for academics but not good for developing the heart. 

3. When others are immersing themselves in the touching atmosphere of Novels, movies and songs, I'm trapped in a strict world full of back to back tuition enrichment lessons, "parent-approved" books like einsteins discoveries, and classical music(because pop music does nothing to brain development). I soon became a studious robot, knowing only logical stuff but severely missing out on emotions. 

4. As a normal person in the past, I used to have a slight crush on a certain celebrity. I saved up my pocket money to buy the VCD and CD,only to have them confiscated by dad before I even listened. "Stop focusing on idiotic crushes, study! Understand? Why other people score better than you? Because when you're listening to his songs,they are studying!" Another try at love killed. 

5. When other people choose their lunches based on taste&  other emotional factors, I have learnt to be a completely rational and emotionless being: to choose based on vitamin and protein intake. I don't even know what is "like" as its not a word in my dictionary. 

6. But, there's a complication. I have a high level of intelligence and with that comes the dangerous thing: I learn to "fake" emotions to prevent anyone from finding out how inept I am. Yes, I do admit I'm academically smart as i was chosen for a science research Programme and another h3 subject in JC(as I kept studying ) So I learn to perfectly mimic feelings. 

7. Although movies and music  make everyone else cry but me, I blend in using cognitive skills. For example, when I hear about a breakup, I nod my head in understanding, saying things like I know how sad it is. Truth be told, as I have never immersed myself in a romance (from movies or otherwise), I'm clueless. But I know that's the "correct" thing to say to be a good girl,so I follow the script. 

8. When I slipped and had a nasty fall in school,  I saw that many people were looking on in horror at me. I quickly rearranged my facial features into "pain", deciphering that it must be the most appropriate expression on my face for a normal person who feels. I proceeded to groan even though I have no idea how "pain" must have been for normal people whose emotions aren't blunted. 

9.  Every attempt to feel emotions like a regular person is thwarted by my parents. Even if I want to go on a class outing, my mum will say," can't you see you've so many subjects that didn't get A? Don't waste your time understand?" Friendship and love are seen as inferior to studies. So repeated incidents like this shaped me into the insensitive, unfeeling beast I am now. 

10. Sometimes, my superficial cover drops on accident and people start suspecting I'm a psychopath. When my class was Organising an outing, only a handful turned up;me included). My friend was feeling really upset about it and she couldn't stop complaining about it. I merely listened and nodded but I failed to feel sad about it. Taken aback, she gingerly ventured,"errr....aren't you affected? You don't seem affected at all. " yes,whoever you are,if you're reading this. I'm not "affected" and I know it since young because every time I want to understand how getting emotionally "affected" feels like, my ears will burn with callous remarks like "STUDY! Study! Don't you know that studying is important?" 

11. Relax, I'm not a true psychopath with all senses of the word. I don't inflict harm on anyone, I treat everyone with courtesy, I even donate regularly to charity. I'm not the one who poisons lab mates, I'm not a school bully, I don't flare up at anyone. I have never done bad things. I just don't feel love instinctively in my heart, and I am overly rational. 

12. There's no way I can be a loving and sensitive girl who can open up. There's no way I can understand how crying over a touching story feels like. There's no way of understanding breakups, as I don't feel love. But I don't do bad things, and I don't think evil thoughts.

Uh... I took a Less Peaceful route to solving my parental problems. I hope no one would do this, because it strains relations.

Any thing regarding family? 
Sorry, I don't have the time. I'm busy studying. Can you don't disturb me? Yeah, I am being your "good kid", being all "grown up", just as you wanted, right? I can cook for myself, provide for myself, live by myself (I actually do that, I don't stay with my family any more). STOP FUCKING COMING ANYWHERE NEAR ME.

Understand this: I was not exactly the most normal of children - I had ADHD. Somehow or rather, my mom decided that it was justified that "I would rather beat the fuck out of you, than let you take meds." 

That, and because of the large family I have, she tried putting as much things in my mind against my other family members, blaming me for any shit, reprimanding me for it. 

It was not really until my secondary school, when my ADHD went into something like a full-blown autism. Head banging onto the table, stabbing books, threatening to slice people with a wood planer (lol), etc..I didn't make it to the secondary school my mom wanted, you see, and she made sure I remembered, every other day, along the way of my secondary school life. 

Instead of making sure I got help, she just kept blaming me, saying that I "needed to grow up", "I am waiting for the day you grow up" "why must you be so childish? Can't you see others? Why can't you be more normal like them?" 

I got into JC. My GP teacher can poke at me for being in my "Lalaland", others can call me weird, call me names for running and jumping around, but hey, as long as life goes on, I can live another day, it's fine, right? I won't use my brain any more, I promise. If I use my brain, only bad, childish things will come out, right? I won't do it anymore. Just please, stop disturbing me.

You see, the thing about people like me, is that you can either whack us into submission as you hoped, or whack me into becoming a deadbeat, stubborn person. I turned out to be the latter.

I started showing signs of my other nature at home, randomly crying when I couldn't get an A, etc., and I don't remember being able to smile. This was when my family saw something wrong with me. After all, I was only worth something if I had gotten into a JC. I was anti-social. I refused to take part in anything social. I exhibited escalated violent tendencies, from when I was in secondary school. During PE Lessons, I would just run by myself, while others play games. They could ask me why I was like that, but they would just get shot instead.

It was around NS, that I actually moved out of that hellhole of a terrace house, into living alone in the HDB flat that she owns today. 

Peace and tranquility. It was something I sought after, but never really got. I quarreled with them, telling them outright to let me live in peace, that as a person who was going through NS (seriously man, NS, a very nice card to use), I should have the right to my independence. And I fought with them for it. 

Your grandson is at fault, you better fucking admit it. Yes, I am not afraid to talk back to you. Respect? Sorry arh, why the fuck must I respect you just because you're older? You've done a very good job having this kind of grandchildren eh?

Unfilial son? Been called that many times. "Someday, you will get struck by lightning for treating me this way" Yup. Someday, I will, but well I'm still standing here, am I? 

You can blame me, call me a monster, but has anyone apologised for turning me into one? I don't think an apology should be in place, nor should one be needed. I'm here today, ain't I?

Throughout these few years of my uni life, living alone, I learnt to become more responsible for my actions. I learnt, I grew. I started to be able to think properly again, recently, though unfortunately I was 3 years too late. The sparks that died, recently got revived again (mostly because I haven't been around people who keep putting it out). True, that part of me that is partially psychotic still lives, but I am dealing quite well with it. I would say that I can deal with it very well because I have experience with it. The key is to channel it into something useful, like... Spontaneous Randomness!!! Woooo~~~~~~ That, and being more confident helps a lot. You'll be surprised.

Still learning how to feel and interact with other people though - the problem being, if you're a tank, you just tank, but you tend to overlook things that others do not tank.

My friend has constantly told me, "Hate is like hot coal. You'll hurt yourself if you hold on to it. Why are you holding on to it?" I look back, hey, it's a lot of rage, a lot of hate, a lot of childishness. 

I can only sit here, laugh at it, and look forward. In a moment of rashness, I hurt a lot of people. Relations are better now, and I have reached newer levels of understanding with my family (though still, as separate uh... cells? I have to keep a safe distance from them still, for no-bullshit reasons).

Point being, we can always drag such bitterness around, but it is what we do from now that will change, and define us. Having too much flaming baggage, ain't it a bit tad heavy and incendiary for flight?

Honestly, I'm fed up with the bunch of friends and whispherers who keeps posting stuff about how no one understands what an extroverted introvert is.

Pleeease. You're just being a normal person. It's entirely Normal for a person to feel tired after talking with people for an hour at a party. You don't possess introverted superpowers like being able to stay at home doing work/hobby for an entire month without needing to talk to another person to relieve stress.

And if you find it strange why other people can continue talking for hours. It's more likely because their sucking their thumbs and putting up with you, and not going around facebook complaining about how tired they're actually feeling.

Either you tell us face to face that you're feeling tired during our gatherings, or you jolly well put up with it. We had already allocated time to meet up with you, so how do you think we feel when we get home and see you complaining about it on facebook?

-
 
 hmm... bring some mutual friends along for the lunch. 

I don't think his violent tendencies will act up, after all, what you see on social media is just one side of the person (more often than not, an extreme side, a lot of people don't get that). 

Coming from perhaps, one of those "mentally ill" people, your friend might just be extremely lonely. It's a form of reaction, but the fact that people actually avoid it makes it A LOT worse. 

"I am not wanted,why are they doing this? Why are THEY like that?" It pretty much becomes a "me vs them",downward spiralling perspective. 

If you want to help your friend, and are sincere about it, I am hoping that you can put in the immense amount of patience and effort, to listen and be his friend. Be sincere, and extremely patient about it, make it such that he "cannot peel away your facade".

Find out what makes him tick, and slowly (can take months,etc.,) normalise him. Make him understand that there is a life outside that can be more enjoyable than where he's cooped out now. 

I hope this helps, because I was there once; I wore out the patience of many friends, and ended up regretting it.
-
 
Anyone still using Letterbox? LOL
-
 
I really hate socialising. And there are a few reasons how I've come to this.
In JC, I was pretty much known by everyone in school. Not trying to show off or anything here; I was involved in a lot of "unofficial" cca's, projects, and events so I was able to maintain a very close relationship with all of my classmates. I led a social project with 20++ members, all of whom I personally convinced and inspired. I wasn't the fun-popular type, but people came to me and told me their deep secrets and worries. I was good at listening, and people needed that, as they were facing exams and stressful mugging nights.
But after those years, I realised that nothing was left for me. When I socialised in the past, I would never look at the benefits; people seemed happy when I listened to them, sympathised with them, gave advice, and crack a few jokes along the way. And I enjoyed making them happy. Before coming to uni, all I realised was that there was no time left for me. I knew nothing about myself and didn't even have enough self-esteem. I was skilled at earning trust, and I was partially doing this by bringing myself down.
So when I came to uni at last, I started dreading those socialising sessions. It's not that I don't have any friends; I still have a number of people I can really trust, and I feel proud of myself for already having formed those relationships after only one semester of uni life. But I hate it when we have to stand up, 'network', and talk about superficial matters. I'm tired of asking people how their mods this sem are. I've already asked the question, "how was your break?" too many times. I really don't get the importance of those networking, socialising sessions. People say you should know as many people as possible because they can potentially help you in the future, but that feels too fake. So now I have a tendency of drawing a line between those I consider as deep relationships and those I don't.
So this sem, I've started to do a lot of things alone. I would meet my close friends everyday for a few hours, and Skype with those who are abroad for another hour or so, but I leave all the rest to myself. Excluding the time I spend talking to people during classes, since I have some great classmates this sem. And I've started to enjoy that. I love walking to classes alone and watching people on the way, paying attention to the weather and thinking about how I'm going to spend the day. I love spending some time everyday to read and do some extra studying for my major (by the way, I'm kind of in love with my major right now, which is also another reason I've come to like playing solo). I love thinking to myself, and I don't see a reason to share it verbally all the time. And when I would have hard times, or when my like-minded friends have problems, I would listen to them or talk to them for long hours. But I would spend all those 'petty' and in-between hours alone.
But I think the social stigma on solo-play is kind of a big pressure for me. I really love my life; I love the balance, and I've never felt lonely, living a life like this. (In the past, when I would socialise with everyone and have NO time to myself, then I would feel truly lonely.) I have the best friends in my life right now, and I simply cannot describe how close I feel to them. However, the way other people see me is very difficult to handle. They see me as a unsociable, shy person, which is in fact a personality created by choice. I wish I had the nerve to ignore all these judgemental views, but I can't mainly because I'm surrounded by a lot of people who care significantly about their sociability. How can I endure this? Am I living my life the right way? If I'm happy and satisfied, isn't that all that's important?
-
 
Hi guys, just some tips for singles surviving V-day.

1. Stay away from social media, dont check facebook, dont instag, twit and especially dont post anything. Seeing friends' couple pics and vday plans or posting something sad really does not help the situation and we are better off not having other people's romance shoved into our faces.

2. Channel any negative emotions, loneliness, frustration, fear or sadness from rejection into useful energy, such as learning an instrument, learning to bake a new dish, learning something that improves us as a person, you'll feel better about yourself and be occupied this week, 

3. Accept the fact that you are single, and also realise that you are not alone, despite lovely dovey couples all over you, other fellow singles arent exactly parading their statuses as well, there are many around you who feel the same and would like some company, even as just friends. Graduate surveys state only 40-50% are in a rship upon graduation so really, half your peers are single as well.

4. Get out of the house, dont stay home watching dramas or playing computer games, pick an event, and get out of the house, there are many this weekend if you do a quick google search, doesnt matter if you go with friends or go alone, and when we are there, just have a good time, buy a drink/snack, say hi to a stranger who seems to be there alone as well, any single you meet out there is a more outgoing, friendlier and likely a better match for us than one staying at home, be apart of that community!

5. Do some reflection and resolve for some change, just as how we make new year resolutions, we can make v-day resolutions for the next year as well, if we have always been single, what have we done over the past year to change that? Sitting around waiting for the "right one" doesnt exactly work anymore, for the right one to find us, we have to provide opportunities for him or her to meet us! 

Its really not so bad, and im sure anyone in a rship will agree that one of the most exciting parts about love is the search and the chase, the hope and excitement knowing that there is a small chance we meet someone, gets us up in the morning each day, but we have to help ourselves improve the odds by taking some action! getting out there, and simply saying hi!
-
 
Present: "No one owes you anything." That is so true and has been validated through my experience, and intensified through pain. No one owes you a helping hand, their sympathy, empathy, kindness, loyalty, honesty, understanding, love and so much more. Beneath all that lies on the surface, that seems to be the reality despite occasional anomalies. As I tear up and break time and again, I constantly question if after all this while, I have ever gotten stronger or is it that the path that has chosen me and at the same time, which I have chosen for myself is just getting increasingly arduous to thread. At such moments, I wish the world had been different and perhaps myself as well.

Past: But it is also in such moments, that I remember you having been part of my life and it always seems as though it was only a while back. I see myself living in three separate times, the past, the present, and the future. And the past that haunts me is also the past that etches your presence in my mind. Thank you for having believed in me and I think it's your presence and such thoughts of you having believed in me that has always helped me push through during my tough times.

Future: Just as no one owes me anything, so too does it seem that I owe nothing to anyone, and you might think I owe nothing to you. I doubt that is true, but nevertheless, I owe myself lots. Amongst all that I owe myself, including a reason for my existence and the privileges that I have, I not just think but also feel that I owe myself a reason to be truly worthy of your belief in me and the expectations you had of me, and a reason to be able to look you in the eye sometime in the future and thank you in person for all that you have done for me. Subconsciously before realisation due to pain, you had already become the most important person in my life, someone whom I highly regard and have the utmost respect for.

 Whar are some of the factors that motivates guys to take action and approach a girl they don't know (for her number, to strike up a convo etc.)?
Ans: You ask as if there is a general consensus among all guys which obviously isn't true. For me, I probably have a very complicated answer but here is the short version. It's mutual attraction and mutual attraction only. I have a lot better things to do than waste my resources including time on someone whom I'm not interested in. And just as in a relationship there's no point clinging onto someone who has no or lost interest in you, outside a relationship there's no point chasing someone who doesn't reciprocate my feelings. They may develop feelings (for me and not the chase) after my chase, but nah...

Conversely, what dissuades you from doing so? 
Ans: Lack of mutual attraction and other reasons I deem to be important which is context-/time-dependent, i.e. I have low self-esteem.

Continued from  [part 1]  [part 2]:  
The end wasn't an explosion, it was a fizzle. It ended without fanfare or drama. Looking back, it ended long before we acknowledged it. 
It was a snide comment from me about how I found his friendliness with people (Ok, to be specific, other girls) annoying. It was him, wanting me to love him more, give him all of me, when I felt I had given him everything already. It was me not replying to his messages the moment I got them and it was him stopping the texts. It was hug's that were brief and kisses on the cheeks at the end of the night instead of on the lips.
Somehow slowly we started to drift apart instead of difiring together.
We still loved one another, of that I had no doubt. 
I would do anything to make him happy but we just didn't work as a unit anymore. No longer did we finish each other's sentences.
Isn't that what a relationship was supposed to be? Two people working together, stronger together than separate. Inspiring each other to be better. But somehow along the way, we stopped being a unit. We had become individuals again. 
The last time we met up, it had become a breach that we couldn't deny anymore. His kiss felt like goodbye on my lips. After the first kiss we shared, this kiss became my next favourite. 
After the longest of time, this kiss was filled with passion. It felt for a moment as though he was trying to merge us both together. As if we could stop the inevitable crash if we just held on a bit longer. It was a kiss that was filled with all the "we could have been", "we should have tried more", and "fuck I miss what we had."
As we held onto each other after the kiss, he trails a finger down my nose to my cheek, and stops at the corner of my lip. His finger is moist. I had been crying. He drops a kiss on the tip of my nose. "I love you even now." "Me too," I reply. "But it's not enough is it?" "Not anymore." "Friends?" "The best kind. We are forever."
I am not sure if he could tell if I was lying. Perhaps he could. He was the only one who could tell when I was lying. He still smiled as I turned to walk away. He hugs me once more from the back(his fav way of hugging me), I lean into it and he drops his head onto mine. I try to memorise his unique smell; Marlboro, Hugo boss, and just his own scent all blended together.
We haven't spoken since then or tried to meet up. It's been 61 days. It hurts too much. Maybe he knows that if we met up, we would end up trying to make it work even if we know that in the end, we are better off apart than together. 
Walking away from him was the hardest thing I have ever had to do in my life. How can two people love each other so much but cannot find a way to stay together? It was 2 years of memories. 2 years of being one instead of two. But I know that this is the best thing for the two of us.
PS: I know you read this. I love you. Always. Take care Love!

 I am a guy and I empathize with your bf. I had been in his position before. 
My first love was someone who had three sexual, but not really serious relationships before. 
I had always wondered how it would be to do it with another girl, especially since she could never reach the big O no matter how hard I tried (neither did she with her previous partners).  I guess it's natural to have such thoughts, but it is important not to act on it and not to let it affect your relationship in any way.
She cheated on me and confessed a year later (we were together for 2 years at that point). She was repentant and I tried to get over it, but I couldn't. Apart from the loss of trust, I felt it would be grossly unfair that she got to have all the fun while I didn't even get to make a girl O. I broke up with her. 
At that point, I had just graduated and was worried if I had missed out on all the univ fun. I couldn't be more wrong. I had enough money to pay for "dates", and to rent a unit on my own. Getting girls to sleep with me was not a problem anymore. This is in spite of the fact that I slept only with those who were upfront about keeping it casual. My curiosity was sated, but I realized that sex is more fun when you're in a relationship. 
Eventually, I met someone and am in a very happy relationship now (getting married soon :D). She has had some experience too, so we've some parity in that respect.
