-
 
I recently read about the 80/20 rule of relationships (which I believe is trending on FB). I'm in a committed relationship myself, and I found it to be very true. Our partner is 80% of what we want, and there is no perfect human being out there. There is certainly that 20% of imperfection in everyone, including yourself. I love my boyfriend very much, and I appreciate all that he has done for me, and I to him. Of course there are times where things could have been better (beyond relationships, aren't there always instances where life can be better?). However, we should not immediately think of leaving someone who is 80% right for you, just because of that missing 20%. Yes, perhaps sometimes we see another guy that may have that missing 20% that your boyfriend doesn't have. I confess that sometimes I talk to some of male friends and wonder to myself how nice it would be if my boyfriend also had this interest/liked this sort of stuff, for instance (everyone has different likes and dislikes, and couples need not be 100% similar to each other). But I let myself stop at that, and think about everything else I love about him. I think this 20% is where friends come in, in our lives. There is no reason to leave your boyfriend simply because of that missing 20%, because you don't know other guys well enough, and they may really be only 20% right for you. We'll never be 100% satisfied, and that is okay. Anyone has any thoughts on 80/20?

Dear OP, I went through a similar situation. We found out my dad was having an affair too. I honestly when ballistic when I found out. It was hard but ignoring your dad is really not the way to go. You need to think about your siblings and most importantly yourself. Spending money unnecessarily was what my Dad would do even before we found out about the affair. I'm not sure how your relationship was with your dad prior to you finding out nor how your relationship was between your parents. Not saying is your fault either but people go astray when they do not feel welcomed at home. This is what happened in my case. I don't think I would ever be able to forgive him completely but it's what you need to do. You ignoring him makes him feel useless. Did you ever just come to this sudden realisation that your friendship is pretty much pointless? That you were just used all this while and nothing was ever reciprocated. Not that every favour had to be returned.But it would have felt good to be appreciated once in a while... I just woke up one day, having absolute no desire to sustain this friendship. I was always there for them but they were never there for me. My passive aggressive nature didn't quite aid me in this situation either. I never knew how to tell them how I felt. I was so afraid of coming off as sensitive and weak. Hence it resulted in continuous ignoring on my part. Ignoring calls, texts, SM notifications until they finally gave up. Oh and did I mention that these texts and calls were them requiring some sort of 'assistance' from me? To make things worse, I haven't made friends in Uni either. It took me quite a while to recover. I still have no friends. Zero friends to be exact. I was lonely for a while. But now I'm just alone. There's a huge difference! Being lonely gave me a chance to embrace solitude, which is being alone. It's a chance for you to examine who you really are. A chance for you to work on yourself. Feeding off other people's energy most of the time leaves you with so little time to reflect on your wants. I'm not telling everyone to cut off ties nor am I saying there's anything wrong with being an extrovert! Nothing wrong with socialising either. If you have great friends, treasure them! And if you need people around you most of the time, that's completely fine too! I know it doesn't relate to my situation, but it really upsets me to see those 'I'm so lonely posts', especially when V day is nearing. Take this time to work on yourself. Learn from past relationships and embrace this time you have for yourself! As cliché as it sounds, you do need to love yourself before you want to love someone else. And these posts just show that you don't. Stop dwelling in self pity. It got me no where. It hurts but you have to move on. Good luck! There's nothing wrong with being alone!

-
 
 Because there is a difference between outright rejection versus not giving a definite answer? Don't some girls sometimes do this too? Instead of outright rejection, she may say that she wants to know the guy more first. From what you're saying it seems to me that the guy wants to date w/o having given you a definite answer and w/o wanting to enter a r/s with you proper. I think it depends on the guy (as different persons have different mindsets when it comes to dating and entering a r/s) and you need to question his motive. Here are some possible reasons I can come up with: he thinks that he doesn't have feelings for you or is unsure of them at the moment, yet sees you as a potential partner; he isn't ready for a r/s due to psychological or whatever other reasons; he wants to lead you on; he doesn't mind dating anyone or getting to know someone more as the opposite party might eventually be his future partner; he is looking for benefits while wanting to avoid responsibilities and commitments (as in a r/s).

Here's what I would do if I were you. First, I would get a clear answer and explanation (w/o misunderstandings) of 1. how he really feels for you right now and 2. why does he want to date you, followed by asking myself if I can trust his answer. Finally, I will think if I really should date him given my own mindset and what I think I know to be true thus far.

 Only do things you don't mind doing? So for instance, if you don't like doing something yet don't mind doing it, go ahead. But otherwise, don't? That's how I think everyone ought to live their lives if they are to be worth living. I would suggest to go on study dates like once a week or something if that's ok with you. :) Reasons being:
1 - Who the hell doesn't study? o-O
2 - To get to really know someone, there definitely needs to be some time for talk and you can do that during meal(s) or after study/meal(s). For the latter, talk is after productive work has already been done and when both parties already don't feel like doing any more work. They can then both focus on the talk without being distracted (e.g. I should be doing work right now).
3 - Lines are less clearly drawn when you go on a study date with a person v.s. say, going to catch a movie with him if the former is what is more appropriate for both of you at this point.
4 - Maybe he hates texting in general as well (e.g. texts freaking slow, impersonal, distracting etc.). I think there is also a tendency for parties to want to be perceived as attractive/interesting over text and that's taxing for the mind when you or him has to come up with jokes etc.
5 - Plan is extremely simple and there are only two things to consider, time and place (guys will probably get slammed for this but that doesn't matter in your case I think).

-
 
My friends view me as a social butterfly, sporty and an outgoing girl who looks out for others. However, I am actually diagnosed with egomania and megalomania. My facade is used to gain trust from others, when in fact I don't really give a F about anyone. I am simply waiting to make use of them when I want to.

It was in secondary school when my obsessive streak started. As I was growing up, I started to find my identity. I have to be a winner and I don't see myself anything lesser than that. It was probably due to the bad influence of my parents. They were failures in life, but they always had high expectations of themselves and others, which resulted in the whole family's misery. At the time, I tried to lower my expectations and told myself that everything will be fine as long as I do my best. Instead, my parents started to belittle me and said very hurtful things to damage my self-esteem. From then on, I convinced myself I have to be better than others no matter what. And this conviction couldn't stop, because it just feels amazing to fantasize I was better than others. And it allows things to work out great as well. It was a short-term gratification though.

So what's my definition of being perfect? Surely there's always someone who is better than me right? To be honest, I have no idea. It just depends on how I was feeling at the moment. But the baseline is simple; I must dominate whosoever I feel like challenging, and ignore those who are not worth it. Even if you beat me to a battle today, I will let you celebrate your small victory. However I plan and look forward to the day when I beat you in ten battles and secretly gloat about it :P

While you may think I am merely an evil bitch with a psuedo mental condition, allow me to appeal to your humanity by stating that I have been seeking professional therapy occasionally to prevent myself from crossing the line, such as killing someone which I dream about sometimes. My actions are very extreme but I control myself to execute them without landing myself in jail. I recall an incident of stealing a schoolmate's phone and throwing it away during the O Levels to demoralize him because that guy is always an outstanding but rude student and I disliked him. It was quite satisfying to see him cry on the day results were released. He did well, but he was still disappointed. And I did better. I felt both happy and unhappy at the same time. I was happy because my plan worked, but I was unhappy because I missed the opportunity to get back on a whole list of people using the same strategy. Lame huh?

As I got older, I became more aware of my actions. Sometimes I feel a little guilty for my wrongdoings, but if I apologize to those I have surreptitiously harmed, I will be shooting myself in the face.  A year ago, I was wondering about the exact same things as you are right now. I was in the exact same place as you are. So it may seem as though this is a generic advice, but it's just what I went through from the exact same situation. 

I did go out with her on V-Day for the first time. It was a day of intimacy for us (emotionally, not physically). I thought it meant something, and it could grow into something special. It didn't. 

Just want to let you know that asking out on V-Day may not be as special as you think. If you're asking her out for the first time, V-Day just provides an excuse for you to do so. What matters is what happens after V-Day. Not that it's all on you, but the reciprocation you get on V-Day may not last as long. 

Watch out for signs afterwards, and be a bit mindful. It mayyy not be as positive as it would be on V-Day. 

And yes, your efforts do not stop at V-Day date. If the first date is extra special, keep in mind to maintain the effort level afterwards. 

Anyway, this is what I went through. I do hope that you have a positive experience! Good luck :)

-
 
My earpieces have an interesting function. 

Putting them on, the world around me does not matter. 
People along the corridors can become just faceless, moving blocks that I walk around.
Unless they're someone I know, and make an obvious gesture (or noise to break through the music, as someone did), I wouldn't actually notice anyone's faces (specifically, identities), which would explain why I've been told that I would tao people (my apologies,it was unintentional).

However, it also enables me to read body languages. 
Ironically, it is precisely that I cannot hear what others say, that I am actually rather sensitive to their gestures, their mouthing of a simple "thank you" when I hold the lift doors open, their playing of phones when you're speaking to them...

Unfortunately, I tend to read too much into it as well. Paranoia sets in, and I start panicking because I do not know how to respond. What to say? What to do? Will what I say be relevant? Should I say it? Such questions come flooding in.

I start reading people, and realise that, at times, I have to purposely ignore a person's presence (and it actually hurts quite a bit every time), or make my presence around a persons scarce, because I would make the person feel uncomfortable, and I'll feel unwelcome, if I ever engage with him/her.

You see, I don't deal very well with people  - it's extremely draining for me to hold a conversation, for some reason. I will soon drone away after a while. I get rather nervous and stressed when talking to people I do not know very well (ladies, in particular), and tend to go haywire. If an outgoing person suddenly just starts talking to me, the most I can muster is a "ok,uh... I see." because it is just too overwhelming.

Which brings about the point... Did that lady I met on the bus when school started just wave hi to me a few weeks back? Omg... Well... Sorry if I sort of ignored you. Perhaps, I might run into you on the bus again sometime? Well, perhaps, who knows, I might make a new friend.

Perhaps, I should just very well take off my earpieces.

Is it bad to be a bit of a patriot?

I keep saying that even if this country didn't conscript, I would have volunteered to enlist anyway. Having gone in, served my 2 years and gone out, my feeling hasn't changed, for what it is worth. I do feel bad, however, that SNAFU truly applies to the armed forces, and that it feels as if we who served were superfluous and forgotten. For better or for worse, for the chiong suas and kengsters, serving felt like something to be proud of, and it tears me up inside to see it, and the people above, below or alongside, for what all of it really is.

I'm curious to see how our country would fare in a hot war, and maybe feel a bit the hero doing my part. However wrong it truly is, for there is no denying that war is hell both tragic and farcical.

Part of me resents this country and the service for the way I felt from it, but I still take pride for being the boot on the ground, that I could stand up and be counted. Why didn't I sign on? But why would I? I can't answer this to myself rightly, the pride mixes with the cynicism.

I love this country, and I feel bad that doing my time didn't feel as good as I hoped, as I thought it could.

I don't want to be a forgotten serviceman

In the beginning of this sem, my boyfriend and I had planned to take this same mod together. I had planned my timetable and shared with him those tutorial timing which I was taking for the mod. But a few days later he told me he couldn't take the that tutorial during that timing as he plans on taking another mod's tutorial with his friends. At that time, I didn't think much of about it so I compromised and agreed to push back that tutorial timing by an hour to take it with him. However, on the day of the tutorial itself, as I sat there for 2 hours outside the building and attempt to study while waiting alone, time passed by painfully slow. And I felt slightly uncomfortable thinking that he so willingly pushed aside my plan just to take the tutorial with his friends. It made me feel as if I was not as important as his friends. 

So a few days ago, I told him I wasn't comfortable waiting 2 hours for lesson to start (afterall my day starts really early on that day and I'll get tired) and I'll be taking it at the timing which I had originally planned to take instead. In the meanwhile, to my horror, I also found out from him that he wasn't exactly taking it with a group of friends. He had planned to take that tutorial with another girl. What's more poignant is the fact that he pushed aside my plan aside after I had shared with him my timetable because this girl couldn't make it for the tutorial on other days. I gave him and option to take that tutorial with me today after explaining that I would feel uncomfortable knowing that he's attending a class with some girl which I don't know about while I wait alone. However, much to my disappointment, and after I had explicitly explained to him, he still went ahead to take it with that girl. Don't get me wrong, I have nothing against him taking lessons with other friends at any other timing. But this incident truly reveals where I stand in his life as compared to his friend. And to be honest, I feel extremely disappointed in him because it made me feel like I'm not his priority and I thought he could be better than that. 

What do you guys think?

Recollection:

While dining at the UTown dining hall today, I met a 'marvellous' girl by the name of Y. I know her and now have escapades with her in the east, but I didn't realise Y now lives in the residential college.

Here's the story.

I liked Y when Y was still attached to another guy, who we can call D. As far I know Y, she was a dominatrix and was overpowering D. I used to allow D to confide in me over Y. D would say that, for all of his skills, he could find no way to satisfy Y. So I tried to teach him a few tricks, but deep down, I was curious about Y.

Fast-forward to the day of fun: we had cider. Then we had some wine. And then she was saying that I was weak. I then challenged her to whisky. She accepted. I demanded she drink first. Y then promptly enslaved her life to me. Poor her. She was begging me literally to take her home, which I did, and accompanied her for the night. She was ridiculously hard to resist and I thought D was so damn lucky; she was smart, witty and had the sexual drive and attraction to turn any guy on and mad.

One day, Y suddenly confided in me with regards to D. She asked me whether D was completely committed to her. Confused (pretentiously), I asked, how so. She then spilled all about her "needs", and the more she said, the more I was shocked. Shocked because she was really like a guy more than a girl: having sexual needs that needed to be gratified, and that D just won't cut it.

Then she suddenly asked... P, should I break with D? In return, I know you actually like me very much.

Skipping all the details, according to her, I gave her the best night possible, but now that I glance at her, I am myself sometimes afraid. Each time we see each other for dinners, it almost always ends up in me staying overnight at her house without D knowing.

A few weeks ago, I heard Y and D having the most serious argument in a while. The problem? D confided in me again, that Y said that thrice a week was insufficient. D contended that his FYP meant that he couldn't meet Y as often as he would like, but Y would have nothing of that. I was conflicted because I was already involved should Y and D break up. Yet I like Y, and we have already got sexual.

Admittedly I am afraid myself, meeting her twice a week is already beginning to be slightly taxing even though she is still quite a desirable girl, except her almost insatiable desire for something normally men would want more.

I didn't say hi to her for fear that I'd spend a night in the residential college when I could have been studying. You see, I don't always have condoms with me.

May be you could try to ignore him and see if he restarts the convo again? Depending on the contents of the conversation between you two, it may be any of those reasons stated above! Or you can just ask him outright if you're brave enough. That's the best way forward I feel. Take care!

-
 
@15923
It depends on your relationship with that group of friends.
For me, my life revolves around a few groups of people. 
My core - the guys that I grew up around that I'd happily give life and limb for.
My secondary group - guys which I've been friends with for a while and get along just fine. However, despite being close with these guys, they're not exactly family. Nonetheless, I'd be happy to help them out whenever they're in need

The minor circles - people who I've no choice but to hang out with like classmates or maybe people I just got to know that I'm not close to. People here are either here to provide temporary companionship in certain situations or they are simply well connected and may be of use to further my agenda in the future.

Id be more than happy to split the cash with my "core" group of friends. I've grown up with them and I see them as part of my own family. Hence, I wouldn't feel apprehensive sharing any good fortune I have as I know they'd do the same for me.

The second group is slightly trickier. I would vaguely tell them that I received an unexpected windfall but not from that particular lucky draw and treat them to a crazy night out or maybe a meal at Joel Robuchon.

The last group? It's a lot trickier cause fuck em. You don't really wanna invest too much money on them unless there's individuals there that are well connected and could help you land that prestigious internship you always wanted or they're filthy rich already and you wanna build rapport with them because of the free country club visits, club tables and whatnot.

At the end of the day, do whatever makes you the happiest but keep in mind it's a dog eat dog world and not everyone is willing to share that money with you.

My current one is starting to do the same. Ever since I told him about my past, and how I'm not a virgin anymore, he thinks about it and gets sour at me suddenly at times. He peeked at my whatsapp (accidentally or not) and saw my guy friends talking to me, and ever since that he has been really frustrating me. He monitors my whatsapp 'online's and blue ticks. He assumes that I'm talking to guys if he sees me 'online' but not on his chat. I explain to him everytime to avoid him misunderstanding, but sometimes his accusations just cause me to feel really wronged. I have tried to reassure him many times, but every time my phone sounds to alert me of a notification, or every time he sees my guy friends online in game (yeah he adds them), or every time i do something that may be related to them (like playing a piano game when the guy plays piano), he thinks they are talking to me, flirting with me, playing games with me even more than I do with him (which is not true, I don't even play that much with my other friends), or tells me he doesn't like the game because he must have introduced me to it. I really don't know what to do. He says he trust me, but I really find that really hard to believe. This arguing has been going back and forth for a year now. I've tried to talk it out with him, but nothing seems to work. It doesn't help that it's an LDR and we only see each other once every half a year.. I feel like crying because I feel so lonely, I really don't know what to do.

Thanks for hearing me out, I just wanted to let it out.

I'm in a dilemma. There's a close female friend of mine who recently wanted to borrow an interest-free four digit sum from me. She said she need the money to pay for her brother's school fees. Although my parents are well-to-do professionals, I am not. Ever since I entered NS and subsequently NUS, the only thing they provide me is a roof over my head. My phone bill, utility bills, food, transport and school fees are all paid for by myself using the money I earned as a freelancer and savings from NS. Therefore, I know I won't be able to lend her this amount of money, considering my own financial constraint.

Ya, I know the easiest way is to just say NO straight in her face. However, she is a really good friend of mine and she's real gorgeous. I don't like her romantically, but it's a male ego thing to find it harder to say no to pretty girls right? Also, she knows my family is well-off and a four digit sum is trivial to us. Hence, I am afraid she may think that I am being a miser if I do not help her out. 

However, based on past experiences, she does not have the habit of properly returning things. She once borrowed my book because she said her friend is looking for the book but cannot find it. So I passed it to her to lend it to her friend as I've finished reading it. And guess what? After a whole year, she never mentioned anything about the book. So naturally I asked her if her friend has finished reading it, and she said he had read it, then she gave me his contact details and told me to find him to get it back. WTF?! I don't even know him! It will be really awkward for me to go up to a random stranger and say "Hey give it back. That belongs to me!" Hence, I never saw the book again. This is not the only time I find it hard getting things back from her. A few of my stationary, magazines, textbooks, water bottle etc. are long gone. >:O

Returning to the money issue. Although I can easily ask my parents to lend her the money instead, my greatest fear is that she does not or find it hard to return the money, this may sour the relationship between all parties, since my parents take the notion of personal responsibility very seriously.

I don't believe she's greedy or selfish, but she's just very irresponsible, low self-awareness and take things too lightly. When a person borrow something on someone's behalf, he/she is obliged to take responsibility for the transaction. They must make an effort to place clearing their liabilities at the top of the list! People can't just start returning things only when it is convenient for them to do so! 

Although I personally explained all these to her countless times, she will just say "Okay sorry!" with a cute smile, and then she'll forget everything I told her. Should I not lend her a single cent with the risk of affecting our friendship because the money is important to her brother's future, or should I lend it to her with the risk of not seeing the money again? Help!!! D:

-
 
So I've seen a lot of people confessing that they do not know what a guy is thinking through their texting habits. Firstly, if you think he isn't interested then you're most probably right. If a guy likes a girl, he would go that extra mile to reply her messages as soon as he can and he will not do funny things like reading your message and then go offline before replying you much later. And as for the initiating conversation part, if it's you who's always initiating the conversation, he doesn't like you. Simple as. I mean he could like you if he tries to keep the conversation going. But if he keeps wanting to end the conversation by giving you shitty replies, then you should probably stop bothering him and move on with life. I know it's hard to accept that someone you adore so much doesn't like you back, but this is the cold hard truth. You should move on to better things in life that are worthy of your time.

-
 
 It's hard to say if the guy will find you irritating given the limited information. He might have lacked initiative or was unresponsive previously for the following reasons:
1. He's in fact giving you the space that he thinks you need.
2. He thinks you find him irritating.
3. He thinks you're not interested in him.
4. He thinks you're playing hot and cold or whatever mind games girls nowadays play.
5. He thinks you're irritating.
6. He's busy.
7. His interest for you has faded or he's uncertain.
1 - 4 especially possible if you were previously seemingly disinterested or unresponsive.

These are some reasons I can think of and I think you're the best to decide which category or categories apply to you and whether if you should still initiate conversations.

-
 
Advice to those trying to enter a relationship:
1) Don't give up, keep trying
2) Romance does not drop from the sky; it takes effort

Trust me, I failed several times before I got into a good and stable relationship now. I did embarrassing things, like confessions on V-Day. I experienced lots of awkward moments pursuing girls. I cried after rejections, feeling lonely, miserable and depressed. But I emerged stronger, more resilient and more confident. Most importantly, remember that your crushes / people who rejected you are also human. If they reject you, it's NOT about you. They might have different priorities or needs, and not because they don't exactly like you or even dislike you. And don't overly romanticize them (or hate those who rejected you too much). Always pick yourself up, and tell yourself that at least you have fallen in love before, and have tried.

Dear ,
You may want to search up the term 'sexual fluidity'? 
I think it's quite common that at some point of time people might feel attracted to someone of the same sex. 
However, the important thing is to find out what you're truly feeling. Is it pure admiration (since you mention she's highly intelligent & very good looking), lust or love?
Ask yourself questions: Can you picture a future rs with a female? Or are you just curious about girl x girl rs? 
Don't worry too much about it & take time to slowly figure out your feelings & thoughts. 
I guess the last resort would be to consider dating women & see if you're comfortable with that. If not, you can always go back to dating men (:
All the best  xx

But everything changed when the fire nation attacked. Nah jkjk. In the second month, things changed when she suddenly became very moody all the time, and even constantly had suicidal thoughts. They slowly became worse when she actually tried to commit suicide, and I had to drag her off the edge a rooftop and pin her down while she struggled.

She was having quite a stressful time, with the endless work, projects and presentations from school, and there were also problems at home. As (arguably) her only pillar of support, I sacrificed a lot of time and effort to be there for her and to stop her if need be.

Things got better in the third month and things became smooth sailing again, until the last month of our relationship. We kept quarreling more often, even over the smallest of things, and she often blew it up to exaggerated proportions. 

During one of our fights, she said that the reason why she had the suicidal attacks was because of me. I was really puzzled. Me? What could I have done? She continued on saying she constantly felt very insecure around me, and I didn't give her enough security and comfort. But the thing is, I showered her with so much affection, attention and love and we had such a great time before she had the attacks. How could I be the cause????

A week later, she broke up with me. I honestly didn't know/still don't know how to feel about all of this because I feel like I've  been wronged.

Hello NUS friends! I graduated from NUS Law in the last academic year and am now working. Although work is tough, life is relatively stable and I'm earning a comfortable amount. My social life is fine - I'm busy but still stay in touch with friends. But here's the issue... I want a girlfriend.

I broke up with my ex-girlfriend in 2013, after a long relationship that went down in flames. Ever since then, I hardened my heart to the idea of a relationship, focusing solely on school, work and securing myself a good job. I can't complain because those years were fulfilling and I did well for myself. But now, as I see peers in love, dating and getting married, regret is starting to set in. 

In school, it was really easy to meet people, particularly when I took modules at the main campus. It was not strange to speak to strangers in classes. Things are very different now. Its odd and awkward to speak to strangers in public and certainly creepier still to ask a random girl for her number. In the workplace, there are barriers and I don't think my colleagues or myself would countenance an office romance. Long working hours also limit dating potential - even those in relationships confide in me that they can't spend sufficient time with their significant others or worse, they don't have enough time to get to know their significant others. SO YES, ADVICE HERE! PLEASE GO AND DATE AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE WHILE IN UNI. 

I've tried dating apps, but it has never worked out. I suspect because there's little to go by except your photos and a short description, looks matter a lot. And I'm fat. I'm also troubled by the extremely cursory way people get to know each other on dating apps.

So here comes the crux of it - I want to get to know more people. Any advice on that? And also, being sort of out of touch, do looks matter a lot to girls, too? I'd like honest opinions. 

Lastly, and this is a shameless sell out, if anyone would like to get to know me or give me advice, I've created an email account just for this purpose: a0073408@hotmail.com.

To the guy who wants some advises on how to see signs that a girl is interested. 

The thing is, if you're interested in someone (this applies to both genders), you should try to invite the person out politely for ..anything! Politely ask for what the other party is interested in, hang out, get to know the person, and progress on. 

Back to your question, it's honestly difficult to tell whether a person's genuinely interested in you just basing on text messages. Let me give you my personal experiences. I have learned not to trust and rely so much on text messages because several guys have texted me before, and this may just be my case, but things didn't always turn out well. So now I become cautious around text messages, until the person is brave enough to ask me out, or at least we still have face-to-face interaction, then I can trust the person and continue on with the messages. Does it mean that I'm not interested? No. It's just that text messages don't reveal so much of a person than face-to-face interaction. All I'm trying to say is, there are many angles in seeing this "ignoring message" thing, the best way is, ask the girl out and be genuine in getting to know her more in real life. :) 

Plus, I believe many people would feel delighted to be asked out. If she's uncertain about her feeling or don't have any particular one, give her some space and allow her to think about it. I believe it's time wasted on waiting for messages. Better be more pro-active (but not in an aggressive and invasive way) to get to know the person more. :)

Hope this helps! Cheers~

A common trait among these commentators is how they like to show off. Be it their assumed-to-be-correct liberal views against a conservative, their apparent abundance of sexual experience against a first-timer, their presumed intellectual prowess against a slightly dull student, or their self-proclaimed Very Successful Life against a struggling soul, without fail, their comments will appear to be giving advice, but between the lines subtly belittling the OP while stroking their own ego.

If you want a person to go away, don't avoid him outright. Instead, just act natural. The more unnatural you act, the more I actually mind you. 

I understand that somehow or rather, things have become awkward as friends, but if you would want to avoid me, just be natural, really - I will just fade away, like many other acquaintances before me.

Trust me when I am typing here, that I am making a conscious effort to avoid you as well. I do not have a social media account, and I don't want to ask for your number for no apparent legit reason(that's a bit creepy to me).

If you act unnaturally, you are showing and emphasizing that you mind my presence. Don't do that. Take it from me. It's bad for your mental health, fretting over something that is unconfirmed. I do not want to end on bad terms on your side either.

I'll admit it, I liked you. Given that I have only known you for around half a sem, I really hoped to make an effort to know you better, to decide on things.

Confess to a girl on her birthday, and with a card? Unless she has a super huge crush on you to begin with, good luck.

It's her birthday and instead of saying "happy birthday", you said "I love you". Think of the shock, disbelief, and huge betrayal of trust if she only sees you as a good friend or perhaps an acquaintance. 

Try asking the new girl out on dates, and tell the new girl face to face next time. And read more nuswhispers, and watch "How I met your mother" (when Ted first met Robin). I'm making the assumptions that you have not gone on dates, and test ioi (indication of interest) enough before your confession of a lifetime. Honestly, I think being super direct, cheesy lines, or being flirtatious will work better than such sentimentality. 

It's fine, a lot of people have been a noob before too.

Best Regards,
BSG

We are strong advocates of "己所不欲，勿施於人" (What you do not wish upon yourself, do not extend it to others) which in turn give us strong mutual trust. For those who have given up faith in relationships, don't give up! A relationship can be perfect (in your eyes) when you find someone with the same values and beliefs.

-
 
On a random reflection why people tend to meet their partners overseas. Quite a few people I knew met their partner overseas (including myself). Being in another country gives you the feeling of absolute freedom (of course this is exaggerated) but the uplift of restrictions and responsibilities make you feel akin to that. 
The word 'adventure' comes into play. You would hardly say,"Let's have an adventure" in your own homeland because things are hardly new. You might be doing new things, going to new places- but some things like your companions remain constant. Overseas, everything is new. A new you, a new adventure, a new companion etc. More importantly, you actually realize it and appreciate new things. Things become refreshing-not only to you, but others' view of yourself too. 
With a new you, you had to build new friendships and relationships again. This gives you the chance to better control your social skills. Forced in a new environment, you had to make friends than break them. 
With all these factors in play, you feel closer when you meet your partner during one of those 'adventures' you had. Naturally, there are some assumptions here but this is just what I have observed.

so after reading  i went to watch Man Up (also because i was trying not to do school work) and i really liked it, despite the unrealistic ending.

the film resonated with me a lot - i took an extremely long time to get over my previous relationship because i didn't truly believe that i would meet someone better. half of the time i replay the good memories from the past, and the other half of the time i am cynical about the future. and i was also super risk-averse and self-conscious about putting myself out there. i always wanted to do things right, but never actually doing them because i would be over thinking things, before eventually putting off any plans i might have had.

and recently i have been trying to put myself out there a little more. baby steps, but i actually put my thoughts into actions. i tell myself that all the judgements you are feeling are actually just your imagination. nobody cares (enough to judge you). and that makes things easier, of sorts, getting over yourself. 

signed up on an online dating app recently, just to see how things go, and to try to know new people, just to get back onto the dating scene. well, so far things haven't been super positive (i.e no dates yet), but i'm not going to quit so soon. i know that part of me still doesn't quite believe that the future is going to be great, but at least despite that, i am still trying to make it better? 

so other than just ranting about my emotional state here, i guess any comments on how i can do this better/ how i can meet more people are also welcomed?

"The truth is that the more intimately you know someone, the more clearly you’ll see their flaws. That’s just the way it is. This is why marriages fail, why children are abandoned, why friendships don’t last. You might think you love someone until you see the way they act when they’re out of money or under pressure or hungry, for goodness’ sake. Love is something different. Love is choosing to serve someone and be with someone in spite of their filthy heart. Love is patient and kind, love is deliberate. Love is hard. Love is pain and sacrifice, it’s seeing the darkness in another person and defying the impulse to jump ship."

Guys and Girls, I hope this quote serves you well in times of adversity. Sure, it's never black and white in any relationships. But if you decided to be with a person, decided to love her/him. I begged you to be patient. This is coming from someone who have quite a few failed relationships because I refused to fix my own mistakes, only to keep looking for someone even better out there. I thought i had tried my best when in actual fact I didn't really. Looking back, there was this one time where for quite a while, I thought she was the one. But as time goes by, i began to see many of her flaws which i thought at that point in time was an absolute deal breaker. But I failed to see that she was still the same girl i fell in love with. Witty, funny and loving in her own ways. The constant fights that plaque the last few months of our relationship completely made me forgot about all the good times we had. I thought she had changed. But on hindsight, that was her defying her impulse to jump ship. I wish I hadn't let you go :( Sorry

-
 
#thingsilearnfromrejections

note: this is from a guy's perspective and I thought by typing out all this would be therapeutic and cathartic for me, and maybe it can help someone out there too :) 

1. don't be the rebound.

Rebounds seldom if ever work out and some of the reasons why is because:

1) She haven't really moved on and will subconsciously project the feelings/image of the ex onto you. And the worst thing that can happen is when comparisons start to surface eg: "my ex-bf use to do this and that for/with me, why can't you do the same." 

2) She still has a lot of emotional baggage and is just not ready to be in a relationship yet and this could due to a myriad of reasons such as there wasn't any closure or she just needs more time. 
The amount of time needed to move on is different for people and you shouldn't force or pressurize the other party to be in a relationship with you if they are just not ready. 

3) She gives you signs of interest but the reality is that she jsut misses the feeling of being in love and the routine of a relationship

tl;dr: if you can, try to avoid being the rebound or using others as a rebound.

The thing is we don't even have mutual friends whom I'm close to, so she couldn't have known what I told my close friends. We are from different faculties, so our closest friends don't mix. And mind you, I never spoke ill of her, and never accused her of anything or slandered her when talking to my friends about the breakup.

So now I'm being portrayed as the bad guy and she as the victim, when I never did anything wrong. With her big mouth (yes rude but sorry not sorry), her whole faculty probably thinks very badly of me.

What am I supposed to do?

-
 
TL:DR Life isn't a smooth sailing journey and it doesn't have to be. Do what you like and accept what you don't if it can't be changed

I always been wanting to share this post but after reading SP confession , 166 https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=738624486239751&id=329564370479100, I decided to share this story.

I joined a CCA for the entire 3 years of my poly life. I faced many problems in this CCA. I was disliked by the club members, coaches, seniors. The timing was also very bad. My lesson on Friday ended at 12pm but my CCA starts at 7pm. As I live far from SP, I had to stay in school for the entire 7 hours. Imagine people saying, "TGIF" at 12pm but I could only went home after 9.30pm.
 
That wasn't all. I have a weak stamina and several people actually gave up and quitted the CCA halfway because of that. Moreover, many of my friends changed CCA throughout their poly life.

Imagine the amount of influences I had to change a CCA?

Not only did I joined the same CCA for the entire 3 years of my poly life, I also went for training even during holiday despite living far away from SP.

Many things in life aren't perfect. Many things come with flaws. To commit to one CCA, what ever keeping you there(which in my case was interest) must be stronger than what is chasing you out(in my case social exclusion, timing, distance from home, stamina, peer pressure)

This advise also apply to a relationship. A relationship isn't a smooth sailing journey. Your partner will bound to have some flaws. 
-You might end up having less time for your other friend(social exclusion)
-He/she might be late often(timing)
-He/she might live far from you(distance)
-You might want exercise with him/her just to spend more time with her even if you aren't fit(stamina)
-His/her friend might not like you(peer pressure)

When that happens, ask yourself this. Can you accept those flaws?

I am not encouraging you to find flaws with your partner and leave. I am telling you to have a realistic view of relationship and hopefully, you can tolerate some of the flaws and continue the relationship if you really like the him/her.

What do you do when you miss someone a lot? And that someone is already attached. And you just can't seem to forget that person no matter what. Its just do difficult.

To  and anyone yearning and pining for someone else,
Over-dependency on a certain person is kind of like addiction. Try watching this short (4min) video from 1:46 (or from the beginning :) ) for some good advice!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N-g5V27Jyus#t=1m46s

Have more friends and connections: the more relationships you have, the less attachment you have to any one person. To start getting rid of attachment, go and try new things! Finding a passion/hobby will take your focus off that certain someone/something.

Best of luck!

-
 
To , 

I can understand how you're feeling now as I was in a similar situation as you a year back.

I cried all the time for almost a year, but looking back I've really come very far. Thought I'd share some tips with you: 

1. Make a conscious decision to stop telling him things. Send other friends that funny link, get advice/ share your happiness with other friends instead of him. Type the message to him out of habit, but delete it before you send it over. You'll get used to it after a while and the emotional connection will weaken in time. Resist the urge to tell him things when you meet him as well. 

2. Let yourself feel all the emotions. I've always been a generally happy person, so crying so frequently was rather strange for me. However I realised that just accepting and feeling your emotions is the best way to get better. Cry as much as you need to, write out your feelings, write a song, feel all the hurt and pain and tell yourself you'll be ok despite it. One day you'll realize that the crying has stopped, and the pain comes a lot less frequently. 

3. Talk about it. Talk to your close friends, listen to their advice (or not). But talking about it always helps. See a counsellor if you need to. I saw the one at UHC for a semester!

4. Focus on the fact that there are so many other people who love you, even though he didn't. Spend time with friends and family and strengthen the relationships that matter to you. You'd be surprised as to how much better you'd feel being around these people. Remind yourself that you are worthy of love.

5. Put in the effort to meet new people. I joined new CCAs, went on school trips, made friends with group mates. Looking back now, I realized 2015 was the year that I made the most meaningful new friendships, and I'm so grateful to have crossed paths with these people. Talk to that cute guy in your class to distract you, but remember not to get into a rebound relationship (that shit does not work). 

6. Focus on improving yourself. Work out, put in more effort in school work, focus on building your character. Volunteer at an old folks home. Take up that new hobby that you've always wanted to try. Remind yourself that the best way to meet someone who's the most suitable for you is to focus on being the very best person that you can be. Most importantly, work on being someone that you are proud of. 

7.  Forgive him, and genuinely wish the best for him. I have always loved him, and I think a small part of me always will. Don't hate him and get rid of all negative emotions towards him - you're only giving yourself more baggage to deal with. Accept that you guys are not meant to be. Want the very best for him anyway. 

8. Tell him how you feel. It took me a long time to be fully honest with that guy. He didn't give me any closure or any answers whatsoever, but the honesty really helped me get over the situation. Sometimes the lack of a response is the very answer that you need. 

9. Take it one step at a time. Its cliche, but its true. I used to cry a few times a day, but I'd tell myself that its ok and it will get better soon. Without realizing it, days, and slowly weeks will past between the last time you cried over him. You'll no longer think about falling asleep in his embrace. He will not be the first person you think of when you wake up. You'll look back and realize that you got a lot better just by taking baby steps. 

10. Keep contact with him to a minimum. I know you still see him around and talk to him. You don't have to avoid him entirely, but don't talk to him as much. Tell him honestly that his presence is affecting you, and ask him to keep his distance if possible. You don't have to pretend that everything is ok. 

11. Don't give up on love just yet! Work on healing yourself, and becoming the best version of you. Don't get into rebound relationships to distract yourself / seek the love that you crave. Look within yourself and your support system to make you whole again. Remind yourself that it is possible to love again.

Hope this helps somewhat! The road ahead may be tough, but you'll emerge a stronger person, I promise. You can do it! Till then, keep your chin up and remember to take baby steps! =)

@ 

Hello, "passive" guy here. I chose not to make a move on a girl I like(d?). 

I think, even now, I still think that she's the perfect girl for me. She's brilliant, true to herself, unafraid of showing how much she's into her fandoms... and I think I like that about her. She came into my life when everything else seemed quite uncertain, and I don't think that I could have gotten through my first semester without her.

I chose not to act, because I thought she wasn't interested in me. I think somewhere along the line since that point I realized I was wrong, but who knows - feelings come and go, and the only thing I can do is regret that I gave up too early. 

And so I chose instead to look at her (to love her?) from afar. Some part of me knows that she'll be happier with someone else, seeing as we lead such different lives, but another part of me knows that I have all the right in the world to try, but I don't want to sour the memories of times that I once shared with her if it all ends in an ugly falling-out.

I feel like you're misunderstanding guys here. Sometimes, we're anything but passive - sometimes, we want to move, but if moving comes with the risk of losing you forever, we won't, because you are just -that- important. We do stupid things, like doubting ourselves and giving up too early. We attempt to justify these things to ourselves, and sometimes these things become self-fulfilling prophecies. Sometimes, we answer shitty NUSWhispers because we feel that twinge of regret in our hearts.

And so it goes.

Be passive, caring for someone from afar, and etc is silly. 

Like what a certain poster has mentioned previously something along the line of there is no such thing as "Like girl, confess to girl, get attached and go on dates". Movie/drama-esque perspectives do not work most of the time. I have fallen into the cycle in my university days too. 

"Man Up" is a pretty decent movie though, as they have certain positive messages like "putting yourself out there" and "the list of compatibilities is no guarantee" even though the ending is still unrealistic.

If you find someone attractive, talk to her and interact with her more, ask her out 1-1 (if you are too humji, 1-1 interaction in group setting shall be your stepping stones first) before deciding if you really like her. As much as it feels like love, your feelings are infatuation and her unmatched goodness is simply a collage of your fragments of imagination. Anyway, independence and assertive are sexy, so don't be an emotional clingy vine plant.

Recently, I had asked someone out for dinner. I only had a few interactions with her (and it totaled less than 15mins). She is cute, seems sporty, sounds intelligent, works hard, and is ang mo pai. I am very cheena, but I am drawn to amp females. Don't ask me why, I had failed to answer my friends that question every time.

My boyfriend is exactly like you and I was exactly like your girlfriend. I would suggest you openly talk to her about it, the way my boyfriend did. 

He is a straight A student while I was a straight B range student...with the ocassional C. Like your girlfriend, average grades never seemed to bother me as long as I was passing, until we got together and he told me upfront one day about how my satisfaction with mediocrity, not being the best version of myself, lazing and procrastinating and not doing my true abilities justice, frustrated him a lot. 

He is right, you know. I was indeed shortchanging myself. Your girlfriend will be able to see this if she's honest with herself. What he said essentially means, if I don't pull my socks up and continue slacking around with my academics, it will threaten the relationship. I vowed to do much better the next time around. 

Many commenters at your original post may have told you to just accept her/she probably has strengths and interests elsewhere/not to be arrogant with your own achievements and drive; but this is how I see it: Her behaviour of taking her studies (and eventually work, most likely) lightly and lazily, is a negative one, no ifs and buts about it. It is NOT some quirky character trait that you have to "accept".

She has nothing to lose if you tell her upfront. With me, I now have a better understanding of how to make my relationship work, I get to keep my boyfriend whom I value deeply, my grades are improving, and I'm now seeing my boyfriend as my source of motivation, rather than constantly brushing his achievements off as "yeah that's him alright" and thinking it's unattainable for me. 

In a relationship, if something about your partner or the relationship itself bothers you, bring it up, reasonably. It can only help the both of you in the long run. Else she might think you're ok with her behaviour which can actually totally be helped and changed for the better; plus you'll also now be with someone who will be more in sync with each others' values in the future. 

She will be hurt and maybe even defensive when you first tell her, but if she's any honest with herself, values you enough and is reasonable, she will understand and make changes. Trust me, I used to be in her position.

-
 
 Actually, it really depends on the situation. Say, if I only know you after exams last semester, and I find that I am infatuated with you, I would spend my time observing you, and interacting with you, to get to know you better, before I actually confess (or not) to you.

Reason being, I won't know if it's just a one-time crush (coming from a course where majority of the student populace are guys, it's common), or if I can make it work. Sometimes, it is better not to rush head-on into a relationship, though at the expense of your "confidence".

For me, I learnt it from experience - I rushed head-on, and got hurt real bad (like CAP drop to no honours bad), because I didn't know the other party well enough. 

If I were in my 1st, 2nd or 3rd year, it would be easy. But in my final semester now, I am more interested in making and keeping friends.

If I let my impatience take over me, and confess to you outright, I'll be desparate. 
If I continue interacting with you, learning more about you and others, and at the end of the day, if I take the risk and confess to you, I look forward to a great future with you.
If I choose not to confess, at the end of the day, I still make a new friend.

The fool sets out on another journey, taking a step to a new frontier. Who will he meet today, and how will he grow?

 Here's what I would feel/do (I'd like to think I'm a responsible individual) and for the most part, what I think other guys (or even ladies) ought to do. I would first ask 'why' just for curiosity reasons and perhaps get an idea of what the other party's philosophy on dating is. So for instance, if a lady comes up to me and says 'I just find you attractive/that you have good character,' it doesn't fit with my philosophy on dating so that's an instant 'no.' It doesn't fit with my philosophy on dating which means that I see no good reason to date you and in which case, I ought not to date you if I were to be responsible. From here on, the best I could do would be to suggest that we remain as friends till I see a good reason to date (if it ever happens).

If I see at least some plausible reasons to date, I might agree to the date but specify right at the beginning my intentions/thoughts of dating you and ensure that you are clear about it (especially so if my reasons for dating isn't that I am fond of you and/or at the point of time I don't see us going further into entering a serious r/s).

I'm not sure if I have answered your first question since every guy has different reasons for dating and there are scumbags around but I would think most if not all guys will be highly impressed/admire your courage and straightforwardness.

Whether or not you should ask him out depends a lot on you and the reasons you have for doing so? Is risking annoyance or asking him out on a date/getting to know him more, more important? I can't tell you what you think about this. If getting to know him more is all you want out of the date then you could probably do so through other means such as befriending him if you guys aren't already friends, or become close friends etc. If this can't even be done, the guy must be really mean. :/

I saw the story posted by xiaomei about her sexual exploits and would like to share mine too. 

Unlike xiaomei,  I wasn't so sexually mature from a young age.  I was informed enough and often joked with my friends on sexual stuff but I never actually put any of this into practice.  Perhaps part of the reason was that I grew up in a sheltered environment with a conservative family and was in elite schools all the while.
 
Uni was the turning point for me.  I stayed in one of the happening hostels and was introduced to the world of drinking and partying.   I became part of the cool crowd and indulged in nightlife as much as I could. 

As I can be considered reasonably attractive, I had no issues attracting tons of guys in clubs.  Being a girl who was previously evergreen and shy among guys,  this made me feel really good about myself.  I began to view the attention of guys as a source of validation as to my attractiveness.  I craved and enjoyed the attention so I tended not to reject the guys.

Of course,  with guys came the sleaze.   The number of guys I made out with in a night became a trophy to me and I found it fun to go back home with guys or bring them back to my hostel.  I have lost count of the number of guys I have had some sexual intimacy with especially since some of the trysts were one off.  Maybe 20?  I went to a budget hotel for a tryst before and also got picked up by a random guy on the streets after a night out. I know these sound horrible,  but these were the cool exciting stuff to me then. 

I knew I was judged by many people as they somehow managed to find out about my promiscuity.   But to be honest,  I kind of enjoyed having such a reputation.  This is as it was juxtaposed against my background as an elite smart student and I felt it was cool that I was both smart and happening. 

Fast forward to today,  I have a loving boyfriend who is blissfully unaware of my past.  I try to keep this all in the past, but due to my existing history,  I constantly feel the temptation to cheat.  I have been keeping it in check and I hope I continue to do so.   Why let my past taint my future? 
-
 
Social anxiety struck a chord with me. Although I am a quiet person by nature, one would not normally classify me as someone with SA. Like any normal NUS students out there, I took opportunity to go for programs like NOC and OCIP where I have to meet and talk to many new people and pretend that I am extroverted. Nothing kills me more than to pretend who I am not to be and during overseas I would cry myself to sleep on many nights because I feel that I am so different from my peers. Peers who could not understand when I do not go for outings or why would I stay home on a weekend when everyone is out having fun. 

Everyone around me is so witty and confident and loves going out to meet new people. When attending parties (which I cannot avoid), I would hide in the toilet so that I can be alone and cry and prepare myself for the next 15minutes of socialising when I go out again. This cycle continue on and on until I start realising that it is not my fault for being quiet. I am just being placed in an environment which might not be optimal for my growth. I slowly started to love myself and began giving less fks about what other people thought of me and do my own things. 

I feel happier and is more confident about my own personality now. I know how it feels like to have SA and how crippling it can be. Everyone is different and I cannot advise you on what to do but please stay positive. Surround yourself with close friends who understand you. Godspeed.

-
 
Sometimes, I read through the confessions posted here, and some posts just cause a hint of sadness. 

Why do some girls crave the 'excitement', as they call it, of having new guys chasing them even when they have a steady, loving boyfriend? I've been through 3 relationships, and none has worked out (obviously). My point though, is that when you already have something so worthwhile, can't you cherish what you have? I want what you girls have, yet you are throwing it away just to chase something so fickle as a feeling of 'excitement'. If you feel that your relationship is fading away on your part, that's another thing altogether. But 'excitment', really? Don't cause unnecessary pain. It sucks, and I don't wish it on anybody.

Which links to, if you think it's not working out, speak. Why is it that I must question what is going on, whether you are in this at all? Every single relationship-though few-have required me to do this. Whether you're female or male, if you have the guts to get into a relationship, then you'd better have the guts AND responsibility to break it if you don't think it's working. Even if you are not in the best state, even if you are so stressed, be it about your relationship or something else. Don't force your SO to ask. It hurts. Badly.

And don't ghost. 

It has happened to me, and many things happened at that very moment as well. Breakdowns aren't pretty, even if they don't involve tears where other people tread. While I got my answer eventually, it is not something you wish to repeat. Try being so worried, so afraid of what may have happened to your SO, and yet having to chase for an answer as to the status of what you thought you had. Because soon enough you know he or she was alright all along. 

Respect what you have, or at least what you had, if that's the case. 

Have a good day :)

Hello  and ,  I can completely relate to how you guys feel. I am in my year 3, and in the past I used to feel anxious and had blank outs during exams. I started seeking help from a counsellor in UHC nearing exam period when I was in year 2 to help me to cope with my exams anxiety. However, last semester when I was attending a lecture, I suddenly had a panic attack in the LT. It was my first time having a panic attack, and initially I thought that it would be fine, it could probably be due to caffeine overdose. However, the following week during the same lecture I started having symptoms of anxiety again. I decided to seek help from UHC and shared what I experienced to my counsellor. She provided some suggestions such as practicing mindfulness and deep breathing exercises. To be honest, I feel that those techniques are only helpful to a certain extent, but personally I believed that it will be more beneficial if you can try to be open and share what you experienced to your close friends. Friends that you know that will be there for you. I am really grateful for the support that I have received from my friends when I shared with them what has happened. Anyway, all the best for the new semester! Jiayou and stay strong! :D

-
 
To fellow schoolmates with social anxiety, you guys are definitely not alone. I've always had social anxiety. However, I've never once felt embarrassed about it. No one's going to "help" you except yourself. Talk to a school counsellor about the cause of your social anxiety. Be truthful to yourself and of course to the counsellor. If counselling doesn't work, see a psychiatrist (we have them in UHC). You see, in NUS we are blessed with all these services that will cost a bomb outside. Treat these sessions as another medical consultation (like a cold). There is really nothing you should feel ashamed about. Instead, my close friends and family were relieved and proud of me for being able seek professional help voluntarily. Hope those who are suffering or have friends suffering from social anxiety/depression read this and seek treatment soon. Don't wait till a breakdown or it'll really be too late. Face it, treat it and thereafter spread the words. Good luck!:)
#counselling isn't embarrassing #counselling is therapeutic
-
 
What will you do if you're still single @35 y.o. ?

Assuming that you have a above average career and some savings. You have enough money (for deposit) to purchase a resale HDB by yourself near your workplace and a car if you want. Your life dream is to be financially independent by 45 y.o. so you can quit your stressful job and do something more relaxing and interesting.

1) Consider dating an old friend who is about your age. She has been interested in you since you were in your 20's but you never liked her as much because she isn't very attractive. She's a nice person but basically spends most of her salary on branded goods and luxuries. She probably doesn't need to be 'supported' financially since she does fairly well at work. She does have CPF so she will be able to help you pay for housing.

2) Ask your cousin's Vietnamese wife to introduce you to someone. Your taxi driver cousin married a Vietnam girl several years ago, however despite his relative poverty they seem to be a fairly happy couple. You assume that if you marry a Vietnam wife, you will have to support her and your 'dream' of early retirement will be delayed by at least a decade.

3) Ask your married friends for introductions. You have several good friends who have been happily married for awhile. You could ask them for introductions but it might take awhile and you might have to re-enter the dating game again.

4) Have fun with a Sugar Baby. You always wanted to date someone when you were younger, unfortunately you were too poor and too busy with your career to succeed in a serious relationship. Perhaps having a Sugar Baby would let you fulfill this part of your dream.

5) Remain alone and buy a 3-room HDB. Continue skimping, investing, and working hard in order to retire @45 and fulfill your dream of being financially free. Profit?

I was here a while back confessing how sad it was to end the year with you losing our friendship, and me, losing my mind.

Then came our clique outing, you appeared out of nowhere and started talking to me again out of the blue, normally, as if nothing negative between us ever happened. As if my heart remained intact, never broken. Then we started texting, and the next minute - you unsurprisingly disappeared again.

I'm really, really tired of all these leaving me hanging situations. You don't get to decide when you'd like to talk to me, to your whims and fancies. You don't get to decide if the medication works on me or not. You don't get to decide my mood. Stop, just leave me alone. Leave us alone. For the last time, I dug out our photos and I couldn't help but noticed that you used to laugh so much more genuinely and happily, before you knew me (or even when we first knew each other). As our friendship grew closer, your smile went fader.

I used to think it's really stupid when one says if you really have feelings for someone, you don't need to own that someone but just hope for that person to be happy. I never understood that, I even questioned such a saying - claiming that it probably wasn't even true love to begin with. Now I know how wrong I was then - I truly want you to be happy. And for that to happen, I have to withdraw from your life - by force or otherwise, permanently. Even if it means putting everything to an end, it has to happen. I will watch you from afar, or wherever else that may be, hoping that you find your true happiness and I'll be really glad (from wherever I may be) when that happens.

Nights, and goodbye. You gonna welcome a 2016 without any presence and thoughts of me.

So many confessions about...confessing. 

Is there an ideal time frame for confessing? (Yes, this really depends from person to person, couple to couple, but I'd like to hear some views).

I see people lamenting that 1-2 months is too short. For myself, if the feeling is mutual, I would accept him in a heartbeat. 

However, I've heard from friends that if two people get too comfortable with each other, the timing is gone. I've also personally experienced this...being too close to someone for nearly a year, only to find out that the other party only views me as a very good friend. 

What do you all think? 

There's also the point about confessions not being necessary, but my personal take is that both parties should be sure of what each other feel...

Anyways, to orientate your visual image of me, I'm rather beautiful, sexy, confident, some may say I'm rather exotic looking girl. For the sake of identification, call me #MissM. 

It's been a while since I've ventured out into the dating world and especially a such an adventurous age (about early twenties), I've got a lot of qualms about casually dating. Don't get me wrong, it's not something I've never done. I've gone out on a couple of dates in between breaks with my ex (woah, totally miss that red flag there, right?). Faced with a mixture of super desperate guys to guys who probably wont even give me the time of day for me, I actually do enjoy going on dates with an array of selection of men. So many things run through my mind when I'm on a date. Whether I should reply the guy messages? Is it too early to start staying over? How do I tell him that I'm not interested without hurting his feelings? Does he get the condoms or do I? Is it okay to joke about marriage?

2015 has definitely helped me develop my dating skills. My first "adventure" was like a splash of cold water on your face after being out in the hot sun for a really long time. He was a friend of my good friend who I hung out a fair bit with. I knew about his dating antics. He is smooth. He daring in a sense where he'll ask the girls out even when they seem as though she way out of his league. From a rather prestigious discipline in engineering. But due to his super huge fear of commitment, we'll call him Mr Scaredy pants(SP).  Having a bf who barely made any effort to plan dates, it was fantastic that he took a lot initiative to plan them out be it a spontaneous or pre-determined date. 

Date  was fantastic and chemistry was above average I guess. (from my perspective I guess)
 Fast-forward to date ? Idk. I've got a terrible memory. One of his close relative passed away and he was rather torn about it. I guess that why he stayed longer than I planned. I wanted to dump him that day actually. You cant dump a guy whose grandparent passed away. Anyways, with every date, he kept saying he wanted to keep it casual and stuff. I was cool with it but not great at saying goodbye. Prefer the whole thing fazed out and he stop replying my messages by thinking that I'm a commitment junkie.

Start posting a crap load of #relationshipgoals post on my social media to add a cherry on top, I'd write/say rather coincidentally commitment-rich things to my friends and on my accounts. Woah, with he consistently yakking about how scared he is, I thought he be gone in a few days. Two weeks guys....that was sooooooo long. It was perfect tho. The semester ended. He flew off for exchange? I dont even remember now. It was nice while it lasted but if you scare easy, you should leave early. 

-#MissM

I honestly don't know what I'm confessing about but I just wish to share my story before the semester starts next week. 

After my break up from a long term relationship, my male friends from my lecture gang who were all single immediately pestered and bugged me to install those dating apps on my phone. Initially I was like -.-. But out of boredom I installed those apps( yes including letterbox) to play around since I realised I had a lot of free time after being single again. Tbh, most of the girls on those dating apps were obviously using fake or heavily photoshopped profiles of themselves as their DP.  Having an ex who had the ability to manipulate make-up and body posture to make herself look more attractive made me more wary of those Super "chio" profiles on those dating apps. After a while, I grew disillusioned and uninstalled all of them. 

Anyway, feeling super bored and lonely, I decided to chat up my jc friends (who were all guys) and we went for a drink together at a  restaurant bar. One of them decided that a dick-fest was too boring and decided to "call in some chicks". Somehow, from a group of 4 guys, it became a party of 9. One of the girls that came along immediately caught my eye. In my eyes, she was really attractive and maybe perhaps bored being single for a while, I decided to chat her up. I found out afterwards that she was my friend's friend's friend(work that out yourself) 
Long story short, we clicked well and we exchanged numbers before we parted for the night. My guy friends decided to go clubbing with the girls(including her) while I went home to sleep. For those who want to know why I didn't go along , of course I was tempted to follow along to get to know the girl better along the way, but at the same time I was terribly tired and felt a bit sick. 

After that night, I initiated a conversation and things progressed very smoothly for quite some time(Being in a previous Long term relationship really helps one understand girls much better lol). After texting a while, we found out that we really clicked quite well. Importantly, we were the same age and still both studying, me in NUS while she was private Uni. Therefore, somehow, we were able to relate to each other quite well. We started going on one-on-one lunch/dinner dates as well as outings to GBTB and Coney Island just to name a few. We were still unofficial then. After a while, I was sure that it was the right time to confess to her and that I was so confident that she would agree to be my girlfriend. Then one day my friend(who was part of the group that night I met her) dropped me a bombshell. One morning out of the blue he texted me something  along the lines of " hey bro, I'm so sorry to say this but I can confirm its true, the girl you have been going out with is a social escort"( I altered the actual text as saying it would give away my identity lol). I didn't believe it, I asked for evidence, and immediately he sent me images/screenshots as proof. I shall not discuss the images in detail here as it would be inappropriate. There were other things discussed but I shall stop here. From the evidence he provided, it was impossible for me to deny that she wasn't a social escort. Naturally of course I was extremely heartbroken. It was more painful than rejection. It was the feeling of being "cuckolded" or "戴绿帽”. I took a while to calm down, gather my thoughts, and I called her to meet to talk about something urgent. From her response, I reckoned that she thought I was going to confess to her, since I managed to calm myself down to speak to her in my normal tone. 

We met outside the MRT station. I brought her to a quiet corner since I didn't want anything nasty to happen when I broke the news to her. From her demeanour and expression, I guessed she thought I was going to confess to her lol. (Quiet corner and everything). When I broke the news to her that I found out about her "job", her expression immediately changed. It was a very long and emotional talk so to summarise what happened: She said that she was planning to tell me about it once she knew I could be trusted with her secret. She said she had really cut down a lot of her "work" after meeting me. She asked me if I still wanted to be with her. She kept apologising and crying. I said I wasn't planning to break up with her at that time I found out. I said that I was heartbroken but I didn't want to end things like that immediately. She cried a lot. 
I immediately felt guilty when I saw that she started crying uncontrollably. That was when I knew I really liked her a lot. Then I made a decision that I don't know whether I will regret in the future. I said something like " I really like you, and I don't mind what you did in the past, if I ask you to become my Girlfriend, will you become exclusive to me only? That's all I ask for. " Of course many things were said after that but basically she agreed to be my girlfriend and promised to stop her social escort job immediately. 

Till now, we are still a couple and are going strong. However, there is still a bit of awkwardness between us especially when we try to get intimate. Therefore, our relationship has never progressed beyond normal kissing/hugging /holding hands. Neither of us has suggested to each other about the more "intimate stuff" so far.  I am happy with the status quo and I guess she is too.

Personally, I believe that if you really like a person, you would accept him/her despite their past. If they love you, they would willingly change for you too. I believed that she would change for me, so I gave her that chance. To all the singles who are dating, it doesn't matter what your partner did before he/she got together with you. What  matters is what he/she does in the present and in the future. That will be the true gauge of their commitment to you. 

Ps:  I know she often reads NUS whispers. I love you HANNY.

  I know exactly how you guys feel. 

It's the attention that we miss, where the guy actually shows interest in you and actively chases you, it makes you feel wanted and desired and it gives you all the butterflies and the initial feeling of the "chase"

Many times after being in a long term relationship, the guy tends to start to become lazy. (To leave all the chasing to the guy is sexist of course but read this with a pinch of salt) slowly the girl feels taken for granted, that she's no longer worthy of interest as the relationship settles into a routine. 

Talk it out with your bf, give them a little shakeup. Take the initiative, arrange some dates and reignite the passion between the both of you. It doesn't always need to be the guy initiating all the time! Talk to each other about your love languages, to keep the flame going. Don't look for excitement elsewhere when you have a great guy at home.

Peace
