We had a few more serious talks about it and he finally relented and said that he's okay with me practising Buddhism. The days after that were blissful as our personality really matched each other. We managed to work out our differences and were having a great time together.

However, after about 1.5 years he suddenly asked me about it again. We argued for a bit and in the argument he asked me this " Can you really imagine us having a future with different religions? Will you be okay if I'm bringing our kids to the church instead on Sundays?"

What really hurt me was him questioning our future. We're the kind of couple who talks about marriage openly. Marriage was not something we take extremely seriously due to our young age but it was something that we could talk about casually and not a topic that we shunt. He said that he's sorry afterwards and that he was just over thinking but I can't help but feel that words uttered doing an argument is the truest of all. I don't want to lose him but I feel that this relationship is damaging to my self-esteem. The promise to allow me to stay a Buddhist sounds like a utter joke right now.

More thoughts on rejection.

Rejection elicits disappointment. Disappointment breeds doubt. Doubt inspires change. I think the kind of change that happens varies widely. Rejection need not always be cruel if you can clarify the doubt. Be it no chemistry, no clubbers or no whatever. If you let his imagination run wild I think its even more cruel and simply mind-f him. Usually the guy will understand one laaa. (If not even close enough to discuss this then gg lor)

Many people I know are happily in love or looking for a relationship. Me? I realized I'm scared of being in one. 

Firstly, I'm not an attractive looking girl. Kind of nerdy even. I feel uncomfortably self-conscious just thinking of going on a date with someone, so I made myself seemed cold and rejected all date offers so far. 

Secondly, I find it difficult to put so much trust on a guy and making myself vulnerable to heartache. I find it hard to believe that there are good guys out there who could love me for all that I am, and not eventually go down the path of infidelity or endless arguing. 

Thirdly, I feel like there are so many things I can improve myself on. Looks, fashion sense, talents, and of course personality issues such as patience and emotional stability. 

Lastly, I am in it for the long haul and don't see the point of dating just to play the field. With this in mind, there seems to be so many things to looks out for in a guy as long term compatibility means small issues can easily become deal breakers. 

So yes, I'm certain I am not ready to be in a relationship. What scares me is if I can ever make enough changes to feel ready for a relationship, or will I stay feeling forever inadequate to be in one. Sigh. Perhaps I am only having this dilemma because I haven't met the right person. 

Any mature advice is welcomed, and do share if anyone of you feels the same way I do.

Yet you say you are depressed and sometimes even take medication. You never mentioned what you are depressed about; yet I helped and supported you despite myself. Sometimes I wonder; perhaps you should be the one helping me to 'get my life back to order' (you love to say that)?

Now that I helped you past the stage, you flew to somewhere else and left me here to struggle. You used to light the way and I used to guide you. Now you left a half-alcoholic, heartbroken me fighting through the darkness that once I thought left me. But I loved you more than you know; even if the sky fall, I would tank it all. Goodbye from the other side.

Is our current conversation too lame that she cant be bothered to reply? Am i that far down in her priority list?

I come from a faculty that requires alot of human interactions, and looks inevitably allows you to do that job better. People say looks aren't important, but people are just less kind to the ugly. I'm not happy with the status quo, and I find myself unhealthily obsessing over the idea of plastic surgery. But my parents would never allow for it, and I know numerous people share similar sentiments, we've all seen XX/QQ/etc being vehemently lambasted online with caustic vitrols. Besides the risks (clearly people do not detest strangers who went under the knife because they put themselves at risk), what other reasons are there for hating on those who underwent PS? I know the usual reasons: "ugly babies" "fake" "vain" (methinks the appropriate word is self-conscious) "you will turn out like MJ". This is coming from a person who thinks there are really 0 reasons to hate on someone who had succumbed to standards from society and eventually resorted to cutting into her own face, i feel sad for them, maybe because of empathy. If someone is extremely hideous, what possible reasons could you have to despise them for wanting to fit in? People always have an oddly cheerful view of "ugly", by ugly i really mean it, not fishing for compliments. "Your personality is more important" save the platitudes, the slight bias is always there, so tangible i can feel it. 

In a similar vein, i feel equally bad for transgenders, nobody likes the idea of hurting their own body, so I urge everyone to think of the reasons for them wanting to, instead of condemning them blindly. Was it for vainity? A lack of morals? Maybe for some, but not all. Imagine you have a face only your mother could love, it cripples your career, your love life, the way you're treated when mistakes are made. They're subtle (not really actually) but it drives you nuts. I've known ugly friends who have the best personalities, and yet boys do not pay attention to her. It's like the opposite of Lang leav's poem, "her arrow sprung in worlds of dark, she turns their heads but not their hearts" except she would never turn their hearts because their heads won't even turn. I shall end my rant here, if you have some important reasons for hating on the transmutation of ugly people then feel free to write them below. I doubt there's any real concrete reasons though.

Hey , using rejection as a measure of a man's maturity is at best; a one-sided view of maturity and at worst; naive on both sides.

One-sided because maturity is more than 'accepting it like a man'. It's about responsibility (my Ma taught me that). I'm responsible for my studies, my actions and my own happiness.

I consider myself a mature guy. I put effort into thinking of original jokes and make her happy in the messages. I prepped my first date with small gifts and gestures. If she rejects me, I accept it and move on. I don't see the point of attempting to start random convos and annoy her just to prove the 'feelings are true'.

Yes, some guys aren't worth your time and will show their pattern after rejection. But rejection is a blind trap and will also hurt the rare species. Perhaps even more so since they will keep trying. If the trapper expects loyalty from the victim. I think that's pretty naive as well.

Just my thoughts
#NotLaoNiang

@ the OP of  I know how you feel. I was in the exact same shoes as you! Sharing my own experience so that more people can know about rejections... especially when girls make the first move. Last year, I liked this guy (a friend/classmate) unknowingly and i decided to confess right before he goes for exchange in Norway. Worst decision of my life. He is a shy guy, and dont have many female friends, nor text girls often. I thought i stood a chance, but i lost to exchange. After my confession, he said the exact same words: Not ready for a r/s. Yes, by this he means that he is not ready to be in one with YOU. He did not accept my feelings, but he did not reject it too. He suggested to keep things status quo, and wait til he comes back. At that point of time, i didnt know what to do. But if i had a chance again, i wouldnt confess. FYI, we are no longer friends now. We eventually stopped talking because i felt like i was putting in way too much in this "relationship" that sees no future. He acts all awkward when he sees me now. Hes a nice guy, but just doesnt know how to treat girls properly. So girls out there, open up your eyes. Yes, a r/s is a mutual effort and requires 2 way communication. So if you realise that your messages to him are insanely long and he replies not as fast, or even blue tick your messages before replying you 2-3 hours later.. Face it. You are just not that important to him. I accepted this cruel reality and moved on. I guess what hurts the most for me was that, i felt like i wasnt good enough, not pretty enough.. It was hard because i liked him a lot, got constantly worried and reminded of him EVERY single day and countless moments in a day. Its hard, but you need to tell yourself that hes just not deserving of you. Your love can be better put on another man, a man that will shower you with equal love and attention. Sad to say, its indeed more blissful to be loved than love. 

TLDR; Girl confesses, did not get rejected nor accepted, guy went on exchange, game over.

-
 
In response to , I think the reject-first-then-observe method is okay for the women but I think it's super cruel to the guys, don't you think! (I am a female here by the way.)

Because rejection hurts like crap. Maybe it's just me but I would feel really bad to reject a guy and then accept him again/chase him back later? Or maybe by "reject" OP means to tell the guy that we can be friends first or something? 

This grey zone between being single and becoming an official couple is so complex. My theory is that there are two main groups of people: outgoing and reserved. The outgoing ones dare to date people they are attracted to even if they don't know them that well, and if it works, it works; if it doesn't, then it's okay and it ends there. Consequently these people are more social, and able to manage different situations, and are more experienced in dating and socialising with romantic intentions. This way makes sense because you are open to different individuals and have a lot of chances to test water and get to know people. For people like this, it's probably okay to go up to them and indicate interest right away. 

Then there is the other group who is reserved, but will totally devote a lot into one dating relationship when it actually happens. They date people with a long-term view, so in a sense they are quite picky. Contrary to the first group, I think this group rarely gets a chance to know a large number of people because they don't date a lot of people and don't respond to indications of interest at first sight. So if someone you like belongs to this group, it's better to be friends for a while, try to control the romantic feelings and focus on understanding who the person is. After being friends for a long time, and seeing what the other person is like, you can reevaluate.

-
 
7. Catfish

Hi everyone, #laoniang is back with another story to add on to #datingstoriesbylaoniang. Can’t promise any more stories after this, but I was looking through my old conversations with people I met on dating apps and was reminded of this horrible terrible vegetable sorry excuse of a man. Because his character is so jiat lat, we shall name him Chou Dou Fu.

So Chou Dou Fu had an extremely captivating Tinder profile. Dimples, sexy smile, hipster glasses, athletic, that boyish yet sexy kind of look you know? As I swiped through his photos, I was smiling to myself while thinking “Why hello there you beautiful creature!”

CDF and I start chatting. At first, he seemed like a decent good boy.  We have a mutual friend, an acquaintance of mine. Not super close to him but he’s an okay guy. So I assume that since CDF and my friend are friends, that means CDF must be an okay guy too.........right? Wah, Laoniang was too foolish back then lah. As a rookie, Laoniang was sibeh noob. So Laoniang let her guard down and allowed her heart to be captured by CDF.

For many days, I spent a lot of time texting CDF back and forth. I tell you, of all the captivating conversationalists Laoniang has ever spoken with, this person takes the cake okay. Not just the cake, he takes the cake, eats the cake, then finishes the cherry on top and ties a knot using only his tongue. Yes he was that smooth. His words were as sweet as UMF 25 grade manuka honey. Just like the other sweet talking guy. But you know what the difference was? Sweet talking guy was not a huge intellectual. CDF was super smart and witty. He knew the words to say, WHEN to say it and how to flirt in a non-creepy, very attractive way. 

CDF stated that he was not on the app for sex or a relationship. He was on the app to look for a workout partner. He proposed that we meetup and exercise together. Okay, but get this – he wanted to go swimming. TEEKO ALERT! You tell me, how to read guys, how? They nod their head yes but they want to say no. (lol.) They say don't want any hanky panky romantic thing, but they want to exercise with you in your skimpiest possible article of clothing. Haiz.

Laoniang was young and gullible indeed. Actually I still am hor. Hahahaha! But not gullible enough to be fooled by CDF. In Laoniang’s gut there was this feeling that something wasn’t right. Something was very…………off about this handsome, flirty and intelligent man. Women’s intuition. I asked myself, why does this guy know my friend, yet I cannot find him on his Facebook account? Very strange leh, if I cannot verify his Facebook account, then he could be a catfish.

Fellow NUS friends, what should we do in such a case where a person’s identify is fishy?

1. Screenshot every damn photo. YES! If he has 6 photos on his dating profile, you better screenshot all 6 photos.
2. Crop away the background just to keep the photograph in your phone.
3. Now one by one, upload each photo to GOOGLE IMAGE SEARCH. YES! You can google search an image. Even your profile picture on Facebook to see if anyone is trying to impersonate you online. Technology is amazing isn’t it?
4. Make you sure you search every single image and open up all the “leads” aka URLS/websites that seem useful, or remotely linked to suspected catfish.

Laoniang did this. I was so excited, doing it for the first time. I quite smart hor. Hahaha. First image, nada. Second, nada. Third, nada. Fourth………na- wait. WAIT. I GOT IT. OMG. I FOUND THIS MAN’S INSTAGRAM ACCOUNT.

CDF’s Tinder photo was also his profile picture for his PRIVATE Instagram account. But CDF’s name was different. He didn’t write CHOU DOU FU there. Instead, it was a completely different name. Instagram account private, nevermind. I typed that Instagram name on Facebook and BOOMZ, I found it.

Found out that:
1. CDF’s real name was obviously NOT CDF
2. CDF wasn’t 23, he was 31 years old
3. CDF said he was still a uni student, but he’s actually………….WORKING LIAO. For many many many years.
4. CDF is MARRIED and has been married and living in his new house for more than a year with his beautiful WIFE (ya she’s quite chio, I would swipe right to that)

Lesson learnt:
1. You should google image search someone you've met online that wants to meet up with you, because catfishing is a very real phenomenon. It would suck to fall in love with a married person. Glad I dodged that bullet.
2. If it seems too good to be true, it probably is. Refusing to live in his reality, CDF painted such a beautiful photograph of himself, what could've been perhaps. 
3. CDF’s photographs were him, alright. But they were photographs of him from like 8 years ago is it? Last time so sexy and hot, but his Facebook showed that he was no longer a young stallion. Instead, a lumpy Dou Fu. Please la CDF, using old photographs on Tinder is still being deceptive. You should be a decepticon. Go for Transformers 5 casting lor!
4. Don’t assume people on dating sites are single, they might be attached. Yes it is horrible, why would attached or even MARRIED (WTF were you thinking CDF????) people be on dating sites/apps? Flirting with young, undergraduates some more. Walau. Tai guo fen!

CDF matched up with one of my uni kakis after I unmatched his sorry ass. I helped her to dodge that bullet. I hope that he's not still on the app. I truly feel sorry for his beautiful wife. She should create a Tinder account and maybe Laoniang can swipe right to her ;) Joking lah! But on a serious note, if you're attached, do your partner a favour and delete all your dating app accounts and apps. Emotional cheating with other people is just as bad as physical forms of cheating. Don't cheat hor.

Bye,
LN

Hi OP of , before I start, I don't get why you see your friendship related post as a less important post than other posts here. Your post is definitely not stupid. I too, has yet to find platonic friendships in university, I have my suspicions too, but I have been trying my best to believe in them. 

Like you, I joined camps but I didn't manage to make close friends. I am currently only closer to a few whom I will attend lectures with. Even so, we are not very close. 

Most of the time, I attended lectures and tutorials alone. As much as I like to make new friends and maintain friendships (yes I value friendships a lot), I like to be a loner too. I really find it burdensome to adjust my timetable just so as to fit others' timetables, or waiting for others for hours to have lunch/go home together/to go somewhere together. Ok maybe at this point, some people will say that I am selfish. Yes, I may be selfish, but I really prefer to have a greater say in my own timetable and my own life. Of course, outside of school timings, I am more than willing to hang out with my friends and accommodate to their timetables. During school days when different people have different timetables, it is just really burdensome for me to accommodate to them. Of course, if a friend ends school at around the same timing as me, I am more than willing to go home together. 

I am saying the above because I hope that you may see that being alone isn't that bad. Of course, you may feel lonely eating alone/study alone/have lessons alone, but look, you have a greater control of your time which is very precious in university especially when you have many commitments. 

Some people may say that you cannot afford not to have friends in university since you have to depend on others sometime and somewhere during your journey. However, I don't see the point to find friends just for such practical reasons. I make friends and say hi to others as I genuinely want to be their friends, and I hope each friendship last beyond university. 

I hope to make more friends, however, I need more time to warm up with people and I find it hard to trust people. For example, I hope to be close with my project mates too, but to no avail. I have to admit that I am a little dubious of them because of my very bad grades which have projects. I have been suspecting that they marked me down despite my efforts as they were absent most of them time when I contributed to our report, and I was not as vocal as other members during project meetings, hence they may not be aware of the efforts I put in. This was especially when finals were not that hard for me, and I did pretty well for my CA and mid terms. I don't know what to expect from the 5% peer evaluation though. Maybe I am thinking too much. I have not voiced to others my concerns. I feel apologetic to my group mates whenever I think this way. Frankly speaking, I really don't like myself for being this suspicious. I hope to change this mindset. 

Also, rather than knowing people through an app, why not open up yourself to more people by saying hi? This is more practical isn't it? If you really want platonic friendships, you have to learn how to trust people and make sacrifices. This is something I myself have to buck up on. Yes, platonic friendships exist, it is just that we have yet to find it in university, and I hope that you don't give up. Maybe one day, we will find each other as friends. Cheers~

So today, I happened to glance through screenshots of our old conversations.

Do you still remember those conversations where we'd talk about our various game obsessions? How we bonded over Portal 2, and how we used to say that Fallout 4's never gonna come out until we're 50 (heh, how wrong we were.)? I still remember I'd watch you play and die multiple times on Dark Souls. You'd get so frustrated that at one point you even nitpicked that sigh-like sound the game makes when you die. It was pretty hilarious.

Do you still remember those cheesy romantic messages we used to send each other? Man, you were so fucking smooth with your words back then...and to be honest, you still are now. I don't think I could ever match up to that. You were so quick-witted, knowing how to make a witty romantic remark in response to an innocuous statement. I guess that's one of the things that made me fall for you back then.

I still remember that night I felt so down in the dumps that I was pretty inconsolable. You got so worried that you even messaged my younger sibling to check up on me. You stayed up all night reassuring me that everything's eventually bound to work out, and cracked those jokes that made me grin despite all the tears. I still recall jokingly telling you to "cut it out, I'm supposed to be crying!"

But I suppose all good things must come to an end. It's been almost a year since we broke up.

I don't think you'll ever know how everything suddenly felt like it shattered and lost its colour when you told me that maybe we should break up. You told me that "maybe I wasn't good enough as a girlfriend", and those words still echo through my head up to this day. 

And yet somehow, looking back to everything I've gone through this year after we've broken up, I feel that maybe this breakup was a good thing.

After you've said those words, I've started to reevaluate my life. I'm not perfect, but it doesn't mean I can't be better. I've decided to change myself for the better. Maybe I did it in the hopes that we might get back together (we never did). Or maybe I did it as a sort of spiteful show that I can do fine without you. Whatever the case may be, after a year of figuring out what I needed to improve about myself and actually doing something about it, I've never felt so assured of myself for a long time.

I've found my own happiness once again. I used to rely on you so much to make myself happy, and that was a mistake on my part.  I used to complain about the boring life I had - in fact, I did nothing but send complaints your way. It's actually no wonder you've grown tired of me and broke it off. Now I'm slowly easing back into doing things I used to love, and I'm actually pretty overwhelmed with the amount of things I wanna do. 

I won't deny the fact that I still long for that feeling I used to have when we were still together, and that I still long for how things used to be. But I also feel like I've moved on, and I'm ready to take on another adventure - in singlehood or otherwise.

So in the end, I wanna thank you. You definitely won't be able to read this, since you're busy with your own life now and our friendly messages have slowly decreased in frequency. I'll never forget all the things you've done for me, and all the memories that we've had. I thank you for being the best boyfriend I've had so far. I don't think I'd ever find somebody to replace that part in my heart, even though I know I'll find the man who's really the one for me sometime in the future.

Most of all, I thank you for letting me go.

I wish you all the best, my dearest A.

- M

After reading the post  and , I can’t help but give you guys a heads up about rejection, coming from girls who think like me. Just a perspective; I have quite a few guys chasing me before, and have dated before too.  

When talk about BGR thing, I have a “reject-first-then-observe” rule for a few reasons, incld guys I’m initially attracted to. It’s bcos guys who chased me are those I don’t know super well (and I think this is the main reason why most girls would reject guys also). I hang out with my female-only kakis most of the time. And I don’t believe in platonic friendship, one party is bound to fall for another I believe (feel free to disagree though, it’s just my opinion). You have to see a person through their ups and downs in order to really know them, and not just based on the previous moments when they behave themselves around you just so that you would be attracted to their good-boy/girl front. There was once I rejected one and woah once we resume as frens, all the pattern chut lai/come out already sia (walao, I felt like I kena cheated). That’s when I know that that guy is not for me. I doubt people can put up a front for long. It takes only time for you start seeing their true nature. 

Next, I have to agree with OP of . If guys can handle it like a gentlemen, woah I think I will end up chasing him back lehhh..! Mainly bcos I found that very mature, which I find very attractive *gasp*. Handle it in a way that the friendship is not affected in any way, that you don’t resent her for rejecting you after all that you did to chase her (that you worked on your body or your looks etc.). It’s ok to be affected, after all, it’s like a failure after putting in so much effort and it seems like it is all for nothing. For one, the girl didn’t ask for any of it. Take your time to recover from it. Handle it with maturity (ie BE A MAN; most girls like men, not boys); everyone has a choice, and respect her decision that maybe it’s just not the right time for her, maybe she just hopes that you’d improve in other aspects like your character, or maybe she still have someone else in mind (in that case you suay lor, or you can give her time you know), or maybe she wants to date after graduation, that’s all. Rejection is a good thing in a way, at least you know she’s not toying with you or your feelings and just to fill her boredom temporarily. One of my kakis she will just date any guys (with acceptable standards) who chased her just bcos she pity them and she feel bad for not giving any chance. Btw she's a chiobu and Ms Popular, more chio than me. Eventually she’ll initiate the break up and jump to the next relationship (she’s heartless that way). Time will tell if the you guys are really into the girl and vice versa, or it was simply a temporal attraction. For the latter, rejection is still the better decision imo. If feelings are true, I hope you guys will not give up chasing bcos...just maybe, she hopes that you would ask her out again (UNLESS she tells you directly the first time that she’s not into you at all, then I think chasing her again might just turn her off hur hur). Trust me, the efforts put into chasing her is not for nothing. Perhaps she hopes for other changes as well, not just the physical. Relationships aren’t easy; couples do fight quite a bit (don’t fool yourself with K-dramas/Disney love stories); it ranges from some jealous third party, work stress, boredom, family problems, her PMS, differences in expectations and so on. If guys can’t even handle a rejection, I don’t know how they’re going to handle all that is to come. 

One of the rules when comes to dating: don’t expect your partner to “make you whole” or to handle some aspects of your life which you can’t handle yourself. In other words, if you can’t handle loneliness yourself/just want to tell the world that you got girlfren (that you are desirable too)/just want to have fun/stop being an evergreen, I think the relationship might not end off too well (again, just my opinion, feel free to disagree). Sometimes people want to fall in love for all the wrong reasons. I learnt from NUS how to be happy and alone sometimes when your kakis aren’t ard: to eat, to attend lectures, to survive a difficult module on my own. It’s not easy, definitely. I do fall into mild depression that the world/life in NUS is just too cruel. But it takes time to see it otherwise although reality is that no one is going to be there for you every single time. But friends are out there, gotta make an effort to meet them you know. At work, one is bound to meet a bitch (unless you super heng). Sometimes in a relationship, you’ll realize that you feel alone even with that someone. Somehow you guys just can't click/talk things through. So my advice is to learn to be more independent first, else you might end up pestering/clinging to your partner a lot (this will suffocate them and tire them out eventually). That you’re okay being single, but you’re happier being in a relationship. I hope my words shed some light to those who are wondering about the things I’ve mentioned. Of course, I’m just speaking from my point of view, every girl is different. There are those like me, just as there are those like my chiobu kaki, just as there are those who have no idea who they really want HAHA. My Singlish not super fluent lah, sorry it’s not as funny as #laoniang or #laobu story. 

ps. I hope #laobu will update soon. 

-from a girl who is still waiting for her Mr Right but her standard is just too high

-
 
 This is with reference to the post about gift rejection.

Having read the post and the comments, allow me to give my comments after careful analysis.

1. I understand that OP does not really like the gift, but after all, the guy did make the effort to wrap it nicely, hence MAYBE you could have just accepted it, and like what others have mentioned, you could do what you want with it after that.

2. Even if you hate chocolates, you shouldnt have told him directly in a crude way. Perhaps, you could have made a polite excuse to reject it. For example, you could have told him that you cant accept such an expensive gift? Or rather, reply "I understand your intention and I greatly appreciate that, however, I have a bad experience with chocolates, maybe this gift would suit someone else better? Thank you!( With a smile)". If he still insist that you accept it, then take it and pass the kind gesture to someone else who would like the gift better.

3. Indeed, the guy also has his own fault. "He then said he would throw the gift if I don't take it as he already have "lots of chocolates" at home" would imply that he did not put in enough value in this "gift" of his, or rather treat it like a garbage.Such a reply could be due to his disappointment or anger, or he is trying to make you feel hurt or guilty. 

4.Neverthess, it is no excuse for him to reply your rejection in such a manner. I do agree that it is hurtful. After all, you give someone a gift to make her happy, and now are hurting her just because of rejection, isnt that reductio absurdum? Guys, if you get rejected, have some 君子风度 and accept it. There is no such obligation to accept a gift, as long as someone refuse it politely. It is understandable to feel hurt getting your gifts rejected, but the other party has the right too.

5. Throwing away chocolates is a wastage of food. There are tons of people suffering in Africa due to hunger. Donate the chocolates to these people if you dont want them. Dont say such 缺德 remarks.

Verdict: Both of you have your own faults, as the situation could have turned out differently if both of you think before speaking.

To the OP: There is no need to get frustrated over such a trivial matter. In life, there are better things to get frustrated over. At least you know what kind of person he is. Take this as a life experience of learning how to reject. Start the new year with happiness, not frustration. Do not be upset by the commenters with rude remarks, as they might have meant the same thing, albeit in a crude way. Cheer up and Happy New Year!   Huat ah!

-
 
Lately, I have seen some posts on nuswhispers regarding people discussing about height issues, ego etc.
 
Well, let me give you my personal opinions on what I think about this.

Even as a guy with average height, I must admit that sometimes I do have this kind of thoughts, such as whether the girl I like will end up taller than me in heels, whether I will feel sian when an amazon with heels walk past me, etc etc. ( I know some guys do feel that way too ).

But think carefully. If you really like a girl, you shouldnt be bothered by this height difference stuff. Also, if that girl really likes you and is a girl with mature thinking,I believe she wouldnt mind that height difference. A true relationship works when both sides really understand each other and ignore the trivial differences. Why do you want to care what other people think of when you 2 walk side by side? If you 2 really like each other, it would be as though both of you are in your own world, where others are invisible right?

As for the other case where guys feel hurt getting towered by girls in heels, you need to ask yourself this. Is it important? There are sheet tons of tall girls in Singapore and you cant expect yourself to get affected everytime a tall girl walks past right? You are yourself and shouldnt be affected by such trivial issues. I believe there is a girl out there (with the ideal kind of height)who will like you for who you are, so you shouldnt be bothered by the rest of the amazons.

In case some of you vertically challenged guys need some ego boost, here are some facts that you might want to consider. There are in fact short people who are successful in real life, as elites of the society. 

As long as you put in effort, I dont see why you cant end up on the top tier of the social ladder, and eventually command people who are much taller than you? You may be the shortest in the clique, but once you open that golden mouth of yours, I dont see why those people wont just shut their mouth and listen to you with due respect yeah? (No offence to the tall people)

Moreover with success, I believe a girl will have that 安全感to woo you instead of you doing the work,because some girls do want their partner to be financially stable. (What good is a tall and buff guy who flirts everyday without a life ambition?)

Once you secure that relationship, you can proceed to make her like you for your character and who you are.

In conclusion (Well I have said alot and pardon my Engrish...), short guys, you are not alone and please be confident of yourself and take note of the aforementioned scenarios. With a great ambition and successful career, a 4 foot guy can also be seen as a 8 foot guy ;) ! 

(Hope you dont filter this admin, it can help some people wake up their idea)

I am the OP for .

I was hoping for some help but it looks like I could not get much.

Not even the trolls will bastardise my post.

Let me explain a little more.

I try hard to make friends, and I think I make friends well. However, whenever I try to make moves such as getting to know the girl better, either I am auto-friend zoned or I sometimes get told straight in the face "I know you like me, but I don't".

I mean, I try to keep myself open, read about all sorts of things so that I can at least talk a little about different things to try to break the ice. But I don't get a chance to. I read about Japanese anime and manga, about wines, about Asian cuisine, shoes, travel and more so that I am somewhat knowledgeable about life.

Yes, I know romance is realistic. I know the other side of love is cruel. People get together and break up. The head can live with that. But while the head always says I need to let it go, break the ice and try again, the heart just gets shattered harder and harder with each acrimonious resolution. In the past I could still salvage the friendship, but I remembered how a bitchy girl bitched about me and hence causing my interest to block me without a chance to defend. I also remembered how another girl said she rejected me "peacefully" but then got her friends to shun me.

I am not here so much to find Ms. Right. I want to know how to defend against gossip mongers and how to give myself a fighting chance at getting a Ms. Right. How can I stop being gossiped about because either they say I try to hard, I creep people out, or that I'm just weird and not worth people's time?

I'm sorry admin.

i'm someone who went through something similar. i just wanna let you know that if a guy leaves you confused, he does not love you. if a guy loves you, he will not bear to leave you puzzled & hurt. 

seeing that you're already interested in him, i would advise that you pull yourself back before things get too late, because the pain and tears would be of so much greater intensity if you allow things to grow. although i guess even if i tell you this, feelings may not always go the way you want them to, and you may be enticed to venture further, especially if he continues dangling carrots in front of you. but always remember that it's still a life experience & please don't hate yourself for it. still, protect yourself & what's important to you (ie your values).

would love to share & advise further if you need someone to talk to. you can find me on griddit ^^

-
 
General Tips for lovelorn NUS guys: One of the more constant type of posts I see here is the sad rejected guy lamenting his unjust deprivation of love by enigmatic women who appear to be equally interested in the guy, only to confine him cruelly in the friend-zone when he confesses. The outcome is painful for both parties (and for me to see such unnecessary emotional hurt), but it can be avoided. Here are some tips from bro to bros (ladies feel free to constructively criticise)

1. Pre-First-Date Confessions are for the movies and serials. They don't belong to real life dating.

movies: [attraction] -> [interaction] -> [confession] -> [first date] -> [happily ever after]

real life: [attraction] -> [interaction] -> [ask on a date] -> [first date] -> [many more dates] -> [confession/ "the Talk"] -> [exclusivity]

2. Be honest of your intentions, don't pretend to be just a friend
instead of asking ambiguously "wanna hang out/ eat dinner?" like any of her other platonic friends might do, make it clear that you are not looking to just 'be a friend' if that truly is the case. Don't waste her time by acting like a friend when your "friendship" would crumble without promises of romance. But of course, "making it clear" does not mean "I love you and I want you to have my babies" confession style...

"If you're not already attached, could I take you out to dinner sometime?"
This makes your intentions very clear, without being too direct and pressuring. (usually... see point 4)

3. Accept Rejection like a Gentleman
Another lie we are fed by movies and serials is that a man's effort (despite his initial unattractiveness to the woman) should always be rewarded by a woman's affections eventually. Misogynist bullshit. It's ultimately her decision, and if she says no, stop bothering her and move on.

And no, this is not because its some sneaky way to gain her respect and admiration in the hopes of asking her out again. It is because you respect her decision. Period.

4. Women are not like standardised locks to be picked with a secret manual

One of my close female friends prefers to be strictly platonic friends for months before any romantic hints and doesn't like the pressure of going on on "official dates" even with guys she finds attractive. For every 10 girls harassed by suitors and stalkers, 1 girl would find her true love in a guy who persistently chased her despite rejection for a year. Each individual is different, and these tips, while applying to most people, are not laws or rules that apply to all people. Keep an open mind.

Good luck, 
-A below average guy (in terms of wealth, looks and fashion sense) with an above average dating life
-
 
It's hard to be myself even in front of my family. I know I have a very low boiling point,  meaning I get pissed and flustered easily. Because of this, I tend to keep to myself and not talk much even to my family when I'm at home. My speaking loudly is also another factor. People think that I'm angry when I speak, but it's actually my normal volume. Because of all these, I stay in my room most of the time and have very little interaction with my family. 

It's even worse with friends because I put on and facade. I pretent to be happy and interested when actually I'm just an empty shell in front of them. The worst part is, I smile a lot in public. I read in an article that smiling makes a person more approachable. That's why I keep smiling when I don't feel like smiling. My face is a natural sulking and pissed face. 

I apologise to all my friends and family for being such a fake person. Yet, I have to do this, because if I don't, I will argue a lot with my family, and not have friends. Although I'm tired, I will still do all these, because in order to survive, I have to do these.

Companies have directly told me that I was rejected because the jobs require the person to meet clients and my looks don't cut it. My friends have also told me that it's difficult for others to break any ice when my looks don't make a good first impressions. You know at camps where people go around trading numbers? I'm that person who others never bothered asking. 

As if heavens is playing a prank on me, I have skin that is sensitive to heat and sweat (and dear Singapore always has plenty of those). When I start feeling hot or sweat, my scalp and occasionally my back itches terribly. And no matter how much I resist, the discomfort will show on my face and eventually I end up scratching like a monkey. I have seen a dermatologist for it, and the only advice he could give me is that for a permanent solution I should migrate to a place with cooler climate, and that medications can only do so much. That's why I am terribly afraid to go out into the sun and only hang out at night.

Personality wise, I am an introvert. I am the kind who feels like I am being a burden if I just approach others with the intentions of making friends (and they'd probably think I am creepy too), so I will sit at the canteen tables alone frequently, hoping someone would notice and come up and make friends with me. I guess it doesn't help being a male in this case. Also, as a person with limited social energy, I spend it  on a few people who appreciates it and intensely while at it. I am the kind of friend who is loyal to a fault, and who would pick up a call at 3am and rush over if the person needs me. But in return, I also expect them to do the same for me. But for most people who are extroverts, such a friendship is too intense and eventually it fades off when I feel the other party isn't giving enough. In fact I don't think I have found any of such friends in NUS. Which begs the question, do I even have people consider me as a friend in NUS.

I am the kind of person who would spend like a year just knowing someone just to decide if the person is compatible. However it always end up that if I ask them out after that one year, things get awkward and the friendship that has been built up over a year disappears in flash. That's why it feels like there's so much to lose. 

I don't need hundreds of people in my life, I just need a few who would always be there to have my back along with a special someone that I would give the world for. But it seems like there's nobody in my life. Is such a life worth living on? I've hinted that I need help a few times, but no one ever gets it or notices. I am just afraid that if I ask for help directly and I don't get it, that will be the last straw for me.

Hey . I think you're probably blinded by so much emotions that you're not making sense. How does "bad treatment by JC friends" relate to NUS students, even?

Ok, fine, maybe these JC friends moved on to study to NUS.  And maybe you met a bunch of not-so-nice folks during the orientation camps. I cannot deny that such people exist within NUS, but it isn't representative of the folks here. Sure, people here can be competitive as fuck or extremely clique-ish. Being someone who usually takes modules on her own, I've had my own share of being isolated in class since everyone else sticks around with people they already know. But I've met my share of friendly people as well, folks who'd have your back til the end.

Thing is, this isn't a thing you'd find only in NUS. You're gonna see the same types of people in other unis, or heck, even in unis in other countries. Heck, it even gets worse in the workplace, if you're unlucky. Some folks will just never be as nice as you want them to.

Point is, you don't need those people in your life. Deal with them if you must. If you must deal with your sadness, that's ok, but you can't dwell on that forever and be miserable for life. You've got a choice. Forget about them and move on. Reflect. Meet new people. Life's too short to bear grudges.

It's all up to you, mate.

I was shrieking, struggling, sweating up a storm and whimpering throughout, ocassionally even asking him to pause because the burn was too much. My point is, maybe you're feeling the same way I do. Maybe you just have to grit your teeth and pull through the first one or two painful times as you get stretched out. Make sure he goes slow and is well lubed (because you sure as hell aint gonna be wet in that much pain). All the best.

#datingstoriesbylaoniang

5. Poisoned Candy

Adam was Mr Popular. He was a floorball player, did well in school, had many admirers. Was from a wealthy family and his parents gave him whatever he wanted.

He knew the words to say: the words to make me melt, the compliments to give, the promises to make that would make a girl swoon. All this was done on Whatsapp. The strangest part about this whole story was - I had never even met the man. Yet he was talking to me like I was his wife and we had just gotten married.  I was slightly guarded when I noticed he was being too familiar with me although we were strangers. I let my guard down because I believed he was an okay person with no malice. 

 When we finally met in person, he turned out to be all talk but no real substance. Attempts to engage Adam in intellectual conversation failed as he did not enjoy talking about macro issues, even though we shared the same major. After our very underwhelming date, he disappeared. Blocked me from WhatsApp and all forms of social media. Didn't even bother to explain. Just said he was sorry and never spoke to me again.

I told my Uni kakis what happened, they encouraged me to channel my WTF emotions and anger into working out. I exercised every day that week.

It took me a whole week to fully get over Adam. We went from texting each other good morning to sweet dreams, to silence.

Lessons:
1. Never trust sweet talking guys who try to win you over with their words. Do not believe in the talk, unless they display the walk. Be cautious if it sounds too good to be true. In fact, if it gets too disgustingly sweet, my best advice is to not even go there girlfriend. Do not entertain the player. Don't let the poison infect your system or you shall suffer from confusion and heartbreak.
2. This one is for both the males and females: To make dating in Singapore more enjoyable, please tell your date if you no longer wish to pursue him or her romantically. It is sibei disrespectful to disappear, especially if you've made a promise to this person or even made another date with them. Leaving people hanging reflects poorly on your character and you should be ashamed if you always take the easy way out.

Till the next story, LN.
-
 
I haven't been able to tell my friends about the family problems I have. Not anyone ever. I don't think they can solve it for me, or be able to fully understand my state given that they all have a happy family. It's not like something that happened when I was young, it's recent, it's happening now. When my friends see me with either parent, they will casually ask where the other parent is, and I'll have to lie and brush it off because I'm not ready to explain the entire story to them. Or maybe it's just I can't be bothered to explain. I don't wish for them to feel uneasy whenever we touch on family topics, because I know they will try to be considerate and avoid that. I don't like lying to them, cause each time I lie, a part of me die inside. 

At times I do wish I could speak to someone about it, but I never have the strength to do so. But at times when shit happens, I tell myself to go head on with it, take it hard and get it cleanse out of my system with something good - like a banana (scientifically proven to help with constipation, no i'm serious) cause it'll be a sunny yellow banana day and thats the way it should be - looking at the bright side of life! #midnightthoughts

Hi. First I must apologise for bringing up "VH" once again, but I thought I must.

I used to be his friend back in HCI, where we were in SMTP. SMTP was where the brightest science and math talents came together to undergo research-like training. When I first met him he was known to be a very bright person and thus I enjoyed his company, even though he sometimes cracks weird jokes.

One episode, however, made me learn what a jerk he is.

I had been attached to a girl called "G" for 3 months or so. After Chemistry Olympiad, where I got nothing while "VH" got a bronze, "VH" was celebrating that he did well. We were all happy for people like "VH" and company who got good results.

One fine day, "VH" stopped me at the canteen while I was queuing up for noodles and whispered into my ear, "I will get G."

I was completely puzzled, but brushed it off as "VH" being weird. After all, he did crack the inappropriate joke from time to time, and like guys who liked girls, bitch about how he would never date certain types of ugly girls. Moreover, in SMTP, we guys were seen to be too nerdy and hence I intended my relationship to be low-key. Alas, sometimes we chit-chat over lunch and it inadvertently spilled, but not many people knew.

Thinking it was a joke, I jokingly told "G" that "VH" was being a usual joker and tried to taunt me. "G" and I shrugged it off until we noticed that "G" kept on getting prank called between 2 to 3 am each night.

Still, I didn't think much of it until "G" confronted me one fine morning. She asked me about "photos and a meeting at Coronation Plaza". I only remembered that another girl "X" asked me for chem homework help and I agreed to teach her outside school. "G" then quarrelled with me over this girl "X". "G" started to become a little more demanding, but I knew something was not right. Why would "G" be told of a casual homework meet-up and lunch, and be sent pictures of something seemingly innocent. I asked "G" for the pictures. Indeed, it was the homework meet-up, but I did not realise "X" was acting seductive and doing all sorts of hanky-panky! This was an obvious set-up but finding the culprit proved futile.

I wanted to keep this as secretive as possible, so I did not tell anyone about this except my best friends, who were not in SMTP.

It was all cool until "X" suddenly sent me a message. I deleted it a long time ago, but it was along the lines of "X" saying sorry for what she did. I asked what exactly she did. She then told me "VH" gave her $20 to do that. Apparently "X" liked "VH" and "VH" told her that she should do that to gain his favour. I told "X" that her moment of folly was forgiven, but the inconvenience she gave me was a problem still. What was confusing was why "X" owned up. After much hesitation, she said that "X" felt terrible for being a bitch and causing "G" and I to nearly break up.

Talking to "X" felt awkward, but I realised that day what a jerk "VH" could be. I guess that "X" was foolish at that moment, but I would like to say, thank you "X". If not for your confession I would never have learnt about my supposed friends.

Eventually "G" and I broke up, and on the very next day, "VH" suddenly approached me and said, "I got her, right?" I was fuming mad but he didn't know I knew what he did. I did feel like low-browing him but restrained. Someone like him did not deserve that.

I'm sorry "G". I also want to thank "X". But more importantly, I have vented my frustrations with "VH". I would never have vented if not for the fact that "VH" showed up on NUSWhispers.

I was so shocked when my friend told me about this recently, and it made me question if I was really justified in being so upset. Was it all in my mind that we were together? On the other hand, I'm also very upset now that he just brushes off what we had, when all along it did feel like a relationship.

I know I shouldn't care about this anymore, but I feel like B did so much emotional damage to me at the time, and even now when I think I'm over it, he's still affecting my self-esteem. I know that my self-esteem should not be measured by another person blah blah blah but we're all human beings and we've all felt hurt by others at one point in another so don't judge me.

We don't have to start a serious relationship or anything but we could still casually go out a few times to try something out. Actually I would also find it more romantic this way. 
Knowing someone has an interest in me does not make them just a friend to me. Its not what friends are. I just want to make this label clear in my life. And what's all this about being "zoned". I think friends are very important. It's not like i want to be friends with just anyone. 
I don't know why my thinking is so different from many people it seems. I guess I am old fashioned. I would not want to continue being friends with someone who has confessed and I don't feel the same way and thus in the term nowadays friendzone him. I would feel really sorry for him and honestly I would find him a bit pathetic if he hung around me just to be around me as a next resort. I can foresee some people disagreeing with me already but I needed to vent. I'm sure there are girls who feel the same way too, we view friendships in a different light. Also the fact so many people view friends like this is making me feel really insecure about a potential boyfriend's female "friends".

#datingstoriesbylaoniang

Laoniang is experiencing some inertia when it comes to writing this series of dating stories. How many more stories do you all want to hear? If you’re getting bored, I’ll just skip to the end. Please let me know. Anyway..….here’s one for the road.

4. The Gentleman

“Hello!” I said with a wave, as I walked up to Glenn. He was taller than I expected and had a boyish face.

“Hi!” he replied with a smile. “Where do you want to go for coffee?”

“I don’t know, I’m fine with anything really.” I shrugged, looking towards him for suggestions.

“Okay, let’s go to Dean and Deluca then. Their coffee’s not bad.”

Prior to our date, I had talked to Glenn for a month on WhatsApp. From our month-long conversation, I could tell that he was a very down to earth guy. He was family and friend-oriented, loved travelling and had a stable job. I really enjoyed talking to him, as I knew that he wasn’t trying to impress me or pretend to be some nice guy. This was really who he was. Naturally I was very nervous to meet him. After such a long build-up, after wondering what he was like in real life for such a long time, it was time to finally 
a) Have my expectations shattered 
b) Be blown away by Glenn in real life

We entered D&D and looked around for a table. Once we found one, he pulled out the chair for me with a smile. Not a weird smile. It was a genuine smile. The kind that moves from your lips to your cheeks, reaching the eyes. I know this sounds cringe-worthy, but in that moment, I felt shy. When a guy treats you like a princess through simple gestures of chivalry, it’s a wonderful feeling. Who doesn’t like being treated like a precious gem?

At the counter, I intentionally stood behind him so that he wouldn’t get to pay for my coffee. He very smoothly asked for my order before paying for his and paid for our orders together. I insisted on paying him back, trying to slide a ten dollar note towards him but failed.

“I’m already working, you’re still in school. Let me pay,” he said with smiling eyes, pushing back my note.

We talked about travelling, music, our friends and family, school, work. It was a well rounded conversation. He told me about his travels in New York. But despite him being such a nice and well-mannered guy with good principles, I did not feel any strong chemistry as we talked over coffee. You know what I’m talking about? How at some points in life, you meet people that you just click with and want to be friends with for a long time. The chemistry comes naturally, both parties feel it, both parties treasure the relationship and want to fortify it. It just wasn’t like that with Glenn and I felt disappointed. Chemistry is so important. When it’s not there, you just know it. You can’t force someone out of the friendzone. Some people just don’t fit well together romantically.

After the date, Glenn and I still talked to each other on WhatsApp. I did not want to lead him on, so I friendzoned him.

“I like you as a friend, Glenn. I’m sorry that we did not work out romantically though,” I typed apologetically. I turned off my phone, hid it in my closet and walked away. Half an hour later, I gingerly retrieved my phone to read his reply.

To my surprise, Glenn replied in an objective and positive tone.
“Thank you for telling me that. I’m surprised you told me so directly though, most girls are not as bold as you are. It would be nice if they were more forward! You’re a sweet girl and I’d love to remain friends,” he replied.

Till this day, Glenn and I remain friends. I’m glad I met him. Glenn taught me that chivalrous guys still exist. Glenn taught me about myself, that I like chivalrous men very much as good manners go a long way in life. Glenn is a type of guy that I would bring home to meet my parents. 

The little things go a long way. Something as small as holding open a door for another, pulling out the chair for something, paying for coffee – all these are small gestures that speak of a person’s character. Do these things and also look out for these things in others, in your pursuit of love.

 Till the next story, LN.

Hi, just another lonely student here. Well I know this isn't the best place to seek advice but I just wanna seek opinions from people who have gone through similar situations, so that I'll know if this warrants a visit to the counsellor.

By nature, I'm a reserved, awkward person and I can't click with majority of people like my classmates. Although I sorta accept the fact that that's how I am, I still have periods of self loathing where I feel like no one likes me and I'm dysfunctional, that comes every few months. It has been going on since JC (3-4 years ago), but I always took it as just stress or simply a down period in life.

However, for the past year or so I've been overseas for studies and these episodes have become more intense and frequent. Maybe it was my messy breakup and subsequent loss of my closest friends that acted as the catalyst. Or maybe it's the lack of social support since I don't have any friends there. I do try talking to people, but they just aren't interested in talking and being friends with me. Everyone there seems to have found their cliques and they're always participating in activities, and going out, and being so normal.

Sometimes if it's a big group event and I'm invited (by default), I go home feeling even more rejected cos all these negative thoughts will just take over. Then I'll spend the rest of the week/month curled up in bed, alone in my room, with the heaviest weight on my chest.

Nowadays, I have a breakdown almost everyday where I think about all these things and I suddenly find it harder to breathe. Even if I try to think of positive things in life, it's hard to overcome the self-doubts, and I just wanna hide in my room. I also wanted to stop being selfishly mopey by doing some volunteering work, but I just can't bring myself to do anything..

Sighpie. Sorry for the rambling post. But I don't want to be that sad bummer that everyone avoids. I want to be a happy kid again.

I'm a 20 y/o evergreen girl, and I've been talking to this guy who is 3 years older than me. I've been asked out by several guys these few years, but I'm very introverted and somehow I just find it really difficult to get close to people, especially those whom I know have an interest in me - it's almost like a reflex for me to push them away.

We started off as friends, started talking randomly one day and we've been talking every day since for about 3 months now, and this is the first time I've ever wanted to see and talk to a guy as much as him. He makes me smile even when he isn't around, and he makes me laugh even when I feel like I'm having the worst day of my life. 

But I can't say for sure that I'm in love. Infatuated maybe, but not in love. How could I be?

I've been struggling with depression for 2 years (it's on and off now) and there are some days when bouts of depression will just suddenly hit me. Some days I feel like they're the best of my life, but at night for no reason at all, I think about how worthless I am and that I want to kill myself. The sad part is that he has never been there for me.

Whenever I show hints of unhappiness or looking like I need some cheering up, he avoids me and pretends he can't tell. His replies become shorter, as though he doesn't want to talk and it just hurts me sometimes. He just can't seem to talk feelings.

Yet, I'm desperately trying to convince myself otherwise. I tell myself, you haven't known him long enough yet for him to want to be there for you. He's afraid of showing he cares too much. But he makes you so happy during other times - do you really want to give him up? I say, give him a few more months. Maybe then he'd know better. But am I just deluding myself? 

My gut tells me he isnt the one (though my heart believes otherwise, of course.) The truth is, I'm scared. I don't know if I will ever find anyone who makes me as happy as he does anymore. But with my condition, I can't just have a "fair-weather boyfriend". I don't know how to feel anymore. 

Am I just being paranoid and jumping to conclusions to soon? Or should I pull away before any damage can be done to either of us?

Delete Facebook and hit the gym? Nope...

I don't care about my partner's exes (gender neutral!), despite it bearing strong similarities to a United Nations meeting. I'll admit: I'm envious that he/she had those amazing experiences with all those different people across US/Eurasia while I've been stuck in Singapore with my hands :( 

I can handle that envy in the relationship. No issues at all.

But whenever I can't find the motivation to work out, I'll go on FB and see photos of my partner being happy with the exes all over the world. I will let envy turn into jealousy, and have it slowly build up inside me, pic by pic, until I storm out of my room and into the gym/track. 

All those negative emotions are released in a brutal, one-more-set-till-you-die training session. My team mates think I'm a driven athlete who's willing to push myself to the absolute limits. It's unhealthy but you cannot deny the results.

So I say, scroll through Facebook and hit the gym for maximum results.

#datingstoriesbylaoniang
Met someone on OkCupid. He kept talking about his toy collection and this female classmate that he was close to. Not just close to, but he kept talking about how all his friends liked to tease the two of them and pair them together, even though there was "nothing going on." Wts right he was going on and on about it!!!!!!!!!!!!! Why...? He wanted to hang out again but I turned him down. This guy had no game. Males, please don't talk about other girls in a romantic light unless it's your mom or your sister. And I have no issues with your toy collection, unless it becomes the sole topic of interest in your life. Moral of the story: Don't limit the conversation to one or two things in your life. At least ask yourself if you have any interesting stories to share beFore the date. Also try to leverage on a common interest that you share with your date, this information is readily available via text messaging before the actual meetup. This will avoid boring your date to tears. Dating takes effort if you want successful results and it is sibei fun, #laoniang swears by it!

#datingstoriesbylaoniang

2. Worst Tinder Dinner Eva (heres a long one for the bored ones)

When #laoniang was a rookie to the dating app scene, I went on my first date with a male from Tinder. LN was first introduced to dating apps by my uni kakis who were swiping on campus with zeal. This was sometime last year and I tell you, I was sibei nervous to meet a total stranger.

Let's call number 1 Hao. When I first swiped right to Hao, I was ecstatic to be talking to such a hottie. He looked Japanese, with long twinkling eyes in his main photograph. His picture was taken in what I presume to be an office, with cubicles in the background. "So he's earning his own keep, very good," I thought to myself, giving him a mental checkmark. We starting talking on the app and later on exchanged digits.

"Do you have a pet?" he asked.

"Yes I have a rabbit. You?"

Hao sent a pic of a cute cat. Needless to say, LN was smitten. Girls love guys who love animals..........at least I do. He gushed about his cat, sending me more pictures. Awwwwwwww. I was sinking deeper into a puddle of feels and I loved every minute of it.

Hao started sending me "picture jokes." He took pictures of objects around his room and made witty captions about them. I was already sold when he popped the question.

"So.....do you want to have dinner sometime this week?"

I thought about it at great length. While he was cute, intelligent and pleasant to converse with, something was not quite right. Was this a date? Was he romantically interested in me? Tinder is a dating app, isn't it?

"Is this a date?" I typed.

"Nahhhhhhh, we're just having dinner. How's gimbap? I know this fancy Korean place with authentic gimbap in town. We can meet after I get off from work."

Authentic gimbap in town? Sounds expensive. If we're going as friends and it isn't a date, I can't blow $50 on a meal....presuming we're going dutch. I would rather spend that dough on duty free booze. Vodka with the girlfriends at the rooftop loft. Much, much better.

We ended up going to a cheaper restaurant on a weekday night. On Doomsday, I was sibei anxious. Now I know he said it wasn't a date but he was hot, so I had to look cute. My girlfriends came over to help me get cute. Hair, makeup, outfit, accessories, perfume. My CAP would be so much higher if I didn't spend so much time on being female. Haixz

We met in a crowded mall, he was really tall and slim, I'm guessing 1.8m? He was even cuter in real life........ I tried so hard play it cool. I didn't want him to see me flustered by his good looks. We made small talk as we walked towards the dinner venue. Things seemed to be going alright. We got a nice window seat overlooking the water. The view was pretty. I controlled my breathing to slow down my pounding heart.

This awkward tension started to build. Sexual tension????? Dream on!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It was the kind of awkward tension that Raj Koothrappali experienced when attempting to converse with females. Hao was looking out the window, thinking of what to chat about. 

Between extended pauses, we managed to talk about his job and how much he despises it. He went on a mad rant and grieved about how much he hated this, that, them. My heart started to sink. This was getting morbid. I felt his negativity rubbing off on the surface of my scalp, permeating my brain and colouring my mind a murky blue.

Apart from the rant, Hao and I talked about our experiences growing up. Somehao (see what I did there? lmao), we got into a disagreement about elitism. Something I said triggered an emotional reaction in him. He disagreed with my vocabulary on the subject. The discussion ended abruptly. Painful silence ensued.
 
Dinner ended, we went dutch, no surprise there. He carded it and I paid him back in cash. Now you may ask, why did I foolishly pay for my share? LN believes that there is no such thing as a free lunch. If you go on a horrible date, you never let the person blanjah you or you owe him/her one. Just. Pay. For. Your. SHARE!!!!!!!!!!!! No strings attached, sever all ties after the horrible date, sayonara.

The first dating app date was so horrible that I deleted Tinder the second we split ways. Traumatised, I bought some booze and headed over to my gf's house to dish out the dirt and drown my sorrows in my failure.

Moral of the story:
When meeting up with someone from a dating app, agree to meet for drinks, not dinner. If you meet a person you have no chemistry with, you can siam ASAP if it's drinks only. Assuming you're a nice date and will be paying for your own share, it will be easier to leave a drinks date than a dinner date. Drinks can be:
1. At a bar
2. Tea/coffee at a nice cafe
3. Michael Jackson at the market if you're sibei budget

Dinner on the other hand, is a commitment of an entire evening to a random stranger. You have to dine with that person. Awkward or not, you must finish your meal.............just don't.

Second lesson:
Be positive! Nobody likes a whiner. Yes, life is hard, but I wouldn't be your friend in the long run if you're going to dominate our nice dinner conversation with complaints. No. 

I'm glad I gave it one more try or I wouldn't have found him. Till the next story, LN.

Ah, all this talk about religion tempts me to post about my experience too.

I am a free thinker. My family are all free thinkers. My other relatives are free thinkers too. So I don't know much about religion. Since young, my family has been focusing on academics, so I have this mindset that things out there should be able to be explained by science or whatever. However, I also understand that we live in a multireligious society, so I learn to respect other religions too.

In fact, I have never been bugged by anyone regarding religion until I came to NUS. Previously, my friends will just go "ahhh" and respect that I have no religion, they do not try to force their religion on me. So I was taken aback when one day, this small group of girls claiming to be from dunno which society came up to me when I was waiting for my friend. They asked me if I know about Jesus, and I was like, "yeah sure, I heard from my friends before". Next, they sat down opposite me and started talking about how Jesus can save us, blah blah, all those usual talk which most of you should know by now. Being shy, I just nodded along and listened to them. But when they asked me to join their society, I politely apologised and told them that I don't plan on having a religion. One of the girls was like, "what?" and gave me a weird look. I told them that "if I wanted to have a religion, studying in an Anglican primary school would have converted me long ago". They were silent for a moment. Just then, my friend arrived and I excused myself. But when I was running to catch up with my friend, I heard one of the girls saying this:

"What the ****, she just totally wasted our time. Don't want then should have said earlier, *****."

Ok, I'm pretty sure Jesus will forgive you for saying that and send you to heaven. Meanwhile, I'll continue to believe that my body will just decompose under the ground after I die.

So to those who go around and spread the message, please watch your words and actions, you may indirectly ruin the "reputation" of your religion.

To  Hey there, I was sort of in the same situation as you before. I initiated the break because I didn't want him to waste anymore time on me. It hurt him of course but I didn't want to prolong the pain for him as it would get worse in the future. Right now, we are back as friends and we still go out with our other friends together occasionally. Initially, there was of course this silent period between us but it got better over time. I would say It's not really impossible or possible to be friends again. But I think right now the main issue is to settle the relationship rather than worrying about whether you guys could remain as friends. There were guys whom we completely lost contact after rejection even though we did say we hope to remain as friends. There's no sure answer to this so just let things take its own course. It's not easy to come to such a decision but do what you feel right. :)

Had you ever feeling afraid of asking for girls numbers because you are worried how others think of you in case you failed?

If the answer is yes, this post is for you.

Don't care about what others think of you. Why? Because others won't be thinking about you. Everyone has their own life. They won't be so free to be thinking about you all the time. If you don't believe me, try doing something strange in front of everyone and see do anyone care about you at all. They may speak about it once or twice but they will soon forget about it as they have their own life. If they don't, hat mean there is something wrong with them, not you.

So if you want to ask for girls' number, don't avoid asking them because you are worried about how others will think of you. Avoid asking because you know that asking for their number out of the blue will certainly get you rejected.

You asked me why I insist on seeing you for the last time. I think you clearly know the answer. I want to see the smile and that pair of beautiful eyes I have fallen for for the last time. I wish to treasure and spend every remaining moment with you before you fly off to a new life. I know we can't be together because I will only drag you deeper into depression but she can bring you further in life. I hope, with all my heart, that she loves you more than I do and takes care of you more than I do. Nevertheless, I am grateful for the short moments we had and all the efforts to cheer each other on during the periods of depression. I don't know if I can ever meet someone who understands and cares for me like you did. I don't know if I can ever meet someone who gives me strength to climb to greater heights. I don't know if someone can ever light my path the way you did.

I just ask for one more hug and for me to say 'I love you'. As I turn back to the world of pitch black, I hope you fly to a place flooded with light and joy. I gave you every hope and dream I had; I hope they are not in vain. Goodbye, I hope you see this and remember that I always love you.

So, women who don't behave like overly attached girlfriends do not want to be in that relationship as much? Or independent women who make such comments are automatically deemed as being jealous when they share their opinions like OP did? There was nothing wrong with what the OP mentioned. This is coming from personal experience. Being overly attached to someone felt great at first. It felt like something I had to do as a partner- which meant devoting most of my time to him, cancelling plans with everyone else etc. But when it was all over, I felt so lonely. I never realised that I lost so many friends in that process cause I was so blinded. Even when they gave me advice, I would think they were jealous or had nothing better to do than to comment on my relationship. Sharing passwords was the worst thing we did. It made me paranoid and suspicious every time. I just wasn't myself anymore. I lost friends, friends that I was extremely close to. So like OP mentioned, don't be that kind of a girlfriend. It doesn't show how much you want to be in the relationship at all. Don't lose yourself in the process.  All I'm trying to say is that in a relationship you do need personal space. Otherwise you're both gonna suffocate.

5 years ago, we first met in that restaurant. I remember that shy innocence on your face. Both of us were exchanging glances and secretly smiling at each other. As time passed by, we frequented that restaurant more often and became more acquainted and I plucked up courage and walked towards you, asking for your number. That marked the start of our 5-year relationship.....

4 years ago, I got enlisted into National Service. You were always there for me, never lamenting about the fact that I couldn't be there for you due to my busy schedule in the army. On weekends, you would be there at the MRT station, waiting for me with that cute smile. Whenever I am feeling down, you were always there to encourage me , giving me that ultimate strength to persevere and push through those tough 2 years. While the rest of my army buddies have failed the test of patience with their SOs, our relationship on the contrary, has grown stronger. 

2 years ago, on the very day of ORD, I felt liberated as I could finally spend more quality time with you. On that very day, we decided to buy a pet dog, called it Tracy. I remember vividly that this pet was a representation of our deep love and sacrifice for each other. We would go jogging in the park with Tracy, never leaving her out in any occasions. Whenever either of us went overseas and couldn't  be there for each other, we would confide in Tracy whenever we missed each other. Tracy has become a part of our life. 

10 months ago, you had to go for your overseas Community Involvement Programme. I remembered sending you off at the airport with that goodbye kiss, along with Tracy's tail wag, as though she knew we hard to part for some time. Thereafter, we would still be constantly texting each other despite the absence from each other.

As the days passed by,  the number of replies from you has declined. Well, I could fully understand that because you had to be on standby anytime for emergency situations. I began confiding in Tracy, our love representation. Despite not knowing whether she understood human language, I still talked to her as though I was talking to you, sharing with her my woes, like a best friend.

2 weeks ago.... I made a terrible mistake. A mistake of my life that is quite unforgivable. That late night, I returned home in a half-drunk state after drinking with my friends. As I opened the door, I saw you, lying on bed in that sexy gown. At that moment, I knew you had returned for me and wanted to give me a surprise, after having parted for 10 months. I began taking off my clothes and caressing you all over along with kisses.

The following morning, I had the greatest shock of my life, and felt as though the world was collapsing before my eyes. You weren't in my arms. I kept rubbing my eyes to make sure I wasn't seeing wrong.... but I wasn't... What I was holding had a pair of doggy eyes staring at me, letting out a soft gentle bark.... I knew it was GG.com.
