Some women can be termed as being 'overly attached girlfriends'. And by that term, you can already assume that isn't a good thing. Oh and men can definitely be overly attached boyfriends too. But I'm a woman and I would like to share some advice to my fellow sisters. Please have respect for yourself, and stop behaving like a psycho! It's great that you show love to your respective partners! I mean why stop exerting effort altogether once you're in a relationship right? I get that. BUT there's a fine line that separates you from being incredibly sweet to being a needy and clingy girlfriend.

These are the signs of being an 'overly attached girlfriend'

1) You always want to talk to him for hours and hours even after you just saw him.

2) You hate it when he needs to be with the bros- Cause you think you're the only friend he needs in his life? LOL NO! 

3) You demand to join when he'a hanging out with his friends- Because you should be close to his friends too? Sigh

4) You get super jealous when you see a girl talking to him or commenting in his posts online- Your thought process when going through your boyfriends feed. What does 'hehe' mean? Why is that 'hehe' there? You're practically going crazy imo. 

5) You LOVE playing damasel in distress- Girl are you fo real tho? 

6) You ditch your appointments with anyone and everyone once he calls and makes plans with you. 

7) You ALWAYS demand for time and attention

8) You are ALWAYS suspicious- You need to check his phone, demand for online passwords. 

9) You think you love him more than he loves you- Is your relationship a competition? 

10) EVERY single plan you have involves him. You need to get a life, one in which your world does not revolve around HIM! 

So if you feel that you can identify with these signs, it's high time you start to change. Like I said earlier, where's your self respect? Where's your TRUST in this relationship? Why be in this relationship if you don't have trust? These signs just scream insecurity in the relationship! Aren't you tired of behaving like a possessive girlfriend? I'm getting tired just by reading the signs! This is NOT love. I've seen tumblr posts of praising women who are the jealous type and the 'my boyfriend is mine mine mine!!' attitude. This isn't CUTE. You look PLAIN STUPID. Please just stop this awful behaviour now and GROW UP. Learn how to trust your partner. If you can't, tell me why are you in this relationship again? I'd really like to know. And to women who are currently not in a relationship, please do not behave this way. 

Source: candymag

To 13564: Before you read this, please don't judge me... I'm just sharing my story because I saw your post about your sister being sexually suggestive.

First of all, - just for some background: My mom died right when I was born, (she was actually really, really hot- but this isn't about her. I guess that's screwed up to say, but whatever.) I actually grew up with my dad's family, because my dad has all sorts of emotional issues and he bailed before I was born. So you can see, my childhood was really kind of messed up.

Anyways, growing up I feel like there was always a lot of distance between me and my sister. When I was about 17 or 18 I first noticed that my sister was a hottie.

I don't want to go into too many details about it, but basically what happened is that I accidentally found a video that she made of herself. I knew she didn't make it for me- but I thought she was so damn beautiful that I watched it twice. I probably would have watched it a hell of a lot more, except that like right around the time I found the video, all this crazy shit went down and I had to leave home. (My dad's family who I was staying with got in bad trouble with the law. I never talk about it).

Sooo... I was totally lusting after my sister at that point. She was also having bad trouble with the law. She was actually in custody when I left home.

My friend and I went to go pick her up. When I saw her that day, after seeing the video, I have to be honest, I just wanted to f*** her brains out. Looking back on it now, it's pretty messed up- but I think she had feelings for me too. She actually kissed me right after we came to get her... and it wasn't a sisterly kiss, you know? I mean, it wasn't like ridiculously sexual or anything, but it definitely wasn't sisterly.

After we left, we all went to crash with my Sister's friends. On the trip there, my friend sort of implied that he wanted to get with my Sister, and I got a little jealous. He's a good looking guy- and even though she was my sister- I just felt like he was competition. Not much else happened between us for a while except some maybe-sexy hugging.

Pretty much everyone in my life at that point was wanted by the government, so we all moved around a lot. I'm not saying that I'm proud of it or anything, but it was kind of an awesome time.

My friend and my sister never hooked up I don't think- but I thought there was some serious sexual tension going on between them. It was around that time that I got really badly hurt in an accident. It was screwed up. I almost died. But when I was in recovery my sister came to see me, and out of the clear blue sky she started gives me this awesome, slow, passionate kiss on the lips.

Sadly (although, I guess for the best) nothing ever came of it. We spent some time apart... and I started to get really religious, so I tried not to think of her that way. It was actually going well for a long time- like I was totally over her. But I have to say, like a year or so after all that stuff went down, we were out sailing (not like a date or anything romantic like that), and she was wearing like the hottest bikini I've ever seen and it brought back all the old feelings. Sigh.

A little while later she actually wound up with my friend from before (the sexual tension guy). I can't say I was surprised.

But even after she was shacking up with my friend, there was one time we were at a party... my friend was inside, and my sister and I were outside alone. It was a really intimate moment. I think something might have happened, except that I killed the mood when I told her that Darth Vader was our father and that I had to go face him.

Many students have come forward to say that they have gone through the similar experience as the OP who is going through an abortion. And it is important that we all girls have to learn to protect our bodies and try our best from reaching a point in making a tough decision such as abortion. We should be well knowledged about the preventions if we are going to be sexually active. I am not some expert at this subject but I would like to give some tips to girls out there. Download a period calendar. Regularly key in your period. It will calculate your fertile window and your average cycle length. Do not have sex during your fertility window. Even with condom. Try to stay away from sex during this period. And at other times when you have sex, if condom breaks or leaks, quickly go get plan B emergency pill within 24 hours. If you really want to feel more safe, consult a doctor and get birth control pills and use it with condom to have maximum protection. Or you can just stay away from intercourse. Abstinence till you both are sure and mature in your relationship. You don't have to have intercourse to have a healthy sexual relationship. There are many other ways to please a partner. Talk it out with your Boyfriend and he will understand your concerns and paranoia if he loves you.

The only time i truly speak up in class is when there is class participation marks and i will really force myself to overcome my fear because i just can't afford to lose those marks. Everytime on the streets, people approach me for doing surveys, i simply "siam" them without looking at them or saying anything because i do not like talking to people i don't know. I think the "siam" made some people angry because once, i was called rude and no manners.

During one of the chinese new year, according to my mom (because i don't know this was what i did and i don't know what really happned), when the relatives came, we did wish one another happy new year, after which i go up to my room for a while as i felt a bit uncomfortable with too many people. Then i came out to get some drinks and this was when my mom heard one of my cousins said "she so weird". My mom told me that i simply walked into the kitchen to get my drinks without looking at the people chatting in the living room. She said when i walk past the living room, i should at least look and smile at the people there. Really? Is that how we should conduct ourselves in a gathering?

I don't deny that i feel very uncomfortable every time there's too many people. I don't look at people in the face on the streets only because i don't see the need to make eye contact with strangers. I don't join a single thing simply because i am not keen to meet new people. Also i really disliked taking photographs simply because i don't like to and i am also not active on social media. I also felt that i am just shy. All these i felt, are characteristics of an introvert and someone who's shy, but my mom disagreed. She felt that my case was something worst than an introvert. I explained to her that if one is inborn like that, there's nothing much that can be done but she disagreed, thinking that i should put in some effort into changing myself. But is it really that important that i come out of my shell? I thought we should always be ourselves and not be influenced by what others think? If i chose to remain as what i am now, would the consequences be very bad? 

Is it a sad reality that people like me, tend to be judged by people as weird, no friends etc? So would you all classify my case as being an introvert, shy, socially awkward or perhaps all 3?

Scroll to the bottom for TL:DR 

Is being being single bad?

Does getting rejected by your crush mean you are bad?

What if  I tell you that there a greater concern that this?

If you think you are worthy and think that getting rejected by your crush is their lost, will you still feel as sad?

What you need isn't a girlfriend to prove that you are worthy. What you need is self confidence. 

With self confidence, not only will you not feel sad about getting rejected, you will have a lesser chance of getting rejected because confidence is a very sexy quality that attract many  girls.

How do one gain confidence?

1)Getting rejected doesn't mean you are bad. There are tons of girls out there. Many are more attractive than your crush. Getting rejected by one doesn't mean anything much.

2)Don't set self limiting belief. People tend to find fact to support their belief and ignore face that doesn't coincide with their belief. For example, If you believe that you are worthless, you will think any girls who are nice to you are just nice people instead of thinking you deserve them. On the other hand, if you think you are worthy, you will think any girls who rejected you are girls who are myopic and missed a Gem instead of thinking that you are bad.

TL: DR Confidence!

One day I was traveling alone in a new city and I went to eat at a burrito place (it was really good by the way). When I was eating an Adele song came on; it was the new song Hello. I usually like Adele songs but strangely that moment I was just annoyed at her and rolling my eyes. I just suddenly remembered how I felt last time listening to her songs and being all emotional, sensitive and l felt like I was just living in the past last time, always so sentimental. I wanted to tell Adele to stop it, stop living in the past and stop her regrets. Stop singing about men who probably don't even care much about her anymore. I guess I was really telling myself to stop as well.
I am (well probably now was) the kind of shy girl who always prioritized being seen as nice, I loved community service, always quite naive about guys, always giving people the benefit of doubt. I felt like I just grew up in that moment; naive little girl who liked being nice to a modern woman who had her stuff together. The reason I was traveling alone? Tired of everyone, tired of my last travel buds whom I tried hard to be friends with and be nice to but they just kept being asses to one another and to me somewhat and didn't appreciate me a bit, never apologised for the hard time they gave me. The time alone also made me realise that I wanted to break my 6-year friendship with a close friend. I saw that she never wanted to compliment me, I remembered times when she was secretly evil and putting me down or just not caring about me, I don't know why I just ignored her glaring flaws for so long. Its the price to pay for striving to be kind everytime. Its not like I'm going to start being an ass but I just don't care anymore. I just do what I think is right, no need to worry about looking nice. It took me this long to realise that a lot of people just don't care so much. Its also not what the world likes the most and you can never get by being so nice. "She was funny/hardworking/outgoing/pretty/fashionable. I like her. Oh yeah and she was nice I guess". Its always just a little bonus. It's time to move forward in life, do things that make me happy, stop letting people step all over me, live in the present.

There seems to be quite a lot of confessions on this page about the falling in love aspect of relationships such as how to get your crush to like you or tell if they're interested or how to ask someone out. I just wanted to share some of my fears regarding falling out of love, because falling in love is actually the easier part in my opinion.

Based on past experience, I feel that I fall out of love for the same reasons that I fall in love. This post from the Artidote explains it much better than I ever could.
 
"A lot of people ask me what my biggest fear is, or what scares me most. And I know they expect an answer like heights, or closed spaces, or people dressed like animals, but how do I tell them that when I was 17 I took a class called Relationships For Life and I learned that most people fall out of love for the same reasons they fell in it. That their lover’s once endearing stubbornness has now become refusal to compromise and their one track mind is now immaturity and their bad habits that you once adored is now money down the drain. Their spontaneity becomes reckless and irresponsible and their feet up on your dash is no longer sexy, just another distraction in your busy life.

Nothing saddens and scares me like the thought that I can become ugly to someone who once thought all the stars were in my eyes."

So I'm just wondering if anyone has some advice on how to maintain a relationship and continue loving your partner in the long term?

Thank you!

-
 
To 

For me, it's when you do the same thing with another person, and your first thought is not the past.

There are some r/s that you can get over entirely, there are some you never "get over", in the sense that you still care about the person and treasures all the memories you have made together. Nevertheless, you can still move on without having to trivialized the existence of your ex (or worse, hating him/her).

Sidenote: I feel that it is easier to let go of the past by appreciating the good things that happened. Acknowledge that, despite the failure of the relationship, you were truly happy in it. For me, it does weaken the negative thoughts/emotions, and maybe that's why I don't feel bitter about my ex. My 2 cents.

My experience taught me it's alright to never get over someone entirely. It just means you have once gave your all to someone and the memories, beautiful or not, is staying with you. The important thing is to learn to love again, and like I said it doesn't have to be mutually exclusive. 

My gf and I talk about our pasts once in a while or when things are in context. We don't get jealous over each other's good memories, and we comfort each other over the bad ones. In fact, we like to listen about the good memories and learn from the bad mistakes. What we could agree on is that the past shapes us but does not define us. Loving each other means accepting each other's past, and we have the future to create memories of our own.

However, it is important to know that all these have to be based on strong mutual trust. If either party is insecure, everything can crumble in a day. There was this other post about truth vs white lie, I'm all for truth. Maybe it hurts, but it also shows trust. Trust that he/she can accept your past. If he/she cannot, I suggest you rethink the r/s.

Anyway, an interesting question, is it difficult for guys to accept if he finds out that his gf isn't a virgin (which happens before the r/s)? Does this differ for virgin guys and non-virgin guys? My ex and I lost our virginity to each other, while in my current r/s, both of us aren't virgin and we know that before we got together so obviously it wasn't a problem.

dont know if my post got filtered but im wondering if a guy will like a girl from an entirely different religion? i really really like him

Hi, I'm a different OP from previously. In reference to post , I have experience in which you are lacking in.
So, I went to the polyclinic, visited the GP. told him i was pregnant, and told him I wanted to get a TOP. You have to tell him this, straight up. Then the poly set up an appt at KKH a week later. Went to the first appointment, went for the ultrasound. Then, turns out the fetus died at 7 weeks. That was tough. As you are waiting to see the doctor at the end to sign some papers and confirm the date of surgery, they will take you in for some counselling. 2 stops. One to discuss an alternate method, they will try to talk you out of it. The second, to discuss contraceptive methods. Then you see the doctor. The day surgery was a week later. 

I remember the entire period being one of the most demanding periods I had ever gone through. Other than that, it was right smack during finals but I had no choice. That was tough. The nausea didn't stop until the day of the surgery. 

Try to stay away from home. Minimise physical contact with your family, at least until everything is over. They will sense that something is wrong. However for me, I went through the entire thing without my family suspecting a single thing. 

I paid $150 through medisave. The other $600 my bf of that time helped to offset the cost. Even then, it caused a lot of emotional strain between us. We are no longer together. 

I wish you all the best, truly. I have been where you are. There will be countless nights leading up to the surgery where you feel stuck and it feels like shit but trust me, it gets better. Find people you can trust to confide in. If you can't, you have me. Most importantly, know that this is what you have to do and trust that you will get through this. God bless. 
-
 
Saw the post on the girl going for the abortion and quite a few confessions replying to it.  Thought of my own experience and would just like to share. 

I had been using protection consistently with my bf and we had only been only sexually active for about a month when disaster occurred.   I was shocked to find out from a usual doctor's visit late last year that I was pregnant.  I mean,  I thought  protection would be safe right?  So not!  It was quite shocking to suddenly have to deal with this,  as I come from a rather elite background and always thought that having a baby out of wedlock would only happen to naive teenage girls who didn't know better.  But alas,  this was me now. 

To be very honest,  there was not a bit of hesitation involved in making my decision.   I instantly contacted my boyfriend and told him the news and together,  we set out finding a suitable abortion doctor.  It was really more of a pracfical decision.  There was no way I could have a baby at that point of time.  Firstly,  my parents are very traditional and would probably kill me (okay maybe not literally but u get the drift) for having pre marital sex, what more for getting knocked up.  Secondly,  I was still studying and had no financial capability to raise a child.  Thirdly,  I had,  and still have,  no motherly instincts. I am young and would still like to have my fun and would not want to suddenly have to alter my entire lifestyle.   Lastly,  I have not been together with my boyfriend for that long yet.  If I were to keep the child and marry him (I don't want to be a single mum), I would be jumping into this decision to make this guy my husband and the one I will be with for the rest of my life.   This is definitely not something to be taken lightly.  Don't get me wrong,  I don't mean that abortion should be taken lightly.  But in my situation the pros weighed heavily against the cons.

Getting the abortion was kind of scary to me as I don't have a high pain tolerance and was not too sure what to expect.  Furthermore, I was in the second trimester already,  which necessitated a more complicated and painful procedure.  I was really self-conscious about what others might think too. As I still look kind of young I guess,  at the gynaecology clinic,  I kept thinking that people were staring at me and judging me for being pregnant before marriage.  Perhaps I'm just paranoid but this mental barrier was not easy to overcome. 

Long story cut short, I went for the abortion with my boyfriend's company and support.  He was really a great source of strength and I am glad that he gave me complete autonomy in the decision to make.   He also paid for the entire procedure which was really expensive as it was a second trimester abortion and one done at private hospital. My procedure caused  me quite a lot of pain but I was relieved when it was all over. 

For now life is back to normal.   Just occasionally I will have the fear that my parents may discover the truth someday.  I guess I will deal with it if it really happens,  but for now I prefer to hide this secret deep deep down.  And when the time is right, I will have a child of my own.

-
 
If I die, don't cry. I would have left living my life to my fullest. I may not have been in the best of health, or the happiest of states, but I know I would have died while doing all the things I chose to do :)

If I die, please come to my funeral. Don't talk about me, or the happy memories we had. Take this special time to catch up with the people you missed for the past few or even tens of years. Friendships never die, and I just gave you the best, most convenient excuse to ensure it doesn't :)

If I die, please don't bring gifts of bereavement or mourning. Don't bring 白金 or white gold. Optimistically I would have saved enough to pay off my own funeral and be of no burden to my family. Instead, use that money for something else. Something meaningful - charity, making someone happy, or even just for an act of kindness. I think dead me would like that a lot better :)

If I die, please don't hate me anymore. Between my life and death, I am sure that I would have done and said things that upset. I've moved on; will you? Maybe you'll see that from a broader perspective, there's no use blaming human beings. We make mistakes, we learn from it. It's not to late to reconcile with a friend/loved one whom you've been holding a grudge against? :)

If I die, don't leave my family with words of condolences. Help me. I never know when I'll move on from life, so help me. Help my wife and my children, with anything at all. Ideally I would like my kids to pick up some useful life skills, maybe expand on their interests in sports, games or whatever. If my wife is lonely, take her out sometime. Help me, because I no longer can :)

If I die, please don't love me anymore. I was a part of your life, and I no longer am. I've literally left! Channel all that into something meaningful, on something/someone living. In life, I hate being a burden or imposing on someone/others. I would very much like to maintain that stance in death :)

If I die, thank you. Not thank you that I'm dead. Thank you for having walked this life with me. Whether we knew each other for 10 minutes or 10 years. It's been great :)

You must be having a lot of courage to be able to describe your sad feelings in words and share it. Also, no need to look for likes. Your worth does not depend on them. Write what you feel like and don't care so much about what other people think. There are some people (like me) who read your post but are too shy to like because they wouldn't want to reveal their identity.

I have been in your situation before. Exactly like that. From your text messages, I feel that you were normal friends earlier but after a certain point, you began to sound pushy, especially when you asked whether she got your message. She is not into you. It is  painful to accept, but you have to accept it. She may have figured out that you like her and she doesn't want to lead you on, so she avoids you. Girls are quite sensitive at noticing these things.

I know you feel sad because she prefers J over you. It has NOTHING to do with you dude. It didn't work out because there was no chemistry. Don't try to analyse further. Don't compare yourself with J in terms of wealth, looks etc. You are what you are and that is what makes you unique. Someday some girl will love you for who you are and accept your financial status.

Reduce contact with A. Don't text her so often. Let it go and move on. It is painful but you need to accept the reality. You have better things in store for yourself. This is not the end of the world. She wasn't the right one. Not saying she is good or bad, she just wasn't the one for you. Leave it to fate. Love will come and find you. You don't have to chase it. It will be very obvious when you love a girl and she loves you back and it will happen someday. Just don't lose hope. :)

In the meantime, don't feel sad about having crushes. It is very normal and it adds to your experience. Remember, the pain that doesn't kill you makes you stronger. In the future, you will recall these memories and pat yourself on the back for having the strength to overcome disappointments in life.

Since there are many relationships/sex/marriage/dating posts thus far I had the urge to write this post as well, since exams are over (for most now) please read it and let me know what you think. If you still have exams, it's really long and please read it only if you need something to read for a break.

I do not deny that it isn't easy finding the right partner. My brother has been dating many girls (depends on your definition of dating, some of you may define it as hanging out as friends) before he finally found the right one for him. 

I on the other hand, am in a different set of circumstances. I am not exactly very smart nor very good looking, and have faced numerous 'rejections' thus far by the opposite sex. It may be the case that my approach was wrong but these rejections were mainly by girls who were attracted greatly to the superficial stuff (nothing wrong with being attracted to it but Im highlighting the word 'greatly' here). 

I'll give a few examples, I used to like (or so i thought) these two girls, lets call them A, and B. A was like an ideal girl during that time for me, she was sporty, friendly and fun to be with, (note that if we were to talk about looks she isn't good looking). I hung out with her, studied with her and had fun in general with her, and I thought we had an exclusive thing going on between us. Soon later I introduced her to my friends whom she got close to as well. Long story short, a few months down the road, she stopped replying my texts, or our conversations would mainly end with a 'haha' or 'ok' from her. 

I was crushed, and curious as to why this was happening and I traced back hundreds of texts to start inferring what happened that could've lead to this downturn in our >friendship thing or even our friendship, since everytime i asked if something was wrong she would either not reply or reply with 'nothing haha' after 10 hours. I realised that there was this brief conversation that we had (which was like the marker for shorter and shorter conversations subsequently):

Me: Hey what're you doing?

A: Had pingpong training! soo tired hahaha, gonna go back and take a warm shower now :)

Me: Oh i had pingpong training also, but I didn't get to exert at all heh, the coach only let the main players train as its competition period

A: huh, you not school team?

Me: haha i not so pro lah

(sidenote: we were from different schools, but met in primary school and were in multiple tuitions together in secondary school, kept in contact on and off then, and then got close when we were about 19)

A: -noreply-

Me (2 days later, attempting to start another convo): Ehh how've you been? btw this weekend wanna have breakfast/lunch/dinner? Anyday is ok :) can go to the eatery near your house! 

A: Haha uhh maybe, see how? :) 

Me: ok!!!! haha are you doing ok? You told me your exams are coming and you're always tired from training

A: Ya haha, very tired lah wish someone could send me home instead of taking the bus everyday, then got more time to study lor. :p

Me: ohhh I wish I could haha, if i had a car :d. Next time when i get a car can send you wherever you want. :P

A: :P i thought someone already has a car then why never send me :(

Me: huh what you talking about? dont have haha!

A: Huh then that time after we all met (note: with the friends i introduced her to) at xxx cafe you sent your sis to tuition that car not yours meh.

Me: Huh ohh!!! that car my cousin one lah I help him collect from repair shop cause he overseas. 

A: Oh ok. haha

Me (the next day): so this weekend on? :)

A (next tuesday): oh sry my phone spoilt so i couldnt get your message.

Me: huh... ok

And that was where we started talking less and less. I asked my close friends for advice and they were like aya maybe her phone really spoil, dont think so much lah, you guys so close liao now, maybe thats her way of texting someone shes close to also (referring to the way she talks in general, not the MIA for a week). 

So we didnt talk for like... 3 weeks?

3 weeks later:

A: heyyyyy u there? :)

Me: haha wassup? yea i am

A: do you have jason (not his real name)'s number?

Me: huh what do you want his number for 

A: -noreply-

(Note: jason was one of the guy friends i introduced her to, he used to be my classmate.)

2 weeks later:

Me: hey how've you been, so long never talk haha, ok not

A: -noreply-

Me (2 days later): yooooo, got my message?

A: ya haha. 

Me: Free tmrw night not your exams end liao right! dont say not free haha

A (the next day): probly not, going out with friend.

Me: oh ok.

The next day:
I was scrolling through facebook and i saw her and jason tagged together in numerous photos, they had dinner at an expensive place (estimated $40 per pax (sorry my threshold for food prices is pretty low)), and they also went to gardens by the bay. Just the two of them. Garnering my courage, i texted jason.

Me: Eh dude how've you been man

J: ok la chilling now that exams end

Me: haha i saw that you went out with A ;)

J: HAHA how you know sia :PP

Me: On facebook lah, u guys together ah

J: no laa, but I asked her out she said yes lorrr :p

Me: haha gratz (note: im already crushed by this stage)

How could i compete with J? J came from a wealthy family, had his own car (a cheap mercs but still a mercs), and would always pick up the full tab whenever he went out with her (I always call for a split-bill as i do not think it is right splurging on a friend or anyone else with my parents' hard-earned money). 

Ok i havent gotten to the part about now (5 years in the future), and to girl B as well. But I will so, please let me know if you want to know more guys and I'll write because a post like this already took me 2 hours. It'll be painful to write more if I cant get a word of affirmation. thank you. (i know my language isnt good sorry)

So please like this post if you'd like part B.

Reply to 
Three years ago, my mom said similar things to me too. Back then, my bf was still studying an engineering course, not having a spectacular GPA(he was in NTU), but I was getting pretty good results in my JC back then. He had no idea of where his future lies. He said he might want to take some fitness training teaching course and become a private trainer next time. He was just very uncertain of what he's gonna become in future. To make things worse, we came from very very different family background too. My family is considered wealthy? But he has divorced parents and his parent not earning 1/5 of what my dad brought in every month. Do no take my wrongly, just want to lay the background out to let you know how different we were, but I had never ever looked down on my bf. I do not believe in 门当户对 but what's more important is, a couple needs to have similar future aspects.

My mom told me not to be so serious. She thought my bf didn't seem like a reliable nor responsible person. She did not foresee us having a good future together. She thought he would not be able to take care of me(especially financially). We stayed in private properties ever since young, but my bf stays in a HDB flat. She told me, I would never get used to staying in such a small flat without all the facilities and bigger space and luxurious feeling. She was very very skeptical and it really broke my heart when she told me that. She had her points and I had to agree with her whatever flaws she mentioned about my bf were absolutely right. However, I had faith in my bf.

Three years later today, my bf got a scholarship and signed on. He is earning more than 4K per month now and I am very proud of his achievements. His family background is still the same but again, that's not important to me. His mom loves me and treats me very well. My mom has changed her view to him and unofficially agreed on my decision to take him as my future spouse.

I just want to say, the condition now may not be well but if you have faith in your bf, things will only get better. All the best!

As a person who is extremely passive, I didn't make any effort to befriend this girl from my philosophy tutorial class throughout the semester. During reading week, I realized that I would like to know her better, and so I gathered some courage to attempt to talk to her after the paper. 

The paper was a 2h MCQ paper which I completed fairly quickly, and thus waited outside MPSH1 while calming my nerves. When she came out much later, she started looking around, and while I was about to walk up to her, another guy joined her, and they started to leave the area. Not knowing if the guy was just a casual friend, I didn't have any guts to approach her, so I merely watched as they walked off. Since it was my last paper, I decided that this chapter has closed, and I should probably forget about it and move on.

My hopes of making my first friend since entering uni was crushed today... guess I will be returning to the daily lonesome grind in a month or so. I would like to advise the more introverted people out there to act decisively if you're trying to forge friendships, not wait until the end of the semester. 

This song describes how I've been feeling about my life in general.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aVU0NnSoEKM

Also, if you happen to see this (though I don't think you have facebook?), I just want you to know that you have a really nice smile and personality.

Reply to ,

I am kinda in the same situation like you but in my case our roles switched. It's my boyfriend that went through the similar past that you shared about. However, sadly, his is worse. He gave his virginity to his ex too. He didn't want to tell me but, let's just cut it short, I found out about it. It was very very very, hurtful when I realised everything that he'd told me was a lie. To be fair, it was his past and I had no right to know if he didn't want to tell. However, now that I know about it already, the thoughts of him f**king his ex always appear out of no where and it's just freakin annoying. I honestly do not know when will all these thoughts stop coming to me. Maybe my whole life? 

My suggestion is, if your bf asks, you shall not lie. But if he doesn't mention it at all, maybe he doesn't want to know it. In that case just let it go. But if you are planning to go far with him, I don't think there should be any secrets between a couple. So, just tell him. Though it will hurt like hell. But if he does truly loves you, he will stay. Just like how I'm still together with my bf after 2.5 years because I love him though his past won't stop haunting me.

-
 
I had an interview a few weeks back, and I would like to share something that really struck a chord in me.

It was a skype interview for a career opportunity overseas. The interviewer asked me a very interesting question: "share with me a life lesson that you have learnt in university. I do not want to hear those standard 'teamwork' or 'time management', tell me something more personal. Don't worry, it doesn't have to be work-related." After clarifying what he wanted, I took a minute to think about it and this is what I to shared (or almost).

I learnt about hate. 
I learnt how people fight with one another over CAP, over the bell curve, at the canteen to queue up, boarding the ever-crowded NUS shuttle bus. I hated them. 
I learnt to hate certain professors for their style of teaching. I've learnt to hate certain modules as their content is incredibly dry and boring. 
I've seen how cliques break apart. I've seen how friends become enemies due to hate. I've seen how couples become strangers due to hate (a lot in fact). I've seen how people backstab one another just to get the better of one another. I've seen how people avoid one another because they hate another.
I've learnt to hate the flaws of our education system. I've learnt to hate the NUS negative academic environment and pressures. I've learnt to hate people and things around me.

Bringing this hate out of university, it becomes a reality in the working world. We fight with our colleagues for results, to prove that we are better, we hate them if we lose. We hate having to pretend to like our colleagues even though we dislike them.
We hate fighting with all other people to get to/from work. We hate the social pressures of having to 'fit-in'. 
We hate our bosses because we feel that they are unreasonable or terrible leaders. We hate the working pressures to keep your job. We hate having to meet the KPIs set by our bosses. 
This hate that I learn from university, it simulates the working world. This hate drives us. It pushes us to outdo one another, but at the same time it demotivates us. This hate, is powerful.

But at the same time, I learnt about love.
I love how people, just strangers, come together at the start of their university lives to become friends, forming cliques and going through hardship together. I love how lively and vibrant the university is with activities happening all around. I love the freedom when it comes to studying. I love the fact that I have the opportunity to have fun with my friends everyday at school. I love how NUS provides convenient transportation services despite the overdemand at peak periods. I love how we are all driven to perform our best during examination. I love the cheap and delicious food in NUS. I love the people around me, looking past their flaw and seeing their beauty, their sincerity and friendliness. I love seeing how people find love in school, a few of them (seniors) are engaged/married now. I love the fact that we are one of the most recognised education systems in the world.
I've learnt to love people and things around me.

This love. I will love it if I have the courage and ability to apply this to my future career. Will I be able to? Will I love my job? Will I love my colleagues and boss? How powerful can this love be? Only time will time.

I believe most of us hate readily, but I urge everyone to try and love as well. It seems to be easier to be a hater than a lover. A simple act of commenting on NUSWhispers, how many of you are haters and how many of your are lovers? 
How many of us will be able to say that we love more than we hate? I know I myself cannot say for sure. What about you? Do think about this and reflect and share your story if you want to. You never know if one day someone asks you this question for interview!

-
 
With the multiverse theory, there will be a universe out there where we are together.

We'd still be spending our days together, laughing about things we read on the internet and maybe relaxing in hall. Maybe we'll go out to dinner, somewhere significant like we always used to. We'd trade notes like we do every year, and I'd add it to my ever growing pile of gifts from you. On rainy days you'd shelter me from the thunder and we'd cuddle and play video games until it was over. In this universe, we wouldn't have ended like we did. They say time heals, but I say time helps us to forget. Forget how everything felt when we were together, forget the promises we made that we never kept. But we never truly heal.

One day I hope we can meet up, and we can talk like we used to. One day when the pain has subsided, one day when we stop hurting.

There's this classmate of mine who takes CM2142. Every Monday he would saunter into the lecture hall and have a seat.

I began to grow slightly fond of this smart guy who I will just abbreviate as "VH".

However, speaking to other batchmates revealed the other, more perverse side of him. He would regularly make fun of everyone, be it lecturer or tutor. He would snigger at how easy the module is. He would also put on airs suggesting how smart he is together with his friend, who I respect.

Soon I lost interest in "VH" until I heard recently that he was into gay porn.

Today, I say for my CM2142 exam. The essay question was difficult. I know I can't beat "VH".

But it's all over now, for "VH" is gone from my life. At least I know I can beat "VH" in decency and character.

I've been in a relationship with my bf for almost 4 years. Let's call him A. All seems well until recently when my mum had a serious "talk" with me abt how she doesn't think A is my "destined one". Reasons being 1. A doesn't seem like a man enough guy who I can entrust my future with... Yes I admit that A can be quite timid and unsure of himself at times, but I fully understand his insecurities and have always been encouraging him. I believe that it just takes time for him to mature. Reason 2. A doesn't pay for our dates...We like to split the bill, and mum feels that that shouldn't be the case in an official relationship. But given that A's family is not very well off and he has yet to start working, I don't think I should be imposing any financial burden on him now. 

There are also many other reasons that are too trivial to even talk abt :( but what my mom said really saddens me...I thought my parents liked him and I ve always been very sure abt this relationship. Despite his flaws, A has always been a very supportive, loving and doting boyfriend. And I absolutely loathed it when my mum insists that he is not the one for me. I hate myself even more for being affected by her words and casting doubt on my relationship. ;( I'm just...so sad right now...have been bottling up all my feelings for days! Well the thing is, how physically closer can you be with someone other than sex? How more "open" emotionally and physically can you be?

Personally, I keep it because I believe that I want to share it only with one person whom I love and who loves me so much that we have promised to commit to each other through thick and thin to the end ( i'm one of those who do not believe in divorce). Why would I share a special moment with someone who does not reach that level of closeness? I think that kind of love that requires commitment deserves to be celebrated. Our culture often describes love as merely a feeling or emotion. I think love is more than that.

Also, even if the notion that "sex/ vitginity is valuable" is a social construct, so what? what's wrong with that?( I do not think it is, though, I think it is there for a reason) Why can't I keep some part of me special and reserved? A VIP room is special because people set aside a special area for special people, and only certain people can come in. It makes it special. Why can't we reserve sex for a special person who deserve it? Sure we can save other moments, i guess, though as of now i can't think of anything better. 

Based on experience, I regretted that I kissed my ex. I shared a moment with someone that I barely talk to now. I do not regret it to the point that I see myself as not pure anymore etc etc or that it affects my self-esteem etc. Just that I wished I did not easily share that intimate moment with someone in the heat of the moment. Probably because I want to see it as more than just physical pleasure and I think it is an expression of love (and I think love requires commitment)

On the topic of rape, I agree that a raped woman is not of less value than a virgin. I know the pain and shame is extremely hard to bear with, but demeaning sex/ virginity is not the answer. Like, even children who do not even understand what sex means are traumatised by sexual abuse. Their tendency is to avoid the rapist. They sure do not like it. It is natural to feel sad/traumatised when you are sexually abused. 
Just like when people are slashed, they bleed, they feel pain. 
Would we say that "it's okay,the cut will heal anyway " and do nothing? 
No, we should recognise that it is a painful experience and try as much as we can to heal them, though we cant do it completely. There will still be unsightly scars that make them want to hide at home
People who look down on the victims are like those who mock the slash victim because of the physical scars.
 It is unsightly, maybe. We might have to admit that rape victims might have emotional scars that affects them.
Instead of dismissing their pain, we should show compassion, understanding and empathy. Each of us are broken in some ways anyway.

To  If your friend is not a b-baller, model or any role that requires height to be advantageous, he probably needs a gf to feel secure. That's likely his area of insecurity, if not, I am not sure why he is feeling so low. You can try narrowing down his insecurity to its roots to figure out how to offer a new perspective.

I am shorter than your friend, and my height has been stagnant since secondary 1. It has never been an issue of concern to me. It definitely helps to build up confidence in oneself, but I don't have any tangible advice to dispense. I always think I am smart, calm, funny, handsome, and have a whole lot of other awesome characteristics. Some people are just innately more insecure than others, and it is really hard to get them to man up.

Two other things for your friend to note:
1. The more you show that you are affected, the easier it is to attract things that affect you. Take things in your stride, and give the "hahaha c'mon shoot me more, like I give a fuck" attitude.
2.  Maybe it also helps to be politely vulgar to people who are mocking him. I always say "Fuck you lah" in a friendly/nonchalant tone to silly things, silly people, or mildly offensive stuff. Don't remember things turning confrontational, or anyone trying to step over my head. 

Your friend can learn to be comfortable with laughing at himself, and also be more confident in saying no. Grumpy cat is your best mentor.

Response to the comment in 

You are contradicting yourself here, saying that you are not insisting on  OP "having any other contact" while saying that she "should tell the guy".

I would feel really creeped out if I were the OP. There aren't enough facts here to assume that a 5 min talk will resolve the problem, like you seem to believe. I'm actually curious as to what makes you think a talk will straighten things out. Certainly that is one possibility, but we can go to the other end of the spectrum and say that he might be so enraged as to hurt the OP when the OP tells him the truth. 

Staying quiet is not something that gives that guy the right to do all that. Like you said, there are many reasons for acting a certain way. The same can be said for the OP as well. You seem to presume that the OP is behaving like this for no particular reason. You may not understand why the OP is staying quiet, perhaps the OP is frightened, perhaps the OP has a traumatic experience, there are all sorts of possible reasons. 

I don't think there is a need to tell because this is obviously just a problem to this guy, which is why he has been disturbing the OP. In fact, I think it is an issue he needs to resolve by himself, by reflecting upon his actions and not just the author's behaviour. If the guy doesn't understand her silence, he probably won't understand even if the OP explains it. 

Nonetheless, even if there is a strong case for OP's obligation to tell the guy, it doesn't justify his actions or words.

-
 
So here's the guy's side of the story (long story ahead).

I met her earlier this year, when we were still freshies. There's something about being a first-year that I miss: the magical feeling of having a whole uni life ahead filled with promise. 

Anyway, I was really attracted to her and asked her out. We hung out quite a few times after that - lunch, llaollao, escape room.. I remember how we texted everyday and supported each other through midterms and finals. How, despite our very different courses, we found common interest in horror movies - sharing and discussing our favorites late into the night. 

We talked about everything. We talked about the ideal number of kids to have in a family. We argued over the correct way to express a facepalm using emoji. When she ran a fever I rushed to bring her medicine. But what I remember the most is how we agreed to go on exchange together - I even asked her to cook for me, and she responded that she didn't mind!

I guess I will never know if that meant anything to you at all. But it meant the world to me.

Fast forward. The new semester came. Year 2. When the workload starts piling up, it's easy to lose touch of the people around you. By the time I realized, we had become more distant than I ever imagined. Every conversation ended abruptly with my texts going unreplied. When I asked her out to a special event, she told me to ask another girl, a mutual friend. It cut me deep.

As the weeks went by I became increasingly confused and upset. 
"Why are you ignoring me?" 
"It hurts."
Nothing seemed to move her. That's when I decided I would have to go and find her in person to get an explanation at least. 

I found her sitting in the LT after her lecture. We had small talk but I couldn't bring myself to ask her the questions that had been suffocating me for months. Just when I thought I had maybe started things going on the right track again, she texted me afterwards that it was uncomfortable for her and never to do that again.

I was crushed.

What was I supposed to do? If you didn't want to be friends anymore, just tell me early. Yes, it would have hurt, but I would have been fine after that. Leaving me hanging was such a cowardly thing to do - absolving yourself of responsibility at the expense of someone else.

I won't lie. Things got a little ugly in the end and I swore at her (through msg). Judge me if you will but I did what I had to do.

Judging from her whispers post, it's evident that she treats friendships as disposable: something you can neglect when you don't feel like being a friend anymore, and reconnect when it suits you. I guess that's where our similarities end. I can only hope that she treats her other friends better.

To  
I am a girl, and because of an ex-boyfriend who kept pressurising me to have sex (but was unsuccessful; this constant pressurising was the reason why I called it off), I viewed my virginity lightly then, and even considered just giving it to him when I was still with him. His constant pressurising made it seem as though it was nothing much (which I believe that's the opinion of many - we all have the right to our own opinions). 
It was only when I met my current boyfriend (after breaking up with my ex) that I was so relieved I kept my virginity, and I now see the value of it. I guess I can call myself a convert on this issue. A few days ago I literally looked down there (self sex ed lesson I guess - sorry if it's TMI), and I realised that I have never seen it properly before. It dawned on me how precious and private these parts are, and many of us (virginity believers or not) may not see the beauty of it. I feel that we should have more self-love, we're beautiful creatures. Treat yourself with care.
My current boyfriend is very conservative, and does not take kissing lightly as well, so I guess that also influenced me. I'm actually less conservative than him and has initiated things that he wasn't ready for yet. (Maybe my boyfriend is a special case)
But what my past relationship and my current relationship have taught me was that there's a reason why you should keep your virginity until marriage (but of course you really have to love the person when you decide to marry him/her, else, the marriage will probably fail). It is mainly because sex is an act of love, an act of the deepest connection you could ever have with someone, and you really want to do it with someone you love very much, because you will remember it forever.
While I have not lost my virginity yet, I lost my first kiss to my ex (and a couple of other acts), and from time to time I get reminded of it, and I regret it. In fact, sometimes I even feel disgust (obviously it didn't end well - I'm not speaking for those whose past relationships ended well) that it happened. I'm sure I will remember it forever, and regret it forever. My current boyfriend is an absolutely great guy, and I wished I never had these bad memories from my past relationship, and have saved it for him instead. Of course I can't undo these things I've done. Now I'm certainly saving my virginity for him on our wedding night (or if anything happens which I hope not, the next person I will love). 
So, you will certainly remember your virgin experience as well. So are you sure you want to give this up to someone you may not be together forever/love forever? (not saying that marriage lasts forever either - that's why you really need to marry someone that you really love and can foresee yourselves building a life together) You are going to remember your first time forever (feel free to disagree with me on this). And what if... Just what if, it doesn't work out between you guys? You will bring this memory with you forever, and you just can't erase it, and this regret may follow you for a long time to come. If you can't bear this thought, don't create this memory.
And if after it falls apart you meet someone fabulous and someone you love even more than your previous, then now what? Whenever you both engage in sexual acts, you will always be reminded of your first time with someone else. At that point in time, would you have wished you have saved it for this perfect person instead? There's no "start over" then.
I have to stress that I'm not coming from a religious angle (sorry if the part on beautiful creatures seems so), and that I am a free-thinker. I'm just highlighting how because we always keep those parts private, we may not actively see the beauty of it, and how we should really let only someone we love very deeply handle it. We all have private parts, something that belongs only to ourselves - we're equal like that, I guess. Something we can truly call "our own". It should be something personal, something vulnerable, something you reveal to someone you really trust. This is something I really disliked about my ex - the fact that he's always so open to giving something so private to him to others and that he even influenced me to think like him. 
I don't see how virginity should not be held onto even when someone is 24. Love yourself enough to acknowledge that your current relationship, no matter how great it is, may not be your last, and it is a risk to create a permanent memory of something that may be temporary. Choose wisely. 
Believe me, I have seen virginity lightly before and I didn't realise how precious it could be. And now I do. To have a self sex-ed lesson only at 20 is a tad late, and I can already imagine how inexperienced I can be on my wedding night and just how much I really don't know about sex, but hey, I think it will be a sweet (albeit awkward) memory to learn along with your partner - it's going to be sweet if you guys really love each other. 
PS. I'm sorry if this post has offended anyone (virginity believers or not/religious or not) - I certainly do not mean to, and I'm just sharing my thoughts and my own experience. Feel free to disagree, it's a free world.

Dear op of  , or to whoever needs an opinion on the matter that their bf/gf doesn't allow them to have interaction with the opposite gender. He/She is just your partner for now. Assuming that things doesn't go well and both of you decide to go your separate ways, the person controlling your interaction with the opposite gender is going to hurt your interest in the long run.

Assuming that you are more than likely to get attached after a break up, you will definitely have to know people of the opposite gender and you just eliminated yourself out of the competition by keeping to yourself because you oh so love your current partner so much that you are afraid to hurt his fragile feelings.

To come up with a pragmatic deduction for his actions, he is likely to be knowing more people just in case things turn sour. He will still have other people that he chase after. So why not just do the same thing that your partner is doing?

-
 
 I might not be the best of people to provide advice coming from an evergreen, but here's my two cents as a fellow bro: That's an obvious no-no. 

It might not feel like it, but it's a short-lived infatuation. You might be attracted by her looks, her personality or anything really that caught your eye. Don't let that confuse you. If you don't even know her that well, you might find that she's not the one for you. 

Worse still, if she doesn't have an interest in you beyond friends. It may end up making your current friendship awkward or even end it if she's the type who avoids dealing with these awkward situations.

Not discouraging you from going for her though. Go out with her a few times for lunch or something, the simpler the better. Avoid movies unless you'll spend time talking over a meal afterwards. Use that chance to talk to her and get to know her personally. Engage in some htht once she's comfortable enough to share it with you and learn more about each other.

After a few one-on-one outings, if you still feel the same way as before, then go ahead and confess. Better yet if you can "sense" that she likes being around you. Don't rush it. There is no time limit to getting into a relationship. You have your whole life ahead of you so just enjoy the process. All the best~

-
 
I agree with , although for a different reason. The issue isn't really about sex, it's about what each of you want in the relationship. We all want different things, what you want may be different from what your partner wants. But more importantly, what you want now may conflict with what you want in the longer-term. For instance, wanting sexual pleasure now may come in the way of wanting a sustainable long-term meaningful relationship. May. 

So it's about the relative importance you place on your current wants vs future wants vs partner. If you place so much importance on your current wants and your partner compromises, then all's good. But if your partner doesn't, then you have to weigh how important your wants are vs how important your partner is to you. If your current wants are so important that you would seek other means to fulfill them, then perhaps you guys are not suited for each other after all. Or put another way, since your partner views her wants as far more important than yours, then maybe you guys aren't suitable for each other. 

Not saying either of you is "wrong" or anything, just saying that we all have to make decisions about what we feel is most important. If we can't find a compromise between conflicting desires or work things out, then maybe it's time to find someone else who has the same wants as you or is willing to compromise.

-
 
To , my gosh, I felt like I might've written that status myself. Do you also sometimes realise how similar some people are to yourself, and end up disliking them as they remind you of yourself? Cuz that's totally me right now. 

I haven't gotten out of the problem completely myself, but I have found some possibilities that I'm trying right now. 

1. Try to build your self esteem by getting really good at something. Actively test yourself on it and make it your thing. For me it's my piano skills. That way you have other things in your life to occupy your thoughts other than how lonely or insignificant you are in the lives of others. It'll also make you more interesting and have something you can tell/do with others when you get to that point. 

2. Resolve to make a change in your life and do something you thought you might've wanted to try. For me, I was always a math and science kind of person, but I've always wanted to try philosophy and literature. Was never a sporty person, but wanted to try a martial art. I ended up taking mods like PH1102E Intro to Philo, and GEK2020 Film Art. I also joined an introductory TKD course at a dojo outside of school. Some of these ventures worked out, others didn't, but I felt happier engaging in things I liked. More importantly, I felt like I was going somewhere, unlike my relationships with people, because I was making decisions in my own life. An added benefit of this is that now I have the general knowledge to talk with people interested in these aspects to some extent. 

3. Realise that people don't really judge you thaaaat harshly (as long as you observe good general social conduct), and relationships are actually more durable than you might think. In social situations people are probably more occupied with coming up with things to say and worrying how other people judging themselves than how much of a weirdo you are for saying / doing something. The important thing is, to be there, and be seen. Those who are never around are mysterious, silent, and thus weird. Once you have a relationship, people are typically willing to entertain some quirkiness, and it can be something that people relate to or joke about. So don't be afraid to show your flaws. (Disclaimer: this doesn't apply if your flaw is something that imposes on others. People will find it annoying really quickly and... shit happens. Fix it quickly.). Also, watch this video: https://www.ted.com/talks/brene_brown_on_vulnerability?language=en. It helped me a lot.

To get things going quickly, you could perhaps try to tie 1 and 2 together and find something you're even mildly interested in, join a related group and just go at it. You'll be able to work with like minded people and grow alongside each other, which is always a worthwhile experience. 

My advice dies though at this point though cause I'm still stuck myself, albeit in a different way. I've made good friends through my interests, so I do have people I can talk to, and relatively deeply too. The loneliness in the day is thus more manageable. But bridging this over to having people interested in you enough to evolve into a proper BGR (or whatever your inclination is) is still something I'm lost over. My attempts at love all end with a feeling of needing to sacrifice my dignity just for face time, and I am just getting increasingly frustrated. I am, seemingly, always the only one working on the relationship.

Since there's supposedly a lot of you out there, if you have overcome these problems and is willing to share, I'd gladly hear them.

 Hey I understand how you feel. I am also going through this lonely with no friends/gf phase right now. I am terrible at keep relationships as well, and I always wait for the other party to initiate contact with me. To make things worse, I am really shy and introverted as well, so getting to the real me is really difficult. The result? I only have one close friend from secondary school that I am still keeping in contact with, and he's attached as well.

 In classes nowadays I am that guy who is seemingly friends with quite a bit of people, but they are basically all acquaintances. So I guess we are quite similar in this respect. I wish to become closer friends with them, but I am too socially inept and awkward to do it. Even though I am acquaintances with them, I still sit in lectures alone. Have been this way and always been ever since I stepped into NUS 3 years ago, because I don't know anyone at first since I didn't join any orientation camps. I was so desperate for companionship and a girlfriend last academic year that I delved deeply into the PUA (Pick up artists) teachings and I almost flunked one semester because I was too obsessed with it.

If there was anything that I can take away aside from the many Cs and Ds I got last year, was that in order to form closer relationships, you have to be assertive and be open in relationships. If you aren't assertive and taking initiative in relationships, you will be living a very lonely life. Being a popular girl is quite advantageous in this respect, as usually guys will initiate contact with you, and from there you can decide whether to accept them or not. (Hooray to you :) ) But in order to form a deeper connection, being assertive is one thing, and being open to people is another thing too. The latter can be quite difficult for shy people. Personally, I am struggling with both right now, and I am trying to change myself by being less passive and be more outgoing and receptive to other people. From your posts I think you are ready to be open in relationships, but I think you have to be more assertive in initiating contact with your friends. 

I hope that you don't feel too alone in this with my post, and I hope that my experience can help you somewhat. Cheers :)

 If you would just spend more time trying to get to understand and know him, you'd realise that him, as with everyone else are never really closed off to relationships even if they appear to do so. Pardon me for my tone but it just seems to me as though all you are concerned with is what you yourself want and expect for yourself out of the relationship.

-
 
 If you are really in love with the person, your love for the person will be selfless? He or she comes before you. I don't find it difficult at all to not love a person who keeps doing nice things for me. You may feel this way and think you love him or her because you enjoy being loved and doted upon, or enjoy the attention etc. whatever it may be; you may in some sense be insecure, uncomfortable or unsure with yourself etc. But at the end of the day, if you don't love him or her, he or she will still only come after you. Ask yourself if he or she stops doting on you, will you still love him or her the same, love him or her for who he or she is, even his or her flaws and past, even if one day things turn bad for him or her.

Do spend the necessary time you need thinking, less you hurt any innocent party, if any. Think about what love means to you.

-
 
Hey , it is great that you are out there socialising, and that you have been proactive in befriending that person of interest (POI). You seem distressed and it is frankly not a good idea to be bogged down by these feelings during such a time- presuming you are a university student with exams imminent.

Perhaps you could cycle back on your focus on "finding the one"...now, and even later when you are about to join the fray again, advisably when you are more ready- emotionally, psychologically and if it's your thing to be, spiritually as well. I don't know you personally but it could be that your eagerness to connect presents itself as desperation, and desperation often doesn't sit well with people- whether you are looking to befriend someone or looking for something more. In more contemporary language, "chill".

Invest in your own potential OP, and harvest your own swag. Find "your thing". Refrain from adopting a fishbowl perspective- you said that ''apparently everyone finds (finding romantic partners) easy''. That sounds very much like a sweeping generalisation- people have different priorities, and if you can scroll through previous whispers you can see that NOT everyone finds it easy. So, ''chill".

You mentioned that POI is avoiding you. Well, perhaps POI does not feel comfortable with your advances, and/or is making an effort to reduce interactions with you because POI is not interested. Respect your POI, everyone has their limits. 

Lastly, your life is NOT worthless. Please do not ever peg your worth on the acceptance of your self by someone else- in ways romantic or otherwise. 

post-script: really disagree with GHY's advice of "acting like you don't care" and/or ''like you rejected them". You and POI are the ones who know most what the fact of the matter is. Don't swaddle your ego further because then not only are you deceiving yourself, you are hindering your growth. 

Be vulnerable. Be sincere. And "chill".

Now go listen to "We are young" by fun. Have fun. Studying.

-
 
To the OP of 12042: Hi, A! Sorry this comes so late after your confession. I'm a gay guy in NUS as well, and I know how you feel. Like you, I'm a typical guy who likes some sports and other guy stuff, exception being that I prefer the same gender. I see myself as a typical guy who happens to like other guys. In fact, some people to whom I've come out didn't believe that I'm gay at first. 

Initially, I had no plans to come out to anyone while in NUS. After all, my orientation doesn't affect my academics or my performance in group projects, so why should it be anyone business? And I was also afraid that it would give people even more reason to ostracize me. But when I was in year 2, I got to know an amazing group of friends. This group is made up mostly of straight guys. Being in the same major, we attended class together, studied in the library before finals, and basically hung out together a lot. Eventually in year 3, they noticed I was single and not looking, so they kept asking me if I liked anyone. That led to me coming out to 4 of them over dinner one day during summer break. And as things go in this particular group of friends, the word spread. Everyone's ok with it, and I'd go as far as to say they're supportive, helping me cope with bad dates, heartbreak, and all that. Because as they've told me, it's my life, and there's nothing wrong with being gay. If being with another guy makes me happy, then they shouldn't judge. To this day, I maintain that they're the best thing to happen to me in NUS, and I wouldn't trade their friendship for anything. 

Moral of the story is that your friends may be more open-minded than you give them credit for. But having said that, please also do your own due dilligence and really think about whether you feel comfortable about coming out to a particular person or group. Although it's rather cowardly, I'd say to err on the side of caution. If you don't feel totally safe telling someone, don't do it.

As for finding buddies and friends, I'd say to keep your eyes open. Sure, you could resort to certain infamous apps if that's your thing, but if not, there are more "legitimate" ways of making friends. Please also bear in mind that you don't hav to pretend to like girls. A possible approach would be to use the "single, not looking" thing like I did, or just refrain from participating in conversations in which your friends are rating girls and all that (Incidentally, I personally find that quite distasteful).
 
The situation with your male best friend...it's tricky. Not knowing much, I don't feel that it's my place to advise you to confess to him or anything like that. Just bear in mind that he could be super comfortable with you as friends, or he might be hinting that he wants a deeper relationship with you. If you're best friends, I believe that the both of you should be able to have a serious talk about this.

Hope all goes well for you! Remember, it's never as bad as it seems. Hang in there!
-
 
I just really need to get this out. 

People might think I am the popular girl and all but... I don't have friends. Or rather, I can't seem to keep my friends. Maybe it is because I am a horrible friend. 

I had a best friend in primary school. We drifted apart in upper primary due to change in class and later on, due to different secondary schools. We got to meet new friends and also had different timetable. 

In secondary school, my closer friends did not about my family situation (single parent family) because I was not able to accept it to share it. As we moved on to different JC, we drifted apart. New friends, new lifestyle, etc. 

In JC, i met a few friends who brought me out of my shell. Some from my class and some from my CCA. Same thing happened. Change of classes in J2, stepping down from CCA, drifted apart. J2 friends were good but J1 friends were better. Again, drifted apart once we graduated. 

Entering university, I met wonderful friends from camps and also got to know some really great course mates. But friends around me seem to be attached / getting attached. And over holidays, everyone have their own plans and we don't really meet. 

Maybe I'm a selfish person that doesn't care enough to keep my friends. Maybe I am not putting in enough effort but my mother have this mindset that there is no need for me to meet up with my friends so often and that there is no need to text them etc. Is it my upbringing or am I simply unimportant in my friends' life? 

For example, watching a movie, I don't have anyone to ask. All of them have watched the movie with their other friends or other half. 

I might seem like I know a lot of people and all but I truly have no one. There is no one I can talk to when I am stressed out. No one to talk to when I am having a bad day. No one to study with, no one to watch a movie with, no one. How can I change so that i can keep my friends?  T.T
