Just a story I wanna share with people reading this. 
I was madly in love with this lady. She was a mystery to me. At times, she would be really sweet and at times she would be very cold. Many times I tried to confess to her but wasn't give a clear answer yes or no. 

I reached my limit when she once went to India (which I am really not comfortable the security there), I tried to text her every day to know if she is safe there, but she wouldn't reply me (even when she read it) which made me very worried. I thought maybe she wants some peace over there. When she's back, she did not text me or anything until a friend told me. I know I can't blame her since we are not an official couple and then I told myself, time to forget about this one-sided relationship. Because I know I won't be happy when such situation happens again. 

6 months later around now, I found a girlfriend. And I thought we forgotten about each other until she texted me again saying wanting to get together and missing the things we used to do. I've told her straight away I have a girlfriend now, but she's still texting.

I am not asking any advice since I know I love my current girlfriend. And I will still tell her straight its not gonna happen. However, to guys and ladies out there, I know I'd sound like an asshole, but please, if you think opportunity will always be waiting for you, you're wrong. If you think you like someone, please let the other party know, else you'd regret the rest of your life.

Hey guys, Hope everyone's preparation for the finals are going well :) This is a rant, please skip it if you don't want to take in negative emotions. To the admins, please let this through... I would take comfort in the fact that I have not become completely invisible and non-existent yet.
That said, let me let out some of the causes for my lying in bed crying alone.
With my self-esteem having hit an all-time low,
Having developed a habit of screwing up everything,
Feeling like the best scenario is to merge into the background and fade away,
Feeling ashamed to be me for the first time in my life,
And I cannot even point a finger on the reason for being so miserable and negative
Feeling like I do not matter at all
In the grand scheme of things, if I were to die, the world or even the people surrounding me would not lose anything.
I have always been ambitious and dreamy but now I feel like everything I have ever thought to be true about me is being torn down, tested and annihilated. I just don't know who I am or what I am here for anymore and it is destroying my soul a bit more everyday.
I am trying my best to hold on to something, to hold everything in (haha, not even like I have any true friend I can confide in), to hold everything together and not fall apart. Why do I have to be so damn defensive?! How easy would it be to break down and let go of every single thing that is eating away at me?! But no, in my heart of hearts, I know that I will never be able to do that, because I suck at expressing myself, because I will never ever be able to look them in the eyes if I ever broke down to someone.
To all my project team mates, I am sorry if you think I did not contribute more to the projects. I assure you, I did everything that you asked me to and the things I felt were left out in the discussions, it is just that I didn't update you on what I did and didn't do and remained silent when you agreed on something which I personally didn't agree with because I was afraid of being judged and shot down (what is the point of being a one-person minority anyway?!), that you got the impression of me just slacking. 
From experience, I am tired of being shot down in team projects, admittedly because of my inability to express myself clearly. Why does every single damn thing have to be done in teams? Where would the introverts among us seek reprieve?! I wish our education system would allow all of us to shine through, then again, who the hell am I kidding?! Uni education tends to the career prospects and when the world is so damn extroverted, OF COURSE, they are looking to develop extrovertedness and team skills in everyone. Sigh... I wish I did not have to pretend so much in my everyday life... Introverts, shy people and socially awkward people out there, Touch your heart and tell me, you have not pretended to enjoy teamwork because that is what everyone looks for, in our careers, for our CCAs, in the EXCOs...
How I wish I could just die without a care! What is the purpose of living in a superficial world?! I cannot sense anything other than scheming, planning, pretending and tailoring in the air. How I yearn to experience love and acceptance in the environment around us... It is not to be. God, I never thought I would ever lose hope before, but now, I realise how easy it is and how close I am to doing so...

I am sorry that it was such a long, probably incomprehensible post. Just one more request to the commenters, save your snarky comments please, I have enough crap to deal with on my own. Thanks.

Guys always ask girls to make a move, but as girl I can say that it's not as easy as it seems. In society, it is normal for guys to be hitting on girls and getting rejected. In fact it kind of shows that those guys have balls. But if girls were to do the same and get rejected, her worth is diminished. This is what most girls feel and that's why even if I like a guy I won't make a move until that guy shows me that he's interested first. In fact to me, it's better this way since a guy who would bother to go through all that trouble to show you he's interested despite possibly getting rejected is probably more worth it than a guy who is interested but not enough to come after you

just two cents from a girl for all the guys out there

I never post. First time on this page. But I thought I might, as I see some posts on lonely people. Here's my take:

I spent 4 years of my uni alone. I made no friends from my course. I refused to have any obligations to people. Never went to any camps. I have never felt more free in my life. Facebook is good enough.

Don't feel negative about being lonely. Embrace it. Go for a 6hour hike by yourself. I do that. Its fun. You learn about yourself.

Don't feel pressured by the "need to be socialised". We are the ones with the wild style. 

Safe.

But in the end he didn't. He also unfriended me on fb and blocked my WA/calls. Anyway similar to yours, I also met my ex on a dating app. I guess it's not a good platform to find a proper SO yeah? There must be a reason why the people there are still single, despite some of them having above average looks and good career. A shoutout to all guys and girls out there who are thinking of 'ghosting' their dates, if you know right from the start that you're not that into them, please don't drop any hint that you're interested and after that disappear like nothing happened. For those already attached, take some time to sit down and talk to your bf/gf about what has gone wrong that leads to your decision to end the relationship. Because being 'ghosted' hurts so so bad. Breaking up sucks, but knowing that you're not even worthy of a proper breakup is a lot worse.

I believe the reason for that is because I am afraid for letting people see the true me, I am afraid of getting judged for the weirdo that I am, even though I know this is a highly irrational and self defeating thinking that I have.

Recently, I have been reading up on massive amounts of self help books, in a bid to better my interpersonal skills, and though I can see slight differences, I still can't help by being depressed when I see I am so many years behind my peers socially. People I know have close friends since young, bonds built upon one another, and eventually finding their soul mates by now. Some of them are even getting married. Heck, some of them already have kids! Meanwhile I am still trying to crawl, trying to find friends and trying to find a girlfriend.

The former, well, I have quite a few of acquaintances now, but I have no idea how to become close friends with them. But I do have a few friends now though. The latter, man I am still a wreck. I get so nervous and awkward when I talk to girls that I have practically zero female friends right now.

Right now, instead of studying, I am thinking about how great it will be if I have a girlfriend right now, thinking about the future possibilities together. Thinking about future possibilities is what kept me going for so long without intimate human contact, but recently dark thoughts about how I will end up forever alone is beginning to depress me. I have read that to be attractive to a girl, you must be confident and not be desperate. But how does one be confident and not desperate when you have spent 24 years single, with no girls ever seemingly giving off the much-mentioned ''signals'' to you, and when you have no prior dating experience to start with? And also not to mention being such a nervous wreck when I am around the opposite sex, and I have read that girls want guys with lots of experience.

After typing all of the above and reading through, even I am cringing at my own inability... Why is life such a struggle? I am trying hard to prevent falling back into the victim mentality I had long ago, but when life deals you with such shitty personality it is really hard to be positive.

I am sorry that this post is so depressing, it came out kind of in a different way I wanted it to, just wanting to ask for relationship advice at first. This is the OP of  here. I wanted to thank ,  and  for sharing your experiences.

This problem has plagued me for over 10 years now, affecting how I interacted socially with the classmates around me when I was in school and JC. Army, things seemed to turn for the better for a bit, then it went downhill again. Maybe that's why I've never really had a close friend. I ever wanted to tell my family members, but it wouldn't be easy for them to understand (I tried it once, the only response I got was "why are you like that?"), so I've been dealing this on my own for a long while.

Come uni, I met a few friends who really understood what was going on and didn't force me if I felt uncomfortable, which I'm grateful for. I've never looked to an SEP, NOC, or internship, because I felt I wouldn't cope well to the new environment I was in, given my inability to eat out.

I've always been an optimistic guy, but it gets difficult at times, especially when thinking whether this would be how I'll be for my remaining life.

Being a Year 4 student currently, I've missed out many opportunities because of this, and it sickens me that my mind's so weak that I haven't conquered it yet. But I'll remain strong, seek help and find ways to get over this. I really want to go on that grad trip with my friends. I really do.

Thank you for your words of encouragement. It means a lot. :) All the best to all of you as well.

Dear OP of ,
Funny how the same thing actually happened to me last year. The details are a little different (I met him in NUS when he was on exchange, and then I went on exchange to his home country and we got together). What followed after that was more than a year of LDR (with very expensive 2 visits in between, once he visited me and once I did). Now I'm a postgrad student in the same country as he is, although we're in different cities. I have been very fortunate in that he is willing to put in as much, if not more, effort into this relationship as I am. My advice: let it be, and if you can do a postgrad in his country, do it. It will give you time to think. A relationship takes a lot of effort, especially when distance is involved, but it allows for a lot of room for self-improvement and growth. Do not be afraid to be hurt. Do not let go of something that could be wonderful because of fear. After all, you can't stop loving someone just because of geography. Take care.
-
 
To the op of , your problem sounds similar to mine. I'm not sure how to categorize my own issue, but it seems like I'm suffering from public eating anxiety because I simply couldn't eat in public. It started 3 years ago so I sort of became a loner as I felt uncomfortable joining groups of friends for meals. It was probably the lowest point of my life (it was during JC) because I didn't know what was happening to me. I fell in and out of depression because of this. I've seeked help from psychologists but it didn't help me at all. This problem started to manifest into other problems such as my social interactions with people and I had great difficulty adjusting to uni life, especially in year 1 sem 1. There may be some days when you feel really down, but as for me, I've made a mental note to myself to be optimistic everyday. Fortunately, though not many people know about my condition (seems ridiculous and people probably wouldn't understand either), I'm fortunate to have a supportive family as well as a bf who doesn't mind about my problem. That really keeps me going and especially motivated to do well in my studies. Initially, 3 years ago, I wasn't able to eat in public even with people whom I'm familiar with. Nevertheless, I begin to make improvements gradually, and I'm even able to enjoy simple meals with my bf outside. Hence, you shouldn't give up either! It's good to have a trusted friend with you to help you through this journey of recovery and remember to always stay positive! I haven't fully recover from my own problems yet, and I'm still rejecting friends' offers for meal outings, but I am still hoping that one day I'm able to overcome this. :). Perhaps you could also look forward to the happy things in life, such as sep, summer programs etc. All these probably kept my sanity admist all the deadlines and upcoming finals! Jiayou and good luck!

-
 
 Hey OP, I was in the same situation for a few months. My appetite was shit for almost every meal, to the point where I felt weak almost all the time cos I wasn't eating enough. It just felt really hard to swallow the food, and sometimes I would feel like there is a lump in my throat that is preventing me from swallowing, and making me gag alot, especially when I am in situations that make me more nervous. I eventually went to CHAT and got a referral to see a psychiatrist, and was diagnosed with mild depression. Tbh there were some pretty big changes in my life at that time and I was simply overwhelmed and emotionally drained. After going for some counselling sessions and taking life one step at a time to adjust to these changes, I am much better now! What I mean is that there is probably an underlying reason that is making u nervous or anxious, and I suggest booking an appointment with CHAT, where they will help u assess ur situation and help u find out what is the reason for your anxiety. Don't lose hope!

It's probably going to be the same cycle again; me looking around for escape, finding excuses to not eat, acting like I'm actually eating when I can't.

It's not that I can't eat out. I somewhat can, in takeaway boxes, although I still gag from time to time for no reason. What I really can't do though, is eat in public areas with massive amounts of people around. Eating on a plate. With people nearby. That scares me, and I don't know why.

I don't want to disappoint anyone, so I just go along with the flow, but I really wished that I just never received any meal invites at all so that people won't know how weak I really am mentally.

People say that you need to want it bad enough to work for it. Guess I'm just not wanting it bad enough, because every time I want to try to break out of this cycle, I crawl back into my shell again, fearing the possible consequences of what may happen.

Has anyone had such issues and overcame it? How did you do it? I really want to know, because I'm slowly starting to lose hope and accept that this is who I will be for the rest of my life.
-
 
It is funny how it is the very things you declare never to do that you end up falling into doing, tripping you up and messing everything. 

I was lucky enough to go on a year long exchange this year and am almost coming to the end of it. I remember before leaving being all excited to check this place out (I've been thinking of doing post grad studies here too), enjoying the new education environment, and meeting new people. Before I left, my friends would tease me saying I should come back with an angmo boyfriend, to which I would reply that I'll only date Singaporean guys because I want to come back home even after all the possible years of being away from it.

Things have been amazing at exchange, even made more concrete plans to do post grad here. But I met someone a few months ago and for some weird reason that maybe only a Taiwanese romance movie can explain, I ended falling for him despite knowing that we can't have a future together unless I decide to eventually make this place my home.

Initially I thought this was just a phase of crushing on someone, but as I got to know him better, I started falling for his quirks and nature- the way he smiles with such kind sincerity at everyone he meets, the way he chuckles with the patient resignation at some joke that I can only pull off by rolling my eyes, the way he furrows his brows as he explains how worried he is for the people he works for but cares so deeply about, the way he looks at you as he tries to understand what you're finding so hard to articulate, and god, the way he sings could steal all you young maidens' hearts as he has taken mine. I realised also that we have quite some things in common- interests, values/beliefs, and even mannerisms (goodness, he will be saying something mid way and I would somehow suddenly see myself in him- the better side of me). After all those years of being with good, but incompatible people, this is the first time I can say I think I may found a better half of me. 

I'll be back by winter this year and it aches me to wonder what will come of us. We aren't officially together, and it's really only the beginning of whatever love story that could come out of this, if any at all. I'm afraid to come to a stage whereby we are in the position to speak about our future together, and then realise there is none. It'll be tragically painful to go through. I don't know if I should let things take its course and let my heart take me as I go or if I should rationally deliberate my actions. Even if we do take our relationship further and I come back here in a year to do post grad, then what? The only way for us to have a future is if someone moves. I'd hate to sound blindly patriotic, but I really love Singapore and want to go back to do what I can to make this a better home in the years to come. He has his whole life here already and I can't hope to have him move- besides, this place is beautiful and if not for this odd patriotism I have and all the friends/family back home, I would love to live here. 

All you wise and strong souls of my wonderful school, what should I do?

Hi-five girls, I thought I was the only one around who was facing this sort of problem! But I managed to find balance with myself after realising the real problem was deciding between only two guys. The trick is to have a different guy for every part of life, or even NUS. So during the weekends I go out with my boyfriend, I have a guy for my biz mods, another one for my language mods, and another one for my classes in UTown. I suggest that you try to find another a guy who's in some hall or residence because that's really the best way to enjoy the best parts of having boyfriends in NUS. Hope you can get on my level, girls.
Cheers!

To the OP of 

I was in the same situation. What I was advised on, was similar to what the comments to your posts were. "if you can like another, you were never really strongly in love with the first one anyway."

The second person, B, was chivalrous, and too, couldn't leave a person like me alone. 

And so after months of going back and forth, I left my JC bf of 2 years, for someone I knew for 4 months.

After honeymoon  period, we both saw flaws in each other, and chided each other about it. Conflicts came, just like most relationship, and there were times our r/s was rocky. 

During one such time, 8 months into our r/s, halfway through settling problems, I brought up the issue of me being pressured into mild sexual abuse in my workplace (stupid tired me at that time didn't realise I could just run away for help). The issue was eating me up inside for more than a month and I had been finding the right time to tell him about it (I wasn't sure how he would react to it.).

He was angry? I'm not sure. His face just turned red and he just started screaming. He asked how can he ever trust me again? I don't even know the answer myself. But inside, I was deeply hurt. 

He had confessed to me one month earlier that he almost left me for another girl because to him she was very hot. There were also many instances where I felt emotionally blackmailed from his actions(long story). And at that time, after talking it through, I forgave him completely.

But this, we were both victims right? Shortly after I had to go to work again, and he sent me to the station, and told me he needed time to think.

There was no reply from him since then. I called him about a week later, only for him to answer "We broke up already, we are finished, you are free to do whatever you want."

This time, I never shed a tear. I simply hung up and carried on my way to work again.

I eventually slowly became friends with my very first bf, I picked up gaming and we have been close friends since. There was never an instance where we deliberated about getting back.

Did I regret breaking up with my first bf? Yes, BUT we were bound to break up anyway. We got together just cause we were close, but we wanted too different things in life, and expected different fundamental things from each other. We just broke at a wrong time.

Did I regret starting a new relationship with this new bf? yes, cause it was only by being close in a r/s with him, that I realised he was very different from the person I thought he was even after spending months with him. I was deeply disappointed in who he really was. Looking back, I was deluded by his words and lonely from my bf's limited time.

To OP: I understand how hard you are trying to reason your heart with your brain, to maintain your initial relationship. 

There is still strong attachments with your first bf. But because of NS, your bf's time is limited, it gets lonely, I know.

And also, 4 months may not be enough to know a new person deeply even if you meet everyday. 

Have you tried talking to your current bf about it?
If he left it up to you, can you hold on a bit longer? 

If I were in the same situation again, I would request for a week of no contact with B. And I would wait until weekend to meet my bf again, at his house to talk it out, don't make any commitment promises. And see his response. 

If he decides to spend what little time he have with you or left it up to you, then I would maintain being friends only with B for one more month at least. During this one month, I would try to understand why am I feeling this conflict. Is he really the type of person I want to spend my life with? Do I really know B deep enough? Or was it because I was just really lonely and he just happened to be there to provide me with company(for both)? Am I even ready to end it with my first bf? If both of them told you that there is someone else that is interested in them, who would you want back more?

When you are ready, make that choice in your best ability, brace your heart and pray. And know that you already made the choice in your best efforts, despite being hurt months later.

Good luck

You see. I'm a plain (plane) geek. I enjoy engineering. I will probably be building something eventually. People say engineers are stable but unromantic. I guess that's also the reason why I like the B77W: an extremely versatile aircraft but one that people won't fawn over unlike the A380 rival (darn whale) or A340-500 (because it looks nice, but gulps fuel like crazy).

I can talk about all sorts of things, but I realise I'm notoriously bad at small talk. I suck at talking about the latest movies (despite having the latest IFE). Neither can I understand what makes Trump so entertaining (I think he's bullshit). I mean, I see the joy in things, but it's a different kind of joy... I see concepts like efficiency, versatility and extremely long range, for instance, as beautiful. I see anonymity like NUSWhispers as beautiful because it allows for the experimentation of alternate identities.

Unfortunately this conceptual view of the world exposes myself badly to trivia because I will just summarily claim trivia is a "clickbait" concept with little nourishing value. Of late, though, I realise it's of use just saying sweet nothings to someone (sweet nothing is really just swet talk that's devoid of proper meaning, just the sugar).

Can someone teach the B77W to be more than just a marvellous plane, but a beautiful one too?

I do not know if they were telling the truth or is it just the case of making me happy. But nonetheless, I started acting differently because I feel more confident. And that is when I fall in love for the first time and was rejected by my crush within a span of 2months. Long story short I was friendzoned. I was like 70% sure she was into me because we go for dinners/outings alone and her friends will tease me even I kept the “tryst” a secret. 

And that made me feel like shit. I felt like I was being led on and being made used of. She seems so blur and innocent and I really don’t know whether she know that I had a crush on her or not☹. This post is probably making no sense. I just felt that what is the point of “looking cute” and working so hard to obtain a nice body when you can’t even get someone you like? I know that is the wrong motivation but deep inside I mean that is what we want right?

Ever after getting rejected, I have been hitting the gym everyday. It helps me to spend my time faster. I will think about her whenever I am free. Why do you have to make me feel like I am not worthy? As my guy friends said, “where got one shot one kill one”. I know it sucks but Im gonna work extra hard in everything I do so one day you will look back and ask yourself, “why didn’t I give him a chance”.

I miss this guy I love in JC. I actually love him unknowingly and did not expect myself to fall in love with him. I used to like another guy in JC and was sure that he was the one, until this guy, lets call him X, came into my life.

X and I were in different classes. He used to be from top class back then in secondary sch, but he chose to give up his study in JC. He was always involved in fights outside, and it was a surprise he was not expelled from the school. I met him by chance and we became friends. Not that i really wanted to be his friend, but he approached me first and I did not know how to turn him down. Perhaps becos he was quite tall, tanned, and quite handsome too, but due of his lousy results and gangster behaviour, many people did not want to be close to him.

But I realised that i was slowly falling in love with him as we spent more time together. He would always ask me to help him do his homework and for some reason, I did not decline. Perhaps I was afraid of going against him since he was famous for being the school gangster. I was pretty sure he was just using me, but I did not turn him down.

As we spent more time with one another (he would always find me) I tried to urge him to study. He was once from a top secondary sch, but chose to fail everything in JC and constantly involved in fights. Eventually I think I managed to knock sense into him, and he began to work hard. We would then study together after school. Its funny how later, he would be the one who helped me in my studies instead, especially math as it was my worst subject.

As his results gradually improved, so did his character. Once speaking like a gangster, he is now more gentle. Maybe becos of the hours we often spent alone together, i got to know more about his strength, and realised that he is actually a nice person afterall. 

But in his heart, he love another girl. Also, he was aware that I was in love with another guy (becos a lot of my friends knew anyway). Honestly, I did not expect myself to fall in love with him. Later on I realised that he got together with this girl he like and I was feeling broken instead. That was when I knew I had unknowingly fell in love with him. 

He eventually went to the states to further his uni education. Sometimes, I would recall back those bittersweet memories we had together, and deep down, I still love him and miss him a lot. I could vividly recall our conversations, and the one that was etched deeply in my mind is that he said he would ask andy lau to sing for me one day. Miss those times, our times, a lot.

I know it is an illogical thing to wish for, but I had forgotten to make a wish before blowing the candles. My friends reminded me to close my eyes and wish for something fast and this is the first thought that came to my mind. Even I felt disappointed that I am thinking so negatively but I realise it is because of the emotional pain I went through in the past few days. 

I wanted to talk to someone about it in person, not text, but all my close friends were busy with concerts, festivals, project meetings and their own boyfriends. I didn't want to disturb them and also didn't want to cry in front of my parents, so I went to watch a movie alone, chose an isolated seat right at the back and cried as much as I could in the dark. 

I had done a lot of reasoning already - he wasn't the right one, I will find someone better, it's neither his fault nor mine that he doesn't like me etc. However, at that moment, I just couldn't reason anymore. All that came to my mind was that I liked someone and he didn't like me, and this pain was unbearable. What's worse is that all this while I had been guessing that he likes me too. It later turns out that they always take advantage of me. Some of them who always got excellent result will act blur towards me when I consult them regarding my tutorials. I also start to realise people will only be nice towards you if they need a favour from you. I starting to lost trust in some of the people I once trusted. Saying so much of this, I believe everyone who is studying in NUS are victims of academic bullying but to varying degree. Those who are poor in academic like me suffer the most.

 Totally agree with you. Love is a wonderful thing even if its one-sided and even if it cease to exist after a while. I used to think no one understands me, no one went through the same route as me. Until he came. I thought I found someone with the same thoughts, the same experience, the same sentiments. We were so close; we shared our most intimate thoughts/fantasy. I admit, I cared more for him than he did for me. Through that, I learned how caring for someone can be tiring yet rewarding. And when he cared for me, I appreciated every thought and moment he cared for me. We are still friends but I can never forget nor let go of the past we had (though he claimed it's not love). Love is beautiful in that way. I think we should not demand it to be reciprocated but we should appreciate the moments we had and treasure it somewhere deep in our heart. It's tiring, sometimes demanding; but its worth it to make the person you love smile. 

A year has passed, we are still friends. But I still love you and my heart is still locked for you. Maybe we will eventually part; for now I like the way we are.

I'm just going to sort out some irrationality bothering me. 
Am I the only one who's increasingly bothered by close friends asking for relationship advice? Though I've episodic manifestations of lusts, all of them conforming to the societal norm of heterosexuality, I've been disgusted by feelings of love and unwilling to explore them.

Am I the only one who enjoys going to lectures alone? Sadly, none of my lectures are webcasts, and class participation for tutorials are graded. Maybe that is a relief for my mental well-being. I'm being rather reclusive since after National Service.

Being a Freshie marks new experiences. I've never experienced panic attacks before NUS. It happened a few times on a weekly basis in the first few weeks, subsided towards recess week, and periodically once every week after week 9. 
Sweaty palms, churning stomach, breathlessness, heart-pounding, fidgeting. I hate it when it happens during a lecture, where I need to find a perfect moment to go out. I'm always sitting at a corner seat, hoping no one sits near me. Sometimes placing my bag on the seat beside me. 
I've suspected it has got to do with my diet, because I've to habitually go to the toilet before every lesson. I'm avoiding meals at crowded times and areas. 
I'm grateful for being able to study here, although I've not told anyone that.

Thank you for reading...

I met an angel on 13th February of this year and life has not been the same since. She liked me a lot, but mainly because I was kind and helpful. I started to care more but never pushed. I walked her to her hostel every night, I spent late nights working with her in my office and my home, etc...

She also did everything a friend could. She gave me her band. She used to call me 'beta' and comfort me whenever I missed my mom. She used to bite me, etc..

It is sad how she drifted apart. It had a lot to do with what her guy friend who could speak the same language as hers (I could only talk to her in English) and whom she trusted more than me told her. I also got the feeling she was just using me for her work. My friends also started calling her 'bitch'. I was okay with her using me, maybe because I really just liked spending time with her. But yeah, we did drift apart and she started hating me lol

I guess she has found someone new she can love now. I try not to meet her, so I don't know. This is what mutual friends tell me. It is okay, I told her I just want her to be happy anyways, so can't really be selfish now :)

I have stopped chasing girls now. She has converted me into a man. A man which carries her photo with him all the time and cries in the rain sometimes, but a man nevertheless. She did take away a piece of my heart, but it matters much less, because at least I have started to understand the value of my own heart :D

My secret wish is that one day, when she has her cute children, she does let me play with them. I like kids. And then maybe, just maybe, she bites me, ruffles my hair and calls me 'beta'. That would work like a balm :D

I love her too much to not to let her go :))

Saw this on Tumblr:
The “friend zone” and unrequited love are not the same thing. Unrequited love is, “I love you, you don’t love me in that same way, I am sad about that.” The “friend zone” is, “I love you, you don’t love me in that same way, you have therefore wronged me.”

Unrequited love is, “My unilateral crush is my problem.” The “friend zone” is, “My unilateral crush is your problem.”

Agree??

 nu
This is in response to , where the poster was worried about his level of comfort with his bros. 

Please note that platonic affection (ie friendships) can vary - you can be very close to someone else, without being romantically or sexually attracted to one another. Having a bunch of tight-knit friends who are comfortable with one another to a point where you can drop casual expressions of affection and butt smack each other - that's a real privilege, and not something to be worried about. Plenty of people think that this is something to be avoided, because it might mean that you're gay. That's bullshit because all of you know very well that you're friends, and even if things develop past that point, it's not a bad thing too.

Case in point: me. I have a couple of friends with whom I usually hold hands, link arms, am physically affectionate with etc and people give us strange looks sometimes. But we're clear about being friends, and since it makes all of us feel good (hugs feel good, get what I mean?), there's no reason for us to stop. :)

-
 
After seeing all these posts about loneliness and relationship issues, I am kind of shocked as to how much I can relate to them. 

For me, I have always been the type of person who compartmentalize my friends, and as such, I always act a little differently around each group of friends to experiment around. As for the reason why I do that, I don't know. But I think it can be attributed to how I have always felt uncomfortable letting people fully into my life. I guess it can also be attributed to how my father always drilled in the notion of 'a fresh new start' every time I had a change in environment.

The persona that I had on ranged from loud uncaring and obnoxious kid in secondary school, to a quiet, seemingly intellectual kid in JC, to a seemingly demanding and confident officer in army, and to my current seemingly shy and awkward dude persona in NUS right now. 

I don't know why I did that, and now I feel drained as hell trying to keep up with all these different 'personalities' around different groups of friends, and sometimes I would just shut myself out from the world altogether, fearing that somehow friends from different groups would come together to discuss about me, and then finding out how different I am to the person that I made them believe to be me.

As a result, I never had a true friend. No one knows the real me. Even I myself am confused as to who I really am. Needless to say I have great difficulty in achieving intimacy in both friendships and with girls, and this have been bogging on my mind so much lately that it has been affecting my studies. I did so badly on my mid terms that I don't think I can ever pull up the grades with my finals.

I don't know what I want to achieve with this post, but I guess I just want to let those of you who feel lonely to know that, you are not alone in this.

I need some advice here. It's pretty long but please, I'm really out of choices now.

My clique has 7 of us, and I'm the only guy. We've been going out as a group quite a lot (outings, lunch, dinner etc). For the past few months, they have been my closest group of friends in NUS. 

Here's the thing - when you spend a lot of time with someone, feelings develop. Gradually I felt attracted to one particular girl in the clique. She's not the prettiest (as what my other guy friends told me since they always talk about me) but she definitely caught my eye.

Recently we had a chalet just for the 7 of us. (There were some alcoholic drinks but I didn't drink a lot since I know my alcohol tolerance is really bad) At night we decided to play truth or dare. At this point in time, I was probably the most sober.  The girls were slightly tipsy.

Halfway through the game, one of the girls decided to reveal her secret crush. It turned out to be.

Unfortunately, she's wasn't the "one".

There was an awkward silence then and I decided to use the toilet. I went to pee and wash my hands before exiting the toilet. Little did I know that this time another girl decided to confess to me. She hugged me mumbled something like "please tell me I'm the one you like."

Not knowing what to do, I unhooked her hands and told her "you're drunk, go wash up and rest early" and left the kitchen. 

I proceeded to head outside the chalet and sat near the pool to reflect on what just happened. As if matters couldn't get any worse, another girl decided to pick this time to confess. She sat down beside me and started talking about how she wanted to "bring our relationship further." 

At the end of the whole chalet, I was wondering whether I had struck lottery there times in a row. But the thing was, I didn't really want those lottery, I wanted something else.

I wanted "her". 

What should I do from here? The clique is getting tensed up since a few of them vaguely remembers what happened that night and I haven't given them any response. Should I still go for the "one"? I really find her alluring but I don't want to cause our group to crumble because of my selfish desires. 

Ps. I'm an evergreen that am absolutely clueless about how to handle relationships.

To  This happened to me before and I was really annoyed and quite disgusted initially. Instead of just sitting next to her and saying hi suddenly, be a bit more indirect and ask if there's anyone sitting next to her then start talking by using the lecture's content as a topic? It probably will be less terrifying for her then. It's unlikely for her to fall for you right away so it'll take some time.  Since it's already week 11, if you really want to get to know her then just try? And maybe you guys can study together for finals. Even if it fails you won't have many opportunities outside lecture to meet her again anyway.

I think that there has been several posts regarding why guys text you often after class but do not talk to you that much in a group. 

I am a guy and I'm doing just that at the moment. Firstly, I constantly text this one girl often especially after classes about school, asking her about her work and reminding her to sleep early even, and occasionally I try my luck asking her out for meals or movies. If I like a girl, I will care for her and go out of the way to do something sweet for her. If a guy does this for a girl, she probably holds a special place in his heart. 

Now when it comes to a group setting, I do not talk to the girl I like as much too. After all, you have other friends around and all of them have a different level of closeness with you. Chances are that things that you are going to share with the group, that girl would have already known since you text her often outside. Also, you can't really ask private or specific questions only to that girl. Either your friends will think that it is directed to them also, or they will feel that you are outcasting them by treating them as transparent. It will leave a bad impression of both the guy and girl among the group. 

 the guy in this case probably likes you if he only does this to you. Try spending more time together alone at your dinners/movies if you fancy him or just want to talk more with him, he'll be so happy :) Good luck!

Don't tell me you do something sweet for your crush and expect nothing in return. Touch your heart.

Sucking it up and thinking okie it is her right to reject me => good guy?

-
 
Be warned, the following is not a success story. 

When I first entered the workforce I didn't know what to expect. I've heard stories of people saying how equipped school had made them and how ready they were for anything that came their way. But I was still unsure. I tried to stay optimistic and true to myself at the very least. On my first day, a senior colleague told me not to expect much, told me that career progression here was unthinkable and even a pay raise was near impossible. I tried not to be disheartened and tried my best to adapt to the working environment. I was attentive and did everything to the best of my ability and was rewarded with employee of the month. But after multiple awards with no promotions or pay raise or any benefit at all, it became more and more normal rather than something extraordinary. 

After years of working, I must say I am exhausted. I have a friend who chose not to work and has fun everyday sleeping or just minding his own business and while I have other plans for life, I do envy his lifestyle. For me work seems to be so ingrained that despite my happy disposition I can't help but feel like a robot. I repeat to myself certain things to keep my spirits high but from an outsider point of view I'm no different than my colleague who spends each and every of his day lamenting about life. A female friend of me supports me wholeheartedly in pursuing my passion and is always introducing me to new ways to have fun, but I always felt she was living inside her own dome. 

So that's my work life and as you can see, it's far from ideal. 

But if there's one benefit of it all, is that I do have some free time and I get to spend the most of it doing stuff I enjoy and hanging out with the people I like. Money has never been an issue due to my enthusiastic work ethic and if there's one thing school has taught me, it's that no matter how bad things may seem, no matter how many people put you down, and no matter how green the grass on the other side is, stay true to yourself and work hard - things will get better. 

After all, despite being drained each working day, I love to head back to my pineapple to get a good night's rest. 

P.S. For the secret to success, repeat to yourself "I'm ready" each morning

-
 
 Perhaps professional help from a psychologist/psychiatrist would help? Or perhaps reading related books? Time? There were times when I was rather pessimistic with regards to the outlook of things and thought that time would never heal the wounds, but looking back now, I think things have been a lot better.

If he doesn't like you then I think there's really nothing else to ponder over. But if you truly like him and he too feels the same way, respect him as an equal in the relationship and talk it out. If both of you decide to stick around, work things out together, and perhaps he's someone to be part of your remaining life. Things he could possibly accept if he likes you could be to remain purely as friends till you are mentally ready or a relationship without physical contact of any sorts till you are mentally ready.

If either party doesn't want to start or that things at the end of the day just don't work out, then so be it? It really wouldn't be the fault of anyone and some things just turn out the way they do and at times we can't seem to comprehend why that is so, even if we very much want answers and struggle to find them. Furthermore, if he likes you, I'm sure he would want the best for you, even if things don't work out the way either of you wanted.

Bottom line is, don't be too hard on yourself :)
-
 
Shoutout to all those lonely people who feel like they've no friends. I'm not going to address a particular post but hopefully sharing my experience will help at least somebody even in a small way. I joined uni knowing no one else in my course. Having self esteem issues, I was constantly self-conscious and awkward and felt that attending any camps would just make me feel more unconfident because my awkwardness with big groups of strangers just makes things weird and uncomfortable. I found my first friend by asking a course mate who wasn't in a group for lunch, and subsequently attended lectures with that friend. Yet, I had multiple classes and tutorials to attend alone, and often time to spend in between as well, all of which I'd spend wondering why everyone else had friends but me. Things got pretty terrible and I'm sure it affected my studies. Being alone and friendless essentially worsened my pathetic semblance of a self-esteem, and the more I lost confidence in myself, the more awkward, desperate, yet reserved I became which isn't the best recipe for making friends. 

It took time and introspection but ultimately I realised my issues were beyond just the bad circumstances I was in. I inherently looked down upon myself and hence expected the same of everyone else, and with that fear would subsequently put up walls to protect myself, shutting any potential friends out. It was a self-fulfilling prophecy. Eventually I decided to go to CPS and met a very sensible counsellor who frankly helped me realise that listening to the condescending, judgemental voice in my head was a choice not an obligation. As I grew more confident, willing to make mistakes and laugh at myself for those mistakes, I also found it much easier to connect with people without worrying about judgement. 

My friend got to know other people in our course, and when they joined us for study session or lunches, I tried to make it a point to be friendly so I could at least get to know people in my course even if on a hi-bye basis. One of the most important things I learnt was that just as I was shy to talk to people, so were many other people. Nowadays, when I meet someone new I try to be friendly (even if they seem a little unapproachable) and take the initiative to make conversation. Sometimes you find new friends, other times you just find out who's not interested which is okay too. There's definitely a dash of luck involved, but with some of the people we've met, things have worked out and our "clique" has been growing, as have my acquaintances.  Friendships, like all other relationships, are controlled by multiple factors including the subjects and circumstances. You can't force things but you can always put in your best to create a more conducive environment to facilitate the progress you hope for. 

I just want to say don't lose hope, I've morphed from a "talks about once a month in class" to "lonely to the extent of suicidal thoughts" to "confident and nice to talk to (as described by friends)" person. It's a tough journey but when you get to the other side it'll be beautiful to look back and see how far you came. Cliché as it is, love and respect who you are, it'll make your head a more peaceful place to be in and your body a healthier, happier home for you soul. 

P.S. Also, if you have self-esteem issues do try to address them before you start working, because it's likely to make a huge difference in your workplace life and career prospects if you do (from experience).

I feel like an outcast for most of my life. I have quite a bit of acquiantances to whom I will say hi to whenever I see them nowadays, but I actually have very little friends at all.

Before I entered NUS, I was that kid who was really awkward, whom everyone would shun because of my weird antics. Somehow, someway or another I tend to offend people unknowingly, against my best intentions, and this repels people away and drew unwanted verbal and sometimes physical abuse from bullies in the past. I guess I had shitty social skills and emotional intelligence then. Throughout my secondary school to JC, I literally gained zero friends whom I could confide to. Yes, I was THAT weird. 

Thankfully going through 2 years of army had my head smacked hard in a good way, and I managed to be more 'normal' when I entered NUS. Actually, until now I still not sure if I have become 'normal', or that people simply grew out of the way they used to treat me. Though I can tell people definitely treated me better now as compared to in the past when I had zero social skills. I even gained a few friends now. I guess you can say my skills leveled up and I can somewhat connect to people on a superficial level.

However, my loneliness was still there like a gaping hole. Superficial interactions simply isn't enough to fill this gap. I find that I have a severe deficiency in my ability to connect to people on a deeper level, which results in my inability to form meaningful relationships with people, in particular in my endeavor to get a girlfriend. Somehow I have this inability to talk to people about how I really feel, my deepest thoughts about things and my outlook on life. It's like I have this barrier, this unconscious filter that I put up so that whatever I say would be pleasing to the person I am speaking to. But the things that are said are never deep enough to form meaningful connections with the person. The words spoken are politically correct, but never personal nor intimate. I want to get closer to people, but I have no idea how to.

I guess right now I am having some sort of a quarter life crisis right now , with everyone getting attached and some even getting married at my age right now. I still have one more semester left in NUS and I plan to make full use of it, but I have no idea to. Any advice from people who have gone through what I went through? Thanks

Relationships really cloud your judgment and mess up friendship dynamics.

For my case, it was this group of 8 of us, 5 guys and 3 girls. We were from the same hall and same hall CCA. Among the 8 of us, there's this prominent pair (and they are a couple) as both of them are quite good-looking and the male is really one of the best among all the halls. His girlfriend is quite good-looking but skill-wise she is just so-so. 

All of us except for 2 (her boyfriend and another girl) are from the same major so naturally the 6 of us hang out together quite often. The girl is the most outspoken and tends to be the center of the clique, she would say really childish things and crack super lame jokes that are not funny at all (even in the lame sense, some don't even make any sense) but everybody will always humour her and seem to place her on a pedestal. I'm unlike them as I'm more reserved and I tend to enjoy observing from a distance how everybody sucks up to her although they are more skilled than her, in studies and in our CCA.

On the field (not exactly, I changed this so it won't be obvious) she always likes to bark out commands and talk down to people as if she's the captain or one of the most skilled. Sometimes she calls for team meetings and rants on and on. Sometimes her rants go in circles, sometimes it hits a dead-end and keeps beating on the dead-end. Due to all these really idiotic circumstances, I decided to leave the CCA and clique altogether. I made up some stupid reason that I couldn't continue the CCA anymore, and some conscious efforts to distance myself from them and their happenings.. It was tough getting around on my own at first, but I was able to make some friends by joining other CCAs and from my tutorial class. 

Half a year down the road, I found out that he had broken up with her due to unable to stand her childish ways, and I could see that she was quite broken. He got poached by another hall and our 1st/3rd placing dropped to 4th/4th placing. She left hall due to personal reasons and the clique became fragmented (I see them sitting separately now).

I don't know exactly why I wrote this, but I feel somewhat vindicated for not pretending to like someone due to clique dynamics or peer pressure or whatever it's called. I'm also glad because breaking away from this clique allowed me to meet someone who eventually became my girlfriend :D

Dear OP of , (apologies in advance, this is quite long) 
I'm a freshie and I've just went down the same path as you. I missed every orientation camp that there was due to my late acceptance as well...It was quite demoralising at first when I attended lectures and tutorials, I felt that majority of the people knew at least one other person in the lecture theatre (through JC, secondary school, army mates...) Sometimes it felt as though everyone knew everyone and I was just the awkward one left out (because none of my high school friends are here).   :(  I've joined a few CCAs and I'm also in a hall of residence so I have made quite a number of friends, but there is still a little distance between us. I guess that's expected because most of them have lived in Singapore all their lives and they have a closely knit circle of friends. So it's hard to just join and blend in...(sometimes I envy that they have stayed in just one country because I've moved around growing up and never got to establish the kinda friendship people here have). 

During the first few weeks of the semester, I was plagued by the thought that the next 3/4 years of university would be a nightmare because I knew no one, went to lectures/tutorials alone, ate meals alone, went to Welcome Teas ALONE... it was the complete opposite of what I anticipated university life to be.

As an introvert, it took immense effort for me to come out of my comfort zone in my attempt to make friends. Some eventually became my friends while others simply acted as though they don't want to know me, ignored me and saw right through me whenever I greeted them. It was harsh, painful and often made think whether I made the right choice to return to my homeland (as I always had the assumption that I would just fit in here). Some people also look at me as though I'm some sort of an alien when I tell them I've lived overseas my entire life, others judge my accent, the way I dress, even my handwriting...

By the end of week 3, I could list the number of friends I had on one hand. That was miserable. I attended events held by my hall and by our house and made maybe 1 friend...So then I realised, that it would be best to join a CCA/Interest Group where I would be with those who shared the same fervour in the arts as I did. 

Now it's week 10 and I'm overloaded with assignments, CAs and tutorials. And it seems as though friendship should be the least of concerns...but I meet new people everyday and I try to make new friends. So dearest OP, it will be difficult and frustrating at times, but as long as you keep trying, I assure you, your efforts will not be in vain. Some of the closest friends I've made so far were through the CCAs and Interest Groups because we share the same passion and enthusiasm which will not be influenced by our background, instead you will make friends who value you   not for your vivid overseas experiences but for your personality and who you truly are, it just takes time. 

Be adventurous, be brave and be capricious! :)

Hope this was helpful, please feel free to reply to monotonecrayons@hotmail.com or perhaps critique it! (Please don't judge the email address, it's an extra I made in the past...)

Most of us seem to drink and party a lot. You'll see a lot of different kind of drunks; 

The angry one- that knocks over other people's drinks and complain about their exes.
The pretending to be sober- to get another drink because he doesn't want to disturb the rest
The sad one- who literally burst out crying over anything and everything from happy moments ("you guys are the best friends EVER" *sobs*), to upsetting moments (see the angry one)
The crazy happy one - who proclaims to love everyone and hugs and kisses everything and everyone, smiles uncontrollably.
The horny one- who tries to hump everything and everyone.
The baby- who needs to be loved after puking everywhere.

And then there's my guy friends whom I frequently drink with and I don't think I've seen anything like it. They start to speak intelligently. Like. When they are sober, they sprout absolute nonsense, typical dude stuff. With alcohol, they talk about politics, gender issues, monetary inequality, wars and people, disparity, racism, love for poetry, philosophy etc in the most civilized manner as if partaking in a gentlemen's debate of sorts with active discussion, laden with facts and statistics to back up their arguments. 

I'm just amazed how alcohol  can transform a person so much even for the better. I love going to get drinks with them for the same reason of some sense of odd sophistication I suppose.

Would like to hear any other kinds of drunks you know of! CHEERS!

Two months ago I wrote about Sam, a baby I aborted when I was 19. I kept secret my decision from everyone I knew, including the father of my child: my boyfriend. I made a decision that I wasn't going to keep the baby. I deeply regret not involving my boyfriend in the decision, but I honestly believed at the time, that I did it out of a place of love. He would've assumed responsibility and he would've asked me to keep the baby. And I would've loved him for saying that and I would've said yes, but I genuinely didn't want to rob his chances of being a regular, maybe even boring university student, whose worry amongst others is about not being able to meet deadlines. I wanted him to experience life and didn't want him to have to forgo that to become a father, husband and student all at the same time. 

It took me a long while but two nights ago, I came clean to him about our Sam. We cried our hearts that night. My heart ached terribly not just for the baby we lost, but for my boyfriend too. I had not seen cry, so vulnerable. I had always known him to be the stronger one. He was - and still is - my pillar of strength. I explained to him the events that led up to the abortion. From the time I got my first, second and third positive test, to the first clinic appointment I made, to the many times when I thought about telling him but didn't, to the time when I sat in the clinic... cold, scared and alone, to the times when I just couldn't get through my day because the grief overwhelmed me. He was angry and disappointed, but mostly, he felt sad that I went through it by myself. 

We sat on Bus 10 from Kent Ridge that night heading home. As I laid my head on his shoulders, the same one prior to tonight I had always found comfort, I felt tears land on my face like bullets. I looked at him teary-eyed; I was afraid that I was only going to see in his eyes the death of our relationship, but all I saw on the bus ride home was a long future, a house and kids in it. "We'll be okay, our kids will know about Sam," he said.

Home, is where he is.
-
 
They always marvel at my achievements. They always ask how I do it. I never tell them. Because the truth is so simple, and yet so bitter.

I hate myself. Everyday I look at myself and I see no redeeming qualities, and the rest of the day is a futile attempt to try and change that. How can anyone constantly find the motivation to change, unless they cannot tolerate what they are? Always trying to be a better person, a superior person, a person I could eventually come to like. But what is better? Don't know, but just pick a direction, any direction, and start running. Running as fast and as far away from me as I can.

Am I happy, doing this to myself? I don't know. But I would be miserable if I didn't.

In response to  I think you should only tell her not to feel bad only when you're sure that she's open to that idea, and that you won't develop feelings for her again. Sometimes a girl may feel even more awkward when you tell her not to. So you gotta make sure that she is the type that will be open to be friends with you. To do that you gotta tell her that you will be aware of your position around her. Of course you have to mean it, meaning you should expect less frequent sharing of feelings as compared to the past. In the beginning it will be awkward and you'll feel that the friendship isn't the same as the past, but as long as you guys work for the platonic relationship I suppose it'll work. 

I think the most important thing is that before you continue with this friendship, you must promise yourself not to fall back to that prior-confession smitten state. Otherwise it will just make things worse between you guys. Also, remember that being friends means there's a possibility that you'll see the girl getting together with another guy, and you have to be happy with that sight.

-
 
noticed there are a lot of guys asking about how to confess recently! I'm not sure how useful this will be, but at least you have a girl's perspective? Maybe if girls agree/disagree can also share your views.

for me usually what happens is I meet the guy, we communicate with each other via fb chat then whatsapp. this doesn't happen super often, maybe at the initial phase we text each other once every 2 days. sometimes people are busy so if there's no reply for 2-3 days maybe think about whether the other party is busy. however, if all seems good, after chatting a while, either I'll hint to the guy to ask me out, or he will make a casual suggestion to hang out. this is usually done in reference to some part of our conversation (e.g. girl wants to try this cafe, tell girl you've also wanted to try and ask if she wants to check it out together). if the girl says yes, this is a good sign. if the girl says no, maybe don't confess la. I know this part seems difficult, but by not asking directly "will you go on a date with me" at least it won't be so awkward for both parties, and you still get an idea of whether she's interested or not. if you don't try asking to just casually hang out, you really will never know. personally I'd much rather the guy ask me this way then confess straightaway which may seem a bit weird (sorry I don't mean to be judgmental but that's just how I feel).

if she agrees to go out with you, try to be aware of how the date is going. there have been dates I've agreed to go on which ended up in awkward silences, and there've also been some where we ended up having a really good time and making more plans! if you breach this final barrier where you're pretty confident she's having a good time with you because she doesn't mind hanging out with you one-on-one frequently, then maybe you can try your luck. but really, anything before this stage is a no-go.

actually not sure if this helps but TL;DR is - the most difficult and crucial step is actually asking her out in a casual way! good luck fellas (and girls too)!

To , I can't say you won't ever get into argument because I've never experienced that before. However, I can offer some advice in the event that you do get into an argument.
In my previous relationship, both my ex and I had little or no experience with handling arguments before. We would either just get angry at each other and eventually leave the matter without a resolution, or we'd just keep the issue to ourselves and let our feelings slowly build up. Obviously this didn't solve any of our issues, and ultimately led to the end of our r/ship.
After that experience, I realised that an argument, if resolved properly, could (most likely) strengthen your r/ship and help the both of you to grow together. I am currently with my partner of six months as well and we've argued more times than I can count. Little arguments, big arguments... everything. But I feel even closer to my partner than before. I feel like I'm rambling on now so I'll just give some general dot-point advice:
1. When in an argument, emotions tend to run high and if you feel like you're gonna say something mean, just tell your partner you need some alone time to cool down. But be sure to tell them when you're ready to talk again.
2. If you're the type to clam up when you're upset (like me), try not to. Especially if your partner is also that type. You won't be able to work through issues if you don't talk! If you're really upset, see , but just don't clam up.
3. Even when you're arguing, show you care for your partner. Make sure they took their medications or have enough food or whatever. After all, your partner is the one you may potentially share your life with.
4. When you have arguments you might feel like giving up easily. DON'T! You need to systematically work through whatever it is without the "break up" mentality in your head. Sometimes you need to compromise so be open minded.
These are really general points that might not apply to everyone and every situation, and the best way to learn is really experiencing it for yourself. Don't be afraid of arguments but rather, embrace them and handle them carefully. All the best :)
- Honey Banana

Subsequently, I didn't manage to make any friends close enough whom i can even ask out for lunch (I tried though, but it was awkward for the other party.)

However, I feel that, from the start, my character is not even suitable to be in camps, and that it is sort of not surprising that i don't make any. I joined a CCA which i enjoy and made close friends whom i really treasure. Just wanna press you on and tell you not to give up. If you feel that attending hall and camp activities give you more stress than enjoyment, then i feel that maybe, your character just don't suit them or click with them. Don't force yourself then. There are many other ways for you to make friends. If you tried really hard but that dun work out, then just forget about it, try new ways. Also, you may want to reconsider the way you approach people - is it too awkward for them? Sometimes, i think i tried too hard to act like i was close with them, i feel that this had a backfire effect which made others felt uncomfortable. Go slow and steady! Furthermore, it is only the first semester! Who knows, maybe next week, or even next semester, you can meet really close friends.

The member felt very bad afterwards and apologised numerous times, and I felt very bad too as it wasn't easy to be comfortable with each other again. Things got awkward AGAIN, and now, the whole of party B is drifting away from me again. 

I feel that i am losing out now. Like, if i dun spend so much time on A, i could have maintained a very good relationship with B till now. Furthermore, I have to admit that, since members of B are studying in Singapore, I really need them more than A as they are the ones who can be physically there for me, meet me and listen to my woes, give me birthday surprises etc. Also, B members share more common identity (we are locals) and interests with me which i really hope A can have, but it isn't the case. I really hate myself for thinking this situation in such a selfish manner.

To  from 

Everyone is different, and every couple has their own ways to deal with problems. Mine worked out because I chose to be completely open, as my partner and I value communication and honesty as the foundation of our relationship. Maybe you should talk to your boyfriend properly about why he felt the need to hide it in the first place? It could be a symptom of a bigger problem such as insecurity in the relationship or a lack of openness. The important thing is to talk about both his and your emotions, work things out together and find a solution you both can accept. If you two don't resolve this issue properly, it is bound to come up again and fester like a infected wound.

-
 
All these posts about finding the love of your life makes me want to post about mine. I was a couple of years out of NUS when I exited a seemingly stable relationship. Needless to say, it was heartbreaking yet liberating. But what I picked up from there was that nothing could be certain, and when people change, things fall apart. 

I knew my current girlfriend through a dating app (not Tinder). It was on this bored afternoon when I had just downloaded it out of boredom, and started swiping, at first not even knowing what kind of app it was. I thought..it was probably many ah bengs and ah lians like the 90s irc/icq times. However, I was wrong. And the 10 plus or so girls I spoke to were fine and mature people, with quite a few grads from our local Us.

My girlfriend and I hit off really well from the start. We chatted day and night, and sent snapshots of our lives to each other. It was like this best friend I had never met, and we soon took to Whatsapp. Naturally, I was also cautious, and I didn't want to get too close. What if we met in real life, and couldn't click like we did online? It did eventually come to the point where it would appear rude if I did not ask her out.

And so I did, and she agreed.

The first time we met, I was excited but mentally prepared that things might not work in the romantic way, and that things could fall flat. What would happen then to those little <3 emoticons that peppered our online conversations? 

Thankfully that didn't happen, and initial silence turned into meaningful conversation as we bonded over our past loves and dreams of the future. It was as though I knew her for a long time, and dates followed. It was only 2 weeks later when I asked her to be my girl, only because it felt so right to do so. 

Time together was effortless, and we both found comfort in each other's company. We also shared the same goals and priorities in life which was a huge plus. One plus year on, and we are going strong. Soon, we'll be embarking on our next stage of life together.

So my juniors, especially those who are 'evergreen', let nature take its course, as I truly believe that there is someone for everyone. One should not try too hard to make things happen, and if you have to, then perhaps it is not the best person. However, it is also important to put yourself out there, place yourself in new circles, on new paths, and you may be surprised with what you can find.

Never once would I have imagined finding a partner through a dating app, but I'm glad I did, and so did she. It would be a darn interesting story to tell our kids next time.

To OP of , how long ago in the past was the guy's history? If it was quite some time ago you might want to consider if he's changed his ways. Even if most guys who engage in casual intimacy are quite open about their exploits, they tend to hide it from girls they are romantically interested in as they know it is quite likely a deal-breaker. The fact that he has come clean with you means that he's trusting you with the decision whether you can accept him or not. Everyone has their own dark past but it shouldn't be allowed to hang over the future. Maybe he's decided to end all that unhealthy behaviour and commit to you now?

Whatever your decision is, I hope you can keep both yours and his emotions in mind and do what you're most comfortable with.

-
 
Why are people whom confess about their lack of interest in their SO getting so much flak :( I think once you're getting constantly frustrated with your SO, it just shows you lost the spark, or it was never the right fit in the first place, and dragging it out won't do the both of you any good. 
Obviously, you need to try to make it work, but if you can't even dredge up any feelings for him other than guilt, then there's nothing to work with already. Don't be stuck in a dying relationship trying to think it's all good if you force yourself to stay, that just resorts in an unhappy marraige/life. Being in a rs is a chance to explore life together, and if it doesn't work, then don't force it to.
Its not about whether you're mean or that you're being unnecessarily fussy (although, please learn to keep expectations in order) , you're just trying to find a right fit. And although it may seem harsh to those being dumped, it's better than realising down the road that your partner feels no commitment to you at all.

-
 
HOW TO FIND LOVE ON TINDER
(You don't. Because going into anything with such high expectations will set you up for soul crushing disappointment. Here's some tips to increase your probability of getting some matches anyway.)

1. DO NOT swipe right for all hoping eventually one will match: Tinder algorithm discourage such actions and will not send you your best matches.

2. PROFILE PICTURES (mostly for guys): Please at least show your face. Picture says a thousand words so you want to tell the others that at the very least you are not some socially undesirable creature
(DO)
- Non-selfie, candid photos - look like you have social life and friends like you enough to help you take 
- photos with animals: look caring, animal-lovers can't be psychopaths right?? 
- Travel photos: posing with scenery as background is cute, but iconic landmarks a bit tacky
- posed photo with nice background: make sure it's instagram worthy
- engaged in hobby photo: shows that you are interested in life, also plus points if it is cool (highly recommended)
TIPS: wear collar shirt in your photo (make you look slightly classier without being too douchebag). Suits/ blazers are best.
 
(DO NOT). 
- selfie with room as background: I seldom see a good guy selfie. looks unnatural, also i may imagine you as some otaku who never leaves home 
- group photos: you think i come here to guess wth are you meh???? 
- photos of low quality: dont know kope from which hidden dungeons of the interent, or too poor to get decent camera
- studio/ professional work photo: look like insurance agent what if he want sell me something walao

3. Write something in your profile (both genders): state some interests, or what you think is important to let potential dating partners know, or some open-ended question to invite a conversation. Don't just lazily put your horoscope or some results from personality test and expect people to know all about who are you as a person.

4. Don't just say hi: tell you why are you interested in her as a person -she look like she can be the champion of a spelling bee, and you are a sucker for good spellers? her caption says she can eat all day and you would like to challenge her to buffet meltdown? make it personal, or at the very least, don't make her feel like she's one of the many other matches you are concurrently texting. Ditto for girls - in fact i strongly encourage girls to send the first message if you want a more engaging conversation.

5. Basically if you feel like it's a struggle to think of what to say to the other person, very likely this match is not gonna work out. if you can't even maintain a decent conversation online its gonna be awkward irl.

6. go in tinder with a open heart and mind - you may not find your future spouse, but you can make some new friends. <3 if really cannot then oh well at least it killed some time hahaha. 

REMEMBER! people can sense desperation.

Strategise and maximise your chances; YOU ONLY SWIPE ONCE

Hi there, i hope this doesnt get filtered. Recently read that a few OPs are having issues with their mother disapproving of their BF and this seems to be giving them alot of stress and issues. 

Allow me to share my side of the story/POV. I play the role of the BF. When i first dated my gf, i face the same if not more disapproval from her parents. I get comments ranging from "he doesnt look good" to "he isnt even rich, if he doesnt have money why get a gf" to even more ridiculous things like "he must have a motive for dating you". These comments were received mostly in the first 2 years of my r/s. It definitely doesnt feel good. What helped was that my girl fought for me, yes, she argued and quarreled and choose not to accept what her mum had said. However, what i wish to tell you is that you should not be fighting this mission of "change of perception" alone While its important you fight for your relationship, it is also important that the guy is aware of such perceptions. Yes it is unfair, it hurts the ego of the guys, there are guys who takes it negatively and therefore the relationship bursts and breaks. However, if your bf is worth you fighting for, rightfully you should be worth your bf making the same amount of effort too. 

What i did after knowing, was to please her, yes, outrightly please her parents. Buy things over, show the care and concern, bite down the pride and ego, swallow what you have to swallow. Then both of you work together to change her perception. It happened that my gf's mum is extremely stubborn so it would at times be good to get siblings to slowly convince the parents.

I think many times we dont understand the way parents show concern over their children, especially the daughters. Ultimately, daughters are like gems in the family, your parents isnt going to easily hand over a gem to the guy isnt it :) This might help you to understand their actions easier. 

Oh and do always share positive things your bfs did for you, every little surprises, every little gestures. When they see the positivity in you, that you are happier, that there is a future and that you are truely taken care of, they will slowly let go and feel safe that "he can take care of my girl"

Fast forward now, im 5 years into my r/s and planning to continue it into a lifetime long. I am not saying i have the full set of solutions. However, i hope this little thing i have shared will help you guys to feel less stressed.

Lastly, at the end of the tunnel there will always be light! Please have faith! :)
