To ,

Give up hope. At this moment, take care of yourself and forget about your girlfriend (just call her "ex"). Nobody is confused about a person they love. 

Although I do not wish to be the bearer of bad news, there's a high possibility that there is another guy in the scene. Your ex is confused about her feelings about you and the another guy, but she is not THAT confused, because you are getting the boot and not the other guy. 

It doesn't change even if there's no other guys in the scene, your ex is split between you and singlehood in this case, and you are still the one getting the boot.

By being "confused", your ex is embracing the possibility of losing you forever. Would you do that for your ex, who you love dearly? Why would you want to love someone who is willing to lose you? 

She has made a choice, now it's time for you to make yours. Please love yourself and walk away from your confused ex. Do not try to convince herIf she comes back, doubt her, question her. Is she back for you, or is she back for the feeling of a relationship? Nothing breaks a relationship more than a lack of trust.

To  i went through something similar to your bf actually. Was my first job but i was so miserable. Everything was wrong from the first month. I felt lousy. I couldn't handle the stress and politics of that particular job. I cried every single sunday because i had to go to work. My bf told me he was tired of dealing with sad and sobby me after a while coz it really took up all the time we had together. I felt even more lousy. 

But honestly. I felt i had noone to turn to. It was my first job for goodness sake i felt like a failure. I felt guilt, as though i was disappointing my parents and my bf that i was sabotaging our future together coz i couldnt hold on to a job to finance ourselves and our future wedding, kids etc. Really felt like i failed. On top of that, i felt like a burden. A huge burden for my bf to bear coz i was a sobby sad mess whenever he saw me. 

After talking to some really close friends, i gathered the strength to resign. They assured me it wasnt my fault and it could have just been a poor fit with the work culture and environment. I then explained to my bf about what my friends shared with me and how i felt about the entire thing. From initially asking me to toughen up and suck it up for at least one to two years, he supported my decision to move on if the job really made me feel so depressed and lousy. So i resigned after only half a year and took a month of break to heal mentally. 

It was from then that the relationship with my bf began to mend too. He became more supportive and i became less of a sobby mess. Now im in a new job and im back to my happy self! It really was a fit thing. Even though job title is the same, i feel so much more at ease at my new job and im glad to have had the support of my partner. 

Tldr; my advice is to really understand what is making your bf so upset and miserable and to support him. Assure him it is not entirely his fault that he feels that way. It could be an adjustment issue or that he needs to move on. Hear him out and in time things will get better (:

I met him for the very first time at the lobby. I noticed him because he looked so flustered - shirt half untucked, boxers showing, half awake. Later in the day, he introduced himself to me as a new part-timer, waiting to enter uni and choosing between two. I replied that I have already accepted one of the two he was deciding between, and we exchanged number. 

We spent the next few weeks getting to know each other. We were like old friends - talking about everything and anything. Within a month, we became an item. 

Then, it was time for uni. He chose the offer which made us uni-mates, and we embarked on a new phase of life together.

We were a big part of each others' lives - studying together, sleeping over, hanging out. We never stopped learning about each other too - childish bickering, hurtful quarrels, tears. 

There were moments we doubted our decision to get together so quickly. There were times we wanted to just throw in the towel and give it all up. But we've never truly had the courage to let each other go.  

I don't remember when he became a part of my family, but I do remember him being thick-skinned and buying food over just to get to know know them better and prove himself, despite my parents' disapproval. 

Fast forward to today, we are 3.5 years into the relationship.

I don't remember how long I took to get over my bulimic tendencies, but I do remember him taking my hand in his as he checked my knuckles for scarring. I do remember him ensuring that I pace myself each meal until I recovered. And I will never forget the look on his face when I told him I was doing it again. 

I don't remember many things that we do in this relationship because I am a human with goldfish memory. But what I do remember each day is to be thankful for this special someone I so hastily fell in love with. And for someone who knows me better than I know myself.

-
 
, I totally understand what you're going through. With some of my friends, conversation is literally a competition. They can talk over each other for more than a minute without signs of relenting, and only stop when someone tells them to take turns to speak. Every time I talk one of them would definitely interrupt me, and I would just shut down after being interrupted. At one point I didn't even want to talk anymore.

Read online that you could say something like "as I was saying before you rudely interrupted me..." but if you're non-confrontational like me then just learn how to speak more confidently, since its always the people who seem more confident that are heard. Alternatively, you could google or search reddit for more tips, or head to 7cupsoftea to seek advice (these helped me loads). 

If all else fails, get new friends. I'm not kidding. Distance yourself from toxic people who make you feel like shit, and if everyone you know acts this way (like in my case), learn to be alone for awhile before you start hanging out with them again - the situation may not have changed but you'll feel a lot better about yourself knowing that you're not the problem. Good luck, and I hope things get better x

To  I had depression long ago and until today, my family still doesn't know about it. It will turn hell if they know, they are that kind of people who link depression with mentally insane (would probably send me to IMH). I bottled up my feelings, even my opinions are closely regulated to make sure they see the perfect me they wanted. I have a confidante, my best friend, whom I am grateful for. Similarly, OP, look for someone you can trust to confide in. You can start by telling them a little and tell them more as you gain trust in them. And if you really can't trust anyone, vent your opinions in a blog, locked away from everyone's sight. Its the best way to vent sometimes when I don't have my best friend around. Remember, you are not the only one going through this.

I am graduating in less than a year time, but I am still the awkward shy person that I was all these years. Nothing has changed. 

In secondary school, when people were getting steady, I was too much in my own world to join in the fun. In JC, when I was finally aware that I want to get into a relationship to try it out, but I suddenly became awkward and nervous around girls, and so I didn't have any luck. My awkward behavior garnered unwanted attention, and lets just say I got my fair share of ill will from people who were supposedly more 'normal'. I turned to things like anime and games as an escape. They were beautiful as they portrayed romance as the most beautiful thing that can ever happen to a person. And as such, I had grown to have an idealized notion of romance. I longed for a selfless girlfriend similar to that in the idealized stories of anime, and hoped that girls would like me for who I am. But however, reality is so much different from fiction. Countless of awkward encounters with the opposite sex crushed my confidence and yanked me so hard out of whatever self esteem that I might have left. It also doesn't help that my awkward encounters fueled more of the gossips that 'normal' people might have for me. Somehow, they think that it is fun to laugh at awkward people. My chemistry teacher then gave me hope, as he suggested that the best time to find a girlfriend is in university, and that I should focus on my studies. And so I did, hoping that university life will be kinder to me.

Unfortunately,  while people's maturity, the difficulty of the course material , the environment, and my age have changed, my singlehood and my social status still didn't change. I was the shy, awkward, unpopular kid back then, and I am still the shy, awkward, unpopular guy now, and judging from the trend I will likely be the grumbly, awkward uncle that everyone shuns on the MRT everyday in the future.

Why is life so hard on shy and awkward people? It is not like we are people with ill intentions. Why is it that people can talk bad and joke incessantly about other people, often unknowing how detrimental it might be to the victim's self esteem, and still have people and girlfriends gravitating to them. Meanwhile, people who are shy and awkward are treated so much worse, even though they don't hurt anybody. All of this make Karma seem like a convenient lie- a lie to keep the society civilized, and people who aren't afraid to challenge Karma by hurting other people are actually seen as confident and sexy, and thus are popular with the ladies. It seems that all the bullies in the past that I know are all happily attached by now with great jobs and internships, some of them are even happily overseas living the lives of their dreams. It seems that they have 'moved on' with bullying and the damage dealt to the victims and Karma never ever caught up with them. Meanwhile, shy and awkward people are often left in the dust, trying to pick up shattered pieces of their hearts, and are too busy piecing their hearts back together to even navigate life 'normally' with someone that loves them for who they are.

I still have one semester left in nus, and hopefully with this last semester, my life can finally see joy and hopefully I can find someone to love after 25 years of sad existence.
-
 
I have been with my partner close to 7 years now. When I first met him he was the bubbliest and caring person I have met. He made me happy in his own little and special ways that nobody could. It's safe to say that I was his support throughout his teenage life and he will naturally tend to consult me in every life decision. He didn't come from a happy family and most of the time he was alone, which evidently made him more mature than his peers.

We are now at the phase of our lives where we crave our career paths, but he has become so confused of what he wants and should do in life, making him depressed. Everyday, he will consult me for every single decision, even trivial ones, like knowing when he should and should not contact his boss regarding his resignation. On top of that he gets really angry or frustrated over the smallest things. When we meet (only once a week due to my busy schedule), all he does is whine about is unhappiness at his current job. I may seem evil and/or cruel but this is slowly draining me out, and I can no longer stand it anymore to the point that I am ignoring his rants. 

I understand we all need someone to talk to but if its so negative everyday that it makes your significant other feel so empty on the inside, is it even fair? I understand that its not always rainbows and butterflies but I feel that we are no longer happy. Is it all worth it to even stay in this relationship anymore? I feel that it would do both of us good if we had a break in this relationship but I don't want to feel like as if I'm breaking up with him at the period when he needs me the most. I do love him, but I just can't do it anymore.. I feel like a horrible person but I'm really tired. Drained.

Does anyone ever feel like they have just gone through a lot in life compared to the average person and that is why not many people can understand you? 
People generally just want to see others smiling and happy because if people seem depressed I think they get scared.
I went through major depression after being severely bullied years ago. The kind where I could see people get scared when they look at me because it looks like I'm just going to jump off a building anytime. I think I'm still mildly depressed now I just try not to show it. However I think it means that I cannot be as enthusiastic and once in a while I will just feel depressed again and want to be alone. I think people can feel this and that is why even when I'm trying to make friends it is harder for me. It's like I want more friends to make me happy but it just takes a lot of effort to talk more and engage people.
I actually overheard my mother telling my aunt who suggested that I was depressed that she wasn't going to send me to a counsellor as it will affect my future prospects if I were to be diagnosed and that I would get better on my own. My mother has always tried to downplay my problems, has always thought of herself first, I think she lacks eq. When others find out that there are times I do things that my mother doesn't allow, I think they are judging me but they can't understand that I just don't value my mother's opinion so much but I'm expected to be a good obedient daughter. It makes me guilty though.
This extends to a friend as well. She like many others has lived a relatively normal life and cannot understand why people would be so bad and advised me to be more aware of what I do so I wouldn't provoke anyone. It made me more depressed and I just felt even more different from everyone else. 
This is the problem with people who have not been through a lot. They don't understand there are people out there who are willing to harm you, bring you down, make you feel horrible for their own satisfaction. It could be that you were an appropriate target or you just happened to be there. That just because you are nice you expect everyone to be nice back. Life is not fair. 
It makes me want to be alone even more but at the same time I feel like I'm missing out or a little rueful watching everyone else in their large groups or with their partners.
I'm getting tired. There's no one for me to really pour out my soul when most people I meet nowadays are looking for friends to have a good laugh with. Not that I can blame them really...

He also gets offended very easily and can just break a friendship if you unintentionally offended him. Which was what almost happened to me.

So I've been helping him a lot in his studies. He's been asking for my notes (not always) and explanations for concepts. I'm fine with that cause he helps me sometimes too (though not as much as I've helped him). Now recently, we've been having lots of tests coming at us so I guess we were all stressed. We were chatting on Facebook and sent him a meme which offended him when I didn't mean too. And guess what, he deleted me from Facebook. I apologised to him and tried to call him but all he said is he wants to focus on his studies. 

When I finally confronted him two days after he deleted me, what he said really made me upset. He said I was distracting him and that he just deletes anyone who distracts him. I told him he should have told me I made him upset and all he said was he was busy (come on, it only takes a few seconds to say "yes I was upset") and he didn't understand why I was bringing this up because it was a small matter. Then I said "I've done a lot for you. I'm not saying you should repay me back but I was hoping you'd treat this friendship a bit more seriously" and he said "it doesn't matter what you've done for me. If you offend me and distract me from my studies you're not my friend." He even accused me of blaming him, which I wasn't cause all I was trying to say is if he was offended he should have said something and I would have apologised.

So friends, what should I do? I was really hurt at what he said. Now I don't feel too bad but now I know that he really doesn't value this friendship. He did add me back in the end (he said he ended me back cause I apologied wtf). I'll be very honest, I do like him a little. I don't get nervous around him but I do think about him occasionally. So I think me liking him is stopping me from getting out of this toxic friendship. 

Tl;dr: Male friend who I like tried to break off our friendship cause I unintentionally offended him, even though I've helped him a great deal. Says studies always comes first. Should I forgive him and move on or get out of this friendship before I hurt myself more?

I consider myself very blessed. Born into quite a well to do family, with parents who selflessly provide me with a luxurious lifestyle. My parents got me a car at 19 as soon as I passed my driving test, and my own estate at 20. I am already more than a millionaire. But I always believe in being humble, sincere and kind. 

Since I entered uni, I have been maintaining a low profile in school. I try to give back to society, by doing community service with the school club. Being with friends, I never talk about my wealth, or tell anyone about my estate, but my car is sometimes inevitable since I drive everyday. That's because I see no point in purposed flaunting of wealth, and I hope to meet genuine people, friends, or even a potential boyfriend. 

Then somehow, I don't how, one of my friends found out about my private estate. Some things and people start to change. For some of my female friends (whom I like to think of as closer friends), they start to become (I hate to use this word) spiteful. Words about me being a spoilt brat, princess, and even arrogant girl, start circulating among them. I was sadden, to learnt that these words came from those whom I thought were selfless volunteers in the club, or friendly student leaders in the faculty. 

I feel sadden, yet feel sorry for these narrow minded people. But thankfully, Through this incident, I managed to find true friends who are never jealous, and always supportive. 

For these girls, sometimes I wonder if their actions will reverse if I were a guy instead.

Honestly speaking as a girl, when i wear sleeveless, or off shoulder tops, or translucent tops, i wore it that day to feel good about myself. I think i am pretty when i dress up. It makes me more confident when i feel beautiful. The same thing goes for makeup. I am mostly doing it for myself, and not really for guys. It's partly for girls, coz girls judge when you don't dress according to the social conventions and take care of how you look. And i am pretty sensitive to social rejections from their eyes or body language which makes me feel terrible.

About being looked at, i dont mind it from anyone as long as it falls within the boundary of i think that girl is pretty or i like her clothes/style (or even looks like why is she dressing like that). I can tell the difference from a lustful look which looks like they want to tear my clothes apart and see/imagine me naked. Most girls do not like being objectified and just seen as a sex object. We feel good if we feel we are admired. Perhaps this is the difference between why the girls cover themselves up when you stare at them and whisper about you being tiko because the look in your eyes was obviously the disrespectful and undesirable (and honestly scary) kind.

-
 
I've been having suicidal thoughts. 

It's weird. I don't actually want to kill myself, but there's this part of me that feels really detached from myself, and I keep having this thought that I should jump just so I can see what it's like.

Someone tell me what to do please, idk what to do because my counsellor is really useless and I always feel worse after talking to her 
-
 
, I think I understand what you're saying because I guess, I went through that phase myself. I have considered different ways of killing myself, which methods I can actually visualize myself doing. I didn't actually realize it wasn't normal until I spoke to some friends about it, and they said that they don't even think about their death, and any method of killing themselves sound creepy. But, I guess the most important thing is to keep your head up, and remember to always try to rationalize things first. 

I used to self-harm too because of some circumstances, and I have to admit that sometimes, up till today,  I still have to compulsion to when something bad happens that I feel I cannot deal with. But I realised you have to find it in yourself that you KNOW it's not healthy and you have to try to push the idea away, sleep it off or something.

Somehow I think sometimes, you might feel counsellors cannot help because these kind of things are quite internal- it's hard for you to really verbalize what you're feeling cause it's just all that pent-up sadness and emotions that you yourself don't even know where it's coming from. So at the end of the day, try to help yourself :) try to look at it from as mature a point of view as you can - and remember that your brain really is a rather strong organ. You can will those bad feelings away if you wanted and of course, try to busy yourself with meaningful things. You will become stronger through it. Take care! :)

,  I wanted to offer a bit of advice regarding this. Evergreen, but I've felt the impacts of porn on myself, so I can somewhat understand what's going on. 3 months clean currently, and I hope to make this a long-lasting clean streak.

It seems like porn is already interfering quite a bit in your sex lives. It's especially so when you start moving into increasingly graphic/sexual videos, because it means you've become so dependent on porn to get off that you need more stimulus to get off again (just like drugs).

I highly suggest you/your partner to abstain from porn. Obviously it's easier said than done. Too many a time have I gone back to videos and whacked off to it, which usually happens when I'm bored or it happened on a whim. There's really a need to get over this addiction. And yes, Tumblr porn counts. Also, isn't watching porn kind of like, cheating on you/your partner? Since y'know, it's watching other people get off and probably imagining you/them in that scenario.

Support your partner/get support along the way. Maybe start small, such as a week, or a few days if that's too difficult. Offer incentives (sexually?) if you/your partner manages to hang on without porn stimuli, but don't overuse the reward system of course. It's all a matter of balance. You/your partner must also willingly want to actually do this for him/herself and the relationship, or you'll/they'll return to porn before you know it. All the best. :)

To  you should've done the scorched earth policy the moment you broke up! Get rid of everything that reminds you of him (except for 1 or 2 most important photos or letters, and hide those in a box and don't take them out) and don't follow him on social media! You probably prolonged your healing process by continually checking his social media - how to move on like that :( All you can do right now besides that, is be patient with yourself and be open to possibilities. Acceptance takes time, and everyone moves on in their own way. Keep busy, keep improving yourself. Eventually, there will be a day where you realise you're content, and you're free :) It was not a short or easy journey for me but I'm here now and I know you will be too!

People CAN change.

Okay, so here's my confession.

Around a year back, I had become a very dark and sadistic person. I had friends and family members that I could depend on, but deep down I was really lonely. I was fairly sociable and likeable, but I always felt alone. I would skip classes, spend so much time inside my room, would beat off once or twice a day. I could see myself deteriorating. Mentally. I started watching all kinds of things. Horrible things. Things one might call 'snuff films'. No, they did not turn me on. Maybe a few. No. I dont think so. Maybe the ones that involved actual rapes? I dont know, and I dont want to think so. 
Did i ever feel like committing those horrible horrible things I saw? No. This I am very sure about. I had enough sanity. But once, I did have a fleeting thought of what it would be like to torture someone but had to discard the idea shortly as I felt uneasy. I DID wince whenever I saw those films, I wasn't immune to the gore, to the pain, to the reality. I HAD enough sanity. But I DID watch a lot of them. A lot.
Before I could tumble deep deep down into the sadistic abyss and quite possibly end up rewiring my brain, something happened.

I met an angel.

She was the purest of heart. You could see it in her eyes. In her smile. She was stunningly beautiful. Just thinking about her would fill me up with so much joy. The scenery in my mind would change into a grassland flooded with sunlight! She had that halo! 
I felt myself being pulled towards her. I started liking her. The more I thought about her and the more I got to know about her, the more I loved her. She had so much positivity in her! Enough to save me. Enough to bring out the original me. Mind you, the dark phase was totally not the original me. I have always considered my true self soft of heart since I was a kid. She brought out the light in me again. And turned it brighter than ever. 
We are attached now. We are both sociable and likeable btw. I have the support I always seeked. I don't feel alone anymore. She makes me the happiest person on the planet. And I to her.  I am caring and loving like no other. The type of guys one might only see in romantic movies. We truly love each other. I mean it, and she means it.
I can no longer stomach those horrible things. Just thinking about them makes me sick to my stomach now. 

I just want to tell you that people CAN change. At least, I have.

I've been suffering from depression for about three years. My time in NUS has been filled with ups and downs but more ups, which is good! Judging from the number of posts about NUS peeps suffering from mental disorders, I know I'm not alone. I'm going through a down phase right now though. I'm currently in second year and it sucks. Constant low moods and I lost sleep because of something very trivial. I'm super afraid of being judged badly and just let people trample over me just to seek their approval. I broke down, I lost hope, I can't live like this. I feel as if I'm alone and no one understands what I feel.

That being said, I found one of the best ways to cope with depression/anxiety disorders is to find people going through the same ordeal and support each other. I was pretty sad that to know NUS does not have a peer support group for people suffering from such mental disorders. UCH counselling holds work shops for anxiety but at $150, I'd rather not.

Also, for the people who think that you suffer from a mental disorder but have yet to get a diagnosis, do not be afraid to seek help. Go see a private psychiatrist, or go to a polyclinic and get a referral to see one at IMH/NUH. No one has to know about this, but I strongly recommend you let someone close to you know so that you have some form of support. Recovery can be long but you will see how strong you are and you will realise you are capable of so many things.

I was hoping maybe that I could create an informal support group(whatsapp first?) If you suffer from depression/anxiety/bipolar/whatever mental disorder and you feel alone, please email me @ luminatetritium@gmail.com with your NUS email and just say 'Hi!' or something, so that I know that you're from NUS. I'll email you back with my NUS email and we could create a Whatsapp group and maybe meet up if everyone is comfortable!

And to be honest try taking the initiative to know the girl, I know of some girls who will never take the first step or show interest even if they do like you. Good luck!
-
 
Seeing a couple of posts on depression, I thought I should share my story on this platform. To be honest I am not sure what's my motive, maybe I just want it to be made known to people who have depression and probably relate from it.

I wasn't clinically diagnosed with depression, but I know that I had mild depression. I won't go into the details on why I had depression, but I'd roughly say that it was due to multiple factors - financial, family, relationship issues. I was studying in a JC, and while everyone was doing well in at least an aspect of their lives, I was somewhat lagging behind. And after some time, it truly felt like my life was engulfed by darkness, where I would just be really passive and got really comfortable in the abyss. I know it sounds too fictional but when you're in it, you'll know it. I was aware that I was being really negative, and like I've said, I felt way too comfortable feeling really emotional, down and hateful for no apparent reason and so I did nothing to really "save" my own ass and get out of it. 

Somehow, some things got hold of me, which I can't exactly pinpoint on what they were, but after 1.5 years, I finally made the effort to climb out of the hole I've been hiding in for so long, and got out of depression. What helped me was friends, who stood by me throughout my really, really bad days (or year), and positivity from even the smallest things around me (like seeing a kid being all happy and trouble-less, and no, I'm not a pedophile). I started changing my mindset, and I was constantly telling myself to find anything that makes me happy, and invest in it. It was difficult, because of inertia in me, but I started somewhere; I started slow, and I am proud to say I fought the beast inside me.

So to whoever's reading this, if you have friends who have depression, please, do not shun them. Do not leave them in the lurch, but do not expect them to immediately open up or figuratively speaking, hold your hand when you offer them one. Give them time and space. Let them know you'll be there for them, and make sure you mean it. I know we've been told to get rid of any negativity in life, but if you think you can make a difference to someone's life, someone you care about, stand by them.
-

I find myself constantly thinking about when's the next time we can meet, preparing surprises to make him happy, and spending a long time to think about what to wear. Anyone out there feels like once you've reached a certain age being single, you inevitably tend to (consciously or unconsciously) wonder/fantasize if your other single friend could become a potentially significant other?  

I'm evergreen and totally ready to be single for life and depend on myself because I know I can (I also quite like the freedom), so I don't think I'm THAT desperate. But yet, I am also open to relationships IF they happen. Recently when I met new single friends, no matter how hard I try to keep the interaction innocent and focus on the person as a friend, there will be this thought at the back of my mind that says that, objectively speaking, there IS a possibility that this friendship might become something more. And then I feel like my friendships aren't that innocent and pure any more.

I usually don't act on those thoughts (well unless the other person hints positively) and after a while it doesn't affect me that much, especially if I conclude that I'm not interested in the other person in a romantic way.  I feel like gone are the days of true and innocent friendships for me, that is not affected by romantic interests at all. Or maybe this is just me entering a new phase of my life in mid-20s, when we have evolved to start looking for potential partners as a priority.
-
 
 It's perfectly normal... I have been through the same. If she loves you for who you really are, as you say, then she loves you whether you're inexperienced or not. Don't worry about those petty things. You have got to put an end to that kind of thinking at some point, if you expect to trust the other person. It might as well be now.

Girls don't care as much about it as you think they do. And guys don't care as much about small things as girls think they do. Reading these confessions, sometimes it feels like everyone is caught up in the little details of life that are irrelevant in the end. Stop overthinking.

-
 
To  Please don't hesitate to seek some help if you feel like you need it! I've used their services before and it was really the turning point for me. Even if you feel that you can't connect with the first counsellor assigned to you, I think they do offer the option of switching to another counsellor if you want to. 

Anyway I think there's a misconception that you have to have 'serious' issues before seeking such services. Who defines serious anyway, it doesn't really make sense to let other people's opinions and judgement stop you from making an active decision to start feeling better about yourself. It's your life, and you're the one reaping the benefits or losing out from it, not everyone else. My experience with counsellors (external ones as well) are that they really provide a listening ear and open mind regardless of what you say, making it easier to confide in them since they won't have a pre conceived notion of who you are. They don't tell you what to do, but rather give you new perspectives and ask you questions that help you to find yourself on the right path again. 

I would recommend you to try out just once and see how it's like? It's free anyway, so no harm trying. If you're afraid of the social stigma associated, then maybe don't tell anyone about your first visit or just confide selectively in those you trust and know will support you. 

I also thought that my issue was not serious and this led to a rapid deterioration of my condition. Like you, I was good at keeping up with appearances such that I managed to lie to everyone, even my family. I think no one would have known what was going on if I chose not to tell anyone. But I chose to voice out because I wanted to get better and was sick and tired of being, well, sick and tired haha. Sometimes I wish I didn't wait until I hit rock bottom before starting to climb up. 

So good luck OP! Just sharing my experience and opinions. Hope that regardless your decision, you'll be able to find a way to cope with your problems soon!

To ,

Yes it is your fault. Put yourself in your ex's shoes. Imagine you are happily in love with your gf with no signs of any issues, you have always loved your gf the best way you knows, then your gf dumps you because she met another guy and fell in love with him. Going by the scant information you provided in your post, you met the girl while with your gf, and you fell for her despite being attached. You fell out out of love with your ex willingly. The timelines overlap, which actually makes you a cheater. Love is a choice, not a passing feeling. So yes it's your fault.

No it's not your fault. If your gf abused you and treat you like trash, you fought so hard for the r/s that you are driving yourself insane to save it. Then this girl came along and showed you how love can be kind. Then no, it's not your fault. 

So it depends. But the past is the past, what matters is going forward. We live for ourselves, why care what people say about you. You were attached for 2 years before your eyes wandered, that's when the honeymoon period ended. How can you ensure it does not happen again in this r/s, that's the key.

"No one falls in love by choice, it is by chance.
No one stays in love by chance, it is by work.
And no one falls out of love by chance, it is by choice."

I hope you continue to love your gf. You may not see it now, but everyone has flaws, you don't love because of your partner's virtues, but despite her flaws.

And don't try to contact your ex to alleviate your guilt (for your selfish reasons). Trust me, I was in your ex's shoes, and she won't want you to contact her anytime soon.

To OP of  (not sure if correct post, but it's the one on how the mum always gets son to do chores), check out this subreddit called raisedbynarcissists. I can't really offer advice since I've not had that kind of experience, but I think you'll be able to find some comfort in knowing that you're not the only one who has this kind of parents. You may also be able to seek advice there, but from what I've read, the children (those in your shoes) usually move out because your mum has a particular personality trait that prevents her from understanding the needs of other people (i.e. you) so you can't really hold a proper discussion with her without her flying off the handle.

My own advice would be you'd have to continue to tolerate this or try to speak to your sister or dad about it and see what you can do from there. If things get serious, it may be best to consult a professional family counsellor. Then again, I don't know the full context of your situation so this might not be a sound advice.

Ultimately this is about your mental wellbeing in the long term so do speak to someone about this if you can. But if you have ample emotional support outside of your family and you're confident you're able to tolerate your mum's actions, it may be best to leave things as it is to avoid things getting out of hand (I'm assuming a worst case scenario here, I don't know if your situation is as bad as I picture it to be.) Best of luck.

-
 
 as someone who has been in the same boat as you (twice), I say delete his number. The only way to really avoid texting him is to try to be as rational as possible (though I know it's really hard). If you text him to show how mad you are, you're just giving him the satisfaction of thinking "yeah I made the right choice leaving the relationship". The reason why I say this is because I did that before, and I kind of regret how much power it gave him on hindsight.
I know it doesn't feel like it now, but you're better off without him if he can dump a 3-year relationship and get with another girl so soon. Another way to look at it is that maybe you two weren't right for each other, and now you have a chance to look for the right guy (or remain single if that's what you want, which is also cool!). Stay strong OP. You will get over this!

In response to   and  and to all girls who has boob-related issues. We have different sizes and I think we should learn to work with what we got! There will be different pros and cons to having big or small boobs. I used to feel extremely awkward as I have a slim figure and D cup boobs so it made me really self conscious and caused me to have a bad posture. Many of my friends would think that I would look nice in clothings but the truth is, I can't fit into most of what they can! Clothings that dont fit around my waist will make me look fat. Clothings that are tight fitting usually cant fit around my bust area. :( It took me a long time to find clothing types that can fit me better. Big or small also have problems, so might as well just embrace it and keep a look out for things that will fit! :) Also, everyone has different likings and preferences. Big and small boobs are attractive to different people. Some people like bigger boobs, some people like smaller boobs. While your boobs may be just as amazing as your personality, those who like you for your boobs are not worth your time!

Whatever you got, since you got it, FLAUNT IT!

tips for the ladies. how to tell if a guy likes you. 
1) guy friend always sits next to you in lecture/tutorial amongst other friends/clique, and he sits leaning towards you. i.e him sits leaning like this --> / | <-- you sit straight like this
2) when something funny pops up in his mind, the first thing he does is to ALWAYS turn to you to laugh/joke about it. (even though he has other friends beside him)
3) he subconsicously squares his body to you (open gesture) even when amongst other friends
4) he tries to take pictures of you 'for fun'
5) he leans in to talk to you even under normal circumstances (not whispering)
6) he mirrors your sitting posture/arms position unconsciously
7) he tries to establish body contact by poking, and tapping anywhere else other than the shoulder. e.g forearm, sides, cheek etc

girls, if you like the guy, reciprocate! this is one way to 'hint' back to him by mirroring his actions!

but if you know that this guys already has a girlfriend, you have a problem! please do him and his girlfriend a favour by distancing yourself! applies if you do not like him too, don't lead him on!

True story. I'm a girl who's been seeing someone twice my age for the past 4 years with no strings attached. He was a millionaire when I first met him and his finances were like his bipolar illness. One year he was rich, the next year he had donated all his wealth away. I remember he told me "Don't fall in love with me," but I did.  He made it clear he couldn't marry me. His psychological condition and work makes it difficult for him to maintain a marriage. So he let's me date other boys - and I do. Whenever someone breaks my heart, I'll run back to him and he makes it all better again. 

I met him again today. As of late, we only meet once in a while. He had a heart attack this year so he's suddenly treating me better. Some days he'll ask if I want food and he'll drive by my house to drop it off. Most other days, we dine at Trader's or Shangri-la. 

Three times in a row now, he keeps telling me that there's something about me that keeps him loyal to me. He could have any girl he wants but he chose me. I didn't know this. All this while I thought he was seeing other girls behind my back too. Apparently not. 

Sure I date a lot of guys but that's only because he told me to go find someone else. Someone who can promise me marriage. But really, he's the only one I've ever genuinely loved and cared about. To hear him say he's kept himself for me all these years...It's like Nirvana, I just feel so incredibly honoured & happy and peaceful. 

Even though we're not married, we pretty much  are. He's seen me through my best and worst and I him. He takes care of me emotionally, financially, medically, (sexually), mentors me and encourages me to do well in uni. I'm so lucky. 

To the girls out there who stopped believing in faithfulness because you've had a boyfriend who cheated on you before, start believing again. The right one will come and the right one will choose you over any other girl without you  needing to do anything.

Everyone says girls are hard to understand. I think every human is unique and it's very difficult, if not impossible to read people. So, a genuine, open to hearing ideas, question here about the male psyche:

1. Guy talks to girl day in and day out. Says good morning, good night, the whole shebang!

2. Guy talks about his hopes/ dreams for the future - His job, where he wants to travel, etc. Girl responds she shares similar dreams, but maybe not in the immediate future.

3. Guy moves to a foreign country for a job, but the communication/ deep conversations continue through text messages and phone calls, even across times zones.

4. Guy suddenly stops texting, suddenly talks about a girl he likes and has decided to date in the foreign country (but she's also Singaporean).

5. Guy scales back on the texting, only texts girl back home occasionally, maybe once every few days to say 'hi'. 

So, what happened? Girl read Guy's intentions incorrectly from the start? Guy has dumped girl and moved on to someone else? Girl is overthinking being friendzoned? This whole thing sounds impossible/ boring?

Over the past week or so I've seen some confessions by insecure girls who've smaller-than-A boobs. I'm so sorry that you fellow girls exist and have to endure this very real misery and insecurity, but at the same time also so relieved that yall exist. Fellow girls who silently seethe when A cup girls whine about their "small boobs" - what even, they don't even know how bad it gets! And unlike guys, we can't hide our size at mere first glance in public either. Life. Anyway, here's a great repost from NTU Confessions: 

"To the girl who posted about having a flat chest:

Just wanna tell you that you're really not alone in this. I can totally understand how you feel as I have the same problem. I am almost entirely flat-chested, and have been insecure about it since secondary school days. Like you, I can't fit an A cup. I'm an AA or AAA cup (I think some insensitive ppl are gonna say 'then wear a bra for what?'. I'm lazy to give an in depth explanation but in general, small girls need to wear bras to feel a bit more confident and 'less exposed'). You can buy AA or AAA cup bras from lulalu.com. The founders of this bra brand are also small like us they understand how it feels too :') You should try out some of their bras! Quite expensive though, cos you have to ship them from the U.S., but wearing a bra that fits well will really make you feel more confident. (I'm not paid for advertising)
I used to feel abnormal and often wondered whether I am the ONLY unfortunate one with such a flat chest. So I often googled about my problem to see whether there are other girls in the same plight lol. And there are! You can search for forums and talk to the girls who really understand how it feels. That's how I found out about lulalu.com by the way. Haha there are many A cup girls online complaining about how they are too small and want a B or C cup. But whoa I'll be extremely overjoyed if I can even fill an A cup.

When I was younger (start of uni) I thought that no one would ever wanna date someone like me cos of my small boobs and would foresee my sad lonely future haha. But now I have a loving boyfriend, who always reassures me that he loves me for who I am, small boobs or not. And that he still finds me beautiful. Compared to the past, I think my level of insecurity has greatly decreased already. But now and then, I will irrationally have some breakdowns and feel upset that I am like this and start questioning whether my boyfriend will leave me for someone with boobs that he can at least be able to grab lollll. When I'm insecure like that, he actually feels sad too and will gently console me with words of assurance. His support really helps to remind me that there's so much more about me than just simply my non-existent boobs.

I don't know whether you're currently worrying about not being able to find a bf (you didn't mention but somehow so many guys replied your post to say they like small boobs lol), but anyway I'm sure you will meet someone who will love you for who you are (damn cliched but it's true la) cos anyone who doesn't love you just cos of your boobs is definitely not worth your time anyway.

Anyway, I found out that during pregnancy our boobs will grow for sure (like second puberty! Yay!). So you get two bonuses: bigger boobs and a baby! Haha but please don't get pregnant just for bigger boobs.

Hope you feel better knowing that you're not alone :) "

He still doesn't know, and now we no longer talk. I agree with you OP, technology has a really prescient way of reminding you of your past, and in the most bittersweet way! It was good while it lasted, and I sincerely hope he's happy in his new relationship.

TDLR; the past will always come back in the most unexpected ways, and I guess part of growing up is learning how to acknowledge it, deal with it, and move on.

Letting go of the past takes time, but time will heal. Do what you love and the love of your life will love you for who you are. People are not mind-reading machines. Put down your self-doubts, let the other person know how you feel. Pen it down first if necessary. Don't worry about how the other person might judge you because you dont live base on how others are judging you. BUT you will live with regret if you missed the opportunity. 

I never got to know what my dad wants to say before he left. I never got to see him for the last time. At least i managed to do something for my mom. Cherish the people around you. All of you are beautiful <3 

No matter how tough life can be, it can't be tougher than yesterday. Keep going!

Advice to  I have been through depression myself and also helped others along the way. What I can say is we don't really like advice nor comfort. That sort of 'it is all right everything is ok' is bullshit to us. But what we need, is your listening ear. Initially, we might take a very long time to open up our problems to you. But my friend, through countless persuasion, finally made me confess. There are times that we screw up things, get into a quarrel for some small reasons but be gentle with us, because we are going through tough times. Give us some leeway and sometimes, give us time to be alone. When I had more 'me time', I could sort out some problems on my own and with some help and a great listening ear, gotten over depression a little. To be exact, depression can last very long (mine last almost a year) and certain events can re-trigger depression. Ultimately, it was dangling between resistance and susceptibility. to you, OP, it takes a lot of effort but it is worth it for your brother. Perhaps he will thank you someday. Take care! :)
-
 
TLDR: you never quite leave your past behind

I recently changed my phone. During the setting-up process I sync-ed it up with my old email - and in the process loading up old notes from 2012 in my phone. In doing so I loaded up some of my ex's old notes (I recall lending her my Apple ID when she first got her iphone to download stuff), and I saw some of the things that she used to write to me, and some of the old messages I used to write to her.

We used to write each other long messages for our monthsaries - I wonder when we stopped doing that? - but these messages were the mushiest of the mushy, and somewhat laughable too, but I had fun scrolling through all of them, remembering where we were at different points in time - me entering NS, her starting uni, etc.

It's funny because we don't really talk anymore. Not 'funny' as in ha ha (okay, maybe a bit of bittersweet laughter), but funny because we're so different from who we used to be, and yet the past finds a way to affect the present - as much as I (we?) want to leave it behind.

Thanks for listening.

Simple advice. To people with opposite sex platonic friend, don't be in a relationship, 99.99% you will hurt your partner in a way or another. I only knew about basic sex - the way it is described in biology books and nothing more. I heard some of terms before but never felt the need to know the meaning and no one at home talks about it also. Personally, I did not think it was necessary to know so much details so I didn't search online earlier. Everyone had a fun time explaining stuff to me. We all laughed a lot and they called me an innocent kid. At that point, I laughed along with them but later on it slowly struck me that now the guy certainly thinks I am stupid and will lose interest in me. After all, he is so well-informed about these things and I seem to know very little.

However, just because I don't know about advanced sex terms doesn't mean that I don't believe in love. I often fantasise about how it would feel like to have a boyfriend. I imagine walking with someone at night holding his hand, watching stars at Town Green. I imagine watching the sunset together at a beach. For me, love is more than just having sex. It is an emotional connection. It is about sharing your joys and sorrows, caring about each other's feelings and accepting your partner with their strengths and weaknesses. It is the feeling that you can trust someone to be always there for you no matter how challenging the circumstances are. Sex is fine too, but I am quite traditional and would want to have sex only after marriage.

This is my view of love. I understand that everyone has their different opinions and I do not judge people who think otherwise, but I do feel sad that this guy won't be interested in me anymore because I am so 'innocent'. I had some feelings for him but now I have to get over it.

People who know me in real life can never guess I wrote this post. They probably think I am too busy studying and never thought about love and relationships, but it's not true. I feel attracted to guys too and I am looking forward to that day when I find my true love.

I don't know why recently there are so many posts about sex and fwb. Before you engage in those activities, please give some serious thought to these:
1) ask yourself: do you really NOT mind if your future spouse has had sex with exes or fwb? Look at some past posts you will definitely see someone complaining about their partner having done it before with others and is currently feeling uncomfortable with it. If you don't want this to happen to you, then put yourself in your future spouse's shoes. Don't do it; don't let him/her down.
2) Come on, who won't wanna marry a virgin? Exclusively yours for life (yes marriage is for life). Yet they don't save theirs for their spouses. Is this fair?
3) why so despo to lose your virginity? To follow trend? That's silly. Why be a follower? You are young adults so please be more mature.
4) worried about not being able to lose it? Seriously?? Do you have such low esteem and low confidence in yourself? 
5) YOLO?  No. You only die once and live every single day. Live your life with some self respect for yourself. And your body. Sleeping around is no different from being a prostitute. Except that the latter still gets some money out of it while you don't.
6) If you were your parents, how would you feel? Will you want the same thing to happen to your future children? Set the right example so that you don't have to feel ashamed of your past when you tell stories to them in future. 
7) Contraception has its own risks. They do not have 100% guarantee that things won't go wrong. Also, pills are harmful and will ruin your body. If you want to become a parent in future, better think twice.

So please, to all desperate people out there, whether you are attached or fwb, stop thinking about getting laid. Spend all your energy on your studies instead.

PS: I'm happily married. Not some forever alone guy in case you are wondering. And yes, we saved ours till wedding day. It's priceless.

-
 
You know what?
We need a more inclusive awareness about depression.

When depression is described, it usually (but not always) amounts to variations of ‘feeling sad’. But I don’t ‘feel sad’, so I spent ten years thinking that I was just super lazy and undisciplined. 

Then, someone made an effort to point out that I might have depression. Had I never been introduced to the more ‘obscure’ symptoms, I never would have realized that I was worrying about the wrong things.

For some people, depression amounts to;

A bleak outlook on your life - feelings of hopelessness and disinterest in your future.
Persistent and chronic feelings of ‘sadness’ and ‘helplessness’
Thoughts of suicide and/or self harm.
But for me, depression is NOT any of those. I have;

Daily physical and mental exhaustion, but also severe insomnia. I am yawning by mid afternoon, but I can only scrape an average of five hours of sleep.
Lacking the ability to consciously construct a train of thought (without great effort). This prevents me from doing schoolwork, household chores, or socializing.
Chronic restlessness and physical discomfort, which accumulates to general grumpiness and frustration 24/7.
Persistent body pains and aches, especially in my neck and arms. 
An altered perception of time. I forget sentences as I’m speaking them. It’s difficult to tell if something happened two hours ago, or two days ago. Every waking moment just blurs into one big boring stretch of unsatisfactory.
You can’t muscle through depression. Things will not get easier the more you try to tackle them. You know a great treatment for depression? Accommodating to it. Making your life easier. Recognizing the things you can and can’t do. 

We need more people to recognize their depression. Otherwise, they’ll keep struggling and struggling and they’ll wonder why everyone is having such a good time while they’re using up all their spoons simply by driving to work.

Regarding the alleged racism it could be that the OP misinterpreted the presenter but just want to point out that the fact that he could not have had such an outburst without having faced a fair amount of racism before. Our nation has turned 50 but I still have friends who openly profess they are racist and seem to bond over that fact, glorifying in racist "jokes" and shunned me because I expressed my dislike towards racists. I have had a friend humiliated after her secret pal talked loudly to his friends that he was disappointed that she was Indian and dark-skinned. I have had friends openly "joking" about how Malays are stupid and lazy right in front of my Malay friend who was already sad over her grades and who was clearly feeling awkward but didn't scold them as they told her not to take it seriously which I think was just an excuse for them. I sometimes also wonder whether Malays do not dare to aim higher because they would be surrounded by more non-Malays in higher education and be subjected to more discrimination. There are many more examples. So I'm thinking I am not that surprised if the OP's suspicions were true. Of course the majority of Singaporeans are not racist but I think people should not quickly dismiss the minorities' claims of racism even though it may be an overreaction depending on the case. 

Now regarding the feelings of ugliness. I have been bullied over my small, single-eyelid eyes before, had someone hint to me to get surgery, was told that I could never be pretty with such eyes, openly laughed at and was even told by a guy that I would be his eye candy if not for my eyes (not that I care about him though). Of course this affected me a lot and I feel very sad just once in a while remembering the trauma but it actually deepened my resolve to never get surgery because my eyes are not something meant to be fixed and I have had quite a number of compliments about my overall looks before too and most importantly I believe I am pretty enough. I will always remember feeling like the ugliest girl in the world and I hope others have the strength to not feel this way.

To all those suffering from bullying/discrimination do know that you are not the only one and that you have to find people who care no matter if its difficult initially because there are people who do. I'm sorry for the long rant. Welcome any thoughts.

-
 
A few months ago, my JC friend from the student council unfriended me on Facebook. We worked together, although we were not very close, we were on friendly terms, sort of like acquainted. I was shocked she unfriended me and only me, but not the other mutual friends we've got. :O I still don't understand the reason till date.

I don't flood people's news feed with insensitive or offensive posts about religion, politics etcetera, and neither do I post photos of everything I consume. I simply use Facebook to connect with old and new friends and share some articles about current affairs and that's it. Okie, I am okay with it. I take it as a sign that she was not interested to keep in touch with me, since as I quite remember she was the elitist type of person who likes to associate herself with outstanding and popular people, especially the president, vice-president and exco of the council. Since I'm just an average Jane, so maybe I'm not worth to be part of her social circle. I'm fine with it, since I don't need her in my life as well.

However, I received a friend request from her last night. I accepted it, since I gave her the benefit of the doubt that the previous "unfriending" was a merely Facebook glitch. Then she messaged me asking me to like her new Facebook page on her lifestyle. An attempt to "harvest" Likes. On her lifestyle page, she brags about all the branded goods she bought, her expensive travels to Paris, and her hangouts with Caucasian men. "AMDK!" as what my boyfriend always say :-) I'd say her lifestyle page is quite interesting and definitely an object of envy for a poor Singaporean girl like myself.

Politely, I agreed and gave her page a like, and she didn't reply me after that. End of conversation. This morning, I checked her profile out again for curiosity sake, and guess what? There's an option to add friend. She unfriended me again! Wow! So much for online etiquette. It's not because I am hard up for her gold-made FB friendship, but her actions are actually very rude to think about it.

So I blacklisted her and unliked her page immediately. A childish game of tit for tat. If she request anything from me again next time, I'll ignore her. These are the type of friends we should avoid. She's an SMU student btw, but I'm certain not many SMU students are as arrogant as her. 

And in the light of recent news, Facebook is in a dilemma of whether they should add a "dislike" button. I think it is a bad idea, since it's less "hostile" online to either like something or ignore it. Adding in a dislike is damaging to the soul of the OP, because it's very misleading on whether the dislike is meant personally for the OP or for the content itself. The social media can impact the feelings of others as murders have taken place because the victims didn't give a thumbs up to the murderers' FB posts. Online etiquette shouldn't be taken too lightly. I hope she can understand this.

So many stories of people cheating on their partners lately, it's sickening. Is it really that hard to be faithful to your partner? If things are getting old and boring, then it's time for you two to either try something new or to move on. People who cheat are just cowards who want the best of both worlds, the stability of a relationship and the excitement of someone new.

The next time any of you face that temptation, try acting like a grown-up. If you want to have sex with someone else, please tell your partner. Get the slap and break-up you deserve before you do it.

2) people will think something is wrong with me mentally, because it was believed that it's is only natural if you feel attracted to the opposite gender and if you have no feelings towards the opposite gender, then you are just weird in people's opinion.

I think it's better to hear from you all the younger generation rather than my mom who's from the older generation...

Once in a while i'll meet up with some  of them studying in NUS for lunch or something. I know you guys will say go joiN CCAs and stuff to get to know more ppl, but the thing is the major that i'm doing is pretty hectic with packed timetables and content heavy modules that i simply dont have time to do all those stuff. I know its rather contradictory here, me wanting to get to make more friends but unwilling to join CCAs and Its not that i'm antisocial or anything. Its just that im not prepared to sacrifice my studies for the sake of some social life (again, contradictory i know). I guess its the nature of uni life? 

When i was in year 1 i was kinda desperate to take modules with others (those i already knew outside NUS) so I arranged my timetable to suit theirs. I guess this did not help things much since i always stuck around with ppl i was already familiar with. In year 2 i kinda gave up since its not easy to match time tables so I did most of my mods alone. It was a bonus if i happened to know anyone  doing the same mod. To be honest I kinda enjoyed the freedom, being able to do whatever i like (eat, study or just go to the library alone and surf youtube) without having to worry about what others want to do. However in year 3 now the sense of loneliness is slowly coming back and hence the reason for me writing this. Everytime i see a large group of ppl laughing and joking together makes me kinda jealous and sad since i'm alone in school most of the time.

Thanks for reading this damn long and rather emo post. Just wanted to get this off my chest and sorry for any grammatical errors or whatever. Typing this at 2am and im kinda sleepy already. And lastly good luck all for your remaining mid terms!

To , I am in a similar predicament as you are. Despite being able to choose whichever university I want to go to for exchange with my academic achievements, I have to watch by the side while my friends apply for SEP, wait in anticipation for the results, and finally enjoy one semester abroad living new experiences. The bursaries available are insufficient to pay for the all the expenses in any good university abroad, which is what I'm worried about, since there's no way I can chip out any more money to go abroad above having to save for tuition fees as well. And it doesn't end there, does it? I can list out so many ways by which finances have limited me, so many things I'd had to watch my friends do without me while I politely decline without reason, so many ways my entire life would have been different if I just had the finances. 

But honestly, so what if you feel unjust/sad over this? The situation won't just change overnight just because you feel sad, will it? Sometimes in life, shit happens and the best way to move forward is to zone out from the shitty things and zoom in to the things that you can do to improve you situation. Life will always be unfair; look at yourself - you might not have realised it but you've probably had a lot of good things happen to you (getting into university, having arms and legs, etc) that others would kill for. Many good things must have happened and many shitty things avoided, in order for you to even get into university. But regardless, circumstances will remain what they are because they are out of your control - brooding over them will not get you anywhere. What you can change, however, is the way you think, and the steps you take to improve the situation. Ultimately, its the way we choose to think that will define how good our life feels. You have to permit it for any thought to affect you.

Like you, I used to feel so upset over my circumstances as well. But it happened so frequently, that eventually I was able to see that all this negativity never did anything to improve the situation. I keep reminding myself that only my abilities can change my circumstances. Once we graduate, we'll be able to change our own financial situation. What you can do now is to study hard so that you can get whichever job you'd like and then pay for yourself to go abroad, after you graduate. That's what I'll be doing too :)

To make things even worst, while waiting for my boyfriend yesterday, I've came to learn that the two of them are in the same tutorial and are actually sort of close with one another. Though my boyfriend did not introduce me to him as his girlfriend, we did admit that we knew each other before.

-
 
To the OP of 

I came from a family where my mum had mental issues due to my dad's infidelity and there was a lot of physical/emotional violence too. All my life I didn't want to get into a relationship because I was sure there's no such thing as a happy relationship. In the end though I ended up getting attached to someone really quickly after meeting - before telling my partner about the family issues. It only came out slowly over the course of our relationship and it really wasn't easy. In my personal experience at least, I really found my worst fears coming true, that I wasn't able to be "normal" and love my partner as well as I wanted to. My pessimism and own emotional baggage were like a dark cloud hanging over the relationship and I spent lots of time crying on my own over how hopeless and angry I felt, especially since my partner didn't seem to understand why I feel/act/think a certain way. But like in any relationship, communication and compromise is important, and I think if you are both honest about what you want and why, it can only make your relationship stronger. What helped also was that I went to see a counselor (and still see one at least twice a month) - one of the things she said to me was to stop beating myself up for not being "normal". There's really no such thing as "normal" and regardless of the childhood we had, there are people everywhere on the spectrum from manipulative to naive to distant to loving etc. So don't compare yourself to the "normal" people/relationships out there. What matters is between you and your (potential) partner and as long as they are accepting and compatible with you, give it a shot :) 

I guess what I wanted to say is it's really not easy, and while you don't have to force yourself to tell someone about your past immediately, it helps them to understand you and having someone who is willing to make that effort can make the relationship worthwhile :) Sometimes you just have to take the plunge and commit - although I tried to back out of my relationship and I still think about breaking up whenever I can't handle anything, I also remind myself that I don't want the shadow of my parent's relationship to be hanging over my life forever. We all deserve happiness, and you never know who could make you happier than you imagined you could be until you give them that chance. Please don't give up hope! 

-
 
I sometimes feel like my boyfriend is as suffocating in this relationship as the haze ):

Right now, she still talks to me time to time but it wasn't the same as before. I hope that you find another guy in uni that deserves you more than this asshole of me.

Yours truly, the OP of Post

I am a final year undergraduate who have been doing research for more than a year. Recently, I have trouble working with a superior who is from another school and not my FYP advisor. Times when she was asking for my help on her work, she would try to sound polite and friendly. But after the help was given, she would go into some nasty verbal attacks. The first time it happened was when she asked for my opinion on a specific methodology that was within my major. When she didn't get the opinion she wanted to hear, she told me off that I had a "lack of knowledge" of what I had studied. I explained that as I am only an undergraduate, I could only give my opinion as far as I know and that I find her words not appropriate nor helpful when we are discussing about research ideas. If I am wrong, she could correct me, not comment me with her personal attacks. Later, she backtracked, claiming there was "miscommunication" and I severely "misinterpreted" the meaning behind her words. No apologies were given but I accepted her agreement then that future discussions should be more civil. Another mentor of mine who have worked with her before also assured me that he will also talk to her and such a thing would not happened again. 

Recently after I had spent a week helping her collate her results, she 
criticized that part of my method was "incomplete". When I asked her where did she find the exact problem that leads to this "incompleteness", she told me off again that I  "asking too many questions means that "I am not listening to her" and that I have a severe lack of "modest for a young man". I am still deeply disturbed by her words now. Unlike her, I spent hours of weekdays and even weekends on research with no pay and no incentives further than a a few lines on my resume. Since I have always done research work for the passion of pursuing it, I do not believe that I should continue when my motivation to stay in this particular project is now killed entirely by comments on my character or intelligence. I was taught that no matter 
the other person is right or wrong in any argument, even whether he is a criminal or a saint, everyone deserves respect to his/her dignity no less than anyone else. I have worked in previous places with high stress, complex political ecosystem and self-centered bosses. I have  also worked with other superiors and research advisers (many of whom I would gladly catch up with) but this is my first time I had experienced such a person. Even though her words may only sound disrespectful and physically harmless, I have also grown suspicious of what other  things she would do too. Since she believed that my FYP hinged on the success of her work and so has every right for her lack-of civility, then I do not believe that there is any room for me to stay too. P.s. I am already working on another research project which could potentially be used for my FYP instead. Just sharing to hear any other advice or whether there are also any other people with similar experiences too.

-
 
 I have to say this from a girl's POV. You might think not putting too much feelings into it makes it hurt less for you, and true it does. But honestly if you were to move on so quickly, trust me the number of times you are going to get rejected will be way higher than what would have been. I have had 3 or 4 guys that confessed to me that were similar to your case. They asked out girls really quickly and that was a MAJOR turn off. That's because most girls would feel that all you want to do is to get a relationship and it doesn't matter who the partner is. Giving off that kind of signal naturally makes girls shun you, even if they were the slightest bit interested in you before.

I would say ask someone out only if you are really sure you like/love the person, and not act on impulse or feelings that aren't even deep. Even if you do get a girl in the end it might not even work out because you were not even that sure of your feelings. I get what you mean on wasting time hurting over someone for years, but that's what love really is. I never regretted loving someone for 4 years even if it was one sided. Yes it hurt, but it passed eventually. Even if it took a long time to get over it it was still worth it because I'd rather be single than be in a relationship for the sake of being in one.

Regd . 
I'm the one who paid the price for a mistake not mine. I fell in love with someone who had been cheated on. 
Though that relationship was long over, the pain was still there, very much there. His heart was closed and he could let no one else in. So I suffered, loving someone who just wasn't capable of loving me back. The pain was not just his - knowing he was in pain hurt me deeply. Unreciprocted love is really not as romantic as Shakespeare makes it out to be. It's like being so disgusted with yourself that you want to tear your skin off, because you want to stop it but you can't. It's like holding on tightly to a broken glass bottle, fingers clenched around it, not letting go even though you know it's draining the life out of you.  
Thankfully, this story has a happy ending - a new beginning for us. :) 

But the scars of being cheated on will always be there. The heart heals, the pain goes away - but you really have no idea what an excruciating journey it has been. Though I paid the price for a mistake someone else made, he makes it all worth it - every single day when I wake up next to him, I am thankful to share another day with him. I am also grateful that I was able to be there with him, on his journey of healing. 

Don't be selfish. Don't cheat. 

No one deserves pain and betrayal like that, that crushes your soul and plunges the best of men into an abyss of low self-confidence.

Context first: I am an all around average girl. Average looking, average grades, average financial status etc. I am also evergreen and content. In fact I am so happy being single that there is a sense of inertia preventing me from wanting to get attached and lose my freedom. I'm someone who likes to just turn their phone off for the entire weekend and walk down orchard road to people watch. Or spend an afternoon alone at the movies. A whole day sitting at Kino reading books. Even just sitting under a tree singing to myself daydreaming about life. 

And that is where the problem starts. I have had maybe a little over a dozen guys confess to me and honestly, it is not because they aren't good enough that I reject them. I enjoy their company, they are not in the friend zone, I honestly considered giving 'us' a shot. But the timings are always terrible. Some confessed right before psle, o levels, a levels papers. Other confess the week before my cca had major events. Even now, before uni midterm or finals. Or just a bad period when I have multiple commitments with impending deadlines. See the pattern here? 

I am always too busy for relationships. In fact they are so good to me that I feel that they deserve more from me, more time that I am unable to afford and I felt it was unfair to make them wait. I didn't want to be selfish. So I straight up told them no and for them to move on. 

I wonder if it is an excuse sometimes. Because honestly the most recent guy I felt was way out of my league. He was incredibly patient, knowledgeable, intelligent, kind, cute etc. Basically most people would agree he is ideal. He was Oxford grad, and I'm... Well, I'm me. And yet it didn't work out, because I thought we are both too busy for each other that even though we were meeting up it was not sustainable. 

So currently there is a new guy who I suspect is interested in me, and the same pattern is happening. We are talking and becoming closer friends. But I feel like I am doing something wrong by not warning him. Am I leading him on when I genuinely want to give it a try but realise that it may end up as before because I am honestly too busy? (it's not excuses because I don't even have time for hobbies now the way my faculty is) Should I just warn him off and cut it off before he can get hurt? 

Tl;dr my busy schedule is probably going to make me nip another relationship in the bud. Should I warn all guys from now on before they start talking to me that we can only be friends.
