To , from 

You’ve misunderstood me. 

1) I’m not jealous of people who are in a relationship, I’m jealous of the people who have found love. Judging from the number of confessions about cheating, I think its safe to say that both do not always overlap.

I am also perfectly aware that I should be in a relationship because I like someone, not because I want to feel loved. Hence I’ve been single all my life. If I wanted a relationship in order to feel loved, I would have been in one long ago. I already feel loved even without someone to call a “significant other” – I think many of us forget that love need not be just romantic love. Love from your family, friends, and yourself should mean as much as romantic love. 

2) Do you not read – I’ve never been in a relationship. I did not “join” a relationship to escape some life problems. I don’t depend on someone to be my “pain killer”, I face life’s problems on my own, with the help of people I love. I have hurt someone badly before. It was unintentional on my part, but I can see the hurt I’ve caused him, and I’d do anything to fix the scars I’ve left behind. I guess karma is a bitch, because I got hurt by someone else in return, and I’m only all too familiar with the pain and the tears and the haunting words that just never seem to go away. 

3) I disagree, and still think that it is difficult to find someone you love. I don’t mean infatuation, or just the kind of “yea I like you coz you chio”. I mean the kind of love where you see – and I mean really see – the person for who he is, and love him despite his flaws. The kind of love where you will never think of doing something like cheating, because you just can’t imagine hurting this person. The kind of love where there’s respect, trust, compromise and teamwork.  This takes time to build, and there are a lot of other factors that come into play. Even though many people may be “the one”, it takes a lot to really build a healthy, loving relationship with someone, and I just don’t understand how people who already have that can so carelessly squander it away. 

He/she definitely isn’t the only one who posses these traits, but if you continue having that mindset while being attached, you will never be truly grateful and appreciative of the one who is in front of you. If you are not ready to settle down and want to keep fishing/ having fun, then don’t commit yourself to someone and hurt that person. Don’t be such a selfish asshole.

To - I don't know who you are, but I have a good idea of the circle of friends you belong to. I'm exactly like you- I yearn for deep friendships rather than shallow ones. As a result, I haven't made many friends here, just acquaintances. But the friends that I do have, are very close to me. You have to pick and choose the people you can get close to, and who also want to get close to you- trust me, there are many. You wouldn't know, but everybody feels the same way; everybody feels lonely sometimes, it's just that there are some people who share it with others and some who don't. The ones who do- well, good for them, you can drown in each other's loneliness- but I'm one of those who doesn't. I don't believe in projecting my emotions to the whole world, except to my closest friends.
I am an international student as well, and I felt the same way in year 1. Sometimes the loneliness got so bad that I used to call up my old friends and cry on the phone. It didn't help that I lived in a single room. Then finally, I started hanging out with the people who would become my closest friends at NUS. Little by little, I opened up to them, and I think it's the best thing I did. You cannot always maintain a strong front for others- let it go!
Since you're an international student, you must be living in a residence. Learn to interact with the people in your cluster. Don't restrict yourself to people only of your own nationality- that's the greatest mistake you can make. Start by interacting with people on your floor, then with your course mates, and finally, CCAs. I place CCAs at the last place because you already said that you don't have much in common with them. Making friends with your floor mates is the best, because you'll have constant companionship throughout the year. Also, problem of eating meals alone solved :)

OP, you're not alone. I lived through this, so can you.  Sure, I do have my lows but you have to stop wallowing in your own self-pity. 
Life is amazing for me now :) and I hope it gets even better for you.

I'm 21, and I'm evergreen. I know it's not a nice feeling to have this void in your heart. Being involved in a one-sided love in Secondary school, I convinced myself to reset my priorities, focusing instead on my studies, hobbies, family and friends.

I know that void is still there, and I still feel it inside. But those years of neglect have totally changed my perspectives on Love. -
 
 To be honest it will be hard for you to try to forge closer friendships with just attending lectures and tutorials. I wasn't used to this too when I was a freshman. Back in JC we had fixed classes like you with the exact same timetable so you'll pretty much be with the same people all day. But in uni it's impossible to be able to do so even for locals. It's not just you who face this problem, everyone else does. My advice would be to join more interest groups like CCAs, head to more events to know more people etc etc. And if you want deeper friendships, you have to make the effort to spend time with people you want to be closer with. (This goes the same for anyone who thinks its hard to find closer friends btw.) Back in the time where you have the same set of friends you can attend all classes together, no effort was necessary for the friendship to develop. It just occurs naturally over time because you are 'forced' to spend time with each other (I dont mean it in a bad way). But over time I realised that every friendship made in uni needs effort and is different from what you/we were used to. Hence, it is not impossible to make closer friends. Don't feel shy to be the one to initiate meetups even just for a simple meal with someone you think could potentially be a good friend.

That being said, try to put down the feeling of needing a year to consider someone a good friend. It's something emotional - you cant put down a value/time period of how long you must know a person for to consider a good friend. I personally have found a couple of close friends and they are not people whom I attend class with every single day (because we have different modules etc). Some of them I have only known them for a few months but they are much closer friends to me than others that I have known for over a year. Moreover, you mentioned that you are a foreign exchange student. If it takes a year for you to start feeling close to someone, wouldnt you have left SG by then?

I hope you find great friends in NUS. I sincerely hope you can have a good time in SG (which includes the meeting people and forging closer bonds) because that is what overseas exchange programmes should be for :)

To all my attached school mates out there, after reading all the confessions about cheating, I just really wanted to say...

Please treasure your other half, and not take him/her for granted. I've been single my whole life, and I've always been envious of the people who have found love. 

I've been in love once before - the feeling was amazing. I felt at peace, I was overflowing with joy, and it felt so good to know what love from the bottom of my heart feels like. I was one of the unlucky ones though; we were not meant to be, and now I'm left wondering if I'll ever find the same kind of love again. 

I've learnt from two failed almost-relationships that the kind of emotional scars left behind are really really painful, whether or not they are intentional. Before you cheat, or do anything against your conscience, please just think about the hurt that you are bringing to the one you love. Think about all the things you love about him/her, think about what made you love him/her in the first place. Think about all the amazing memories the two of you have together, think about all the times he/she was there for you, and think about all the sacrifices you've made to get to where you are now. Think about all the pain and hurt that you will bring to the one you love because of your actions. 

It's not easy to find someone. Once you've found someone to love, please love them with everything that you have. See their imperfections and choose to love them anyway. Remind yourself of just how lucky you are to have found each other, and know that there are many out there who would do anything to have the privilege that you have. Love is a privilege. 

If you don't love your partner enough, please just let him/her go. Everyone deserves to be loved wholeheartedly, and if you can't do that, you don't deserve him/her. 

Be contented and grateful for the one who chose you. Please don't hurt them, they really don't deserve the kind of piercing pain that you'll bring them by cheating. The grass isn't always greener on the other side!

Dear "slutty" girls, 
I put that in quotation cos that's what alot of people might label you as.
You've been through quite a number of men; relationships, one night stands, FWBs, FBs, etc. 
Some of you are ashamed of it. Some of you are very secretive about it. Some of you question your choices. Some of you regret it. Some of you are now over that 'phase' and are now in lasting relationships. And some of you can't even look yourselves in the eyes when you look at a mirror.
I just want to say, it's okay. Everyone has their own definition of morals and principles and values. No one has the right to judge you or your choices but it doesn't mean they won't. Just do what makes you happy, be that way if you want to be. Just be safe about it. 
That being said, you have to make sure there are no major casualties.
Don't hurt anyone on purpose. Don't play with someone's feelings. If you're in it just for the physical intimacy, make sure they know. if you're both in it for a lasting relationship and you genuinely try but it doesn't work out, that's different from you wanting him/her just for the sex while the other party thinks otherwise.
Now, "playboys", the above applies to you too. 
If you want her just for the sex but she won't put out, don't pretend to love her and then leave her after you get what you want. That is where we draw the line in calling you a manslut and a player.
If you're a single man who sleeps around with women, I personally don't think it's fair calling you a player. As long as you're not breaking girls' hearts on purpose, I think you're free to live your life as you wish. Minimum damage though.
And to people in relationships, do define your boundaries with your partner. How open/exclusive your relationship would be is dependent on how you guys as a couple want it to be. 
Is it going to be say...something like you're allowed to get physical with other people but just make sure not to develop feelings? Are you guys allowed to go have erotic massages but just to inform your partner about your activities? Are u guys going to involve a third person into your sexcapades? Or are you guys going to be absolutely exclusively for each other only? Understand and communicate. 
And don't label or judge. 
-sincerely, a member of society

-
 
With all the love confessions going about now, I felt the need to share my story. Before I entered uni, I used to be a RSAF pilot trainee but I was subsequently chopped halfway through because of my poor performance. Back then, I was too young and naive. Instead of studying hard and practising for my sorties, I invested too much time and effort chasing this girl who I had a silly crush on. I would constantly text her day and night and when she took a while to reply, it was as if my body stopped functioning properly and all I wanted at that time was her reply. It was so bad that the night before my flying assessments, I would have sleepless nights, thinking about her throughout the night and I ended up sleeping very little.
 Aviators would know that sufficient rest is extremely important before they engage in a mission and I failed that very rule. Needless to say, my performance began to show and my peers were surprised that my performances had dropped so much. Of course, in such a punishing environment, bad performances never go unnoticed, and I got "chopped" as a result. I shall not say at what stage I got chopped as it is too much of a give-away. It all ended very badly with my crush too, and after some promising progress with her, she just chose to be with another guy soon after. 
After some deep soul searching, I felt so stupid and foolish to abandon such a good opportunity for myself and a childhood dream for unrequited love. I spiralled into a state of mini-depression where several times throughout the day, I would just find a quiet place and cry every time I was reminded of that painful episode. It took almost half a year for me to recover from that episode.
Fast forward to now, I have learnt from that bitter experience and I hope that this story may be helpful to some of you who are in the same situation as me(i.e having a deep crush on someone). Never invest too much effort and feelings into a crush and neglect everything else around you. The only one that will lose out is yourself eventually. Your crush will most likely never appreciate your feelings and even if there are, it is often grossly one-sided. I don't disagree that sometimes the crushes may reciprocate the feelings after a while, but from my own experience, my friends' and reading NUS whispers, I concluded that it is seldom the case. So unless that the other party makes it clear that he/she likes you too and is willing take things to another level, then please never invest so much feelings and effort into someone you like. You may end up losing so much more than you could have imagined. 

-
 
Dear 
I am the author of . I guess this is a problem many high-CAPs face... even though my CAP isn't that great. Many of these people I spoke to choose to avoid useless obligations through several methods. Some by upping Whatsapp privacy and responding slowly on purpose. Some by appearing busy with boy/girlfriend. A simple "sorry i'm out and I don't have access to my school work materials" does it. Or you can do it like how a girl wants to give negative signals to a guy she's uninterested in. Or you could pretend to have family problems, or simply problems with handling your school work. Some even pretend to have low-CAP but usually if people already know you are smart and thus make you their homework whore this wouldn't work...

If you are in Year1/2, I guess you still have quite some time to slowly flush the crap out and still have a shot at genuine friendships. At this stage people still mingle around and, look out to make friends that they will stick with for their remaining years in uni. Or alternatively you could find fellow high-CAP friends. I sound obnoxious for sure but when you observe study groups and cliques along with their estimated CAP, you will realize that they on average follow a certain pattern so I am actually suggesting something very... normal. If you search online for the experiences of others, they say that friendships in uni work like that because the friendship doesn't seem imbalanced. And where projects are concerned, similar CAPed people are more likely to have similar working styles, or at the very least compliment each other better. 

If you are like in your final year... where all the groups and cliques are finalized, I guess you have to resign yourself that you aren't going to be much better off than your current state no matter what you do, not even going ultra social and joining clubs and CCA will help you for reasons I am lazy to elaborate though it should be obvious.... (also touched on in my confession months ago) In my case I'm way past the optimal time so I am paying for it.

There are several aspects or ways to coming out of this not too badly. I personally avoid the confrontational outburst approach, though this is partially because I'm in my final year. I don't claim to know everything, but more of learning from seniors and people who've long graduated.
1. Be more positive about helping people! Simply this. I'm actually thinking of teaching. Am I supposed to demand some form of returns when I help students out?! No DUH? Though I know very well many people do not identify themselves with this kind of naive thinking.... And yes sometimes I feel stupid and angry for helping certain people and being a doormat people who exist to ask me for homework but okay la. live and let live.
2. Develop a good system to helping these people. Good in the sense that when they ask you for help, it's at least relatively effortless. In my case I have a dropbox which many has access to.
3. If networking is something you believe may be important to you, all the more you should at least appear in their "okay" books, instead of burning bridges. I'm being optimistic here; we all know very well many people in uni do keep people they dislike for utility.
4. Force some kind of feedback from people who use your work. At least when you make mistakes and your work doesn't make sense, some of these people may actually ask you about it and you can thus catch the mistake. Works well for graded homework.

So for now while I do feel utterly dumb and angry at myself at times, from a time-effort perspective I'm not performing too badly.... I guess...

They say that your friends may not always be there for you, but your family will. Sometimes when I feel frustrated and need to talk to someone, other than my friends, I find that I have no one else to talk to.

It doesn't help that I can't express my feelings well and always put up a strong front when I am just a mess inside. To make matters worse, I am staying on campus and since I only see my parents about once a week, I feel like it's straining my relationship with them.

Things were well and blissful for us as he is possibly the sweetest guy ever and I felt like he would be the one. 

Fast forward a year later.  I'm starting to get a little bored of being stuck with one guy. Sometimes I despise myself, but I wonder if I am the sort who can't be faithful or it just means I'm not sufficiently in love with my boyfriend.

For the fear of disappointing him,  I have not dared to speak of the past either.   I have tried to drop hints that I'm perhaps not all that good as he thinks I am,  but he trusts me too much,  too much for his own good. 

I feel that I may one day cause him a lot of hurt but at the same time I am am selfish and reluctant to give him up.   

To him: I am sorry and hope that if things don't work out between us some day,  you will find the good girl you have been looking for.

We have been together for almost two years. We spent almost a year overseas and were happy to have each other's as companions. Things were perfect. 
But everything took a turn for the worse once we returned to Singapore. We began to spend little time together because she was always busy with school and her personal life. In those little time when we were out together, we almost never held hands because she didn't want us to be seen by people she knew because we didn't share the same religious faith. We were falling apart. She got to know a guy in her faculty and begun to spend more time with him. Often flirting with him on chats and meeting up with him for late night chats, drinks and movies. I was kept in the dark about this until I chanced upon her chat history. I was heartbroken, and I realized I couldn't do anything about it as I was the one that couldn't let her go. She was okay to end everything. I was worth nothing to her. 
I forgave her and tried to woo her back again although it was her that cheated. Finding ways to spend more time with her, making my schedule fit her's often jeopardizing my own plans. 
She started working and got really busy. We hardly communicated, my messages to her were often seen and not replied after many hours later. We met once every two weeks for a meal together on average. I was always the one that have to reshuffle my schedule to fit hers as I was more desperate to spend more time with her. I was almost like her back-up plans. 
All these times I was hoping that she could change and that she could understand that it was about the lack of effort on her part rather than the lack of time. 
Finally, I took the decision to end us. She accepted it readily which doesn't surprise me because I knew I wasn't anything to her anymore. 
In a relationship, parties constantly change and make adjustments for each other because there's a threat that the other person will leave or end the relationship. When one party no longer view the importance of the other party, that's when the relationship will start to fail as no effort will be made to make adjustments. 
To those who made it to the end of my confession, I would like to say a big thank you. I'm looking for a channel to release this as I am struggling to move on from this after three month as I can't forget her.

This hall vs. no hall thing... *facepalm*

If you chose to have a more active social life and a more vibrant NUS life, good for you! Do whatever you want. However, when it comes down to project work, you jolly well do your part as a team mate should, because you're ultimately still a student in NUS. Don't bring the entire ship (your team) down.

If you chose to be less social, or just prefer to go home everyday after school, that's cool. You may have things you need to attend to. Maybe school is something draining to you. Just make sure that, at the end of your 4 years, you don't regret not doing anything much socially, because these 4 years may very well be the last 4 years of studies where you could've done anything you wanted.

I respect whatever anyone does, because it's really none of my business. What is an issue though is when what you do is causing grief/problems to others or yourself. So don't be that kind of person, okay? :)

I can relate a lot to the recent bullying incident... bullies were part and parcel of my life in sec school and jc, and I had to live with it with no one to help me. Physical abuse (punching) and verbal abuse (making fun of my appearance) was pretty common. It gave me a lot of self-esteem issues growing up and I hated every single one of my bullies, which funnily enough also included some of my teachers, who were the supposed "caretakers" but still used their position to mock me all the same. But it also ignited a fire in me to change, and when I moved on to army and uni I grew out of my nerdy persona and surrounded myself with nicer friends. Looking back now I feel like I've become a better person because of it, because I understand what it means to have suffered. I want to encourage the bullied ones to stand up to the bullies - not in the confrontational way - but rather to channel that anger in you to improve yourself, to make sure you become better than the bullies who mocked you. When there's a will there's a way, you should know it better than anyone else. We all know that asking for help doesn't work, so you can only help yourself. 

Also to all the bullies out there, I don't believe in all the bullshit excuses about how you have changed, or how you have moved on for the better. A rotten egg will forever remain rotten, and I really hope that you guys spend the rest of your life attempting and failing to atone for your sins. I will never understand why you guys exist, or why you would chose to bully someone who has done absolutely nothing to you. But do note that if I ever meet any of you in real life, I will do everything in my power to make your life miserable. And to all my bullies. If I ever get the chance, rest assure that I will personally make sure you guys suffer for what you did.

I thought I would probably never fall in love. I was never so wrong. It wasn't really love at first sight cos I don't believe in it and more often than not, it's just infatuation. All this time, my close friends always called me handsome and I often had to correct them that I wasn't. This was because I was F--KING handsome. But jokes aside, none of the girls actually approached me maybe bcos I was a bit playful and they probably thought I wasn't in their league whereas I thought the same about them.

This all changed one rainy afternoon. She came into the classroom quietly, and gently closed the door while adjusting her spectacles. She was drenched from head to toe. All eyes in the classroom were at her and I knew she was shy bcos she quickly lowered her gaze and in quick steps put her bag down and went out to the washroom to dry her hair. She was cute, especially her eyes, and I felt my heart skipped a beat. Now it always happened whenever I saw an attractive face so I didn't pay much attention. When she returned, she sat in the second row, two rows infront of me and my friends. A while later, two of her friends also came in together with a guy. I thought she must have been attached, given her looks, but it wasn't true. 

There were 10 minutes to class so I decided to get to know her. I used an old trick from the book and dropped my wallet right next to her table while pretending to go outside of class. It failed miserably bcos she was focused on talking to her friends. I picked it myself and banged my head on her table purposely to get her attention. She was the only one concerned with her other three friends staring at me skeptically. She then spoke with her angelic voice to ask if I was alright and almost put her hand on my head before putting it away embarrassingly. With my best acting I acted as if I had hurt myself badly and stumbled a bit on the way out, giggling to myself. Right after about a minute, I went back in and apologized if I had accidentally hurt her. She reassured me and asked me if I was feeling okay. 

The class ended in an hour and half. I had forgotten about the incident earlier on when she reminded me again by asking me if I was indeed okay. I then acted again to gain more sympathy from her. She even offered me to go see NUH together with her. Not wanting to further lie to her, I told her I wasn't really hurt and also got her name at the same time. We exchanged numbers on the basis of being classmates and became friends on facebook. 

Slowly, we became closer with me asking her out a few weeks later. She was a little gullible at times but her shyness and awkwardness just attracted me towards her. We became very steady when I gave my first kiss to her on our 8th month together. Took me a long time to get intimate with her since she was felt I wasn't really serious but I got my act together and melted her heart with over the time we spent together. We graduated together and then eventually got married. 

Look at the recent turn of events, she got diagnosed with Stargardt's Disease and doctors say it will lead to blindness. Initially I wasn't even sure what the f--k that meant and went to research about it. Her vision has started to deteriorate at a very fast rate. I still love her as much but I am really worried about how it's gonna turn out. Sometimes you see these kind of stories in books, movies and fiction and believe that they will never happen to you. And when they do, you are in complete disbelief on what to do next. I will not leave her side and hopefully I can get some strength to carry in my next phase of life.

Let me end with a quote:

Our love was on an accelerated programme. We plunged so deeply in love we forgot to pace ourselves. We became reliant, we forgot what it was like to be independent. We always had each other, and that was enough.

But life continued to happen around the bubble we confined ourselves in. School demanded our attention, our friends and family wanted a piece of us, yet we prioritised each other above any other things in life. We meant the world to each other. We relied on each other. Eventually we became responsible for each others rights and wrongs. 

Exhaustion kicked in. We chose to take the shortcut - to blame each other on life's misfortunes and unfairness because it was convenient. All of a sudden I wasn't good enough for you. I became a burden. 

We tried really hard to fill up the cracks that were splitting not just us, but our hearts apart. One step forward, two steps back. We kept going back to the same problems, to our old ways. We exhausted all means to help each other. We fought about anything under the sun. And none of them make sense at this point. But we never truly got over any of them.

The good times used to compensate for the downs. But at this point I am beyond exhausted. I had never once given up, but held on when an old problem arise. But I now question if it's still worthwhile.

This is a post for someone who will never read or know that this is for him. Just need to let this all out.

I have no dating experience, or what people would call evergreen. But I've tried and took the initiative in going after a guy before, and it was a really painful process. To be worrying aimlessly everyday, to have a person constantly on your mind every sleepless nights. My feelings were not reciprocated and I took half a year to let it go. Finally I felt free, I feel happy and emotionally strong. I got my interests back and I got to live life the way I did before I met the guy. Everything was good until I met another guy. Damn it every ounce of confidence vanished the moment I fall into this endless trap again. However independent/emotionally strong a woman is, she will turn foolish in front of love. 

I do not want to try anymore, because I do not want to get the same pain I got back then. It was an unpleasant process I wish I would never have to go through again. I know there are bound to be failures in life and not everything will go the way you like it. But I can't help but to feel weak and timid in front of this. Would everything better if we just stayed as friends and take everything naturally? Or would it be better for me to go for it again. Sometimes I wish I will never have to like anyone.

Overseas student reading NUS whispers here: 
Half of the posts seem to be about guys/girls too afraid to talk to the opposite sex, or wondering whether they're in the friendzone or not, or wondering whether some other guy/girl likes them. What good could this possibly do?

The answer to all your questions is the same: 
Show confidence, take a dive, make conversation, put yourself out there. If you think you can't do it, just try. The more you do it the better you will get. Who do you think they would prefer: a nervous, shy, unconfident person confessing their love behind a computer? Or somebody who is outgoing, risk-taking, funny, upfront and honest?

C, i dont see you around much in hall, but thanks for not ignoring me :) since im no longer in the OG i dont keep up with what yall are doing, but i hope everything is well with yall.

Just needed a place to rant and have never posted anything here before so just thought I'd give it a shot. I'm someone that puts others before myself and have often found myself taking up the role of the 'responsible' one in various groups of friends. In my hall I've been a block head, helped set up various volunteer programs, been active in sports, play a few instruments in a music group and actively contribute in any and all communities I'm apart of. In my major, I also often take up leadership roles in project groups and consider myself a very dependable person. I'm a pretty warm, friendly and funny guy so I always try to brighten the mood in tense situations in various committees and stress-filled conditions. 

I used to think that these values and traits mattered to people. Lately though I've been feeling like shit. I've been seeing some close friends pay more attention to others, or actively just show more care and concern for them. This girl I got pretty close to started pulling away and I don't know, sometimes I feel that I am no one's priority. Given the fact that I'm always going around checking up on how people are doing and encouraging them, I might have given the impression that I'm pretty solid i.e. emotionally stable. Maybe that's why people don't seem to ask or care as much for me. I'm especially hurt because my close friends are aware of the various family problems I have at home. Maybe they don't understand how tough a struggle it is for me. 

I'm trying to be a better person by giving without expecting anything in return. I'm trying to be the person I know I can be. One free of insecurities and someone whom others can rely on. I eventually want to go into social services because helping others is a deep passion and my calling in life. So I extend this to my friends and the people I care about. When I actively ask about people and they open up I realize that these interactions do help them out in some small degree. I even am able to give advice at times given my familiarity with family conflict, relationship issues etc. Sigh I don't even know what I want or why I'm feeling like this. Just wish that given all I've done for others, that there'd be some who are willing to do the same for me. But I know I'll press on because when we help others, we don't do it for praise, recognition or even reciprocation (going against social exchange theory here). So here's a shout out to the under-appreciated out there. The unsung heroes who go about making other people's lives better in their own small way even when no one takes notice or appreciates it. Here's to you guys. May we all find happiness and peace eventually.

To , amidst the waves of criticisms, I want to chime in to say that I think you will be fine. Just pretend to accept your parents' train of thought but know that you are more than what these doctrines dictate. After all I think it's difficult to change how our parents think about these things. Easier to just pretend. Many of my friends with religious families still continue to enjoy fantastic sex lives discretely. Could be more exciting to pretend to be virginal and hide under the radar heh. ;)

About healthy. I think as long as you can protect yourself and know what you are doing you will be fine. The danger of having multiple fwbs is not just physical stds but also the possibility of being numb to the spiritual intimacy that sex could bring. The good thing about it though is that it stops you from being emotionally attached to one person. Being emotionally attached to the fwb is really some masochistic shit you do not wanna be near. 

Lastly, do consider what you want. Are you doing it for the liberation that comes with not abidding by religious doctrines? Are you doing it because you are getting back at your parents? Or are you doing it because it brings true happiness? Because it would really suck if sex becomes a means to an end rather than a glorious end (pun intended) itself. 

Love, 

A once super sexually active and (but still) kinky, long time female masochist.

There were 4 of us. 
1 is a gambling addict and is always complaining why his girlfriend doesn't give him sex or perform any sexual acts with him. On his birthday, she secretly invited all of us for a surprise party and even worked part-time to buy him a ps4. And she's an awesome cook. (I miss her food) Then he dumped her because she wasn't willing to have sex with him. 

Another one is a vulgar ass who treats his girlfriend like shit. "Aiyo... i saw every part of your body already, what's left to hide?" 
"I'm just gonna take my time and enjoy every part of your body in my room later." Right in front of us (clique). I feel embarrassed enough already, can't imagine how did his girlfriend felt. She is a very humble and hardworking person as circumstances dictate, she met this jerk at her part-time job and is very impressionable. During the last few weeks of our friendship, he shared with me that he's planning to cheat on her by wooing another lady, tossing his gf away like a piece of trash.

The last one is a controlling whiny self-entitled bitch who wants every gatherings, meals, orders to go her way. And she disrespect every other opinions and is always condescending towards others.

I'm glad I am done with these toxic people. I don't even like them that much. At the same time, they should be happy that I did all of them a favour; they got rid of one nonchalant acquaintance who seriously doesn't care about them any longer.

Since someone has started the ball rolling about friendship problems, I will share mine too.

I am a girl and I met a really likeminded guy friend last semester. We hit it off right away and had alot of things in common. I would like to emphasize that we do not have any forms of romantic attachment for one another. Everything is purely platonic, like bros.

Lately, he has found a girlfriend and his girlfriend turns out to be one of my friends. I felt really happy for both of them because they look really sweet together!

BUT whenever I hang out with that guy friend, his girlfriend would join along and honestly, I felt like a lightbulb. I'm not sure if I am thinking too much or what, but everytime when we talked about inside jokes or things that his girlfriend doesn't know, his girlfriend would toss a distasteful glance at us. I felt really uncomfortable about it but I didn't want to tell my friend about it because it would appear as though I'm trying to sow discord between them.

As times go by, his girlfriend wouldn't even bother to conceal her discontentment. There was one occassion when my friend and I started stalking each other's Facebook, in hopes of finding unglam photos of one another so that we can "shame" each other with silly captions. As I was scrolling through my friend's photo album, his girlfriend turned and whispered to me, "Can you stop stalking him please?" It was not a weak plea, but a firm order despite the softness of her voice.

After that, I made a decision to break off all ties with my friend. It was a painful decision to make because it wasn't easy to meet a friend that understands me well. That friend seemed to have noticed that I've started to isolate myself from his life. So he started texting me and tried hard to talk to me to revive our friendship. It bugged me alot and I told him the reason behind my cold treatment towards him. I felt really bad because it's like I'm badmouthing about his girlfriend. He said that he understands where I'm coming from but he don't see it as a problem because he believed that his girlfriend wouldn't mind us hanging out together.

Agh. So what now? Am I supposed to hang out with him privately or to hang out with him and his girlfriend or to just cut off all ties?

Let me open up a little of the world that we depressed people live in. Some days we are accomplishing stuff, singing and laughing, and on other days you don't see us at all. That's when we are depressed. No reasons, no advice needed. 

For me, depression started with some family problems and tragedy ( I would not state what the problems are to remain anonymous) and few people actually know that I am depressed for many years. My family shuns depression like a disease and I caught that quickly when I saw that they are really worried about me. I'm the happy-go-lucky kid in front of them but behind I'm sad, lonely and tired. 

There are times when I binge-eat to satisfy my cravings and kill the hurt. There are also times that I skipped meal and let the melancholy sink in until I'm tired enough to sleep. Then there are times which I could do all my work at one go and other times I just stare into blank space and wonder about my life. Not to forget, sometimes I cry before I sleep or wake up crying from a nightmare.

For people without depression, it is hard to understand us I know. But do let us feel we can share our problems with you and you would not feel worried or think we have gone insane. We will avoid sharing if it hurts others. And also, do understand that we are not seeking your advice, we don't need your rant to teach us how to make life better for ourselves, we already knew. What we need is just your listening ear.

-
 
Hey NUSWhispers, OP of  here.

Some of you already know who I am, and thanks for the messages. My point of writing my parent's story was not to make you go "ahhh wow that exists.", or to trigger a sort of treasure hunt to find out who that person is. But more of letting you know that there isn't such a thing as a perfect love story, where every day you run through empty fields and watch sunsets together. It was 35 years long but it was tough and there were extreme ups and extreme downs. I'm sure all of you know that's normal for a relationship, even more for longer relationships, and yet more so when it turns into marriage and all the in-laws and children get involved.

I started off by telling you how different my parents are. And this difference has remained through all these years. Both are stubborn and have their own ways of doing things, but they always kept it balance - a mixture of compromises and one-way-give-ins. For as long as I can remember, I watched their relationship grow: from how they were so loving, till when I started schooling and they had differences in how I should be brought up, to them arguing and fighting, to be on the verge of divorce several times, to clear walk-outs on the house but eventually coming back. Those were tough days but it helped mould my idea of how relationships work. It was about overcoming adversity together, even if at times it felt like either sides were adversity. 

It instilled in me the idea that any two persons COULD be together, no matter how different they may be (um, I'm still trying to find someone who believes in that, though), and it was all down to how much both parties wanted it to work. Of course, it's easy to give up at small disagreements, big disagreements. As long as you've subconsciously given up, it's over. And no matter how much the other party pleads and changes, it'll never work out anymore.

Before I get too ranty/naggy, I just want to reiterate my main points, that is:

1) No matter which 2 people are in a relationship, it's not so much of the character or characteristics that determine whether the relationship lasts. It's down to your level of commitment and your willingness to ride out the tough times to strengthen your relationships.

2) No matter how small or big an obstacle is, always have the end-point in mind, that is ultimately marriage with children, or whatever your end-point is, and work towards that. If you keep thinking "Ah this won't work out", or "Wow, can't imagine living with that for the next 50 years" then yeah, it won't work out and you won't live with that for the next 50 years.

3) Find out what works for you both. Whether it's to compromise, or to give in when necessary. But never ever push people beyond their morals and values. No matter how badly my parents fought and insisted on their way of doing things, they never forced each other to compromise on something they truly believed in. And I think that makes a big difference.

Peace out, guys.

I'm the OP of .
hmm, I think I know how you feel. Especially, my replacement is a guy from my own clique. I don't dislike him for replacing me. I just don't like how she kept shoving their close friendship in front of my face. I wouldn't recommend you to ignore him so that he will supposedly pay more attention to you, like your friends did. Because most of the time, it doesn't turn out to be the way we wanted. Most likely he'll just move on with his new friend, and you'll be just as bitter as before because you can't get over the fact that he gave up on the friendship. Time might reduce the frequency you think about this friendship that you once had, but you wouldn't be actually 'liberated' I think.
Like I said before, perhaps you might want to face the friendship with less expectation like I did and focus more on other friendships that you've already been working on. You can try to have an extended friendship that includes the girl too. 
Occasionally, I do feel down that things weren't the same as before. But I usually brush them aside because I think that it's better to look forward than reminisce about the past that we can't go back to.
What I understand is that, nobody likes to be with a negative person. Sometimes, you just gotta act normal and be cheerful.
But if by any chance, your feelings towards him is more than platonic, I suggest you move on from this friendship.

With quite a number of posts on how guys ask the girls out for dates or even tried to hint their love interests that the 'dinner/meal' together is in fact a date, it truly made me wondered if  our generation sometimes viewed things in an overly complex manner. Look... if you tried talking to people from the older generations (our parents or grandparents), you will probably realise things back then were more straight forward: Interested means interested, wanna ask someone out for a date? just ask. got rejected from the girl/guy? move on or continue to do the chasing. Maybe life in those days seemed to be less complicated than today? I'm not sure if you guys would disagree with what I just mentioned (it doesn't matter to me anyway), but I believe we will be happier if we can do things in a simpler way.

To 

I can understand how you're feeling. I went through a similar situation and it's hard for people to understand because it's not common for two people of different genders to be very very close without being romantically or sexually involved with each other.

I had a male best friend too. (I am a girl.) I would go so far as to say I loved him, in a platonic/ familial way. I think he cared for me too, in his own way.

It took several years before he was able to trust me with real emotional intimacy and (I'm crying a little as I'm typing this) maybe I was scared or maybe I was tired and it was too little, too late, or maybe it was something else but soon after he shared his deep vulnerabilities with me, I told him we couldn't be friends anymore. It broke his heart. It broke my heart.

I can't remember now why I thought it was more important for us to stop being friends. I can't remember what exactly happened. All I remember is the pain and anger I felt. I sometimes wonder what he'd think of my current boyfriend, (my friend didn't like many of the guys I dated) and my new friends, my new job, etc. We were very close like brother and sister.

I have not heard from him since then though I've tried to speak to him several times and I saw him on my campus before (we study at two different NUS campuses). I wanted to say I was sorry in person and hope he is doing well, but when I went back, he was gone. Maybe he wanted to hide from me, because his friends were still there.

I think my heart is still a little bit broken. It has been four years.

OP, I hope you are able to get through to your friend. Perhaps you can accept him being closer to someone else, but still remain close friends with him and not expect as much out of him. I would prefer my friend to just be an acquaintance now that I only talk to once in a while than an elusive shadow I can't ever talk to.

I tell myself he is in a better place without me, as I am without him, but it still hurts. So goddamned much.

 hey, I have about the same friendship issue with an opposite sex recently too. I did get really unhappy for 1-2 month because our friendship has been a decade long. I started to play more emphasis on my other groups of friends instead of trying to force a friendship to work. Imo, friendship should make you happy. While its true that you do have to make an effort for it to work, you shouldn't be constantly vying for his attention. If he asks you out, then just go out with him, but don't expect anything from the friendship. If it works out, it'll be great. If it doesn't, then perhaps the friendship isn't worth your constant investment. In your case, you can make the first move and ask him out again since you've been dao-ing him for months. You'll be happier if you have less expectations and perhaps you'll find new friends or discover friends that you've neglected in the past that are willing to make an effort to maintain their friendship with you.(:

Same for another girl friend whom I thought I was closer, but I brought them tgt(as friends), they became much closer than I am to her. I know its unhealthy to keep comparing, but I am not saying I want to reach his level or wad, but I’m just wishing for a group of friends.  And this self-esteem thing is holding me back I think. Is it really practice makes perfect? That I have to keep on trying to do all these stuff in order to become better at that? Like, I think I sucks at texting, so I just keep texting my girl friends and practicing my skills?

And I realize I cant hold up a good conversation like a man too. Looking at other people while they chatted, they were laughing and also at the same time having a meaningful conversation. To OP don't worry, take small steps each day, you will get better in your socializing skills. Please don't overdo it, you will lose you true self.

As time passes, people will change, your personality, behavior will also change with time. When I was young, I used to be very good at socializing, I know everyone from my cohort, even my siblings' close friends, with friends I even got punished for being a chatterbox. But when I was in secondary school, I only speak to people whom I am closed to. 

OP, practise texting your girl friends is a good idea but before you start doing that do sufficient research to make sure that you are not talking too much to an attached girl. If you want to practice face to face, here's some conversation topics: daily activities, hobbies, weather? , school work, news, gossips? :p if you are close to the other party you can ask about their family, their future, etc. 

Hope it helps!

To .. Here's some advice from someone who started masturbation at the age of 12 and have been doing it multiple times daily. While I don't know if it has any effect on health or fertility, it could affect you in other negative ways. 

This may just be from my own experience but after awhile, around the age of 16, I began to get less sensitive (read up on ED) and couldn't get satisfied with just the normal routines. It causes us to view women as objects rather than people. I began to search for more heinous stuff to jerk off to and I finally reached the lowest point when I looked up CP. 

At the same time, I noticed that over the years, my self esteem and social skills have deteriorated (especially with girls). I was once a cheerful and active kid with many friends but nowadays I spend most of the time alone and depressed. The last time I spoke to a girl longer than 5 minutes was back in jc 2 years ago... With my project work team. 

The stuff above could or could not happen to you but my suggestion is that you try to kick the habit. I have been trying to quit for two months now and have been successful for 2-3 weeks at a time before relapsing. I realised that it usually happens when I'm bored and alone so I suggest you find activities to fill up your day and try to be around others to get your mind off it. 

The first few days/weeks will be the hardest but I believe it is for the best for our own improvement... Hopefully one day I can revert back to my old self :'(

But please people, if you already know it is a group outing, do not bring your so along. There's a time and place for everything and leave your dates to the one on ones. Do not even bother asking for "permission" because honestly, no one is as thick skin as you to tell you for fear of ruining the friendship, but it doesn't mean they like your self-initiative to bring your so along for every single group outing. So please, unless you want to appear like an insensitive douche, do not ask buay zi dong questions.

-
 
Don't feel sorry for not being able to hold on to your loved ones. It's hard when they're all you think about. It get worse when you realise you won't be sending each other texts as often, calling each other and having carefree conversations like you used to. Everything the two of you once had is now gone. 

It's tough to accept it. Nights spent crying and thinking how you could have done things differently. Train/bus rides home listening to your music when suddenly a wave of emotions comes crashing back. Trying to see how they're doing and how they're moving on by stalking their social media accounts twice a day. 

Future may seem bleak, you'll definitely feel lost, but one day you'll be over it and one day you'll be glad and relieved to know that you're no longer held on by all these emotional baggage. 

You are never alone. Hopefully they'll be people who like this post in support of this and realise that countless of people are facing the same problems just as you are.

The only thing is, good listener is not always a good speaker. I will never ever share my story with them.

I still don't know why I want share it here but just want to rant I think

Day: Dad kisses my cheek saying "Have fun in school!" Mom makes me breakfast & sometimes pack my lunch (Don't judge me, I still bring lunch to school okay, mom's cooking is the best!) 

Night: Dad takes out his belt, while saying " I told you not to hang out with XXX/YYY/ZZZ! Make u not focusing on study! Delay ur graduation also! Faster work!" Mom just watches me while drinking her favorite beer. Or sometimes sleeping pills. (Lucky no gambling problems)
Red/blue black, pain, scars everywhere. Lucky they're hidden under my clothes. :)

Lucky I don't have any siblings. If not I can't imagine them going thru same experience.

Seems my family is the best representative of family in drama/manga/ series . Happy family outside, inside.... oh well.

I used to think that it's normal to have this kind of family. It was only when I was in JC then I realized that my family is an odd one, different from other families. 

I really don't know why I'm sharing this now and in this platform. Just bored and tired I guess... Too tired to run, but still want to run from this reality.

To  OP:
I am an alumni. Uni life was lonely for me too. I entered a course without any friends, and struggled through a major I didn't like. There were times when I cried thinking how life was unfair. But I sucked it up and decided to push on regardless. After all, getting the cert only benefits me, and will be stuck with me for life. So might as well put in my best.

Fast forward to the present, I am working now, have lost a loved one, and have to deal with workplace politics. How life can be unfair is magnified multifolds. Nice ppl are shoved to one side. Everyone is selfish, including me. Yet I chide myself everytime Others exhibit that character towards me, thinking that everything is my fault. Even though I am friendly towards my colleagues, the workplace competition is so intense that one cannot have a true friend to confide in. There are many days whereby I feel down, yet am compelled to keep up with appearances. Loneliness has never been more apparent in a place whereby you think you have friends, when all you have are enemies. Work life has put a toll on me, and I have lost touch with a majority of them. I barely have a handful of friends left. And everytime they ask about how I am doing, my reply has always been negative. I am forever complaining.  

Someone once told me that "everywhere you go is the same: same s**t, different pot". Though I am not the best person to advise you on how to live your life, I know that losing a close family member makes you question about the meaning of life, when the person you've been living for, striving to do your best for, is gone. Everything just seems trivial that you just don't care anymore.

I have an inferiority complex too. I purposely chose to wear oversized clothes to hide my unsightly body, and often get remarks on my bad dress sense and how my clothes are so baggy. These comments obviously make me feel even more inferior about myself. But I know that I am not dressing to attract the opposite sex, so it doesn't matter how I dress.

So I understand how you feel, but in a slightly different context. I dread every working day and go to work thinking "FML". But I do what I can to get by emotionally, hoping and praying that I can go to the place my dearly departed has gone, soon.

If you're that bored, go find something else to do or at least not an attached person to play with.

-
 
So basically I recently got rejected by my crush and I learnt many lessons from this episode and I would like to share it here. 

The notion of love
The greatest change that happened after this episode was the way I saw love. I was too young, naive, idealistic. I thought he was 'the one', and somehow everything would eventually fall into place and he would be mine. After all, he checked all my boxes and there can never be anyone more perfect than him. Now the heavens would create the perfect environment for him to magically realise that he loved me as much as I loved him. It was the perfect fairytale. However, evidently this wasn't the case considering that he is now happily in love - just not with me, but a random girl he met in SEP. I realise now that love is a construct, and he can only be 'the one' AFTER all the stars have aligned and the feelings were mutual. Just like how he probably thinks that she is 'the one', because the stars have aligned for them with the perfect opportunities to get close, the right environment, the same bouts of homesickness. Just like how it doesn't matter how much I sacrificed for him - joining year-long committees I didn't like so I could get another sentence of conversation with him, replacing my own hobbies with his, texting him into late at night while he was at SEP just because he briefly mentioned that he felt a little disengaged from his life back in SG although I was dead tired from weeks of camp preparation; he decided to choose the other girl whom he enjoyed his weeks of SEP with. This brings me to my next point: the loss of the sense of self.

With all these sacrifices, I unknowingly fell into an abyss of self-denial to the point that I lost myself. I didn't engage in the activities I loved anymore; no more ball games, going to museums, reading non-fiction, discussing politics because he just wasn't as interested in them as I was. Instead, I spent my time listening to mainstream pop, watching concerts, joining high-profile CCAs so as to mimic his likes and interests in the hope that he would notice me more or just spend 5 more seconds in conversation with me. After the rejection, my friends urged me to take up activities that used to like. I was doubtful that I actually liked them anymore after 1 year of pretending to like what he liked but I went anyway. And I felt joy, unparalleled joy. It was the joy of finding myself after a year of self-denial and trust me, you would have never appreciated the idea of your individual identity  so much if he haven't lost it before. 

In conclusion, I now feel that people should never sacrifice so much effort, time, and most importantly your sense of self for someone that might not see it, or have seen it but still proceeds to choose someone else anyway. I do not mean that everyone should be selfish and not chase for what you desire, but be wise on the amount of sacrifice you give for a person, or you might end up being hurt as deeply as I have.

-
 
So many relationship posts, I figured I could try and give some advice from experience. 
I used to have a crush on a guy in my class back in high school, after three months of secretly liking him I couldn't stand it anymore and straight out confessed. He didn't like me, but being a gr8 guy he was still willing to continue being my friend, even with my stubborn feelings for him.

 So, 1) if you really wanna burst with your feelings for someone, tell them. Pent up feelings are never fun. Even if things get awkward after a while,  try to keep up a (non-despo)  conversation, sooner or later the awkwardness will disappear. 

Don't even talk about being in the friend zone. Hell, you should be glad that you're still friends, if you truly "care about the friendship" rather than trying to get into their pants. If you even start to think about that, take a step back and question your motives about starting a friendship in the first place

Fast forward 2 years of unrequited crush that WONT GO AWAY he started to like me too, and we carefully ventured out into a relationship with each other. 

2)a relationship means being independent together. Learn how to be alone without constantly spamming your crush with messages and expecting a reply. Learn how to spend time alone. It's not a easy thing, but it is so important to be independent, because a rs should not be you relying on someone else to be complete. 

Because I grew a habit to rant to him about my feelings, our disagreements don't usually have a chance to fester into something huge and gross, and we make it a point to meet up every week, especially during the weekends when he books out of camp. 

3)TALK TO EACH OTHER. Communication is so, so important in a rs, and messages aren't enough to convey feelings. If you can call, call. If you can meet up, plan a date. It doesn't have to take up an entire day, just an hour for dinner and enjoying each other's company is enough. Talk out problems face to face. Don't hide your discomforts. But this doesn't mean to blow up at each other JFC, discuss. Nicely. Try to agree on a middle ground if the problem seems to  affect the rs. Remember that you will be one of the greatest support pillars for your so. Act like it. Relationships are never smooth sailing, don't even try to pretend it is. Take challenges as they come together, work through it as a couple. There are so many ways it can go wrong, but as long as you are willing to fight for that one path of happiness, it'll work out. 

And holy shit don't say that "your partner doesn't deserve you, they are much better than you". Don't. By saying that, you are putting your partner on a pedestal, and it's not healthy. You both have flaws, and if you think you are lacking, work to make up for it instead of pushing your partner away when they really want to help you. Grow as a person, and grow together. 
(ps if you think your partner isn't good enough for you, you are a horrible person. Stop it) 

Sorry for the long post, but I hope it helps

-
 
I'm not really sure why so many OPs here think that "awkwardness" is something that should be abhorrently avoided, especially in terms of "I don't want to spoil our friendship/make things awkward so how do I confess/turn down their confession". 

To put it most blandly, things are going to get awkward as soon as one party wants something more than the other party wants. As much as everybody wants everybody to get along, the reality is that once this sort of situation occurs, it's unavoidable that someone is going to get hurt.

If you somehow do manage to maintain the status quo by not doing anything, then all this leads to is to increasing stress on at least one of the persons involved even if you yourself are very happy with the current status of your relationships.

So, why try to preserve the status quo in the interests of "avoiding awkwardness" when doing so is just basically moral self-indulgence for prolonging the pain of one or more parties involved?
-

Hi! I refer to ! This is a post to all those 'good guys' who want to become 'bad' because they think that's the way to win a girl's heart. I am a girl who has been through what your friend has been through and I really want to advice you to the following: If you become like one of those guys, sure, and i can guarantee you, you'll get a lot more girls chasing after you! But what kind of girls do you want to date? girls that can take care of themselves, or girls that can't? The reason why these girls accept shit from guys, is because they don't know how to love themselves and put themselves first. they think that love is constantly making excuses for the guy when they have done something wrong, thinking that doing such a thing makes them 'nice' and 'patient' and 'tolerant' 'for love'. the truth is, these girls are insecure about themselves, and think that having someone else's love and attention can fill up this void in their heart which should come from their own self-worth. There are many girls like that and I have been through it too. Hence, if the girl you are looking for fits the above description, go for it, but I think you know that the girl you want is someone that can really love you right, that you can love right as well. After all, these girls will grow and mature, learning to love themselves and wouldn't want to date guys like that anymore... that is if they have learnt their lesson. They will know what they want and not want when looking for love, especially when they're finding a long term partner. They will look for a nice guy who can support her, appreciate her for who she is and make her happy. Not someone who takes her for granted. -
 
I fell in love with a girl. The most perfect girl. Sure, she has her flaws but so do I. Unfortunately, my flaws were too big to ignore, as much as I struggled to fix them, I was too late, and she left me. I was selfish and self-absorbed and I should have doted on her and loved her and cherished her more. I failed to grasp how attention-seeking I appeared, and how these selfish acts had shaken her faith in me over time.

She was my first love, so perhaps that's why the loss cut me so deeply. Every day I lose myself in pointless indulgences, and every night my mind drifts back to happier days, and what could have been. I was even suicidal for a period of time. How pathetic, isn't it!

I can feel myself slowly recovering, getting better as I learn to appreciate the small things again. The warmth of the morning sun, the comfort as I ease my fatigued body onto my bed after a long day of work (i.e. the distraction from my pain) and I feel the recurring thoughts bleed away into slumber. But I am afraid that a part of me is destroyed for good; I can never be as happy as I once was, I can never bring myself to love again. I am afraid that some day I will just give up on holding out, that I have been deluding myself that I would get better.

Seeking help is pointless. There is no point telling my friends or family this because I do not believe that it will help. I do not need their help. I'm just using this as an avenue.

I would never wish this sort of pain onto anyone, and so I hope this serves as a warning not to take your loved ones for granted.

M.

I still remember the first time we met at our first tutorial class. I was sitting down there hoping that my guy friend beside me would just stop talking, because I found the conversation boring and getting nowhere. Suddenly, the tutorial room door opened and there you walked in. Our eyes met briefly and I smiled at you as the much-awaited silence finally came. I said hi to you as I saw your eyes checking me out quickly for just that split second, before you smiled back and sat at the last row of the room. 

I admit that you were just an average guy based on looks. But I felt there was something different about you from the other guys I know, something which attracted me to you after that first encounter. I tried getting to know you better for the next few weeks since then, and I am glad I did. Perhaps you didn't realise how much effort I have put in just to be able to sit next to you in tutorials and also in the LT, even though it meant sitting away from my friends who often wondered where I went and I had to look around the LT just to see where you were, until we finally exchanged phone numbers and added each other on Facebook. It was also a blessing in disguise that you took this module alone.

We have gone out and hang out so many times together since then, and as time passed it became obvious to me that you are a keeper. I know you know I like you, and I know you have the hots for me too. You were shocked when you found out I was still single and I haven't had a boyfriend before, and you asked why. I told you I wasn't ready to date anyone seriously yet, and you didn't seem convinced although you were amused and assumed I must be having a hard time fending off suitors because you said I'm pretty and hot in your eyes. You have no idea how many butterflies I had inside my stomach when you said that, and how happy and heartwarming I felt when I heard that.  

It's true I wasn't ready to go into a relationship, although that was only half the truth. Until recently, I was carrying a burden for a number of years, something that only a few friends outside school know about besides my family. I wished I could share my burden with you and confess to you back then at that moment, but I didn't know how to break everything to you. 

I know you saw it as a rejection when you held my hand as you walked me home that night after our last paper, and I said I wasn't ready to go into a relationship and I needed more time, even though I didn't let go of your hand and held it tight too. I saw what looked like a heartbreak in your eyes, even though I reassured you time and again it wasn't your fault and I wasn't rejecting you. All these months I tried my best to assure you I wasn't seeing other guys or interested in anyone else, and I'm glad you trusted me. You asked "why not now" when I told you to wait for me and give me two months, and you left me at the MRT station with many question marks in your head after I told you I had personal matters to settle and I would explain to you in future. I had no idea this would be the last time I saw you ever since that night.

I was at the airport just a few hours after you walked me home, and flew to Bangkok to correct what was a mistake of nature on my body. I had no intention of ignoring your messages after that night for days, because I was drifting in and out of consciousness as I recovered on the hospital bed and was relieved of my burden for good, my physical body now matching my soul. When I was finally well enough to contact you after returning home, you ignored my phone calls and Whatsapp/Facebook messages. As I continued my recovery at home and became an emotional wreck on many occasions after I found that you deleted me off Facebook, I finally understood what you have been going through in your head that night, only magnified many times for me this time.

I wished I had taken my elder sister's advice and confessed to you earlier. However, I only wanted to be a complete girl for you by the time I confess to you, so that it would lessen any shock/disappointment/disgust from you as much as possible. I have no intention of keeping this from you at all because a couple keeps no secret from each other, and whether you want me as your girlfriend after that, I can only hope and harbour no ill-will if you decide to give up on us. 

It's already the 4th week of the new semester, but my whole mind is still consumed by your memories every single second. I wonder how you've been all this while. I guess you are probably away doing your IA now, after stalking you on Google and Facebook. I've been to our favourite places around campus almost every day at the usual times just to think about our happy times together, and I've waited for you at the MRT station every morning and evening until I had to leave for school or home. But I've never been able to bump into you at all. Every time I go to school behaving like nothing has happened, but deep down inside I am nothing but an empty shell devoid of your presence. My girl friends are sensing that something's not right about me, and I guess there's a limit to how long I can continue putting on a brave front.

If you are reading this, I want you to know that I miss you so badly all this while and how much I want to be your girlfriend if you don't mind my past. I can't wait for you to add me back on Facebook, so I can change the relationship status on my Facebook profile to being in a relationship with you and tell the whole world I like you and I love you :'(

-
 
Looking at the posts about LDR, I need to add this: Toughen up.

Back in the day when I was in an LDR, my girlfriend at that time was studying at a remote place which did not have proper internet connection. Still on dial-up modems when it was already DSL in Singapore. This meant that our exchanges are confined to just daily emails (and more than once if we happen to reach each other at the right time). There was no such thing as data plans to facetime or skype, and I would scrimp and save from my meagre JC allowance to buy an $18 prepaid card for $15 from the parking coupon auntie for 30 minutes of talk time.

When I enlisted, it became worse because we couldn't even email daily anymore. I would read her backlog of emails for the week when I booked out for the weekend, so I paid extra careful attention to not to cock up and get confined. 2-week confinement, field camp and BTP weeks were the worst because it meant 12-14 days instead of the normal 5-days-of-missing-out.  Apart from the occasional prepaid card and weekly emails, we also wrote letters to each other, although these usually only arrived every 2 weeks at best, up to a month sometimes.

I wish this had a fairytale ending, but unfortunately, our RS ended about a year into NS because it was simply too torturous and draining on both our ends to maintain such a long period of sparse communication, and lack of physical proximity/intimacy. I still kept the stack of 50-60 starhub prepaid cards from JC and NS days, because it served as a reminder to how hard we tried to make the relationship work.

And you guys really have it so much easier now. Please don't take stuff like Skype or Facetime for granted.  Plus with the increased affluence of people these days, you actually get to see each other maybe more than one sustained periods a year (we're both relatively poor, so she only flew back for Chinese New Year, 1 week, and that was it.). Please appreciate the convenience and ease of communication you have now. Don't get wound up by small things and bicker over insignificant problems. Treasure every moment together and always align yourselves with the same outcome, that is to be together at the end of the LDR (back to SDR la). 

There were many temptations along the way, and it was tough to resist. I'm sure we all agree that there are needs and urges to satisfy, which may not be possible due to the LDR. But if you never intended to last all the way, why bother starting in the first place, right?

I guess I'm kinda going nowhere with this, so I'll just stop here. :)

-
 
Was reading the confession on LDRs and I'd like share my thoughts too! 

Am currently in year one of LDR (with two more years to go) and yes, it sucks. The 7/8 hour time difference, the weird hours you have to Skype at, the constant lagging of Skype and of course, the physical absence of your partner. Arguments about who's making more time for who begin to surface and when you look at his/her photos travelling to new places, you wish you weren't the one left behind. 

But with all these experiences comes the maturing of your relationship. The physical absence of your partner forces you to be more independent; not only will you have more time for your friends, you'll also have more time to invest in your personal interests. As for Skype, you'll find yourself asking "can you hear me?" more than you imagine but at the same time, laugh at how ridiculous everything is. With enough maturity and understanding, the arguments will soon cease and the next thing you know, you're counting down to the hours you see each other on next Skype. As he/she embarks on their new journeys, you will embark on yours. 

Sure, the road may be unbearable at times but as long as you guys are clear on what your future is, I'd say to give LDR a chance. I was very much against LDR and my friends didn't believe in us either. 

It sucked but at the end of the day, my man's determination to make the relationship work made me to do the same. With ample trust, understanding and love, you'll be that couple who can take pride in being apart but very much together at the same time(:
