-
 
Hi , I'm not sure why but after reading your post, I felt compelled to reply to you. I'm currently in a long distance relationship and we've been together for 5 years, with him overseas and myself staying here. LDRs aren't as bad as what you think of it to be. Indeed, the initial stages are tough, you'll definitely miss the physical presence of your significant other and you'll feel that tinge of sadness whenever you go to places where you two have left treasured memories there. But that doesn't mean LDRs don't work out. Both of you would need to commit yourself to each other, ensure that there's constant communication between you two. It need not be hours of conversation everyday because both of you will have other commitments, like school or work. For myself, we usually talk on weekends, catching up and updating each other on the latest happenings around us. Instead of adopting a negative view towards LDRs, you can try looking from another perspective: it allows you to keep looking forward to the next Skype call (Skype is seriously awesome) and the next time you get to see each other again. Do plan ahead together and have a common goal. Do you see your paths converging after the overseas stint is over? Are you flying over or is your partner coming back? I think these are important but tough questions which you two need to find an answer to, and not run away from. Also, it's definitely possible to fly over and meet your partner (if you have your parents' approval and finances) I myself worked during the summer holidays to fund my trip overseas, and honestly, the anticipation built up over the months and having him pick me up from the airport compensated way over the tears and missing pangs when he was away. 

LDRs are never easy, but it takes both to stay strong and committed to ensure that you would continue walking down this path together with your partner. What matters most is constant communication and planning ahead, having the maturity to aim and reach a common goal together while in this LDR. Ultimately, I believe that relationships are built on trust, and if that trust is broken (which can be really tempting when your partner is not with you), then it would be hard for the LDR to continue. Your partner would be pursuing something better overseas, be it for studies or work, and I think that itself is worthy to be happy for. So, do not fear embarking on an LDR, there are many success stories out there to prove that it can still work out. I myself continue to strive and keep it going, so OP, have faith and courage in yourself. Good luck :)
-
 
During my internship at a small legal firm, I dated my senior who is solicitor. She was then 29 years of age while I was 24. She is caring and attractive with a strong dose of humor coupled with wit and sophistication. When I was first introduced to her, her serious demeanor frightened me. But after several lunch sessions at the hawker centre, she opened up to me and we got along well. Since we were both unattached, within a few weeks I confessed to her and we became an item. A partner of the firm often teased our relationship. When an individual teases me with somebody I adore, I feel very happy.

We enjoyed our time spent together at the movies and eating out. When my internship at the firm ended, we still found time for each other. Her parents and brother are nice and friendly to me when we occasionally visited her home. They made me feel so welcome, as if I am part of their family. However, when I brought her home to visit my parents, they were very unhappy and showed signs of disapproval. In our private time, my parents brought up to me the issue about the age gap. They grimly reminded me I was too young and have yet to finish my studies, while my girlfriend is an adult in the workforce. I told them to stop treating me like a child. I was already 24 for God sake! And it's not as if we are planning to marry. We were just dating and we shall decide our future only at a later stage. It was a helluva heated argument. I don't see the reason why there's a trend of older men having the privilege of dating younger ladies, while older women are discouraged from dating younger men. Perhaps 20 or 30 years may be the case of a cradle snatcher worthy of gossip, but 5 years of difference should be acceptable. 

 However, their unrelenting resistance paid off unfortunately. I discussed with my girl about this and she was very upset. Then she told me it will be for the best if I follow my parents' wishes, since our relationship will head nowhere without their approval. I was so heartbroken and I wanted to strangle my parents. Although we broke up, we continued to meet up often to talk about our lives, interests and current affairs. We became platonic friends for a while. 

Over time, I felt the frequency of our meetups significantly decreasing. The excuse was either I was too busy, or she was. But I speculated the real reason was probably to give each other some personal space since we are not romantically attached anymore. And after a year, she had a new boyfriend, who is someone older. I think he works as an auditor.

Earlier this week, I received a wedding card from her, which led me to write this confession to express my sadness. I am tempted to cut out the groom's face on the wedding card and replace it with my own to make myself feel better. Ahahahahahaha. Nonetheless, I will be attending her wedding held at the end of this year. Maybe it's the last time I want to see her since she has her own family now, and I must move on with my life. I commit myself to stop thinking about her as it's affecting my mood and productivity. 

Despite the regret, I do not blame my parents, since they brought me up well by providing me a good living and education. And I understand they always have my best interest at heart, even though I may not immediately see it. I suppose it's bad timing I was not born earlier. And even if I was born earlier, I might not even know her at all. Who knows. Life is a complex web of interrelated forces beyond our control, we just need to make do with whatever that's thrown in our way.
-
 
Hi OP ,
I'm in the same situation as you. It really sucks to fall in love with somebody at the wrong time. Your head tells you to let go and move on but your heart insists on hanging on, praying that the right time will come. When it doesn't, you force yourself to move on but every single thing reminds you of him. You struggle to fight the urge to text him whenever you have something silly, happy, angry and sad moments to share. You wish time stopped in the happier past. You fall asleep by thinking about how happy you guys could have been if the time was right.

But I wish to tell you, if you know that things are not working out for you, support yourself and move on. I know it's not easy to let go but it will only get more difficult if you continue holding on. Re-focus your energy and thoughts back to yourself and other people around you. Live your life for yourself again. Why drown yourself in misery for someone who stopped caring for you? So pick yourself up, get back on your feet and see that there are other things in the world that matter more than this relationship that could have been. Have a few supportive friends close by for moments when you stumble back into misery. I am not completely over him yet but it does get better :) 

As my bestie always says, "You are single not because there is something wrong with you but you are too awesome for anyone right now and you haven't met anyone as awesome as you yet." Tell yourself you are awesome, regain your confidence and live that awesome life that you are capable of without him.

-
 
I would like to share this article, for those who are like me, in a love purgatory.

Simply summarized, the tragedy of loving someone at the wrong time is different from breakup. In breakups, you may tend to forget someone after a long time but losing a love that you are only halfway through/not even started makes you yearn for your lost even more. You can't wish them all the best and move on because you still want to stay on. That's being thrust into a 'love purgatory' where there is no end.

Yes, you can try to do many other activities to keep yourself busy or meet someone new but guess what? He won't just go away. You'll think, 'If only he is here...." or "he's not like him, he's different". You can't seem to replace the person that is caged in your heart. Such connections that last so long are rare to come by but nevertheless your irrational heart cannot help you at all. Though, sadly this article provides no solution except the torment of going around in love purgatory. Yes, goodnight to all those who are in the same boat as me. Lay down the picture and get some sleep. T.T

Read it here: http://elitedaily.com/dating/love-purgatory/1044856/

-
 
Disclaimer: Sharing love advices and basically ranting. Recently I deleted all whatsapp conversation, messages, pictures etc of my ex and I. It's hurts more than my previous relationships because he was a guy that I wanted to marry to. He was someone that I could see myself spending the rest of my life with. I know for a fact that all relationships are never smooth sailing but I was hoping that we could make it through together. I see ourselves pretty much like a typical campus couple and hence I suppose these advices are highly relatable. To all couples out there:

1) Love is never equal - one of you are giving more/receiving less. True but here is the catch, you can't always be the ONE giving more. It's an alternating role, not a fixed one.
2) No matter how busy both of you are, at least communicate once everyday. It can be a simple text, short meetup etc. Just show his/her that he/she is on your mind. 
3) I'm okay literally means " I'm feeling like shit now and there is so much that I wanna tell you but I don't know how you might react to it"
4) Something better than I love you? Words from the heart. Even if it makes you embarrassed as hell to say so. 
5) Do not count the hours when you are together but count your blessings instead. 
6) Lastly a hug and a kiss sounds like a good idea.

For OPs of    and other similar posts...

Love isn't for cowards. 

If you feel that you are a right fit with an intended partner, gfi! Be respectful though, and sensitive to that person's thoughts and feelings. Some people might be hurting inside, some might be unsure, some may feel bound to cultural pressure to be "chased"- and some might be really oblivious! 

But that's what communication is for, right? C'mon the usual commenters here have said this enough- don't expect the other party to read your mind.

I know my photos aren't artistic, nor are my captions meaningful or witty. I also don't go out a lot so I don't post "cool" stuff i.e. cafe hops and pretty food, group outings/meetups. But does that mean my posts aren't worth a like? Or is it because I'm not part of their inner clique? 
I'm generally quite generous with liking friends' posts that appear on my feed, but when it comes to these people I get a bit apprehensive...perhaps it's a self-created vicious cycle of withholding likes?
Could it be an issue of timing? Maybe they only checked instagram some hours after I posted and my post got buried below. But cannot be so suay right, by now I've posted at all kinds of different times and still nothing. Is it common practice to scroll all the way down to whichever post you last saw whenever you check instagram? And is it common practice to still like those older posts?
Finally, is it normal to like every post on your feed (or at least posts from known friends)? Or is it more normal to be stingy with likes? And for what reasons do you decide that a post is worth a double-tap?
I know this post is superficial as heck (but wow it got so long), and living for instagram likes is not the way to go, but I can't help but feel a little offended by the perpetual lack of likes from some friends.
As mentioned above I don't have many followers or followees, so maybe the way I use instagram is different than normal. I hope a social media expert (since that's a legit title nowadays) can enlighten me. Thanks.

P.S. yes I admit one of these friends is a girl I have a crush on, but in the bigger picture there are also quite a number of friends who never like my posts.

University has honestly been the loneliest time of my life. You need to take responsibility for your own life, such as joining CCAs, camps. It is a place where you can do everything or nothing. 

University life has, sadly, literally displayed to me my flaws and fears.

I have an eating disorder, and i have a very bad body image, to the point that i would not go to school for weeks, missing lectures and tutorials because I felt too ugly to be seen walking in school. 

I went from binging to anorexia and now binging again. It is a daily struggle and I can't see myself getting out of it.

I lost interest in making new friends because it's too hard for me to juggle between school, my personal problems and my social anxiety. People are all over the place, it is hard to really find really close friends. 

I stopped complaining to my close friends because they are tired of me. So i always try to remain cheerful, but i feel terrible inside. I didn't complain so much in the past, but my complaints when uni started were so bad that my close friend of 8 years wanted to end our friendship. 

I joined a few camps and made new friends but I am distancing myself from everyone. I feel bored being by myself but i am too embarrassed and disgusted to meet others, even my old cliques and best friends.

I feel sad for no reason, and i just want to leave the campus once lectures are over. I can't bear to even stay in school for more than a minute.

My dad committed suicide this year and sometimes i see this as an option too. But i don't have the balls yet. He used to tell me he wanted to commit suicide when he was in university, that's like 30 years ago. I never thought he would do this since he had a family. Now, I don't know if i'm going to follow his path in future.

I think I am a boring person, and i beat myself up every time i cannot seem to click with someone. Recently, i broke up with my 2 year plus boyfriend, hoping that my life would be better without him. It has turned for the worse. Our relationship had always been rocky, so this was like the 4th or 5th break up we had, so I am sure we are not getting back together ever again. 

I want to get better but university life is making me miserable to no end. I really want to be more positive about life but I just can't seem to.

I want to have a rock by my side but I know I need to get better myself before I can really find someone again.

"The Best Place"- can be any location or people, it is a boundless paradise where we can truly be ourselves.

The 3 years that I had spent with you guys are the most memorable and crazy fun times. Till now, I'm still quite confused. I'm just a average Joe with no talent or what so ever... But somehow you bakkas always look upon me as a almighty Senpai with those eyes of admiration. 

We would move from faculty to faculty, searching for our "Best Place", where we can hang out and do crazy stuffs. That is the only time we are truly immune to the merciless and cruel world around us. We are just a bunch of rotten social rejects, no matter how other people judge us or ridicule us. Our "Best Place" has kept our heart warm and prevented that burning passion inside of each and everyone of us from being extinguish, isn't it? 

Here are some of the beautiful and memorable moments that I will kept with me forever.....

1) When we gave 小胖 courage to confess to that hot business chick, although we knew that it's a kamikaze mission. He got rejected without even uttering the 3 words. That chick simply told him, "Your B.O is too strong!". In the end we had to offer our brotherly arms to that crying pig XD. We just couldn't contained our laughter, what rotten bastards we are!

2) On one occasion, we nearly got expelled for playing a prank on our professor by sending her multiple emails to confess our love. We even gave her a nickname "Old virgin". These are the reckless times we shared HAHAHA!

3) The night when we laid on the grass patch of U Town gazing at the stars talking about our sexual dreams. It's really gay for 6 guys to be doing this sort of things. We are all unwanted toys, no chick will ever find us attractive.  

The news of me dropping out of university had struck you guys like a 10000 tonnes truck. No matter how sad or depress you are, please continue to search for "The Best Place" where you truly belongs. When I'm typing this farewell message, I cried a thousand times for you bitches! FUCK YOU ALL! FUCK YOU ALL SERIOUSLY! 

Gomen'nasai ! Gomen'nasai ! I wished I can stay with you guys a little longer...just a while longer... But life is still life, I'm still finding my "Best Place" in the outside world.

I guess I'm still the almighty and incorruptible Senpai since you guys haven't seen me crying like a sissy bitch yet! Best of luck to all of you!

-
 
I am an introvert, and I prefer spending my limited social mana on the people that matter, namely my family and my two best friends.

I am in *a design-related course in SDE* and as much as I expect workload to be heavy, I hate the copious amount of "meeting-up" I have to do with group members whom I'm not close with. Neither am I intending to get close with them because.. I just can't see that happening. They are a bunch of sociable, talkative people. A lot more extroverted than me. They practically look forward to meeting up with one another, even for work. On the other hand, my heart sinks whenever I see another message on Whatsapp going something like, "hey, let's meet up to discuss ______ !"

Sometimes, I feel the urge to suggest to "meet-up" online instead of a physical meeting, but this might make them think I'm a lazybum, and possibly raise it to our profs. Sometimes I just want to tell them hey, I'm an introvert. Can we please don't meet up so often? I know you guys have no problem with meet-ups but to some other people, it's draining and mood-dampening and anxiety-inducing. Please try to understand that what's seemingly effortless, even pleasurable to you, may actually be hell to others. But I'm afraid I'll be blacklisted because of my stupid demands. But seriously, sometimes, communicating online is just as productive as doing so physically. And it saves time and money, so practical! You don't have to worry about forgetting to bring something, because home has all you need.

Speaking of home, I overwhelmingly prefer working at home than in the studio. The studio is an assault on my senses. So much noise, so much discomfort. At home, I am in my element. I can do whatever I want - get food from the fridge, blast my music, rest my legs on the table. At home I am surrounded by familiarity, by the love of family, it's a hotbed for inspiration. And you need inspiration to produce good design. It all goes back to being introverted. Sadly, my studio mates seem to be hinting to me that I should be in studio more often, perhaps implying that I should work harder? Because being seen in the studio means you're working hard? The model student sleeps overnight in the studio? It doesn't help that I do not produce outstanding work; my lack of exceptional quality in my work is now being attributed to being absent in the studio most of the time.

Neither am I saying physical meet-ups should be completely abolished. I know sometimes physical meet-ups are necessary. But I do not want to see your faces all the time. Putting up a smiley front whenever I meet you all is mentally draining. If the work delegation ain't complex, by all means stay at home. You get to save your time and transport costs. I get to save my sanity.

To all those who are heartbroken and lonely from a break up: IT WILL GET BETTER. 

There are literally so many other people out there that you have not met. There is no point pining and moping after someone who has left, for they clearly do not share the same sentiments that you do. It is just unfair to yourself, and to those who actually DO CARE about you (family). 

Being a student now already puts you in a very good position. What other situation in your life would you be placed amongst people with roughly the same age and maturity, and in such close proximity. 

Do everything you can to make yourself happy. You are the only person in this whole world that owes yourself your happiness. Get out there and join whatever activities that are available in school (there are tons). 

To have already made it this far into university is already a very commendable effort by you. You are more fortunate and blessed than you think you are (: . Remind yourself this everyday when you are feeling depressed and down. There is always something in your life to live for, as a relationship is only just a small portion of your entire human existence. 

Remember, you are not alone! I too have gone through the days of endless crying and pining, and even feeling suicidal for a period of time. In fact the feelings of desperation and loss are still fresh in my mind. But here I am, still alive and getting better everyday. 

Do also note that there are numerous avenues in Singapore to seek help from if you have no one to sob to or share your pain with. Call "Samaritans of Singapore" at 1800-221-4444. I did when I was at my lowest emotional point, and was greeted by the most heartwarming and helpful person ever. 

Take care of yourself alright! Lastly, here is a warm hug over the internet from your fellow NUS student (: !

OP of , I don't even know if it really is you but certainly, reading the post brought back a flood of memories. 

When I think about us, I think about time. I think about how the clock seems to stop ticking when we were together, how it appeared as though the rest of the world has fallen away and it was just us. I think about how our conversations through the night appeared to hasten the very rotation of the earth's axis and before we know it, the sky is light again. I think about how excruciating each second was, when you were away and it seemed like we would grow an age before we could be in each other's presence. And then, I think about how time dictated our circumstances and brought a jarring end to a connection that neither of us expected, or thought possible. 

I have been, and will remain, a cynic when it comes to matters of the heart. But with you, all the outdated notions of a grand, all conquering love seems well within the realm of realism. So much time has past but still I dream sometimes of how things have been in another time and place. I hope that you are well. I hope that you have chased down all your lofty dreams and I hope, most of all, that you are happy. I don't think that there has ever been a day when I stopped loving you and I do wish that love is all you need. The pain we both feel, even today, reminds us otherwise. 

I hope one day to see you again, if only from a distance. And I hope that when I do, I catch a glimpse of your real smile. The one that speaks of excitement, and more importantly, of a deep seated happiness. The one you used to reserve for when our eyes met. Because then, I would know that you have found love. 

Till then, I miss you, and I always will.

To  When I started NUS, I was 24. I must have been the oldest student in my major. I went in with an open heart, open mind and a clear goal - which was to get my degree. That clear goal I had in mind really helped me in being less self-conscious about how much older I was compared to everyone else. 

And here's a secret, everyone else assumes that everyone is about the same age. Besides, I never felt the need to tell my age to the people I met in NUS through that compulsory camp I went to (where I met most of my friends who stuck with me through my three years) or through the different modules I've taken because my age pales in comparison to something else I have to offer - my personality. 

In fact, the fact that I'm much older than my friends became a source of entertainment for me. When they find out my actual age I get replies like, 'Really?? But you look so young!' or 'I don't believe you.. Show me your IC!'

So open your heart, open your mind and make that goal of getting a degree even clearer in your head. Let your personality shine through, make new friends (and keep your age a secret until they ask you, it's fun!) and keep your eye on the prize. The road to getting a degree from NUS is tough enough, don't let anything break your spirit. 

And it is with that unbroken spirit that I am now a proud NUS alumnus who graduated at 27. I am proud because an NUS graduate is a quality graduate at any age.

Dear  ,  
I think I understand where you're coming from. I tend to feel like this sometimes, especially so in the past 2 years of uni. I joined orientation camps and got really anxious and uncomfortable because internally people were bitching about each other but infront of them they acted like nothing happen. I guess what helped me feel and think better is the acceptance that in this society, nobody is ever 'good' , including myself. Everybody is flawed and makes mistakes and that's okay. Sometimes, we see ourselves in others too. I guess you just have to do what you think is right and surround yourself with people you love and trust. If they don't like you, then it's ok, just move along. U dont need their 'okay'. 
And also, feeling like you have no one to rely on and trust in Nus, isn't being 'toxic'. 'Toxic' is only when you hurt/bring others down intentionally. 
All the best for school and i hope you feel better <3

I posted  and I must say I'm really touched many of you offered your advices and encouragement. To OP , you're strong, and I really admire you. You're right. I hope I'll reach that stage you're at as soon as I can. But right now this period is really hard for me. I'm hanging on to my closest grp of friends now. This incident has shown me how awesome they are, that they are so willing to put everything down to be with me. They've done so much for me I feel so fortunate and I wonder what have I done to deserve then. Because of them, I want to be strong - because that's the only way I can repay their kindness. Nevertheless, they cannot be with me all the time. There will always be times where I have to be alone. These are the toughest times to get by. In the day I work really hard to get my mind off him. I've blocked him off on all social medias. We're no longer in contact. I work my ass off at work, I exercise a lot more than usual, I keep trying to reach out to new people, making new friends. I mingle around a lot more than I used to now and I laugh a lot with my colleagues and new friends. Each day I make myself so tired that I crash on my bed and sleep. But in the mornings I'll wake up and feel so hollow I shed some tears. It's been like this ever since the break up. I can't believe that he could really just let go of whatever we had- that beautiful 4years. Will he ever come back? It's a silly thought I know but whenever I look back, it's almost always happiness and sweetness. We had differences but we always managed to overcome them. This time round it just broke apart, so quickly, so drastically. If you're a guy and you've done this to a girl before, I wish you would explain to me why you did it. How? How did your feelings changed? How did you let yourself change? Why didn't you mention anything when you felt unhappy? Why did you bottle them up and let it all go at once? Was the relationship not worth giving it another try? I'm sure it's not easy for you either, but why would you still give all these up? Is all this chasing and excitement really so worth it? Which idiot would give up on a girl who loves him so much- to chase after someone who doesn't? To chase after all the superficials? Because she was your first love and you don't wish to settle? Because YOLO? I need answers. 
To those who are going through the same thing as me, I wish I could give you a hug right now. It's tough being strong, but you have to do it, even if it's not for yourself, do it for your family and friends. Embrace them, and accept all kinds of kindness. It made me feel a lil better bit by bit. 
To boyfriends out there, please don't make promises you can't keep. If you want to break, do a clean break and don't leave any threads behind. 
To third parties, I don't know if you even have any conscience at all. To give all sorts of false signals to a guy. It's mostly the guy's fault yes. But I think if you're aware you're the reason your friend's relationship is on rocks you should have the decency to back off a little. Sending him a photo of yourself to 'cheer him up'? What were you thinking? Being able to attract a guy's attention makes you feel great, feel superior? Do it to a single guy then, why fool with someone attached? Your own excitement and happiness was rooted on someone else's misery, just so you know. If you're really not interested in him, please stop dragging him around in circles.

In response to ,

That's where you're wrong. Admittedly in NUS you'll meet many hi-bye acquaintances, but I have actually met people whom I've gotten closer to. Join more activities, camps, ccas etc, and when you meet more people, there's a higher chance that few out of the many you meet will stay a close friend. 

In short, dont seclude yourself and complain that all people you know are simply acquaintances. I'm a Year 2 that has met close to 100 people ever since coming NUS, many of them stay hi-bye friends, but there are like 5-10 I can call close friends. And I still intend on being more active and knowing more people.

It's possible and it just depends on you. Not too late to start joining more ccas and events now.

I know my friends mean well, but I wish they would stop trivialising my optimism. Yeah, I can wait for the one to stumble into my life. I don't think I can find her by swiping a few pictures online. I think I'll find her through shared experiences in life. I think that if a girl I might have crush on doesn't like me back, then she isn't it for me. What's the point in trying? I'm Guy and she's Girl. Guy is one of the typical confessors here: shy, awkward (especially with females), introverted, antisocial, lack of friends, alone most of the time, etc. With very few female friends, any positive female attention makes his overthinking mind go crazy. Perhaps that's the root of the problem here.
Guy and girl met two years ago. They clicked and soon had a never ending WA convo going on. Guy thinks maybe there's some good chemistry between them. Starts falling for her.  Even mutual friends notice that they're close and stir them. Girl vehemently denies these, making guy wonder if there was ever anything between them at all, or if she was just being normal and friendly. So as you can expect guy keeps his feelings hidden.
Some months later the WA convo starts drying up and they drift apart. Guy accepts that perhaps it was never meant to be and understands that he must move on. WA contact is still intermittent until present day, but guy knows it is nothing more than small talk.

Fast forward half a year later. Guy was in the vicinity of girl at a canteen. They definitely saw each other, but nothing at all happened. Both ended up dao-ing each other. Yet guy still felt the butterflies, and jealousy when friends stir girl with a new man now. But what right does guy have? Guy and girl are like strangers again.

Sigh, I know I must move on, but it seems impossible to find another girl to at least make me overthink about, so that I will forget girl-from-story.

-
 
To the OP whose boyfriend changed after entering the banking industry, don't get discouraged by this incident. Instead, what has happened should teach you not to depend too much on anyone else and start building on yourself. No matter how stable things might be, it is hard to say that nothing will change, because people change. Often, this happens during the major transitions in our lives (e.g. entering university, getting a new job...etc). I have been through a similar experience, whereby I had once believed that my boyfriend would me forever and we would get married. But as we entered university, he changed. Similar to your experience, he wouldn't stop talking to certain girls despite the fact that I had expressed my discomfort; he had also never disregarded my feelings previously. It is a hard truth to accept but in his eyes, you simply aren't as relevant and important as you were before. Now he has his sights on girls whom he perceives are what he desires. My life had once revolved all around my boyfriend; It took me a long time to stand up by myself again after I broke it off with him. But in the process I realised that him changing was out of my control - it wasn't my failure, it was that his love for me was so easily manipulated by the environment around him. In some sense, if he was so easily enticed by other women, this incident could have happened at some point much later in your lives, even if this girl never appeared. At least you know now. So pick yourself up! Your life is your own.

I met my first true love during our yr 1 engineering freshmen orientation. I was his first love and we dated for nearly 5 years before we broke up a few months ago. 

During the 4 crazy hectic years in engineering, I struggled badly. I really wanted to give up at some points, yet I persisted on with his love and encouragement. He was always there when I needed him. He never had much difficulty, he was really smart and could ace most of his exams.

We were inseparable. People were envious of me because they could tell how much he really loves me. My family and friends approved of him too. They felt that he was sincere, simple and down to earth. He too, was always thinking about marrying me, talking about children, about future. On our fourth year of relationship, I was pretty much set on building a future with him together. But we had to get our career on track first.
Just when things looked rosy, things suddenly went downhill after 1 year into our job after graduation. I went into engineering field, while he found interest in the banking industry. I didn’t think he would be well suited in the banking industry. He is more introverted, and prefer to stay home instead of socialising. I expressed my concern, but also encouraged him to pursue his passion. He was fascinated with the money the banking industry could bring him. I felt that it was good for a guy to be ambitious. However, as the time passes, he started to become nearly obsessed with investments and trading. Not just that. He was hungry for career advancement. He wanted to jump from back office to the front office as quickly as possible. He started to leech on this female colleague who is really popular amongst everyone including the bosses. He became great friends with her, and they went for coffee chats with big bosses to gain connections and all, in hopes of climbing out of the back office one day. 
Their relationship turned from colleagues to good friends within a year. When I found out he has been constantly chatting with her, I told him to stop because it was making me uncomfortable, yet he refused to. This was the first time he refused my plea. I knew then that he has more feelings for her than just a good friend. But he denied. Within just 2 weeks everything fell apart. He confessed to her before he broke up with me. She rejected him. But he broke up with me anyway. He said it’s not me, it’s him. He is lost and he wants to find himself. Later I found out that right after we broke up, he began to actively chase her. 

I don’t know if they are together now. But sometimes I still find it so absurd. That a guy would give up a long term relationship with his soul mate. Yes, even after we broke up, he still called me his soul mate. We never had much problems. We were stable, and just really comfortable with each other. I don’t understand why would anyone give up someone he calls a best friend, confidant and soul mate, without even trying to make this relationship work when he felt that things weren’t right. He never expressed any unhappiness. We hardly ever quarrelled. This abrupt end in relationship is somehow making me lose faith in true love. Because I think we both agree that what we had was true love. 
-
 
The truth is, I really hate NUS. 

If you have heart and show your emotion, then people treat you as weak and stupid.
If you choose to show the logical side then people just use you as a tool to ask for notes and help for homework.
If you're the intuitive kind, then people just pretend to be nice, so that you will be nice back.
If they don't even like you, they talk behind your back. Some pretend to be friendly in front. Some give you a slap and run away* (they think you deserve punishment, but they don't even give you a chance to reason or fight back).

*No man, you are not a good person. If you laugh at someone, insult someone, make fun about someone, gossip about someone, talk negatively about someone, but do not dare to admit to the person face to face, you are NOT A GOOD PERSON. 

And the worst part? Your respond to this is probably: "hey, this is life. The real world is like this, you should get used to it too."

I rather be working right now. I'm so exasperated.

After I came for my exchange, I just realised that I'm really a socially awkward and introverted person.

I really don't know what to talk about when hanging out with my new friends - yes, I do observe, and I found that they normally talk about US dramas, movie stars, or just other random stories they've encountered during their trip in the previous summer. I don't have much of these materials to say, and even if I have, I don't know how to express it in a way that the other party in the conversation would be interested. It is thus always the case that my friends would be able to talk to each other endlessly and (seemingly) with pleasure, and I am usually the (only) one that shuts his mouth. When I don't have much to share I would feel left-out, uncomfortable and will have the drive to leave first.

Also, my friends have all this and that kinds of activities to organise and to go for, e.g. barbecuing, mass-swimming, hiking, clubbing, or maybe just travelling to some random places. I do want to go for some of these, but I also feel uncomfortable doing them with people that I'm not very familiar with. I don't know many people here either - there are very few NUS exchange students - and everything just makes me feel lonely.

That reminds me of what happened before. I'm an introverted, shy PRC guy. I have been trying to integrate myself into the NUS community, joining different kinds of activities in the past years and trying my very best to make more friends, but the results all ended up the same. I did make some friends, but most of them are the hi-bye kind, and I don't think I really know any of them well. It is really the norm that, from my honest point of view, outgoing people are more welcomed and popular, whereas introverted people are more easily ignored, although I don't really see anything wrong with the latter or anything superior with the former.

Now think about it, I don't really know why I came for SEP, or even came to Singapore for studies in the first place. I guess everything would have been great if I did my university education in my own country. Who knows.

With all the 'does he/she love me' kind of confessions starting to appear, I have two points I would like to share:

1. Follow your heart. Instinct will tell you what you need to know. 
2. A partner who is 'not spending enough time with you' does not indicate that he/she is not in love with you. Different individuals show love in different ways; for all you know, he/she is trying to show you their affection to their best effort - google 'Love Language'. 

From: A senior who is about to get married soon :)

Have been seeing a few confessions related to whether a girl would accept a guy who is shorter than her or not good-looking etc. A bit paiseh to comment so I'd just like to give my 2 cents here.

Most girls would have a "dream guy", with all the characteristics she wants e.g. good looks, wealth, intelligence, romantic enough to sweep her off her feet. Being individuals with our own likes & dislikes, every girl would value different traits differently. Physique-wise, some prefer buff bods, some prefer the lean kind etc. If you ask around, many girls would say they EC guys who are taller and good-looking.

But at the end of the day, it is hard enough to find someone compatible in terms of personality, lifestyle & chemistry. If a girl is able to find that in a guy, I honestly doubt she will reject him simply because he is of the same height or not the hottest guy around. 

Maybe there are girls who die die must find a boyf taller than them/above average in looks, but I don't know of any of them personally. 2 of my attached girlfriends have partners of the same height; both couples have been together for 4 years. 2 years ago, one of my friends got together with a guy who we secretly thought wasn't as good-looking as her, but have since grown to like because of his personality and how sweet they are to each other.

From a female perspective, physical characteristics are only part of what we consider when finding our other half. Don't let height or looks deter you from pursuing or accepting someone who could be perfect for you in every other way.

To . I'm in the same situation as you. My bf is also a social butterfly and doing really great in his studies, while I'm just the girl next door. At first, I felt a little inferior too, but I got over it by being kind with myself. I've made peace with myself by having the mindset that I don't have to live up to anyone's standards, and my self-esteem has improved. Yes, my bf will always be the better person, but this is me. If I don't enjoy getting out there to socialize and make new friends, then I don't have to. If I don’t accept and be happy with myself, then probably no one will. Though it doesn’t always work the other way.
About confiding in your boyfriend about your troubles, well, I’m sorry to say that it seems like he’s not being caring and concerned enough for you. No matter what problems couples share with each other, they should be empathizing and lend a listening ear to each other. Your boyfriend should accept you for who you are, and maybe you can make it easier for him by accepting yourself first. I’m not sure how long you guys have been together, but if it still doesn’t help, then give him time, talk through it and hopefully you guys can grow and mature together. Also, it boils down to compatibility. All the best, babe.

-
 
To the OP of 

Yeah I get that feel too. Happens a lot with institution allocated groupings (e.g. class, OG, CCA batch), because the people aren't necessarily going to get along amazingly together, so they usually break up into smaller cliques that may or may not have inter-clique interaction.

My secondary school CCA batchmates have always been "close" but not all of us really "click" together. Being one of those typical quiet kids, I wasn't very close with them. Even now, 7 years later, the core few will go out for meals, but when I or any of the fringe ones come along, our topics of interest diverge so much that it's just awkward and conversation gets mundane and stilted. It's painful all around.

So, as much as people may say that one's happiness shouldn't be dictated by the presence of other people etc etc, I know that subtle disappointment when you find out that you just don't mean that much to the rest. Another example would be Whatsapp group chat birthday greetings, the difference between that for a core person to a fringe person is obvious.

((Before all the "SO SHALLOW" comments start coming in, I make no excuse other than the fact that humans are undoubtedly social creatures. We seek (crave?) attention. It is unrealistic to expect everyone to survive on zero support.))

However, I have found friends who can really be counted as friends, and they can be counted on one hand. They are those I can trust and rely on. Anyway, to cut the long story short, we were the quiet few who found our voices with each other when no one else would bother to listen. #poetic

As a group gets larger, there's definitely going to be inner and outer circles. Getting in is really hard and tiring, especially if you are an introvert. I suggest finding people you don't have to act with. I know it takes a long period of trial and error, but keep at it okay :) Meanwhile, it would be good to develop your own interests and work on becoming "ambivert." All the best!

///

tl;dr: It happens. Find people on your wavelength, and have fun on the long road.

-
 
To all the people asking for advice about liking or even loving someone who is attached:

Run far, far, far away; please do not be the third party. It is better for yourself and the couple as well. My ex had this "good friend" whom I was really really really uncomfortable with, but he continued talking to her (A LOT). In the end, he broke up with me in the most insincere way ever (not even a phone call) and got together with his "good friend". 

You might think that there's nothing wrong with talking to your attached friend whom you have feelings because it's "just friends", but sooner or later, something will happen. 

It's been two years but there are still days when I can't get over it, get over the betrayal (I'm way over him). 

And in case you are wondering, they broke up. It won't last because it might be because he's just looking for someone else and you are "always there".

The ultimate solution to get over someone you cannot have.

There is no such thing as "soul mate". There are more than 5 million people in Singapore. Do you really think you will only be attracted to only one person in your lifetime?

If for some reason you cannot be with someone you like, just find someone else. There are many people out there who can potentially be your "soul mate".

In case you are wondering if there is no such thing as soul mate, Why do people choose only one mate in their life?

The answer is intimacy and commitment.

If so, doesn't it mean that you do not respect and love your partner enough? You want to seek sexual pleasures, but you are still with him/her because you want to feel the genuine love from him/her. I'm a Chinese guy who has always had a weak spot for Malay girls when it comes to relationships. I think that partly has to do with the fact that I went to a neighbourhood secondary school, where there were more Malays than Chinese and Indians. I've went on dates (if you can call it) with girls (Malays and Chinese) as far back in secondary school, but nothing serious ever developed.

Then in JC, I had a classmate who was a Malay girl. The first time I saw her, I thought, "Wah, damn hot. Cannot take it." And she really was. I got to know her as a friend and developed feelings for her from there, but never told her about it until much later. I didn't tell because I was afraid that she wouldn't want to date a Chinese guy. We were walking to the bus interchange when she confessed her feelings for me. I thought she was joking and I asked if she was for real, lol. In my heart, I was jumping for joy. I told her then that I've had feelings for her awhile too So we got into a relationship, but kept it secret from our classmates...

We've been together for four years... It would have been five, but I made a mistake somewhere along the way and we broke up for awhile. She's met my parents who are okay with me dating someone outside of my race. So no problems there... After all, my parents have known of my dating history with Malay girls for a long, long time now so there's precedence. Her parents seem to like me as well, but I'm not v sure... Some days, it feels like they disapprove of our relationship.

The problem here isn't the parents.. but... with me. She comes from a religious family and she is as well. Her religion is something important in her life, but despite of it, she still holds liberal ideas in the sense that she's for equal rights - specifically concerning LGBTs, and I love her for it. I can't imagine raising kids with someone who's anti-LGBT. Now I believe that when you marry someone, you also marry into their family and in some cases, their religion. 

At some point, if I marry her, I know that I'll have to convert to Islam. I don't mind giving up pork or alcohol and I'm already circumcised (sorry if TMI) but the thing is, I can't see myself as a convert. I'm an atheist, always have been. I've read about Islam, I know just enough, but it still doesn't speak to me. Sometimes, I think I've wasted her time. Maybe it would have been easier had I dated a Chinese girl, but I can't help whom my heart chooses to love... I love her, but I feel the issue of religion is beginning to affect me and my relationship with her. I've not told her about this, but I sense she knows. 

I've spoken on this issue to a friend of mine - a Chinese girl - who dated a Malay guy for six years. She married him, converted to Islam and embraced the religion willingly. Talking to her gives me comfort. She understands where I come from, but tells me that this is a decision only I can make. That it would be unfair to both of us if I drag on too long on this issue. :( Haiz... Very stress just thinking about this...

To all the lonely hearts out there on NUSWhispers: 

if you miss someone who does not miss you, or who is no good for you, or is unattainable, take all the love you once felt for them and spread it around other places. put your love in worthwhile people and things, turn the romance in to passions for hobbies or admiration for others- enrich your own life. focus on yourself and those who actively make you happy.
-
 

On your confession:
Don't dwell on it too much, don't pour your guts out on other friends too much, and most importantly, don't let it get to your studies. 

You know that it is a tad bit annoying to keep imposing on your friends, to let them listen to your anguish and rage, so you should take the actions to recover. If not, you will lose friends who cared, and you will jeopardise your future.

Your world came crumbling down, it's about time you built a new one from its ruins, not centered around others. Put on a false front if you have to, and fake it, til you make it. Grab your loneliness, use it as a stepping stone, and leave it behind.

Sorry if I sound crude, and sorry if I am not that experienced on the matter, though. My world also came crumbling down on me before, because of an extremely short-lived relationship. What happened next, I do not want to see it happening to others.

In response to the poster of , look.. here's the deal. No man is ever afraid of a woman who is well put together. I would suggest you put down cosmos and get down that high horse. Stop believing the "men are afraid of women" BS - yeah right. From what it sounds, you want a good, capable man. Well, the truth is ..no one owes you deep conversations, warm company and loving embrace. If you want it, put yourself out there. Beyond looks, what else do you offer? 99% of people fail at this stage. There are a handful (not a lot, sadly) of really great guys in NUS. Some of them run their own companies, some of them have made strides in getting that dream career started while others are very focused and accomplished. 

The problem is that girls (yes, girls) like yourself tend to overlook them and instead waste time on frivolous camps and pageants to look and act cool. Instead of talking to that airhead of a guy who has been clubbing nonstop and wasting his life, why not make an effort to sieve out the wheat from the chaff? Take the time. Pause. Listen carefully in class. Think. Pause. There are gems, really, its whether or not you can see/find them. Good luck, girl.

Guys, remember that girl you'd put on a pedestal and practically worship? You'd do anything for her, anything to make her happy, her smile makes your day and you care for her unconditionally and tirelessly. Her being upset drives a stake through your heart. You respect her endlessly and even if she has a thousand flaws, you look past it all. Sure you want to get physical with her but that has very little to do with lust and everything to do with love. Reading this, you prolly got a smile on your face or maybe shed a few tears remembering her. She has such a hold over your emotions. You were/are crazy in love. 

Also, remember that girl...? The girl you'd do anything to have in your bed, to have your ways with her? What she feels doesn't matter all that much; she's only an attractive face and body to you. Being able to have sex with her would be something that's going to make your friends envious (if you're that open) or just give you an overall ego boost. You were/are crazy in lust. 

Oh you probably don't remember the second girl. Cos her face and body were all that mattered to you. 
Trust me, it sucks always being the second type of girl. Guys may or may not find you attractive (idk whether looks matter when guys wanna bang a girl) and they surely want to get into your pants, but to them you're not a person, you're an object.
Being objectified is something we can't avoid; it's how we see ourselves that really matter more. But the feeling is really terrible, when you know that you never meant more than that to a person. 

Fortunately I've never given myself to any guy, but sometimes I really wonder what's wrong with me, why hasnt there been any guy in my life who cares about me like that, who would love and respect me, though he's not in love with me. I've had guy friends who are good, reliable friends and they seem to respect me but I found out that if given the chance they'd sleep with me.
You know when you just respect a girl so much that u can't even think about her that way? I wanted to be that girl for my guy friends, for any guy in my life, even if I can't be someone a guy is totally in love with. 

Is it something I'm doing? Well I know for sure I'm not giving out the wrong message; I'm not promiscuous; I dress fairly conservatively; Im not very touchy with my guy friends; I have my personal space and I respect others'. I respect people (those who deserve it) and I'm not overly sexual when it comes to jokes and such. Then why am I viewed as a sexual object by people who should be respecting me.
Not only that, whenever I read/see/hear about this guy falling for this girl or that girl, or how they still feel about her, I get so jealous. Why can't a guy feel that way about me.
And I feel ashamed of myself for thinking that way cos no, I don't need validation from a guy to find out what kind of person I am. I believe I don't need to be loved to feel good about myself. I have a great personality and I'm my own person, for myself. 
But that doesn't change the fact that I keep thinking about not being 'loved', wondering why hasn't anyone ever felt that way about me...

She on the other hand likes to ignore me and would rather have some alone time. She is also a very adventurous and ambitious girl. She has gone on many overseas trips with the school. She went to Thailand once for a month and then went to NOC for a year. All this while i waited for her patiently, skyping her every night, making sure that we would at the very least communicate once a day. Recently, she expressed her interest to me about going for an overseas program which would last 2 years. I really didn't want to stop her from doing what she wants, but at the same time, I didn't want her to leave me again. The past year while she was in NOC was hard for me. Due to the time difference, i'd have to sleep at 1-3am every night just so we could have a conversation together. Anyway, when she mentioned that she was interested to go on the program, it suddenly struck me hard whether this is the kind of person i'd want to marry. I mean, first it was 1 year, then now it's 2 years, who knows what opportunity will pop up next and then off she goes again. But even with all these doubts in my head, I still love her for who she is. It's a little hard to explain, but it's just how I feel.

I have been talking to this other girl in school for the past two weeks. The both of us are just friends, I know it in my heart that I have 0% interest in my friend in the romantic sense... Furthermore, that girl already has a boyfriend. She's just a good friend, like the kind who is not fake or pretentious. The only girl in my heart is my girlfriend, and I'd do anything for her. I have been very transparent with my gf about me talking to my friend. I'd let her read our text messages too just so she doesn't feel insecure. I could feel that my gf was getting a little jealous of it and i told her that "if you want me to stop, i'll stop, no questions asked, because I love you and I don't want a friend to come in between us".

She didn't tell me to stop. I thought it was pretty mature of her to trust me like that. My conscience was also clear because I have 0% interest in my friend as a partner. 

Yesterday, she read out text messages again. She cried. I've never seen her cry like this before in my life. I wanted to hug her, but I could tell she didn't want me anywhere near her. She accused me of liking this friend of mine. She felt betrayed. I was shocked. Because not only did i not like this girl friend of mine, I loved my gf with 2000% of my heart. I immediately felt like shit. I would have given up everything I had just for her to stop crying. My fingers, my organs, my money, anything. I couldn't bear to watch her cry like that because of me. She left me and blocked me from calling her and messaging her. At 3am, she texted me that she needed some time alone.

Today, i went to wait outside her lecture with some food in my hand, hoping I could talk it out with her. I couldn't find her when her lecture ended. People streamed out of the LT and i desperately searched for her everywhere. Fearing i might have missed her, I ran around the school, searching for her. I tried calling her again, only to remember that she had blocked all my calls. I called again and again, hoping for the small chance that she would unblock me. But she didn't. I felt empty. I felt like shit. I felt like breaking down. I was perspiring like mad. I felt so helpless.

I don't want things to end for us like this. I know i have my doubts about us, but i always thought I'd have it figured out along the way with you. I don't want things to end between us.. over nothing...

Does any1 have any advice?

I need to rant and get some advice. I argued with my girlfriend yesterday over something silly. She told me that I've had an easy life. It wasn't the first time I heard it. She's said the same on several occasions to a point where I'm sick of it. I don't deny I've had an easy life. I come from a wealthy family. We fly on private jets on our holidays. She, on the other hand, comes from a poor family. They're on welfare and have never been out of Singapore (not even Malaysia). I'm very much aware of the privilege I've had in life. 

I've known her family background since day one of our relationship, but that didn't stop me from wanting to pursue her. I saw my whole life with her, and for the first time in my "colourful" dating history, it didn't scare me. Before, I would have ended relationships faster than I would commit. I really, really love her. I just don't know how to place myself in her situation. I just cannot imagine it.

Last night, I was driving her home... and the topic came up again. I told her out of frustration to "shut the fuck up" and called her naive and irrational. We spent the remainder of that car ride in silence... I WAed this morning to apologize. She's read it, but hasn't replied. I feel guilty for the words I said, but I can't help but feel like it's an attack each time she says something about my privilege... Maybe I was wrong, I don't know lah... fuck.

-
 
In response to OP  regarding what it means to be cheating on your partner:
Pretty impressed you actually had a reply post to your first post, seems you're actually appreciative and really looking for advice. I feel that I would like to comment on this because of my own similar experiences.
When I was with my first girlfriend, (ok fine I was probably still young back then) I admit that even with her, I still looked to other girls to fulfil my self esteem, in forms of flirting or whatsoever. I enjoyed talking to numerous girls especially when I know they are interested in talking to me as well. However, it was different in my second relationship. I was no longer interested in 'flirting' with other girls, they no longer make me happier. I know that I do not want to be caught in a situation where I feel stuck; continue these flirting conversations but hiding them from my gf. The flirting conversations no longer serve any purpose at all, other than being a burden to my relationship. And I realised that it had to do with my determination to commit to the two girlfriends at the different points of time. So, maybe you should ask yourself whether you really want this relationship, to really commit to it, and if you really want your current girl? Because the fact that you are asking those questions simply show that you're not sure enough. I am not saying you cannot have female friends, but know your limits. And obviously you already know that your conversations with the girls are flirting, then why would you still do it?

In a fully committed relationship, you should know when and what to put a stop to. The moment you decide to commit in a relationship, other girls shouldn't even enter your mind easily. You also mentioned that it's the girl who flirts with you even though you try to ignore her at times. Do you honestly think that that is a good excuse at all? You mean there is no other way to stop her from flirting other than to flirt back since you already 'tried' to ignore her sometimes. Come on. It's like you had sex with another women and you say oh you didn't mean to but they girl keeps seducing you and you already tried pushing her away. Fact is you succumbed it in the end and that's what counts. If you know what the other girl's intention is, which includes flirting, you should fully know that you should not do it because you are in a relationship, you respect your relationship and your girlfriend, and you know your girlfriend would not like it. "My gf does not know about it" is NOT an excuse much less a reason. Likewise, if a guy wants to get close to your girl obviously on intention, and your girl actually flirts back, would you be alright with it? If you tell me yes, you are actually fine with your girl flirting with other guys then maybe your relationship is unique in a way that you have your own rules, and if so, you can ignore whatever I said.

Otherwise, if you actually still enjoy flirting with other girls, maybe you should reconsider your relationship. Save your girlfriend too, stop wasting her time and love.

My two-cents on the whole pre-martial sex debacle: your virginity does not define your morality in any way. It's okay if you've done it/choose to do it, it's okay if you choose not to.

However, as a virgin, I would much rather date, and marry a fellow virgin, who is also saving it for after marriage. Not that non-virgins are "damaged goods" and/or immoral (I'm sure we are way past this discussion already - not to mention virginity is a social construct, anyway), but because of the other reasons: diseases is one of them (but there's safe sex/condoms, so okay; fine), but also because I would much rather share something so special; so intimate; such an emotionally loaded act with somebody who will treasure his/her first time as well, instead of somebody who has already slept around/see it as... nothing much; as a casual thing. Also because we could explore our sexualities together as both inexperienced people, that kind of thing. (Even if it could include a lot of awkward fumbling, haha. But I think it would still be exciting all the same, doing it with somebody you love.)

Somebody raised a very good point on how relationships are not supposed to be like business transactions (ie. if I give you my virginity, I must have yours too; if I give you a $500 gift, you must give me a $500 gift too, that kind of thing), but as  might perhaps understand too, it's an... indescribable feeling. (For me, it's disappointment, maybe? Like somebody already has experience/a basis of comparison... Maybe this reeks of insecurity, but I would like to share my first with somebody who still has his/her first, too - there is so much significance attached to such an emotionally loaded act, and I hope I'd find somebody who feels the same about this, too.)

In the light of these pre-marital sex debates, I just want to point out that it isn't just about the two extremes: those who keep their virginity till marriage and those who like to play around and have fun sex. 

I feel quite uncomfortable as I lie in between these two extremes. I had sex before marriage not because I didn't respect my own body and cherish my virginity, but because I thought I found someone that I would love for the rest of my live. However, it turned out that the relationship didn't end up as well as I thought it would. Everyone makes mistakes, right?

And as someone who is quite traditional and conservative, I had a hard time trying to face the fact that I didn't save my virginity for my marriage partner. Now that I have 'forgiven' myself, I just want to say: We shouldn't be too harsh/strict on ourselves as well as our future partners as some things might not turn out the way you want them to be.

I've always told myself to be a strong person. For my family, for my friends, for my past S/O's. I've always portrayed myself that way too, and it wasn't difficult at all, though I've had to put up a false front occasionally. It was always straightforward: how to emote. Be happy for a joyous occasion, be sad for a potentially depressing occasion, be devastated over an unfair situation, etc.

I've never had to deal with loss before. My grandparents passed on when I was too young to understand anything. So did most of my senior relatives. All my living relatives are below 60 and expected to live for years more. Of course, I had my fair share of attending funerals of my friends' parents/grandparents, but that's it.

Recently, my dad felt some discomfort in his chest and as advised, he decided to go for an X-ray. It was bad news. Chest X-ray showed a growth in his lung, confirmed by a follow-up CT scan. I'm afraid that my identity might be exposed if I reveal too much, but let's say that my dad lived a fairly average health sort of life. A bit of vice and a bit of fitness.

As I await further testing and results, I'm not sure what I should be feeling? It's best described as a mixture of hopefulness that everything will be alright plus anticipation of immense sadness if something more serious is diagnosed. The doctors have already advised that it should be C unless diagnosed otherwise, and told us to brace ourselves for the worst. 

This is a brand new experience for me and this whole emotional instability is really affecting me psychologically. Can anyone who has experience with close relatives encountering/overcoming/succumbing to C please share some ways you coped with it and advise me on the best that I can do? Apart from supporting my dad and making him happy in any way possible..

All the talk about premarital sex got me in deep thoughts about it. TLDR; I DO NOT support it even though you might call me a hypocrite.

I was young and foolish and fell head over heels for a guy that wasn't even mine. He was my best friend, we hung out a lot and I haboured thoughts of getting together all the time. I'd do anything to make him happy even if it hurts that I received no reciprocation or inkling that he's felt the same way, all except sex.

Another friend suggested I should give in to his advances, to which I was (and still am) feverntly against it. But... "anything to make him happy"... right..? Wrong.
We nearly went all the way one night with protection... and we had a scare when that time of the month was delayed. 

We fought and argued so badly because neither one of us was mature enough to even think that such responsibility suddenly thrown upon us was possible. Our friendship was gone in that split second. How much of a coward we both were was demeaning and disgusting. It left us broken.

Sex can be pleasurable, yes. It may seem like the in thing to do because we are seen as more liberal. But from personal experience, I regret it so much. Legal age doesn't equate to maturity, but how one handles being thrown in the deep end of responsibility does.

Marriage does just that. It is a legal public declaration of love between 2 human beings that in sickness or in health, in the good and the bad they will support one another. It's about sacrifice in love. You're responsible for that other human being (and smaller humans in the future) who is probably just as awesome as you.

Yeah sure bgr kinda does that responsibility-thingyums and 'we are mature enough to decide' too, but the moment things grow bad, they break down so much faster without as many consequences, which us why divorces can be really terrible because it tears that very contract built in love for years and torn by 'unsolvable differences'.

It's your choice, I'm not telling you how to live your lives. I'm not judging anyone or else I'd be judged myself. I'm pleading, appealing to those who are keeping yourself for someone who is mature and responsible for you, who loves you (not just the sex). Hope you all find what you're looking for. (Sex or none at all)
-
 
I want to confess about my life. But the problem is that I really need help, but am not sure who I can ask for help. I don't know who's my friend or enemy anymore.

People who were once close to me have backstabbed me in ways I cannot imagine. All that remains of a friend I used to call close are two creatures (maybe three) that will never move except if someone moves them. The batchmates who I could talk to have all but become distant away.

You may never know I am crying, or smiling, even if my countenance proves otherwise. But I can cry and smile. It is just that the constant judging of people around me makes it impossible for me to trust people around me excessively. I will never know when my emotions will be seen as a sign of weakness for an opportunist to exploit.

Twice in a row in the same place I met supposedly close friends who eventually turned out to erase me from their lives mysteriously. The cynic in you will tell me to reflect. I did. But I asked why I can make many "non-close" friends, but making close friends that won't backstab is so difficult. Or do I have such poor judgement ability?

I am sorry if you think I am mentally screwed up. You will think I either cannot hold onto friends or have a personality that is so revolting. But I think I am still struggling to emerge from a few friendship and relationship-related traumas. So maybe you are right, I am mentally screwed up.

If you know the confessor, do not tag. Even if you do the confessor will never respond to you. But know that the confessor is human.

I don't know what possessed me to post something like this on NUSWhispers but I shall just share my melodrama here.

I just moved into hall accommodation this year as a freshie and fell head over heels in love with a girl at first sight. Yeah, shallow and superficial but I'm 21 so please give me a break.

She is pretty; really pretty in the delicate sort of way, you know, the pale, fragile, doll-like sort. She really stood out during beach day when the glaring sun made her super fair skin glow like a freaking fairy (probably with lots of my self-imposed filters but damn, girl). I didn't even know her type was my type until I saw her. I realized I was always watching her, always noticing her. Like a stalker, yes, but I can't help it. I always watched her throughout camp, during IBG, when I happen to see her during dinner.

The closest encounter I had with her was when she sat somewhat close to my block during dinner and we randomly included her (it was right after orientation camp and everyone was still in overly-friendly mode) when everyone was saying their 'Traffic Light' color. Evergreen. She hasn't dated before and I couldn't believe it. There was certainly some happiness there -- that I could be her special 'first' if I ever grew some balls and talked to her -- but also, a lot of doubt.

I fear I'm not good enough for her. I'd three relationships before and slept around a bit. This girl, on the other hand, would frown in a slightly perplexed and confused manner at whatever sexual jokes we cracked or innuendos we made, whispering to the person next to her and asking for an explanation. She's super pure. If it was an act, it's a good one.

I wish she'd never change, though I know it's impossible. Who am I, anyway, to wish for it? 'Til now, I have yet to even talked to her.

Is it possible to fall so hard in love without ever talking to that person before?
She probably doesn't even know I exist. Even though I've been through three relationships, I don't think I have the faintest clue what love is.

I'm a freshie and although it's only four days into the semester the experience has not been positive for most parts. I’m always alone most of the time. I have no friends. I have no idea what I’m doing. I don’t know how to use the reserved readings in the library. I don't even know where the canteen is. And I keep getting rejected for modules. I’m already paying so much for an education but yet I'm still being controlled as to what I can study. Because of this I have to go to a lecture tomorrow for a module that I chose as a last minute decision just to meet the minimum 18MCs requirement, which I still don't know if I'll get accepted. This would be my second time submitting a appeal. I'll probably be behind everyone else. And I would still have to reshuffle my tutorial slots.

Like as if I don’t have enough on my plate. All this uni drama will just probably make my anxiety worse. I’ve been crying myself to sleep lately. Not to mention that I relapsed again last month. There goes the new year resolution to be clean for a year. Only made it 7 months. 

And there’s this whole thing about sexuality and relationships and stuff. I’m not one to put labels but sometimes I honestly wonder if I’m just not straight or bi (I refuse to use the g word because it has been used as an insult so much that I feel uncomfortable using it). And this has been quite prominent over the course of these few months. I've been trying to figure out if I have legitimate feelings for this particular girl or is it just because I finally found someone who understands, connects and gets along with me so well. I can imagine being in a relationship with her. She is beautiful to me but unfortunately I'm not sexually attracted to her. I never confessed to her. I made the decision not to pursue it further because I feel it's not fair to her and to myself if I can't give all of me to the relationship. By the time I made the decision, I discovered that she found a boyfriend. I still enjoy hanging out with her but sometimes I can't help but think about what might have been. There's also the issue with my parents. They are quite religious and I have tried dropping hints. I'm pretty sure my mum knows what I'm referring to but we never discussed it in particular. I just need a solid indication from them that they'll accept me for who I am. All this time, I feel that they don't know the real me.

This leads me to the issue of being alone. I’d like to think that it’ll happen when the time is right but sometimes I can’t help wondering if I’m really that terrible of a person undeserving of love. Am I really not enough and that repulsive? I feel that it has reached a level where I feel desperate. I even started using those dating apps, which I never saw myself resorting to. But then, sometimes I feel it’s unfair to the other person if I ever get into a relationship, especially with all the personal drama I’m facing and my family problems. The relationship between my mum and dad have been quite rocky since the end of last year.

Idk man, i just needed to get this out of my chest. Sorry for the long post. You know you reached a new low in life when you’re watching adult videos and you’re crying. I have gone for counselling before while I was in ns but I feel that it doesn't help much. Life feels like one problem after another. I have finally came to terms with accepting myself for who I am, which I struggled with so much during my jc days. Now I have to deal with this. When will I ever catch a break and actually enjoy life? One where I actually look forward to the next day?

Sigh, so in a nutshell, this is what happened:

I have been seeing a white guy for the past 1 year. A few days ago, I found out that he has kissed other women since meeting me, and by his own admission, he would have slept with them too had he been more sex-oriented.

Before I go on, I just want to make one thing clear: we were never gf-bf. Because of our age difference and the different stages of life that we're in, we realized after a few months of being together that a proper relationship would never work out.

But... what bothers me is that he was with other women even before we realized that we would never work out as partners. So he was kissing other women and sleeping with me. He went on vacation where he kissed a couple of women (all strangers), and throughout the vacation he was texting me that he missed me etc.

I know men -- and some women too -- are brilliant at compartmentalizing, but how is it possible to be in an intimate relationship and have it mean nothing? I know this wasn't intentional: he had no intention of betraying me. He simply didn't think we were exclusive and that it was okay to "court" me (at that time we hadn't realized that a real relationship wouldn't work) and be with other women too.

This brings me to the following question: what the hell do non-exclusive relationships even mean?

With most Singaporeans (correct me if I'm wrong), if you're sleeping with the person in a non-casual manner, it's already assumed that you're exclusive. If you genuinely care about someone and you're telling them that you miss them etc., and you're actually behaving like you're in a relationship, do the words "be my gf/bf" actually matter?

It seems that with westerners, those words actually mean something. There is no such thing as simply assuming something.

Had I known he was with other women, I would have never ever continued any sort of relation with him.

This was a good, caring man. He wasn't a young, hormonal teenager who just wants to sleep with women. Yet he did this... and somehow he thinks he did nothing wrong.

Is this simply a difference in culture and values? Or am I just overreacting?
