-
 
I was 18 when I broke up with my long distance boyfriend of close to 2 years. I thought things between us would work out but sadly, it didn't. He cheated on me with another girl in his school and it left me heartbroken. Being upset and irrational, I started dating another guy friend that I had known for a few years after he confessed to me that he liked me. He too had just broken up with his girlfriend, and I suppose we both took each other as rebounds. 

On the second day, he came to fetch me from work and send me home. Things between us seemed fine, until the next day. He came to fetch me from work again, and when we were in the lift, he tried to touch me while we were kissing. I refused and pushed his hands away. But after a while he tried his luck again, but good thing I still had my senses about me and pushed him away again. After this time, I stepped away from him and rushed home by myself. Later that night, he texted me to break up with me. The incident was a traumatic experience that haunted me for a few months, before I finally managed to step out of it with the help of a close friend. From then on, I realised how stupid I had been to get into a rebound relationship without realising its potential to hurt me. 

Thankfully, I was glad that later in life I found someone who truly loved me for who I am. He was the close friend that helped me overcome the trauma. We have been dating for more than a year now and I am living in bliss. He made me recover my confidence in love and I am truly grateful that he came into my life.

To all out there, I hope that no matter what happens in your life, never lose hope.

to 

op of the broken relationship..

i can only say, both of you need to learn how to listen to each other, and not just hear. look at each other, not just glance. speak with each other, not just talk. connect with each other, not just meet.

i got too comfortable with my relationship. both of us stopped doing things we used to. that was the bane of my relationship.
please do not let that happen to yours too.

after getting in this relationship. i now understand that there is no such thing as a perfect partner. she was never my ideal body type, she did not have an ideal face. but yet, she is still the only want i want in my life. because we've been through so much together, we've always worked things out together. we were there for each other. its really the little things that we do for each other that really matters.

but i screwed my relationship up. and now i have no idea how to fix it anymore no matter how much i want to..so please. work things out with your partner. treasure each other. please do not let a third party ruin the things you two share..

if u need to end things. end it because both of you agree that there is nothing left between you two..please. do not end it because of someone else..

 sounds weird but i was in a very similar position as you a few years ago. What did i do? I went with the other boy instead. 

What i did was i really thought long and hard about my future with thenbf and really it was going nowhere. Also, i found out later on that the lack of contact wasn't because he was busy. He had time for other people and other girls but i was not a priority. Red flag right there so i broke it off (yes during his NS as well).

With that being said, if you do choose to break up with bf after thinking it through, dont immediately get with other guy k. He seems like a nice guy he shouldn't be your rebound. Ask him for some time. At the same time, you can test out his character too. 

All the best and take care! You may feel very stressed right now but in time, you will look back on this and find it pretty amusing. (:

To 

When I read your post, it hit me right in my heart. I am now lifeless and sad around my boyfriend of 2 years. 

Things have been well. Conflicts were minimal; I could even count it with a hand. However, we began to talk lesser and lesser as we were busy with our own lives. We always made excuses of "oh, I don't want to disturb you cos i thought you're busy", etc. etc. Initially, I loved how considerate he was as I was really having a hard time juggling between hall activities and school work. However, little did I know that it would meant that good morning and good night messages would cease. Little did I know that random pokes and messages of love would slowly appearing on my phone screen. I know that he is busy with his NS duties, and that reception sucks in red zone areas, but I missed him so much. I feel so unloved and neglected when days could go by when there's little to no messages were received. I know I should also take the initiative to talk to him daily, and I did try (and I felt like I was being a nuisance instead). I've talked to him about these and... no actions were taken. 

Our relationship hasn't even reached a peak yet and the fizzle is already gone. Holding of hands and hugs were initiated by me. And that's it. Our relationship is so... clean and pure. I feel like we are just confused close friends with no lines were crossed. I've talked to him about it and I always ask him to be physical with me but he doesn't want to. (cos he says he is shy. :( ) I got so frustrated that I decided to conduct a little test. I stopped holding his hand. I stopped hugging him. We have not done these... for maybe 7 months already? He didn't even say a thing. And I grew more frustrated and desperate.

Anyways, this story continues on where one of my close guy friend confessed to me and I'm feeling so lost right now. 
Firstly, I don't want to break up with shyboyfriend_01 to go with anotherboy_02. I feel like I'm committing a sin each time I talk to anotherboy_02, cos I feel happy with the latter. I feel like I'm cheating on shyboyfriend_01. anotherboy_02 said he'll wait for me to settle my relationship as he knew about the situation and that he has been looking for a girl like me cos we just click so well. (T.T so touched but I also dk if he is the one for me.)

Secondly, I want to be there for shyboyfriend_01 through his NS life and help him integrate into university life better. The idea of breaking up with me scares me as I seriously don't want him to be sad. I don't want to be the cause of him being sad. 

Lastly, I feel very irritated about this as friends who knew of the situation are all pushing for a break-up. They said he isn't the guy for me, our personalities clash, I deserve someone better. But, the heart wants want it wants... I liked him and he liked me. It's just that this relationship is dying and none of us are taking any actions. 

In conclusion, to , i'm just offering you my side of my story cos I feel like I'm acting like your current gf now. I know it might not offer much condolence, but do know that you're not suffering in this alone. I don't know what to do if I lose him, and I don't know what to do to keep him. Sometimes, I think you just need to take a break and think about what you really want in life. Talk to her about this. If she decided to make a change for you, then put in effort and allow your love to rekindle. If not, I guess you're just another lost soul like me. 

Cheers and jiayou mkay?

To 

I read your confession just yesterday, and I know how you feel, honestly I do. IWhen I joined NUS, I decided I had to join a club/group otherwise I wouldn't get the "full Uni experience", and jusst like you, I have really bad confidence issues and social anxiety. I love music, but I'm too afraid to sing in front of people, no matter who they are. I can't even sing in front of my family or friends once I'm handed a mic. 

When I attended my year's SLF, I remember thinking that I was never going to go back to what I did through sec school & JC, no matter how much I loved it. Instead, I told myself I'd try for a club that I had to sing in. Ever since young, my family's been telling me that I can't sing, as compared to my siblings who sing really well, but I decided heck it I'll try anyway. Nothing ventured, nothing gained right? At the very least, I wanted to push myself out of my comfort zone and try something I really, really enjoyed but never had the guts to try. Isn't that what being in university's about? 

So I did. I auditioned for several groups, one of which was Resonance, the others I shan't disclose. Let me tell you, walking into the audition rooms, I was so afraid, I was shaking like a leaf. I started my song on the wrong note and tried my best not to forget the lyrics, and was so relieved just to finish singing. When they asked me to follow the short tunes they played on the piano, I was so afraid of hitting the high notes that I kept shaking my head and going "I can't do it", but all the panel did was smile and encourage me, telling me "no no it's good! Just try!" When I did hit the notes, they smiled and one guy told me "See! You can do it, it was good!" Everyone was so encouraging and it was honestly such a confidence booster just knowing that I voluntarily walked in, finished an audition, and while I certainly didn't nail it, me not breaking down and crying in the middle of the audition was a win in and of itself.

I got into one of those groups, and the people there are extremely encouraging. I know I'm not the best singer, so I work really hard to prove myself, and everyone wrong. I'm not a fast learner, and I'm not all too talented but I try my best, I have fun, and I've had zero regrets. I only want to improve myself, and hopefully day by day, I'll get better at singing, at being on stage, and I won't be so afraid, even if it's a slow process. 

Try new things you'd never thought you could do, and try the things you always wanted to but never could bring yourself to. Trust me when I say that if you try, you won't regret it. There's honestly nothing to lose, and no one is going to laugh at you. In the worst case scenario, you don't get it. So what? Audition for something else. Come back next year and audition again. There's really no issue. In the best case scenario, you try something new, you find something you enjoy, and you make great friends who will learn and grow alongside you. Friends you can smile at across the stage and feel reassured by. 

I guess, at the very least, I want you to know this: that someone somewhere on campus is rooting for you, if not for you to get into Resonance, then at least for you to find something you enjoy doing. Please go for the audition, do it for yourself. I wish you all the best.

-
 
Throughout my entire school life I never thought that I would fall in love, because I always thought I was different from others. Since primary school I was the girl who was always teased. I was never a pretty, funny or smart person, and because of this I was always left out of the "cool" cliques. But I gradually became okay with that, I had friends that I could hang out with when I needed to and I gradually became okay with being alone and being excluded. When I wasnt in school or with friends, being alone became a time of peace and reflection instead of sadness and loneliness.
So I thought: "Its okay if I don't find anyone who likes me, because im okay with myself", and I became the kind of girl who listens instead of talks, who never becomes emotionally affected by anything to the point she's the one who can give sound advice and support to her friends who need it. A person who listens to your drama but never has her own.

But when I was in JC I met someone, and didnt realise I was starting to fall for him until we were nearing As. At the point in time my results were really bad, so I decided to focus on studies and not let my emotions get the better of me, and I waited for the feelings to pass. But they didnt, and sometimes I would cry myself to sleep because I was so afraid of falling in love and was at a loss of what to do.

After our exams we planned a meet up together with some friends, and after months of praying I decided to use this opportunity to confess. I was a quiet and shy person, so all that I could muster was a letter. And usually its the guy who confesses but I was just like "heck it, I want to say this to him too much to care"

But we had dinner that night, and before I passed him the letter he told us that he'd confessed to someone else. She was someone from our school and the many times I walked by the both of them when they were studying together, it never occurred to me that they were more than friends.

And the ache in my heart at that point in time was indescribable, because before I even gave him the letter I got my answer, rejection before I even confessed. All this time I was in love was so painful, but at least I could imagine about us being together, and think about not being alone anymore.

I've been trying to forget, but its so difficult to let go. Because he's really one in a million, and unlike anyone I'd ever met before. And also because it was the first time I fell hard for anyone.

I havent met him since that dinner we had, him being in NS and me in uni has put distance between us. After awhile I thought my feelings for him had waned, and I told myself to treat it like a passing crush. But he recently posted a photo of him and the girl he liked, together at OCS social night, and all the ache suddenly just came back all at once and I cried for the first time ever since I told myself that I would let go.

Im not really smart or witty or pretty like she is, neither am I super kind or driven like him. Im nowhere, and until I fell in love I was okay with that, just being me. Now, after everything, im not really sure anymore.

-
 
So I finally crossed paths with my ex at my workplace after 3 years. Since we parted ways I've always wondered how I would react to her reappearance again. All I did, quite pathetically, was tapped on her shoulder and uttered a measly "hi". Even as I walked away, my heart was pounding frantically, as if back to the first time we met after my fateful confession.

She was my first love and every shade the dream girlfriend as a teenager I yearned to have. We were also our class' model couple, and received heaps of marriage invitations as if everyone expected us to pull it off eventually. We were also inseparable throughout secondary school and JC; she was there through the lowest points in my life, and so was I for hers. But as it turned out, we grew apart and ultimately went our separate ways.

As far as I know, she's relishing a life of familial bliss now, married and happily raising a son - a future we had once envisioned as a couple. To be honest, I'm just a tad little envious, but mostly happy that she realised her dream. As of me, it has been a rough journey since 3 years ago. The gaping hole that she left behind remains to be filled. There is this girl I met in CCA that caught my attention, but for reasons unbeknownst even to myself I haven't been able to summon enough courage to even strike up a conversation with her, much less start a new relationship. Once bitten, twice shy, perhaps?

To all budding, first-time couples out there: don't be afraid to devote your all in a relationship. Even if it doesn't work out in the end, you would have written a exhilarating chapter in your life - that of first love. There will be countless regrets, and I dare say, they are even inevitable. But the one thing not matched by subsequent relationships is the naive, innocent and pure romanticisation of love; a signpost you will look back later for guidance as you try to navigate romance in the harsh, real world.

To P, I'm thankful for everything. Really.

I have no idea when I started feeling this way. Maybe it was when my latest ex whom I loved so deeply, shattered my beliefs of love when he chose to walk away. Maybe it was when i noticed that my current bf has been giving up on the relationship. Maybe it was when I started to give up on myself, give up on the fact that I'm actually capable of loving someone right and in receiving love.

3)A man care alot about a girl's look because man  are biologically hard wired to like fertile woman and a man can tell alot about a girl's fertility through her look.

This is my theory. Don't settle for just some plain jane. Target those very attractive one. This will make you appear uninterested in those less attractive one which in turn make you to appear less needy in front of them.

Girls don't like needy guy.

Basically, aim for the moon(those attractive one), even if you miss it, you will fall among the star(appearing less needy)

To , I think you'd be interested to know that I take a long time to reply someone's message, and the longest time to reply my crush's messages. When I reply people, I will put in effort in crafting my response which requires time – some may think that this is ridiculous, but I feel that people would appreciate receiving something well thought out, than something that took no more than a second to vomit out. Of course, it does depend on the nature of the question or whatever the other person said, but nevertheless, I am not one who will shoot back a one word reply. 

Furthermore, I am rarely someone who enjoys constant communication through online texting – and by constant, I mean having to reply someone as soon as I receive their message, and them replying almost immediately (and the cycle continues). I find that extremely tiring. I don't want to live a life where it doesn't matter where I physically am, I'm always hooked on my phone replying people's messages. For example, I may be at the Botanic Gardens – I'd want to enjoy the actual nature than to have to engage in a conversation about how beautiful it is with people through texting, to the point where I'm actually there the whole time staring at my phone discussing about how beautiful the place is than actually basking in its beauty.

I feel that some people don't appreciate pauses – or rather, delays – in text conversations enough. Since when has quantity been more important than quality? I know many people will disagree with what I say, but it's okay. You have your own opinions and I have mine. But to say that I'm not interested in my crush purely because of the length of time I take to reply my crush's message is stupid, because that reasoning is too logical and narrow thinking. I understand how it came about though, but I still don't believe that my speed at replying you is a good way to gauge nor is an appropriate determining factor to use to conclude my interest in you, and I think I am a good example of it.

So it's been a week of a new semester. And it's been quiet. 
No more lunches after lecture, no more eye rolling or cringing at terrible jokes. No more conversations about frivolous topics.

Don't get me wrong, I am not adverse to silence, in fact I like the quiet. I always have; even in the midst of laughter I sometimes wish for things to be quiet. I appreciated the company, but I also enjoyed the breaks in between when we didn't have to meet one another. 

Our group dynamics have evolved over the years since we were friends in junior college, and it is no longer what it was. Our expectations have changed, our priorities have shifted. That's good, it means we are growing. But it also meant that I also did not have to hold on to this group as closely as I once did. And so, since the end of the first year, I have told myself to simply let things be, and slowly let it go. But in the mean time while we are still in close proximity, I'll play along and enjoy my breaks of quiet on the side. "I will get more quiet soon" I told myself.

And hence, I thought my entry into the 3rd year would be a good chance to enjoy more quiet. After all, we are all taking different modules, different specialisations, some of us aren't even in the same country at this point. And when I thought it would be nice to have a change of pace, I instead found myself rather lonely at the end of the first week.

I don't wish to say I bring it upon myself since I was never very committed to the group relationship we all had, but I will admit that I have been a little bit complacent in terms of my social life. Perhaps "taking things for granted" would be a better way to put it. 

So here I am, liking my newfound space, but still finding it achingly empty. The quiet is nice for me, until I remember that in the quiet I can hear myself think. And the thoughts aren't always nice.

Basically there are four types of girls:
1) Fuck no- the fat, short and ugly looking ones 
2) Not really- the plain Jane who doesn't really maintain her shape but better looking relative to the ugly girl, but below average nonetheless
3) Yes- the average to a little above average looking ones 
4) Fuck Yes- the gorgeous/cute/sexy/fit ones 

On the other hand, there are also four kinds of guys:
1) Fuck no- the socially awkward, fat and ugly looking ones 
2) Not really- the average looking but college wallflower kind 
3) Yes- the fashionable, tall, sociable, above average looking ones 
4) Fuck Yes- Rich, good looking, smart, charismatic kind

Personally, I think I'm between a 2 and a 3. Most of us singletons are probably in this region in the dating world. Therefore, do things to improve yourself. Read more, go to the gym more often, and be kind and bitch less.

Otherwise, your dream girl/ guy will just and will always be a dream

I'm 21 this year. I've been with my boyfriend since JC1. I was 19 when I got pregnant. I chose to go for an abortion. I never told him about the baby or the abortion. I knew he would have wanted me to keep it. He was that kind of guy who would have done the right thing and taken responsibility. I wanted the baby too, but it was bad timing. He was in NS, due to start school in NUS, and I was already in NUS at the time. I made the decision to abort even though every fiber of my being told me not to. I paid a taxi driver $80 for his time and to make sure that I got home safe after the procedure.

Every year, on the 14th of August, today, I feel guilt and sadness. The kind that feels overwhelming that I find it hard to get through my day. Today,  two years ago, was the day I got my abortion. I never knew my baby's gender, but I chose Sam for the name itself was ambiguous. I miss you so much, Sam, I'm so, so sorry. Not here, but loved and remembered all the same for the rest of my life.
-
 
 people joke may joke about this, but there might actually be some truth to this. I've used tinder for somewhile now and many girls I've spoken to around the 23ish to 26ish years old say the same thing. Just graduated, holding their first job, hard to meet guys either due to the lack of guys in their workplace or they are trying to avoid workplace relationships. When asked if they dated in uni they either say it wasn't serious/didn't work out or they were focusing on studies. Personal friends have also shared similar concerns. 

Of course it depends on what industry you are in. There's also a skew in my example since well, it's tinder. I personally think this applies to guys too. Basically working life gives you less time and energy to date. 

But if I were to give advice to either gender, it wouldn't be to cling on to whoever you know university. Some people (like me) use tinder to meet new people. But if that's not your thing, try taking up some sort of hobby with a large community that you can continue doing when you get older as well. Cycling for example? You see large groups of working adults cycling around Singapore now and then. Community choirs are another, and some really don't require you to have much experience. These activities would let you meet many other people outside your workplace. 
Furthermore, people with a hobby/interest are generally more interesting and attractive too. 
Worst come to worst, if you don't meet anyone, you at least have a hobby and some friends for work-life balance.

I'm still trying to get over him but I think to most people, I seem stupid. But things like 'feelings' and 'love' are hard to explain sometimes. I'm getting married next year, and even though I love my current boyfriend very much and am 100% committed, there is still some regret and sadness due to my FWB. An Ode to the Nice Guys
This rant was written for the Wharton Undergraduate Journal
This is a tribute to the nice guys. The nice guys that finish last, that never become more than friends, that endure hours of whining and bitching about what assholes guys are, while disproving the very point. This is dedicated to those guys who always provide a shoulder to lean on but restrain themselves to tentative hugs, those guys who hold open doors and give reassuring pats on the back and sit patiently outside the changing room at department stores. This is in honor of the guys that obligingly reiterate how cute/beautiful/smart/funny/sexy their female friends are at the appropriate moment, because they know most girls need that litany of support. This is in honor of the guys with open minds, with laid-back attitudes, with honest concern. This is in honor of the guys who respect a girl’s every facet, from her privacy to her theology to her clothing style.

This is for the guys who escort their drunk, bewildered female friends back from parties and never take advantage once they’re at her door, for the guys who accompany girls to bars as buffers against the rest of the creepy male population, for the guys who know a girl is fishing for compliments but give them out anyway, for the guys who always play by the rules in a game where the rules favor cheaters, for the guys who are accredited as boyfriend material but somehow don’t end up being boyfriends, for all the nice guys who are overlooked, underestimated, and unappreciated, for all the nice guys who are manipulated, misled, and unjustly abandoned, this is for you.

This is for that time she left 40 urgent messages on your cell phone, and when you called her back, she spent three hours painstakingly dissecting two sentences her boyfriend said to her over dinner. And even though you thought her boyfriend was a chump and a jerk, you assured her that it was all ok and she shouldn’t worry about it. This is for that time she interrupted the best killing spree you’d ever orchestrated in GTA3 to rant about a rumor that romantically linked her and the guy she thinks is the most repulsive person in the world. And even though you thought it was immature and you had nothing against the guy, you paused the game for two hours and helped her concoct a counter-rumor to spread around the floor. This is also for that time she didn’t have a date, so after numerous vows that there was nothing “serious” between the two of you, she dragged you to a party where you knew nobody, the beer was awful, and she flirted shamelessly with you, justifying each fit of reckless teasing by announcing to everyone: “oh, but we’re just friends!” And even though you were invited purely as a symbolic warm body for her ego, you went anyways. Because you’re nice like that.

The nice guys don’t often get credit where credit is due. And perhaps more disturbing, the nice guys don’t seem to get laid as often as they should. And I wish I could logically explain this trend, but I can’t. From what I have observed on campus and what I have learned from talking to friends at other schools and in the workplace, the only conclusion I can form is that many girls are just illogical, manipulative bitches. Many of them claim they just want to date a nice guy, but when presented with such a specimen, they say irrational, confusing things such as “oh, he’s too nice to date” or “he would be a good boyfriend but he’s not for me” or “he already puts up with so much from me, I couldn’t possibly ask him out!” or the most frustrating of all: “no, it would ruin our friendship.” Yet, they continue to lament the lack of datable men in the world, and they expect their too-nice-to-date male friends to sympathize and apologize for the men that are jerks. Sorry, guys, girls like that are beyond my ability to fathom. I can’t figure out why the connection breaks down between what they say (I want a nice guy!) and what they do (I’m going to sleep with this complete ass now!). But one thing I can do, is say that the nice-guy-finishes-last phenomenon doesn’t last forever. There are definitely many girls who grow out of that train of thought and realize they should be dating the nice guys, not taking them for granted. The tricky part is finding those girls, and even trickier, finding the ones that are single.

So, until those girls are found, I propose a toast to all the nice guys. You know who you are, and I know you’re sick of hearing yourself described as ubiquitously nice. But the truth of the matter is, the world needs your patience in the department store, your holding open of doors, your party escorting services, your propensity to be a sucker for a pretty smile. For all the crazy, inane, absurd things you tolerate, for all the situations where you are the faceless, nameless hero, my accolades, my acknowledgement, and my gratitude go out to you. You do have credibility in this society, and your well deserved vindication is coming.

After reading this, Maybe its time for that nice guys to change themselves into the jerks all girls love and adore...

i am slightly above average looking and people are surprised when I tell them I am evergreen. Well let me just say this. Being evergreen can be a choice too. 
-
 
Today, I got a call up interview at Recruit Express. Initially I was overjoy that I got a part time job but do u know what it turns out?
My agent wants to meet me up today but he was on leave today so he randomly throw a colleague to attend me. So, I find it weird and I just fill up my particulars as told. From the moment I walk in, I sense a bad atmosphere.
Like this looks OK not the worst yet.
After that, I just submit my form and they ask lots of personal weird questions giving a sinister smile while not related to work.

I was really disappointed that this recruitment agency treat our careers like a game. I have work for big companies before and I am currently holding on to a diploma. To be treated like a fool is an insult to me. I am sharing this experience in hopes that other job seekers do not fall prey to this scam.

-
 
to the year 1s, mostly, and some year 2s and year 3s, please attend the student life fair with an open mind. the club, sport, or society that you choose will impact you and your uni life more than you know. it sets the pace for your academics, life style and social circle. i challenge you to step out of your comfort zone, join something that you never thought you could accomplish, something you think you might not excel in, or something you think you are excellent in and can share some experience with some newbies.

with no intention to promote my cca, i want to tell you that joining this certain challenging sport with demanding training commitment and physical demands, i actually made the best friends along the way, accomplished more that i ever thought i could, traveled overseas with the best of comarades, and flew the nus flag with pride. it was beyond what i ever thought i could accomplish back when i was super unhealthy and reluctant to move a muscle.

perhaps give a few ccas 2 weeks of your time. just 2 weeks might change 4 years of uni, and the rest of your life.

-
 
to  Hi, I felt a need to reply you. Anxiety is a common issue. The fact that Singapore is a competitive society doesn't help at all. In fact, it may be one of the reasons why most people have anxieties. Some dont even know that they have it. From what I've read, it seems like your anxieties were a result of childhood expectations, and fear. If i am not wrong, you fear failing. You are insecure. You seek security through these numbers and alphabets. It may be a result of parental pressure, or it may be a result of peer pressure. This, only you will know. Overtime, such expectations, fears, become a way of life. It becomes a habit, and it snowballed into the anxieties you face today. 

Most people with untreated anxieties may eventually go on to develop depression. There are many ways that you can help yourself out of it. Some of the suggestions that I am putting forth, may seem ordinary to you, but they have therapeutic effect on the mind. 

1) keep a timetable. Remind yourself how much time you have. Do not look at how much you have to do, but look at how much time you have to do it with proper planning. this way, it will put things into perspective and remind yourself that you still have time to prepare for you exam. 

2) breathe. Take long deep breaths when you find yourself having difficulty breathing or increase in heart rate. take long deep breaths with your nose, and exhale out with your mouth. practice this constantly, it is a great stress reliever. 

3) when you find yourself fearing, paralyzed, than stop. Get yourself away from where you are. go to another room or smth. Find smth that you can touch, and smth that you can smell. Look far out, or focus on something that brings peace to you. Maybe something blue? 

4) talk to a trusted friend. In order for your own treatment to be effective, it'll be good to have a friend to help you through the deepest moments. Anxiety attacks are like deep valleys, its dark and there is no way out. It will be beneficial to have someone that you can find comfort in, to talk to you, and to comfort you. Their presence will help get you back on track faster. It can be your GF/BF or parents. find someone that you can wholeheartedly open up too. 

5) Accept imperfection. No one is perfect. no matter how much we prepare for an exam, we can never be 100% prepared. The greatest lesson is not learnt from the marks you gained but the marks you lost. Remind yourself, that life is a journey of learning. Ultimately, the greatest teacher, is failure. Constantly remind yourself that you are in the university to learn, and to be better. 

6) Seek professional help. I place this last for a reason. Many people fear getting professional help. It can be for various reasons, some will fear being judged, some feel uncomfortable with a stranger knowing the deepest part of you (link to insecurities). Professionals are trained to help you, they are your best source of advice and help. Find a therapist/psychologist that you are comfortable with. if you cant get yourself to find professional help, you can confide in your closest companion. However, do ensure that your companion does adequate reading to know some techniques of helping you. You do not have to go through it alone. 

Love yourself. It is not all dark and gloomy. you are still young, you have a long way ahead.   

Im sorry for the long post. But this is the only way I can offer my 2 cents to you. I hope this is of help to you, and to any other that is reading this. 

Thank you.

She wanted a Christian boyfriend. I was her second boyfriend, and i was not a christian then. So you see, whatever reasons given by the girl are merely excuses.

We sort of liked one another at that point of time. Before I chased her, I asked her about her long distance relationship. She lied to me that her relationship ended months ago. Recently, i found out that she only broke up with her first boyfriend, months after we begin our relationship. So yes, she was two timing. If i have known that, i would not have chased her.

My ex isn't a simple woman. She is that sort of woman who is never contended. She will do anything to get a scholarship and an award. After graduating from NUS High, she applied for many scholarships. Of course many companies offered her and wanted her to accept the scholarship ASAP. Her method was to accept all scholarships first. After bagging and accepting all the scholarships that she can possibly get, she will choose the best offer and reject the rest. Rejecting a scholarship after acceptance is not simple because you need to pay a penalty. To avoid paying the penalty, she will scrutinize the terms of the scholarship, and make the company withdraw/ terminate the scholarship on their own terms.

So she probably treated me like another scholarship bond. She made me end the relationship on my own terms too. At that point, she knew that i was not comfortable with her mum because i find her overbearing at times. Her mum will only accept me if i do certain things for her. I couldnt really understand because i am someone who can accept another person for who he or she is. Anyway, she told me that her mum was giving her a hard time, and that i did not pray about the relationship, and the relationship ended. And immediately after the relationship ended, she is with this third guy. Yes, and finally she is dating a christian.

After much reflection, I felt that such a girl is not worth it. Many girls like to give reasons like "we are no longer thinking on the same level", "we  have too many difference and personality different too". These arent valid reasons. We are different we are one. A relationship can only be successful if both of you are willing to work on your differences, its about compromise, giving and taking.

As for my ex and your ex, it is unlikely that their present relationship will work out. Why? Because they are unwilling to work on the differences and be on the same level as their partner. At some point in the relationship or marriage, u will realize that u and your partner are very different. (And often these are just an excuse for a change of feeling) 

Anyway, my ex gf's past relationships never lasted more than a year. And this should be a red flag for all guys. Never be too serious about a girl who dates so casually and changes so quickly. She is from computing and treats the search for a partner like an algorithm. I hope you can learn from my experience.

My girlfriend broke up with me. I really love her a lot. However, our lifestyles cannot match each other because she is a staunch Christian while I am a Taoist due to my family background. We met since poly as we're from the same CCA, we got along well and became an item. We have meaningful time with each other. We never fail to meet up daily.

Yet, about a year ago, I felt we were drifting apart when she joined a church via a schoolmate and she became a Christian and became very active in her church activities. Soon, I only met her once a week, or maybe once in two weeks. I tried calling her and messaging her on the other days, however these conversations were short and it felt like she was always rushing to do something. When I asked her to go out with me, often she said she can't as she had this and that activity. She does church related activities for at least 4 times a week.  I felt hurt as she seem to prioritize those activities more than spending time with me. 

As I wanted to save our relationship, I told her I will like to join her in her church activities. She gladly agreed. Aside from the weekly Sabbath, the activities involved around joining and organizing various cell group meetings with praying, singing and preaching. Although I am not religious myself, I was really happy to be part of those activities because I at least get to do something together with her. Unfortunately, she doesn't seem to appreciate it at all. She seemed annoyed that I joined the activities because of her, and I am not sincerely interested to be part of her church group.

I can hardly find any time alone with her anymore, every time when we even manage to go out together, she'll bring a couple of cell group members with her. It's very damn frustrating! It's a date between you and me, not a cell group meeting or something. Call me selfish, but bringing along those so-called "brothers" and "sisters" of yours is just... unnecessary.

I finally mustered the courage to call her to discuss about my unhappiness. She tried to avoid the conversation, but I firmly told her I cannot pretend to be happy and I cannot live like that. I asked her if our relationship will be better if I become a fervent Christian myself, so we can have the same beliefs, but she said there's no point and she does not want me to force myself to change because of her. So that's it. She suggested we break up. I insisted that I didn't want to, because I love her, but she explained it'll be better for both of us since we are no longer thinking on the same level. That night, I cried like a pussy—shame on me — she gave me the impression that she belittles me by saying I am from a different level.

And after that, we stopped contacting each other. During the NDP, she updated her Facebook with the status of being in a relationship with a guy who I recognized as her cell group mate. It's one of her so-called "brothers". Maybe it's because they're on the "same level". LOL. Nonetheless, I gave her my well-wishes. And she replied, "Thanks." I hope all is well from here onward.

Has anyone here ever dated/married someone of a different religion? Is it possible to live in harmony despite different habits and different lifestyles?

-
 
In light of some entries about being a pathetic loner, if you don't wish to remain that way, there's a few things you can do to be more sociable. 

Err.. I can't say I'm a pro, I used to be a stay-home person and, at that time, I honestly ain't a tiny bit keen on expanding my social circle just because I'm so comfortable in my little bubbles of friends. It is until someday these little bubbles aren't that stable anymore when I decided to observe how sociable people interact and try to learn something while I was in army 2 years ago, yeah?(:

Making friends is a skill, though your personality being an introvert or being a naturally shy person, may make it harder to attain this skill as compared to others. Which is the case for me. But you'll get better with more practice, by not shunning people and think that they'll think badly of you. 

There's this 'shit tests' everyone will do on each other when they engage in a social interaction. These tests form impressions of the person we are interacting with. Failing these tests = they don't want to be friend with chiu. If you pass, then there'll be progress. The trick is not to be easily offended and instead, try to turn everything into a joke, and do a comeback even if the person is being rude (being rude is also a form of shit test). Comeback as in in the form of a joke. A counter. This takes practice though. For guys, I've seen many rude start offs but eventually they treat me with respect a friend ought to deserve. I guess I pass their shit test lah. It's like a test on your mental capability to deal with their jokes. This is from a guy's perspective lah, so it may or may not be applicable to a girl.

If they don't like how you interact with them, then nvm lah, there's always other people you can interact with right. Making mistakes is also part of learning what. By keep on experimenting your style with others, you'll eventually find someone or a group of friends that appreciate your humour.

Some people say they no humour, then watch running man, friends, or Ryan Sylvia lah keke. if you watch long enough, you'll learn a thing or 2. And then of course people naturally don't like pessimism one what, HTHT peeps comes when you have a better understanding of these friends/acquaintances you made, then eventually you 'uprank' them to your bruhs or sis. But you gotta treat them like bruhs and sis first (minus the HTHT part if they never initiate), then people will feel like you're a bruh or sis. You feel me? Is this confusing?
Oh ya, gotta be truthful also lah. I read up on body language and laymen psychology. Some people natural in social skills, but if you need the extra help, why not.

Social skills is like a show to finding real friends, imo. People ask you go out, just go only. Then people will want to ask you out again right, since you so anything. Don't be so troublesome like where to go also can decide 6 hours, it only makes people frustrated and don't wanna organize again.

I know some people would say something like 'just be yourself and you'll eventually find someone you can click with'. But imo, being yourself is not an excuse to not going for social events and try to make friends, that is unless, you want to be left alone lah. 

I know this entry is not gonna change your paradigm instantly, but I wish to like put some hope in you guys. You guys like spiraling down from what I read haha. Pick yourself up man, you guys aren't rejects, you just haven't learn the skills yet. Stepping out of your comfort zone and learning this skill is worth it:D. But once again, if you think you enjoy being alone then is fine lah, not forcing you yo, just an opinion. Ciaos(:

P.S. Korkors please have mercy on my entry): don't lambaste my singlish too much keke.
P.S.S you can do mayor Briggs personality test if you haven't done so to know what type of personality you are. ESFJ here(:

To . Hi there, I just want to tell you that you're not alone. I have been part of big groups and hall groups and I really hate it sometimes. There are too many hi-bye friends and soon you'll realize, they don't matter at all. To be honest, if you're in a whatsapp chat with a group of friends, sometimes they will only respond to the popular kid. The kid who is more kaopei, more funny or what so ever. I too get rejected sometimes but try to find someone in the group you're close to. If you're close to someone in that group, when you suggest something, at least he or she has got your back! It helps! And if they all really reject you, you can go out with him or her! I personally prefer going on 1-1 dates with my bestfriend to chill and talk about life. Instead of going out with 10-20 people talking about nonsense (when really nobody gives a shit what you're talking about, half the time it is about making fun of the joker of the group). 

And yes, learn to love yourself. We all yearn for some form of connection with people but don't rush it. Perhaps you have not met your true friend yet. In the mean time, enjoy a book by yourself or just hang out at a quiet cafe. It can be really nice. Or you can travel! Discover just how beautiful the world is. Few years down the road, you'll realize that your hi-bye friends don't matter.

Hey there, I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling like this. I went to the Rag performance alone too. I even knew people in the Rag group, and even helped out somewhat. On Rag day itself I went down specifically to cheer them on, but when I messaged them I got ignored. Wonderful right? 
A bit of background, I am currently a year 5 student, evergreen.  Most of the friends in my batch have graduated, so now I am surrounded by freshies I know nothing about, due to internship - thus missing rag and fop, and the juniors I used to be close with are now all moving on to become "clique leads" themselves. So while the situation may not be exactly the same, I know where you are. Painfully, painfully so. 
I decided I didn't want to feel like that though.
I decided I would enjoy myself as much as I could, or each moment would have been a waste of time. It may sound cliche, but no one can make you feel anything but yourself. In the case of Rag day, I indulged in some Kebab, and found various groups of friends who went and hung with them each a little. I danced like I didn't care when Christina Grimmie got on stage. In daily life, when planning outings, I name the people I want answers from in the group chat. If people ditch me I go out anyway and enjoy a movie on my own. It's tiring, and really draining at times, I know, but it takes effort to get the things you want. 
Like you wrote, I too feel like there's some part of me that's flawed, that I should be receiving the kind of treatment everywhere I go. But I have faith that as we keep taking those long looks at ourselves, and strive to make better of ourselves, that one day we'll have a breakthrough. 
Chin up and fight on!

Hey , i totally understand how you feel, because i think that is what im going through as well. We are kinda similar, but also kinda different. I also feel super lonely at times, so i just end up staying at home or hiding at one corner so that ppl dont judge me as a "loner with no friends". 

There are many places or things that i wanna go/do, but then i realise that i dont even know who to ask out. Even if i do, I'll just get rejected. Me and my clique are drifting further and further apart, which really saddens me. They are probably the closest group of friends that i have, but might no longer be anymore. Who else can i fall back on? Family? Nope. My family members are all working, they dont have time for me. And also because of the big age gap between me and the rest of them, there seems to be nothing to talk about. 

Since i was a kid, i already felt like i lacked family love because none of them had time for me. Well, i can't completely blame them because they need to work to earn the money for my education, im thankful for that. But also because they are always working and have no time for me, I've always felt super envious of others whom i see having a happy family. When i have troubles, i dont tell my family, because they won't understand anything. So i try to turn to my friends instead. When my clique were still close, I was still okay. But as years go by and we slowly drift apart with some getting attached, some at different unis/courses, it was then i realise that I dont have anyone else. 

When I joined the orientation camp as a freshie, i didnt get to befriend as many ppl as i expected to. In fact, i doubt anyone in my OG still keeps in contact. Im starting year 3 now, and i dont even have anyone that i can really call a "friend", maybe more of "acquaintances". I only hang out with one other friend, but if she's absent, I'll be alone again. This sem, we are no longer taking the exact same mods, so I'm really quite worried that I'll have to loner during certain lessons. 

Im glad to see some ppl commenting to feel free to pm them, etc, but its not as easy to take that step to reveal my identity, which is why I'm ranting anonymously. CCAs take up a lot of time, and I'm already struggling with my acads. Im aware of the nusmeetme thing, but similarly, i really dont want any of my friends/acquaintances to know I'm there because I'll just be labeled as a "despo". Fuck all these insecurities.

At this stage, im about to just give up on making new friends in uni and just get out of this school asap. Uni has taken such a toll on me, i dont know how much longer i can tahan. 

Every night before i sleep, i think about this: No friends/family to depend on/talk to, I'm so pathetic. When will i ever find someone that can understand me and go through the ups and downs with me? 

To the people who have someone like that with you, be grateful and cherish them. Not everyone is as lucky as you are.

-
 
 Dear OP, don't want to sound too harsh but you said you have met 3 girls, and you have encountered this problem every single time, then I think maybe you should reflect on the things you have said and done, maybe you have unexpectedly offended them in one way or another, or have somehow portrayed yourself as a stalker or someone who is desperate. Girls tend to be a bit sensitive sometimes (sorry about that). And when you are talking about meeting up, if you didn't make it clear they are dates, then girls may just consider that as hangout with friends. Late night texts also don't mean anything, it can be that they are just trying to be polite and keep the conversation going. And later on, they might find you a bit bugging, so decided to ignore all your messages. The conversation between you and the girls are also important, if it's always about the same things, and given that they are not interested in you (as a friend or more than friend), it would bore them.
And if you have made your intentions clear to them, then it's quite probable that they don't want to lead you on in any way. And honestly, sometimes I think it's better to not reply to the texts and cancel the plans than giving any false hope.

Truth is, due to health reasons, my parents avoid going to crowded places. They can't stand for too long in the MRT, can't walk continuously for a long time, can't stand in long queues, need to eat at regular timings and need a lot of rest. Anyway, they don't like to go out. Being the only child, I have no one else in my family I can go out with. I don't want to give these explanations so I just say 'yes' when people suggest I go out with my family. 

My parents feel sorry for me and say that I am young and should not be confined to the four walls of the house. They encourage me to go out with my friends. I can't bring myself to tell them that my friends don't love me as much as you do. I am an option for them, not a priority. I get rejected and declined for most of the things I say.

-
 
To  - I used to be the same way, and in some ways, I still am. My problem was that I had too few friends, friends who hated going out, friends who were in relationships, friends who were busy with CCAs, friends who lived I'm another part of campus, or friends I didn't like at all. I used to get quite lonely sometimes, even breaking down and crying occasionally. Whenever I wanted to do something fun, like go out wherever, my friends would decline, and I want confident enough to go alone.

So what has changed?

Well, me.

You have to realize that you cant control what your friends do. You can control what you do, what you say, how you behave. Most of all, you have to learn to love yourself and enjoy your own company. I'm not going to give suggestions like join a club lor, or be more open etc etc. I'm going to tell you what worked for me.

Whenever I felt lonely, I called up my parents or grandparents. Remember, they're probably much lonelier than you and would be overjoyed if you call and talk to them. It feels nice to know that you're loved and needed by someone.

After you've spoken to them, go out for a walk or a run. Best time for introspection.

Next- if you live on campus, go and chill out at the 24 hour lounges/common rooms/Starbucks. You'll be surrounded by people and that decreases loneliness.

I've been part of such groups before, and I hated the experience. If you don't know a lot of people, you're not part of the inside jokes, you feel left out, whatever. At the end of the day, when they Instagram a group photo and tag you, you'll just have an unpleasant recollection of the meetup ( while others think you probably had an awesome time)

I swear, do not trust social media.

Don't worry, you'll be fine.
-
 
I am evergreen, never gone on any dates and always feel upset and envy when seeing couple holding hands. Sometimes, I asked myself if there is anything wrong with me since I am fast approaching 30 and still evergreen ( is it my looks, am I too boring or is it I am too shy to approach girls since I always got rejected by my crush ) I always wonder how happy life will be if I can have a girlfriend whom I can go out with to have a meal, visit attractions and check out the latest cafe and chat the entire day. I think at the very best that can only happen in my dream. Thinking of having a girlfriend in my lifetime seems to be as good as thinking of a visit to our nearest star.
-
 
I think you should ask him directly as well. If he hasn't been getting the hints, what are the chances he will get them if you drop more hints? If he has gotten the hints, don't you want a definite answer and an explanation if it's more complicated than just he's not interested in you?

It's hard to make a deduction that he's interested in you solely on the fact that he talks to you more than he does so to other girls. He may just be concerned about you as a friend and is nice to everyone in general. Or he might just find you to be a good friend to talk to or both.

Pluck up your courage and save yourself the agonies, time and potential future regrets. This goes for everyone and any other aspect of their lives.

I developed a serious crush on my female colleague at work. For a few months, I was literally dreaming every other night about her. I was so smitten with her that I started to do things such as filling up her bottle for her before she arrived at her desk every morning etc. 

I was thinking of ways and means to get closer to her. One day, I was tasked organise a company dinner I asked her for help with the intent of trying to get closer to her. Initially, she didn't decline and was kind enough to help in what I asked. However, as the commitments grew, she started to become uncooperative and extremely annoyed with me. She didn't even want to turn up for the dinner on the day itself even though she told the bosses she was helping me. 

I was so angry with her that I told her the bosses were asking for the namelist of those who would not be attending (which was true). But I did it in a manner that must have made her felt threatened. In any case, she did turn up and did her job during the dinner. But thereafter, she left first, leaving me to pack up everything behind.

The day after, and over the past six months, I gave her the cold shoulder because I was really mad with her.

But as time passed, I know I was the one at fault. I got her to help because I was too selfish to care about her feelings. I asked her to help because I wanted to get close to her. How stupid of me! It was also childish of me to give her the cold shoulder when it was all my fault from the beginning.

I want to apologise to her but I don't know how to do it. I want to say sorry not because I want her forgiveness. I don't deserve it anyway.

I want to do so because she deserves my fullest apologies for the crap she had to go through.

-
 
I cry as I type this, but I need to rant.

You'll probably skip over this post, but I'm just going to write it anyway.

When we were just friends, our friendship was perfect. We had so much fun exploring Singapore together, despite having lived here our whole lives. It was different exploring with you. Everything felt so light, airy and positive, doing simple things together. Food adventures, day trips to Malaysia, dessert, visits to the library, exercising together. Our deep conversations. It was all so simple but yet you were so different from other guys. I was intrigued. Happy. I knew that it was impossible for us to be together because my family would never approve, but I was so content with simply having you as a beautiful soul in my life. We spent so much time together. Naturally, we fell in love. 

You make me feel...safe. You make me feel like I can carry on living this difficult life, like I can face up to the problems of this world that try to knock me down every single day. You're always a Whatsapp text away, you're with me in my darkest moments.

Despite all the safety and quality time that you try your best to give me, I feel like we cannot communicate because of our different upbringings. When I tell you about my quirks, I feel like you listen for that moment, remember it for that day, but let it go after that conversation. In terms of emotional intimacy, I need us to go deeper. I need you to WANT to go deeper. I get enough superficial conversations from my acquaintances, but you're so content with simplicity.

Even though I so desperately want to, I don't know if we can spend the rest of our lives together. You could do so much better in this life with someone else who can support you, who's more emotionally stable. Sometimes, I feel like you're so tired of supporting me and of satisfying my need for constant conversation. I'm so sorry for demanding more than you have to give. I'll try my best to stop. I'll find that somewhere else.

I'm imperfect and troublesome. Every now and then, I'm filled with self-loathing. In these moments, I wonder how I can fully love someone if I can't even love myself.

No matter what happens, know that I love you very deeply. You are my first love, my deepest love, my best friend. For you fighting so hard to make this work - thank you a thousand times. If I ever leave, it's because I genuinely want the best for you and your family. I think you deserve a girl who can make you happy most of the time. Life is too short and I don't want you to spend yours settling for second best.

I love you so much my dear. I always will, no matter what happens to us.

-
 
Hi! I have a story to tell, its not very interesting but it might be worth a read for everyone facing relationship problems. I don’t claim to be right or wrong, nor do I know if what happened was an accurate reflection of the average NUS student’s experience, but this is just what happened to me. 

Firstly it might help to describe myself, I am a tall, above average looking, average intelligence, average fitness, average talents (NUS IVP team and play the guitar alittle), relatively forgettable upon sight but memorable upon first conversation kind of guy. 

Brought up in a traditional and conservative family, I was never the type to party, or wreck havoc or spend too much time with the “popular crowd”, put simply, I was a good boy. I dated a girl up till the point I started Uni, when things changed. Dating before uni was simple, not that it was easy, but simple meaning straight forward, I like you, you like me, lets go on an adventure, just the two of us! But dating in uni becomes more complicated, it got me both emotionally confused but also curious. Like most of us here, I never knew what kind of girl I wanted, and probably never will, I mean we know whos hot and who we’re attracted to, we even list criteria which we look for in a person but almost always end up with someone with totally opposite traits. My peers in engineering always complained about being in the friendzone but I never believed them, I always equaled friendzone to rejection, it had the same process and the same result. 

I was attached to someone when I entered uni. We had a sweet pleasant relationship, both our parents liked us, we wrote notes and made scrapbooks, and travelled together and all. She was a good girl but changed as the camps started, partying and drinking and what not, we still had a regular dating life(meet up regularly, safe sex, sincere conversation), but slowly she started seeing another guy she met at a club, whom which most would label as your typical “douchebag”, she told me she was drifting and felt attracted to someone else, I tried my best but I respected her decision to pursue her own happiness and let her go. 

We remained friends even though we only broke up after she started dating him, but she was often heartbroken and always placed on an emotional rollercoaster while she was with him. He would treat her badly and rudely for weeks at a time, only to make up for it with a big yet shallow gesture like an expensive gift, or throwing a birthday party. By then ive moved on from her but was still concerned as a friend, she often complained to me and our mutual friends about him but I kept my distance and offered rapport as a friend. Soon I found out he was also sleeping with/dating other girls(I was not surprised),  but I decided that it was not my business to tell her. Eventually she found out and was so heart broken and drowned herself in parties/alcohol and new friends, and easily found another “douche” which was there for her at that time. That was the last we spoke, not because of anything but because she had changed so much that I could not hold a conversation with her anymore.

I was not dating anyone else during that time, I mean I went on dates and all but nothing developed, I would have an initial spark with most girls but things would fade away after afew dates. I don’t think I was a boring person, nor a turn off, my friends say im quite humorous, sociable and have many common hobbies. When asked, most of my dates would give usual reasons like, im really busy with school work, oh my cca pracs are increasing, the honest ones would say they are not interested anymore or started seeing someone else, but the most peculiar reasons were stuff like, you are too good for me,  you are too nice. Initially I accepted anything they said and told myself it was just lack of compatibility, but I couldn’t help but question their(and my ex gf’s) choice of boyfriends, I cant say im better than these guys, but if I were a girl, I wouldn’t date someone who treats me as these “douches” treat them. I think im a pleasant, honest, decent and relatively attractive guy, but I found it difficult to see how those choices seemed more attractive. So I decided to conduct a social experiment.

In year 3, I decided to be a “douchebag”, it sound ridiculous, but it actually was much easier than it sounds. I joined the camp parties in summer before sem1, drank with new friends and interacted with people outside my circle of engineering peers. I never really enjoyed it beyond the alcohol high and occasional fun music in clubs, but I did it more out of curiosity and boredom, despite it being an expensive lifestyle(each party costs guys about 30+ per entry, another 30 for drinks, and another 30 to pay for girls drinks and taxi because they will forget to bring their wallets with almost 100% certainty, I don’t blame the girls id do it too if im a girl cus there will always be a guy who would pay for u, ironically with money allowance probably from parents). 

It was incredible, I could easily hit things off with girls even before we’ve gotten to know each other well enough, I lived on campus so the hookups were convenient. Because of the constant blasts of attention and having my mind being occupied with hangovers and scrambling to keep up with engineering school work anytime im awake, I often responded late and poorly and sometimes even rudely to my dates, and other girls im texting at the same time. But to my surprise, they always text back! I didn’t officially get together with anyone of them, but we dated like a regular couple each time, (meetups, safe sex, but not as much conversation), I guess I didn’t really get to know them and they didn’t really know me, because the turnover rate was so high (change partner every few months or weeks even), it seemed too tiring to invest too much into a person. I really liked each girl I dated but never got the chance to really fall in love, but I mean, it was better than nothing in year 1 and 2, at least I was trying, maybe the next one would be the one right? 

Towards the end of year 3 I was running out of money, my cap fell almost 1 class, and ive forgotten about my old friends. I reduced and eventually stopped partying and did more healthy activities and joined ccas in school. My cap improved and towards the end of sem 2 I met someone in tutorial class and we started dating. I went back to my old self, a good boy, I was patient, kind, a good listener and did things any decent person would do. She was an honest and direct person, really easy to talk to so I told her about my past, she told me that she was starting to lose interest in me,  I asked why and she gave me an answer that kind of blew my mind, she said I was too easy. She said guys like me, will always be there for her, if they are sad and they ask, I would listen and be there, she could get me anytime she wanted, she didn’t need to put much effort to do so. Yes it was nice and pleasant, but she said girls like her, and even guys, want and desire things they cannot get. When I was not myself (as a douche to be put simply), I was hard to get, I was hot and cold to the people around me, I replied late to texts and sometimes did not show up, I was difficult to get and therefore, seen as more desirable. But when she met this other hot, charming guy who's interest in her vary like a sin wave, she craved for his attention.

It made me realise the case was the same for guys, guys are always blind to the nice girls around them who more likely than not will never reveal themselves to their crushes, and secretly feel sad that these guys only go for the hot, pretty, party girls whom are “douchegirls” simply because its something they cannot obtain. But everyone forgets the simple fact that, what is hard to obtain may not be necessarily good for you, or would make you happy. 

Now, im entering my final year, im still as confused as anyone else as to how relationships work and how the world works for the matter. I don’t think anyone really knows, everyone speaks from their own experience and stubbornly think they are right, but im glad I did what I did, it was an interesting adventure. Im looking forward to the next adventure id embark on.

I really hate the new IVLE. Why fix something that wasn't broken?

Idk why girls say nice guy too easy so dont wanna be with them. Easy is good what got more time for your work? And parents also happy to see a nice guy? You all like drama with bf and conflict with parents meh?

I really don't mean to complain or gain pity from anyone, I'm saying this because I'm worried... what do you think...

-
 
I have a confession/rant to make. 

I am actually very insecure about my self-worth in relations to having a relationship or finding love in my life. And I hate it when people throw the line "oh don't worry you're just 22, and what's more you're a guy, and guys only get better with age and then girls will be throwing themselves at you!" 

I come from a stable and semi-privileged background, however my emotional upbringing and mental stability has never been one of my stronger points in life. Ten straight years of suffering from bullying episodes in the local education system had thoroughly wrecked any emotional self-worth and self-love I can feel for myself, and as I grew older in my teenage years hormonal changes kicked in. All this meant that much of my search for self-validation and affirmation of self-worth to people in general, and females in specific ended up being skewed in the direction of proving my manhood through sexual contact and intimacy. 

Recently I've done some self-reflection and I have come to the discomforting conclusion that my current mental model of gauging someone's compatibility of a relationship or romance with me has become almost irretrievably skewed towards the terms of "how compatible are they with me in bed?" Not to say I'm a serial womaniser, but I recognised that perhaps I've grown too good at concealing my own inner wounds and shortfalls in emotional and mental stability by emphasising on physical sexual prowess through any means available. I tell myself that because I'm always putting the girl's needs before mine I'm the good guy, when in reality I'm just using their satisfaction and pleasure at my ministrations to fuel my own desires for approval and acceptance from a female, as if it was only because of what I could do with my little finger that would endear a woman to me and not because of who and what I am as a whole. 

I don't like feeling like damaged goods, but that is the unfortunate reality I recognise in myself as well. Having gone through a traumatic LDR breakup last October I'm still struggling to put my life back together, and I've grown very cold, callous and skeptical of emotional attachments and commitments to people in general. I tell myself that no, I've got my armor back on, and I will no longer be hurt by wanting romance and love like what any human would want. I wouldn't just use and dump someone either just to get my rocks off, but I wouldn't dare take any openings for a relationship seriously any longer and would sooner end it on my own accord than take the risk and fall again into genuinely feeling love for someone. 

But inside me I know I've not changed. The more I see people around me being able to enjoy the friendships and romances they can form in their lives because they haven't had their self-esteem wrecked to such an extent the more bitter I feel for myself. The more I hear about people from my cohort who are getting hitched and married within the next two years I wonder to myself just exactly what the hell have I done to deserve such rotten luck when it comes to humans and relationships of any kind. I know my addiction to sexual gratification of others and of myself is chewing me up inside, and yet it is but the most familiar show of intimacy and "love" I know and am able to hold my own and prove my worth to the opposite sex. And above all else, I fear missing out on life and love, that I'll be the one left on the shelf and when the day comes that finally someone finds me or I find them, they'd just be settling for less and pitying me instead of actually loving me. I don't buy into societal logic about how age works in a man's favour, because relationships only turn more and more materialistic/calculated as one grows older. Can he provide a stable life for me? Can he earn enough to support our family? Is his social status prestigious enough? Why do people find it necessary to equate age to maturity, success, and increased eligibility for bachelors in life? And what does it do to a male ego to know that some young thing is fawning for his attention because of the money in his bank account, the job he works at, the car he might be driving, or simply because they think age is the perfect illusion of maturity and therefore stability? 

I want to love again. And I want my own happy ending. People tell me not to chase fate, and just let time take it's course. Then who decides that some people get their Happy Ever Afters first, while others take fall after fall through no fault of their own and end up so bruised and hurt they're almost good for nothing else?

On the outside, I'm brash, outspoken, with my heart on my sleeve, and yet loyal almost to a fault. Who's to see how damaged and tearful I am inside emotionally? That nothing matters more to me in life than having a woman to hold your hand and give you a welcoming hug at the end of every day, to remind you that you're never alone in the world to enjoy your successes and suffer your failures?  

To that woman of my life that is still shrouded in the future, I'm sorry for the mess I am when you might find me once the time arrives. I'm sorry for believing too hard in making my own fate. I'm sorry for having thrown myself physically and emotionally too hard into hopes of winning over all those other women who would never have been able to stay in my life. I'm sorry that beyond the acts of physical intimacy in the bedroom I have next to no means of establishing trust and commitment to you, because the intellectual me is too on guard to open myself up willingly to trusting without touching. And I hope you forgive me, because no matter how messed up I am inside, I'll still want to love you and be with you till the end of our times.

1. the posters: these people are very good storytellers, and while many of them may appear to be weird, i strongly believe they are as normal as anyone of us.

2. the silent viewers: they are just you and me.

3. the commentators who tag friends: they just wanna see the world burn.

4. the frequent commentators (>3 comments): these people try hard to be funny.

5. the essay commentators: weirdos. or maybe they are just caring.

I have 2 personalities. 

In summary one is very relaxed and optimistic and innocent. My language of thought here is chinese. When I think in chinese, its almost really gullible like a 16 year old kid. I had friends who pull seemingly simple pranks on me and I fall for it. 

The other is very paranoid and always scheming and planning. Like planning the day ahead, planning how to allocate time. I doubt people all the time. I always scheme to get ahead of people, though I am still in reasonable control and I stop myself from actually doing it. My language of thought here is english. 

In uni, I always make it a point to speak Chinese when I can. Speaking english primes me to think evil. But still when I hit the workplace, where English is a must, I fear for myself (and my colleagues)....

How? Do I need help? I personally think the whole field of abnormal psych is really a bunch of bollocks. I've read lots of literature on this field to research myself but I realised that diagnosis itself is very judgment based. On the other hand I know that abnormal people have a substantial risk of sliding wayyyy down and risk having total breakdowns that changes the whole person.
Plus it is not really affecting my life too much. At least on the surface I am a scholarship holder, doing well in school, completed internships at prestigious firms etc. Personally I think I am still not hitting my best because at this point I've neglected eating healthily and also staying up till 1am often which is bad for health. Maybe I am just trying to convince myself I am still capable of living normally. Even my gf says i'm just someone who has a lot of negative experiences where it comes to english speaking environments whereas most of the people whom I met and speak chinese with end up to be a closer friend. I hope she is not reading this...

Two years ago when I found out my GF cheated on me with my brother, I tried killing myself by taking a lot of aspirin, bleach, and alcohol.

When I woke up I felt panicked and scared. You could say I was no longer insane at that point and so that survival instinct had taken over. It definitely wasn't guilt that I was feeling, but simply a "Shit, I don't want to die!" sense.

I was scared to fall back asleep as I was afraid I wouldn't wake back up. Physically I was very very weak. I couldn't move for a while and didn't have the energy to call for help. I also felt extremely nauseated. (I had vomited while I was out.) I was pretty determined to get up and when I was able to gather the energy to do so, I finally got up and practically stumbled out of my room towards the kitchen.

Only my dad was home that night. The look on his face is something I still remember and at the time that's when I felt deep guilt and even regret. I hadn't thought about my dad when I was in the process of taking everything. I hadn't thought about how much I would hurt him if I died. I felt so bad.

My dad is the only one who knew about it at the time. Everyone else, even my friends, didn't learn about my attempt until very long after the fact. My mother didn't believe me when I told her years later. My ex-GF is now my sister in-law.

-
 
 If you join for specific reason, girls will find it turn off. This is going against the natural flow of things. Learn to act in wu wei.

What Is Wu Wei?

"Wu wei refers to the cultivation of a state of being in which our actions are quite effortlessly in alignment with the ebb and flow of the elemental cycles of the natural world.

It is a kind of “going with the flow” that is characterized by great ease and awake-ness, in which - without even trying - we’re able to respond perfectly to whatever situations arise."

Hi  I am currently in a LDR and here are my thoughts on maintaining a LDR. 
Things that will help maintain your LDR
1) Skype because we spend more time on video calls/normal calls than texting. (I love to hear her voice and she love to see my funny facial expressions)
2) Similar timezones, but she work shifts and I work office hours but it is much easier as compared to being 12 hours apart in timezone. 
3) Meeting each other, she was here last month and I went to meet her in May and I am going again next month so average we get to meet each other once every 2 months. Physical intimacy is still very important in LDR (she agrees with me on this too :D) 

Reddit has plenty of good information www.reddit.com/r/LongDistance/comments/2ckhr5/august_4th_august_9th_what_advice_would_you_give/

Hope to learn from other LDR couples experiences as well!
