-
 
With reference to , the image that was posted was relatively true based on these thoughts.

From my observations, the physically undesirable guy, whether in terms of looks or stature, tend to be rather persistent once a girl catches his eye. My gut feel is that these guys felt that it's either they go all out to get a girl or they stand no chance at all, thus they tend to be more willing to let go of their ego and do whatever it takes to get the girl of his dream. However what he fails to realise is that in the first place, the girl already never had any feelings for him, but given that he is still very persistent, all the more the girl dislike him, thus giving rise to the impression that girls think the ugly guy is a stalker, disgusting etc. The good looking guy on the other hand, usually wait for a slight sign that the girl is interested in him before he make any move to ensure that he is unlikely to get rejected. In other words the good looking guy do not have to let go of his ego too much and still have a higher chance of getting the girl. Girls in the first place may already had caught sight of the handsome guy and have a rather good impression of the guy simply based on his looks, thus when the handsome guy start chasing the girl, the girl all the more felt happy and will think the guy is charming, gentlemanly etc.

Girls am i right to say that this is probably what you all are thinking too?

-
 
Some relationship facts that everyone should know.

Each and every person is constantly in a state of assessing whether the people she meets can make good relationship partners or not even if she appeared as if she doesn't care about relationships.

This mean that you don't have to confess to someone to initiate the relationship. She will constantly access whether you can make a good partner or not.

Also, try to see thing from the ladies' point of view. If some random guy just confess to you, will you like him? No right? You need to know more about him and see his good traits first before you can tell whether you like him or not.

Contrast to what that confessor say, you have to avoid making your intention clear until you are quite sure that the chance or rejection is very low.

Met this girl at a module I took. She was tall, tanned and not bad looking (but not superbly good looking either). Strangely, I thought she was hot. We were never introduced, but I got to know her name through other friends/acquaintances. Her facebook profile is public and there were times I frequently looked for updates on her facebook. (I am not her facebook friend.) We had a bit of eye contact during the semester, but there was no heart fluttering. A few months ago, she went overseas to study. I had this weird sinking feeling in my chest, as though I was extremely depressed that I would not see her again. I could not explain why. These days, although the pain is gone, I will occasionally think about how she is doing. I am a girl. While I do not have sexual fantasies of her, I often fantasize on how we could be good sisters. (How strange! As her facebook suggests that we are total opposites.) Is it strange for me to be so obsessed with a stranger?

I once had a short liaison with this girl who has a bf. It was hot, thrilling and torrid. She liked the idea of me being her secret lover. I liked the idea of being in utmost physical intimacy with another person's girl. We especially liked the idea of her sucking me off and then she going to meet her bf soon after that. She would also make a point to kiss him when meeting up with him.

The thrill was good, but alas she was not someone I could foresee being together for the long term. After many emotional upheavals, I called it quits. Right now, I am attached with another girl. Less passionate, less thrilling and less torrid, but all the better for my mental and emotional sanity.

We've been Facebook friends for a few years, however never did she once interacted with me until now. This is very understandable as we are just acquainted and not very close. So I felt really odd when she invited me to meet up with her out of the blue. She told me she's trying to catch up with some old friends. Okay, she's quite pretty and hot so I agreed to meet up with her. I mean which guy doesn't want to go out with an attractive girl right?  Just Kidding! I do enjoy meeting up with people for their company. 

So we met up and went to eat at McDonald's. We started rhapsodizing about some of the things our class did back then. However sooner than I expected, the reason for her inviting me out became apparent; she began pitching the benefits of some health supplements and wanted me to join some multi-level marketing program. I told her I may not be interested in doing so and she kept persisting and explaining it'll give me better health and a large passive income blah blah blah... Although I love having both health and wealth, but I really couldn't commit my money, time and effort because I've got other priorities to deal with at that moment. I could sense her energy level fell from 200% to 20% after we ended this conversation while moving back to talk about our secondary school class. 

So after that meet-up session, she would mostly give a one word reply such as "Good" or "K" whenever I send her messages to ask how she is doing. The smiley emoticons she once used are gone!!!! D:

Why do acquaintances only contact you when they have a favor to ask for? Is it really that hard to meet a friend just for the sake of establishing a closer bond or perhaps for the mere fun of it? Besides, this is not the first time some acquaintance called me just to ask for a favor and then disappear until he needs another favor again. Why Why Why WHY???? Are friendships really just based on how much the person can benefit you??

That's why I like my dog best.  That little bugger hangs out with me even though I've got nothing much more to offer him other than a simple friendship :D

Dear , I get what you mean. I am a guy, happily with my girlfriend and sometimes face the same exact problem with you. Many people think that you don't love your other half as much when you get bored, but in my own opinion I think it's just this society construct that dictates us to be together with one person all the time. 

Humans fall into a continuum (if my Psych textbooks can be trusted) and for everyone who is dead happy to stick with a same thing for a very long time (be it gf, bf, a car, a house, a job), there are those who craves changes every once in a while. A break from the routine. That's what makes us humans, you know. People with different personalities.

But of course, societal norms tend to favour a certain personality from time to time, which in our case, favours a monogamy relationship. One partner at any one time. There's also society with polygamy and polyamory norms (look that up), but they're mostly considered deviants in our society today and they're the other side of the extreme.

My only question is, if you want change once in a while, would you allow your bf to do the same? If you can work out something (like an agreement where both of you can have little "sexacapes" while remaining faithful to each other) why not? I know of couples who do this or other fetishes (like threesomes) so the key is always communication and knowing what both partners want. Better to be honest than to end up cheating after you get married, right?

The nice guys bad guys debate sound like self-pitying to me actually. Why is it the guy that gets together with the girl is always bad and then the guy who did not get the girl is always nice? Of course the guy who won the girl over is going to look bad to you because he's your competitor, and due to confirmation bias, you're definitely going to look out for flaws and magnify them, and well, everyone is generally blind to his/her own flaws, so you can only see yourself as the good/nice guy. 

I'm a guy btw, and what I believe is happening is that girls generally want to get swept off their feet by the guy wooing her. Hence the bad guys stereotype (clubber, tons of friends, smoke, drink, etc) tend to have a lot more life experience and know a lot of tricks/techniques to do so will have the advantage in this regard, whereas the stereotypical nice guys tend to take it slowly, hoping for the girl to notice him, then try to be attentive to all her needs, etc. It is good, but not enough. And I notice a similarity about the nice guys, which is that they act like they already are the girl's boyfriend when they are not. Think about it, if the girl already has a friend treating her with care and concern and be attentive to her every need without any obligation on her part, so why would she want to get together with that friend? In simpler terms, would you want to pay money for something that you are already getting for free? The answer is obvious.

PS: The above is something I've learnt from repetitively being the nice guy.
TLDR: Girls want to fall in love, not slowly prodded into love.

All the 'nice guy' posts are very interesting! I'm a girl who is slightly older than most of the people who will be posting here, with i dare say more life/dating experience. I dated my share of bad boys and nice guys and I'm now with a bad boy who became nice :), so we compared notes and had an interesting chat about this. 

Actually, the stereotype has truths on both sides.  is sometimes correct when he says that girls say one thing but do another. Girls logically DO want a guy who will treat us nice, loyal, and responsible. however, girls being more emotional can be easily swayed by the charming guy who makes our heart flutter. This is especially so when you're younger and easily influenced (sorry younger girls, speaking from my own experience!) and maybe relationships are abit more fun and games and you don't really know what you want. Not the girls fault! it's just a natural part of life and people's thinking change and mature. I have seen several times, where my girlfriends genuinely are interested to give the nice guy a chance, but then get distracted by a charming, suave 'bad boy.' Girls who do not learn to control this aspect of their emotions will remain girls. Those who do are women :)

This is not to say the nice guys are off the hook! nice guys can really sometimes overdo it, like  says. It is a different story when you are chasing and you are together. Girls like their man to be confident and know his self-worth, and to an extent, street smart. She is not the center of the world, and you are not together, so don't act like she is! (It is a different story when you are together :D) . I admit this is abit of a fine line and you got to learn when to be assertive and confident in moving the relationship (like in 's case) forward but really, if the girl likes you she will be forgiving one :)
Meanwhile, invest in yourself, do interesting things that you are passionate about (not gaming, please. I don't mind guys who game but everything in moderation), get life experience! my bf put it this way: You're asking the girl along on a car ride, you gotta make sure the journey is going to be interesting and that you won't crash the car. 'Nice' guys won't crash the car, so work on making the car ride interesting. YOU DO NOT NEED TO BE A BAD GUY TO BE STREETSMART AND HAVE SOME CHARM/SOCIAL SKILL. if she didn't want to come on the ride, her loss. move on.
I have a few guy friends who were your stereotypical 'nice guys'. but they used their singlehood well, and they have very interesting lives and life experience, let me tell you they are very attractive and have their pick of the ladies. 

I don't want to pretend to be an expert or have all the answers but these are just my observations. Don't worry also. University is just one part of dating life, not the be-all-end-all. alot of people's thinking and perception will change after uni and you are grown-up abit and then it's a whole new ball game.

I don't know, I think in my experience girls do sometimes don't really like the nice guy. 

By all accounts,  I'm rather eligible. I have a good job with a balanced life. I'm sporty and not bad looking. Thing is I like adventure, so I travel alot, do lots of new things. I am very comfortable going out/travelling by myself and doing new stuff alone.I don't club/smoke/drink. I have a good mix of friends, I have dated and am no stranger to meeting girls. In some circles I would even be thought off as the 'bad boy ' because of how people view my rather carefree lifestyle. Never had ons.

Thing is, the people who know me well (including girls) say I'm too nice to girls- I.e. I do things for normal friends other guys won't do, like taking detours fetching them home, and asking how they are if I hear something bad happened to them and other examples. To me this is sometimes abit strange because I honestly think this is quite 'normal'. I don't believe in playing around and I believe that if you're in a relationship you should be serious about it.

My experiences in dating has so far been that girls sometimes don't want you to care so much about what they feel or think; I'll give some examples 

Case 1) 
I dated girl A,  who is was introduced to me by girl B (A and B are good friends) It didn't work out, unfortunately, but things were abit awkward between A and I. B and I got very close over some time, but I didn't want to pursue anything with her because things with A were still unresolved. In the end she chose another guy. 

Case 2) 

Girl C and I met and we had very good chemistry, we started going out over 6 months. Unfortunately at that time she had alot going on with her life- family issues, just broke up, going overseas to study (me too) - and I told her we should slow it down abit and just be good friends for now, and see where things stood in a  few months. She agreed, but next thing I know 2 months later she got together with someone who would be in most circles be considered a 'bad boy' 

Case 3) 
A cousin introduced me to girl D at a wedding, we hit it off and started texting quite abit. We went out quite a few times in the first month of meeting. 
When talking I made it clear that I don't play around and I know what I want. About 2 months down the road I decided to move things along and start being more serious in asking her out and getting to know her, but strangely she started to become cold and withdraw. I was a little disappointed,  but well, move on. 6 months down the road I found out she got tgt with a guy who, let's just say has anger mgt issues and can be violent toward people.

So, really, my opinion is that in my experience girls say one thing but quite often do the other. Am I completely blameless?  No I don't think so, but I think I tried my best. Are all girls like that? I also don't think so, but I think quite a few are.
-
 
To ,

I'm sorry to break your bubble, but I think the term "nice guys" is just used as an excuse to justify us guys sitting around, staying silent all day and not making any moves towards the girl. I used to think the same too, branding all assertive guys (read: jocks) as "bad guys", but the truth is an entirely different matter. I've seen enough assertive guys to know that assertiveness does not equate douchebaggery and introversion/shyness does not equate niceness, whatever that means.

There are jocks who treat their girlfriends as if they're the queen of the world (I personally know of an athlete, the typical "bad guy" who smokes, drinks and clubs but has been with his girlfriend for six years and planning to get married soon) and there are shy guys who are nothing but egotistical maniacs ("nice guys" who prefers to game everyday even after getting attached).

So stop moping around and patting yourself on the back thinking that you're losing out because you're a nice guy.

P/S: Of course there's this issue of shy guys losing out because societal norms dictate that the guy chase after the girl, which I think is where this whole nice guy bad guy debate stemmed from. Hopefully with more feminism we can see girls and guys chase each other equally. Wouldn't the world be a better place like that?
-
 
Talking about nice guy (typical stereotypes of shy/quiet vs alpha), I came across a interesting perspective of two different types of alphas. 

ALPHA APPROACH NUMBER 1: 

Typically people think of the alpha male as the built, popular guy that is always the center of attention whenever there is a gathering of people. When a guy disrespects him he is quick to get in his face - the challenger usually backs down quickly, intimidated by his dominant mannerisms. This guy will be classified as an alpha male by most peoples definition. 

But, let me give you another, slightly different, picture of what could be an alpha male - you decide if you agree... 

ALPHA APPROACH NUMBER 2: 

He's rarely the center of attention. He's not particularly good-looking or muscular. But, the funny thing is... when he has something to say people listen. People listen because they respect him. They respect him because he radiates strength and positivism. The strength is a result of being so secure and confident with who he is. He's genuine, real, and authentic. People can't help but notice and admire that. He has clear boundaries. Guys don't mess with him because he doesn't mess with them. Women notice that guys don't mess with him, they notice that when he talks, though it's not often, people listen to what he has to say. Women admire this quiet power and are drawn to it. No, he's not the type draw crowds with his extroverted antics, and he's not going to go around challenging all the other guys in "the pack," he's not that type... and he's perfectly fine with that. He's not out for other peoples acceptance, he doesn't need other people's approval because he is confident with himself. 

So I would think we should really focus on our strengths depending on the type of personalities we have. Thoughts?

Hypothetical question for the (single) NUSWhispers community:
You are told there is a someone willing to go on a date with you. The only things you know about them is that they are 
1) of the gender you are attracted to
2) between 18-65 years of age 
3) of normal behavior and countenance (to all outwardly appearances)
You don't know their background, exact age, race, occupation, personality, likes/dislikes or basically anything about them. 
All you know is that this person was briefly told about you and has expressed an interest in meeting you. They are willing to meet you anywhere you prefer and at any time. 
But it is however, a proper date and you ought to respect the conventions; stay for an appropriately long time and try to make a decent attempt at getting to know this person (you aren't allowed to bolt at the sight of them). 
Would you go?

I broke up with my boyfriend yesterday. We were together for three years, but things over the last few months have been bitter for the both of us.

When I came home last night, I looked all distraught. My mum was watching TV in the living room. I greeted her like I always do and then went in straight to my room. Moments later, she came in my room while I was already lying in bed still in the day's clothes. She sat by my bed and asked me what was wrong. I didn't know what or how to say it.

"It's that friend of yours is it? The Chinese boy I've seen you brought home?"

"No. I'm tired. Can you leave me by myself?"

"It's ok. Mak not judging you ok? He's not just a friend right?"

Hearing that put all the worries of coming out to rest. I had hidden a huge part of my life to her. I was afraid she would reject me. We are, after all, a Muslim family. The track record in my family would suggest that I would be disowned. That was the case for my distant cousin in Malaysia who was thrown out of his home when his family found out that he was transgender MTF.

"I'm not my sister," she said, "You need to give me more credit. I won't throw you out. You're my son, I love you."

I guess... I've one less thing to worry about now.
-
 
Dear  OP:

tl;dr: Different people express various degrees of physical affection, even towards platonic friends, and assumptions are bad.

I wonder what your classification of "pretty touchy" is, but it doesn't seem like touchy=dating is a logical conclusion.

I've known quite a few physically affectionate girls since sec school (straight guy here), and it was platonic for us most of the time. From sleeve tugging, arm grabbing, hugging, tickling, hair ruffling, to sharing a sofa or a bed in hall or at their houses during Reading Week to force myself to study, there weren't expectations of dating or romantic attraction. I did date one girl from JC, but neither of us assumed we were romantically interested in each other solely because of the repeated ticklings.

Of course, for every physically affectionate friend I've had, there are many more who are not, and that's totally cool. People express affection in many different ways. But it seems to me this guy is one of the more physically affectionate ones, and it might be better (as it usually is) to actually find out how he feels. Assumptions can be very dangerous, and it's also pretty unfair to claim this guy is untrustworthy when all you seem to be saying is that you "consider" you both to be dating, and then faulting him for being too friendly to others.
-

To , I (Singaporean) have dated a Chinese boy before and there are really cultural differences. I think the boyfriend is just thinking of how to break it to his parents. While I have nothing against their relationship, I have to say that it's not easy to have a relationship with someone who grew up in a different culture, and not easy to come out to the parents too. To be honest, the guy shouldn't sing praises about her either, but let the parents judge her based on her own fortes, or actions. And don't ask the guy to devalue himself?! Why should he do that? Don't make it seem like the girl is manipulating him. Let things go naturally.

And please don't confess to her when she's already in a relationship, you'll put her in a very very difficult position. I do regret my cross-cultural relationship but seriously, if they're happy together, don't ruin it. The parents will come to their senses, just give them time. And it's probably not easy for the boyfriend to handle both relationship and family, please understand that.

In light of 

I don't understand why people cheat. Is it so hard to remain faithful? If you answered yes, then maybe monogamy isn't for you. If that is the case, then talk to your partner about an open relationship then. Don't fucking lie. What kind of person builds a relationship on a lie? You've no idea how damaging it is for the person being cheated on. 

I had a girlfriend who cheated on me. We were coupled for two years. I saw it in her chat logs - raunchy conversations that include texts like 'hey is your boyfriend with you now?', 'place empty. wanna fuck?', 'had a great time... xx'. I know I shouldn't have looked, but she was acting strangely and I wanted to know why. I gave her many chances to own up but she didn't. Maybe I was partly to blame for this. I wasn't spending enough time with her because I was busy with NS. But fuck, that's no excuse for cheating. I'm glad I dumped that bitch... But I've never been able to trust another girl since then. -
 
I am really cynical about relationships. Whenever I feel like I like someone I ask myself - Do I really like her (in my case) for who she is, or do I just like who I think she is? Would I love her, 10 years down the road, when all the romance and novelty has worn off? 

I then start to imagine myself in situations of conflict with her. Would I still love her and want to stay with her when she is being totally unreasonable, grumpy, jealous, etc? How about when she insults and humiliates me? How about when she doesn't want to listen to whatever you say, and will not relent until you give in? How about when she does something outright disgusting?

Sounds extreme, sounds like I'm too paranoid or exaggerating. Surely this doesn't happen to everyone right? Surely there is a way to work things out right? But that's what's happening with some couples around me, and even among my relatives. My own parents divorced, and for many years, me and my brothers really suffered emotionally. Got me thinking. The things is, no couple would expect that things will turn ugly. All couples get together thinking that they'll be different, that they'll be able to work things out because they love each other. Most, if not all, divorces started out with hopeful, loving couples making a lifelong oath to love each other. 

None of us know what will happen in future. Your partner may have an affair. Maybe bear a grudge against you for one big mistake you made (forgiveness is easier said than done). Over time, things get ugly. There will definitely be something that you will feel disgusted with about your partner over time. Snide remarks, looks of disgust, those 'tsk' noises she makes when you do something she doesn't like, sarcasm. All these kill marriages, and kill you slowly.

Good for those who can last through that and find a reason to keep loving your partner. The harder thing that is out of your control is whether your partner will do that for you as well.

As everyone started writing down the names of their friends and the commonalities, i felt so pathetic. I didnt even know who i could consider as my close friends, not to even mention the commonalities.

We still meet up as a group occasionally, but its very obvious that we are just not as close as we used to be. I know how this is very normal because everyone finds new friends in uni. But me, i guess i can only blame myself for not socializing much in my first year and not joining camps after. 

I get so envious of people who made so many new friends and their uni life just seems so much more fun than mine. I thought i could try and make more friends without joining any activities, but no, everyone was in cliques/groups, it just didnt seem right for me to butt in suddenly. 

"Friendships" affect me a lot especially because I'm not close to my family. But nowadays, i realize that i dont even know who to approach when i just wanna rant about life. -
 
I had experiences dating a guy living in a condo, before dating a guy living in a HDB flat. This might or might not say much about their family condition, just some musings over the differences in their treatments to me.

The condo guy took me out for lavish dinners at fancy places; the HDB guy took me to hawker centres. The condo guy remembered our anniversary and made a big fuss out of it; the HDB guy treated our anniversary like any other day with a simple 'Happy Anniversary' greeting. Advices from the condo guy included quotes from classic novels, poems, and bible verses I've never heard of, displaying his intellectual ability; advices from the HDB guy...well, he just listened and soothed me, sometimes shushing my sniffles, displaying his patience dealing with a girl with tears and mucus all over his shirt. The condo guy spent on me without blinking an eye, making me felt appreciated; the HDB guy always apologized for not having enough savings for the month to spend on me, making me realized relationships are more than just gifts and presents. The condo guy never call when we were apart, giving me the freedom I liked; the HDB guy was worried-stricken once I forgot to reply his WA messages (when we were apart), giving me the attention I craved for. 

Both had changed my life in different ways, so to the both of you, cheers to the adventures beyond, and wishing you all the best in your search for love :)

While she, and i think many others who have commented, thought that it would be absolutely stupid of you to even ask such a question of whether to still give him a chance or not (and I like many others, if not everyone, think you should not), i understand why to you it isnt so clear cut and obvious. 

I was from poly and since year one of poly ive been hanging with a group of friends, including this particularly guy. 

Over the years in poly, the guy and i grew closer, closer than we were to the rest of the group and by the end of poly, we were basically together. 

I've been a rather religious person, he knows that, and from even before we got together, i thought that he was too. Hence, i was comfortable getting close to him in the first place because I assumed he woul not make any funny moves on me. 

You know what they say about assuming. 

It started with harmless physical contacts like holding hands, and hugging. I wasnt exactly comfortable at this point as I said, i was rather religious and strict about physical contact with the opposite sex (i should probably add that in my religion, physical contact with the opp sex is a strict No-no. You can probably figure out which religion im in now).  But i didnt express it nor told him. I figured and assumed, again, that he wouldnt cross the line with me. 

One day, in a service elevator, he kissed me on the lips. I was shocked, trying to register what was going on, hence i didnt immediately push him away. By the time i did realise what was happening, we have reached our floor, my floor actually, so i went off. I was late for a meeting hence i could only text him of my anger and disappointment while he walked away.

He said sorry and i was weak and i forgave him. I didnt exactly push him away immediately. If i hadnt wanted it to happen, i would have - i reasoned. I blamed myself.

Some time after that, at a very open and public but rather empty spot, he kissed me again. And for the life of me i do not know why i didnt stop him. Perhaps i was enjoying it myself. That would truly have been nobodys fault. But then he started feeling me up (i was wearing a dress). I really had no idea what he was doing. Because the thought of him fingering me had never crossed my mind AT ALL. In fact, i had no idea people did that (i was still rather young and sheltered). By the time he was fingering me i was confused. I didnt stop him. I didnt really know what was going on, and there was a part of me that felt, well, good. 

 When it was over and i 'came to my senses' i cried. In front of him. Like nobodys business. I thought i had just lost my virginity (does that count as losing ones virginity?). 

He tried to get me to stop crying. Kept telling me its okay. Its okay. We're just kids. We dont know better. Its okay. 

Thinking back about it, i think he was more concerned about me crying in public. There were still some people around. 

Youd think after that episode he wouldnt do it again. And if he did, i would have stopped it.

But he did do it again and i never stopped him. Maybe because in the moment i gave in and simply enjoyed it. But when its over and i tell him to stop and he would say sorry, i always end up blaming myself more than i blame him. Which is probably why i never stopped him while it was happening. I blamed myself. 

I left him a few times. But we have a close group of mutual poly friends we always hang with till now. There were times when we didnt speak to each other for weeks, all of those times because i told him i had enough. But  i always end up falling for his sorries and his promises that he is trying his best to be a better, more religious person. And he is. And so am i. I guess we have too much of a history that i cant seem to let him go. 

But , it seems to me that you dont have any reasons to give him anynmore chances or to not cut ties.  You no longer work there at the mall and im guessing you dont have any mutual friends who are close. Please dont be dumb. Delete that a$*h0*! from your life.

I'm a 27 year old Lesbian, and I've always thought I'm just a lesbian. I figured it out when I was about 13, and since then I've never really been attracted to boys at all. I've never ever been interested in boys or having a relationship with one. I have many guy friends, but I've never been sexually attracted to any of them in any sense of the word, or any male really.
I've always been attracted to women. I'd walk down the street, I'd see a woman, and I'd in my head imagine being with her for a night. I'm really shy about it, and I never talk about sexuality in open, except with my partner, since I'm really, really shy about it. But I am a very sexual person towards women, I think about almost every woman I come in contact with who is moderately attractive.
I was in a relationship with a girl for the past 5 years. I really loved her, I thought we were going to be together forever, I really did. Over the past year things started to get bumpy, and she really began changing. Her personality changed and she wasn't the girl I fell in love with. She was sometimes becoming really violent and abusive, and the next day would be very meek and apologetic, and then would go back to being angry. I couldn't deal with her anymore, it reached a certain point where I felt... I just didn't care for her anymore as a person. This was going on for a year so when we decided to break up, it was so clear this was what had to happen.
She wanted to still 'stay friends'. I was struggling to hold back the tears, but many came through. I refused, I said no, it was over, no friends, no nothing, we're through. She got angry, said some really nasty things, I got scared a little, but then it was over. I was just left with my tears.
The next few days were terrible, I would spend a lot of the time crying. And this is when it happened.
I have one friend, he's really close, he's probably one of my best friends. He's a straight guy, but he's also 22, so he's much younger than me. He knows I'm lesbian and has always been there for me, we've known each other for maybe 2 years, 2 and a half years. We haven't known each other that long, but our friendship flourished from the get-go. There was never any romantic tension or sexual sparks between us, he knew I was strictly into women and respected that.
We were together at my home, we were talking. When I say we, it was mostly me. I was just going on and on about her, and what she meant to me, and how she hurt me. He kept reassuring me that I did the right decision because she was becoming borderline abusive, but I had convinced myself that I still loved her. He was telling me I shouldn't do this to myself, and I deserve much better.
I was the one who initiated it, it was all me. I don't know what came over me. He was sitting on the couch, and I pressed forward with him, trying to come on to him, trying to kiss him. He was at first resistant and was unsure of what I was doing, he said "what are you doing" "are you sure, you want this." I told him "please, this is what I want", and then he went with it too.
I then led him up to the bedroom in my house, and that's where the two of us had sex. I wasn't drunk, I wasn't intoxicated on anything, I was fully aware, but I have no idea what came over me. I don't know why I reached out and had sex with this man, my friend, when my whole life I've only been sexually attracted to women.
When we woke up in the morning in bed together, we were both a mess. I feel so fucked up, I don't even know what came over me. I'm not even sexually attracted to him, I don't even find him that attractive or good looking.
I really hate to say this, I'm not sure how to say it, but... from a physical point of view it was incredible. My body felt incredible during the sex, he must certainly have known his way around a woman, because I've never felt that way with a woman before. I still don't know how my mind let my body orgasm repeatedly with him. I've orgasmed with my past female partner many times, even multiple orgasms, but this one felt... much better somehow, more powerful.
I don't know what to say about myself. I actually initiated and had sex with a man. But I'm a lesbian. I have no sexual attraction to men at all, I feel nothing sexually towards men. I have no desire to have a relationship with a man, and I still don't. I still know I'm exclusively attracted only to women.
Then how did this happen? Why did I do this? Am I really a lesbian or am I bisexual? Is it normal to feel this way?

OP of  , I can understand how you feel. From my point of view, what you want is a lover-cum-best friend in one person, somewhat like your soulmate. It isn't wrong to want this, everyone has their own preferences, but does you exbf know that this is what you expect from him? You should have talked to him about it and broken up if only if he disagrees with your idea. Chances are he never felt attracted to his female friend at all and considered you as a best friend too.

Many people have more than one best friend, all of them equally close. You can't choose who is dearer, it's like comparing whether you love your mom or dad more. Sometimes, I feel jealous when I see insta pics of my best friend hanging out with another of best friend of his, but then I control my feelings by telling myself that I also have other best friends from JC. When I hang out with them, I don't include this best friend from uni. 

Insecurity is repulsive. The more insecure you are, the less time he will want to spend with you. Find a hobby that you like, learn a new skill, read a book, watch TV shows to keep your mind occupied. Don't text/call him every hour of the day and seek affirmation that he loves you. I have best friends whom I don't talk to for weeks. When we chat again, we are as close as before. In case you are wondering that he will lose his feelings if you don't talk for a period of time, this is unlikely to happen. If it does, he was not the right person for you anyway.
 
From what you described, you seem to have low self-esteem. Not to worry! You are right that you should love yourself. The fact that you have identified this shows that you are one step ahead already. :) Stop seeking validation for the little things in your life. Give up the wish for wanting others to tell you how nice you are or how much they love you. When you get busy with other things and someone calls you to share their stories with you, it will be a pleasant surprise not a need or want.

Moreover, you must learn to trust. Snooping around your bf's phone is bad. How would you feel if he did it to you? There are different kinds of love and it's not true that you are attracted to everyone you love. If he says his friendships are platonic, take his word for it and trust him. I have a best friend of the opposite gender I am very close to. People think we are in a relationship because we love each other's company so much but both of us know and we have agreed to be friends only. If my friend's gf becomes jealous and insecure of our friendship and tries to pull us away, I would feel very sad.

I felt that freshie camps empasized too much on girl-guy interaction. Initially i was always puzzled by why we have those "funny funny" games that have girl-guy body contact instead of going to nice places for picnic, or going theme parks to play (those innocent kinds of activities). As i progressed through university, all the more i felt like freshie camps is like a speed dating event. I have this feeling that whenever people join freshie camp, their main motive may not necessarily be simply to get new friends, but to hopefully find their life partners there. 

Why did the camps seems to pressure people into having more girl-guy interaction? I think this kind of thing comes naturally, more like a if its yours, then its yours no matter what. No need to force. I even heard the camp organisers get more funds if they promote these kinds of activities, though i don't know how true this is.

I don't see the point on "pressuring" girl-guy to have closer interaction since i supposed the main purpose of the camps is to get friends from your batch so you have someone to discuss your school work with.

Is it really true that girls and guys alike enjoy closer interaction with each other (holding hands, close body contact etc) no matter how shy they may look on the surface? If so what makes them have this "desire"?

It’s my self defense mechanism you moron.

“저.. 많이 많이 보고십은대.”  Remember the short-lived fantasy we had? Remember I wanted to show you I could also be like how I was on the phone with you when I’m physically with you? That Monday should have been the deal sealer and I was fucking pissed it didn’t transpire as planned. Still am.

“보고 싶어.” I’m really wary of getting my hopes up but you raised it sky high and I fell crashing while you looked on not caring. As an empath, have you ever thought about how I felt? Whether there is a possibility that besides you, others can get really hurt too? That you would take your own advice and stand in the shoes of others and “look at things from their point of view” (your own words), and get a sense of how much hurt you dealt me? 

Ask yourself if there is any guy out there who would not be jealous if their love interest laid on the bed with another dude, even if there was no physical contact. Isn’t it 당연하지? 

Have you heard of the logical fallacy of sunk costs? R will never be sustainable and you’ll tire of the lack of chemistry and lack of intellectual resonance all over again. No amount of firefighting and salvaging is going to make you feel like you’re burning red, because behind those pretenses, you already experienced far better. More specifically, has he even made you doubt yourself in eight years as much as I did, commensurately, in a month?

Unfortunately none of this will be to your liking now; you’d only appreciate it after a fucktonne of time and a fucktonne of me pining in suffocating, rasping agony amidst PTSD relapses. You only see things according to your circumstances at present, a commitment you made in “vow and financially”, and fucking lose the bigger picture in an atlas of infinite possibilities and what could be better because you already met me.   

I’ll take my depressive state over my heart being shattered into smithereens. I’ll take having to endure months and years of OCD torture time. For the first time, I actually wish I never swiped right.

To the OP Girl , I can understand you. It could mean that your brother is not happy with his life. Since you mentioned you do not have a father, I assume your mother is taking care of the house and I am also assuming you are not very strong financially and are going through some tough times.

1. For these reasons, may be your brother is not happy about the life is getting. It may not look very attractive as he may have wished and seeing his friends having all the happiness and luxury is making him more sad, angry and frustrated. ( Other parents are giving money/good life and since he is not getting that, he does not believe in mother/sister relationship).
His idea of a mother-sister relationship is, giving a good life, good food and luxuries. If he is unable to get it, he believes these relationships are false and hence those words( even though i don't knw the meaning of them)

2. Another thing is , may be your brother knows that someday he may have to take care of the family and help your mother/sister in daily work like the OP guy 5308. You must understand that not every boy is like OP 5308.
He may be the kind off guy who expected his family to give me a nice decent life without him sweating it out. He may also be afraid he may have to work like this and study at the same time to support which he is not willing to.

3. He is also very immature , childish and if you treat him as one, he will remain the same. And he is  not in a position to understand the difficulties of life and it will take more time than the normal guy for him to become mature and understand the tough situation of your family.

My Suggestion is the following.

1. Try to understand him and tell him to treat others with 'respect' no matter what and especially the family.
2. Make him understand that you all love him and trying best to give him a decent life and make him happy and there are certain things 'beyond your control'.
3. Most important, he may be having a feeling that you guys( you and mother) do not love him as much as they should have. SO make sure you 'shower your love' to him in a way you don't loose your own importance. 
4.  INVOLVE. This is the most important thing. Involve him in family discussions. Ask him some open ended questions. If you ask him, how was your day, how was school, he may not answer it properly.

Ask him for his opinion. Ask him for his advice. ( Not when he is angry or upset and if he is like that all the time, then find a time when he his normal)  and ask casually , about his advice. It should not appear you are asking explicitly and it should appear natural. 
Start with asking some issues and opinions and ask what do you think? or Can you help me with this as I am confused?

I hope this advice helps you.

I dun know when it started. I had a pretty normal childhood when I was younger. My family ( mum, dad and older sis)  would go out together for dinner and holidays. But thing started to change and I can't exactly remember when. I guess most of my childhood are erased from my memory. 

The last family holiday we had was when I was 10. I'm in my early 20s now. The fights got more frequent and scary. To escape from the terror and noise, I would hide in the room. Every time I heard a long thud, I could only imagine if it was a object thrown across the floor during the fight or if someone had been battered. It scare me to find out but it scare me even more to imagine the worst. 

The fight continue through most of my primary school life till secondary school. Maybe because of my home environment and other couple of things the absence of my father. ( I was closer to my dad) I started to cry for no reason in upper primary. I would cry whenever I did not know how to solve a math problem or just suddenly. At first my classmates were shocked that I was crying. But I because it happen every day they got used to it. I lost friend because they were afraid of me crying 

My grades dropped i was refer to counsellors because I was showing disturbing behavior. 

 I manage to get into a secondary near my house but since my dad was absent a lot from home and I was really close to him there was a hole in my heart and because of that I started getting close to older guys. Looking for the 'brotherly' / 'fatherly' figure that I'm yearning for. 

I'm not sure if it is a psychological thing or not but it is an innate nature for the opposite sex to be attracted to each other so girls will get attract to their dad and boys to their mum.

I engage in a lot of reckless behavior, Created havoc in a government area. My parents were called up. My dad told me to stop behaving the way I was but I didn't know what he meant. I didn't know what I did wrong or not. I didn't know why I did what I did. It may seem absurd to some but I had not idea what was wrong from right. I just did what I felt like doing. 
 and self harm just to make myself feel better because their were times when I felt that I wasn't worth it. I almost got retain in secondary 3 and barely make it to N and O levels. 

I met a very good teacher in upper sec and I started looking for him for help. I join all his lessons which piss of his students. I got insulted for joining his class since I was not his student. that teacher was the 'fatherly' figure that I had been looking for. Not only did he teach well, but he encourage me a lot through my sec school life which makes me look for him. I did quite well in the subject he taught me but I did badly in my other subjects. Home was not a condusive place to study in and I would stay in school for as long as I could just so I did t need to go home. 

I grew more mature and with Christian friends and the right support I manage to make it to poly 

My parents got divorce few years back. and even though it is a good thing somehow I can't help but to admire others with a complete family or how some other family would bring their children out for meals. eventhough I'm living with my dad. It feels like im all alone. Throughout my life since secondary school I had been facing very bad panic attacks when facing crowd and started becoming self conscious and due to some past experience I have an aversion to male friends. I still look up to them but I'm afraid that I would give them the wrong impression.

Having felt the effects of divorce first hand, Im not sure if I'm truly able to have a relationship that will last. Why do people get married only to end up getting a divorce. Recently a few of my couples at my church got married and being  at the age when a couple of your friends are getting married/ having a relationship make you want to be in a relationship too.

 But I'm not just looking for a boyfriend nor a husband but a father to my kid. Someone who is willing to be involve in my kids life. 

Love is not just about yourselves but it is putting others before yourself. 

With all the things that I had face. I want to work with kids. Just like how my teachers and counsellors helped me. But im afraid that I will be reminded of my previous rebellious self and that scares me a lot. 

Cause even though things are slightly better im still struggling a lot with anxiety and school work. I'm close to getting kick out of school since I always have to go for appointments and  I have been doing very badly in school but because of the previous experience in sec 3 I'm afraid of looking for lecturers and feel that im wasting their time somehow. I have been mistaken for being aloof because I dun smile and I have that resting bitch face and there are times when I find it hard to do so. 

To any FASS students out there. Is there any requirements to working with kids other than having a degree in a related field?

Riddleman is back:

One night, I was visiting a friend of mine. I hadn't seen him in a long time. We had the following conversation:

Friend: I like having you here.

Me: Yeah, it's been good to see you again.

Friend: Will you stay the night? You can sleep in the spare bedroom.

Me: OK. Why not? It'll be easier than walking home.

Friend: Kill some time here then. I like having company. It's so lonely here on my own.

Me: Yeah. Living alone can be tough.

Friend: You look exhausted. You should probably go straight to bed and get some rest.

Me: I guess I am feeling tired.

Friend: In the morning, I'll have a lot of things to take care of. Sweet dreams.

Me: OK. See you in the morning.

Friend: Your bed is already made. It's the first bedroom on the right. Just go to sleep.

Me: Goodnight.

Friend: Sleep tight.

Is anything wrong?

-
 
 Actually, why would, and why should we be romantic partners? 

There's this common misunderstanding that guys hang around ladies with a motive, especially if that guy is especially friendly to that particular lady. At least, that comes from a course I am in, and a whole lot of my friends. Many of my friends do not approve of my friendship with another lady either, simply because she's attached.

The thing is, a friendship is something that transcends gender and romantic interest. Yet, it is something that's so simple, it's often negatively over-complicated.

I don't look at my friend as a lady of interest. I just see her as... Ok lor, she woman. She my friend, simple as that. 

What's so special about her is that she's a friend - not the type that comes by with the purpose of networking, work, utility, status or anything. This is what I am looking for in a friend. Coming from a person who's quite bat-shit crazy and wtf, you can tell why she's an important friend to me. 

I understand both of us enough that I am not the one for her, and she's not the one for me either.

There are also principles a person should stick to as a friend, and as a man, one of which being considering for her happiness, and I intend to uphold and respect that, which is why I wouldn't see her as a romantic interest.

This is a story about my ex bf and I. 

We were both from NUS but I entered 2 years before him. We met outside of school and got together a few months before he became a freshie. 

At that time, I was doing very poorly and failed a few modules. I was v lost, depressed and suffered from low self-esteem - i was a far cry from the happy me when I was in JC. I became extremely insecure when he started joining freshie camps and started to have female friends. It was a nightmare because the relationship was not as how I had imagined it to be. I tried dissuading him from participating in sch activities and even started to check his phone whenever he wasn't around. Almost everyday I would be worried that he would leave me for someone else. Even though he always claimed that his friendships with his girl pals were platonic, my intuition told me that there was a fleeting period he was infatuted with one of his girl friends. It was very painful for me. Despite being very broken and unhappy, I continued defending him in my mind whenever these negative thoughts came to my mind. I continued in the r/s because I thought I would be worst off without him. Actually I know that he loved me from how he encouraged me and stuck with me during my lowest point in life but somehow, I think that he didn't love me as much I wanted him to love me. Simply because, I couldn't love myself. So I  can't blame him right? Plus love is selfish. Even though I was less problematic into the 3rd yr of our r/s, I still harboured bitterness towards him. 

Recently, he graduated and I was super happy for him. However, the same night I decided to break up with him because he captioned his photo with his girl- friend as "bestie". It sounds very silly but I decided I needed a break and get my shit together. A part of me also thinks that I deserve better. Someone who will not only be my lover but also my best friend?? How would you feel if you always had to guess whether your bf shared his probs with his female best friend instead of you?? 

But I'll also like to thank you, exbf, for always encouraging me to be better. I know you won't deny I was a good and faithful gf to you, but I am so tired of being in your shadow. I think its very obvious this is written by me. Btw, you will never be able to understand how broken i was the past few yrs. I am still working on myself and trying to forgive and forget and also learning to believe that i have my own strengths without relying on affirmation from you. 

To all the single or attached people out there, its true that you have to love yourself first before plunging into any r/s. I learnt it the hard way :(

-
 
It was one of those late nights - the kind when waves of sadness just engulf me like a relentless tsunami. The park was dead silent. I picked up a knife and brought it against the translucency of my wrists. Cool metal met my wrist and I dug deep, tracing the length of the vein. Not thin horizontal lines that brush the surface, but a split that caused blood to gush out. I felt my consciousness slowly slipping away and I was certain that the pain would end soon. 

I roused to find myself surrounded by sanitised white walls with a nagging ache in my bandaged forearm. We both knew what happened, but the doctor still asked out of formality. 

"A freak accident," I said, "I fell and tried to regain balance on an exercise bar, but struck upon something sharp on my inner arm instead." 
"Well. You're lucky to be stitched up in time." 

We both knew that was never the outcome I intended for. 

Fast forward to the present - it's been three years. I still don't know what I'm suffering from; I'm afraid to seek help because I don't want the pity of others. I go about my normal daily activities - school, lectures, tutorials, hall activities, sports - behaving like any other person, but I shut my door only to cry myself to sleep every night. The smallest thing is enough to trigger a breakdown, but I force myself to hold it together until I'm alone. 

A counsellor that I once spoke to told me to surround myself with family and friends that could make me happy. I tried, but it always seemed that if I derive my happiness from interactions with a certain person, it would prove that I am incapable of achieving happiness by myself and that it's solely dependent on another being. In terms of relationships, it's hard to love someone who is so unstable, which is why I never blamed any of them when they chose to leave. However, it seems like there is this one guy who has yet to give up. His sincerity is terribly endearing, and the effort he has placed into developing a better relationship between us goes beyond measure. 

He once said this. 
"You're like a cloud of sadness, but because you're always engulfed in all of those negative emotions, it is so easy to make you happy."
I turned to look at him, confused by what he said.
"Yes, I mean it. The smallest thing is enough to turn your entire day around. Other girls ask for the world, you ask for a pebble." 

This phrase has echoed in my mind ever since. I never thought of it that way, but it made me feel a little better about myself. Perhaps all this sadness made it possible for me to derive happiness from small and simple things. But to you, I'm sorry. You deserve much better than a girl who has a mental disorder that seems almost beyond repair. You're going to keep trying, and I'm only going to keep shutting you out, which only makes this unfair to you. I hope you find your happiness in the everlasting smile of another beautiful girl, and I will continue on my way until the darkness finally overwhelms - when these thoughts are put to rest, lost forever - just like how I have lost myself to them. 
-
 
Hello! I just wanted to share something funny that happened today. I've been with my boyfriend for over a year now and last night, I brought him back home to meet my parents for the first time. Things went well. My parents like him. We talked over dinner for an hour before my family and I resumed our normal habits. What normal habits, you might ask? Well, I come from a family who reads a lot. Every wall in our 3-room flat is shelved with books. Some books you might find under our beds, others under sofas. It's a habit we've had since I was young. Our family bonded over books. It's almost like nerdvana for a family of introverted academicians. My boyfriend, on the other hand, has never read a book outside of his reading list.

Boyfriend: "Eh, your family like you ah. All book nerds one! Abnormal leh?!"
Me: "Erm... in this household, you are the abnormal one."
BF: "Fuck sia, that's true. I go read the children's storybook. My level one. Hahaha"

#winliaoloh I'm making sure our future kids read more than their father.

Just because you have a friend of the opposite sex doesn't mean you necessary get attracted to each other. There might be a honeymoon period where you start to feel 'attracted' to the opposite person but eventually there comes to a point where the feeling is gone and you rather just be friends because he/she is not somebody within your expectations.

-
 
 I can empathise with you, however my story is a bit different. I made it into OCS, but OOC-ed after the service term (only lasted 3 months in OCS basically). Most people OOC because of injury. "What a waste of your talent! A bright future cut short by an unfortunate injury", you'd say to these people. Me, however, I had no talent, as was quickly apparent. I OOC-ed because I failed the assessments. And I guess this has been haunting me for some time. Imagine all the people who were proud of you for being selected for OCS - your parents and family, your (then-) girlfriend, your friends... Imagine all the people who had faith that you'd make a good officer - your BMT PC and sergeants, your bunk mates and platoon mates... Now I was nothing but a massive disappointment. The service term training qualified me to eventually be promoted to 3SG, yet, it felt empty because I never earned it the same way my spec peers did by going through SCS. Therefore in the hierarchy of officer-spec-man, I couldn't really fit in anywhere. 
At least as a Man, there are shared 'chiongsua' 'man-mode' experiences. There are less responsibilities and worries. You don't have to constantly prove yourself. I suppose I wouldn't mind having your army experience over mine.
Well there's no happy ending here. Don't have many friends now, been single all throughout uni, never took up any leadership positions, don't even have good grades. Whereas many of my peers who were "only" men are doing very well for themselves now. So army is army, you are only ever a Man again during reservist. But outside of that you can be so much more! :)

What i'm about to share is my darkest secrets that i hope i'll bring it to my death.

A brief background of myself. My dad passed away when i was 5 years old. My mum single-handedly raises me and my two sisters. She could only take up low pay and long hours job as she's uneducated. Since 12 years old, i started taking up all sort of part time jobs. Supporting my family and focusing on my studies have always been my priorities. 

Fast forward to last semester (my final year). I'm expected to graduate with a second class (upper) honour. Being sick and tired of working part time for all these years. I've come up with, what i initially thought was, a brilliant plan to earn more money. I decided to gamble at casino with my little savings. To my surprise, i'm rather good at it especially playing tai sai. Believe or not i managed to earn about $60k in just 13 visits. My biggest winning of the day was $15k. Nevertheless there are times when i lost money but i'd leave when i lose $2k. At the very last visit i cash in $10k hoping to win at least two fold. But i lost it all. So i applied for casino self-exclusion to prevent myself from becoming addicted. My mum is still unaware that i had stopped working part time because she's always busy working.

Since i came from a low income family, dating has never crossed my mind i.e i have never been in a relationship for the past 25 years. I really wanted to feel how a girlfriend experience is like. But I'm totally clueless how to approach a girl. I hated the fact that i'm forever single. To make it worse, i don't have any best friends or cliques for that matter. I feel like I'm such a loser in life. Why do i have to sacrifice so much for my family?!? What do i get in return??? 

As a desperate attempt, i decided to hire a social escort. I got myself a mid-tier girl which costs $1.8k for a full day session excluding other expenses like eating and shopping. I was extremely nervous on my first 'date'. I won't elaborate on the details. But i felt that it's the best day of my life. I had so much fun when accompanied by her. I actually arranged for another meet up a week later. This time round she asked if i want to spend the night with her. I agreed without a slight hesitation even though i need to pay additional $1k. After that night, our relationship has just moved up to another level. We exchanged our numbers and she's agreed to go on date without going through her agency. She told me i don't have to pay her so much in our future dates. We have been meeting up for about 5 months. I think i've deeply fallen in love with her. I also felt that she's genuine feelings for me. She's hinted me on several occasions that she'll quit her job just for my sake. I got so emotionally attached to the extent that i've lost interest in my studies. In the end, i dropped to second class (lower) honour upon graduation and i've yet to find a full-time job as of I'm writing this confession.

My current dilemmas are:
1) should i let my mum knows that i've been supporting the family from the money that i won from casino or continue to lie to her that it's from my part-time job??

2) should i continue to maintain my relationship with her or try to end this relationship just in case that she actually just want my money??(which i don't have much to begin with)

Any kind souls out there please share with me your opinions. I'd greatly appreciate it. Thanks for taking your time off to read my confession.

-
 
 I had the exact same situation and feelings as , except that instead of continuing on with SCS, I was immediately sent to be a 'Man' as a medic. I felt inferior and that I was a failure, letting my loved ones down since I was probably so bad at leadership that I couldn't even make the cut to be trained as a sergeant (I failed ALL leadership assessments lolol). 

I guess you can say I was "onz" as I am naturally inclined to listen and follow "orders" from superiors. Yet beyond the ranks and formalities (unavoidable since well, army), as long as you were sincere, friendly and willing to open up, there's a certain level of friendliness that people would show towards you as a person. Especially if you didn't hold a high rank. Being a 'man', I personally felt it was easier for me to connect with others.

Even towards sergeants and officers, I was on friendly bro terms with many of them; talking about random stuff here and there before we got down to doing serious work stuff. At times I even used the term "Sir" to poke fun of them, considering how it felt like we were on the same level even with that wide gap in rank.

That aside, army stuff is only relevant when you're in the army. I wasn't a commander back then and I no longer regret it. I thoroughly enjoyed my remaining year in my unit even as a 'Man', interacting with whoever I could and talking cock to kill time. Talking to commanders made me realise we aren't all that different. You see some of them as introverts, shy, wayang, arrogant etc; nobody is perfect. 

I myself feel I'm a leader in my own way within my social circles. I made used of whatever social skills I picked up in army (I was extremely awkward/quiet so I decided to force myself to open up) to make friends in uni. If you want avenues to practise leadership skills, you can join hall/CCAs and run as an exco member. Sure it'll take a while, everybody makes mistakes. But seriously, don't let your army experience hold you back. There's a reason everybody can't wait for the day to shout "ORD LOH" and move on to the next chapter of life.

tl;dr You don't need arrows or a chocolate bar to prove your own worth. Just be a leader in your own way, learn from your mistakes and move on with life. It's more fun that way :).

Day 1: I looked at her smile and immediately was attracted to you. I made small talked with you and got your number. Knowing that I would see you again in future was a happy feeling. You was older by about 5 years, but that wouldn't matter to me.

Month 3: I was happy to spend more time together with you, just as friends. We went together on HSBC treetop walk just me and you. 

Close to 1 year: You made a cake for my birthday! I remember this till today, every time there would be a birthday event and there would be a cake, it would remind me of you.

December that year: You broke your ankle and I had a part to blame for it. That was when I realized you were already married. That moment my heart sank. That I was foolish to believe a girl of your nature and quality would not already have been taken. I start to question myself would I be able to accept another half who have been previously married. I still took you out for walks and spend time during this recover process, perhaps due to mix of infatuation and guilt. I was glad your recovery was a smooth one.

That one fine day we took a overseas trip together we were in group conversation and you asked if I will be able to accept a divorcee, I said something that I could never have taken back. Our relationship went downhill from that day onwards. I had nailed my own coffin right then.

3 years have passed... I am still thinking back about you. Maybe I will eventually move on or maybe I won't.

-
 
I notice many people posting about how that they are introverts and hence not interesting in camps, find it hard making new friends, or feeling depressed and lonely. Don't use the term introvert as an excuse for your social ineptitude and laziness of stepping out of your comfort zone. If you are depressed or have difficulties talking to people, you should see a psychologist. Being introverted does not entail being mentally ill. Introverts are termed as such as they restore  energy being alone but as normal humans they enjoy social interactions as long as they are able to recharge by having some alone time after that. Please stop using the term introverted as an excuse for everything and give introverts a bad name.

After seeing more and more posts on introverts and bring socially awkward I decided to post this. 

Yes I am an introvert, but definitely not socially awkward. There's a huge difference between the 2. If you're not able to step out to the public and make new friends please don't justify yourself by claiming you're an introvert. Not being open and keeping thoughts to yourself has absolutely nothing with your ability to blend in and make new friends with crowds. 

Peace out

To  to answer your question: i think it really is a matter of principle and about character of the parties. It is also really about how you'd like to start out your new relationship. If two people are meant to be together, they will. And if you truly love someone, wouldnt you want them to be happy? I will share my own experience.

I was attached a few years before and my friend, x, really liked me. However, he supported me in staying in the relationship because he thought it made me happy. It was only after he found out that i was unhappy that he let me know his feelings for me but i did not leave immediately (even tho i had some feelings for him too) out of commitment and respect to my current partner. He understood too and left it at that.  It was only after a mutual breakup and some time of healing later that i got together with x.

Advantages? Less baggage and i knew i wanted to be with him for who he is and not just because someone else made me unhappy. Im glad he respected my space and didnt try to crowd me or fight for me when i was attached.

After all, who wants to start a relationship on the foundation of having forcefully wrecked another?

My physical and mental health is deteriorating at an intimidating pace. Nights are the worst, that 8 hours when everyone is asleep while I'm up torturing myself in various unbelievable ways. Nights are supposed to be the best for introverts like me, although I still think they carry their own positive aspect in which is because I'm the most honest and the most 'real'. Many times at night, I evaluate the unfairness in life, think about my own lack of freedom and question the meaning of my existence, and in a worse state of mind, I think about suicide. Lately, I just feel like giving up. I am so tired of trying yet to no avail. I don't think I will ever recover. I am scared of looking at myself for more days to come, and even more afraid of experiencing my impact on others. 

Positivity has always been my goal, but now I can't stop myself from questioning: Is there an escape out of this dark world? Will I ever find this exit?

-
 
@OP of 
I feel you man. Not sure if you are in the similar situation as me, but basically I have lots of acquaintances but am not close to any of them. And from time to time, I also experience that emptiness as well.

As for why you are in such a situation, there are a few possible reasons:
1) Being socially awkward; this is a very big issue
2) Not trusting others enough to open up to them (though of course you shouldn't reveal every single thing about yourself)
3) Having a face that looks unfriendly/intimidating/etc
4) Having very different interests, principles, etc from others
These are just some reasons I could think off the top of my head, I'm sure there are more.

What can you do? Perhaps a change of mindset is in order. As hard as this sounds, you are going to have to stop being so dependent on relationships with others, i.e. become emotionally independent. You try your best, and if nothing works out, you move on. You can at least stay as acquaintances. Never harm others, and do your best to help them when required, but don't expect people to reciprocate your efforts because you need to realize that they are not obliged to do so. Do this, and you will generally be well-liked/respected by others, though they may just be acquaintances. You will also be hopefully spared from the torment of wondering why your investments are never returned with close friends. However, by chance, if you do make some really close friends along the way, make sure to treasure them! And remember that you still have your family as one of your pillars of support.

The next thing to do is to focus your energy on improving yourself in areas of your life that you have direct control over (such as your academics, physical fitness, etc). This ties in with what I said above: the more you improve yourself as a person, the more independent you are able to become, and irregardless of whether you have close friends or not, you will generally be able to stand on your own two feet and live on proudly. As for how, I won't elaborate since it's quite self-explanatory. You know, study harder, read more books to improve your knowledge, go work out, etc etc.

All the best mate, things may not turn out the way you want them to in life but I hope that you find the courage to strive on nevertheless.

-
 
Where are your opinion of finding the one?

I read several comments about creating the one > finding the one.

Are you saying that you should randomly find someone who wanted to commit with you, you two become get in a relationship and build up the relationship over time even if you didn't feel any infatuation for him/her initially?

Are you saying that finding the one isn't important? 

My theory is different. I feel that a relationship won't start without passion. I feel that we have to find "the one" and be in a relationship with him/her. He/She doesn't have to be perfect for you but he/she must be good enough that you will have feeling for him/her.

After that, work toward building intimacy.

 Take note that I do agree that creating the one > finding the one. However, I feel that finding the one is the important first step.

What do you all think?

-
 
I post on social media quite a lot. So much, it's actually... Noise. I lose friends on social media more often than not, because of my emotional outbursts, noise-making, etc.. I actually do monitor  the number of friends I have on social media. 

I'm one of those people, whom others come by with the opinion of "hey,there's something wrong with this guy, he's weird, he's irrelevant to me, I don't think I will keep him around any more, I don't think I would want to even be any where near him." I am very aware of it, much, much more than you actually think. 

How so? I actually do review what I post, and think about it,censor it, the next day. 

Now, why would I do that? I can't say this out loud, and most people who have seen me around might have already figured out (or not) by now, that I am very, very lonely. Having problems talking to others, face-to-face, is not helping either. Perhaps, posting noisily on fb was an outlet to generate some faux presence of company to let me think that I am not alone.

Though thank goodness, I do have a single good friend who is patient enough to withstand and see through my behaviour. I don't intend to lose her.

You know what? Forget social media. I think there's a life outside the net that I should be living. 

At least, I hope the sun will be welcoming as it was, many times when I stepped out of the net. 

Well, that's a lot of "I"s, but someday, it will not be about "I" or "me" anymore. I only need a listening ear,so thanks for listening.
-
 
I met this guy at a 3-day CCA camp in the last week of my exchange. Our first conversation happened during dinner one day. He came over to the group I was sitting with, and introduced himself to me. We had a good long chat about our common interest. I really enjoyed that conversation and I think we hit it off quite well. We weren't talking to each other exclusively though. We sort of alternated between our conversation between us and joining in the group conversation. At that time, I didn't have any interest in him yet, just saw him as an acquaintance.

The next time we talked was when I was talking to some other people during break and he joined in. We had a very intellectually provoking and interesting chat again. This happened again the next day during break. Throughout our interactions he made several comments about how interesting our conversations were, how he enjoyed them, and how we should have those conversations again. What struck me was how he remembered and referenced each occasion of our conversation (first at dinner, then during break at a particular spot in the room), when he commented on how he enjoyed our conversations. He also made several nice comments about me throughout the camp.

The last night, I approached him to start a conversation during a social event, and it went well again. Again, we ended up chatting in a group, but it was all very fun. We were playing a game, and once, when I won, he excitedly placed his hands on my shoulders lightly to congratulate me (not in an offensive way). It was then that I felt something for him. 

Before I ended my exchange, one of the people in his clique, who was also my friend, contacted me to meet up. Then he messaged me and asked me to meet up too.

We eventually met up, with his clique, over lunch. I didn't get a chance to speak much to him unfortunately. I noticed he was a bit jittery when we first met, and a bit unlike his usual self. I wanted to ask him if he was alright, but after a while he was fine. So the gathering ended, and we spoke a bit, but not like how we talked to each other during the retreat. I was quite disappointed because I was hoping to get to know him better personally.

After that I SMS-ed him to thank him for organizing the meet up, just general thanks and take care and stuff. He replied pretty general stuff as well, and it was a close-ended message, like there was no "space" for us to continue the conversation.

Maybe it's too impulsive for me to say that I really like him, because I haven't really got to know him well. Even if I think I like him, it's probably a shallow infatuation kind of thing because of our pleasant interactions during the camp. But he is definitely someone I would want to explore being friends with at least, even if we don't progress. At this point, it seems like he is quite uncontactable and not responsive. 

I know he is currently busy with something, but I'm beginning to feel that this was all one-sided to begin with. Maybe I've been imagining this all along, interpreting everything to be positive hints. I've been thinking about him and I'm quite interested in getting to know him. I just don't know what is on his mind right now, or if disappointment awaits me.
