I've never been good at handling relationships. No matter how much effort i put into developing my friendships or relationship, everyone eventually walks out on me. 

It feels so lonely and hollow to be me. All i've ever wanted was to be the best buddy/bf to those close to me. But, I've always just been treated as a puppet - doing only things that others expect of me, saying only things that others want to hear. Failure to do so makes me a defective puppet, easily thrown away and replaced with another.

I really do not understand what im doing wrong. I've been tolerating the fact that most of my efforts i invest is not returned in the slightest - so long as i know that i still have friends around me. But despite all the giving without receiving, it doesnt seem to be enough for anyone. They all still fade away eventually. 

I've got nothing to my name. im not rich, im not smart, im not good looking and i dont have a ripped body to show. All i have is my honesty, and my loyalty. but i guess such things are no longer valued in this day and age..

I know how you feel. I have absolutely no interest in any of the things you listed out in your post either (I don't know any of the popular English or Chinese Pop songs or either; the only songs I listen to are Anisongs), and none of my friends in NUS share the same interests as me. However, do not restrict the topic of discussion with your peers to just interests alone!  When are your friends are in their own world talking about things that seem alien to you, just listen quietly, or you can even introduce to them what your interests are.
PS. I tried introducing my friends to some Anime, Manga or games like Kancolle, but it didn't work out very well =( But that doesn't stop me from interacting and getting along with them!

To OP of ,
I totally understand how you feel about your older brother. Mine's exactly the same, except now he's 4 years out of NS and cannot hold a proper job/education. Everytime we ask what he wants to do, pursue another education (he kinda flunked poly) or get a full-time job (he's jumps between adhoc jobs, he hates every single one of them and quits so easily), every response is a shrug and an "IDK", which annoys my family to no end.

What many are terming the mid-twenties as the prime of someone's life is the bane of his existence and all he does is play computer games with little or no communication to the outside world. He refuses help for anything, and worse still he buys things with whatever little savings he has to feed his addictions.

We were all at our wits ends, but we try our best to reintergrate him back into reality by forcing him to pick up life skills such as driving in hopes that one day if he realizes that he really needs to support himself, he has a driving job to fall back on.

dearest OP, you're not alone. We can only support our brothers as much as we can the only ways we know how. A supportive community of friends and family would really help, so perhaps you can try to engage him in whatever ways we can.
-
 
I received a whatsapp msg from my mum over the weekends. Bad news. My grandmother has passed away. I gave my mother a call, asked what happened and if she was okay. She said i didn't have to come back for her funeral (i'm on exchange). After hanging up the call, i had dinner, eating and talking with friends in the restaurant, like nothing happened.

And it is during times like these, late at night, when i reflect on the past few days, that makes me feel bad.
Not because of the passing of my grandmother.
But because i didn't feel anything about it. The reaction i had was just like a ''oh okay''.
And even the concern i expressed for my mother was not genuine concern, but just actions expected of one.

I've always known that i'm a cold person, but not till this extent. Not batting an eyelid when someone close passes away.

-
 
To  

Just want to let you know that you are not alone. My parents are also overprotective of me (more so than my peers'). At 21, I still have a curfew, am not allowed to go for sleepovers or on overseas trips alone/with friends. I've talked to them but it just ended in lots of shouting, weeks of 'cold war', the 'I'll disown you' threat and basically it went nowhere. I used to really hate my parents for the missed opportunities and experiences I could have had. I was jealous of my friends' parents who trusted them and let them do what they wanted. I was even jealous of broken families because the parents are rarely there and children could do whatever they want (I know, I was young, stupid and ungrateful). 

As I grew older, I understood where my parents are coming from. Not to say that I do not resent them for the restrictions and control they placed upon me. After all, unless you're financially independent, your parents still have a lot of leverage (money!!). But it's a lot of give and take, I guess. Others with less controlling parents will not understand why people like us don't just break all their restrictions and yolo - after all, parents will likely never disown us despite their threats. But every parent and every family is different. Some parents need more time to 'let go' of their children. I guess I am more harmony-loving and figured that I cannot tolerate days of quarreling with my parents. I took the more gradual approach and struck compromises to slowly help my parents come to terms that they have to let me go some day. My parents have always been there for me in their own ways, gave me all they had and raised me in comfort all these 21 years. I think they deserve that much, and that is all I can do to help them and help myself. 

Even if the process is slow, be patient with your parents. Start small. Explain to your parents that you're young and you still need a social life, but reach some kind of compromise with them. Show them that you understand their point of view, and placate their worries. Try to take your chances and push some boundaries (but not too often, or you'll lose their trust). If you have friends who guilt-trip/look down on you because of your situation with your parents, let me tell you, you don't need them. I am very lucky to have friends who are super understanding of my situation - they always made sure I got home before my curfew and they never ever make me feel guilty for not being able to go on trips with them. Surround yourself with supportive friends and treasure the time with your parents. 

All the best!

On the face of it, you might see me as a cheerful, easy going, and probably an intelligent lad. Beneath the facade, I feel that no matter how hard I try, I just can't convince myself. I don't have a high CAP, nor am I rich. In fact, I am looking at a huge amount of loan after I graduate, and so does my parents. That don't matter, I don't mind living at a bare minimum for years. What scared me is that with my low scores, I can't find a single employer. I do have a sense of direction in my life that I want to achieve but at this point, nothing seems certain.

I have a fair share of s***ty moments in my life, mostly from abusive peers and teachers back in high school, that it sometimes gave me a depressive episode. I don't want to trouble no one, my family included. They have never knew of this issue before, which is reasonable. Because I have never told them about this. Our family's facing financial issues and also they're a firm believer of 'you-can-stop-depression-by-not-being-depressed' method. They're all in a lot of stress already and my condition won't really help them at all.

I often wondered about ending myself, but there's not much ways I can do to seriously kill myself. If this were America I might have ended myself long ago thanks to the second amendment. I have always accepted my mortality, but I just don't want to leave any loose ends, should the attempt fail.

I deeply apologise if my content lacks coherence (I do feel it goes all over the place) as I am typing this in a kind of a... well, not so good condition, and I purposefully omitted a lot of details so as to preserve anonymity.

A lot of breakup stories here recently which I found interesting to read. Really kowtow the admins of this page for sifting through the immense number of posts man. I can't even keep up reading all yet you guys are able to look through everything. Keep up the good job and sorry to add yet another post for you to read.

Before I entered NUS, I only had one bf, not because guys weren't interested but because I always felt awkward after a few dates and would pull away. This carried on in the first 1.5 years of uni as I dated a few guys, until I met my ex through a mutual friend in a club. He was the one who chased me, and for the first time, I felt like, okay maybe this is a guy I can see myself being with. But once our 3 month relationship began, he would say things like "What if I go to NTU and find somebody better?" (he is my age and I was Y2) or "I don't think I want to wait for you when you go for SEP". Eventually I broke up with him because I knew it was for the best, but being weak, I regretted it immediately and asked him if we could at least try again until I go for SEP and we see how (I know, I'm so lame). He said no, and even until today, it still hurts to think about that period in my life.

After SEP I came back, and met another guy through another mutual friend. He seemed nice, and we seemed to have a lot in common, and there was much more chemistry compared to my ex. On one of our dates, we started making out in his car at Kent Ridge park, and I was happy that maybe I finally found a guy who is really into me. Fortunately or unfortunately, I started thinking about how my ex hurt me, and I stopped and asked him if he saw us progressing into a relationship. I was honestly quite shocked when he said no and that we were just fooling around. He didn't really want to talk to me after that night. Again, I regretted asking for a serious relationship, and hinted if we could just hang out and be make-out buddies, but he wasn't interested as he was going on SEP. After this second heartbreak (and a slew of dating other guys who just didn't want to commit), I was quite disappointed with the whole dating scene, and I felt like I would never be able to find a guy who would ever want me and love me, and maybe I didn't deserve it since it seemed so impossible. Up to that age, I'd never even had a serious relationship before, and I just felt like I was too lame to be anyone's girlfriend.

Fast forward to today, shortly after I graduated, I met my current bf, who really makes me feel like I'm so loved, and I'm so grateful for him. It makes me wonder why I ever bothered asking those 2 guys to take me back and trying to compromise my standards.

TL;DR: if you break up with someone, it's probably for the best. you never know if something better will come along for you, so don't give up hope!

I am the guy with the girls' shit fetish in . Firstly, thank you all, I expected to be condemned yet again, but instead I found understanding. Especially Nuo Ning, Hillary, and Darryl, really thank you for the effort to undrstand. 

I guess I will elaborate further so everyone will understand a little more and won't be so quick to judge. Since young I already was adverse to all kinds of dirty things. Mud, sand, feet, farts, dirt etc., even I was disgusted by my own shit. Since I was always scolded that being dirty was unbecoming, I grew to become an absolute clean freak.

I think as I grew up I totally switched to the other side. All till one day during sec sch class chalet, one of my female classmates pranked me by farting on my face while I was half-asleep. I pretended to still be asleep as they laughed, but I couldn't resist getting turned on. The smell was so disgusting, as if something died in her bowels. For a girl to be that dirty, I thought it all to be so wrong, yet so right! Especially since during those years, most guys probably have the illusion that girls fart rainbows and don't poop.

Fast forward to this year's ocip when I found my female friend's poop half-flushed. I thought of simply ignoring it, but when I saw the speck of undigested red chilli skin from the veggies we ate 2 days before, and imagined how a small girl can produce something so nasty from her butt, I lost it. In effect I had cheated on my gf with two other girl...s' shit. Its really as wtf as it sounds :(

From a clean freak, I seem to have changed 180 and become totally fine with being dirty and all, but perhaps too much. They always say when you love someone, you wouldn't mind their dirty side. Like when my ex vomitted on me when she was sick, I was totally cool. 

So thanks all for trying to understand a little, I really appreciate it. For a rather well-liked guy to be hiding this from all his friends, it seems a little wrong. But I really do hope to find an awesome girl who doesnt mind, or is even into, this weird fetish of mine. To my ex, I'm really sorry I grossed you out and caused you hurt, but please move on and find a better guy.

-
 
 Hi there,

I think it is really great that you managed to continue with your current boyfriend despite the effort you may feel at times. 

A personal thing I feel is that it is often easy to have "that kind" of attraction for some else; it may be because you seek something unexpected (since it's three years, you probably are accustomed to doing the same things with your boyfriend). But one thing though: they don't last long. 

I feel that what's most important is a friendship: with your boyfriend. Not just the romantic side of it, but on a soulmate/friend level where you confide/rant about daily things to each other. Often in the romantic side, there's a need to present one's best side to each other. What you may been feeling is the liking of the other guy's best side, but perhaps on a friendship level you may find yourself incompatible. The key thing is the soulmate, romantic attraction, while nice and fun, should come after that. 

My take is of course, dont be too quick to fall into that. After all, you've gone through 3 years with your current boyfriend. I'm pretty sure on a friendship level, you are close with him. And that's really important. It may seem a little dry and unexciting compared to the other guy, but hang on there. Relationships aren't perfect, it's perhaps a usual down that you face. 

As to what to feel, you can suggest asking your boyfriend to do something different? Maybe that may include a holiday to somewhere different, perhaps do something like hiking? But apart from that, I think you will have this feeling for some time to come. A possible way (but it can be negative) would be to pick out the points you dont like about that guy, and it may reduce the initial attraction to him.

With camps ending and camps happening

Is anyone interested in the idea of a 'camp' for introverts? Granted, a number of introverts go to the current camps as do have fun and make friends, but there will be many who choose not to go/have a bad experience.

Even in the current camps, there will be chit-chat sharing sessions in after/in-between games, but I was wondering if people would be interested in a more 'low-key' orientation 'camp'. It probably wouldn't last as long everyday, and would be more of a long discussion with maybe board/card games rather than the high adrenaline kind which I feel that not everyone would particularly enjoy it. 

It allows people who tend to be less outgoing to be able to 'play' at their level. After all, we talk about being "our best selves" right. It can be difficult for people (me included) to be at our bests when meeting new people. I have the 'dao' look 95% of the time and I only drop it when I'm engaged in my 'level' ie not at those kind of games. 
-
 
With the recent decision in the USA that gays are entitled to marriage rights by the constitution, and the ongoing debate over being able to express one's own identity and being able to love who they want, I feel this is an apt time for my story.

I am a girl who fell in love with another girl 2 years ago. I first met her in my club activity, where she was handing out flyers to freshies asking them to join. This was a performing arts club and besides singing and dancing, which she was very good at, she was also in charge of costumes for the club's activities. She spent lots of time working on making the club a success and I fell in love with her diligence and dedication, while at the same time having a cute and engaging personality that charmed me to no end. During some weekends she even worked at a cafe but was too shy to let people know this, and almost tried to run away when I happened to chance upon her working. Even when she became part of the student council, she continued working hard for the club. When she made a mistake over another club's submission in the annual budget meeting, she was distraught and it tore my heart apart to see her like that. Despite this, her mistake only made her more human to me and made me want to care more for her and help her out. Through these past 2 years I have supported her and hoped that one day, I might be able to get together with her. However, hindered by the shackles of what society deems to be moral or acceptable, I have been unable to proclaim my love to the world, to make her accept my love, and for me to see any future with her. Because of this, I have kept my feelings a secret, although I am sure she knows how I feel and does not want to respond knowing the circumstances it will place us in. When I heard about what the SCOTUS decided, my heart leapt with joy. Maybe now, a future where one can marry whoever they want will arrive, and I will be able to be with my true love.

P.S. I'm in love with an anime character. 
-
 
I'm enrolling this year and never felt the need to attend any sort of orientation camp/activity. Being an introvert, I've attended several compulsory orientation activities from secondary school and JC, only to find myself not enjoying them because I was forced to play silly games and do silly, embarassing things in the spirit of bonding. But the sense of camaradarie that orientation was supposed to inculcate turned out to be skin-deep. Instead, cliques start to form. The shy ones, being outshone by their more outgoing and good-looking counterparts, become more insecure. Everyone knows a bit about one another but not a lot, in fact just enough for judgements to be passed and gossips to thrive.

My point is, as an introvert I've had enough of orientation activities. Recently I've read plenty of posts from people like me who took part in the recent orientation camps/activities by choice, only to find themselves blending into the crowd, not enjoying themselves, or becoming sufferers of camp politics. Allow me to advise these people to rethink the purpose of attending orientation, and if it offers too little returns for the shit you're going through, it's okay to leave the camp, go back home, have a shower and snuggle in bed with a good book. Introverts do need time to recharge, and 3, 4 days of non-stop socialising will obviously take a huge mental toll on us. It is perfectly fine to take a break, or to avoid these extra social activities altogether.

Personally I think making acquaintances is overrated, would rather have a few close friends than a vast network of acquaintances whom I exchange fleeting hi's and bye's with, and who only contact me when they need me and vice versa. It is also okay to lag behind in assimilating to Uni life. We will all catch up eventually, no need to be kancheong. It is perfectly fine to go through Uni as a loner. It is true that the outgoing, vocal ones are highly influential, but there's no need to give in to societal pressures. Just be comfortable with who you are. You can be self-sufficient. While love is a wonderful thing, there is no need to actively search for your other half too. Personally I prefer leaving love to fate, and if I'm fated to be evergreen, I accept the freedom of my singlehood with open arms.

TLDR; If you're struggling through orientation activities, there is no need to keep yourself there for the sake of marginal returns. Look at the bigger picture, consider keeping your happiness and sanity intact. Things will still work out fine without attending these activities.

For me, it took a few "encounters" before I fell in a love with my girlfriend. She is currently in overseas for exchange and I really miss her company. I want her to be back to my side asap and continue to build more memories together. 

I hope to post something positive so that everyone can share their romantic journey as well. 

Stay happy!

Freshie confession.
I have been to 2 orientation camps as of now; my fac's FOC and course camp. I am slightly introverted in nature but when I am close to the people around me, I can be pretty outgoing and vocal. 

I signed up for camps not wanting to miss out the fun of meeting new people,have a first glimpse of university life and not wanting to be lonely when school starts. 

Camps weren't too bad, I did made some friends and OGLs were friendly but honestly... I feel that I TRIED SO HARD to fit in. 

For my course camp, the more outgoing and vocal ones basically took charge of all the games and led the group in everything. But I had a really bad time that I was literally counting down to going home. There was this girl who is really nasty to me; during a game she just shoved me aside because the had enough people/told my OGL to pick another person for a role because(I quote her) 'Pick someone who talks more' etc. All because I play a passive role and is quiet most of the time. Half of the time I just feel very left out. When I say something, they don't listen and once that nasty girl used my idea as hers and everyone thought it was good. 

I did make efforts to make small talks with the girls in my OG(like talk about FOC/jc life etc) but somehow they don't really make the effort to really continue the convo(they rarely initiate to ask me anything) and me being slightly introverted and quiet, I usually listen to their convo and fade away or sometimes comment. However when they talk amongst themselves together, I feel like we do have similar interests and can possibly be rather good friends. 

Don't get me wrong,I mean the majority of them are nice people and we could talk but I don't foresee making much close friends. 

Now I am feeling quite helpless about my social life in university.I am thinking of joining a CCA to meet people outside of my fac but have no idea what to. I know I shouldn't change myself to suit others but this has been bothering me.

-
 
Just asking, i met this guy that says that he is interested in me but he doesn't like me enough. But his actions doesn't show that he is interested in me in either way. E.g. He doesn't really reply my texts, he does not initiate conversations, he doesn't ask things about me it's like he doesn't care. Is there a situation where a guy likes the girl but still does all these stuff? Pretty hard to understand for me hahaha.
-
 
Commencement is just around the corner. It is a day of celebration for the 4 yrs we spend to become a “bachelor of something in somewhat”. It is of great significance, as we put a closure to this life stage. I have watched you grown from someone who is totally obedient to your mum to someone who enjoys drinking behind her back. From the 19+ year old girl to the going-to-be-23 year old adult.

Let me recap a short summary of our love story. I met you in the middle of year 1 sem 2.. Some day in March during one of the interest group activity. After 2-3 months of knowing each other and spending time with common friends, we got a little bit more serious and courtship started. Then we both went for summer school, two different places with a slightly different time zones. They say distance makes the heart fonder. I guess that was true. Then came year 2 sem 1 where we got together, and also started spending lots of time with each other. I loved your laughter. I loved having breakfast/dinner with you everyday. We also took part in many activities together and organised an event together. Many couples celebrated birthday between themselves. But i know u are well-loved by your friends, and so I made sure that your birthday is celebrated with as many of them as possible. Even so, during our exchange together. 

Yes, we were fortunate that we could go to the same exchange universities together. We made things happen together. Lovebytes, our blog, our Facebook secret group, overseas trip, your fyp and my fyp.. We've been through many things together, stress, loss of matric card, your injury, my injuries and being there for each of us.. Throughout the journey, nothing seems to be impossible.. You gave me strength, you were my destination. As long as you are with me, it doesn’t matter where this journey leads us to. 

There are so many things we want to do together too.. or rather I want to do with you.. starting your own etsy store, renting a villa overseas, snorkelling, adventure cove, getting our first home and so many places to go together…Some people says, relationship is either break up or marriage. I think the longer the relationship is, the more pressing this question becomes...

This june, after your overseas trip.. U told me we are not compatible. I questioned myself so many times.. really? I thought of how many happy times we are together… with our friends, our families, or just our own. enjoying the long stroll, the cycle, watching shows together, slacking, playing photo hunt, playing mobile games and so much more… If we were not an item, we would be best friends…best friends by my definition… And yet, i tried to counter argue or convince you that things would be better for us after ur overseas trip… U would not listen… my emotional words just added on to your emotional turmoil… and mine cascaded too… Love shouldn’t be like a battlefield… 

Relationship has its ups and downs.. it is about growing together… The shared memories we have together, good or bad are ours.. And… in my darkest year of my academic life… u were there for me… you are the reason why i survived… and yet that took a toil on you.. And you decided to give up on us… Now… u are moving on to the next stage of your life while I am extending my candidature.. I got ejected out of your life.

I can think of many many reasons of what leads towards the breakup and many factors that helped u make the decision.. But I just keep telling myself, all that doesn’t matter now because u don’t love me anymore.. And.. all that matters is u don’t love me anymore... no love me anymore.

It’s been 1 month plus since you wanted the break up… The pain in me subsided… though my health is not exactly good now…  Everyday, I wake up missing you .. It’s like, Jaime Lannister losing his arm. The worst pain is over, and the pain felt like a dream.. Yet, I woke up like a crippled, a big part of life missing. I still cry from time to time… The weak side that my friends would never see. Some people move on faster than the other.. Me.. I know I will have a hard time moving on.. Take it as a respect I have for our relationship… U won’t see me in another r.s for a long time to come...

If you ask me, I already can’t remember any part of NUS without you. 

I am missing out on your commencement, the celebration of your NUS life, the growth you went through and the closure to a stage in life and you are moving on. I can’t be with you.. As much as I want to.. I can’t.. I am not supposed to love you or pester you any more.. I need to let you go.. You are the rainbow that I can never have.

Happy commencement.
- Your Whale

-
 
For those of you who saw the girl of your dreams and are willing to go all the way to pursue her, it's always good to slow down in case you turn her off.

In freshman year there was this really cute girl in this engineering mod I was taking, and because there's not a lot of girls in engineering in the first place, a lot of other guys were trying to go after her too. I think she announced that she wasn't looking for a relationship, but 4 other guys were still really persistent. Of course, I got anxious because of all the competition, so I didn't stop either.

Eventually, I think she got tired of our antics, and told us to each get her a different item of her choosing to show our sincerity. I was told to get her an asbestos suit (I have no idea why she'll want one), so I bought one online. Thinking I'm the only guy who would actually be willing to spend time and effort getting her what she wanted, I approached her after lab a week later only to find 2 of the other guys already in front of me. The first guy was told to get her some kind of bowl, but she said the one he gave her was a fake, so she rejected her. The other guy was supposed to get her this limited edition jewelry, but turns out he made a copy himself instead of getting the real one, so he got rejected too. I mean, like, okay he's a rival yes, but I feel kind of bad for him too, all that blood and sweat but getting rejected like that.

Then she got to me. I handed her the suit, and she used the bunsen burner to test it. It caught on fire, and luckily we managed to put it out before the fire alarm went off and the rest of the building knows about it. So it turns out I bought a fake suit off Taobao. Needless to say I got rejected as well.

Eventually I think she switched out, because we never saw her in class again. Sometimes I will think all the "what if"s, like what if my luck with online shopping wasn't so bad, or what if I wasn't so persistent and annoying back then.

Kaguya, if you are reading this, please forgive me for being so insensitive back then. Hope you're doing well

-
 
To , Was in the same situation, with 2.3k/mth, all the quarrel at home plus dad who is ill (high blood, high cholesterol, diabetes).
Took some burden off by not taking allowance - taking on tuition assignments, and if you had saved enough from army, you can possibly do less. Also, having a group of understanding friends who doesnt force me to spend more than I could really helped.
After graduation I worked really hard and finished paying off my loan within 2 years. Paying $1k/month was no joke either, but I survived.

Of course, I envy my friends who can spend $500 without batting an eyelid and travel to far and expensive places back then. But now looking back, I am glad for this experience. I am spending and travelling now, but saving alot more since my experience had "trained" me to be conscious of how I am doing the spending. And now I am much better at saving than most of my friends.i

As someone who also passed this phase, I want to tell you that there would be many times you feel like giving up. Uni fees and expenditure is a whole different level from JC, and juggling part time + studies is really bad. Make sure you have "me-time" to keep your sanity, make some supportive friends and also learn to become understanding towards others.

It would also be hard for your friends to understand at first - Dont expect people to simply understand what they had never experienced and what you never explained. 
They might say that you are skipping outings because you dont care about them, and yes, it would be really hurtful. If you want true friends, you need to open up and explain your situation to them first. If they choose a cheaper restaurant so that you can join, be thankful and go along, show them that you appreciate what they are doing. 
Dont expect them to always compromise too - they might still want to try their expensive cafe.

-
 
 I'm 21 this year and the thought of finding a life partner seems as unlikely as the chance of Singapore becoming a truly accepting state in my lifetime.

Being a realist and a somewhat pessimist, I've come to the conclusion that if I stick with the status quo, I'd probably die in an apartment too large for the occupancy of one person. I hate loud noisy places and have not been to a club before, and don't intend to. 

I'm not advising you to harden your heart like me. I'm a coward. But, I find that people who open their hearts to others are extremely courageous and somewhat admirable.

What I'm trying to say is that you should always look forward, but learn from yesterday. I believe you have it in you to make the right decisions when the time calls for it.

I'm probably the last person in the world that should put out this sort of advice, so do take it with copious amounts of salt.

The best of luck with life!

P.S. If you think about your exact situation in the gay guy's version, I'd like to think that we'd face pretty much the same thing. You're not alone :)

I could only encourage him. Then, he went on a SEP the following semester and supposedly found a new 'girl of his dreams' and even claimed he wants to marry her (she's from the country of his SEP). I was totally devastated but I couldn't do anything except to congratulate him. So, summer trips and SEPs will be bound to send you a hell of a ride down the emotional rollercoaster.

To the OP of  what do you mean by "(they) want (your) life to be in hell"? Are you relinquishing control of your life and how you feel about your life to someone else? If this is another love war post, be mature and ask the other party outright (Option A) "eh what's happenning now?" or "are we, or are we not?" If you're too nervous to do that and/or too impatient to wait the scenario out (Option B) why not try Option C: leave anyway and free your mind, fill it with other things, fill your time with other thoughts. There's no need to "turn a cold face" but be firm and guard your heart. Sincerely, a person who thinks they've gone through a similar situation

Since everyone is sharing their life stories, I thought I'd share mine. This is something not many of my friends know, probably only my boyfriend and my clique in JC. My family (consisting of myself, 2 brothers and my parents) were involved in a car crash while driving up to Malaysia. By some stroke of luck, I survived while the rest of my family did not. (it was also due to the fact that I was sitting in the last row of our 7 seater car). For a very long time I wanted to die as well, since I had lost basically everything that mattered to me.

This happened during my JC2 year and I was deep in depression, while still maintaining an outer facade of happy faces to my teachers and schoolmates. I only ever break down at home. It was a miracle that I managed to get into FASS here in NUS. 

After As, while most of my peers were drinking/clubbing/working, I was emptying out my house that was still filled with my family's things - clothes, books, day to day items, because I was moving to stay with my grandmother in Upper Thompson. I sincerely wish that none of you will ever have to face this alone. It took afew months but I finally settled in around July last year, just in time for school so I did not have the opportunity to join any camps whatsoever.

I'm not poor as compared to all the stories that are shared here, as my parents had prepared for such an occurrence in their will and I am forever grateful to them for that. However, I do not splurge either and think twice about things like starbucks that may seem like a normal good to some but a luxury good to me. 

It's not easy having to partition money to endure that I have enough money for the rest of my uni life as well as supporting my grandma should anything happen to her. So yes, to everyone living life on the "easy mode", please think twice before making a judgement on why people can't club/spend money on alcohol or even things you consider basic or a "given right" like camps and Starbucks.

Treasure your family. Don't wait till they're gone.

To the OP of , I am in a similar situation as you, but it's really much more tricky for me...

I'm also in a long term relationship (6+ years too). We drifted apart since last year because of issues with his ex, and other factors (gaming, work, escorts etc) Yes, I allowed him to visit escorts, I don't know for what reasons. But I guess many would think that this relationship a screwed up one, if you even managed to read till this point. 

So anyway, during this period of time, I met another guy. We got really close too, and he was the first to confess to me, and he said that he liked me. At this point of time, I was just starting to fall for him. I knew he had a gf and they already had a BTO flat under construction, but they were not on good terms...

But we got together anyway, we were each others' "part-time gf/bf". But it wasn't the case, we talked everyday on the phone for more than 2 hours, usually till 2-3am. We would meet almost 4-5 times a week till late night (not hanky-panky activities, that didn't happen very frequently). We told each other things that not even our close friends and partners knew, we had our own inside secrets and jokes... Basically it felt like he was my real bf instead... I would hang out with his friends (his gf doesn't like them, she's much older than him). I felt much more comfortable around him only after a few months as compared to my bf of 6+ years.. 

Before I knew it, it was a full blown affair, both emotionally and physically. And before I could realise it, I was totally in love with him, and he told me he loved me too. We talked about replacing our gf/bf with each other, and returning the BTO deposit to his gf... I really contemplated breaking up with my own bf for him. 

One day, he asked me seriously if he should break up with her. I didn't know what got into me. In my heart I was furiously saying "yes of course you should", but I didn't want to act like the evil third party in the TV shoes, so I asked him to consider it carefully. And we didn't talk about it anymore. 

I REGRETTED IT. That was the biggest mistake of my life. 

A few months later, he told me that he was getting married at the end of this year. I asked him what happened to the promises that he made to me, and he replied that he did consider his choices after what I told him, and he chose her eventually as he didn't want to break his promise... 

I was devastated when i heard it. I still am. 

We are still together today, I can't let go, it's too painful. i fought to make him change his mind, I really tried... I know my time is limited with him so I'm cherishing what's left of the moments with him. And I don't know what to do. I am crying everyday because I miss him so much. 

It's impossible to turn back time, and I cannot find back the feelings that I had for my bf anymore. 

I'm stuck. 

I do not regret my decision because this past 1.5 year had been the happiest days of my life. But my darkest days are coming, once he leaves me to get married to her. 

If it is tl:dr for you, basically, I let 2 third parties come into my r/s with my bf (both his and mine), and I became a third party in someone else's relationship.  I'm very screwed up, I know. I don't have any advise for you because I think I need more advise than you. Just follow your heart and don't pretend to say something when you don't mean it. Your heart will know what you want and don't want. 

sigh.

This is because she is a strong believer of Christ and I am a free thinker. Apparently there is this verse in the bible that states that Christians should not get together with non-believers. She was afraid that we would drift apart because I won't be able to fulfil her spiritual needs. Even her Christian parents and church leader said no. Hence we concluded that it might be better not to start a relationship that is likely to fall apart one day or another.

Despite me saying that I understood what she needs, a part of me just want to lash out at her. So she chooses to sin (ie doing something that goes against some verses) but she cannot go against that verse for me? Maybe she just doesn't like me enough...

And up till now, we still talk and go out. We are even talking about going for a jb trip together (which she initiated). Also, she is not the gold digger type. Always insisting to pay for her share of the meal/movie/USS trip together and she did.

So what do you guys think? Should I move on or patiently wait for the day that she will change her mind and consider getting together with me?
-
 

I feel your pain as well since my family lives on 2k a month only. The frustrating part is that it's really difficult to 1) confide in anyone about my financial status and 2) for anyone to understand that my habits are due to my near-broke situation.

Many seniors advise us freshies to enjoy ourselves and get to know more people through camps and social events, but little does anyone know how much thinking and stressing I go through each time before I sign up for a camp or social event. $80+ for O-Week may seem like crumbs to some, but $80+ can keep me going for 3 whole weeks if I will myself to. Of course many people would say that one cannot and should not compare money with the value of bonds forged through camps and social events, but in my situation isn't it fair for me to consider twice or even thrice before deciding to go? It's really demoralizing when people say that it's disgusting of me to measure everything in monetary terms, but given the choice, the family background and a greater degree of financial freedom, would I do that? Of course not.

To those out there who are playing life on "easy mode" right now, I just hope that you guys will be able to try and understand the mindset of people playing life on "hard mode" before labeling us as awkward, anti-social, "money-minded" freaks. We are here trying to do our best in the hope of breaking out from the poverty circle and such demeaning comments are of no help in alleviating our situation. If you could reach out to us, understand the difficulties we face, give us a pat on the back and say "well done, keep it up", you might just gain yourself a loyal confidant.

Thanks for reading my rant. Bye.
-
 
Sometimes I look at my CAP, and wonder if I can ever manage to pull it to a decent CAP of 3.5.

I'm a Year 2 and going Year 3 and my CAP currently stands at 3.38. It's not that I don't study hard or study smart. So far, I've never gotten a C+ or below, but the thing is that I've only gotten an A- so far and most of my other modules were B-.

I once asked my friend, would you rather get a range of As, Bs and Cs or would you rather get just a range of Bs (B+, B, B-). My friend didn't give me a definite reply. Sometimes I feel so small around my friends who are smarter than me, and because I feel so ashamed of my lousy CAP, whenever I'm asked my CAP, I lied saying "It's within the Second Lower Class Honours range".

I don't even know if I will get there. I'm not even aiming for an impossible, like First Class (because I know my abilities). This lousy CAP of mine would probably haunt me until the day I achieve my goal of 3.5. Will I even get there? A train of "What Ifs" ensues as well, What if because of my CAP I couldn't get an internship? And what if I don't get a job in future :( My future seems so bleak.
-
 
Guy A and I used to be project mates for a module, hence I knew him and we would say "Hi" if we see each other around in school. Last semester, I found out that he was going to the same summer school programme as me. Hence I was quite happy because this means there's one more person I know going for summer school. 

When summer school started, I didn't talk to him or hang out much with him because I always hang around with the group of friends I signed up summer school with. Somehow Guy A and I started talking more to each other after being put into the same project group. Each time after project, we would have meals together and chill, sometimes with our other friends as well. My other friends thought that we would make a good couple because whenever me and him made conversations with each other, it's always as if we were a married couple, bickering at each other. He would even play along, calling me "Dear..". Initially I found it gross, although it was meant to be a joke, but as time passed, I found myself liking it whenever he does that. And I'm not sure when, but gradually, I found myself liking him.

Time and time again I would catch myself waiting for him to pass by, hoping that he would come and talk to me, etc. Then one day we had nothing to do after school so, me, wanting to find out more about him, I said "Hey why not let's have some proper, deep conversations. You tell me things that I don't know about you and I will tell you things you don't know about me." He found it interesting so he agreed to my request. After sharing 3 things about each other, when it was his turn again, he suddenly said "I like a girl who came for this summer school." 

At that moment when I heard it, I did wonder if it was me (deep inside, I was hoping it was me), but then I doubted so. Even though he played along with the "married couple" joke, I doubted so. I tried to guess who's the girl he liked. He did give me clues on who the girl was, and he even teased me, saying "What if it's you?" 

Well, I am a girl who always feel that guys wouldn't like me, simply because there are tons of girls who are better and that all these guys deserve better. Even though deep down I wished what he said is the truth, I rolled my eyes and said "Please..." and continued guessing who was the girl he like. When I mentioned Girl Y's name, he immediately went "Was it obvious?". Upon hearing that, I wasn't sure what to feel. But one thing for sure, a part of me shattered. I never knew he was actually trying to chase Girl Y - because I don't see them hanging out together often. 

Ever since that conversation, I wondered if what he said was true - that he actually liked Girl Y. I soon realised how if the both of them walked together, he would at times, stop to match her pace (he didn't do that when he was with me or other people); and there was once he even sent her back to her dormitory after school. Upon knowing all these I was a little upset. A part of me wondered if I should stop crushing on him, the other part of me wondered if I should prove to him that I am the one for him. I had the latter thought because there was once, a guy friend of ours asked him if he would consider me as his gf and he said "Yeah, why not". My other friends also told me that they doubted Girl Y actually likes him because he wasn't her type. 

Now, despite summer school's over for me, all the times spent together, the memories never stop flooding back to me. Sometimes when I think about the conversations we had with each other, I thought that we would really make a good couple and hence wish that we could get together. What my friends told me are making me feel that I might stand a chance. But I don't know how he feels about me, if he ever thinks about all these things like I do. I'm not even sure if he's going to continue his endeavour of chasing Girl Y; if Girl Y will eventually like him; and if she doesn't, will he move on. I don't think I will know any time soon

Post mortem: i dont know if i am capable of real love at the moment. I mean its alright. Im always the one my friends turn to for advice with their relationship and they hope I find someone who really deserves me when in fact I feel too broken inside to put all this behind me. not a soul knows about this past habit of mine. And I dont want anyone who is with me in future to deal with this hard truth. Its not fair to them. 

I know i am  being irrational. We all are. We have these irrational worries. Whether we are facing difficult situations. Or problems in relationships with family friends lvoed ones or other issues in life. Its always clearer from a third person point of view.

In the end I want to strive to help the world in one way or another. A soul too broken to have a mate still has so much to give. Millions of people out there do not have enough food to eat, no clean water to drink and here we are living probably one of the most, i shall put it this way, "provided for" childhood/youthhoods in the world. We all face varying hardships in our lives but when we compare it outside of this comfort zone. Our hardships sometimes cannot even compare.

And it also makes me wonder why we waste our lives on such pleasures that consume us from within.

-
 
It is supposed to be an honor to receive a wedding invitation from someone, yet it seems to have become a plague which is to be avoided, especially when the person is merely acquainted to us.

Recently, I've have been receiving a lot of wedding invitations from people, even though I've only met them a few times and we are not close. Yes, I am pleased you remembered me and I am most honored to be present at your joyous occasion, however I've been listening to other colleagues around me, and they were complaining they have been "saman" (a.k.a. given a parking ticket), since they were obliged to give the newly wed a red packet with money. 

This made me feel very sad and a little disgusted at their behavior towards a couple's happy occasion. A small amount of red packet money goes a long way for the couple since it helps them to defray the banquet's cost and most importantly, acts as a sign of blessing.

Perhaps I cannot entirely blame them as well, because it's the culture we have which makes a wedding ceremony less and less enjoyable, especially for us Chinese. (I am not sure about the other races) As I've attended countless weddings of family and friends and had been listening to their conversations during so, I realized that wedding ceremonies have become a platform for people to, unfortunately, "hao lian" (show off) to others. 

During the ceremony, their conversations usually revolve around who's winning in life and who's not. And who and who is what and what in where and where. And those who or whose kids are doing well, tend to talk the loudest. 

I really hope that their conversations could be more about interests, hobbies or current affairs, but no, it's usually about self-promotion.

Once there was an auntie (I don't even know who she was or where she came from) who talked to me about her son and how capable he is, how he also studied law but instead from the UK and he is working in a top law firm in Singapore. Her son was just quietly sitting there eating the food. And just when I thought she wanted to hook him up with me since I told her I am single when she asked, she started bragging about how capable and successful his girlfriend is. WTF! -_- Okay, okay, okay. I get it, your kid is awesome and you'll have a wonderful life.

During a casual reunion with NUS friends, I brought this issue up to them. They recalled similar events when they were reluctant to accept a wedding invitation of someone they were not close to. However, they accepted the invitation and give them their blessings anyway. "意思意思就可以了." they advised.

I hate giving someone my blessings casually. It's not because I don't like them, but it's because I don't know them well enough to feel anything genuine for them. I would rather not give them any well-wishes at all, then to give them insincere ones for the sake of it. Hence, when my special day comes, I'll never invite people just to fill the seats and to brag about the number of people who attend my wedding, I will only invite those who I know will truly share my nuptial joy and give me their most heartfelt well-wishes.

To the OP of .
How did you 'semi-confess' to the girl? There could be several possibilities why it is going nowhere.
-She is too shy to show that she reciprocates your feelings although she does know that you are interested in her. 
-She semi-rejected you.
-She is blur. (Likelihood low because girls can feel it usually.)

To  What kind of "semi-confessions" did you make?Evergreen = no relationship experience. Chances are that the girl isn't sure how to interpret your advances. What seems to you as an obvious display of interest might come across as normal friendly behaviour to a girl who hasn't been in the dating game. It will take courage, but why not confess once and for all and see what happens next? 

Speaking from my own experience-when I first met my gf, she was evergreen. I tried hinting my interest but she didn't dare to think of the possibility that I liked her that way, simply because her hopes had been dashed before and she thought I was just being friendly. I had to take the initiative to text her first and eventually I was the one who asked her out first too. In the end I simply said I wanted to be her boyfriend but I was fine with waiting & getting to know each other better if she still wasn't sure. Now we're together and I'm glad I decided to be truthful.

So many opportunities pass us by cos we are afraid of taking the risk and wearing our hearts on our sleeves. Take my advice with a pinch of salt (sorry in advance if you get rejected/heartbroken ah), but sometimes being honest and sincere about our intentions can open up new beginnings. Enough with the ambiguous mind games and "push & pull".

-
 
To: 

I doubt that Internet advice could really solve your problems, but here goes.

The thing about having low self esteem is that you end up telling yourself things that may not entirely be true. It becomes a cycle in which you self-handicap because the anxiety and feelings of worthlessness that result from your low self-esteem probably worsen your performance and end up reinforcing your own low self-esteem. 

It isn't easy, but you have to break the cycle. Stop telling yourself that others have more talent than you, that others look down on you or that others hate you. Yes, there will always be people better than you and people who genuinely do dislike you. But you don't have to focus on them. If you can let go of your desire to prove yourself to others and just enjoy the activity instead of turning it into something that makes you miserable, perhaps you might find your own performance improving as a result. Live life by your own terms, not those of others.

And I find that distraction helps, though only temporarily. Find some other activity you enjoy, reading, watching films, or something that you can do without invoking those feelings. It's not a long-term solution, but at least it may give you some relief.

I think the best remedy for such personal issues is having strong support from friends and/or family who stand by you no matter what, though that's not very realistic an expectation sometimes. But how sure are you that your friends actually do hate you, or if it is your own mind telling you things again? It is true that it is not easy having to talk to someone who has emotional issues and you might feel that you're annoying others (I feel that way too). But there may still be those who're willing to listen and help.

If you really do need help and really feel that you can't get it from anyone, seek professional help. And while it is weird to talk to your family, you really should if you feel that your issues are seriously affecting you. 

I sincerely hope you'll be able to iron out your issues. Hang in there!
-

A long rant about myself...

I consider myself a rather abnormal person back in JC days. For one I was quite asexual back then (straight now though). While the rest of my guy cliques are checking girls out, I'm the only person who is rather indifferent to this. When girls attempt to want to know me through my guy cliques (i don't really follow my friends around while they are out chatting with girls from other classes), or tell my friends that i'm rather good looking or so, I brushed them off, or even be brutally honest and tell my friends that the girl is ugly in my opinion. I even once said "her face looks like a hamburger" and made sure that girl in particular could hear it. I pretended to be effeminate, pretend to worship kpop flower boys like lee joonki, pretended to be a fan of the guys in Boys over Flowers, tuned my body language and speech. All to siam romantic encounters with the female breed as I was slightly more interested with platonic friendships. I never once believed in relationships that start early as I knew that statistically they mostly do not survive through the period when the guy serves NS. The average marriage age for guys was clear as day back then in singstats. The average duration of a typical relationship back in JC? LOL. The probabilities are stacked harshly. My world view is largely shaped by cold hard numbers and known facts. (no wonder i'm a stats major)
To summarise, I'm a cynical asshole since long ago.

I read internet forums, especially topics where people seek advice, dispense advice, share their life experiences. I've noticed that,

Friendships: many people lose about all their friends rather early on. first wave of fatality comes when your friends hit working world, because work,family,significant other ranks higher than friends but eats up almost all the time one has.
The surviving friendships die off one by one when the particular friend gets married (especiallly female friendships). In fact, according to many, attending a female friend's wedding is almost similar to attending her funeral. This is all assuming that the strength of the friendship was decent in the first place! And we have in fact do have many advocates of "learn to say no" when people seek help from you. No wonder friendships don't survive long. This style of thinking in my opinion stems from the networking/gain friends for benefits way of viewing others(will talk about this later).

Relationships: talking about my observations about this and the views of many people is akin to beating a dead horse. One thing of note to me is that at working age, girls all shift their thinking towards the "how much is he earning" route. And that it is more probable to find a girl who is into "through thick and thin" in a schooling environment. It feels kind of empty that the chance of "true love" is proving to be very low at this point of my life. I sometimes wish I was at least naive early on in life.to have a.better shot at "true love".

Aforementioned things are largely my interpretations of the life experiences of others, often with the tone of resignation, sometimes heated debates. I put a lot of weight in internet contributions because people have much less reason to be EQ-oriented in their words than in real life interaction. I believe people are more candid in their opinions.

Now to uni. The bulk of my whatsapp conversations is initialised by the other party due to their need for my help (mostly studies). Depressing huh. I have people mostly from my major, some from other unis, some from other unis in other countries. I never had an issue with helping unless it takes up way too much resources. 

Until;
1. When various friends/romanical interest hint that another person/group is just using me. I have people leaking by accident to me about their opinions of people around me. I have another set of people telling me in the face who and who is just using me. I could go on and on about the many instances but the thing is, most of this leaking and telling happened when it was uncalled for and unexpected. Its a huge web of allegations. I was still a prostitute back then who availed myself to pretty much everyone. These happenings was what prompted me to analyse my past whatsapp conversations with about everyone.

2. I asked for advice on the internet about this and various beentherethroughtthats told me about the concept of "friends of convenience" in uni and that I should just focus on more worldly goals like first class, getting internship and cushy job as they are definitely real things I can take away from uni. In fact in other discussions I realised many of the first classes and dean listers make no apologies about cutting not so stellar ppl off project groups simply because they do not want to risk their CAP/GPA. 
I am utterly confused as to who is true and who is not. 

I have always believed the concept of networking to be disgusting. To the point whereby I avoid knowing new people. Because I know very well majority of the uni population is developing worldly views especially 3rd year onwards when the perceived need for internship sets in and part of it is buying the networking thing. I do not want to be remotely part of this bullcrap. I'm starting to think that perhaps I was part of others' network all along. 

And as I mentioned earlier I am a cynical realist who weights the opinions of others greatly,statistician to the core. And the funny thing is until a year plus ago, I was able to sustain my own dissonance, thinking all friends are friends and concurrently am convinced that many people are deceitful and self-serving in nature. 1+1=2 came late for me.

I was once convinced to find a job which requires less commitment on the "time" aspect because I wanted to have time for people who mattered. But the number of such people seem depressing.
I'm thinking of working my ass off for my final year, aim for a high paying job and be the workaholic I once set out not to be, get married at say age 32, to someone who is attracted to me for the financial stability I will bring, and maybe she will cheat on me behind my back because I am too busy working and maybe we can get a divorce 1 year or so into the marriage. Or we could stay married for the sake of it. Or I could stay single and thus save lots of money for a fine life of luxuries for myself since there is no child rearing costs, no wedding no HDB.

I will take my current state to be the manifestation of karma as a result of my asshole behaviour in the way I dealt with people I didnt care for in the past, my brutally honest and stubborn opinions in conversations people probably got pissed about. My 0EQ comments were bad, but I make no apologies for being honest.

This long long rant was the result of me being insomniac and long lasting effects of monday blues in an army camp. It bears my signature mode of thought and world view so any friend of mine who remotely knows my style of thoughts would know this post is penned by me. Structure is probably bad, typos and bad grammar littered everywhere because its 4am right now. Would appreciate brutally honest 0 EQ comments because i'm confused as hell. Finally, thanks for reading!

-
 
I'm straight and have been with my girlfriend since our first year in NUS. But she wasn't the first person I fell in love with. In the army, I had a good friend, K. I had just arrived to the unit as a newly minted officer. He, on the other hand, was a sergeant who arrived in a few months before. K was a good person. He was smart and helpful. He was exactly the sort of guy you can count on to do things quickly and effectively. 

Due to our jobs being similar, we teamed together and soon, found ourselves a friend in the other. Although he was to report to me, I've never really given a shit about ranks. I saw everyone I worked with as my equal. Neither I nor them were there by choice. My relationship with K was always very informal. We shared meals, played basketball in the evening and even gymmed together. We knew that we could depend on each other to get out of any shit we may have found ourselves in. 

There was one particular weekend we did duty together. This was six months after my posting in. An alarm had gone off at one of the buildings. It was a 25-minutes walk from HQ. The duty driver was no where to be seen. We had no choice but to run quickly there. After shutting down the alarm, we made our way slowly on foot back to HQ. On the walk back, we bitched about how the driver was absent from duty and how I planned to sign him extra duties for making us run. We talked about work. We teased, elbowed and pushed each other around. At one point, I found myself pushed into a drain. To me, that sort of behaviour was common, especially amongst NSFs. Ask anyone who's been through the NS and no one will raise an eyebrow if they see that kind of behaviour in camp. It was just boys being boys. I saw it as mere playfulness and nothing more than that. 

I guess the playfulness got too much that night. He pushed me against a wall... and kissed me and confessed his feelings for me. Not knowing how to react, I pushed him away and told him to fuck off. We didn't speak the rest of the night and the following week. He tried to make things right, but I kept insisting that we be professionals. I became cold to him. I got easily frustrated when people asked stupid questions. It wasn't so much the stupidity of people that bothered me; rather, it was what happened between K and I. I didn't had anyone to bitch to about work; more than that, I felt like I had lost a friend. I had no one else to blame but myself for I chose to call off the friendship. I played basketball by myself, I worked out alone, I ate alone, I swam alone.

One night, two weeks after the incident, I was at the gym doing weights. I remembered feeling so frustrated that night that I took my anger out on the weights. I didn't know why, but after, I made my way to his bunk where he slept alone and knocked on his door. When he opened it, I went in for a kiss. It took him by surprise. We had sex that night (no penetration though) and spooned till morning. That was the first time ever I had sex. Certainly, I didn't expect it to be with a guy. We got into a relationship; unfortunately, things didn't work out. He broke up with me. He knew I loved him, but he also knew that I wasn't fully in the relationship as he was. I simply couldn't see a future with him. He was right. Despite all that happened between us, I still didn't see myself as gay.  Shortly after ORD, he left for his studies in the UK and we stopped talking altogether, despite being on each other's Facebook.

While out in town with my girlfriend, I saw him. He was back in Singapore for awhile. I introduced the two of them to each other. We talked, briefly, before going separate ways. Later he texted me on Facebook to say that I look happy. I told him that I was. That she (my girlfriend) makes me happy. He was glad for me. I don't look at or feel for other guys the same way I looked and felt for K. Looking back, I did genuinely loved him. K will be the only guy I've ever had feelings for and given my heart to. But now I have this wonderful girl... and I love her. And I won't do things to hurt her. She has all of me now as I do of her. But she will never know about this.

Sorry this is so long... It's just that when I saw him again today, it made me think about the relationship I had with him. Crazy, huh?

To 

I was in your shoes once. I'm the more serious kind and she kinda just wants to have fun. I knew it right from the start; that our personalities were just... different. But I was willing to give us a try. And try we did.

About 3 months on, she must have felt it too. Started putting distance between herself and me, giving short and delayed replies etc. It wasn't until my insistence that she finally told me the reasons for her sudden change of behavior (seriously, why do girls keep quiet and then somehow magically expect guys to know what went wrong, but I digress). Anyway, long story short, I listened to the brain and initiated the break-up.

I thought I could handle it. Never was I so wrong. The heart does indeed wants what it wants. I was super miserable; I did lots of stupid things I wished I didn't; screwed up that entire semester, and the following one too.

I don't know what's the purpose of my post here; I guess I just wanted to share my story with you (and help you make an informed decision), since you seem like you are contemplating break-up. I'm a bit like you actually; if she didn't give hints that we couldn't work out then, I'd probably have held on for years (in your case, 2 years) despite knowing of our personality differences right from the start. Anyway, whichever option you choose (and there's no 'correct' or wrong one), I hope you don't regret it like I did. Good luck!

He's not the one for me; yet I decide to give him a chance.

Basically, we have very different personalities. While I'm a serious, pessimistic and future-oriented person, he's an easy going and optimistic guy. While I know what I want to do in the future, he doesn't.. And he's also a very lazy and unromantic guy.

2 years have passed and up till today, after knowing him better and all... My brain still insists on telling me that he's not the right guy, but my heart tells me otherwise. After all it has been 2 years and we have spent so much time together.

I'm not sure if breaking up is the correct option because I'm afraid I'll miss him. But I have tried my best, and him too, to accommodate one another because of our differing personality. I'm really tired of all these & I really hope to find a guy who has a similar personality as me so that everything's more relatable. Can anyone advise me what to do?

To  I'm very sorry that you went through such a traumatic experience when you were younger. I'm also sorry that you have to struggle with feelings of attraction towards both boys and girls. 

I think it's amazing that you were able to overcome the transphobic stigma attached with dating a transgender person. I'm sorry that it did not work out between the two of you though. 

On the current relationship issue that you're facing, I hope that you can talk it out with her and find closure. I know it's hard and life seems really unfair that it has dealt so much difficulties and pain to you. 

Please know that you don't have to face this alone and there are many of us out there who are here to support you. If you ever need to reach out for support regarding your relationships, be it straight or queer, do consider talking to someone from Oogachaga. They're LGBT-affirmative and I think it would help if you were able to share your feelings with someone. 

All the best and take care, friend! We may be the architect of our own destruction, but we also are the architect of our most beautiful creation so here's a response to your quote from the poem, Invictus: "I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul."

She is plagued by a whole host of problems, such as depression, suicidal tendencies, anxiety, an eating disorder and severe mood swings. We can be having a great time together, and 2 seconds later, with no warning whatsoever,  she can sink into a state of depression. This has happened more times than I can count, and many a date has been ruined as a result of this. She has been seeing a psychiatrist for the past 3 years and has been hospitalized at least 4 times for malnutrition and attempted suicide. Each time this happens, a little piece of me just dies inside. I love her greatly and desire nothing more than helping her through this rough period, but truth to be told, I am emotionally exhausted. It seems like everything I do in an attempt to get her back on track is for naught. I've been disappointed so many times, be it the ruined dates, the unfulfilled promises made on her part to change and put the pieces of her life back together, and her constant avoidance of food despite acknowledging that doing so is bad for her health. Am I a bad person for not being able to accept her and her emotional baggage unconditionally? Am I in the wrong for not being like the spouse who diligently visits his/her perpetually comatose wife/husband in the hospital everyday for years despite knowing in their heart of hearts that they will probably never wake up, and that they are holding on to nothing but a silver of hope? In marriage it is said that partners should stick with each other in sickness and in health, and while I personally feel that this applies for serious relationships as well, is there a point where enough is enough? Is there such a thing as unconditional love? Or is unconditional love really just love with hidden conditions tacked on afterall? I'm feeling really lost right now. I don't know how to cope with the situation at hand. Please help me.

What frustrates me, though, is that as soon as they needed help they would pester me for it, as though suddenly they have a lot of time to chat (about their computer problems). As soon as I helped them with the problems, the lines went dead again.

I decided we're just acquaintances now. It's not really worth my effort to connect with these people when they see you as their local utility shop. Is there any wonder why IT people tend to stick with their own?

If you've been doing this to an IT person you know, I hope you'll reflect on this.

Conversations—one after another—were so effortless and enjoyable.
Not until they were replaced by awkward silences.
What in the world happened?
Couple of times, she had asked you what went wrong.
But there was no response.
Hurt, broken, and torn; she tried to move on.
But still she struggles to figure it out; she couldn’t just give up. 
She constantly ponders: did she not try hard enough, or never will she be good enough?
Was it something she did, or something she said, that was utterly wrong?
Or was she simply a bother all along?
She’s dying to know the reason; she’s dying to know why.
Tell her everything, even if it’s a lie. 
A sentence, a word, or even just a letter; anything is fine.
At least, there’s a reply.
After all, knowing something is better than knowing nothing at all. 
She won’t have to make wild guesses about your thoughts anymore.
People may ask: why so naïve; why fall so deep?
For something so trivial like a friendship. 
She doesn’t have an answer.
She never thought you’d matter.
If you think you’re the person she’s referring to, talk to her and let her know.
Only then, can she let you go.

It may be nothing much to you but it definitely breaks my heart seeing how we’ve drifted apart.

Hi (again) , im the OP from confession 

Well, to put things in perspective. My life since 17 has been rather uneventful. I had my first girlfriend in JC1. I dated someone who was suffering from Bipolar Disorder. So an inordinate amount of my time was spent with her as she manifested various forms of behaviour. I saw her self mutilate as I tried to calm her down. That's the memories I had from my 1st relationship. Sadly, she called me the night before my JC1 promo exams asking to talk. As i was busy mugging i ignored her. She jumped at 2am the next day - 9 floors down. 9 floors of nightmares for me. I found myself subsequently missing her, and contemplated suicide. Till this day, I still miss her deeply.

Then came National Service. NS is time for you to think and actually reflect about life. Since 13, I began to feel attracted to guys ( Yes I'm a guy ). I found myself spazzing over certain kind of guys ( not going into details on my type ). I took a leap of faith and began dating a transgender first. It was a first time for me as we went out in public, people staring at her and what not. Of course, we went all the way. Had sex, got ourselves emotionally messed up and called the relationship off. Till today, I still wonder how is it possible that I can feel attracted to girls and guys at the same time. It's painful trying to convince myself that I am normal.

Lastly, the 3rd girl I dated was the one I mentioned in post  . As of now, I'm confused over my sexual orientation and simultaneously trying to fill up this emotional void within me. It has reached a point where..... i'm neck deep into flings and everything with the female gender. I go for everything ranging from people my age to mid 50s ( MILF ). Its not so much about the sex now, but the thrill now. Self mutilation does happen from time to time
Disclaimer : Of course, I ensure the other party is willing and is single/divorced.

As I progress on to 2nd year of my engineering studies, I wonder how I have lost my moral compass and entered an emotional void. My deepest fear is that one day, the Mr Hyde in me takes over and I lose myself. 

I am the architect of my own destruction

Hello friends, the NUS Evergreen Club is finally here! Check it out at https://www.facebook.com/nusevergreenclub
Now we can plan all the fun activities we want to do in school.

I am an evergreen too. I liked a guy last year, took the initiative and confessed to him but got rejected. I was very depressed at that time. I cried a lot and found it hard to do my day-to-day activities, pay attention in lectures, etc. I thought I would never be able to get over him. However, time is the greatest healer. Over the past few months, I learnt to accept reality and moved on in my life. Now I am a happy person again, just as I was before I met him. 
Most importantly, I learnt that it is perfectly fine to be single. It must surely feel great to be in a relationship, be in love with someone who loves you back and have a companion who cares about you. However, being single is not bad either. It teaches you how to love yourself before loving anyone else. Better not to rush in love. You will meet the right person one day. All in good time.
As my favourite quote says - Yesterday is history, tomorrow is a mystery, today is a gift. That's why it is called the present. So to all the singles out there - don't worry about being single or evergreen. Don't brood over your past or be anxious about the future. Enjoy your singlehood and let's have lots of fun in the NUS Evergreen Club - go picnicking, fly kites, play frisbee at Town Green!

P.S. I guess singles who are not evergreen can join too. After all, going through a break-up is as harsh as being rejected in the first and they deserve to join in the fun too. The more people, the better. They can give the evergreens some valuable advice and tips as well. ;)
However, I still prefer the name to be NUS Evergreen Club instead of NUS Singles Club or NUS Green Club (sounds more like an environmental awareness club).
