-
 
The groundbreaking news that was (not so surprisingly) relegated to page 32 of today's Straits Times World section makes me feel a nudge deep inside to share this story of mine.

I'm pretty close to my old man, kind of his favorite daughter and always accompanied him for runs and outside makan. It was no different when he was hospitalised with a minor heart attack a couple of months back. There was one afternoon I was alone with him in the room and he was going on cheerfully about the places my ah gong brought him around when he was a boy. 

After a while the conversation changed and he began to reminisce about the fond memories he had of a friend he grew up with from pri school up to uni. All sorts of stuff that ranged from getting caught by the discipline master for drawing on the school walls, accidentally breaking windows while playing soccer and running away, even going fishing in the longkangs and streams near where they lived. In secondary school and his times in NJC, they helped each other get through some tough times like when my dad's rebellious streak got him into a big falling out with grandpa and he stayed at his friend's place for an entire week. Or when they each had their own relationship issues, having each other to lean on through the break-ups. They didn't get enlisted in the same camp for national service but they were pretty much go-to company on most bookouts. Sticking together, they even enrolled for uni in the same dept of business admin course (now the nus biz school). Throughout all this, my dad had this wistful look in his eyes and seemed to be looking at a point infinitely far away.

Out of the blue, I casually mentioned "if you guys are still best pals, how come I've never seen Uncle WK before?" Suddenly he paused and became silent for a while. Then in a hushed tone he told me: "J, I'll tell you something that I've never told anyone before not even your mum". 

He started to recall in vivid detail what happened a couple of months after ord-ing, when they went on a trip to phuket with their mutual bunch of JC friends. One of the nights they were out, all of them ended up in a disco (that's what clubs were called back then). The night ended abruptly when a Caucasian guy repeatedly harassed one of their friends. In her defense, WK got into a major scuffle with the guy, ending up getting cuts on his shoulder, a broken nose and bruises near his eye. It only didn't get any worse because my dad managed to pull the guy off before the management came over. The night ended abruptly and they were bounced out. Back in the hotel room, my dad spent a good while fixing WK up with some first-aid. 

As he was applying the bandages, he said "You know, thanks for taking care of me, all these years I don't know what I'd have done without you around".

To this my dad casually replied "Nah it's nothing, I know you'd have done the same for me likewise without even asking". Being slightly drunk too, he was unaware when WK placed a hand on his thigh until he suddenly leaned in to kiss him. 

My dad was stunned and immediately pulled back. Unable to process what just happened, my dad violently shoved him away before storming out of the room. 

WK trailed him to the beach where my dad was sitting by the water. There was a long moment of silence before my dad demanded to explain what had just happened. 

In a stutter, WK said "I don't know. I guess I've felt something for you all this while and I'm sorry it came out that way. I was just so drunk there I must have lost control and I didn't mean to force that on you"

"So are you telling me you're gay?!"

"No, I mean I don't know. I don't know how to explain this. You're the only guy I've ever felt like this for. And I did really fall in love with Jane and Mei Yuan back then"

"Don't give me this bullshit. I can't believe that you've been pretending to be someone else all this while."

"That's not true! Everything we've gone through is real!"

"Real? Now I don't even know who you are anymore"

"Can we just pretend this didn't happen?"

"Yeah whatever it is, I don't want to talk to you again"

With that my dad headed back to the room and it was pretty much silence between them for the rest of the trip.

For a while my dad avoided him and when it came to uni, things improved but they only met together with mutual friends and it was just never the same between them. They did attend each other's weddings though but it was never more than casual acquaintance. In his own words, my dad said he decided to put up a wall between them. 

"So have you still been keeping in touch with Uncle WK?" I broke the silence that followed.

That's when I realised my dad's eyes were slightly wet.

"No and I wish I had. 2 years ago, one of our friends informed me that he had passed away from heart failure." He paused. "I should have been there."
 
"Hmm yeah well but there was no way you'd have known he was ill." 

"No that's not what I meant, I should have been there for him all these years. Whether or not he was really gay or it was just a spur of the moment.. I never should have abandoned him.. he was the one friend I confided everything in. The one friend who never judged me for whatever I did or how I felt. The one friend who believed in me and all the really stupid dreams I had."
 
And then as the tears flowed, "No one has ever understood me like he did. It's like we instantly clicked all the time."

"Not even mum?"

"No, not even mum."

It was pretty much silence for the rest of my visit.

My dad passed on 3 weeks ago and his story constantly bugs me. I came from a pretty liberal all-girls school here before NUS but it just struck me how in our 'first-world' country and several others in the world, we are still pretty unaccepting of people who don't stick closely to the stereotypes set out by society when it comes to love and relationships. Sure, things might be slowly getting better here but it's still very much a two dimensional affair when we talk or joke casually about relationships and sexuality.. the real stuff's all hush-hush behind doors. 

The thing is no two people are the same and that's what should be beautiful about life. This isn't even about the whole brouhaha over LGBT rights or religion. It's about how we can't and shouldn't box the way we form connections with every one of our fellow human beings out there in the world. I'm lucky to have a life partner for about 3 years and yes he's also my boy who I hope to walk down the aisle with (we're both graduating (; ). But I wouldn't have a moment's hesitation sharing my life with another girl if I really found her to be my soulmate (and yes, it's really amazing how he understands that too)

I hope that when we've reached our parents age having growing kids of our own studying and working, that they won't be judged for who they choose or choose not to fall in love or even lust over. That Singapore would truly be a place they can call Home.
-
 
 There can be many reasons why that happened, but I think the most likely reason is because she does not like you in a romantic way. They assumed the friendship was purely platonic, so when they noticed signs that you are falling from them, they pull back. It is also possible that they didn't feel as close to you as you were to them, so you might have subconsciously try to progress the friendship beyond their comfort zone.
Whatever the reason, move on and focus on the people who are and who will be in your life.

Thus, I am reconsidering my decision to initiate conversations in the case that he may just see me as a colleague and nothing more. He isn't from NUS by the way (even harder to catch up with one another after school starts) that's why i decided to take a step back and see how things goes. The first time we sat together at U Town green sharing a Starbucks frap. I remember that day very well. It was something that I didn't expect to happen. Subsequently, I found myself spending more time with you at U Town.There were days where work was crazy, and you would make time to meet me around CLB. We talked it out, cried together. Late night phone calls, crashing each others lecture and surprise Starbucks deliveries.
Then came the day where we were walking to KR Station. You asked if we could take this friendship further. Elation ? Sheer Rapture ? I cannot describe this feeling. It seemed like things were falling in place. As the semester progressed, things took a turn. You introduced me to an exchange student you met at U Town pool. I was jealous, and overly protective. But I left it as it is, after all, everyone needs their personal space. As weeks passed, I had friends telling me that he was spending his nights over at your room. I was crushed.
I was pissed, super pissed and sad. But I decided that I could talk things out, and try to forgive you in whatever little ways I could. But you just blocked me out of my life. Then came semester 2, we met again. I didn't expect you to run towards and hug me in the middle of U town, crying. You introduced me to your boyfriend. I was confused honestly. I asked [why] you cheated, and you began growing defensive. Saying I didn't make enough time for you, and that he understood you more than I did. For all that it's worth, I don't understand why.
It's been 2 semesters now. And i'm still wondering why. I've experienced physical pain, but I must admit that this emotional pain is something that I cannot come to terms with yet.
Was it worth it ?

Like you, I used to be scared what would happen if I were sharing a bed or a room, but that's has never happened. It happens only when I'm sleeping alone or with my partner, so I guess subconsciously I need to know I'm in a safe environment. My pillow doesn't mind it and none of my partners have complained so far. I met this guy online. 

We were both in U.S. at that time, but stayed in different states. We texted each other for a few weeks. Then the day came when I had to return to Singapore. 

A few months later, he made a week long trip to Singapore (for family reasons) and we decided to meet up with each other for the first time for dinner. That's it.

I thought we would break communication after that and forget about each other's existence, but no - to my surprise, he texted me a couple of weeks later. 

Our texting continued - though replies were infrequent, our conversation never really 'ended.' 

I went for a little holiday to the U.S. a few weeks later to visit my cousins over there, and decided to meet up with him for the second time for a quick meal, since my cousins happened to stay in the same state as he did.

I decided to text him a few days after we met again because he didn't, and I didn't want him to have to initiate the conversation again just because he's a guy, even though I was really scared to (but I was even more scared of the fact that we might really cut off communication once and for all).

I won't deny that I like him. In fact, I'd say a bit too much. And I know I'm silly for feeling that way. 

Fast forward a few weeks later, we're still texting each other. Though I have to say, our conversations are pretty shallow and slow. But it doesn't matter.

Sometimes I can't help but wonder why we're even talking to each other - really, why? Even with the 14,000 km distance between us, with uncertainty of ever meeting again in the future. It's been more than half a year from the first time we texted.

I do it because I really like and admire him. I thoroughly enjoy his presence, be it online or offline. 

But why does he bother keeping in touch with me? He may feel the same way, but I honestly feel that it's highly unlikely; I just can't imagine it, and his replies aren't exactly super enthusiastic. And that's why this question keeps floating in my mind. WHY? Why else? Maybe he'd just like to keep a friend like me?

I know it's hard to say with such vague details, but if you were in his situation, why would you keep the text conversation going with a girl? Especially one who you first met online? One whom you'd potentially never be able to meet again in real life, in the near future?

P.S. This situation is rated PG.

I've commented publicly on quite a few confessions before, particularly those relating to love and life (gotten quite a lot of likes which makes me happy because I believe it shows my comments are well received and advice dispensed is sound), but I guess this is my turn to seek advice anonymously.

To many people, I lead an extremely good life. I graduated with a first class honours from a faculty people regard as one of the top two in NUS (although I tend to disparage such opinions - I think every degree is valuable and every calling is meaningful in its own way), finishing 2nd in my cohort. I've published in journals and won accolades, scholarships and prizes. I'm well known in my faculty and it appears like I've no lack of friends or social life. My facebook page displays positive statuses, posts from friends sharing things with me or various tags. People regard me as a kind and happy person, for various reasons e.g. I openly share my notes with juniors and people tend to turn to me for advice, whether on academics, love or personal issues. 

And yet, I'm deeply miserable and depressed quite a lot of the time, something which has been exacerbated by the holidays. I've not shared this with many people but I come from a broken home, with an abusive father and long suffering mother. It hasn't helped that my father is currently being charged with two criminal offences and that I have had to bear the burden of advising him how to escape liability, liaising with the police and having had to generally be the pillar of support for everyone else in the family. Some of my family members, including myself, may further be charged with being complicit in these criminal activities (abetment) - something I worry day and night about. I'm not rich, and am actually in debt due to course fees and paying for my mother's medical expenses. I feel even more miserable looking at all my friends travelling the world on their graduation trips, with nary a care in the world, while I am stuck here having to deal with all this s__t. Even now, I can't rest, having to 'study' various sections of the Penal Code in an attempt to help my family.  I wish I could be like any normal student from my faculty and resent the fact that I had to finance myself throughout university, working and studying. I don't look forward to the future at all and hate myself for accepting a job which will bring great financial remuneration at the expense of my values and beliefs. Deep down, I want to accept a lower paying job where I can impact society and help people with what I do. I also look back on my university days and see nothing but pain and sorrow, as I worked myself to the point of insanity and misery to achieve all I have now. I'll admit now I should feel grateful for all I have, but pardon me for feeling a little like I haven't found what I really want - peace and happiness. It has been strife, pushing myself and fighting to survive all the way. At this point, I sometimes feel like killing myself - that is how much I want all of this to end.

To compound matters, I feel desperately lonely. Yes, I have my friends. But quite a lot of them feel like sycophantic suck ups or people who want something or other from me at times. I'm thankful for those genuine ones but even with them, I feel a huge void left in my heart. I want a girlfriend but it just hasn't worked out. I don't think girls like a guy who is obese, who has issues, generally doesn't dress himself well except on occasion (simply because I don't have time to, I can't afford to and honestly, I really don't care) and who isn't rich. I've tried tinder and okcupid but generally, responses have not been favourable when they know that for now, I am unable to provide financially for them and beyond that, I'm not good looking (I've done the whole improve my health thing, lost a lot of weight a few years ago though I regained some of it, so I hope no one lectures me on losing weight. I can do it, want to do it, but not at this moment where so much is going on). I even was explicitly told by one that since I'm not a ______ yet, I can't provide for her and even though I'm a nice guy, she doesn't want to date me, especially since I'm not handsome. Sad to say, I'm becomingly increasingly jaded with the superficial society we live. Of course, I'm sure I could play up my successes but what would the point of that be? Being with someone who doesn't love you for you but the paper and titles you hold? And I'm not looking for friends with benefits either. Several girls have approached me with regard to this, but as tempting as such a convenience sounds, sex does not equate real love. And I worry that as I enter the working world, the chance of finding someone who loves me for me will slowly evaporate. I'm wondering whether something is wrong with me - I'm a great conversationalist, I don't lack confidence and I'd like to think I know how to flirt. Are weight, money and status such important factors? Please tell me because I'd like to know. Maybe I'll revise my views on the issue someday because I understand girls need someone who can 'take care of them.' But surely, someone's ability to take care of another extends beyond just finances? Aren't things like loyalty, fidelity and stability important too? Personally, I'd really like someone to give me a chance so that I could show them the real me, even though I must admit I'm not very stable :P

I broke up with my ex-girlfriend a few years ago. She is the only person I know who has loved me for who I am and nothing else. She saw me through my dark days, she was there when I had nothing and was a 'failure' (for various reasons). She was my everything as well. However, something terrible happened and we broke up. We tried to make things work after the terrible event but it was just never the same. I miss her because she was my best friend as well (longer than girlfriend). I miss her everyday. I just want that friend, that companionship and most importantly, that someone who never judged me for anything beyond my character. I miss that someone who would laugh at my achievements and pseudo mock me for my successes. To this day, I question whether giving her up, even despite the fact we could never work out, was the right choice. She's getting married this year. To her, if you see this, will you at least be friends with me? -.- 

Thanks for reading this if you've read this far. I love this platform because it allows us to put down our masks and show the world who we truly are. Thank you admins for the hard work you put into this and everyone who supports this page and keeps it going (including serial commentators and just anyone who 'likes' anything :P).

I'll end by saying that it really is true when people say never judge a book by its cover. And that love is the most important thing so cherish it. I don't know where I'm going to go from here but I hope that I find meaning in life. Currently, I'm playing with the idea of applying for a job where I can help people in trouble (this is really vague because I want to remain anonymous) although people will call me crazy for passing up 'greatness.' But maybe, just maybe, it is time I did something for myself and followed my heart.

It's quite common to hear of guys who have ambiguous relationships with different girls at the same time. Not saying it's always intentional, but they often end up giving false hope while "trying to get to know each other better". Sometimes there's already a girlfriend in the picture, or someone he is "amber" with, just that the poor girl doesn't know or fully understand. I think there's even a term called "fishing" and hoping to hook as many "fishes" as possible?! Do  reflect on your own behaviour and if you realise that you're guilty of doing this (maybe not consciously), do remember that these are actual humans you are toying with and they have emotions too. Some may be trying their best to look for the right partner to spend their life with, not just for a casual fling or the excitement of a chase.

Whenever I tried to confide in someone, phrases like ‘you can get sad one mehh?’ comes out of them. This compounded matters and I start to learn how to live in a façade, hiding my innermost fears and feelings away from everyone. The only person who knew me and saw me through my dark days when everything spiraled out of control was my ex-girlfriend, whom for various reasons (the breaking point was LDR where she went to London to pursue her undergraduate law degree) broke up with me 5 years ago. She was my best friend, my confidant, the only person who understood me and knows when I’m feeling down even though I have a smile on my face. I miss her (even if not in a relationship way but at least as a platonic soulmate), her companionship and her ability to understand me more than any others (am I dumb to do so?). I tried dating after we broke up but I just cant find back the same connection. Recently, I just got wind that she’s engaged. If you’re reading this, I know there is a reason for you keeping your distance, but could we be friends again?

-
 
To OP  

Firstly, the cliche advice of 'Be yourself' is very often misunderstood. It doesn't mean you don't change for the better. It means to change within your comfort level. It's a little oxymoronic but I will explain more later. I will try and answer your problems.

1. 'But the conversations with them would seem so awkward'
Make her laugh. It's one thing to get her to talk comfortably with you. It's another thing for her to enjoy talking to you. Making her laugh will make her remember how much she enjoys talking to you. Don't be shy to say, 'Hey, wanna hear a joke?' Even if she doesn't laugh, she knows you're deliberately trying to make her happy. 

2. 'But I would often fade away in conversations' 
If you met a new girl and you are in a social setting, pick-up lines can be helpful! If it's someone you know like a classmate or colleague, remembering the things she says helps. If she mentioned a TV show she's watching, ask her when the show airs then ask her how was last night's episode the next day. Better yet, watch the show. You can talk about the show and even tell her why you didn't like the show. The fact that you watched it just because of her is flattering enough.

3. 'Yes, I am indeed despo' 
Any good advice involves some effort by you. Girls like confident guys and confidence is not about portraying a facade. It's about the willingness to put aside your fear. Be it changing for the better or showing the real you. 

Some other tips that might help you!

4. Okay, so you strike up a conversation and have her number. You can tell if she likes you by eye contact. You know how people tend not to look at each other in the eye for too long? Well, look at her a little longer than a random glance then give her a little smile before looking away. Don't stare! Just don't be afraid to show that you like looking at her.

5. If you are getting the signals from her, ask her out. Just the two of you. Yes, it's a date. It could be a movie, drink... Don't treat it as if it's a big deal, as if by saying yes she'll be making a big commitment to you. If she declines, say, 'Hey, it's just a movie/cafe/dinner, I'm not asking you to marry me laa.'

6. What's next? You just let it happen naturally. If you've gotten this far and the girl has been showing the right signs, it will happen naturally. No need for confessions. You may be surprised at how easy it was. Which it should be if the guy and girl like each other. This is how mature adults do it. 

All the best! I'm not active here but if you find this helpful and found a relationship, do help other dudes! 
-
 
It's been almost a year since I met my girlfriend, and it's been like four months since we've been together, yet I still find it really hard to believe we're together. I'm not here to be a douchebag to show anything off to anyone, I just wanted to express how grateful I am to have her in my life.

We met one another during orientation camp (See, this is why it can't hurt to participate in more activities and meet more people. You don't have to be loaded with motives, just go with an open mind.), and luckily for me, she was a freshie in my OG. I had a really good time with my OG, and I had an equally awesome time with her as well. She's a beautiful girl with a beautiful heart, caring, really understanding and child-like at times (Which makes her really fun to annoy).

Fast forward eight months, we've found each other in one another's arms, and it's a really blissful feeling. I'll admit it's not easy trying to balance work and each other, but we eventually found a way to keep things working. I  hope that things will continue to work out for us both, especially now that I don't stay on campus with her anymore.

Cheers to all those who are in love, and for those who aren't yet, don't despair. Just find 10 seconds of courage and little windows of opportunity to make a move. And hey, if things don't work out, your life will still go on and you'll find someone else. The world's a harsh enough place, so hey, chin up and smile! You never know who's looking (:

P.S. Tembusu College is a wonderful, magical place. It's really a Home of Possibilities (;

Single for 24 years here. After much trial and error, I can only conclude that girls don't like shy, awkward introverted guys, and I was only living a delusion in which girls would reach out to me instead of the other way round.

People say, just talk to more girls, eventually you will find the one. Which was what I did. But the conversations with them would seem so awkward because I am shy and I don't know what to talk about. Sometimes girls would even shun me for making them feel awkward with the silence and weird conversation topics.

People say, just be more outgoing, join more activities to meet people, and eventually girls. Which was what I did. But I would often fade away in conversations because I am shy, and I will often observe that girls only pay attention to guys who talk the most, and would find them funny. When I talk to the girls? Well, not so funny. 

People say, just don't be so despo, girls can sense it. Which was what I did, or at least I thought I did. After all, if I really wasn't despo, I wouldn't be seeking help and relationship advice from people, right? Also the very fact that I haven't gotten a girlfriend after two and a half decades on earth signals an alarming 'Yes, I am indeed despo'.

People who are less good looking could go for plastic surgery in a bid to become more attractive.

I guess the day I get a girlfriend would only come when they offer plastic surgery with personality alteration as a package.

Isn't that a more rational conjecture compared to jumping to conclusions that 'her heart isn't good'? 
I feel like when you tend to be not too good at work, the people at my workplace tend to be less inclined to treat you well and also there's this unspoken rule that it's okay to gossip and be snappy at people who are not efficient at work. Good work performance means you'll get better treatment at the workplace.  
And then I notice office people like to get so caught up in stupid things like giving food/presents to the entire dept if they are back from an overseas trip. Now time for me to put in my two cents' worth of advice after reading a lot of the posts recently on being evergreen & wanting to be in a relationship:

TL;DR: Try to look at & evaluate people for who they are, not for the (sole) purpose of romancing them.

I am an evergreen girl myself, 22 years old this year; and if I were to be honest to myself, I would admit that I have always wanted to be in a relationship & have a boyfriend to see what the whole fuss of being in love was about.

But one thing a friend said has stuck with me ever since: "If you're only going to look at guys as meat to snap up, you're never going to treasure them for who they are, or even see them as the people they are." 

I would like to advise the same to guys who are afraid of being awkward when talking to girls (aim being to get close to girls just to see if they are girlfriend material) or girls who are just waiting for Mr. Right (snap out of the cliché too plz) to come along & chat you up. PLEASE STOP. People exist not so that you can just go through all of them to see who's meant for you. You can make all of them meant for you by cherishing their humanity,  friendship & companionship. 

I qualify this by stating that I don't mean that you have to be friends with every single person; I don't mean that everyone will have an equal standing in relationship with you - what I mean is just that please evaluate everyone based on who they are, not who you want to get together with. Don't get close to/start talking to someone just because s/he just seems like someone you could potentially love. It makes your life a lot less shallow than merely making acquaintances as a bridge to love & takes a lot of pressure off yourself. What will happen will happen. Cherish the moment.

To the OP of 

Please treasure him. I was in the very same situation as you. He wanted to continue pursuing his studies till 30, while I was already in the workforce. This would mean that I would probably not have kids. At the same time, I would also have to convert due to the nature of his religion. I thought it was the best way I could move forward. My family would also be happier if I were to end things with him. This was in spite of the fact that he stuck through all the difficult times with  me and loved me with all he had.

To be honest, I truly regretted breaking up with him. If I could turn time back, I would put aside all the practicality issue and stay by his side. This is what true love is supposed to be - "us against the world". Now I am still friends with him but I'm trying to win him back. Everyday, I'm praying and hoping that he would change his mind. 

So OP, don't be like me. The future can be built together. At the same time, you might want to consider motivating  him. Yes, our parents' opinions are important but also remember that we are adults now. How we want to live our lives, is entirely  up to us. When in doubt, always choose love. I hope you would take my advice into consideration. Wish you all the best ahead :)

There's this particular dude (current NUS student as well) whom I got acquainted with during NS. For a period of time shortly after ORD-ing, he was continually bugging me through Facebook/phone messages, asking how I was doing and pestering me to meet up with him for a meal. Initially thinking (naively) that he truly just wanted a simple catch-up, I agreed to the meet-up, which turned out to be nothing more than a pitch for an obscure "business" (in his words) he was involved in, merry-go-round fashion of course.

I did truly consider it (i.e. I did not simply shut myself out from what he was trying to convince me on) but eventually told him I wasn't interested. However, his messages to me continued; he would regularly ask me things like "How's your day?", "What have you been doing?", etc., and I would reply sincerely and sometimes try to carry on the conversations. Yet, the irritating part of this was that the messages would often stop at those few introductory lines/questions, never ever developing into any sort of meaningful conversation. He would initiate, and then I would try to continue, and then he'll be the one to effectively end the conversation by not following up with any substantial reply beyond superficial words. Imagine this cycle repeating itself at least once every few days or so! Eventually after quite a long while of this nonsense I got fed-up so I blocked him on Whatsapp and ignored his FB messages (did not block him on FB, though).

Nowadays, probably as a result of the teachings of the faculty he's enrolled in, on FB he is CONSTANTLY preaching about his "positive" outlooks on life, the importance of making money, his misplaced sense of "generosity" (seriously, anybody would be able to infer how pretentious his posts of this nature are upon reading them), etc., etc., etc. Every other day he posts something like this. Not to mention, his posts are often poorly-constructed, with "u"s replacing "you"s, first letters of each sentence not capitalized, and bad wording. Of course, nobody is perfect when it comes to this, but if one is constantly "encouraging" others on important matters such as life and finances on a social media platform, you would think he should at least take some care in ensuring that his posts aren't downright eyesores to those reading them, no?

The things he posts can get rather obnoxious. E.g. "If I am the boss, you should be asking what YOU can offer ME instead of the other way round", "Anybody wants to work for me?", etc. All this coming from him. And he's being completely serious. And, he's not even anywhere near graduation as of now. Granted, some successful people start being successful from a young age, but until this dude makes it in life, I won't count on him being the general public's to-go guru for insightful advice on life/money/success.

I keep him around on FB solely for his entertainment value. It sure is hard for someone as pretentious, obnoxious, and deluded as himself to NOT be entertaining.   ;)

Sometimes I'd be 5 minutes away from the meeting point and she calls to tell me that she can't make it because she had a sudden bout of depression, and she's just lying in bed crying and thinking about committing suicide. She isn't the type that lies, just to be clear. I don't understand depression very well, but I'm always patient with her, and I comfort as well as counsel her when the need arises. She is also profuse with words of gratitude and apologies once the episode has subsided. However, with the unusually high frequency of episodes of late, I admit that it has become very tiring and frustrating to have to be her psychologist/counsellor/lover/friend because doing so drains me physically and emotionally. We both know the toll her depression takes on the both of us because we've discussed it at length. Plus it's not like she's in control of the mood swings that occur when depression strikes, so I can't really hold her accountable for the consequences that ensue. Am I a bad guy for occasionally feeling that she can and should be better at handling her depression after having had it for so long? How can I cope with this unshakable feeling that no matter what I do she's never going to improve and I will be stuck with being her crutch and support for the rest of her/my life? Is there any way I can help her and yet remain emotionally unaffected? I like her very much and foresee going the distance with her (and she feels the same way), but this tiny little snag has been impeding the development of our relationship. Any advice will be highly appreciated.

To the guy who shared about his girlfriend having depression. I may not know you personally. But it very nice and motivating for you to love your girlfriend for who she is despite her bouts of depressive episode.  Whenever you doubt your capability ask yourself what makes you love her in the first place and let that be a motivation for you to continue pursuring and loving her. Personally I'm struggling with Anxiety and I understand how she feels. There are times when I  just dun feel like doing stuff and spent my whole day wallowing in pain and misery. I cut myself out from activities, I skip school and do all kinds of stupid stuff. Last minute cancelation of dates. But having and anxiety disorder or rather in your gf case depression is no excuse to cut yourself out from the love of your friends / love ones.  All the more you have to try coming out from your barrow bit by bit. It takes time and it is a long process but with love and moral support depression can be treated. Continue to be with her through her ups and downs and reassure her that you love her no matter what. Listen to her faustrations and advice gently if possible and whenever needed. It is nice that you guys talk about your problems and worries. Do simple and romatic stuff for her like cooking her a meal or making random stuff for her like composing a song. Try doing an activity that both of you like to encourage her to go out. Exercising helps too since it releases feel good hormones.  Encourage her to talks about her feelings and to seek for help.  There are a couple of service out there to help people with mental illness. Something I have learnt Psychotherapy and medication goes hand in hand in the path of recovery. One thing that means a lot to me and I guess to everyone suffering from any forms of mental illness. It is to reduce the social stigma that comes along with mental illness. My illness does not define me. It is just a mask that covers and hinder my true abilities and personality. Do look after yourself too so that you can continue looking out and loving her.   No matter what, I wish the both of you all the best.

-
 
 When you mentioned nice guy, it would really help if you could actually describe the type of nice guy you see.

1) The "nice guy" who wears a mask who is has a motive for being nice.
2) People who are generally nice by nature, no problem, they're just like that, cannot change them. The "Gentle Giant" type.
3) Those who have gone through things that made them "nice guys" in the first place.
4) The type who simply keeps quiet.
5) The type who is full of himself.

You have a very reasonable taste, and it makes a lot of sense. However (why of course, there is a however), it does take a rather... patient eye to actually appreciate what can a nice guy be, and what he can do. Something like a "beauty is in the eyes of the beholder", and "you need to unlock this character" thing. I think you have heard this argument a lot of times, no? 

It's something which many of them hope for, but rarely get.

And by the time a "nice guy" actually becomes truly better (hey, no offense, but if I have to become better simply for the sake of getting a girlfriend, I'll pass, it's a bit pathetic an excuse), you might find that we would grow up to find ourselves silly for chasing after ladies like that, and won't really... Let's just say it's a lot of changes, yeah? For better, or for worse.

Just wanted to get this rant out because none of my friends understand. I am an overweight girl for as long as I can remember. I never thought of losing weight until last year, when the motivation just came. Pretty clothes did not come in my size, and I wanted to look and feel better for myself. I lost 10kg within the first 6 months.

But after that, my weight has been fluctuating around the same range (for almost a year now). I would lose some, and then gain it back again despite exercising every day. I admit that I have not been eating extremely clean, but the amount I eat is half of what I used to. Because of this, I can't help but feel disheartened and I am losing motivation. Also, all my friends are slim and none of them understands me when I count calories or share stories about my journey. When they complain about the "rolls of fats" and "hideous cellulite" they have, I feel really bad about myself. Some friends have told me to hit the gym, but I don't dare to. The gym feels like an intimidating place where muscular guys and toned girls hang out, and I don't want them to judge me.

I understand that weight loss is more or less a personal journey, but I feel so lonely in this. Some days I feel like I could live with this body forever, but I really don't want to give up this journey and let myself down.

I find my female friends in a relationship sweet but it isn't as if their existence makes mine any less worthy just because I have never been in love. That they seem so happy regardless of their relationship status (and I see a lot of single female doctors around) because they are doing something they love. 

So go out and find something else to love instead of waiting around for someone to love you. And come on lah at 20 plus you have so many more years to get attached. Sincerely, just another 21 year old girl.

-
 
Listen, this is for all the poor sap dudes(or girls it applies to both although guys more so) out there who are virgins, can't talk to girls and are wondering why you've never been in a relationship, no girl has ever been attracted to you despite being a nice guy but a bit shy while they always seem to go out with the bad boys: 

The truth is this: You've been probably brought up to think that just working hard and being nice to girls will be sufficient in eventually meeting a nice one and settling down. No. This just equals boring. You got to bring something more to the table. You have to be intensely passionate about life, be it through a hobby or a skill or a dream etc.  Being a stable nice guy is a necessary but insufficient condition in an ideal partner, and this is the kicker - being a stable nice guy is easy, having that innate joy, passion and excitement of life is what most guys in this world don't possess. And that my friends, is what is extremely attractive across the board.  And no, playing video games or being insanely caught up in fandom doesn't count (unless you find a girl who is equally into that but even then I have seen most nerd/gamer chicks still end up with guys who does all the nerd stuff BUT on top of that have a more 'grounded' physical passion). Everyone wants a partner they can go on the adventure of life with and purely stable nice guys don't provide that at all. 

Anyways, this is the main reason why girls are drawn to the so-called 'bad boys'. These guys are exciting - sometimes for all the wrong reasons, such as playing games and having drama - but they can initially attract girls because their lives seem adventurous and everyone (both guys and girls) wants some sort of visceral stimulation and excitment in a relationship. Most times girls might realise the current guy she's with is a dickhead and leave him but she still keeps dating around the same kind of guys until she finally snags one who at this age shows the potential of being an ideal partner - he is exciting with a lot of things going for him but he's a bit aloof and unstable and doesn't treat her the best - she will stick with him in the hopes that he will mature with age and through the course of the relationship to eventually gain the 'stable nice guy' quality in addition to his exciting life. Some of these guys once they get married however end up trading their exciting qualities to become a purely nice, stable family guy and thats when his wife will realise this is not the guy I fell in love with and divorce him - but that's a story for another time. 

So yea, the first step is to craft an exciting life for yourself first, this was going around a few years back and its a good read: http://www.cracked.com/blog/6-harsh-truths-that-will-make-you-better-person/
-
 
To all the worried evergreen people, a real relationship will happen for you only when you realize you are adequate. 
Confidence attracts people. 
Self-sufficiency attracts people. 
No one wants someone they need to help, people want someone they want to love and know how to love themselves. 
So get on out there and do other stuff, a hobby, a passion, an interest, anything. 
When you stop questioning yourself why things aren't going right for you? That's the time you are ready for a relationship and someone right will be there for you.

Honestly, I was an evergreen girl till I was 23. I had some admirers but they weren't anyone I liked and plus, they never took that last step to ask anyway. I'm not the skinniest girl, prettiest, smartest etc but I had some good points so I always wondered why I was alone. Apparently make up and contacts made me look different and there were guys who had interest after seeing my new look. But the one guy I liked for a year didn't seem to care at all, so it was a bummer. 

After some interesting mishaps that the guy and I went through (we were sort of friends), we ended up together lol. Seeing all the evergreen posts have kinda prompted me to jump on too and maybe give some form of perspective.

As a former evergreen girl (and my bf was also evergreen lol- we're getting married ^^), after talking with my bf, I realised some guys/girls are just rly diff so don't despair if you don't find someone yet! Here are some advice that might help in the wait!

1) Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
I honestly think I'm chunky compared to the typical chio blogshop Singaporean girl beauty, but he likes curvier girls. And though I look more "chio" with makeup and lenses, he prefers my spectacles and no makeup face. So every person has their own type, don't feel bad!  

2) Better yourself and help others! 
When I was crushing for a year, I made it a point not to dwell on the crush, but to focus on helping people and building relationships around me. Although I tried to grab his attention by dressing up, in fact, it was that one time thing where I helped a mutual friend of ours that attracted him (he didn't like my dressed up look) and I didn't noticed at all!  Plus, by bettering yourself, you become more attractive and you gain more than just looking back and realising that my one year was a pathetic forever alone phase. 

You're not too old to be evergreen. And if you really are concerned, you could try dating through tinder and okcupid. I know a few couples who got together and are sticking strong.

But they do not know I secretly have commitment issues and would probably screw up any form of female relationship beyond the friendzone level and that is why I chose not to get in one and even stay clear most of the time. 

I enjoy some female companionship but at this point in time I'm mentally ill prepared to get into one. The reason why I'm posting this, I've been getting weird stares and recently some guys even try to hit on me. What should I do. If you think this is funny it's not, I shit bricks everytime this happens. 

I get questioned am I homo or into guys whenever I mention I'm not really into girls at the moment. I wouldn't consider myself homophobic but it bothers me from time to time . 
And I'm pretty sure I am a perfectly straight male and how do I shrug of these complimentary "gestures". 

And how do I talk to ladies without giving unintended false signals. Purely friendship purposes. 

Why am I writing this?
1. Does my mental thoughts sound normal? 
2. My commitment issues with ladies, how can I overcome this. 

Thank you guys.

But I was pretty excited when she decided to go out with me, just the both of us, for the third time. This is a good sign right? Being the socially awkward person I am (both of us are), this was a big thing for me and I really really liked her a lot. 

I was running out of words, and our time together was filled with so much awkward silences. I attempt to bring out a topic which I thought all girls are able to relate to, make-up/cosmetics. She didn't had any on (I shouldn't mention that to her), not that she needs any, she is beautiful just the way she is (she really is). Little did I know, this topic affected her a lot. She is very... self-conscious on her appearance and really beat herself for it, even till now. Patriarchal power, societal view on beauty, forced image of femininity, "my body was never mine" etc. 

Yes, she caught my eyes in the first place because she is pretty. But it was through the messages we had that I found out that she is such an awesome person. She likes gore and dark stuffs but that didn't really bothers me. She kept 2 tumblr, thinking nobody will ever discover the other one. One filled with fashion/quotes/hipsterism and another filled with anime gifs she made; I have been reading both everyday (she doesn't know that I know).

It has been more than 6 months since we last met. Maybe you got tired of me, I know I am not an interesting person. If that topic upsets you so much, I am sorry. It was supposed to be an innocent conversation starter and not supposed to imply anything.

To her and every girl reading this, you are beautiful just the way you are. If you don't like it, you don't have to subscribe to the conventional view of beauty. You are free to be anything you want. There is no need to chase after something you don't like. The moment you let others' reactions to dictate your choices, you give away the decision-making power to your own happiness. (same goes for guys) Of course this discussion on defending against conventional perception of beauty/femininity/masculinity can go deeper but it is not the point of this post.

There will be someone out there waiting for you, appreciating everything about you. When I said I want to know you better, I am not merely paying lips-service. After everything, I still like you, even more so after knowing you better, even with all the self-loathing part but you should quit that since it is emotionally unhealthy.
I hope this is not the end between us.

There was this girl I liked. She is a friend of my friends and sometimes she joins the group for lunch. She is very pretty and looks like a Hong-Kong actress and dresses fashionably. As I am a rather good looking guy who comes from a well off family, I've got the confidence to get her number. So only chatted via WhatsApp for a few weeks, then I actually asked her out for dinner. She agreed. Yippee! I plan to start off as friends first before going steady.

Okay. So I drove to her place and picked her up and she's darn gorgeous I tell you. She's in a dress, and I'm in polo shirt and jeans. In the car, I suggested to her to go Swensen's for dinner. It seems quite reasonable for a first date and I told her that I'll treat her to dinner. However, she politely started suggesting to go a Western restaurant at Chjimes as she said she had not tried it and her friend recommended it. Although I'm aware it's gonna be quite expensive, okay sure. No prob! I'll love to try something new too.

So when we ordered our food, she ordered the really expensive stuff such as prime steak and the deserts. And she kept asking "Can I have this?" and "Can I try that?" It's really difficult for me to say no, right? I said okay. I am not being a miser here as I can easily afford it because my parents give me about 600 dollars a week for allowance, but I thought she'll be more modest. Never mind that.

But what really pissed me off is that whenever I am trying to talk to her, she's texting on her phone and only looked up to smile at me when the food arrived. It's kinda funny as previously whenever I sent her a WhatsApp, she'll take almost a day to reply even though I saw two blue ticks. And now, she's glued to her phone. 

Later, we went shopping together. And she kept going to the branded shop and telling me this and that look really nice. She's obviously hinting me to get her a gift. WTF. I don't mind if you are my girlfriend or wife, but on the first date? Srsly? Glad I said "yea looks good" but didn't buy anything for her :D

I realised she isn't really my type and after that night, I never wanted to go out with her again despite she occasionally asking me to. I dunno if she's really interested in me or not. Or perhaps some stupid friend of mine told her my parents owned a multimillion dollar business. 

Maybe it's my own fault for being attracted to her because of her great looks in the first place. After this experience, I come to the conclusion that I like girls who are simple and modest. And I hope that this beautiful girl finds her sugar daddy soon.

 Hey there. I feel for you. I suffered from depression too and I was exempted from NS. I will never understand what you will have gone through in those times but I get the part about feeling 'distant' when the topic turns to NS. I suffer from a guy-related anxiety so I don't really have much guy friends. But for those that I do talk to, I feel really...disconnected from them. 

I don't think you should feel what you are doing is wrong. I used to worry that I would be judged against for having not gone through that experience, but usually, people don't seem to care. Perhaps I'm lucky I met the right people who don't, but I would still feel that most people don't really bother much.

Perhaps try talking to your female friends? Not all would really ask about your NS and you can feel better compared to talking to guys.

You will have to consider what you mean by "close friends". I'm assuming (from my own perspective), someone who is able to connect with you emotionally, and to some extent hang out with you ALONE on many occasions. Hmm, as I type here I really do wonder who are my close friends, while I can't say you will find one, rest assured you aren't alone.

But I've never felt the intense need to have someone by my side before. It's not like I'm a loner either; I actively participate in group events.

I do know what it's like to be lonely, though. I go through life knowing that I am not complete but never feeling that way, which is sort of paradoxical. I always wonder what I'm missing out on, as though there's an entire aspect of life that evades my experience. I look at people who talk about going in and out of love, but I only have superficial sympathy at best.

Suffice to say, I've never felt strongly about anyone.

I'm a Chinese guy in my second year of university. In January, I got acquainted with an Indian girl (not NUS, but from SIT) through a mutual friend. We hit it off as friends. I found her funny, smart and beautiful. I wasn't also objectifying her, I genuinely thought she was beautiful then and even now.

After a month of hesitation, I picked up my balls and asked her out on a date. She agreed. Prior to this, I've not been with an Indian girl, only Chinese ones. She also hasn't dated a Chinese boy so we were both noobs. If anyone had told me before her that I would be dating an Indian girl, I would have laughed. After all, I've always had a preference for Chinese girls simply because similarities attract. That first date went well and we had many subsequent ones. Later in March, I asked if she wanted to be my girlfriend. She said yes. Some of you are probably thinking it's too soon. I've known her only for three months. But there are some things in life that I know for sure that it is what I want. She, I'm sure of. Confirm plus chop. 

I've met her family. Her family is Hindu, she is too. As far as religions go, I'm an atheist and I'm not bothered. Her family has been accommodating and nice to me. They taught me their cultures and fed me like really awesome home cooked Indian food. For instance, her mum recently told me that "she was going to curry me up." Lol! 

Here's the problem. I want to introduce her to my family, but I know undoubtedly that my mum will not accept our relationship. She knows I'm dating a girl, but she doesn't know I'm dating an Indian. My mum is traditional in her mindset and has said some rather unsettling, racist remarks about Indians and Malay on several occasions. I grew up listening to negative remarks and having negative stereotypes of the minorities in Singapore. It didn't help that I went to SAP schools, and although there was a handful of minorities, I hardly ever interacted with them. In defence of my mum, she's a nice lady, stay home mum... she's just misinformed.

My first "real" interaction, I suppose, was when I was an officer cadet in the army. My buddy was this crazy Indian dude who made OCS super enjoyable. For me, NS challenged the prejudices I had and changed them. Now, whenever my mum says something bad about Indians or Malays, I would correct her. Even now, after NS, I am constantly listing down prejudices I've on paper and I challenge them to see if they still align my values now. If they don't, they get striked out. Before, on top of being the son of a racist (or a misinformed) mother, I was also a homophobe, but I went for my first Pink Dot this year as an ally to a gay friend. So.. I'm learning. Slowly.

Back to my mum... I'm not sure how I'm gonna let her know that I'm with an Indian girl. I've told my girlfriend that my mum is incredibly racist. That the only reason I don't want to introduce her to my mum is because she's probably gonna say something really insensitive that might be hurtful. She said it's fine that we keep our relationship secret for now, but I know it's something I've to do and it would also mean a lot to my girlfriend to know my family. My dad's pretty bo chap about inter-racial relationships so as far as he goes, I know he'll be okay with it lah. Maybe he'll just tease me about it. 

Also, not exactly a big problem, but I've had a friend from JC ask why I was with an Indian girl. I'm pretty sure he's being an ass but his opinion doesn't matter to me. But it might matter to my girlfriend. I fear she might have to deal with future snide remarks like that.

Any advice for me and her? Sorry, this is super long.. I meant to write like three paragraphs, but went over limit. Paiseh. Thanks for reading!

I read somewhere that contrary to popular belief, guys are actually intimidated by pretty girls. Which means to say that as much as guys in general like pretty girls, they don't actually dare to approach these girls unless the pretty girl appears friendly and rather receptive to have a chat with the guy. Some bold guys may try come nearer or perhaps find something to talk when the pretty girl wasn't with her usual female friends, but if the pretty girl still appear aloof and not very interested, not many guys persist in talking to her, unless they happen to be in the same school/workplace. If they feel that they cannot get to talk much to the girl (mainly because the pretty girl is always with her clique of female friends or she simply appear uninterested), at most they will just steal glances at the good looking girl.

So from a guy's perspective, i noticed that no matter how good looking a girl is, if she appear aloof, not many guys dare to approach her in the first place,which means it is not necessarily true that a pretty girl confirm have many guys chasing her. This happen only if the pretty girl is also quite sociable. Agree?

By all accounts, I am a highly successful NUS student (good grades and all). But I really don't want anyone to lead my life. For I was (am?) afflicted with depression since my army days 3 years ago, and have never fully escaped its grasp.

You might think I'm one of the numerous slackers/chaokengers you met in army, but I'm really not. When your days are totally devoid of happiness and are full of negative thoughts, life gets hard really really fast.

No one in NUS knows this part of my life. In fact, I try my hardest to cover it up. I want to start on a clean slate. I don't want you to think I'm crazy/suicidal/chaokenger.

Because of that, I have to constantly lie to my friends about my past. Like when I meet someone new and the conversation inevitably turns to the topic of NS, I lie about having some condition while trying to repress unpleasant memories. Not only am I unable to contribute anything to the conversation, many of them end up thinking that I had a slack and really enjoyable time in NS, which leaves me stricken.

I know what I'm doing is wrong. The constant deception gets wearisome. But I really don't want to be stereotyped in that unpleasant way.

I suppose I will never have close friends.
-
 
I have this close friend of mine who is in his late twenties. I know his family as we were from the same secondary school. Unlike myself who came from a well-to-do family, he came from a below average household whose parents worked as a cleaner and a provision shop assistant. And the problem with this friend of mine, is that he is a spendthrift and wanted to show off that he is rich, at the expense of his family and those close to him.

He graduated years back and is now working as a marketing executive in a local SME. He gets about S$4.5 to S$5K every month. He loves to enjoy the finest things in life, and he wanted to have them. He goes clubbing, drinking, going to posh restaurants for meals, travelling, and a year ago he bought himself a Mercedes. He even bought a $7K handbag for his girlfriend on an occasion. And he loves posting his wonderful experience on Facebook to harvest likes and envy from friends. Okay, I'm fine with that. Have fun.

But the problem is, he is always getting into debts as he spent all his money on the wants and ended up borrowing money to buy those needs. There was even once he borrowed a five digits sum from me because his father needed it for a leg surgery. I reluctantly lent it to him on the account that his poor father really needed it and he even told me not to tell his parents. I agreed as I don't want to hurt his parents. But the amount hasn't been returned till date.

I believe I am not the only one who he had borrowed money from, but I seriously hope the words "loan shark" are not part of the liabilities section on his ledger. The sad part is, his parents who are in their late 60s are still working to support themselves, and when I casually ask them if their only son gives them monthly allowance, they said that he doesn't because he needs to save for his future and that they are still fit enough to work. I am very angry at this irresponsible friend of mine. Even during our schooling days, he always go out of his means to impress others, especially girls, and this attitude brought him more harm than good. 

I confronted him about his issue, and he told me he will soon repay the money. And his "soon" appears to be "never" because he has not even returned a small part of it. And he constantly said he is waiting for his big break in life and always complained about how Singapore limits the opportunities for him to be successful and badmouthing the company he worked in. He blamed everyone except himself.

And a month ago, he told me he is planning to get married as his girlfriend is pregnant. Oh gosh! Does he really think that he can support a family and give his child and wife a comfortable life in the situation like his?! Then I told myself that's it. I ended our long friendship by ignoring him and not wanting to be involved with anything to do with him. I bet he is going to ask me to loan him for the wedding too. I should spend more of my time and money with family and my girlfriend. Enough is enough! I had it with this mf guy in this mf life!

I am now much happier after I pretended this friend doesn't exist. As young adults in our 20s who have a decent salary, it is essential to save and make long terms plans instead of instant gratification. Life is unpredictable, and we cannot always assume that we will definitely earn back what we had loss today.

-
 
 I personally think you should thread very carefully from now on moving forward, especially so if you very much value your r/s with your boyfriend. We can't turn back time and the world is unforgiving. That is reality. Even if unintentional, some mistakes once committed can never be unwritten and may have grave consequences.

And what sort of guy would hug a girl like that knowing she is attached. A good guy wouldn't do that even if the girl was sending signals. You ought to reevaluate him if there's a difference between what you think of him and his true self.

I think you need to come clean with your boyfriend. Honesty is the best policy and is required for a healthy r/s. Besides, I highly doubt you can keep it under wraps given your guilt. Hopefully everything will work out fine. :)

Greetings fellow NUS peeps! I'm sorry to have to do this, but here's another gay-related post. I know by now some of you are probably sick of reading gay-related confessions. I am too, but please, bear with me for I must rant!!!!

I'm like the Mahcik Gateway to a lot of gay boys. It started in poly. I was from mass comm., so naturally, there were a lot of gay boys in there. The assumption between the girls was to assume all guys in our cohort are gay unless otherwise stated. Yes, it was THAT many. It was in poly too that I became very gay-friendly and started hanging out at gay bars and clubs on invitation from my lovely and fabulous gay friends. So you can somehow guess that my network of gay friends grew and I dare say is really quite extensive. Since coming into NUS (quick shoutout to all my nus Y2 biz peers!), I've stopped clubbing mostly because I tire so easily nowadays.

At my internship, I befriended this really cute SMU boy! He's sweet, charming and very gentlemanly! The kind that holds the door open for you one and buys you coffee in the morning. We always got lunches together and the conversations we've are quite fluid and varied (we both enjoy discussing politics and cats). And I really, really like him, and have half a mind to ask him out a date (yeah, I'm the kind of girl unashamed to initiate dates). We've so far maintained a cordial, professional relationship between colleagues... but recently, he added me on Facebook.

And well... 50 mutual friends. Of these 50.......

40 are gay boys........ That's 4 in 5 chance he's gay. A staggering 80%.

Can I cry now? Y MUZ U DO DIS 2 ME, CUPID? 

- Sad, lonely NUS girl
-
 
I graduated from NUS, and I follow this page because there are a lot of funny stories, a lot of heartwarming stories, but mostly because I effing miss NUS a lot. Besides the LGBTQ debate, I realised there are a lot of incoming freshies asking about tips for making friends, so here's my two cents worth.

I didn't manage to go for my own home faculty's orientation camp, but I managed to go for my (secondary?) faculty's one, and I did not regret it one bit. I'm the kind of person who probably looks very bitchy and dao, but honestly I am very shy when it comes to making new friends because I'm always afraid people will judge me and think I'm a loser. However, I think most of the times the orientation camps will really allow you to make long-lasting friendships (okay at least for your 3-4 years in NUS) that will change your uni life.

I do regret not being able to go for my own home faculty's camp, because I ended up always going for lectures and tutorials alone. I tried making friends during lab and tutorials, but it's hard cos I'm shy and I also look unfriendly. However, because I went for the other camp, I made so many friends that have changed my life forever. So to all the freshies out there thinking of whether or not going to orientation camp makes a difference, I say, if you don't even go, it's a 100% chance you won't make new friends at the camp.

Strangely not many have asked about staying on campus, but I'm just gonna put it out here in case any incoming freshies are wondering...do think about staying on campus at least in your freshman year if you really want to make friends. Although going for the orientation camp was useful, I think staying on campus was even more helpful in making friends. All the late nights studying (okay, more like eating supper and gossiping) were really memorable and I would not have traded staying all 4 years on campus for anything else in the world. If you're worried about your studies, just try in your freshie year; you've not much to lose anyway.

Sorry for the long post, but as a working adult now it kind of sucks, and I'm always thinking back on my NUS days and how they were probably the best 4 years of my education life. And all because of the friends I made. So freshies, be bold! Even if you're shy, just try! Think about it this way, NUS is a whole new place. Most people probably don't know you, so you can start from scratch. Everybody's too worried about their own things to be judging you, and people are actually much nicer and more accepting than you think because they're more mature.

(worse case scenario, even if you totally mess up, you get to reset once you graduate, because again, work is a whole other ball game. GOOD LUCK!)

-
 
I've heard a lot of people say, "Looks are not important. Personality is." Really? It sounds pleasing and encouraging but do people really practice that, or is it all talk? People will first associate themselves with you if you are good-looking, before being interested in your personality, especially if you're a girl.

I was born to be short, plump, bad skin, bad hair and I have a slurred speech. Both my parents are unattractive too, hence most of this is obviously inherited.

During secondary school, my classmates are constantly bullying me over my looks, especially the boys. They kept calling me names and even once said that I look as if I got hit by a truck. Some girls joined in too. Thus, I became an introvert, just focusing on my studies and didn't bother to have a social life. It is really very depressing knowing that people always judge me by my appearance. Even if I try to be nice and want to join in a group, they may reluctantly let me but they will roll their eyes whenever I speak and they kept replying "Duh can can" or "Obviously". They blatantly showed me that they don't value my opinion as a person at all. And they seldom include me in their conversations and hangouts, hence I usually stay away from them because it is very hurtful.

There are moments in my life when I feel like committing suicide. What have I done to deserve this? I am not rude, I try to be polite. I know my looks are not presentable, and it is a great disadvantage in my life. At least in NUS, the people here are more mature and they don't intentionally show their contempt. I am thankful.

Especially for a girl, success in life is largely determined by the looks. You get to choose a better husband, a better job, guys will shower you with gifts, and people are more willing to help you and associate themselves with you. Maybe this is a good example of natural selection, to put an end to my inferior genes so I won't pass it on the next generation. Should include this example in my LSM answers lol.

Recently, a close friend of mine shared with me about his love story to be. This includes his story of how he is chasing this girl, how she makes him feel, dem feels he had during the first date, etc. 
Normally, I would listen and entertain such stories as they are somewhat interesting. However, when he was sharing his story with me, I felt really uninterested maybe because I couldn't relate.This might be because I do not see the value in relationships.

Coming from a rather poor family, I just do not understand how I would want to spend money on someone else who may or may not even reciprocate the feelings I have for the individual. I guess I just don't want to make an investment where the returns are uncertain and I do not want to feel vulnerable to another person, only to be rejected. "Playing safe" and not taking risks has certainly not brought me happiness.

I wonder how people can spend so much on relationships which are destined for doom, and not save for the future. I wonder what they see in some relationships that the other party is worth spending all their time and money on. I envy some of my friends when their partner understand their current financial situations and willing to share the burden.

Engineering student's guide to confess to your crush and never get rejected:

- Take your crush out for a dinner or movie.
- Afterwards, take her to a quiet and romantic place. Ok, now is your chance to confess.
- Hold her hands, look deeply into her eyes and say: "I've been having an awesome time with you, and its time I need to torque to you about something"
- Before she can say no, lift her hand over her head and twist gently.

@ 
Note: This is going to be a long post. 

‘’I'm afraid to post on Facebook and Instagram because I know I won't get many likes’’

Firstly, social media (Facebook, Instagram etc) doesn’t reflect reality accurately. 
So what if your ‘friends’ get 200 likes per photo? Likes are not a good reflection of anyone’s worth (your egs). Do you really need validation through likes? Having more likes doesn’t make one any better than the other. You are worth much more than the amount of likes you receive. 
--
Post whatever you want to post. Then again what is your intention for post pictures? Are you posting for the likes? Or do you genuinely want to ‘share’ your pictures with others. I’m assuming it’s the former in your case. If so, I suggest you spend your precious time on something else that will not make you so miserable… Life is too short for this crap! I guess it really boils down to what you want/expect from social media and your purpose for using it. 

//
‘’No one whatsapps me anymore and when I whatsapp them they don't reply me’’

Maybe it’s the way you present yourself to others. Could it be that you might come off as too clingy etc idk and you don’t realise it? You can confide in your CLOSE friends and ask them for some comments and advice. / How do you know that they are replying out of politeness, perhaps they are really busy… Then again true friends would make time for you and have the basic courtesy to reply your msgs at the least. Maybe you can try meeting new people. ^^
 
//
‘’It seems like everyone hates me’’

Don’t be silly! How can everyone hate you? There will always be someone who appreciates you (like you’ve mentioned, your family members. Or maybe you don’t realise that there are people supporting you passively).
Perhaps you could spend more time building solid friendships (quality over quantity). True friends are hard to come by and are worth the effort! You can also join some interest groups to meet new people. Volunteering is a good way to meet new people IMO. People who volunteer are generally nice haha (sry for stereotyping)

//
‘’low esteemed freak’’

LASTLY, you are definitely not a freak and fear not, you are definitely not alone in this. (Shall not go into the stats) You might not realize that some of these people with 200+ likes might be feeling the same way as you do if they are constantly comparing with others who are getting more likes than them.

Just remember: There is so much more to life than ‘’LIKES’’ and social media though I’ve to admit that social media does play a large role in our lives now. 

I have so much more to write but I shall stop here. 
Hope this helps!
Conflicted. Posting as anon although I would love to help if you need someone to talk to. Oh well….
Anyways, Jiayou! :)

I had been in this 5 year long relationship with my girlfriend whom I met in JC and we were going to get married this coming year end. The reason to engage in this legal ceremony so soon was due to certain unforeseen circumstances which I guess most of of you can guess what it is. However, everything came crashing down when last month, she told me that she didn't want to get married with me. I was devastated. I was so looking forward to building a happy family with her but this dream has now turn into ashes. As I could not take this lying down, I probed and questioned her for the answer, the reason, hoping that I could still salvage it no matter how feeble the attempt could be but I was wrong. The truth as it has always been came in like a wrecking ball, crushing whatever bit of dignity and pride that was left in me. I was uttered speechless and helpless, being reduced to a pile of crap...

As it turns out, the truth is the baby wasn't mine to begin with. It was a product of her and her lover which she got together with when I was doing my time in the army. In other words she was two-timing me and almost wanted to make me the father of his child!!

My father is in his early sixties and had retired half a year ago. He had saved enough money to provide my mom and me a decent standard of living. Therefore, currently my tuition fees, food, transport everything was paid by him. 

However, there is something about him that drove my mom and me to frustration. He could not communicate well with people in general and thus he can't socialise well. This resulted in him "feeling bored" all the time, having to scroll through channels and channels of TV Programmes but yet not knowing what to watch. Then he start to look for old things and when he can't find them, he verbally abused my mom with vulgarities and said very nasty things. Precisely because he can't socialise well with people, he always demand that my mom accompany him out for all 3 meals. And because his lunch and dinner is always 2-3h earlier than me, he will only demand that my mom eat with him and as for me, ever since he retired, I never really had the chance to enjoy lunch/dinner company with my mom. 

There was once I managed to end school only at 8pm and I already arranged to meet my mom out for grocery shopping. However, I only ended up having only enough time to eat my dinner and we went home empty handed. Even then, he still shouted and nagged at us using excuses like we never bring him food when the truth is he is afraid being alone at home. In short, when I go out with my mom, we am not allowed to leave him alone at home for too long or he will find excuses to shout and scold my mom.

My mom still felt that we should try to chat with him, if not he might end up with dementia fast. Problem is, when talking to him, sometimes certain phrases for no reason annoyed him and he started quarrelling and nagging and criticising for super long over a minor topic. If you don't talk to him, he ended up finding topics to talk and always kept bringing out old days stories again and again. 

I'm currently on internship and had only weekends to truly enjoy myself by playing computer games. Many times I do not wish to hear him talk because he always talk same old topics and I damn sian of hearing same old things. Then out of nowhere he would start finding things to be critical about you if you refuse to chat much with him.

My dad by nature is very bad tempered and controlling, simply because he think he have the money. My internship paid me $600 and he don't even allow me to use a single cent of my money! I really do wish to bring my mom out for a big meal and spend quality time with my mom but given how he controlled my money, I don't think I am going to get a chance to do so:( 

He is not the kind who can be talked to for the sake of giving way to us. Can anyone tell me if this is typical of growing old? Or is he being selfish by not allowing my mom to go out with me, except once a week and not for too long. Is he simply feeling lonely? Our family is small, only my dad, mom and me so if my mom and me goes out, it's only him alone at home. 

What puzzles me most is why neither my mom nor me minds being home alone but then he minds it so much? Why must he always find someone to talk but yet no topic to talk? No topic talk then don't talk lah, don't find excuse to verbally abuse/criticise or nag us over minor things just to release your frustration of being bored.

I'm so sorry for the long post but I really hope someone can let me know and understand what exactly is going on with my dad...
