Although they knew that I wish to stay single, they do not know the exact reason why. I always questioned them why they wish I settle down and the answer I always get is "it's just a natural rite of passage". To me, I will never accept this reasoning. Just because it's the norm doesn't mean I should follow it right? Why must I marry a man? Why not I be with a woman instead? Yes biologically it's simple, because a man and a woman can produce offspring. However, I never wanted a child and all I wanted is just a partner who can go out enjoy life with me, provided we have the financial means. Other than the biological reason, or the fact that men offer women emotional and physical security and also because it's the norm, I don't really see the need to be with a man. In fact I felt that women offer better emotional support because they are in general empathetic in nature.

Truth here is I wanted a long term relationship with a woman because I don't think I can be truly happy with a man. I simply like woman more, ever since I was in secondary school. Although I occasionally fantasize sex with man, most of the times I fantasize sexual relations with females and females who attracted my attention are usually average looking but in my opinion, they have a "sensual look". To put it simply, I wish to have a female partner both for companionship and sexual relations.

So yes, I'm a evergreen virgin because I do not know which other females are interested in women and thus I can't even get started. I look like any other girl and is considered decent looking and no one would ever suspect that I am actually attracted to women.

One more thing, I would only try enter a relationship with a man if and only if a relationship with a woman turns out really bad. Otherwise I will always be questioning the phrase that a woman can only be happy with a man.

I'm the author of . I just wanted to say: thank you to everyone who left comments on my confession and to the page administrators who have provided me (and many others) an outlet for them to express themselves. Actions beget consequences; I understood the risks when I first became an escort. I knew that my past would catch up and there was a high chance that it would complicate any future relationships I have. I thought long and hard about it, and made the decision to be an escort. I certainly don't regret the choices I've made and I take full responsibility for them.

I took the advice of the crowd and one that my heart tells me it is the right thing to do. I told her about my past. We were running together at Bedok Reservoir on Tuesday night; at the end of our run, when we were cooling down at the floating platform, I blurted it out. I told her, "I know we are getting serious now, and I know  that I owe you a reply with regards to our future. But before we even think about that, you need to know that for the last three years, I've worked as an escort." There was neither nervousness nor pause in my speech. I had gone over the conversations in my head hundreds of time — but the truth was, I truly felt nervous and scared. I told her I had resigned from my job, and that my feelings for her were genuine and uniquely hers. 

She kept silent for a bit before she asked me questions. How many women (and men) have I slept with? How many casual partners have I had outside of my job? Why did I choose to be an escort? I answered her honestly. Her voice shook as she asked. I knew she was affected by the truth. I could sense it. I've spent numerous hours listening to my clients tell me about their problems. I've heard the changes in tone and pitch of their voices, and now, I was hearing the same in her.

After she was done asking me questions, she told me she wanted to go home. We had planned to have supper together, but alas, it didn't happen. I walked her home like I've faithfully done at the end of each date except that this time, in complete silence. Neither words nor laughters were exchanged. I knew she was thinking and processing what I just told her. She always had this look when she thought hard about things. I've gotten too familiar perhaps with her facial expressions that I now know them by heart.

When we arrived at her lift lobby, just right before she went in the lift, I asked, "Will I hear from you again?" She turned to look at me and said, "Yes". That she needed some time to process this first and would let me know soon what is going to happen moving forward. The doors to the lift closed, and I made my way home feeling both defeated and hopeful. 

Yesterday night, while I was out bowling with friends from school, I received a Whatsapp message from her. She wanted to meet me. I made an excuse to get out of the game, and left to meet her at the playground near her place. I didn't know what was going to happen, but I felt so anxious on the cab ride there. When I got there, she was already waiting for me on the swing. I sat on the other empty swing. We kept silent for awhile, before I asked if she's made a decision. She nodded her head, and then told that she wanted a future with me and that my past, to her, is just that, my past, and that as long as I remain faithful to her, she was willing to have a go at the relationship with me. She made me promise that her parents must not know of my past.

In my head, I was jumping up and down in secret. I reassured her, again, that my feelings for her are genuine and I too wanted that future with her. 

"I guess this means we are a couple?", I asked. 

"Couple of weirdos, you mean?"

Thanks again for allowing me to share my story and giving me the advice I needed. I promise to treasure her. P.S. It's not all fun being an escort, trust me.

Dear , your post reminds me about myself in my past relationship. I agree with you that there are some things he has done wrong. He shouldn't restrict your uni choice and he should let you know about the girls he had been talking to, since it's only fair when he had asked you about the guys you had talked to. Well he's also emotionally dependent on you (nothing wrong with that, perhaps just immaturity). But let me offer you this other perspective about the "cheating" part. I also accused my ex-gf of cheating. Why? Because she didn't spend quality time with me and I felt that she enjoyed herself more with other guys than with me. I don't know about you, in fact I don't know you. But it takes two hands to clap. It could be your actions (or lack of) which made him feel so insecured. It is not so much about you cheating but more of because he didn't feel loved by you. Did you enjoy yourself more with your other guy friends than when you were with him? He might have felt this way.

Having said that, I do agree with the commenters that it's the right move to break up with him. Be careful that he may find ways to come back to you again and ask for forgiveness (read: emotionally dependency). But draw the line clearly, and make sure he knows that you are serious about it. Cheers!

-
 
 Life is too short to be thinking of what if's and could have been's. We ought to be thinking of what will's and can I's. Don't leave any regrets behind.
Step 1: Why did you let him/her go in the first place? Do you really love him/her? Do you still love him/her?
Step 2: Have you confessed? Have you got a definite answer from him/her? Is he/she important enough to you to not let him/her go now? 
Step 3: If things didn't turn out the way you wanted them to, ask yourself if it's time to give up. Can you look back at yourself in the distant future and say "I did what I could."
-
 
I'm about to be a final year undergraduate. To many people in my life, I am just yet another NUS kid. What they don't know is that I am also a male escort. I have kept this part of my life secret to everyone including even my family. 

It started in my first year of university. I was waiting for a friend at a train station when a man in his late thirties approached me with an offer for an interview. I thought it was sleazy at first and didn't think much of it until a week later when I decided to drop in for a visit. There, he told me more about the job and the expectations he had of his escorts. I wasn't exactly attracted to the job but rather, the promise of material wealth (money and luxurious goods — think cars, gadgets, accommodation, etc) that came with it. Having come from a low-income family and from a secondary and JC where most of the kids who were in it were extremely rich, I wanted desperately to be them by any means necessary.

Over the next six months, I was groomed to be a male escort. I was given a new wardrobe and overall, a new look. I went for private etiquette classes where I was taught to be a gentleman. I learned how to behave when I'm with my clients. More than that, I learned to be charming and charismatic, traits I never thought I had, especially with women. The grooming  to be a male escort wasn't easy. Often, I was criticised by my agent if my physical appearances (including my body) wasn't "perfect" by their standards. The criticism took a huge toll on my confidence and self-esteem yet it also built an internal resistance to rejection. Within a year after my training, I had earned enough to pay for my degree and still live comfortably.

My clientele consisted of mostly women between the ages of 35 and 50. A majority of them were married and had kids (some even my age) of their own. Others were single and weren't so lucky in finding a partner. There wasn't always a "fixed agenda" when these women hired me for my company.  

Sometimes, all they want is a company at formal events or dinners. Their husbands and kids had their own lives, and as a result, they felt lonely and neglected. I remembered a client hiring me for three hours simply to have dinner with her. She related to me her husband's infidelity outside of her marriage, how her kids had neglected her, and how her "friends" were just interested in her because of her status in society. I felt pity for her and remembered thinking myself that I hoped her story was never going to be mine. 

Most times though, they hired me for company and sex, something I, at first, felt conflicted with my values but became comfortable with over time. It was through my job as an escort that I explored my sexual side. Since I was young, I've always enjoyed being in control of people for my own gain, and with these women, in bed and out of it, I was often in control of them.

Earlier I mentioned that a majority of my clientele were women. As I got more into the job, I began offering my time to gay men who were in sham marriages with their wives. These were men who were in high positions in their companies and in society. Don't get me wrong. I am straight and I love women. But the gay men paid much more by the hour in comparison. Money was the bottom-line for me. If they had it, I was more than willing to go the other way round. Funny thing though, most of these men weren't so much interested in emotional connection (unlike the women) than they were in the physical.

Outside of my job, I've had a number of sexual partners (girls of my age). These were purely for casual fun. I've been unable to maintain a sustaining relationship due to the nature of my job and have never found a reason for it. Even sex, for me, has become transactional in every sense of the word. The reason why I'm writing in is because recently, I met this girl. She is, in all regards, average in looks, and but rich in wittiness, skin-deep beauty and personality. I asked her out on a date five months ago and things are going great for us. We are still in the stage of getting to know each other, but we both feel we connect well and fancy the other very much.

When we were dating, I was still a male escort. At the beginning, I wasn't sure that we were going to be serious but it did. I have fallen in love with her in every way possible. I love the way she squints her eyes, I love the way she looks so thoughtful when we talk, I love that she works with kids, I love that she steals food from my plate and I love that she would travel two hours to get to my place with soup when I'm sick. Now that we are getting series, I've tendered my notice of resignation to my agent. I haven't had sex with her yet even though I would love to tear her pants off; I'm holding back for two reasons: (1) I want to treat her right because she deserves it and (2) I am afraid that she will not be able to accept my past if I told her.

I've never... been in love before. I'm clueless as an evergreen when it comes to this. I'm excited and scared at the same time... I don't know if... she will love me if she knew. I don't want to start a relationship with her with a lie... but I can't bear the thought of losing her. Is this what love feels like? The uncertainty of it all? Fuck, I'm a mess now. Please don't judge me for my confession, I'm in a pretty vulnerable place now and don't have anyone else I feel comfortable telling this to. Even if I had someone to confide in, I wouldn't be able to due to certain legal liabilities (discretion is everything in this trade).

I don't like the phrase "she wants the D". I'll acknowledge that sexual attraction works both ways, but I think that the phrase is used even when a girl isn't showing obvious interest in a guy. It comes out of nowhere sometimes, and it feels more like the guy is reflecting his own interest onto the girl. Aside from that, it's often said with an aggressive feel which I can't properly express. Also, most societies still accept male dominance in many social, economic and political respects. For it to be reasserted in a sexual domain, in a way which suggests yet again that men are needed for the happiness of women, is off-putting to me. Guys, you may disagree, but ask a girl about how she instinctually feels about this phrase. It might broaden your perspective.

-
 
I don't presume to be THE EXPERT when it comes to relationships, but hopefully getting married while still being a student gives me some credibility. (No, not shotgun, sorry to disappoint haha)

1. People change. Don't expect that the person you date will be the same person after being together for a few months/years. With that perspective, how much does if the person is/isn't "perfect"?

2. But you cannot decide how they will change. NEVER get into a relationship thinking "he/she will become better", because you are setting yourself up for disappointment. 

3. When people say "We are too similar", they are just using that as an excuse for giving up. It's good to be similar. You can genuinely share your interests! 

4. When people say "We are too different", they are just using that as an excuse for giving up. It's good to be different. You can complement each other! 

5. What matters is that you decide & commit to staying together.

#loveisajourney

-
 
 Hi there.

I think if you're socially awkward, chances you won't like what the camps will do and may not enjoy it. For me, my level of enjoyment at something is very evident if one were to look at my face, and oftentimes things like this leave with with a "black face". So I feel that you shouldn't feel obliged to go for one, it can backfire, and I have a couple of friends who went and it backfired.

That being said, I would recommend you to do your own orientation. Depending on the faculty, try to walk around the place to get yourself used to moving around. Places that you would definitely visit for example the Central Library and Utown are additional places to go. This saves you from being 'lost' when school kicks in. 

You may also wish to reveal your faculty and the major, so the people from that faculty can help you better. 

You may like to consider if you feel comfortable going for classes and tutorials alone. I know of some who join camps so they don't feel alone when lessons start. Maybe that can help you decide if you would like to go for a camp.

I'm not sure about the club part though, you might contact them and ask them about it.

Feel free to reply to this if you have any other concerns, questions

2. Let's just be friends. (I'll expect to end our friendship immediately since I don't want to give you any false hope)

3. I've got a boyfriend (Duh, he's sooo much more handsome and richer than you.)

4. I've got more important things right now. (Yep, I'll be painting my nails soon)

5. *ignores* (I am waiting for you to send me a long message about how you like me, which I'll read and then delete it with a sense of satisfaction, knowing that I am in demand in the market.)

Top 5 rejection lines by males and (what they mean):

1. You are like a sister to me. (You're quite ugly.)

2. Let's just be friends. (Yep, friends with benefits.)

3. I've got a girlfriend. (She will make me feel more proud among the other guys.)

4. I've got more important things right now. (Nose mining [see picture below])

5. *ignores* (You're damn ugly)

sorry for long post ahead. on the topic of pre marital sex, i think the idea of girls having to hold their virginity for the one they think is the special one is very cute and highly advisable. it doesn't do to give it up to the first guy that you meet and have feelings for because you deserve to respect yourself and hold it. however, having the mindset that pms is bad and downright deplorable is not good either. because when you're with someone and you feel that physical attraction (usually happens early in the relationship), you'll want to be closer to them, know more about them. and if sex is something you both agree on doing or not doing, it's by choice. and not because pms is "dirty". sex is not dirty. in fact studies have shown that having sex helps to bond a couple due to hormones and stuff. that's why it's good to hold on until you've met someone you think is really special and is willing to commit long term.

but of course there will always be guys who are just in it for the sexual gratification because they're immature and still needy and desperate. those are the kind of guys you might want to avoid. like those confessions about players and cheating. it's ... not responsible behaviour.
I'm not saying that only guys are like that either. but somehow there is this stigma that guys would want to be their gf's first. but their gf doesn't have to be their first. it's a strange double standard which is changing, but still rather prevalent.

tl;dr: at the end of the day, it ought to be of your own choice, made responsibly and while sober. no one can or should make it for you. society doesn't have to know about private choices.

Alot of posts here lately about the woes of guys and the difficulties we face getting girls due to various factors (physical or otherwise).
Guys let me tell you not to worry. Why?
Because time/age is on our (male's) side. You seldom see society questioning why a guy at let's say 35 years of age is still single, compared to a female of similar age who would likely be labelled as a spinster etc. 
I tell you; yes now at this age range of 20+ when it's the prime for girls they'll have all their high and mighty expectations for their male partner. When they start to near 30, I ASSURE you they'll start lowering it alot because they realize that all their preset expectations over the years came back to bite them in the ass because they were unable to get their unrealistic 'perfect' guy. And when age catches up with them they'll begin to eat humble pie in desperation of just wanting to get a life partner before 30 or 35. 

Then there...there is when those girls that used to reject us will start crawling back to us after realizing their follies. 
So guy, don't sweat it. Time is on our side so just sit back, relax and wait for them to come running to you eventually. Remember, girls are always the ones who lose out with age. 
It's laughable how they even dare to have such expectations when they're on the shorter end of the stick. What a joke.

When I entered NUS after my NS, I decided to make a big change in my life. I no longer wanted to live an aimless life mired in mediocrity and just getting by. I wanted to be the best after living my past few years as your stereotypical loser.

Looking at the hugely talented people around me and the world, I kept thinking I was short on time. You have smart people 3 to 4 years younger owning the crap out of you and I realised I had to catch up. It wasn't easy.

Now two years on, I wonder all of this have been worth it. I sacrificed a great deal of my social life, holiday time, sleep time - just for a little more time to be able to punch above my own weight. Academics and job experience wise - I am doing fine. However, is "fine" enough? Doing "fine" seems like a Pyrrhic victory, tryharding, only to be left for a fool in the end.

I take all defeats personally. Defeat plants a seed of doubt and makes you question your abilities. It creates a sense of burning rage that you just want to unleash on yourself.

We only have a few decades to make a difference before we are six foot under. I fear that I might just be a normal person, destined to be filler, destined to be just something in the background. If that is the case, I am having serious doubts about chasing a lost cause, that I am trying to turn an ordinary stone into a diamond by mindlessly and repeatedly hammering it. 

Some things just cannot be fixed..

Let me share my story. I did badly in my Year 1 Sem 2, which made my CAP suffer a lot. It almost fell below 3.5 I think. But I didn't give up. I knew I could do better than this. Guess what, I managed to pull it back to 4.18 this sem. I didn't expect such a good result this sem, but there is one thing I am pretty sure of - I have put in my best effort and I have pushed myself beyond the limit. So if you did badly, just don't give up. Keep the faith, work hard and most importantly, persevere.

Just like (almost) any girl, I do think it will be nice to get into a relationship, but I don't believe in actively seeking one. I guess for me I have always thought that my future boyfriend will have first been my friend and someone that I will naturally grow closer to.

Perhaps because of that, I think I get scared off by guys who are interested in me. I'm a pretty average girl so I am just basing this on the few cases I have experienced so far. When a guy, who I don't consider myself close enough to, starts dropping hints or confesses to me, I feel like it puts stress on the friendship/relationship and that makes me feel like distancing myself. The way I think about it is, if I am not interested in him, I shouldn't continue to meet him or talk to him so regularly. But every time this leads to the friendship just dying off. 

The contradiction lies in the fact that if I don't give myself the chance to get to know the guy better, I wouldn't start to like him either. And it seems stupid of me therefore to behave the way I do each time. Just wanted to hear what you guys think about this and thanks for even reading this to the end haha!

Unpopular opinion coming through!
Reading some of the confessions claiming that they are moral for not having premarital sex is really getting me on my nerves.
Is virginity a priority in a romantic relationship? I believe sex and romance CAN be separated.
As a single male, I can have a one night stand with a lady without romantic attachment, while we both satisfy our sexual desires.
Likewise, I can have a romantic relationship with a girl without wanting to get into her pants.
That said, having a sexual and romantic relationship with your SO is probably the best thing ever.
Only when people realise this, we will have less "players" who make use of romance to get sex, or "victims" who use sex to sustain a romantic relationship.
Does anyone actually agree with me?

Hi guys it's troll knight again!! 

Recently I have noticed a lot of posts regarding " confessing to a girl". At one point of my life, I'm also a clueless chap, often conducting kamikaze strike on my eye candies and scared them all away. The problem is..it's really difficult for a evergreen guy to know when is the right time to confess to the girl.

Let me share with you some advice so that you can successfully get your dream girl. 

If you are facing the following problems, chances are the girl isn't interested. It is better to give up and find a new girl.

1) The girl take damn long to reply to your message most of the time, and her replies are one word.

If the girl is really interested in you, she will reply in just 5 seconds. And her replies will be long sentences and full of emoji.

2) If your text conversation with a girl cannot last throughout the day and till late night.
3) If you and the girl are not chatting over the phone every single night.

When 2 person like each other their topic will be endless and they can really talk forever. 

4) If you flirt with her and she is not comfortable with it.

When a girl like you, she will be really happy when you sugar coat her with sweet talks. She might flirt back too.

5) If you stop texting the girl and she won't take the initiative to start a conversation with you.

6) If you drop hints and the girl starts to distance herself from you.

To  please don't sterotype how fat a girl is by assuming their weight in the first place or even say a girl is fat, use words like big size instead. If she knew that you commented her this way she would've been upset. In addition weight would be affected by height. If a girl is 1.4m with 74kg her bmi would be in an unhealthy range if she is not muscular, and if she is 1.8m with 74kg then she is of a normal weight range. Please dont go around asking girls their weight, and just giving an example I'm a girl myself with a body weight around yours (fluctuates between 70 to 76kg) and my bmi is in 120% range. However when girls and guys guessed my weight their guess is usually 60+kg. So weight is really not a good indicator.

You can protect her heart without saying any defensive words if you are willing to stay by her like a loyal faithful friend. Maybe you can try and we will get her to give you chance.

 Do you feel you are pretty boring or do your friends think you're boring? If you don't feel like talking then so be it. Even when in small circles, close friends or couples may be silent when together and it's totally alright. You need to learn to be comfortable in your own skin, understand yourself and develop your own identity as an individual. This doesn't mean completely ignoring what people around you think but rather, only do so if you want to. If they misunderstand your silence, just tell them you just don't feel like talking or explain to them whatever reasons you have?

2) No! No! & No! Sorry mate. Strictly speaking, the answer to your question depends on various factors; for example, which country/city you go to, have you travelled alone/with others before, are you street smart etc. But the very fact that you even asked and the way you phrased your question, the answer for you is strictly "No." Your best shot would be to connect with other Singaporeans going to the same partner university as you or partner universities in the same area and try to arrange to travel together. Even then, you still ought to consider if you guys should be travelling together, if they are trustworthy etc. Can you and should you trust local students or other international "friends"? YOU BETTER THINK TWICE BEFORE YOU ACT. You and others might think these advices are crap, that you only live once, you have grown up now (my impression is otherwise) and that you ought to be adventurous. But more than anything else, being an adult means being able to think independently for yourself, make the right decisions and take sole responsibility for the results.

A concerned friend.

-
 
TL;DR — It's really hard to feel so strongly towards someone who you don't know whether feels the same way towards you. It's even more difficult when this person lives in a different country from you. 

I can't say I'm in love with this person, because we hardly see each other, only a few times in fact; I just can't describe this feeling, but to keep it simple, I just want to get to know this person more - their life story, even the little insignificant things. I appreciate every single second I'm around this 'special' person; we don't have to be doing anything exciting, because their sheer presence simply makes me feel adequate, like my life is complete. 

We keep in contact through a couple of text messages here and there daily, but that's really the only form of interaction we ever have. Every single time this person's name pops up on my phone screen, I can honestly say that it makes me feel like I'm the happiest person on earth for that moment. This person doesn't even have to reply me, keep the conversation going, or even bother acknowledging my existence since we, honestly speaking, have no real 'purpose' to do so, but they do, and I genuinely appreciate it. 

It's really difficult when you're always (sub)consciously thinking about this one person; you just want to see them in person (not for any sexual purposes), but you just simply don't know when the next time you two would meet again, if ever. You know, witnessing their one little smile in real life makes all the wait worth it. That amazing feeling you get when you finally get to know that you'll be seeing them again in person, that feeling you get as you countdown from months to weeks to days to hours to minutes before you see them next... then that completely contrasting feeling you get the moment you say goodbye to them in person with uncertainty about future meet ups. It's painful, it really is.

I don't even know how it's possible to feel this way and maintain this feeling towards a person you hardly ever see physically, a person who is geographically far away from you, a person who might not even feel anything more than a friend towards you, but I do. 

I feel so strongly towards this person that I'm willing to put a hold on everything that's going on in my life now and just move to the place they're living at, in the future. Even then, this person may relocate afterwards for whatever purposes. I wouldn't even mind the potential disappointment I might be hit with for doing so, because this is how special this person is in my eyes. 

I really cannot explain what I'm feeling... I just want to be close to them, physically, mentally and emotionally, you know? Perhaps this is simply a phase, perhaps this is what they call infatuation, and for all you know, it may be. I've been through months only communicating through text messages, not knowing if I'd ever see this person again, but this feeling still persisted. Perhaps this feeling may die down if I give it a few months or so, and I guess that may somehow be a good thing. But I can honestly say that right now, my biggest fear is this person making an exit out of my life. 

To answer what some of you may be thinking, no, I don't think I will ever confess to this person about how I feel. I don't have the courage to, and I don't want anything to change – yes, I know sometimes we need to take a risk, but as of now, I don't think it's worth it nor the right time to do so. And because of this, as counterintuitive as it may sound, I act as reasonably nonchalant as I can towards this person, and I try as hard as I can from dropping any hints about how I feel towards them. So guess this person will remain secretly special to me, without them knowing, without anyone else in the world knowing... only me. 

Until next time, hopefully. Till then, I'll continue patiently waiting for your replies, helplessly thinking about you when I'm listening to sad songs, and everything else I do, and put on a strong facade. X

If you actually read everything, thank you, really, for listening to what I had to say.

P.S. I'd appreciate if nobody commented anything negative, because this is something that has plagued me for the past few months and something I've been wanting to let out but never had the chance to as I'm someone who keeps everything to myself.

P.P.S. Apologies for any grammatical errors. If I were to proof read it, it'd probably take me the entire day because I would go on and on.

There's always the negative connotation with the words "Sissy" and "Tomboy".

However, people who excessively behave in their stereotypical gender roles are often more annoying than these so-called "sissies" and "toms".

Guys who are associated with masculinity, often tend to arrogantly shout and behave in a rude manner, as if to impress others. It's not cool y'know. Whereas guys who are more feminine (a so-called "sissy"), are more friendly, polite and caring. 

Girls who are associated with feminism, often tend to complain over trivial matters and constantly hoping to find the "Mister Perfect" to secure their ideal future, while putting the other guys down. Whereas girls who are more masculine (a so-called "tom-boy") are more fiercely independent, creative and always looking out for the well-being others.

Just my little observation.
What do you guys think?

To all freshies who are worried about camps, my advice is to go for it. Make new friends and expose yourself to the culture. Cos during camps, they will familiarise you with the surroundings. And it allows you to make friends, so that you won't have to sit alone for your first lecture. Not that it's a bad thing. 

If you are really worried, ask the ogls for advice on studies and lifestyle during the camps. Stop worrying and look forward to a great time in NUS.

During that time period, I started falling for a jerk. Which lead to many tears, of which he cheered me up plenty of times. He was always there for me. 

Long story short, I fell for him after our secondary school. After we went out for a movie "date", which I agreed to go, trying to convince myself that I didn't like him. Totally backfiring, I remember telling my friends how sweet he was, or how much he understood me. How he was always there for me. I fell head over heels for this guy. But he didn't feel the same. He told me he liked someone, who I didn't know. I was disappointed, hence I never confessed.

Now I'm in uni. He's now waiting to be enlisted. We are still in contact. After some time, I finally started cool down, and started to look at other things.  We went out one more time to another movie "date"... I guess it was my fault for being so comfortable with him. Now he's the one who likes me.  However, during my time in uni, I started to like someone else. But I don't think there will be any development between this guy and me. We seem to be of different world. but regarding the guy who likes me now... I don't know what to do. I did like him A LOT before. But I think he's getting further away from my ideal type... but then again, they always say its better to have someone who loves you. However, when I told my friends some of the stuff he does.(he might be sorta perverted) They don't seem very supportive of him. But right now, I can't seem to get him out of my head.

-
 
I am lonely.

Loneliness is distinct from being alone; I do love the latter so, for I prefer solitude to downing many a dram of alcohol with a group of friends or acquaintances, or watching a concert. Crowds tire me; even small groups leave me yearning for peace and quiet.

In the silence I find clarity and rest - my thoughts are uninterrupted and unaffected by anyone else.

But I feel lonely.

I know not why, but I cannot feel love for anyone - not my family, not my closest friends, not even my pet cat of several years. If they get hurt, there is only a faint stirring of emotion, easily lost in the utter bleakness of my soul, like tears in rain.

I can only cry for myself - and I have done so until I cannot cry any more.

There are times I can hardly breathe, for my loneliness overwhelms me, and I can only sit or lie and wait for it to end.

But I am strong! My mind suffers no one to insult its ability, so I should be able to overcome it - or at least that's what people say about me. So why can't I do it?

Why don't I just die?

I know the arguments; speak not to me of eternal damnation or the absurdity of this world. Mention not the pain people who care for me will feel - who are you to say that their pain triumphs mine, and that mine does not even compare to theirs?

To be or not to be - that is the question.

I am lonely, ladies and gentlemen, and I fear I am beginning to love it, even as it wounds me to the heart. Strange, isn't it? I am growing to love my own loneliness.

But there still remains the silhouette of a beautiful dream I had: that I can find someone to spend the rest of my days with. It is the only true wish I have right now, and it keeps me going.

But when I think of it, I grow afraid and turn away from it. What if I grow bored of her, as I have done so for many of my past interests? What if I am not good enough for anyone?

You won't recognise me on the campus - I can fake being normal as easily as breathing. I can laugh, I can smile, I can appear carefree.

In the wee hours of the morning, my facade fails.

-
 
To 
I have gone for uhc councelling and it were a series of meaningful conversation I would say. It isn't stated on uhc website but actually there were eight sessions, normally one every week, and you can call your personal counsellor at any time when you need it. By the end of it I gained confidence to talk more to people around me and started to think positively and laughed more. There was a lot of advice from my counsellor that was quite suitable for me and I experienced a surprising change of my mind. BTW, it's free for NUS students.

To  's 'Perhaps some of you might question why I appear to be so needy and in desperation of new friends when old friends could be enough, but I feel afraid of being socially left out and ostracised after unpleasant experiences which happened to me a good few years back. I hope people would really, truly understand my experiences, but that is a different story for a different day.' There's nothing wrong in admitting that you seek some kind of emotional connection. “I love being horribly straightforward. I love sending reckless text messages (because how reckless can a form of digitized communication be?) and telling people I love them and telling people they are absolutely magical humans and I cannot believe they really exist. I love saying, Kiss me harder, and You’re a good person, and, You brighten my day. I live my life as straight-forward as possible.

Because one day, I might get hit by a bus.

Maybe it’s weird. Maybe it’s scary. Maybe it seems downright impossible to just be—to just let people know you want them, need them, feel like, in this very moment, you will die if you do not see them, hold them, touch them in some way whether its your feet on their thighs on the couch or your tongue in their mouth or your heart in their hands.

But there is nothing more beautiful than being desperate.

And there is nothing more risky than pretending not to care.

We are young and we are human and we are beautiful and we are not as in control as we think we are. We never know who needs us back. We never know the magic that can arise between ourselves and other humans.

We never know when the bus is coming.”

—Rachel C. Lewis, Tell The People You Love That You Love Them

To 
“What keeps you going everyday? What's your motivation? I'm comfortable being alone and not giving a hoot about anything.”

This is my short answer to your question. Not sure how relevant it is, but I tried.

I am someone with low confidence and who has social anxiety. During school term, I struggle almost everyday with the fear of attending classes and even passing by people along the walkways. Everyday I battle with my anxieties and feel so mentally drained. Even during the holidays, I worry that my condition will worsen because I tend to meet people on a less frequent basis. Still, many things keep me going.

I love my family and friends, and I want to be someone who they can share their troubles with. I want to communicate with them and hopefully learn how to be happier people together. I’m not from a rich family, so I want to work harder to be able to provide a better life for my parents in the future. 

Right now, I am single. Someday, I want to fall in love and get married.  I want to be able to share my happiness with someone else. Usually I am very comfortable alone, because when I am alone, I don’t have to be preoccupied with negative thoughts of what other people think of me. Yet, I know this is not what I want in life. Instead of closing myself up, or telling myself I don’t care about life anymore (because that is easy to do), I tell myself to continue challenging life. Instead of limiting my life experiences, I want to keep living and learning. I want to become emotionally stronger for the people I love, and that is my motivation for living because that will be what makes me happy as well.

She's not a lesbian and seems interested in this other dude she got to know. But when we're together, there's something in the way we flirt and look at each other that got me thinking that maybe she feels something too. She seems to want my attention more than a normal friend would to or more than that that she want from our other friends ... I don't know if she actually feels something for me. But who am I kidding, this is Singapore... Where our relationship would never be recognised and even viewed at with disgust. Maybe I should just forget it and move on but I keep thinking about her. I'm just so confused now, about my sexuality as well as my feelings for her.

To  and 

Hey, it's  here. I just wanted to thank the both of you for your kind words. I did not expect to get any replies, and to know that there are others in NUS suffering the same (or worse) problems just makes my heart sink. No one should ever have to go through this sort of pain and mental stress.

Having to think up of an excuse to avoid eating with groups, wanting to go places to eat but knowing you can't. Reunion dinners and any sort of gatherings are just the worst, because you know you can't really avoid them, but you also know when the food is served it's going to be an awkward scene of you not eating and just finding excuses.

I always think of what it would be like if I didn't have this problem. It seems like a world full of colors and happiness. Okay, maybe I'm exaggerating here, but seriously. If I could eat out without issues, the first thing I'd do is invite my family to a fancy restaurant to eat. That's a dream I'd love to achieve one day.

To attain that dream and more though, I'll just have to keep working hard. I should really seek help once again, and seeing both of your kind words serve as more motivation to do so. I hope the both of you (and anyone else facing any sort of difficulties) manage to overcome your difficulties as well and come out as better, stronger people. :)

-
 
Guys, hope that this confession goes through as I'm rather afraid to share it in public. So here it goes:

I'm a photographer (stereotyped with professional-looking equipment with awesome prices to match their cost), and to many people, I appear everywhere around school. It's not uncommon for me to be found taking photos for the various school communities in school camps, and faculty and major-level events. I think I'm imagined to be a very popular guy, knowing tons of people and friends, and friends of friends, appearing to mingle around effortlessly with the crowd and becoming part of the image of camps themselves.

But I always, always can't help but feel that I'm living one of the most fake facades ever. It seems that people treasure the presence of a professional looking camera, but not the emotional soul powering it. Conversations take place and start because of the act of photographing, but not because of the qualities of the person who takes the photographs in the first place. And as I appear to know a huge number of people, I'm never included in any close friend-groups, often finding myself lunching and taking dinners on my own. It can't be helped that I'm a rather poor in-depth communicator; often running out of ideas in small, inquisitive talk. 

Even more so, I feel I am valued only because of what I do, but not who I really am; when I am not needed, I feel forgotten and terribly left out of crucial social communications. I just do not know who to call out and hang out with, other than my own old, trusty friends who knows me as a person and more than just a photographer who appears out of nowhere. Perhaps some of you might question why I appear to be so needy and in desperation of new friends when old friends could be enough, but I feel afraid of being socially left out and ostracised after unpleasant experiences which happened to me a good few years back. I hope people would really, truly understand my experiences, but that is a different story for a different day.

I take photos because I like the art and the act of taking them (with the experience of constructing the shots), and also to hopefully make new friends and find potential soulmates. I find myself knowing loads of acquaintances, but almost zero or even zero close friends in university. And I feel very vexed about this entire thing, because I feel like I'm not being emotionally valued, and sometimes being equated to a commodity. 

So to all you camp-goers and other people who meet photographers, please take the chance to know them better. We might appear very sociable and talkative, but in reality many of us could be tremendously shy, and are secretly lonely people who really appreciate a close friendship. I might not speak for all who do similar work to what I do, but we are people who choose to take photos out of our own free will, and that we often enjoy the craft itself, while adding to the smorgasbord of experiences that you all undergo here in higher learning. 

Still hoping I could feel more emotionally important to others, but seems like it's not happening :(

Sincerely,
the frustrated photographer

Regarding friendship, I know making new friends in uni is different and seems more difficult than in secondary or what :( but I would encourage people to join a CCA or smth to make friends. Find one that suits your interest! It really helps to know more people and make friends! It all depends on you to integrate yourself with others and approach them! -
 
Looking at the number of posts related to "hopeless" romantics, and all the descriptions of desperate people trying to "get into people's pants", I really wonder what it is that traps everyone in these states of mind. 

I'm a guy from a well to do family studying in a faculty that parents mention to kids in stereotypical asian dialogues, where I balance multiple commitments within and beyond school, in which I hold titles of some sort in many of them. I commit to causes I believe in, pursue achievements that further my career prospects, spend freely on what makes me happy (no need to save for the special festivals and events), and work on whatever piques my interest. Basically all things that could have gone right have gone right. 

To say the least, I would never have been able to survive in those commitments or in my academics should I be in a committed relationship. I believe that neither choosing a relationship or experiences is wrong, as long as it makes your life better. (Sure doesn't seem that way in many of those confessions.) It's all about living life to the fullest, and having a partner to share in your world is just one way. And no matter your choice, to be confident about yourself and the value on life and the events that define it.

Of course, I also know of many happy couples within NUS and to them I give only my best wishes. But would I trade what I have for what they have? I don't think so, not at this point in time at least. Romantic relationships are built upon feelings, and feelings are fickle. They change as we grow and our experiences accumulate. That isn't even take into account incidents that shock us out of our previous world views. What I have won't.

As a disclaimer, I do have a healthy social life and friends from both genders. We hang out, have fun, share our thoughts on issues, and we help each other out when need be. I have also had romantic interests in girls in the past - and I did confess to them, in case some people think this is about guts - and probably will again in future. I am evergreen because those girls turned me down, but hey, at least I'm still great friends (without any vested interests) with many of them and I don't see anything wrong with it, neither do I harbour any excessive hurt or worse, hatred, for the rejections I have experienced. With a good family and wonderful friends, isn't that already plenty enough? Why let your world be so heavily influenced by just 1 form of interpersonal relationships?

I just hope people don't try to judge me for doing things alone. I don't understand the need for people to always require a companion to not feel like they are being silently judged by watchful eyes in the masses (e.g. when going for meals). To me, it is extremely liberating to be able to think of something and know that I can just do it because I have 1 less consideration. To each his/her own. Sometimes, feeling "sad/pity" for someone is about empathy to you as much as it is hurtful to that person who sees nothing wrong with his/her current state, not to mention those who associate myself and people like me with negative character traits. I'm just trying to live my life "without strings" ;)  while I can.

TLDR:
1. Don't judge people who prefer performing most tasks alone.
2. Relationships are based upon feelings, not some objective measurement. Don't get too worked up about not being in one because it doesn't mean that the cosmos is against you.

-
 
It saddens me whenever I read of comments describing LGBT as lifestyles or mere values.

There is this part of me that want to scream out at these people; You don’t know how many sleepless nights I spend crying and praying that I could be straight. Praying that I would like boobs. Forcing myself to look at images of hot girls just so that somehow, I would start to find them hot. I felt dirty and was disgusted with myself whenever I was having an episode of ‘homosexual tendencies’. 

I grew up expecting to lead a normal life - school, work, wife, children, grandchildren, death. Gays were wrong, dirty and intertwined with HIV. I could never be like them. I had to be straight. There was no other choice. 

I forced myself to somehow, miraculously, crush on a girl. It did help that she made the first move. It didn’t feel right though. There was zero sexual or physical attraction, no matter how hard I tried. 

Still, I couldn’t even entertain the thought that I could, in my wildest imagination, be gay. It was simply a phrase that refused to fade away.

It took me months after my twentieth birthday that I finally acquiesced that I would never be able to have sex with girls. To have kids. To lead a normal, traditional and ideal life that everyone seemed to be able to lead. I was, to the very least, disappointed. 

Maybe being LGBT is a choice. Maybe there are some individuals that would rather be discriminated and risk being kicked out of the family. Maybe they would rather be denied the ability to have your lifelong partner visit you when you are in the ICU. It may very well sound like an appealing lifestyle. But certainly not for me.

Well, all I can say now is, to quote from wicked, who can say if I have been changed for the better, but because I knew you, I have been changed for good.

I am a guy who is not interested in a relationship, because of a bad one (with a lady) around a year back. I like being nice to people, doing nice things to and for them, and I was taught by an important figure in my life to always be nice and friendly towards ladies. I find them more approachable than guys, because I connect better with ladies than with guys (I just don't get what's the deal with guys around me always talking about grades,homework, their social life, etc.). As such, I tend to be more open towards ladies, without the intention of getting into a relationship, nor into their pants. I tend to do random stuff for others, such as getting coffee in the middle of the night for some people I don't even know that well (yes, you now know who's posting this). I don't need a reason to do stuff like that, but I do see reasons why I don't need to do stuff like that, reasons which I tend to ignore.

Point of the matter is, if you feel uncomfortable that a guy is being overly-kind or friendly to you, just tell us. It is very hurtful that, if we are doing something in our nature, and all you interpret is that we are doing things with various motivations,dubious ones at that. While it does hold true that many people nowadays do things with practical motivations, it does not necessarily mean that everyone does that. Some of us just see others as simply friendly next-door neighbours, that is all.

Odd guys such as myself, we do exist. We want to be, and act on our notion to be nice to others. Easiest, most direct way is to talk to us about it, face-to-face, and read our replies, body language and all. If not, if you keep posting about how desperate guys from my faculty (engin) are, you are being extremely hurtful.

We didn't keep in touch for half a year and when we began to again, I also started to see him in a different light. 

For the longest time, I thought they were because he was always such a sweetheart to me and that I was over-reciprocating his kindness, or that it was the guilt I felt for being such an asshat to him previously. It wasn't until exchange last month that I realised I had probably been suppressing my feelings all this time. I really miss(ed?) him and would always wait for him to call me yet not initiate the call cos I was afraid he would be too busy. *self-berates at wimpyness* Every guy I now meet, I instinctively compare them to him (yes, even the charismatic young men of foreign blood who ace the game of chivalry). For some queer, impossible reason, no one is as kind, gentle, patient, trustworthy and can make me feel as safe as he does. 

I keep wondering what it'll be like to be in a relationship with him, but my practicality (or cynicism, if you wish) always project a dead end. Maybe it's because I feel that we communicate differently and have different faiths. And perhaps also that I fear my feelings wouldn't be reciprocated. Any how, it's a friendship I fear very much to lose should things not work out between us if we did get to that stage. 

This feels like such a trivial issue that I should let time dismiss out of my life. But as of now it feels like he'll never stop being an important person in my life. Advice, NUSWhisperers? 
-
 
When it comes to relationships people are always so scared of the what-if’s that they forget the what-is. They spend so much time thinking, ‘What if I get hurt?’ and ‘What if it doesn’t work out?’ that they stop thinking about that things that are already real. They forget the feeling they get when the person they love walks into the room and the excitement that rushes through them when the phone rings because it might be the person they are waiting to hear from. Never let the fear of what-if stop you from letting yourself take a chance on love…because “what if” this is the person you’re destined to spend the rest of your life with?

Since we are on the topic of LGBT, I shall share my experience on gays and lesbians as well. 

Before you think that I am gay, no I'm just a straight male. In fact, like a lot of us, I had the impression that gays were just "going through a phase" and often made fun and ridicule them. 

It wasn't until I found out that a close friend of mine was gay. I was initially quite shocked and surprised. A friend of more than 10 years and yet I had no inkling? I went to read up on it and soon realized my deep misunderstanding. Upon thinking back on my past actions and words, I cringed and immediately called my friend to apologize. I guess people just don't really care until it hits them close. 

All i want to say is, the change will come, albeit rather slowly. 
Hang in there my friends!

Sincerely, 
Your straight friend.

I've been wanting to tell this girl how i feel for a long while now but i'm already 4 years too late. And after reading those whispers here of guys not having the guts to tell the girl how they feel, i hope you guys can get the motivation to do so and not make the same mistake i made after hearing my story.

First and foremost, back in JC days, i was failing at my subject combi so bad i wanted to just give up. The jump from secondary school to JC was too huge for me to the point that I didnt care about the numerous U grades i got for exams and had several meet the parents sessions to talk about my grades. This was especially so for my H1 subject as i've held the record for the lowest marks to be given out for the paper for prelims.

Additionally, i was an evergreen myself. Didn't have much contact with the female kind and if i did, i'd find myself in awkward silence situations with them. It was not until a certain subject teacher paired me up with one of my female classmates for a whole term that i got to interact with, lets call her Kathrine. Kathrine wasn't your typical good-looking girl either. She was just above average in looks, the kind where i knew there were several guys in school who eye candied her but not too many to the point she became popular. She was gentle at heart and had a very pleasant character. Her personality was also her charm. But what set her apart from other girls was that she had a strong faith in her religion. She would care for her friends as though it was her own siblings.

She soon learned that i was failing badly at my H1 subject and decided to tutor me at it. She would make hand written notes, lend me her books and even took time out to personally explain to me the concepts of the subject which i couldn't comprehend. We soon found ourselves skipping lectures and remedial classes just to get together to have a meal outside school and went out to study together. As A'level was fast approaching, our study "dates" (if i may call it that) became more and more and to the point my friends thought we were an item. A'level came and my only motivation to do well and not give up (as i mentioned in earlier paragraphs) was so that i could be in the same uni as Kathrine so that i can see her time to time in school. Results day arrived and both of us got into NUS.

But NS was in for me as she entered her first year. We would still hang out on occasions and jio each other out to celebrate our birthdays. But i could feel we were drifting apart because we're not able to see each other often. I could feel that she has been waiting for me but I've still hadn't told her how i felt. I really wanted to but the only factor stopping me was that we have opposing faiths. I knew her family couldn't accept me nor my family could accept her. She told me once before that "don't start something you cannot end well" and sooner than you can know it, our texts while i was in camp was getting less frequent and it would stop for months. We just stop talking.

I matriculated into NUS and promised myself to turn over a new leaf. To not be the socially awkward guy around girls and found myself to go out on several dates (some of them are blind dates while others are dates which my friends set up for me) with several other girls (more than 10), trying to find someone who is on par with Kathrine. To this day, no one i went out with was remotely good as her and i turned those girls down as the dates were over as i didnt want to play with their hearts. To this day, i'm still an evergreen. I would see Kathrine in school once in awhile and my heart would still skip a beat for you. I miss you, i really do.

So to the guys out there who still haven't confessed their feelings to that special someone. Dont make the same mistake as i did. Just go, don't scared.

The less time you spend hanging out with your friends, the more time you have to study.

The more time you have to study, the better understanding and grades you get.

The better grades you get, the more your friends will ask you to hang out to help with work

Therefore, the less you hang out with them, the more you hang out with them.

There is this girl I like since long ago. I say I've forgotten about her, but I'd be lying. I say I love her, but I cannot really be too sure. For many many reasons. After so long of not being able to get together with this girl, and convinced somehow that all the other girls don't count, I was pretty much left with the thought that perhaps nothing counts. No relationship is going to turn out. And true enough, none did. I don't see relationships and love as primarily sexual.

But my coping mechanism for the lack of it is. I told myself, just pleasure. Seek pleasure. Because nothing will last anyway. I'm ashamed to say (and it's also my greatest regret) for going to prostitutes. I've since stopped. Because the depth of my desperation irks me so much. This desperation forces difficult questions on me too. If I'm so unsuccessful in getting with a girl then perhaps I'm made for guys, no? And trust me I've tried. But it is only sexual. There is no love. And ironically it takes a gay encounter to tell me I'm not gay. 

Looking back, it just pains me to know that my desperation is so disgustingly deep, that even if this girl that I like since a long time ago were to tell me that she wants a relationship with me, I think I owe it to myself and to her to say no. Because I'll always be more fucked up than her, plenty more fucked up than her. Recently she shared that the next time I hear from her, I'll be hearing wedding news. I'm so happy for her blessedness, but I cannot help feeling so bitter, either. 

They say good things are worth waiting for. I agree. Just make sure you are worthy yourself through the wait.

To 
You probably already have an answer deep down on what you want to do with your situation but here's my 2 cents worth. 

I used to have a guy friend from JC (girl here) and when I was crushing on him very badly, I found myself in a similar situation as you. Basically, I seemed to be the only one active in our friendship. If I don't contact him, we can go half a year without talking kind of thing. It had gotten to the point when I wondered why bother? and then time passed and we graduated. After I got over my bout of unrequited love though, I decided that some friendships were worth keeping. I messaged him regularly but this time instead of playing the nice person and worrying about his opinion of me, I was quite honest about what I thought. When the opportunity arose, I also talked to him about his past behavior which frustrated me. Turns out, he was plain clueless. Now, we managed to salvage our friendship and on occasion, he's the one to initiate contact and even cheer me on during my exams. (No we're not in a r/s. He's just a really good friend. We've talked about it and he decided not to pursue one so there.)

In your case, my advice to you then would be, assuming you still want to be friends with her, to drop the passive aggressiveness. If you find her behavior to be annoying or worse hurtful, talk to her straight about it but not in a confrontational way. Sometimes you might have to find or create an opportunity in between your friendly banter to do so. If she actually treats you as a friend, she might stick on and return your honesty. From there, adjust and your friendship might turn out for the better :D

I feel that I'm selfish here, but yet I also feel I can't have no expectations either. I'm not sure whether I should contact her to repair the friendship, and what to say if I do contact her

To: 

There really isn't a need to force-fit yourself into any particular category. Sexuality is a spectrum, and something that's fluid, which would require an infinite number of labels to qualify. 

On that note, you are not alone. I'm sure many others, myself included, don't quite know what to feel about our sexuality at some point. It might not feel normal, but really, there is no "normal". You are the way you are, and things will be that way regardless of whether you like it or not. So, i think it would help to just accept things the way they are, and not feel bothered by them.

Personally, I've been through various phases. I remember I felt quite repulsed by the idea of homosexuality when I was little (perhaps reinforced by the stigma), and only felt attracted to girls. Years later, I eventually got a girlfriend, but the relationship didn't last long. I felt terrible at the time when I found out she left me for her ex. 

I haven't had a partner since, and don't feel particularly attracted to any particular sex. Having a romantic relationship would be great, but like yourself, I'm not entirely sure sexual attraction should come with it. I can't quite picture having sex with my future partner, only romantic feelings makes more sense.

So, yeah, there's no real answer I guess. You're not alone for sure, and let's just accept things the way they are and see how things turn out in the future.

I've learnt multiple languages in order to connect to people in a meaningful manner. Some I learnt well, some not. I can speak like a native PRC-chinese, I can speak like a brit and many Brits were surprised that I've never set foot into UK. 

I pick up things and pretend to have an interest in them. In fact I can speak as if I am a hobbyist/enthusiast/passionate about something, though the truth is I don't care. Just a month ago I went for a job interview. I steered the conversation to animal rights knowing she's very into this and got the conversation going. I got the offer though I turned it down for a better offer. When I was young I used to find ants to step on. I shot rubber bands at birds.

I've made several close friends throughout the years  and only 2 of these friends (whom I show my true self to), know about this insanity of mine. I am popular in school (pageant), and I sometimes wonder if people really can't tell that something is way off about me, which is the case for many sociopaths.

I do like a particular close girl friend currently (that is after knowing each other pretty well). I like to talk to her whenever I can & feel lonely when I don't. However sex & physical intimacy is hardly ever on my mind. Nothing more than just slight curiosity or to please a partner. To me sex is simply for the purpose of reproduction to please our parents, a chore so to speak. I don't even masturbate even once as a guy.

While hanging out with my guy friends, I have no idea why my peers would take glances at girls too. While I'm busy doing work. Is this something biologically built-in to both sexes to check each other out?

This does fit well with some of the description on asexuality. The lack of sexual attraction towards anyone. It is normal though for asexual to have romantic attractions (biromantic.etc) as I have read in several sources and I have a very intense "bromance" with a guy friend who I suspect might be in the closet but that's just pure guesswork.

I'm not fully sure. Especially the difference between romantic & sexual attraction. Does it mean that if say 2 girls liked each other very much yet have no desire for sex in the future, it means they aren't lesbians after all? What do we call them then if their attraction is only in a romantic sense?

Sexuality is so confusing.

 & in continuation from 
Like I said, please do move on as it seems to me that you yourself don't want to be "stuck" where you are right now. Quit inflicting pain and suffering on yourself and smoking etc. if you haven't already done so. Escaping may seem a really nice route, but ultimately, if you think about it, it won't be enough. Running away may prevent you from falling once in a while, but only by gaining strength, being a stronger individual, will you guarantee that you will never fall again.

For me at least, there came a time when I was tired of being weak, that all I was able to do was cry. I was one whom constantly told myself that one day, someone will come along whom will see me for who I really am, to love me as I would for her, perhaps not able to understand me, but at the very least, tries to do so. I wanted someone to be there for me when I needed help, comfort and advice, and to give me strength. But ultimately, I knew I needed to pick myself up. I hated my past self. If you too feel the same way, be the change you want to see in yourself. I'm not sure if these are good advices, but here goes. Strengthen your mind; workout and push yourself, have a headstrong attitude in everything you do, and stay disciplined. And of course, do seek help when necessary.

Why would you think it matters to him, if you are not the angelic, or demure girl that he sees you as? I'm no love expert, but I think love isn't so much of not finding "faults" within the other party, but rather, being able to accept them. I believe any guy who sincerely loves you will try his best to look past them. If he still chooses to stay, doesn't that already say something? Its your insecurities at work and which you'll have to overcome, hopefully not alone.

I'm guessing the emotional support you yearn for is extremely hard to come by, only from someone whom has fallen hard and whom understands you enough to be there for you. Me? Haha... My advice would be for you to first pick yourself up and recalibrate your expectations and figure out your thoughts as you go along. You are just lost and not thinking clearly right now.

Stay STRONG :)

To post , I believe if you have a boyfriend whom you love dearly and cherish a lot, you wouldn't even care less about the extra amount of attentions you get from other guys even if you did not even tried for it. Yes I have no doubts over the fact that platonic relationships do exist and I myself have many close guy friends but I don't feel happy over the extra attention  (if they have given me). A sincere relationship is not about finding better partners or trying to find someone with better capabilities, it's about accepting all of your partner's flaws and continue to love him. I have a boyfriend and I'm in a guy-dominated faculty a well. I understand how easy it is to gain attention from guys but it's up to you to decide whether you are affected by it, or will you choose to not be bothered about it. You are probably still in the younger stage of life where the idea of settling down seems too far fetched, therefore you should probably not have a boyfriend and enjoy the fun as for now. There's no guarantee that guys wouldn't pursue you in the working world but it just boils down to how much you love your boyfriend, and how disciplined are you to not be bothered about it. When you truly love someone, you have no eyes for anyone but your gf or BF.

In continuation of 

I thought I had moved on after all it has been close to 3 years since it happened. But when I read the encouraging comments that some of you had written, I broke down in tears. I did not expect that this would still affect me so much.

The hall senior broke up with his ex, and got into a relationship shortly after we ended our short-lived fling. It took me some time to get over it and because I felt so bad about possibly causing the break up between my hall senior and his ex, what came after this was a period of self-hate whereby I did things to hurt myself so that I feel less guilty and bad. One particular night when the self-hate was at its peak, I felt so miserable and walked out to a convenience store near my hall to buy a pack of cigarettes. I even had to google a specific brand so that I know what to buy, and also the instructions on how to smoke a cigarette. I knew it's harmful to the body, but I hated myself so I wanted to inflict pain and suffering upon myself on purpose. I started avoiding people in hall, and often get suspicious when I sense people looking at my direction. I had a guilty conscience and I was afraid that the hall seniors would spill the beans as to what transpired between us. Now that I look back, I could have been suffering from mild depression.

As for me, I also got into a relationship quite soon and it lasted for more than 2 years.

When I was in a relationship with my ex, I guess I still felt insecure. I didn't know what he liked about me and would often ask him questions that could prove my self-worthiness and give me assurance. Deep down inside, I know that I am not the angelic, or demure girl that he probably sees me as. After all, I had a fling with a guy who was attached before - I was like the evil third-party who came between my parents. I hated my dad for having a mistress and an illegitimate child, but I hated myself even more because I myself became a third-party in someone else's relationship.

My ex knew about my dad's affair, and he knew about my insecurities. But I never felt or received the kind of emotional support that I needed from him. He was a great guy, but I never felt that I could be in a position to love someone selflessly and unconditionally. Maybe we're just not so into each other, or maybe because it could have been a relationship out of convenience for the both of us. Fundamentally, I guess I don't know what love is. I am so broken, so flawed. Am I incapable of loving someone?

Being in a guy dominated faculty, even though its only my second year, I have managed to attract a number of guys even though I never make any effort on my part to get to know them better. Its always that they start asking me out first, for study sessions, meals etc. And every guy that I encountered has their own unique attributes, personality and character which I admired a lot. Moreover, I do take other modules apart from my engine core mods so I tend to meet guys from other faculties such as SOC too, and I think they are kind of hot especially when they type furiously away and try to solve some complex coding problems whenever I am studying with them. Sometimes, even though I am aware of having a partner already, I cannot help but try to get closer to some of them because I feel young and attractive myself and I too, want to find a partner who is capable as well. Also, I tend to prefer to make guy friends rather than girls because I feel that guys can be really nice people and are especially less selfish when it comes to teaching you, sharing of notes etc. I feel that as long as I am not married, I should give every guy equal opportunities for us to be together despite being 'committed' to a relationship. Hence, to the guys out there who are confused about whether to pursue a girl who already has a boyfriend, please do so because we girls secretly like it. I mean, who doesn't like the feeling of being pursued? 
-
 
Now that finals are over, I can read NUSWhispers without feeling guilty ;)

29-4-2015 will definitely be the saddest day of my life. I'm using NUSWhispers as a platform to vent out all my sorrows.

This is my story. I'm a guy that most guy will look down upon, I'm used to being called an "ah gua" since primary school. Unlike the normal conventional guy, i lack masculinity that most girls prefer. To make matters worse, my character and behavior are almost like a girl, because i grew with little interaction with other guys. My friend circle is always just made up of purely girls .Despite having female attributes, I have to tell you guys that I was never gay.

Although I'm a independent person, I do have mood swing sometimes(I confess that I cry a lot too)  and i wish that i have a gf to comfort me and protect me. Sounds like what a girl wants right? Most guy will start judging me and hurl insults at me, but I'm alright... my heart is already numb to all these abuses. 

Most of you will laugh at me and say that I'm a dreamer, truly I don't believe that any girl will love me too. But GOD is really kind to me. He answered my prayers and sent me the women that changed my life forever. Let's call her Jane ( I don't want to reveal her real name), I met Jane from my SS mod. She is a strong women, decisive and full of bright ideas. We started calling each other every single night and chat till 3am, she will always console me whenever I'm crying. She will also knock my head softly when i do or say something stupid, she is a pretty rough girl isn't it? =). She can be quite fierce too, there was once, she confronted a group of young boys who called me "bapok", I was so shocked then! Whenever Jane is around me, I feel so safe and secure. I told myself "this must be my true happiness".  I wish that time can freeze and we remain happy forever. But fate is really cruel,  Jane got struck by cancer. She lost 14 kg in 5 months and lost all her hair, which I always like to play around with. Ever since then, I have been putting up a brave front when I'm around her, in order to motivate her.However she soon found out that I was frequently crying outside the hospital ward. She knocked my head again and said "silly, I'm not going to die" ,and gave me a faint smile. After 11 months of fighting and suffering, she finally left the world today ... leaving me behind.

Thank you Jane, my love. Thank you for coming into my life. Thank you for making me cry a lot lesser and laugh a lot more. 谢谢你，让我知道世界上还有人会爱丑小鸭，爱 ah gua. I will remember all your advice, from today onwards I will be a stronger man and stop crying. I promise!

Never believe his words when he says I love you too soon. 

I've never believed in love at first sight and it was just part of the many lies I've said to get in your pants. I could tell that you were attracted to me and I merely played along. I became your first just months into our relationship. I wanted to end it then but you were persistent and I relented. I did not expected us to last for four more years. 

I was expecting to feel relived, finally being set free from this one-sided relationship. But all I felt was emptiness. Over those years I've gotten used to waking up beside you, receiving the cute morning texts that you'll send, the scent you leave in rooms, the warm embrace that you give. It is only when you lose something do you realize the value of it. I definitely deserve all that I am feeling right now. I wish you all the best in your new relationship. 

There is no love at first sight, but you can definitely fall in love.

to  dear friend, thanks for letting me know about your story. when i came across your confession, i was traumatized by how the college lifestyle had destroyed my feels. 
before your post, and pretty much for the whole first year in college, i had been so overwhelmed by concerns for grades, deadlines, competitive internships, SEP, boredom with NUS, mugging and all stuff that i barely remembered college was just a short four-year term that may or may NOT decide my happiness. you remind me of tons of things that are more important than grades; you remind me that sometimes, instead of fussing over the tests and assignments, i can actually settle for a slightly worse outcomes at the expense of a better emotional life.
