When I was in Year 1, I met a Year 4 senior who was staying in the same hall as me. He was not particularly good-looking, but I found him smart and competent. Maybe I was just feeling needy, but I eventually developed feelings for him even though I knew he was attached. He was in a relationship for a few years and would always tell me how he feels unhappy about his girlfriend. I thought I could be the special one, the exception. I secretly wanted to make him fall for me, as if to prove my self-worth and capabilities. Looking back, I was just an insecure 21 year-old girl who craves to be wanted and loved. When the hall senior asked to come over to my room to watch a movie on a particular night, I did not declined. He brought over a bottle of red wine and we drank while watching the movie. It eventually led to us making out and he wanted he have sex with me. That was something I did not expect. I expressed my reluctance, but he did it anyway. I didn't know what to expect, because it's my first time. Our fling remained for a few months before he told me that he wanted to end this. I was so hurt and felt used even though I knew I brought it upon myself when I tried to seduce a guy who was already attached. Till this day, I am still regretting what I did at a moment of my folly. Just want to remind freshies who are inexperienced in relationships to not fall prey to seniors who may just be looking around for flings or one-night-stands. I was a loser because I started to take it seriously and thought that we might have a future together, and that I could replace his current gf. But I was wrong. I am sorry for what I did even up to this day.

For those who claim that "every girl is beautiful" and that "you should not change anything"; it simply reflects self comforting at best and self delusion at worst. 

I think my POV  is bound to get plenty of hate from these people but I will voice it anyway: Hoping for prince charming to appear one day and accept you for all that you are is simply wishful thinking. Like it or not; most guys are visual creatures. Your looks tends to be the first thing that they notice and make them decide whether they want to talk to you or not.

Yes, not everyone is born with Miranda  Kerr's  face but the very least you can do is to take the effort to appear presentable. You can't change your face but you can definitely work out to change your body. And trust me, it makes a world of a difference. 

I am a rather average looking girl but I find myself being able to attract good looking guys by virtue of a good figure and some decent clothes. this may sound boastful but it is just like applying for a job really. If you want a good company to notice you, you would put in effort to write a good cover letter, try to do whatever it takes to have a great CV  etc right? So if you want a good looking bf, put in that effort to dress well,do whatever you need to attain a decent figure. Everyone can indeed be beautiful,but only if you choose to work for it.

This story is about a guy that I met in my first year.
He's an awesome guy. Good looking, friendly, kindhearted, very smart, extroverted, and the list goes on.
His kindness and caring personality appeals to many. In short, I fell for him.
I join the committee just to be closer to him. I try to match our interests so that we have topics to talk about. Numerous efforts have been done just to be closer to him, but not too close to make him suspicios of anything.
One fine night, I blurted my feelings toward him even though I know the chance is near zero. He declined, but he says that we can still be friends. I'm happy, but the childish-me is devastated. So I disconnect any communication with him.
Until one day he got a girlfriend. My feelings for him is more or less diluted already, but i can still feel the pain. The awesome thing? He ask me out for a dinner, just to check on my wellbeing. Another solid proof that he is an indeed awesome guy.
Somewhere inbetween I also get into some relationship, and of course it ended quite badly for me. Apparently, he also broke up with his girlfriend around the same time when that happened.
We try to console each other, and mend each other's wounds. This time, there is no more romantic feelings towards him. It is replaced by a strong platonic love for a truly precious friend.
His ability to oversaw my flaw and childishness, and still accept me as one of his best friend is another solid proof that he is indeed an awesome friend.

And what makes him even more awesome? Is the fact that I'm a guy.

Yes, a guy, fell in love with another guy, and this other guy just stay cool, even offering help to overcome my feelings.
If only all people had such a great, nonjudgemental, open heart. This world is definitely will become a better place right? :)

-
  
There was this girl. 
The first time I saw her clear eyes, her easy smile, I knew I wanted to know her better.
Her awkward laugh, the graceful ease to which she held herself drew me in.
We talked. I shared my passions with her, and she about her recent breakup, the depths of the scars left on her from that first encounter. She gave a wry, pained smile, and said she'd probably not love again any time soon. That image stayed with me as I went to sleep that night, and far into the week after that. I made a decision.
I started going to school earlier, before even the first student arrives, just to meet with her a little before classes began. I would bring snacks to class, so she could have something to eat between back to back lessons spanning over lunch. I tried hard to break into her clique, despite my personal aversion to these interactions in general, and succeeded (much to my surprise). But I was naive to think I had time.
She met a guy in the middle of the semester, and at the clap of the hand, within a couple of weeks, about only a month after our first meeting, they got together. There was nary a warning - she would deny it if any were to ask about their relationship - but like the tides, like time, like fate, they came together, unrelenting, unstoppable. 
I hung around, like nothing was wrong, like I didn't care, and expressed my joy with a smile, a smile meticulously crafted, controlled from by a mind now readily separated from the body. I made sure to raise my eyebrows, smile with my eyes, and give them a pat on the back, as I struggled to loosen that tight constriction in my chest, the ice in my hands. I wanted to rage. Wanted so much to hit something. Instead I made fun of them with harsh jokes, witty jokes, as I frantically built my bridge to control under the mask. Fortunately, reach control I did. 
For a long while after, I felt like I was lied to. I would divorce my mind and body each time I met her, and rage maniacally, helplessly inside, while I calculated the perfect response to each oblivious, carefree interaction. Was there a point to the rage though? Was there a point to anything? The silent cries echoed deafeningly only in the darkness of my mind. 
Slowly, as their relationship progressed, I inevitably faded into the background. In the end, I was nothing but a passing person in her life. Why couldn't I toss her out of my life, my mind, as I was so easily, so readily tossed out of hers? Unfortunately, even in that deep abyss, she was just too precious, far too much to just toss aside in any way.
But who was I to demand that of her? That she should keep me around? That she should treasure me as I did her, when I barely had any impact on her - she never did realise, despite all I thought I did. Am I actually not the one who is the failure, to try so hard, and yet make no difference in the end? At this point, I could only give a wry smile, much like the she gave me back then, though the underlying emotions differed. After all, could you truly say you loved someone, if you cannot accept the choice they make for their own happiness, and wish them well?

To 

Totally similar experience. Graduated senior who seems like he is sometimes interested and sometimes not. So i went ahead and flashed a big hint and got back a hint thats reflects his disinterest. 

My advice is: if you have to guess, he's probably not interested. Some guys are just enthu and random in nature. It's gonna be obvious to a girl if a guy likes her. You can still try though, well at least you tried even if it doesn't work. But our friendship was awkward after and we haven't been talking for months. So, it's all about risk taking and whether you feel comfortable and appropriate to confess. Good luck!

1. If you love something that much never trust another person to take care of it. 
2. Someone whom you love and trust can and will betray you, even if they are suppose to be kind, loving, etc.

So to all of you out there who has a lovely mother, appreciate her more often. As for me, I guess should just suck it up and plant a new pot.

Some people, when confronted with a problem, think, "I know, I'll use regular expressions." Now they have two problems.

Some people, when faced with a problem, think, "I know, I'll use binary." Now they have 10 problems.

Some people, when confronted with a problem, think, "I know, I'll use threads," and then two they hav erpoblesms.

Some people, when confronted with a problem, think "I know, I'll use multithreading". Nothhw tpe yawrve o oblems.

Some people see a problem and think "I know, I'll use Java!" Now they have a ProblemFactory.

Some programmers, when confronted with a problem, think "I know, I'll use floating point arithmetic." Now they have 1.999999999997 problems.

Some people, wanting an escape from their full-time job, think "I know, I'll contribute to open source." Now they have two full-time jobs.

(This confession is long, but if you want the summary: don't feel bad, 加油 for exams, think about life, read the bottom!)

I am a recent alumnus from FoS. I still remember NUS Confessions and I think NUSWhispers is awesome.

Admittedly, after reading social media, it's likely that one  might not be very happy with myself. You might ask why. One could feel:
- envious because others have already got attached but one is left on the shelf.
- backward because others have A+ and A for their modules but one needs to be content with the B+.
- ill-prepared because others have already got life's journey worked out but not one.

But this is social media, friends. There may be trolls running around dissing you, or claiming some other friend is trying to square you up. There are friends of mine who probably posted confessions that turn out to be relationship wreckers more than actual confessions. Sometimes I don't even know if the anonymous CLB incidents were even legit --- I thought PGP was more secluded, or say... near the bus park.

I still remember, when NUS Confessions first started in 2012, it also had such elements. People ranting, confessing real and supposed acts of intimacy and well, frustration with modules. (History check: https://www.facebook.com/nusconfessions?fref=ts). It's a nice experiment with social anonymity: with anonymous postings, what do people make out of that? Apparently, pretty much everything under the sun. In all good fun, I believe it shows the nice side of NUS (with the exception of some trolls who jab a majority of posts). NUS students come together to diss trolls, call out rubbish behaviour confessed by some arrogant punk, celebrate the overcoming of the bell curve god. Sometimes, it shows the ugly side of us: dominating the walls, writing rubbish that no one benefits from reading, not even a good laugh. But these are far and few. 

For people who feel pissed at what you may read, it's a good idea to stop comparing. Social media has always, and will be tinted. People always report the good stuff, hide away the bad stuff, and only on an anonymous platform may one see some of the not-so-nice stuff online. It's funny reading posts like  (how to manipulate),  (silly thoughts),  (probably a shy jock),  (sad but real advice),  (self-apologetic),  (untruth),  (real feeling --- I was like this before),  (trivial stuff making one smile),  (advice from some probably damn old alumnus from SoC),  (actually some debate over NUSSU, phew!),  (desperado, I understand your pain),  (blast to the past),  (satirical),  (serial replier),  (nice guy explaining the grading),  (awwww moment),  (continue discussing about worth of a grad please!) and more (lazy to scroll). Darn, now I feel like I am testing the bot, which will tirelessly fish out all these confessions. Yay to computing.

If one takes a step back, actually we're a cool bunch of people. We joke about trying to overtake the next guy on the bell curve, but recognise we're still friends outside the exam hall. We whine, curse about the serial farting king, but certainly laugh it all off. For a university, this is pretty darn lively and warm culture.

Fast forward to me: currently I work at a bank (cannot say which one, otherwise my boss will tell me to do more work and not post confession!), and life IS stressful outside. Pay is sustenance but at times, one's sanity is called into question. Do we really want to work that long hour simply because we have a job to protect? Unfortunately we do. As a student, I could sometimes just say, heck, let's keep the work for tomorrow. Life can be crushing sometimes; people fight just for the next rung on the ladder, but the battles are much more brutal than those on the bell curve --- backstabbing is common. Consequences are aplenty: the careless folk can be easily sabotaged and manipulated. The workplace is harsh.

I miss NUS, even though some people say it's just a place to mug for 3/4/5 years and then bye. It's really short, come to think of it, considering that the average person now will have to work for 40 years odd.

Sigh, I feel so old now.

Ok, maybe the specific replies I have to some:
- To the employers who posted here, thank you for the time and effort. But I think the young should be given a chance to prove themselves. I think the typical Singaporean is demanding, but when called to the fore, will step up to do something good. NUSWhispers is an example: for a module, they go over and beyond.
- To the sexually depraved: go get a life. Free sex stories is it? Even if we read it, we don't really know if we should envy you or ermmm... think you're just trying to make us all jealous.
- To the CAP 2.0 folk: take heart. It is hard to get a job the traditional way, but there may be other ways to make it big in life. Do you have a skill outside academics? Hone it, and maybe it'll be your lifeline.
- To the chasing: all the best. It is hard, fraught with rejections, but hopefully you'll do well.
- To the chased: play a little hard to get, but don't drive your queue nuts!
- NUSWhispers: Thank you for posting this confession. It's probably the longest confession, but I hope it has been worth your time reading this.

(P.S. I wish I had better Chinese. It might be something not graded anymore, but bad Chinese really hurts chances at going to China.)

All the best for the final exams! It's quite silly to say may you be on the right side of the curve (since half will be left), but I should say, may all do well and prosper. ;)
-
  
I like a guy from biz. He have a girlfriend but still hugs me in hall. I know he is a player and not a boyfriend material, but I think I have something for him. What should I do.
-
  
I'm a girl from SOC who just finished her last final exams in NUS. Looks and figure wise, I consider myself slightly above average only but not so much that I attract too much attention generally except in SOC. I would probably be nothing if I'm in FASS. Even so, let me recall dating record, 7 propositions from guys in SOC throughout my 4 years, one from FASS and one from Business. I dated 2 guys from SOC for just 6 months in total, FASS guy for 6 months and the Business guy for my final year. We are still together.
Now, this is generalisation, but I feel being in a male-dominated faculty like SOC or Engin really makes me feel like a piece of meat being mentally undressed wherever I go for classes. I seemed to get most of the attention and hence switch off from SOC guys totally. All the SOC guys who propositioned me are either ugly immature nerds or are just plain jocks who chose SOC only because it was the only course they could get with their results. There seems to be a variance between the the number of eye-candies in Business/FASS vs Computing/Engin.
I dated the 2 guys in the hope that their hearts are better than their outside appearances. Sadly, it was not the case. They are more willing to spend time understanding their video games and computers more than they spent understanding me or women in general. Come on, even though unlike most girls, I know programming and algorithms, must you discuss those topics again outside class? Women are not like logical machines, we need the emotional connection.
Dress sense in SOC is clearly no where near the league as in Business for example. Even on important presentations, most of you dress worse than a Business student in his slackest days. In fact, I got weird comments for overdressing when my group of guys chose to present in their shorts and slippers.
I find Business and FASS guys way more articulate and mature. Their command of English seems light years ahead compared to the stuttering nerds. Business guys especially, seem to have the aura of ambition that SOC students seem to lack. They can voice out their inner thoughts and emotions much better, know how to cheer me up when I'm down etc. It seems all the SOC guys are horny copies of each other whereas the non-Science guys have a more unique flavour to them. About the FASS guy, it was only because his parents didn't approve of us because of differing religions.
Fitness wise, I seem to feel that Computing guys are not as physically fit in general. I know they are exceptions so don't flame me, its just that the majority are short, skinny, nerdy dudes who seriously need more time out in the sun and on the track than behind the screen. Business guys seem to be taller, more buff and give me the feeling of protection.
Oh and finally the fun part, the sex bit. I admit my sample size is small, but from the 4 guys I had, the FASS guy was the most creative (sorry my bf, but thats true) followed by my current bf with the 2 SOC guys far behind. I chalk it up to them being inexperienced virgins and if they have, its probably from porn. I know the argument, you can't get better without more experience but seriously as a girl with modern sexual needs, I don't care about your excuse of me being your first gf. It just proves how much of a loser you are for being a virgin or having your first relationship only in Uni. Either you give me a good time or I show you the door, the fairer sex is the one that decides when to spread our legs for you so we make the rules. My rule is that you don't waste my time learning on the job, you better know how to do yours before you start. Your learning should have started on innocent girls from your JC or poly. Imagine applying for a a fresh grad job when you are in your 40s. Uni girls like me have higher expectations of sex as we climb the academic ladder and gain more sexual experience.
So as a piece of advice to girls in NUS, date FASS and business guys. They are more mature, posses greater awareness of the real world outside the land of the Matrix and communicate better with you. Poor communication in a relationship is as good as bad or no communication. Sex with SOC guys, totally cmi, feel more like an emotionless porn actress after the act.
For my final advice to my male SOC mates before I leave, watch less porn and jerk off less, it is not only bad for you, its totally inaccurate. Dress better, go to the gym more often, take up those CELC speaking and writing classes then maybe you stand a better chance with women in the dating game. Remember, computers don't propagate your genes, women do.
#from a girl who actually feels disadvantaged in the dating game in the land of nerdy guys with so few eye-candies.

One of those awesome things about being a loner - I can do all the odd stuff I want. I wander off to places where I can hide, and I don't feel the need to make a conscious effort to fit in. I don't need to be around large groups of people, which makes me extremely stressed for some reason. 

However, having said that, it does feel very lonely to be a loner. I don't interact well with people, I cannot make jokes like many other people, I seem highly unapproachable and creepy because of the odd things I do, and the odd behaviours I exhibit, when I am under stress.

I don't mind company, but I do mind the fact that I feel obliged to try to entertain my company, by constantly trying to talk to the person. If you attempt to reach out to me suddenly, I really don't know how to react and give a proper response.

At this juncture, it really does seem that the best company for me is a probably a Lego figurine, or a stuffed toy.

I'm on my journey of self-discovery.

-
  
In everybody's life, they are the 'stars'. They are the main characters. They are the ones who will find love, do things, amazing things... They are the ones with all the excitement and joy. They are the ones who will overcome the obstacles, and should they fail, die some honorary death. Some heroic burial.

Yet, most fail to notice that not everyone can be the main character. Not everyone can be the hero. If everyone were the hero, who's the villain? If everyone were the best lovers, then who would lose in a love triangle? Who would have their hearts broken, and not mended? Who would be stranded alone, forgotten...? And who will be left to wilt in a corner? Who will slowly disappear? Whose mark would be the faintest? And everyone says, "Not mine."

For every Princess to find her Prince, there must have been a lot of suitors cast aside. There must be countless other admirers, who will remain as nothing but admirers. They will be others, won't there?

And perhaps, for them to find their Princes, I must remain as nothing... Nothing but an admirer. Nothing but a flower left to wilt in the pot at the corner of the garden. Nothing but forgotten. Nothing but faded away...

And this is so that they will live their happily-ever-afters.

-
  
I was trying to start an herb garden a few years ago. That may sound trivial, but it was after my dog died and it was sort of symbolic for me.

Anyway, I was having trouble getting the herbs to grow. I followed all the instructions and even looked things up online, but I just couldn't get it going very well. Most of the herbs were half dead after a couple of months. They were hanging in there, but by no means flourishing. I was having particular trouble with one plant that I really coddled and tried so hard to get it to hang on, but this was becoming my cat all over again. It was heartbreaking.

Then come this year, I decided to enrol into School of Computing . I finally understood through the magic of algorithms and stuff. That what really matters is that you try, and if your heart is in it, any victory is all the more powerful. I was in tears by the end of the last lecture. I finally let go of the guilt about my dog's death; I felt this great release of pressure from my chest as I accepted that sometimes pets die no matter how hard you try. I felt like I was breathing for the first time, and my tears were like letting loose years of pressure.

I immediately went into my backyard and looked over my herb garden. I had tried, and that was what mattered. Everything was still alive, but the point was that I had put in the effort to make it flourish, not that it actually had flourished. I looked at that one stubborn herb plant and finally let go. I was done obsessing over a stupid plant. Thank you, School of Computing.

TL;DR - SoC helped me through a rough thyme

 You can't change the past and what happened in the interview. Life is funny sometimes, perhaps you were meant to be with another better guy and a better job then the one you just went interview for. We all have bad days where we are off form but life is full of opportunities and chances, so learn from whatever failures and make tomorrow a better day :)

 If it is tiring and not working out for you, you should take a break. It's more important to have few good quality close friends than many random acquaintances. We are all weird in our own unique way and we are worthy, You just need to find the people who can connect with you. Keep going and i'm sure you will have close friends that will be with you for life :)

 We all have our own demons and battles to fight. Hope keeps us alive and keep fighting for a better tomorrow :)

 Life is full of regrets, don't add to that list of regrets. Just go for it, what's there to lose? No risk, no reward :)

 You don't need to wait for signs that someone likes you, have faith in yourself and if you really like that someone go for it. :)

In order to prevent yourself from falling into friendzone, you have to pick up flirting skills. If your conversation with the girl are mainly related to studies, school etc. and nothing else, you will never ever break the "friend barrier". Girls do not like to hear all these boring topics. Entice them with exaggerating sweet talks even though it may not be true. 

There's a saying, " Girls love to hear sweet lies".
Inflate them with all these sweet lies and coat their minds with sugar, she will fall in love with you deeply.

This method is 100% effective to evergreen girls. They will believe whatever you say and promise =)

Confession: it's a make or break. If you break, you feel stupid about yourself, especially if you do it multiple times and get rejected on all occasions. Good thing is that you can laugh about it (all the silly instances, and stupid things you might have done), bad thing is some times you might even cry thinking about how foolish and embarrassing it had been. Yet if you don't confess and a take a leap of faith, nothing can happen.

I suppose there isn't a full-proof way to go about it - sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. I was told though that love isn't something you can mug for it. Whether the other person reciprocates isn't necessarily equivalent to the amount of effort or feelings that you might feel. Kinda sad huh..

Personally, I feel thrice broken. But I suppose that makes me who I am now. Can only hope that the next time will be better I suppose.

tldr: never try, never know.

and with regards to MA1506: You die, I die, everybody die!

PS: Thanks for NUSWhispers, it was a good read

Quite some time ago, a friend confided to me that she was extremely jealous and pissed that her bf was very close to a female colleague (who is married) when she was on exchange. 

Red flags (what my friend told me) included her bf and the colleague NOT corresponding via whatsapp and using some other messenger app (avoiding traces), going out one-to-one many times, the colleague telling my friend's bf about her marriage troubles and not having sex for a long time.

She told me that her bf "didn't do anything that betrayed her". I didn't probe too far, though I believe she meant sexual stuff.

My friend belongs to the blur/clueless type, and was evidently blur when she confided to me because she was simply not thinking right and not drawing the obvious conclusions, and has little sense of how guys think, or even how women/girls think.

And so I told my friend the obvious, that the colleague was clearly improper and wanting intimacy from her bf, and that she's definitely right in wanting her bf to stop contacting that colleague. I also told her to obtain more advice from married women in her late 20s (same life phase as that indecent colleague), and get validation for my opinion.

What I didn't tell my friend, that it was also obvious to me (from a guy's POV) that her bf was "looking to eat outside", and at the very least there was some form of emotional betrayal. I didn't dare to make quick judgments as the guy felt like some easy-going chill dude (don't know him very well), and I thought there's a chance her bf really was clueless. I didn't want to be responsible for breaking up a relationship, even though I kinda liked her.

Today, they are still happily together. I'm not sure I did the right thing, still feel a tinge of guilt.

This is a long one. Guys mention about being friendzoned, being afraid to ask the girl as they are not sure if she seems them as only a friend or more. Well I would, JUST ASK and do it sooner than later. Why?

Say you know a girl for like 5-6 months, you see her as more than a friend, you have feelings for her. Just tell her in person what you feel. Pros: TADA gf. Cons: It probably would probably become awkward as hell and u 2 might even stop talking. No daily SMS-es, not seein her smile on a daily basis and basically becoming strangers. Is it worth it? hell yes. Because you were being honest to yourself and to her. She isn't a mind reader to know how u feel if u don't tell her. And the longer u wait before asking her it just becomes even more harder to get over her if eventually you do ask and it is negative. The consequences are painful but time will do its magic. Join ccas, hang out with other friends, focus on studies/passion, hit the gym whatever. Occupy yourself. You will move on. You may even meet another girl and she could be the one. The longer you wait to ask, the longer the healing process and I highly doubt by just being around her she will magically one day know your feelings for her and say yes. So just be honest to yourself and to her. Don't be afraid of losing her as a friend, since you always saw her as more than a friend :)

-
  
 I feel you my friend. Money is such a big problem now in uni. However I am in a different position that I'm an international student. My family is considered middle class in my home country but that doesn't mean shit here due to exchange rate. My parents' combined salary is about SG$400 per month. Some month if they save up really hard they can give me $100 but less often that not. I'm not on scholarship so I have no choice but to work part time. It's really tough and stressful when you are doing part time job plus hall activities plus 6 mods per semester. 

One of the sad thing about being poor is that it's hard to make friends with Singaporeans. I really like most of my Singaporean friends but it's really difficult to get in their clique while you reject every single hangout invitation from them because you just can't afford to hangout and spend money. A simple meal could well cost over $15-20, and maybe a movie or clubbing on top of that. Eventually no one ask me to hangout with them anymore. My best friends in JC are all Singaporeans and I haven't met them since the start of uni because of that.

Sometimes my mom called me to have a little chat on Skype, but I had to reject her because I was busy studying/doing CCA/working. It's the worst feeling ever.

I like girls.

I still can't discount the possibility that I might find a guy who I can bond with on a deep emotional level but it'll never be a bond that is physically and sexually fulfilling. Divorce is unacceptable especially if we end up having kids.

Being in Singapore means its tough to avoid homophobic friends, means saying that 'I'm a girl' can only come with a 'but' after 'I like girls'.

Do I be who I am?

It isn't a simple choice.

I hope I'm not alone on this.

Be overly nice, comfort her when she's feeling upset, go out of your way to do nice things, and eventually, congratulations! You'll end up in the friendzone.

PSA guys. Being too nice gets you friendzoned faster than the biz western food uncle taking your order. As paradoxical as it sounds, when girl's say they want a nice guy, they're not referring to someone who is nice to everyone, or whom does everything they say. Why would a girl want someone who treats everyone as special as her? Don't believe me? think of the nicest person you know of. Chances are, they're single.  

Limit your niceness, but also, don't be an outright ass. You won't even have friends then.
Good luck!

Of course, it isn't easy to find friends in Arts too but it seems like I meet more people who I can converse with in my faculty. Anyway, people become friends when they have common interests?

I wouldn't want to generalise though. This is just what I observe from my personal experience.

-
  
Freshman year; you get extremely excited to see that you have been accepted into one of the most "popular" halls on campus. Decked out in blue, shorts and slippers most of the time, you have a hellvua fun in those years: Sleeping at hours where even ghosts have decided to retire, having the wildest activities that paint a happening life on your social media pages, and forever being surrounded my friends; never needing to fear you would go for a lecture, or even supper alone. 

In these four years you have become the cool kid, the Mr.Popular, the jock who does well in many sports and hangs out with all the pretty girls. On top of all of these, you carry a decent CAP and become the envy of many.

Then, as you near graduation year, you proudly send out your CV to all the companies that surely, must be dying to hire the charismatic, multi-talented you. Yet, it has been weeks, months and all you've got are rejections or worse; no replies at all.

You get desperate, your supposedly nerdy peers at school have found nice high-paying jobs while you struggle to even get an interview. In a last ditch effort, you call the career services centre; a place where you have not once stepped foot in for the 4 years of your college life. When you meet your career counselor, you spill your indginance and worries: Why is it me, the popular, charismatic guy who has captained over half a dozen sports teams, took part in nearly every CCA possible and with half a decent CAP can't get a job?!

Your career counselor looks at your CV, shakes her head and drops the bombshell: "well, to be frank, these activities mean nothing actually". And the facade of what you thought were you most glorious years came crashing down upon you

As a procrastinating (graded) exchange student, I want to offer alla y'all a little bit of love advice from across the pond, which me and my friend epiphanised the other night.

1. As long as you are not obvious about your stalkery, boys, you can woo waaaay more girls than you thought possible, just by paying attention to them. Honestly - a gal's perception of you will change if you make them feel wanted. Literally, any guy. It's properly easy, and even though I'm not one to stereotype, it's tried and tested. Just be nice and gentlemanly, and the worst thing that could happen is that you have a nice friendship with a nice girl. Just ask her for lunch one day, or offer to buy her a Starbucks if you're a classy guy who has money to burn.

2. Girls, unbeknownst to you (or even them) it is possible for you to get any guy you want, or at least a nice one who you are pleased with. If you show confidence in yourself, and that you're comfortable in your own appearance (regardless of your appearance, honestly) and personality, you will ultimately succeed in the game of luuuurve. I know it's easier said than done, but if you act like you are the most awesome person ever, people will start to believe it, despite their own thoughts. Mind over matter, folks.

I don't understand how there are so many couples here - everyone appears to be so shy! But don't fret, follow my advice, and you will prevail. 

P.S. Apparently guys don't really like girls wearing make-up, and most of the time they can't even tell the difference (so why waste your time and pores?)

P.P.S. In terms of your chances with the exchange students, the poorly (yet so accurately) termed "yellow fever" definitely kicked in a good month or two ago, and what with the end of term swiftly approaching, alongside a whole lotta time to fill with procrastination, now is the perfect time to romance an international hottie. And they will definitely appreciate a free coffee cos now they're poor AF.

-
  
@

Friendships are forged not through happenstance. You have to make a conscious effort to want to get to know people more. That said, it also depends on certain circumstances, namely, 

A common interest, a lot of common time, convenience, and stage of life.

You don't become friends merely through one event, or just because you take lectures together. You need at least two of the circumstances above checked, before there is even a chance of a friendship, and two being the most minimal. 

Of course they are going to ditch you, you aren't that important in the beginning. But you have to try to reach out and get to know people, and show an interest. It's a tiring thing, but that's how you make friends past your adolecent and teenage years. Everyone starts getting busy in the routines of their lives and you dont have as much common time together.

So.... cheer up! While being alone may suck at times, you seem pretty well adjusted. I'm sure you can make friends, it's just that you might have been approaching it with the wrong mindset :)

Friends dont come about by happenstance!

~L
-
  
To the lady(I think) in ,  :

I'm in a sort of a similar situation, but I'm the other party, i.e. a guy(don't worry 
I'm not the person in question this confession is directed towards). I think that the subject does have feelings for you.

Either he is really keen on chasing you regardless of your current relationship status, or he feels that it is blissful enough to maintain what he has now and does not want to risk destroying the friendship. I think that it's probably the latter but you know better than I do.

He probably won't know that you're starting to get uncomfortable for being treated overly nicely, unless you tell him. You can choose to avoid him from now on too, if u're certain that he takes the hints. Otherwise, it'll be better if you can tell him personally as it might be a bit cruel on him if you don't say anything. If he likes you and/or is understanding enough I'm sure he'll fall back and maintain some distance after hearing how you feel. I'm sure he has helped you at some point in your school life so now may be the best time to return the favour, maybe? This way it won't be awkward when you see each other and you can still have a simple, healthy relationship.

If he's not as understanding as you would have hoped(I hope it won't be this case), then I guess he'll be intruding your privacy and not thinking about your feelings. In that case, you should probably put some distance between him and you, on your own, and move away from him. You should be able to judge it yourself.

Good luck.

On that note, if person A likes person B, then is it impossible to be friends? Especially when B knows A's feelings towards him/her, does A only have 2 choices, i.e. to chase after B or to stay away from B completely? Will B believe A if A says that he/she only wants to be friends? If not, isn't maintaining a boy-girl friendship also a desperate attempt not to fall in love with the other person? There exist a limit to how nice A should be towards B, but is it really wrong to treat the guy/girl one likes super nicely? 

I don't know the answer to all these myself.

The irony of having lots of acquaintances yet so few are close friends. Spending time in solitude has become a norm especially after college life started. You attend lectures with a bunch of friends, join numerous events, know lots of people from various faculties, yet none is considered close. Friends ditch you when they have more important things to deal with. None show p at times when you need them. Indeed, nobody could have 100% of his/her time to you, yet having to spend a day without saying a word/making any contact with another human being is unhealthy.

Yes  I do enjoy solitude, but perhaps human are just social creatures. Prolonged periods of alone time are unbearable. At times you are glad to be independent and just spend some time with yourself, at times you will start to feel the loneliness creep in bit by bit till it consumes you. And the latter just gets worse in this stressful period of finals preparation. 

A universe full of humans/lives. A world just with myself.

-
  
Programming is like sex because...

• One mistake and you have to support it for the rest of your life.
• Once you get started, you'll only stop because you're exhausted.
• It takes another experienced person to really appreciate what you're doing.
• ...Conversely, there's some odd people who pride themselves on their lack of experience.
• You can do it for money or for fun.
• If you spend more time doing it than watching TV, people think you're some kind of freak.
• It's not really an appropriate topic for dinner conversation.
• Public schools don't do a very good job teaching kids about it.
• It doesn't make any sense at all if you try to explain it in strictly clinical terms.
• Some people are just naturally good at it.
• ...But some people will never realize how bad they are, and you're wasting your time trying to tell them.
• There are a few weirdos with bizarre practices nobody really is comfortable with.
• One little thing going wrong can ruin everything.
• It's a great way to spend a lunch break.
• Everyone acts like they're the first person to come up with a new technique.
• Everyone who's done it pokes fun at those who haven't.
• Beginners do a lot of clumsy fumbling about.
• You'll miss it if it's been a while since you've done it.
• There's always someone willing to write about the only right way to do things.
• It doesn't go so well when you're drunk, but you're more likely to do it.
• Sometimes it's fun to use expensive toys.
• It usually goes faster when you do it alone.
• When women hear guys bragging about it, they become disgusted.
• If you're not careful about how you do it, all sorts of nasty bugs can appear.
• ...And debugging is annoying, painful, and very embarrassing.

From: http://www.thealmightyguru.com/Humor/Docs/ProgrammingIsLikeSex.html

Korean universities students have this thing known as '미팅’ (meeting), which is basically a group blind date. Arranged by someone else, a few guys meet up with a few girls (say 3 guys & 3 girls) for a meal, and they exchange contacts. 

If any of the guys/girls find someone within the group they're interested in, they can try to bring the relationship further after the 'meeting'. 

We don't have such a culture, but looking at how many singles there are in NUS, it would be nice to start such a culture here. Well, even if it doesn't end up in a relationship, it's always nice to know more friends right? 

Wonder how many in NUS are interested in such an idea?
-
  
J and I met in army. We were officer cadets in the same wing. We bumped into each other at the sauna where we talked. Just talked. Over the next few months, we got to know to each other better and soon, found ourselves falling in love with each other. Our relationship went well for first year, but spiralled in its second year.

I was addicted to alcohol. It started in army. My weekends revolved around opened bottles and loud music at the clubs with my camp mates. J hated it when I arrived at his place drunk. I would get so high that I don't even remember the events of the night. Things get so dark when I drink. I lose control of myself and I get violent. My friends and I were Attica one night. J was there too. I drank too fast and too much. J, being the caring boyfriend he was, told me to stop. When I refused and chided him for overreacting, he forcibly took the bottle out of my hand. I got angry at him for that, and made my way out of the club (miraculously given how drunk I was). J followed me closely behind. When I told him to fuck off and leave me alone, he wouldn't, and I guess I lost all rationality and punched him in the face. I don't remember what happened after that, but I awoke in his bed the next morning.

I apologised for my behaviour, for which he accepted the apology. But that unfortunately was just the beginning of things which eventually drove him to end our relationship. When he told me I needed help that he couldn't give me on his own, I knew I had lost the most important person in my life.

J entered NUS soon after we finished army whereas I deferred an additional year off to get the help that I needed. I'm happy to say that I'm a year sober now. I contacted J last night for the first time since we ended army and we arranged to have coffee at Starbucks U-town, where I am due to matriculate in August this year.

"You look good," he said.

"Thanks," I replied in kind. A long pause ensued. "You look well too."
I related to him that I've been a sober a year now. He was happy for me that I had my issues sorted. He apologised for not sticking through, but said that he was at his wits end, and he didn't know what else to do to help me. I assured him that he had nothing to apologise for; that his decision to leave me was just what I needed to put my life together again.

"Love forgives, love forgives immeasurably," he said. J and I decided to have another go at the relationship again. Clean slate, we agreed. I am hopeful — no, I am certain — that this time, I will treat him better. I can't deny that there are times when I desire a sip — he's well aware of this — of a drink, but I'm well equipped to know that I can stay away for it.

Actually the real reason is because I wanted to increase the chance of my love being reciprocated. Why is this even happening to me? I shared the feeling of those who felt lonely despite knowing many people. Honestly speaking, I have thousands of facebook friends and tons of contacts in my phone. However,  when life takes a turn for the worse, I don't know who to confide to and just hide one corner and think about it myself.

One day, i was thinking 'What the heck!' I took a leap of faith and called one or two friends to hang out. Their quick positive response surprised me. I am able to unwind and let go of some emotional stress.

Go on and take that leap of faith. I'm sure there are many of your friends who is facing the same situation, but simply push it aside and sweep it under a rug. Be spontaneous once in a while! (:

Cheers

Looking at the other confessions on love and romance, I cannot help but be amused at some of them. But it reminds me of my own struggles of finding that special person; an issue which could be very serious and a genuine concern, at least for some of us. (Yes I'm still evergreen)

Like some of you, I worry about finding the right partners, having tried some or other ways in finding suitable people that I could comfortably share my life with. I've been languishing in university for almost 2 years now, lingered around in camps and even in school matchmaking (!) events, finding ladies whom I felt attached to in the process. It became clear that even the end result of falling in love is hard; because girls and ladies are extremely hard to comprehend, and it is made all the more harder with my weird personality and my own concerns over their emotional stability, religious beliefs or simply the attention that they give me. A lot of my friends tell me that I try too hard. Actually, I don't even know what I'm doing; stumbling around school, orientation camps, welfare events, trying to know people just to maximise my chances of finding the right one.

Then one day during a certain school outing, I got to know this girl. She doesn't really seem to fall into the type of lover whom I desired to have, but I immediately got the fatal sense of attraction towards her. Somehow, I even invited myself to have dinner with her at her residence for a couple of occasions already, getting to know her better, and I found myself talking about suitable types of ladies in school. The thing is, though we are currently friends, I just feel afraid that she would be just like the others; eventually floating away and losing contact. Yet, I have this sense that she's waiting for someone to chase her; and yet I don't know how she feels, it doesn't seem like she's showing anything, or any telltale signs. I don't even know if we would have the chance to meet more often; and I'm scared to push things. 

I’ve been attracted to so many people that my friends call me popular and as the guy who seems to know the entire faculty. Yet, I've never felt lonelier here in school. All I really wish for is the chance for me to continue having contact with this girl. I'm so tired of waiting and trying; it's not funny anymore. Being alone is okay and bearable, but I just desire to share my life with someone else.

What should I do? 

(Sorry people if I've been extremely long winded, just trying to express my inner thoughts here:/)

First time I'm on herre, last time I'm on here. You know how it is said that if you want to attain a goal, go make it known among people, so you'd be socially pressured to take action? I think that's crap. It's applicable to how some of us are posting on NUSWhispers, is it not? Sure, this is a venting spot. But you know inside of you that you want to do something. You are telling the world about it, whatever it is. Don't feed your uncertainty with distractions. Don't sit in your warm bath of telling a confession. You felt like you did something about the situation but you didn't do sh!t, sorry. Just go for it. Do yourself some justice. Don't leave anymore what if's. All the best.

I wonder if it is possible for one to start off as a heterosexual, but as life goes by and such gender identity is eroded by apathy, one becomes an asexual shell? 
This post was not meant to be depressing at all. In fact the lack of romance in NUS, as anything in life, can be explained.
Applying Porter's Five forces, we are the customers, the "company" is the idea of romance. Unfortunately, all odds are against the "company"'s favour. Due to higher barrier of entry (none of my relationship comes anywhere close to the idea of romance), abundance of substitute (friends, YOLO attitude...), high bargaining power of customers ( the switching cost from being single to coupled is pretty high given the high opportunity cost of time "wasted" with one partner), and so on.
Here is a business idea: someone can design an app to help NUS students to arrange speed dating. For example, one can meet up and talk to a new person for one hour during lunch break, but has no oligation to see that person again whatsoever and has plenty of options to diversify one's lunch experience meeting with other people. If such app existed, NUS students might be willing to pay, perhaps, 1$ per match. I know I would.
Wise men say only fools rush in
But I can't help falling in love with you
Shall I stay, would it be a sin
If I can't help falling in love with you

Like a river flows surely to the sea
Darling, so it goes
Some things are meant to be

Take my hand, take my whole life too
For I can't help falling in love with you

I think I'm in love, for the first time in 21 years.

Hi guys,
When I see people posting every day about how much they hate being single and how girls have screwed them over, I feel truly bad. Everyone goes through times where they feel lonely, but that doesn't make it easy, and it's a feeling nobody deserves.

You may think that you will be single forever, or that you are marred by some flaw that will keep any decent girl from wanting you, be it acne, your physique, or your ability to interact comfortably with girls. However, I promise that this is not the case.

There is something about you that makes you irreplaceable to the right girl. The right girl might not be a 10/10, but she is the right girl for you, and as such, you will think she's beautiful. All of you are attractive in some way, even the "weird ugly nerds". Maybe you are funny, or you are smart, or you are dependable, or you are just good at listening. The girl who is worth your heart will see these things in you and you will be in love and happy.

I'm ashamed for how my sex treats you sometimes. Like a lot of guys, a lot of girls look for the wrong things in a partner. It seems like everywhere you look, people just want somebody who is "hot" and "charismatic." You've wanted a lot of girls who haven't given you the time of day. However, you are better off for having these girls pass you by, because they are vapid, shallow, stupid girls.

Someday you will find somebody who loves you deeply and completely. When this happens, I hope you realize that all of the time spent striking out was worth it, because it led you to something wonderful.

I love all of you and wish that you could love yourselves. Things will fall into place in each and every one of your lives. Just hold tight until then.
My bf is studying in SoC. He's not a romantic guy and he's always busy with studies and CCA. I may not be happy with him sometimes, but I love him and will be with him forever >.<

For some reason the girls I like are always either attached, or become attached soon after I meet them, and I just never have a chance. I'm in my 4th year now, and I have never dated, and I'm always awkward around the girls I like... Sometimes it just seems like I should just give up and prepare for a life of solitude...
Every semester for the past three years, without fail, I would have crushes on the TAs and/or GAs.  But it's so sad that I only get to see them for one semester because they are graduating already. I miss my CS1020 tutor the most. J, hope you're doing well.
I am a final year student who happen to be an evergreen. So recently at the start of my final semester, I got to know this girl from another faculty and we appeared to hit it off well. Fast forward three months to today, we have become an items and I have grown attached to her. However, after a quarrel yesterday, she told me she's sick of trying. Although i could see several differences btwn us, i must admit i was never good at the dating game and it will only get worse when i leave school and go out to work. Now I am wondering if i shld persevere and pursue further, or should i just let it be, and be a #foreveralone. ?
I know this guy since Y1S1. Let's call him XF. We have many things in common and we became really good bros over the years. However, we have that weird friendship thing where we get along by insulting each other, but in a friendly way. Out of everyone in school, he's the closest friend I have. 

However, recently I realized that he has traits that really appeal to me. Our sense of humour match, he's really musical and eloquent, loves animals as much as I do, and as much as we rib each other, there's care and concern below everything. Few nights ago, I had a dream where we almost kissed - which freaks me out, because I have never thought of him that way before. 

Now I am confused and slightly afraid, because we've been bros for so long, getting together is probably going to be just a fantasy. Furthermore, I'm not even his type. 

TDLR; so deep in the friendzone, not sure what to do.
Seriously? I have been a TA in SoC for many semesters but how come not a single girl had a crush on me?
I told my TA that I wasn't depressed, but in truth, I am.
So there is this senior, who has been always helping me since we barely know each other when I first came to NUS. He has his girlfriend and we all know each other. He seems to be nice to everyone but I feel that he pays some special attention to me. I do not know how he feels about me, and I am not sure whether I like him or not. Nevertheless I really enjoy being together with him, but I will not be staying in hall next year.
I've known this one girl before going to NUS, and now we both study in FoS. We were somewhat close friends considering what I've heard about her attitude towards boys before becoming her friend. We talked a lot, sometimes went out together, and I really considered her my best friend. However, things have changed since we went to NUS. It seemed to me that she doesn't want anyone to know that we're close friends and try to distance from me. I don't know why, but that shit drove me mad. I became an ultra-jealous monster who exploded every single time she talked to somebody else "too friendly". I tried to control my temper, but it kept bugging me that even though she tried comforting me that I'm still her best friend here, she never displayed that when there were more than two of us (I was basically invisible to her in a group) and tried so hard to avoid me and limit our time together to a much lower level than close friends should be. I asked her why, she never gave me an answer I could understand. I became more and more jealousy, our fights got bigger and bigger, we started throwing insensitive words to each other... Now she has blocked all communication with me. It has been a few months, and I missed her so much. I tried to reconcile, but she refused. I just want my best friend back. So can someone show me how to get to 4k5 mmr in DotA 2 while waiting for her to (hopelessly) change her mind?

P/S: For romantic lovers, there's nothing between us. She has warned me not to fall in love with her (during the time when things were not that bad) and I haven't dreamed of that either.
Should I feel bad for being called an introvert?
I am stuck in this endless need to prove myself in this world of intense competition. With whatever I do, there is someone who is always better. I'm tired of finding meaning in this endless competition. I'm just lost in the crowd of the ordinary. I long for a day when there is nothing that matters, but a single cause. A single cause which I can fight for...A single cause which I can die for. That then will be my purpose in life.
I'm a sociology major. I love my major, but there is one think I hate about it: an overindulgent feminist. I'm fine with a girl being a feminist. In fact I support feminism. But what I hate is when they become overindulgent and start thinking that all men are out to suppress them. Oh please... There are times during tutorial that when the topic of women's rights enter into the picture, the discussion starts getting really heated. What's worse is that I'm the only guy in many of those tutorials. X.x Many times I just want to leave and let them indulge in their 'discussions'.
I feel like now, with all the progressiveness, that it is more socially acceptable to just say I'm asexual. At least, rather that than admit to a terrible truth that I try to deny: That my standards may be a tad too high for my own good. 

At least, people find you a lot less of a b***h/arrogant if you say 'I may be asexual, I don't know' compared to 'I just haven't found someone I respected enough to really have a crush/fall in love with.' At least I don't get reactions like 'Well maybe you should stop having such high expectations/be so stuck up/idealistic.'

Ok, so respect may be the wrong word. Something closer would be admire with more than a point of passing interest. And so I pretend to have frivolous crushes on people that most people find good looking (and objectively, they are) but I absolutely feel nothing for. I don't even find them attractive. 

It's not like I don't want to try either, but feelings are hard things to fabricate and I find it far more cruel to lead a poor guy/girl going on a date on hoping I'd finally have feelings. With all due respect to everyone I have amazing friends and meet wonderful people in my life but it feels so hard to form connections that are beyond friendship. Trust them with my life? Yes. To bail me out of jail if I do stupid things? Yes. With my heart? Absolutely not romantically. So maybe I need a reality check, but I a) Don't fangirl over any celebrities, singers, bands, actors or otherwise. b) Don't really fall in love with fictional characters in anime/movies/books beyond really rooting for them against their enemies. (For instance, I adore Tyrion but marrying the man? Never.) 

Yet I know I am not fully asexual because I have been capable of having a crush once, and it's not like I was burnt, I simply fell out of my crush once I wrote down a confession speech and everything and realised that I just didn't feel it anymore. 

So now I'm stuck. I'm okay with living happily alone till old age, but I do wish I can genuinely join in or empathise when people have relationship woes. It makes me feel like a terrible human being when I catch myself thinking 'She/he can do better' or 'Eh, if you want to settle he/she's a good choice.'

Her: So you are doing... Polscience right?
Me: Nah, history.

And I'd ask for her major. Because for some reason I'd forget after every semester; maybe just to find something to ask her again the next time we meet.

But that's not the only thing I've forgotten. There's something else I need to ask her, and I've not been able to. It's just too awkward. Nobody just suddenly pull this on someone that you've known for 3 years.

Thought she was on exchange this sem but I did see her again last week; but she was with a guy i didnt know so it'll be even weirder.

We had a debate about whether it was love at first sight, but I dont even know. I remember telling my friends about this guy I really like. They said they were more than happy to help. so I told them the story and they were like you really dont need us. It happened rather fast before I can figure out whether it was because of love at first sight or because we hung out so often. although, Im really grateful to have been where we have been. 
I remember you holding my hand to cross the red light when all I wanted to do was being a good citizen. I also remember you told me that I should buy new clothes so we went to uniqlo and bought matching snoopy t-shirts! I kept the tags cause its so cute, but we never got to wear the tshirts together.  :( I also remember being on the plane in the middle of the night, crying and all too tired, drenched with all the good memories I had with you.  
Now that we are half globe apart, I still can't picture myself without you. cant wait to tell you about new stuff in my life and so "sian" when you go to sleep. considering how hard it is to find someone to like you back  as this website is suggesting, being so far away from each other still makes me a heck of a lucky person. 
I guess thats how relationship should be, if it's too easy to get, nobody's gonna treasure it. & just keep it up!

I feel like the reason Nus confessions died off pretty quickly was that unless some other countries in Singapore there is only so many things to confess to. Nobody in their right mind is going to confess to taking hard drugs with a death penalty hanging over their heads. And while drunken stories and partying definitely occur there is relatively far fewer of them to confess to real debauchery like cheating or orgies or messy break ups  or whatever people get up to that needs confessing without mentioning specific circumstances that narrows people down and loses the anonymity.   So we are left only to confess about crushes which is sweet but gets stale after a while or bitch about group mates. And even then it wears thin because of corse everyone's crushes is unique and something beautiful but it is the same boy meets girl or girl meets boy and they are too shy so too bad you're Gonna miss the girl/guy. There is only so much variation. Here's to Hoping whispers will last longer.

Submit your own confessions at: http://nuswhispers.com
To all kids still studying in NUS - cherish your time there. I can honestly say that my time in NUS was the best 4 years of my life. I was lucky enough to meet and make friends with many highly intellectual people and it opened my mind to new perspectives and possibilities more than I could have ever imagined. 

Staying on campus was THE BEST - making new friends, gaining a greater sense of independence. If you are undecided as to whether or not to stay on campus because you fear for your studies, JUST DO IT! Even if it's just for a year. Personally, I couldn't imagine having as awesome a time if I didn't stay on campus all 4 years. As somebody else said, after you come back from SEP, your perspective changes (also because you're going into year 4 and don't give much of a crap anymore).

I went back recently just to see the campus for the first time since I graduated in 2012 and I realized I miss NUS so. damn. much. So students, don't just spend all your time mugging, make friends and have fun. This is probably the last time you can really let go and do whatever with little consequences.
